title: Albany Asserts City Will Exceed Its Income Estimates for 197980
description: ALBANY. Jan 31  Governor Carey's administration has informed Mayor Koch that New York City's income will exceed its estimates for the fiscal years 1979 and 1980, perhaps by $150 million each year. City officials acknowledged that their revenues were running better than expected, but they were at odds with the state over the extent of the improvement.

title: Panel Urges Congress to Extend Medicare to Hypertension Tests
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI)  A panel of medical advisers called on Congress today to extend Medicare to cover tests for high blood pressure, the silent killer that endangers the lives of 60 million Americans.

title: Pope John Paul Finishes His Latin American Trip
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan 31  Pope John Paul II ended his latin American trip today with the same evangelistic zeal with which he began it During snips here and in Monterrey today. the Polish Pope told students to study for the future of their people.

title: The Sears Refrain
description: For all its deficiencies as a lawsuit, the case of Sears, Roebuck & Company v. Attorney General of the United States, et al., has struck some responsive chords. Sears. the target of job discrimination charges by Federal agencies, has turned on its accusers and blamed them for race and sex bias in employment. Sears says that their confusion, oppressive tactics, incompetence and delay have denied Sears and other employers the right to comply with equal opportunity laws. It asks a Federal court to block a lawsuit by the Equal Employment Opportunities Commission and any Federal contract cutoffs until Washington providQs a properly balanced national work force.

title: Teams of Experts Visit Shipyard In Investigation on Cancer Cases
description: KITTERY, Me., Jan. 31  Federal health investigators and a team of civilian experts assigned by Congress to assure the impartiality of their findings today began studying allegations that workers at the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard here have been contracting leukemia at up to six times the national rate.

title: G.M. to Sell Frigidaire To White Consolidated
description: DETROIT, Jan. 31  The General Motors Corporation plans to sell its moneylosing, but prestigious Frigidaire appliances division to White Consolidated Industries Inc., the nation's thirdlargest appliance manufacturer, it was announced today.

title: U.S. and China Sign Agreements; Carter Sees an Irreversible Trend
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  President Carter and Deputy Prime Minister Teng lisiaoping signed agreements today to provide a framework for what the President called a new and irreversible course in ChineseAmerican relations that both sides expect to follow after the normalization of relations.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 31 (AP) A.J. Foyt, the star driver, resigned today as a director of Championship Auto Racing Teams and said he would rejoin the United States Auto Club.

title: Taped Talk, Purportedly by Shah, Urges Army to Foment Civil War
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  In a tape purporting to record the final remarks of Shah of Iran to top military leaders just before he left the country Jan. 16, the Iranian Army was urged to create a prolonged civil war to give the Shah an opportunity to return and regain power.

title: Creamer Completes W.H.W. Purchase
description: Creamer Inc., New York, said yes.. terday that it had concluded its purchase of Wilson, Haight & Welch, Hartford agency. Litigation has ended in the Superior Court in Hartford on move to restrain the acquisition from taking place.

title: Hers
description: WRILING away the hours in the office of a Park Avenue specialist, I noted in Vogue that Amy Vanderbilt's bible on etiquette has been expanded and con temporized by Letitia Baldrige.

title: BLOKHINTSEV DEAD; A RUSSIAN PHYSICIST
description: Prof. Dmitri I. Blokhintsev, a prominent Soviet theoretical physicist, died last Saturday at the age of 71, according to reports yesterday by Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: New Life for the Old Bronx River?
description: The Bronx River is the only true river in the confines of New York City, and for decades it has been growing increasingly stagnated. But if the City Planning Commission has its way, the Bronx River may soon be brought back to life.

title: Cheesequake (an Epicenter?) Is Shaken by Identity Crisis
description: CHEESEQUAKE, N.J., Jan. 31 For decades in this small crossroads hamlet in Central New Jersey, schoolchldren on field trips have gone down to the big tidal bog in Cheesequake State Park.

title: CUT OF 12,000 MILES IN AMTRAK'S SYSTEM PROPOSED BY ADAMS
description: Brock Adams, the Secretary of Transportation, proposed yesterday that Amtrak slash 12,000 miles, or 43 percent of the total, from its rail system, for a sav ing to taxpayers of nearly $1.4 billion in five years.

title: Deaths
description: FOXLeo. A resident of the Cricket Club in North Miami Florida. Passed away January 27, 1979. He is survived by his beloved wife Janice (immermen) Fox, devoted father of Kenneth and James, adored brother of Edith Richmond and cherished grandfather of Pamela, Thomas, Jonathan and Jeffrey.

title: Home Beat
description: TRUST Bloomingdale's to get into the act. But then, if you were a film company shooting a movie, and you needed model mom in a department store. where would vou go? Bloomingdale's.

title: Excerpts From the Rockefeller Letter
description: Following are excerpts from a letter Nelson A. Rockefeller wrote to Richard Rosenbaum, New York State Republican national committeeman, dated Jan. 18, eight days before Mr. Rockefeller's death. Hugh Morrow, his press spokesman. said Mr. Rockefeller's thoughts on the Vice President's role represented his last political statement.

title: Home Improvement
description: NEW and improved plumbing systems that make use of plastic pipe, fittings, connectors of all kinds and even plastic valves now make it easier than ever to do your own plumbing work around the house.

title: Donation to Neediest Is Tribute to Woman Killed in Auto Crash
description: There were several memorial contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Furd this week, among them a moving tribute to a young woman who was killed along with her sister in an automobile accident near Syracuse, N.Y., last fall.

title: Gilligan Is Resigning As Director of A.I.D.; No Successor Named
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  The White House announced tonight that John J. Gilligan, administrator of the Agency for International Development, had resigned and would be appointed to an important post in international economic affairs.

title: Rev. Joseph Olsovsky; Long a Pastor in Jersey
description: The Rev. Joseph Olsovsky, pastor emeritus of St. Joseph's Slovak Roman Catholic Church, Raritan, N.J., died Monday in a nursing home in Allentown, Pa., following a long illness. He was 79 years old and had lived in Allentown since his retirement in 1970.

title: How a Card Counter Can Win at Blackjack
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 31  Blackjack, also called 21, is a card game in which a player wins if the total value of his hand is closer to 21 than the dealer's total.

title: City Antipoverty Plan Backed by Washington
description: The Federal Government has approved New York City's plan to restructure the $37 million antipoverty program by abolishing community corporations as operators of projects and replacing them with 26 area policy boards. Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: Dance: Matteo's Mixture
description: THE view that dance in all its ethnic varieties is universal and meldable is not a popular one at the moment, but Matteo, whose doctrine might be said to be Mix, with respect, has long been of that opinion. On Tuesday, at the Theater of the Open Eye, he and the Matteo EthnoAmerican Dance Theater presented folk and Classical dance from around the world, and some hybrids. too.

title: Giving Your Fern A Growing Base
description: Cuisinart isn't just for cooking. Although the manufacturers probably didn't have ferns in mind when they designed the machine, it can whip up a tasty footing for your plants.

title: Furniture Kits: DoItYourself Reproductions
description: AT an apartmentwarming party my husband and I gave, a friend pointed to a candle stand and asked how we ever managed to spirit it away from the Metropolitan Museum. She was kidding, of course, but I was flattered that the kit I'd put together in only three hours looked enough like the original for her to recognize it.

title: Heating With Wood Poses Fire Hazards
description: With many people trying to save on fuel bills by heating with wood, several oldfashioned fire hazards are making a comeback.

title: New York Urban League Criticizes Koch Rhetoric
description: The New York Urban League called yesterday for a halt to namecalling and strident rhetoric by Mayor Koch, saying that it had led to a polarization of the city's racial and ethnic groups.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: HANGING plants in the window has become an accepted window treatment, especially in highceilinged lofts and apartments. But tending a dozen or so plants eight or 10 feet in the air can be a nasty chore  either one hauls a ladder along and climbs up and down or one raises and lowers each plant individually.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Market Place
description: YOU'RE a customer of a brokerage house and you follow the market closely. Last week, you bought 100 shares of the Northern Trust Corporation at $39.90 a share, or a total of $3,990.

title: Opera: Leonie Rysanek's Tosca at Met
description: THIS is the 20th anniversary of Leonie Rysanek's debut with the Metropolitan Opera, and the soprano returned to the company on Tuesday night in the title role of Tosca. Joining her for their first appearances in the Puccini opera this season were Placido Domingo as Cavaradossi and Renato Capecchi as the Sacristan. Cornell MacNeil was the Scarpia, with James Conlon conducting.

title: ROBERT A. OBERFELL
description: Robert A. Oberfell, secretary and associate general counsel for the Gulf and Western Natural Resources Group, died Sunday in Nashville. He was 60 years old.

title: Oil Curb Ruling Set For April 1
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger said today that the Administration must decide by April 1 whether to impose mandatory constraints on gasoline and oil consumption because of the halt in imports of Iranian oil

title: P.S. 194 Boycott At End of Week: Most Pupils Out
description: On the eighth day of a parents' boycott and mass picketing, 400 of the enrolled 534 children were absent from Public School 194 (the Countee Cullen School) in Harlem yesterday. It was the last day on the job for Russell Cunningham, the principal.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY. JAN 31 1979

title: Luxury Sportswear Meets Resistance
description: Expensive designer sportswear, which American women coveted in great quantities for so many years, has had rough going recently. In the last few months, clothes bearing such labels as Anne Klein and Ralph Lauren have languished on the racks.

title: Arrows to File Suit On Star's Suspension
description: The president of the New York Arrows said yesterday that he would seek a court injunction to force the Major Indoor Soccer League to lift the suspension of the team's star forward, Slavisa (Steve) Zungul.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Copper futures scored new advances yesterday as prices in the cash market neared record levels.

title: Continental Bank May Cut Its Rate
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank may be forced temp?? rarily to reduce its prime rate as result of competitive pressures. Roger E. Anderson, the chairman said here yesterday. He stressed that any such action would he tem porary, however, and predicted that interest rates would continue to climb until the third quarter, peaking at about 13 percent.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 31 (AP)  A Federal judge cleared the way today for the United Technologies Corporation to complete its takeover of the Carrier Corporation, but ruled that Carrier must be maintained as a separate corporation pending the outcome of a Justice Department antitrust suit.

title: Public Housing That the Tenants Helped Plan
description: LONDON WHILE a taxi waited at the entrance to the estate, Maureen Killick chatted with the architect about the dimensions of her new kitchen and speculated about the best spot in the en closed garden for the rose bushes she wanted to plant. Her husband, Henry, looked on indulgently.

title: Bethlehem Net $74.5 Million in Quarter
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation. the nation's secondlargest steelmaker, reported yesterday that its profits soared to $74.5 million, or $1.70 a share, for the fourth quarter of last year, more than triple the $19.2 million, or 43 cents a share, earned in the depressed fourth quarter of 1977. And directors announced a dividend increase.

title: DR. THOMAS F. MAGOVERN
description: Dr. Thomas F. Magovern, a retired orthopedist, died yesterday at the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune, N.J. He was 77 years old and lived in Brielle, N.J.

title: Alaskan Skier Rated Prime Olympic Hope
description: WATERVILLE VALLEY, N. H., Jan.31  When Alison OwenSpencer was 13 years old, she created a major stir in skiing circles by reporting to Winter Park, Colo., for the national junior crosscountry championships. She was the only girl in the field.

title: Paris Shows: A 40's Mood
description: PARIS, Jan. 31From the moment they installed the soundtracks in the cool, elegant couture salons, the jig was up. The couturiers here could no longer pursue their aloof ways. They picked up some of the street smarts the readytowear people have used to attract attention.

title: Pop: New CainKral Act
description: JACKIE Cain and Roy Kral have been singing their crisp, flippant, ironic, witty duets  a repertory based on Rodgers and Hart and the Gershwins, as well as scatsinging jazz songs  for so long that their identify as performers is fairly well established. But that preconception is being shaken up in their fourweek run at Michaels Pub. which began Tuesday evening.

title: Survey Shows Inflation Brings Cutbacks to Many
description: Eleanor Scheetz was hoping for a lot of things, but she cannot afford most of them now.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia  What could the United States do now to stop the fighting and encourage a real political settlement in Rhodesia? The question is not of preoccupying concern to Americans; it is not Iran or SALT or China. But the chaos in Rhodesia affects all of southern Africa, and before long there may be scenes of flight and misery that will rouse U.S. opinion.

title: Baker Creates a Group To Seek Funds in 1980
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the Seriate minority leader, took a first, tentative step today toward seeking the Republican Presidential nomination next year.

title: Ballet: Duet Equalizes Positive and Negative
description: IT was to have been a normal New York City Ballet night on Tuesday at the New York State Theater. On the program were the season's first performance of Jerome Robbins's In G Major and George Balanchine's Kammermusik No.2. Merrill Ashley and Joseph Duell made their debuts, as well, in new roles in The Four Seasons, the latest Robbins ballet.

title: Treasury Is Defended On Trade
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal sought today to rebut criticism from industry officials and some members of Congress that his department had been lax in enforcing trade statutes as he declared that the Treasury had to be fair to both importers and the domestic comnetition.

title: Q&A
description: Q. We live in a threeyearold town house that has doublepane windows whose two sheets of glass are set about a quarter of an inch apart in hollow aluminum frames. Condensation has appeared between the two panes in several of these windows, and our neighbors are having the same kind of problem. A merchant we consulted said they cannot be repaired since they are factory sealed, and the entire window must be replaced. Can this problem be corrected without going to such expense? Mrs. R.B., Reston, Va.

title: Playing Panda to the Polar Bear
description: No American of the cold war era ever preached more zealously against the danger of Soviet world conquest  hegemonism, as he calls it  than China's Teng Hsiaoping during his current tour of the United States. Mr. Teng calls for a tight SinoAmerican alliance to place curbs on the Polar Bear. Unquestionably, the Soviets are ambitious for greater power; but what the Chinese leader's argument ignores are the limits of that power.

title: TV: Man Who Took Geronimo
description: THE screenplay for Mr. Horn was written by William Goldman, whose Academy Award film credits include Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid and All the President's Men. Evidently. that's the primary reason CBSTV has made Mr. Horn a big production, with two hours scheduled for tonight at 8 o'clock and the remaining two set for Saturday at 8.

title: The Fantasies Of Ludwig II
description: THE eccentricities of Ludwig II of Bavaria are legendary; his Disneyland palaces have been tourist attractions since they were constructed in the 1870's and 80's. Their extraordinary design and decoration, representing dreams and delusions inspired by everything from Wagnerian romanticism and German mythology to the ritual splendors of the Bourbon Kings and whoknowswhat Freudian impulses, were far out even in the 19th century, which was not given to understatement.

title: Estimate Revised On Gasoline Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  In a discussion with reporters today, Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger pointed to a report released yesterday by his department and said that the average price of gasoline would go up 9 cents over two years if present price controls were kept and by nearly 13 cents without them.

title: Thai Premier, on Eve of U.S. Visit, Expresses Need for Defense Aid
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 31 Prime Minister Kriangsak Chamanand said in an interview today that the Vietnamese invasion of Cambodia might upset his Government's plan to spend more than $1 billion this year for rural development and force him to transfer some of that money to defense spending.

title: Ruling Coming On Sugar Price
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)  The Carter Administration expects to make a final decision on new proposals for sugar pricesupport legislation in ??a matter of days, a key official said today after a session with representatives of the sweetener industry.

title: Dick Vitale: Frustrated But Still
description: Dick Vitale was going to be a professional basketball coach. He decided that long before his three bleeding ulcers, and years before health problems forced him to resign as coach of the University of Detroit team. He was going to make it, and when he walked out of Madison Square Garden, the kids would wait for his autograph, just as he once waited at Eighth Avenue and 50th Street.

title: Stage: Minnesota Moon
description: IN a small Middle Western town, two young friends have a last meeting bebre one of them goes off to college and the other stays at home, presumably to become mired in provincial life. The situation is familiar in John Olive's Minnesota Moon, the current entry in the Circle Repertory Company's lateshow series of oneact plays. However, in a brief time and through indirection, the playwright succeeds in evoking an atmosphere of wistfulness and eagerness. A life appears to be closing down its prospects at the same time that another life is opening to experience.

title: Rockefeller Left a Last Political Comment
description: In what a press aide said was Nelson A. Rockefeller's last political statement, the former Vice President and New York Governor wrote that he had known all the nation's Vice Presidents since Henry A. I Wallace and that I think it is fair to say that all of them were frustrated.

title: Corporations Report Their Sales and Earnings Results for the Quarter
description: For periods as shown: (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) overtheCounter

title: EARNINGS
description: Philip Morris Inc., which has the knack of piling up profits and acquiring companies, yesterday reported profit increases of 20.6 percent for the fourth quarter and 22 percent for all of last year.

title: White House Bars Woman Aide's Senate Appearance
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  The White House, citing the principle of executive privilege, today canceled a scheduled appearance by Sarah Weddington, the President's special assistant for women's issues, before the Senate Human Resources Committee.

title: OnceExotic Ferns Are Now Easier to Find
description: FERNS have been among the most popular and at the same time most monotonous of house plants. As long as it was a Boston fern or a maidenhair you were looking for, or maybe a staghorn if your luck really held, you would have no trouble getting it.

title: People
description: Charlotte Beers joining TathamLaird & Kudner Advertising. Chicago, as a managing partner and member of the management committee.

title: FreeAgent Status for Csonka
description: The Giants did not pick up their option to keep Larry Csonka yesterday, and the running back became a free agent as of last midnight.

title: Gems Get Miss Logan
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 31 (AP) The New Jersey Gems of the Women's Professional Basketball League acquired Karen Logan from the Chicago Hustle today in exchange for Tanya Johnson and future considerations.

title: How to Save Social Security
description: The President's tight budget has brought forth protests from potential victims of the economy ax and none have been more anguished than those of the traditional boosters of Social Security. A close look at how Mr. Carter proposes to pare outlays, however, suggests that thoughtful supporters of Social Security, in Congress and out, should be cheering, not booing.

title: Volunteers Aid the U.S.O.
description: Thousands of disabled and hospitalized former servicemen  veterans of conflicts from World War I through Vietnam  are not forgotten thanks to volunteers of the United Service Organizations who give time and effort to Veterans Administration Hospitals across the country. U.S.O. shows come to the wards as well, and provide the only live entertainment that many of these men ever see.

title: ITS PRISONS JAMMED, STATE PLANS TO BUY RIKERS ISLAND JAILS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 31  Governor Carey. faced with severe overcrowding in the state's prisons, has approved a plan to take over the Rikers Island jails from New York City, build two 512bed prisons upstate and phase out the antiquated Ossining prison in Westchester County.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Urges Firmer Action To Stop Britain's Spreading Strikes
description: LONDON, Jan. 31  With strikes by hospital, sanitation and other lowpaid workers still spreading, Margaret Thatcher, leader of the opposition Conservatives, said today that if she were Prime Minister she would stand up to those who disrupted Britain's vital services.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Gov. Arnold's March; Air, Shaw; La Chasse du Jeune Henri, Overture, Mehul; 16 German Dance. Schubert; Mazurka. Chopin.

title: Knicks Rout Pistons As Rudd Stars, 10886
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Jan. 31  Coach Red Holzman would not like his New York Knicks to play the rest of the National Basketball Association season with eight men, but that number was enough tonight to rout the Detroit Pistons, 10886, before 9,139 fans in the Silverdome.

title: Princeton Conquers L.I.U., 8264
description: PRINCETON, N.J. Jan. 31  Princeton marked its first basketball meeting against Long Island University with an 8264 victory tonight before a crowd of 1.452 at the Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Financial Corporation, a diversified financial holding company, has elected Ronald F. Walker executive vice president

title: Deaths
description: HOROWITZRebecca. Beloved wife of Seymour, devoted mother of Charles Ferman, dear sister of Ruth Davidson and Louis Ferman. Services today 10:30 AM Parkside Chapels, Queens Blvd at 66 Ave. Forest Hills.

title: Celtics Suspend Barnes After He Misses Practices
description: BOSTON, Jan. 31 (AP)  Marvin Barnes, the often controversial Boston Celtic forward who had missed recent practice sessions, was suspended for two games today by the National Basketball Association team

title: World Gold
description: WEDNESDAY. JAN. 31. 1979

title: Sound
description: THE common language is having a rough time. Semiprivate jargons pervade the professions and.other cliques, defeating the purpose of communication. Of course, there are other purposes. The special languages of priests and medicine men or  more recently  of lawyers, engineers, stockbrokers, baseball fans and philosophers, are superbly ef fective as egoenlarging devices and for creating exclusionary ingroups. Like a tribal recognition mark, the lingo sets off the enlightened initiates from the untutored rest of the world.

title: Deaths
description: SCHILARWilliam. Temple EmanuEl of Boro Park records with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed and long time member. Services Thursday, 10:15aM, Boulevard. 1901 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn. Rabbi Baruch Silverstein Irving H. Fine, President

title: Concert: Leontyne Price In Philharmonic Benefit
description: LEONTYNE PRICE doesn't sing very often in New York, or at least as often as her admirers would like, so they were out in full force last night at Avery Fisher Hall, where the soprano was soloist with the New York Phiharrnonic in benefit concert for its pension fund. Zubin Mehta conducted.

title: Economic Indicators Drop Again
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)  The Government's index of economic indicators declined for the second consecutive month in December, giving support to predictions that a recession might not be far off. The index dropped fivetenths of 1 percent in December, the same as in November, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Carnegie Report on Public Radio and TV Reflects Panel's Political Astuteness
description: The report by the Carnegie Commission on the Future of Public Broadcasting reflected political astuteness on the part of its framers in carefully tuning its recommendations to the interests of key figures in Government concerned with communications issues.

title: Black Supplants Rabbi as Crown Heights Board Chief
description: The community board in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, which has a large Hasidic population, has voted to oust a rabbi as chairman and replace him with a black man.

title: Deaths
description: PERLSTEINAnna, beloved wife of the late Max. Dear mother of Lucille Brody and Justin Perlstein. Loving grandmother of Phyllis and Richard Taylor, Teresa and William Perlstein, Susan and John Perlstein, Thomas Perlstein and the late Robert Brcdy. Darling great grandmother of Deborah and Daniel Taylor and David Perlstein. Dear sister of Rebecca Kudwitt and Joseph Brett. Services at BoulevardPark West Chapel, 1450 Bway, Hewlett, L.I., Friday at 12 Noon.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: I LOOK back over my shoulder at this book, because a masterpiece may be gaining on me. Little Lives has already been compared, rather predictably, to Edgar Lee Masters's Spoon River Anthology and Sherwood Anderson's Winesberg, Ohio. Less predictably, it has been mentioned in the same sentence with William Faulkner's The Hamlet. In other words, Little Lives is about rural folk in short takes. In this case, the rural folk abide in Washington County in upstate New York.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Humor, Chaos and Sales Trail Pope
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 31  As Marcelo Galan, a Mexican journalist, arrived to cover the Pope's visit to the Basilica of Guadalupe, he was handed the robes of a bishop He was understandably puzzled. The previous day he had been sprayed with Chemical Mace by the police for getting too close to rope John Paul II

title: Going out  Guide
description: BEATING TRUE These wintry days, the South Street Seaport Museum is a fascinating area to prowl, whether to see the old boats moored alongside Fulton Street or the historical old buildings, or to visit the museum, the thriving indoor flea market and the refurbished sites along Water Street.

title: The City
description: Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein denied a motion to lift restraints preventing the Chancellor of Schools from removing School Board 26 in northeastern Queens for its refusal to collect racial and ethnic data.

title: Rhodesia's Whites Look to U.S. for Aid
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 31After voting overwhelmingly yesterday to accept a limited form of black rule, white Rhodesians turned their attention today to the reaction in the United States and Britain, whose acceptance of the plan is held essential to hopes of turning back black nationalist guerrillas.

title: U.S. Warns Russians to Stop Encoding Missile Data
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  The Carter Administration has warned the Soviet Union that an attempt to impede American efforts to monitor a Soviet missile test on Dec. 21 has jeopardized the ability of the United States to verify Soviet compliance with the terms of a projected treaty limiting strategic arms, Government officials said today.

title: World News Briefs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 31 (AP) North Korea said today that it would stop using epithets like puppets and bandits for South Korea starting tomorrow, and it called for resuming talks about reuniting the divided peninsula.

title: Money
description: WEDNESDAY, JAN. 31. 1979

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The American Express bid for McGrawHill was rejected unanimously by the publishing company's board of director as not in the best interests of stockholders. American Express called the rejection precipitous and said its offer of $40 a share for McGrawHill would remain open until March 1. The rejection appeared to be a victory for Harold W. McGraw Jr., the McGrawHill chairman, who has expressed strong opposition to the takeover. [Page D1]

title: East German Protestants to Unite
description: EAST BERLIN, Jan. 31  The Protestant churches in East Germany have announced a plan to form a unified evangelical organization, thus strengthening the church's stand in this Communist country and ending a regional division that dates back to the Reformation.

title: From Kit to Canopy Bed In Less Than 12 Hours
description: On unpacking the contents of the carton. I am relieved to discover there are a mere 17 pieces of wood that will make up the bed. alone with an assortment of screws, bolts. Dins and hangers.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Swede Accuses Chile of a 74 Plot
description: STOCKHOLM, Jan. 31  A top official of the Social Democratic Party here said tonight that he had received a document indicating that the Chilean secret police in 1979 ordered the assassination of Olof Palme, then the Prime Minister of Sweden.

title: Philippine AirBuys Jets
description: MANILA. Jan. 31 (UPI)  Philippine Air Lines announced today plans to acquire three new widebodied DC10 jets from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation at a total cost of $120 million. An airline spokesman said a letter of intent to buy one DC10 for delivery later this year was sent to the aircraft makers earlier this month.

title: Miss Fratianne Gains Figure Skating Lead
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 31 (AP)  Linda Fratianne took a big lead today in her bid to win a third straight gold medal at the United States figure skating championships.

title: Putting It Together
description: 1. After unpacking the shipping carton. lay out all pieces on the floor and check against the contents list to make certain everything has been included. If something is missing, call or write the company for an immediate replacement. In the meantime, return the pieces to the original carton and store in a cool, dry place.

title: Railway Clerks Approve Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)  Members of the Brotherhood of Railway and Airline Clerks have voted by a 5to1 margin to approve a contract signed by the nation's major railroads Jan. 13, the union president, Fred J. Kroll, announced today. With all but a few ballots still to be counted before today's deadline, the tally showed about 50,000 members accepted the pact and 10,000 opposed it. Some 105,500 persons were eligible to vote.

title: In Teng Visit, A Natural Hit
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  However modest the concrete agreements, the process of teconciliation between the United States and China has gained quick new momentum from the whirlwind threeday courtship of the American Administration, Congress and the press this week by Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping of China.

title: Insider Reports for Exchanges
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: KHOMEINI ARRIVES IN TEHERAN, URGES OUSTER OF FOREIGNERS; MILLIONS RALLY TO GREET HIM
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Thursday, Feb. 1 Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the 78yearold symbol of the Iran revolution, returned in triumph to his homeland this morning and urged the expulsion of all foreigners from the country.

title: Iona College Student Dies in Karate Session From a Heart Ailment
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 31  A21yearold lona College student, William J. Slavik Jr., died last night during a karate sparring session, but the Westchester County Medical Examiner's office said after an autopsy that he was the victim of a rare heart ailment rather than blow to his chest that was originally assumed to have caused his death.

title: Calendar of Events: Antiques and Memorabilia Show
description: Antiques and Memorabilia Show, Statler Hilton Hotel, 33d Street and Seventh Avenue.

title: Ski Conditions
description: Figures in parentheses show total trails andnumber open at each area. Skiarea forecasts appear on the weather page. For information: New York, (212) 7558100; New Jersey, (609) 2928456 Thursdays and Fridays from 2 to 4 P.M.; Pennsylvania, (717) 4215791: New Hampshire. (603) 2242525; Vermont, (802) 2290531, and Massachusetts.(800)6285030.

title: SHIPYARD'S PICKETS REDUCE WORK FORCE
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Jan. 31Long lines of shouting but disciplined pickets persuaded thousands of workers to stay off their jobs today at the huge Newport News Shipyard and Drydock Company as the United Steelworkers of America tested its strength here in hostile Southern territory for what may be a long union recognition strike.

title: Talking Business
description: From Feb. 17 to Feb. 19, a highpowered group of financial experts from throughout the world will gather in Bermuda for the first time. The mandate of the new Group of 30, headed by H. Johannes Witteveen, former managing director of the International Monetary Fund, is nothing less than to find answers for some of the troubling questions about the way the international economic system is, or is not, working.

title: Times Seeks Injunction In Deliverers Stoppage
description: The New York Times is seeking a preliminary injunction in United States District Court here to enjoin members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union from continuing a work stoppage that began last week at the newspaper's printing facility in Carlstadt. N.J., in violation of a nostrike clause in their contract.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 31  The Internal Revenue Service, charged by its own manual of procedures with the mandatory auditing of every President's tax returns, appears to have been lying down on the job in the case of the Carter family businesses

title: Kidnappers Free Wealthy Italian
description: BRESCIA, Italy, Jan. 31 (AP)  Kidnappers freed Enrico Gnutti, a steel manufacturer, today after reportedly collecting $2.2 minion in ransom. They had held him for nine days.

title: 3 in Migran t Family Face Pennsylvania Hearing in Killings
description: WEST CHESTER, Pa. Jan. 31 One day next week, William H. Lamb, the District Attorney here in Chester County, will address the local court with a tale of a family who moved north from the hills of Tennessee. He will say that some of its members stole for a living and killed to keep the stealing quiet, and that a father, in order to hush his sons, had one murdered and the other shot eight times.

title: Backgammon:
description: The first Turnberry Isle Gold Cup of Backgammon, under the direction of Lewis Deyong, took place last weekend in Miami. The total prize pool of more than $100,000, including $7,500 added by Don Soffer's Turnberry Isle, attracted a strong international field that included several dozen of Europe's best.

title: Traffic Jam on Truck Deregulation
description: It has all the markings of petty Congressional politics two powerful Senate committee chairmen, each demanding the right to draft legislation to increase competition in the trucking industry. But appearances deceive. The current contest for committee jurisdiction between Chairman Edward Kennedy of Judiciary and Chairman Howard Cannon of Commerce is the opening battle in a bloody Congressional war over the deregulation of trucking.

title: Pan Am Quits I.A.T.A. on Fares
description: Pan American World Airways announced yesterday its unconditional withdrawal from the International Air Transport Association's faresetting bodies, effective March 31.

title: Ohio Reporter Gets Jail Sentence After Refusing to Give Up Notes
description: MANSFIELD, Ohio, Jan. 31  A reporter for The Mansfield News Journal was sentenced to jail on a contemptofcourt charge today after he refused to surrender notes to a judge.

title: Risk in Estrogen Found To Decline if Use Ends
description: BOSTON, Jan. 31 (AP) The very high risk of uterine cancer among women who take estrogen during menopause declines sharply when they stop using the medicine, according to a new study.

title: SOLAR ENERGY HELD STILL DECADES AWAY
description: A panel of leading specialists, convened a year ago at the request of the White House to assess prospects for generating electric power from sunlight, has concluded that the ultimate prospects are bright but that for at least a decade the technology will not be sufficiently advanced to initiate a major conversion effort.

title: New York's New Policy On Dog Law Beginning
description: Starting today, New York City dog owners who fail to clean up after their pets will receive summonses, not warnings.

title: Westchester and Nassau Face Cut In School Aid Under New Formula
description: ALBANY, Jan. 31  Nassau County would lose nearly $15 million and Westchester County would lose nearly $8 million under the schoolaid formula Governor Carey is proposing as part of his new budget.

title: Music: New Generation In Moscow Philharmonic
description: THE new generation is upon us. and the oldtimers of the establishment organizations are being replaced by younger figures. Last night the Moscow Philharmonic gave a concert in Carnegie Hall, and the two major participants were relative newcomers. Dmitri Kitaenko. the conductor, has been showing his talent in the West for only a short time. This was not his American debut, however. He had conducted the Moscow State Symphony on an American tour about three years ago. The violinist in the Tchaikovsky Concerto was Ilya Grubert, who won the gold medal in last year's Tchaikovsky Competition (sharing first place with an American).

title: Borg Advances At Richmond
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 31 (AP)  Topseeded Bjorn Borg of Sweden breezed to victory in the second round of the Richmond Tennis Classic tonight, ousting Russell Simpson, 61, 62, in only 50 minutes.

title: Letters
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Effects of Carey SchoolAid Formula on 4 Counties
description: Following is a table showing how state aid in thousands of dollars for school districts in four counties in the metropolitan region would be affected under Governor Carey's nesw schoolaid formula:

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY. FEBRUARY 1, 1979

title: Rangers Trail, 51; Lose, 54
description: DENVER, Jan. 31 (AP)  Merlin Malinowski scored after 13 minutes 30 seconds of the third period tonight to give the Colorado Rockies a 51 lead, but they had to hang on for a 59 victory over the tenacious New York Rangers

title: Consortium for Iran Oil Waits
description: LONDON, Jan. 31  While chaos rules in Iran. 3,000 miles away, the Western consortium based in grassy Finsbury Square that normally decides how much oil will be produced in Iran is unusually quiet these days. It no longer calls the shots.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times Nov. 19 reported erroneously that the coroner in Richland County, Ohio. had ruled that two deaths of prisoners in the enttrity jail were suicides. An article ?? details is ??.

title: SellOff Hits Blue Chips; Dow Slides
description: Bearish economic news sent the stock market sharply lower yesterday, with the glamour and blue chips posting the biggest losses.

title: HIGH ALGERIAN AIDE IS NAMED PRESIDENT
description: ALGIERS, Jan. 31  Algeria's acting Defense Minister was named by the governing National Liberation Front today to succeed the late President, Houari Boumediene.

title: The Region
description: MINEOLA, L.I.  The Long Island Lighting Company opened a 90day amnesty program to recover millions of dollars in revenue lost to meter cheaters. Ira L. Freilicher, a Lilco vice president, said. The customer agrees to come forward and make a full and accurate disclosure and the company, on its part, will keep all the information confidential and promise not to prosecute, he explained.

title: Security Agency Holds A Quiet, Crucial Power Over Communications
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  For the last quartercentury, one of the Government's most secret agencies has played an important, largely undisclosed role in shaping the nation's privately owned communications network of microwave towers, underground cables, satellites and computers.

title: Criminal Court Tried  Just 164 Cases in '78;  Lack of Judges Cited
description: More than 80,000 misdemeanor cases were filed in Manhattan last year. The number that went to trial was 164, down from more than 2,000 in 1971. The reason, judges and law enforcement officials say, is an increasingly severe shortage of Criminal Court judges.

title: Many Jews, Upset About Future, Leaving Iran for West and Israel
description: TEHERAN. Iran, Jan. 29  Members of Iran's historic Jewish community say that anxiety about the future is causing many Jews to leave the country.

title: Plimpton at It Again
description: George Plimpton, as we all know by now, is willing to do almost anything. Now, you can drop the almost.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The Times has been beguiled into endorsing government schemes ('The Feds Prescribe Generics, editorial Jan. 19.) that would urge doctors and pharmacists to substitute less expensive generic prescription drugs for expensive brand names. In theory, such plans would boost competition and provide large consumer savings. In the real world, they will do little of either.

title: Transcript of Statements After Signing
description: Mr. Vice Premier, American and Chinese friends, what we have accomplished in the last three days is truly exceptional. But our aim is to make this kind of exchange between our countries no longer the exception, but

title: Union Membership Rolls Queried
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  A study made public today by a unionfighting affiliate of the National Association of Manufacturers implies that Government figures may overstate total union membership in the United States by as much as 10 percent.

title: St. John's Sets Back Army for 3d in Row
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 31  Suddenly St. John's is justified in thinking about tournament basketball again this season.

title: Advertising
description: SEARS, ROEBUCK & COMPANY, the nation's biggest retailer and one of the country's largest advertisers, will spend 7 percent less on advertising this year than in 1978. Most of this reduction will be accomplished through lower expenditures for network television and national magazines, with newspapers showing only a slight gain.

title: Golden Glove Heavyweight, 25, Dies After Losing Fight
description: Francisco Rodriguez, a 25yearold machinist from Middletown, N.Y., died early yesterday morning about four hours after he had been stopped at the Felt Forum in the first fight of his career, a heavyweight subnovice bout in the New York Golden Gloves tournament.

title: NEW &USEFUL
description: Basic Furniture

title: Teng Is Leaving Today On FiveDay U.S. Tour
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  Having concluded the formal side of his visit to Washington, Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping leaves tomorrow morning on a fiveday tour that will take him to the sun belt and the Pacific Northwest before his departure for Peking on Monday.

title: Dance: Joan Strasbaugh
description: DANCE IN THE PLAIN STYLE was what Joan Strasbaugh called her program Tuesday night at the Kitchen. Well, it certainly wasn't fancy. Neither was it so plain as to be drab. What Miss Strasbaugh did  and she did it with impish glee  was to take ordinary, even trivial, movement and present it either in curious new contexts or with such intensity that looked bizarre.

title: Cash Prices
description: WEDNESDAY, JAN. 31, 1979

title: It's Just a Museum But He Calls It Home
description: See Page C8

title: Gold in the Mud for 57735
description: RAHWAY, N.J., Jan. 31  In the morning James Scott had done his yard work. For other boxers it is known as road work, but this light heavyweight lives in Rahway State Prison where the road is outside the high cement walls. He has to run on the hard, brown dirt of the prison yard. When he returned to his cell, he

title: 4 Makers Raise Copper Price
description: Four copper producers raised the price for copper cathodes yesterday by 2 cents a pound to 82 cents, the highest price since the summer of 1979. The record domestic price is 85 cents.

title: Around the Nation
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31 (AP)  A snowstorm swept through southern California today, stranding hundreds of motorists and paralyzing normally balmy desert towns.

title: Deaths
description: BRONSTEINMoilyBeloved aunt Of Ruth & Fred Arnold; devoted great aunt c1 Scott & Malcolm. Services Thursday, Feb. 1, 10AM, Nassau North Chapels. Great Neck.

title: Kodak Appeals Berkey Case
description: The Eastman Kodak Company ?? asked the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit to rev?? the decision that ordered the ?? graphic giant to pay an $87 million an?? trust damage award to Berkey P?? Inc.

title: Andreotti Resigns, Bringing Fears Of Rise in Italian Terrorist Activity
description: ROME, Jan. 31  Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti today submitted the resignation of his singleparty ChristianDemocratic Government that has ruled Italy with the parliamentary support of the Communists for the last 10 months.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday. Jan. 31. 1979

title: Keeping Mobility Unfettered
description: NEWARK  Americans have long taken for granted their domestic freedom of mobility. We have always assumed that we are free to come and go Without having to account to a policeman. so long as we are peaceful and lawabiding. The United States Supreme Court this year may confirm that assumption or put an end to it.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Prices Drop On News of Refunding
description: Prices eased slightly in the credit markets yesterday on the heels of Tuesday's strong recovery. The big event of the day was the Treasury's announcement of its refunding operation for February.

title: Clippers Top Nets, 112 to 104
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 31  The New Jersey Nets win not forget their first visit to San Diego.

title: TV Campaign Set To Back Look Magazine
description: The first issue of Look magazine, due out next Monday, will be promoted by a strong television campaign, also beginning Monday. The theme is Look Again.

title: It's Just a Museum, But He Calls It Home
description: SOONER or later, visitors to the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston look above the Roman courtyard filled with exotic flowers, marble gods and medieval music, and speculate about the palace's mysterious fourth story that is closed to the public.

title: McGraw Spurns New Offer
description: The board of directors of McGrawHill Inc. unanimously rejected yesterday a $1 billion takeover offer from the American Express Company, saying that it was not in the best interests o?? McGrawHill and its shareholders.

title: About New York
description: There are more ways than fire to measure change in the Bronx. Up in the great union housing projects by the Van Cortlandt Reservoir, life seems holding up well, but the bar mitzvahs are down.

title: Teng Again Says Chinese May Move Against Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Teng Hsiaoping, the visiting Chinese Deputy Prime Minister, reiterated a warning today that Peking was prepared to take military action against Vietnam because of its takeover of Cambodia and continued incidents on the border with China.

title: Notes on People
description: The desire of two mothers; one in California and the other in Iowa. to breastfeed their babies made for unusual stories this week.

title: Rep. Moffett Elected As Chairman of Panel After Quiet Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  Representative Toby Moffett of Connecticut, one of the more aggressive young Democrats in the House, caught a number of his colleagues on the Government Operations Committee off guard today and won the chairmanship of the panel's Subcommittee on Environment, Energy and Natural Resources.

title: Sports Today
description: New Haven at Adelphi. 8 P.M.; Yeshiva at Brocklyn College. 8 P.M.

title: Resorts Excludes 17 Card Players From Blackjack
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 31  Resorts! International cracked down last night on blackjack card counters, barring from play 17 persons that the company said were among an influx of professional gamblers who had moved into the city in recent weeks.

title: Disks: Qawwali, Pakistan Sufi Music
description: THE SABRI BROTHERS Ghulam Farid Sabri and Maqbool Ahmed Sabri  toured America in 1975 and again 1978, playing Carnegie Hall both times. But it can't be said that they or their music is widely familiar here.

title: Defense Rests Without Calling Rep. Flood to Stand
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI)  Defense lawyers for Representative Daniel J. Flood rested their case at his 13dayold bribery trial today without asking the Pennsylvania Democrat to testify and answer charges that he took more than $50,000 in payoffs.

title: Unusual Othello Staged By Theater for New City
description: THE snickers grew into giggles and the giggles became barks and snorts; and this during Othello's pathetic final scenes.

title: Sweeney Todd: A Little Nightmare Music
description: SWEENEY TODD will be Murderous musical. The title character of the new Stephen Sondheirn show is the demon barber of Fleet Street, an 18th-century. Englishman who carries out a concerted campaign of vengeance for the supposed death of his wife and daughter. The musical, based on an 1842 British melodrama by George Dibuin Pitt, is now in rehearsal and begins previews on Tuesday, heading toward a March 1 opening at the Uris Theater.

title: Entertainment Events
description: THE UMBRELLAS OF CHERBOURG, a musical staged by Andrei Serban. Book by Jacques Demy and music by Michel Legrand; English translation by Sheldon Harnick, in association with Charles Burr. Presented by the New York Shakespeare Festival. At The Public Theater Cabaret/Martinson Hall. at 8.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Yesterday was the final day in office for John Dulany deButts as chairman and chief executive officer of the world's largest corporate enterprise, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. And in keeping with the spirit of the day preceding Mr. deButts's formal retirement, the courtly North Carolinian who led the company during the last seven turbulent years, was honored by some 900 of his fellow employees at a reception during the afternoon.

title: Deaths
description: LOOMISDr. Frederick J.On January 30th. Beloved husband of Jean, father of Harold John II. son of Ruth S. Loomis. grandfather of Martha Kay and Frederick John II, brother of Dr. Richard Loomis. Service and Interment private.

title: Bridge:
description: A substantial percentage of bridgeplayers in the metropolitan area were introduced to the game through adulteducation courses in a variety of centers. Perhaps the most important of !hem are conducted by Morton Kaplan at the 92d Street Y, where the 1979 classes for beginners and intermediate players begin next week.

title: U.S. to Raise $4.25 Billion In TwoPronged Offering
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  The Treasury announced today that it would sell eightyear notes and longterm bonds next week as it refinanced about $3 billion of maturing securities and raised about $1.3 billion of new cash.

title: Allied Chemical Profits Fall 24.3% in Quarter
description: The Allied Chemical Corporation, a major chemical company and an oil And gas producer, reported yesterday that its earnings for the foutth quarter of 1978 fell 24.3 percent to $29.6 million or $1.04 a share

title: Bavarian Legislator Arrested as Spy for East Germany
description: BONN, Jan. 31  The Federal Prosecutor's office announced the arrest today of a Bavarian state legislator as a suspected spy, the 15th case in less than two weeks involving alleged espionage for East Germany.

title: The Germanys' Kapital
description: POUGHKEEPSIE. N.Y.  Karl Marx defined the proletarian class in terms of its relationship to the means of production. Workers, owning no capital, had only their labor to sell to those that did, the bourgeoisie. In the face of competition with other firms, the bourgeoisie could pay workers no more than a subsistence wage. Thus, the capitalist system ordained the existence of two classes, with the living standard of the proletariat far below that of the bourgeoisie.

title: German Prices Increase
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, Jan. 31 (AP)  Increases in food and oil prices helped push up the costofliving index in West Germany in January, according to a preliminary report issued by the Federal Statistics Office today.

title: Peak Enlistment Bonus Offered
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)  The Army has raised by $500 a bonus that it offers to attract volunteers into the armored forces, which have fallen short in new recruits over the last 15 months. From now on, the Army will pay an enlisted man $3,000 to sign up in the tank forces. This is the biggest enlistment bonus permitted under law. The Army also offers $2,500 bonuses for young men who volunteer in the infantry, the artillery and other combat specialties.

title: Khomeini Is Thankful to French
description: PARIS, Thursday, Feb. 1  Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the man who brought down the Shah and has called for a new Iranian Islamic republic, left here early today to return to his country.

title: Arthur James Wallace Jr., at 63, ExPolice Officer and Professor
description: Arthur James Wallace Jr., a retired police officer and professor, died Tuesday at the Point Pleasant Hospital in Point Pleasant, N.J. He was 63 years old and lived in Brick Township, N.J.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's secondlargest steel company, yesterday announced a major realignment of its senior management, giving two younger executives equal power with the three present vice chairmen. What's more, one of the new executives at the power center has been with the corporation for only two years.

title: Where To Fine The Latest Disco Steps
description: PEOPLE who dance for a living are divided on the subject of giving their all on the discotheque floor. New York City Ballet's Suzanne Farrell is too shy to enjoy more than an elegant waltz or two, off the stage. Patrick Bissell had to curtail his disco dancing as he was given larger and more exhausting roles at American Ballet Theater. But Arthur Mitchell discodances away all his worries as founder and director of Dance Theater of Harlem and Tim Wengerd, of the Martha Graham Dance Company, finds that occasional letting go at a disco kind of gets all the kinks out. Tap a chorus kid or Broadway gypsy, however, and you'll find a good deal more afterperformance hours are spent shaking it all out in a blitz of colored lights and the thudding, driving howls of such disco songs Freak Out.

title: Papers Disclose Allies' Edge In Knowing German Codes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  Firsthand battlefield accounts written just after the surrender of Nazi Germany document the enormous advantage the Allied armies had over the Germans as a result of breaking enemy codes, according to topsecret documents declassified today.

title: Late Rally Helps Dow Close Up 1.65, to 840.87
description: The stock market staged a finalhour rally yesterday that left prices showing little change for the session. Earlier, stocks were under some pressure, partly reflecting political turmoil in Iran, the world's secondlargest exnorter of oil after Saudi Arabia.

title: Around the Nation
description: WARRENTON, Va., Feb. Feb. 1 (AP)  A mechanized group of angry farmers bivouaced here today, awaiting the arrival of a 26milelong convoy of tractors so the two groups could join in a protest drive on Washington.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Broadway
description: WINGS has opened, had laudatory reviews and shown that, yes, it may be possible to get a serious play done on Broadway. Moreover, while the season was threatening to become a big black hole, bereft of much that would grip you, there now seem to be all kinds of interesting thine to come. Of all the interesting things, however. the most interesting may be this: Al Pacino will do Richard III, and it will open on Broadway on May 1. The winter of our discontent, therefore, may be over.

title: Anita Ellis Tells Why She's Singing
description: ANITA ELLIS, the slim, darkhaired singer who began performing 40 years ago (she was In the film version of Babes in Arms, with Judy Garland and Mickey Rooney, when she was 18) and who has won an intensely devoted following although she has rarely appeared in public, will give her first fulllength concert Sunday evening at Alice Tully Hall at 8 P.M.

title: Teng Takes Quest for U.S. Technology to Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 1  Teng Hsiaoping, China's senior Deputy Prime Minister, carried his quest for American technology and a common front against the Soviet Union to the South today, receiving an enthusiastic welcome that drowned out a few scattered protests.

title: Music: Vermeer Quartet
description: THE Vermeer Quartet, one of the better ensembles in the business, appeared at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday night, playing Mozart's Quartet in D (K. 575), Bartok's Quartet No. 6 and Schumann's Quartet in A minor (Op. 41 No. 11.

title: WASHINGTON Henry Kissinger's Revenge
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  The Economist of London, which is not a frivolous publication, is now printing Henry Kissinger's extensive and mystifying views on the wisdom  or otherwiseof signing and ratifying a second strategic arms agreement with the Soviet Union.

title: Once Upon a Sunday, in a Children's Bookstore . . .
description: Robert Welber, who writes children's books, is going to spend part of his Sunday morning at a bookstore in Manhattan that sells children's books exclusively. And that can be only one place.

title: Carter, Ford Will Attend Rockefeller Rites Today
description: On the eve of an invitationonly memorial service for Nelson A. Rockefeller in New York City today, members of the House of Representatives in Washington joined in a tribute to him yesterday.

title: Papal Journey: New Guideline
description: As Pope John Paul II returned to Rome yesterday after a grueling, boisterous week in Mexico, many concerned with church affairs were still wondering what the flurry of words he had delivered would mean for the future of the church

title: Net Up 3Fold At Scott Paper
description: The Scott Paper Company reported that profits in the fourth quarter soared threefold to $32.6 million, or 84 cents a share, from $7.8 million, or 20 cents a share, in the same quarter a year earlier. The 1977 quarter earnings had been adversely affected by mill closings, the company said.

title: Pupofon, With Puppets, At La MaMa Next Week
description: Pupofon, a production from Vienna that combines puppetry with live actors, will begin a limited run at La MaMa Experimental Theater, 74A East Fourth Street, next Wednesday.

title: Royal Shakespeareans May Come to New York
description: STRATFORDUPONAVON, England (UPI)  The Royal Shakespeare Company, announcing plans for 29 new productions, a European tour and a third theater at StratfordUponAvon. has also said it may go to New York, where it has been invited for a season in early 1980.

title: Auctions
description: AS optimistic as Sotheby Parke Bernet executives were over the advance interest in the sale last Saturday of the late Stewart E. Gregory's folkart collection, not one of them was prepared for the mob scene that developed. Folkart buffs began queuing up at 8 A.M., and by the time the galleries on Madison Avenue and 76th Street had opened, shortly before 10 A.M., the lobby was wall to wall with people. For the first time in the 41year history of Sotheby's, a morning session became a standingroomonly event. It was as big a crowd, in fact, as at the more significant afternoon session. Throughout the day, folkart records were toppled, and when John L. Marion's gaveling had ceased after 5 P.M., 17 records had been rewritten, and the sale's total had skyrocketed to $1.3 million, 70 percent above the presale high estimate of $800,000. It was the highest total ever brought for a singleowner sale of Americana and for American folk art. Mary Allis, the 79yearold doyenne of folkart dealers, who was one of the major dealers to help form the collection, was the top buyer, paying $102,485 for 13 lots.

title: Brazilian Flood Toll Is Rising
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 1 (Reuters)The death toll from floods in the east-central state of Minas Gerais has risen to 53 and more than 10,000 people are homeless, state officials said toddy. Some 30 towns have been isolated by the flooding, brought on by a month of steady rains, they said.

title: MOVE TO END STRIKE AT SHIPYARD FAILS
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Feb. 1  Virginia's young lieutenant Governor, Charles S. Robb, a soninlaw of President Johnson and the only Democrat now in top state office, tried and failed today to organize behindthescenes discussions that union officials here said could have ended the twodayold strike by the United Steelworkers of America against the Newport News Shipyard and Drydock Company.

title: Sunrise and Other Data Were Listed Incorrectly
description: Because of a clerical error, the rising and setting times of the sun, tie moon and the planets were reported incorrectly in The New York Times last Saturday, Sunday and Monday. The times given were from a table for December instead of January.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELFAST. Northern Ireland, Feb. 1 (Reuters)  Two soldiers of the British Army's undercover Special Air Service will be charged with murdering a youth who walked into an army stakeout, the police said today.MADRID, Feb. 1 (Reuters)  Spain introduced tough new regulations today to discourage sympathizers from cooperating with urban guerrilla organizations.

title: Joyful Miss Hearst Leaves Prison Five Years After Being Kidnapped
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1  Almost exactly five years after she was kidnapped from her apartment in Berkeley, Patricia Campbell Hearst was released from a Federal prison near here today under an executive clemency order from President Carter.

title: From Kidnappers to ExFianc: Some Figures in the Hearst Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb.1 (AP) The tiny organization of terrorists who kidnapped Patricia Hearst ceased to exist long before the heiress's sentence was commuted by President Carter.

title: Army Seals 2 Jerusalem Houses
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 1  Two houses in Jerusalem were sealed by Israeli security forces early today, an army spokesman said. He said they had been used to harbor terrorists.

title: Poll Finds Public Looks on Peking More Favorably Than on Moscow
description: The American people now view China far more favorably than they do the Soviet Union, even though they strongly support a new strategic arms treaty with Moscow and are critical of the recognition of China by the United States at the expense of Taiwan, according to the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Bribery Charge Against Rep. Flood Is Taken Up by Federal Court Jury
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  A Federal court jury began deliberating this afternoon the bribery, conspiracy and perjury charges against Repredentative Daniel J. Flood of Pennsylvania.

title: ChinaJapan Import Finance Accord Nears
description: TOKYO, Feb. 1  After months of haggling over details, Japan and China appear much closer to concluding a major, longterm deal on Japanese fi- nancing for Chinese imports, according to banking sources here.

title: Seaboard Air Buys 747
description: Seaboard World Airlines, a leading cargo carrier, said yesterday that it would exercise its previously announced option to buy a new 747 cargo freighter from the Boeing Company for about $59 million for delivery in August 1980. The company said the purchase brought to six the number of 747's in operation or on order.

title: Pistons Send Cays To 3d Straight Loss
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Feb. 1 (AP)Bob Lanier and M.L. Carr each poured in 29 points to pace the Detroit Pistons to a 120116 National Basketball Association victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight.

title: Director of Census Facing Ouster
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  The Carter Administration is seeking to replace the ,director of the Bureau of the Census, Manuel D. Plotkin, amid growing concern about the 1980 census, according to wellplaced Government officials.

title: Ballet: Vienna Waltzes
description: NO one would call Romanticism the hallmark of the New York City Ballet. Yet from time to time the company does sound this note in its own special way, as it did Wednesday night at the State Theater with two different ballets.

title: The Umbrellas of Cherbourg and Seduced Open on Stage
description: IN his last years Howard R. Hughes was such an insubstantial figure, flown from hotel room to hotel room and surrounded by nurses and guards, that one enterprising writer thought he could get away with manufacturing a biography based on nhonv Hushes interviews.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: JAFFEHenry, L., M.D., Died at the age of 82, on January 12. 1979. Dr. Jaffe was born in New York City in 1896. He graduated from New York Medical School In 1920. and was aoPointed assistant pathologist at Monteficre Hospital two years later after serving internship at Monteflare Hospital and Bellevue Hospital. He came to The Hospital For Joint Diseases as Pathologist and Director of Laboratories in 1928. and worked there In this capacity until his retirement in 1966. He established and developed a Department of Laboratories which provided outstanding diagnostic services, in the field of bone & joint diseases, not only to the hospital itself, but to an ever widening circle of orthopedic surgeons; pathologists. and radiologists throughout the world. Personally, and with a number of colleagues. including Dr. John Blair. Dr. Aaron Bodansky, Dr. Sheldon Jacobson. Dr. Arthur Ginzler, Dr. Louis Lichtenstein, Dr. Golden Selin. Dr. Howard Dorfman, and Dr. German Steiner, he carried out fundamnental research into the pathology of many skeletal diseases, particularly bone tumors, where the present day nomenclature of the subject is a telling memorial to his efforts. His text books on Tumors and Tumorous Conditions of the Bone & Joints and Metabolic Degeneratives and Inflammatory Diseases of Bones & Joints are classics. Dr. Jaffe's work has helped to make the Hospital For Joint Diseases an outstanding center for teaching and research in the field of musculosskeletal disease, and the hospital takes this opportunity to pay tribute to a great man, whose memory will remain with us always, and whose example will encourage us in our present tasks.

title: REFORMS PROMISED FOR JOB PROGRAMS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  The Carter Administration, conceding severe problems of mismanagement and inefficiency in its public job and training programs, announced today what it described as a broad program of reforms aimed at ending abuses and providing jobs to those who need them most.

title: The Indispensable Mr. Chi
description: Chi Chaochu is hardly a household word in America. Yet Mr. Chi has been an indispensable man. If Teng Hsiaoping had not brought the former Harvard man from the Chinese Foreign Ministry as his interpreter, his discourse with President Carter might have gone uncomprehended. The United States Government, it turns out, does not employ anyone fully qualified as a simultaneous interpreter from English to Chinese.

title: Money Supply Off $3.1 Billion
description: The basic money supply declined by $3.1 billion in the week ended Jan. 24, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This was a sharper drop than most money market analysts had expected. Most had predicted a shift somewhere between a decline of $2 billion and a rise of $1 billion.

title: TV Weekend A Comic, a Spinoff And British Drama
description: DIARY of a Young Comic, tomorrow's replacement on NBC for Saturday Night Live at 11:30, is a struggling film about a struggling young comedian. Perhaps in a clever attempt to reflect its subject, it is childish, pointless, wildly uneven and, not infrequently, devastatingly funny.

title: Morgan Rarely Far From Big Golf Money
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Feb. 1 The title Dr. rides in front of Gil Morgan's name on the scoreboards of many events on the PGA Tour, but he would be perfectly happy to see it disappear.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, FEB 1. 1979

title: Market Place
description: WITH so many shares of McGrawHill in the hands of arbitragers and dissatisfied shareholders following the publishing company's decision to turn down a takeover bid by American Express, a proxy fight appears to be a distinct possibility, according to security industry sources.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Deaths
description: PORTAROSalvatore, 85, on February 1, 1979 of Jamaica Estates, N.Y. Beloved husband of the late Ida (nee Rizzo). Loving father of Cara P. Campanella, Violet and Aurelia Portaro. Reposing at Fox Funeral Home. Ascan Ave.corner Metropolitan Ave., Forest Hills. N.Y. Mass of Christian Burial at Immaculate Conception RC Church. Edgerton Blvd., Jamaica Estates, N.Y. Monday. February 5,1979 at 9:30AM. Interment Mt. St. Mane's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions to UNICEF.

title: Books: Upper Classless
description: THERE have been so many accounts, so many commentaries, so many recollections by and about those who were processed by Soviet justice that it is reasonable to question whether yet another one is necessary, whether it can shed new light on an old situation.

title: Scientist Finds That Solar Wind Acts as Giant Atom Accelerator
description: The solar wind, hot gas that constantly blows outward from the Sun at speeds sometimes exceeding a million miles an hour, is a prodigious accelerator of atoms, according to a physicist who has studied data from the Pioneer 10 and 11 spacecraft as they fly into the outer part of the solar system.

title: Algeria's Next President
description: ALGIERS, Feb. 1 A whitehaired colonel who had remained outside Algeria's political infighting was called to Algiers from his post in Oran last November to serve as acting Defense Minister as his friend, President Hou

title: Sports News Briefs
description: RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 1 (AP) Secondseeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina and thirdseeded Brian Gottfried posted secondround victories today in the Richmond Tennis Classic.

title: The Night Ray Conger Beat Nurmi
description: Paavo Nurmi was a fairly bony young man with a receding hairline, high cheekbones, no expression, a slow heart beat and fast feet. If he wasn't the greatest footracer that ever lived, he was the only one who grew up racing a mail train that ran through his home town of Turku, Finland. Like the United States postal service, the train was distinguished for stamina rather than speed. On the track, Nurmi wore a pale blue jersey with short, floppy sleeves. It had the Finnish flag on the bosom. He carried a stopwatch and occasionally glanced at his cupped right hand as he ran. He may have been clocking himself, Westbrook Pegler wrote, or merely studying his nails like an orator pausing for applause.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: It still feels like the Nutcracker season outside, but this weekend the Eglevsky Ballet on Long Island is opening what it solemnly calls its spring season. Performances tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at and 5 P.M. in the John Cranford Adams Playhouse at Hofstra University in Hempstead. The program will feature the premiere of Pastorale by Michael Vernon, a company ballet master, who staged its recent Nutcracker production. Pastorale, set to French folk songs, is an abstract work described as evoking the feelings of the French countryside. Also on the program are George Balanchine's Pas de Dix and William Dollar's Combat. Tickets are $5. $7 and $8.50. Reservations and information: (516) 7988296. From New York City, take the Long Island Expressway to the Meadowbrook Parkway; go south to Exit M5 west, and follow the Hempstead Turnpike a mile to the playhouse.

title: High Jump Mark Tied
description: BUDAPEST, Feb. 1 (AP)  Hungary's Andrea Matay, 24, today equaled the women's world indoor high jump record of 6 feet 4 inches at an international track and field meet. The mark was set by Rosemarie Ackermann of East Germany in 1977 and equaled by Italy's Sara Simeoni in 1978.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday

title: Brooke Testifies Before Ethics Unit
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. I (AP)  Former Senator Edward W. Brooke of Massachusetts was called before the Senate ethics committee today amid reports that the panel's staff had concluded that he acted improperly in divorce proceedings last year.

title: Business and the Law
description: IT used to be that corporate lawyers were a fairly stationary group. A New York lawyer might only get as far south as Washington. But with the redistribution of personal and corporate wealth across the country, lawyers have gone where the money is  so much so that three United State Supreme Court Justices observed last month that interstate law practice and multistate law firms are now commonplace.

title: CELIA FORMAN DIES; STAGE ACTRESS, 89
description: Celia Adler Forman, an actress who was known as the first lady of the Yid- dish theater in her heyday, died Wednesday after suffering a stroke at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale, the Bronx. She was 89 years old and since 1975 had lived at the Andrew Freedman Home in the Bronx, a residence for the elderly, until her health required nursing care.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Jeffrey Siegel at the Y
description: The pianist Jeffrey Siegel will perform tomorrow at 8 P.M. in the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A., at Lexington Avenue. The program will feature Mozart's Sonata in F major, Brahms's Sonata in F minor and works by Debussy and Rachmaninoff. Mr. Siegel played last May with the New York Philharmonic. Tickets are $5, $6 and $7.50; students and the elderly can obtain tickets at halfprice (but no lower than $3). Information: 4276000.

title: Cabaret at Judson
description: Semina DeLaurentis, a singercome dian, will appear today and tomnrrov, at 8 P.M. at the Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square South. Miss DeLaurentis has performed at the Ballroom. Tickets to the performance. the first of this year's cabaret series. are S3 (Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted). Reservations: 777 0033.

title: Opposition to Freeing Of Miss Hearst Voiced
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. I (UPI)  Public reaction to Patricia Hearst's release has switched from favoring it to opposing it, according to communications received at the White House, the press secretary, Jody Powell, said today.

title: Overpayments on Sugar Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)  The Agriculture Department's farm-program agency improperly approved at least S29 million in sugarsupport payments to ineligible processors in late 1977, the department's inspector general has found.Congressional auditors are following up on the preliminary report by the inspector general, Thomas McBride. The report, dated Oct. 25, 1978, was disclosed late yesterday by Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota.

title: Hanoi Charges Chinese Raids
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 1  In a series of official protests and published articles, Vietnam accused China today of massing troops and heavy artillery along its northern border and staging raids causing many casualties.

title: Deaths
description: FRUCHTERBeniamin, loving husband of Edith, loving father of Hervey and Bonnie Fraser. Barry, Caryl and William Levy. Dear brother of Lillian Price and Sylvia Godsberg. Cherished grandfather of Robin. Larry, Benii, Emily and Eric. Service Friday 12:30 at The West. chester Riverside 21 W. Broad St.. Mt. Vernon N.Y.

title: Cabaret: Michael Brown
description: MICHAEL BROWN, dressed all in white (white suit, white shoes, white tie. white belt) and looking like a debonaire, cleanshaven Mark Twain, is singing songs about New York past and present at the Ballroom this week and next. They are all his own songs and, en masse, they reveal in him a fondness for the waltz, a warm nostalgia for New York past, a dim view of New York present, a fascination with murder and the presumption of murder, and an ability to wriggle out of such strict commitments as doing program entirely devoted to songs about New York.

title: Economic Scene
description: THE world had a fright last fall when the dollar, the currency that holds the world monetary system together, suffered a severe sinking spell. This provoked the dramatic Nov. 1 rescue operation, with the Federal Reserve jacking up interest rates and the United States joining with other major countries to support the dollar in foreign exchange markets.

title: Tickner Takes Lead In Figure Skating
