description: CINCINNATI, Feb. I (AP)  Charlie Tickner, the world champion, piled up a huge lead today in the men's compulsory competition at the United States figure skating championships.

title: Former State Dept. Official Favored to Head A.I.D.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  President Carter is expected to nominate Thomas Ehrlich, a Washington lawyer and former State Department official, to be Administrator of the Agency for International Development, Government officials said today.

title: Mortimer Marshall; Acted on the Stage, In Films and on TV
description: Mortimer Marshall, an actor on the Broadway stage who also appeared on television and in motion pictures, died yesterday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 60 years old and lived at 363 East 76th Street.

title: Vietnam's Quagmire
description: The leaders of Vietnam are learning that counterinsurgency is a trickier military art than the insurgency at which they once excelled. Wellequipped with armor and close air support, an estimated 100,000 Vietnamese troops quickly overran Cambodia, brushed aside the smaller, poorly armed forces of the Government of Prime Minister Pol Pot and installed a Cambodian regime of Hanoi's choosing. Nearly a month later, however, Vietnam is still meeting stubborn and widespread resistance. Fighting against guerrillas soaks up manpower like sand soaks up water. Large in one sense, the Vietnamese expeditionary force is very small if it must long police and garrison so large a territory.

title: Legal Storm Over Discounting
description: Consumers who shop for name brands at reduced prices in discount stores may soon find some brands of appliances, cosmetics and other items unavailable at discount, in the wake of a littlepublicized United States Supreme Court decision of 1977.

title: Investing With Assurance
description: More than 10 million Americans regularly invest in Series E savings bonds, a safe, convenient and assured method of accumulating money, particularly for those able to save only a small amount at at a time. The total value of outstanding bonds is now over $80 billion.

title: Trifecta Pays Off $88,761 for $2 Bet
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 1  The largest trifecta pay- off in harnessracing history $88.761 for $2  was posted in the fourth race at the Meadowlands tonight.

title: Death of Crewman. Mars Florida Race
description: Kialoa, Jim Kilroy's 79foot ketch from Los Angeles, was the first yacht yesterday to complete the 370mile St. Petersburg-to-Fort Lauderdale ocean race, which was marred by a tragedy. Tom Curtis, a crew member aboard Obsession, was killed on Wednesday when he presumably was struck in the head by the yacht's boom.

title: Beatty Demands Recall of Mayor On Poverty Plan
description: Enraged by Mayor Koch's plan to reorganize the city's antipoverty program, the chairman of the state's Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus yesterday asked for the Mayor's recall.

title: CALLAGHAN DEPICTS STRIKERS AS VANDALS
description: LONDON, Feb. 1 (AP)  Prime Minister James Callaghan said today that wildcat strikes by public service workers amounted to free collective vandalism, and insisted that unions curb their pay demands.

title: Islanders Turn Back Flyers, 41, Scoring 3 Goals in Final Period
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1  The Philadelphia Flyers trotted out their new coach, Pat Quinn, at the Spectrum tonight. But that didn't help much, as the Islanders scored three goals in the last period and posted a 41 victory that extended the Flyers nonwinning streak to nine games.

title: Doubts Emerge on Tape Of Shah Talk to Military
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  Doubts arose today about the authenticity of a tape said to contain final remarks by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi to top military leaders before he left the country last month.

title: Art People
description: RUMORS that it had been canceled to the contrary, the show wilt go on  a huge Picasso show that will fill the entire Museum of Modern Art, that is. Once slated for a November opening, the show, a large piece of the Modern's 50th birthday celebration, has been postponed for two or three months because of scheduling conflicts on the part of lenders abroad.

title: Markets
description: The nation's money supply declined $3.1 billion in the latest reporting week, the Federal Reserve reported. The decline was sharper than anticipated in the money markets and reflected the sustained impact of the Fed's credit policies. The basic supply, known as M1. continued to decline at an annual rate of 2 percent, the Fed indicated. [Page D1.]consumer spending remained strong in the first month of 1979. But Sears, Roebuck reported a drop of 2.8 percent in the fourth consecutive month of falling volume for the nation's largest retailer. [D1.]

title: Furlow, Lee Call Trade Good Deal
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 1 (AP)  Terry Furlow said today he was happy to be leaving the Cleveland Cavaliers in a National Basketball Association trade with the Atlanta Hawks that sent Butch Lee, a rookie, to Cleveland yesterday.

title: Corporate Earnings Are Reported for the Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) Ind!. cafes stock is listed on the New York Stock Eechange.(A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) over-thecounter.

title: Women and Smoking  Newest Research Shows the Health Tons Mounting
description: I never realized that by smoking I was killing myself  not until I got lung cancer, said Jeanne Owens, a New York City artist who lost part of a lung two years ago and the rest of it last Jung when the cancer recurred.

title: Some Comments by the Pope During His Journey to Latin America
description: MEXICO CITY. Feb. 1  Following, in translation, are excerpts from a number of speeches made by Pope John Paul II during his Latin American trip of the past week.

title: Hagler Awaits A Title Shot
description: Dawn on Cape Cod: A pantherlike figure wearing Army boots runs along the sand dunes by the beach, the early rays of the sun gleaming off his shaved black head. Periodically, the man some people think is the finest middleweight in the world and the finest American fighter of any weight punches the salt air in the manner of all boxers doing road work.

title: On Khomeini's Flight: The Morning Prayers On Newspaper Mats
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 1  As the jumbo jet bearing Iran's exiled Islamic leader home from France approached Teheran early today, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and his followers knelt for prayers in the firstclass upstairs lounge.

title: Mexico Said to Be Ready To Join GATT Compact
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  After decades of isolationist trade policies, Mexico has signaled its intention to accept the rights and obligations of the international trading system by acceding to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, United States officials say.

title: Miss Rysanek, Exhausted, Cancels Four Toscas
description: Lennie Rysanek has canceled her four forthcoming performances in the title role of Tosca at the Metropolitan Opera. The soprano said she was suffering from exhaustion.

title: Brown Steps Down As Coach of Nuggets
description: DENVER, Feb. 1 (AP)  Larry Brown relinquished his duties as coach of the Denver Nuggets tonight, citing health reasons. His assistant, Donnie Walsh, was named interim coach for the remainder of the season.

title: Arkansas Conquers Texas Five by 6858
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 1 (AP)  Sidney Moncrief scored 23 points and Arkansas's tight defense shut down Texas sizzling offense tonight for a 6858 Southwest Conference baskeball victory.

title: Colleen Dewhurst Takes Brookes Role
description: Jacqueline Brookes, the actress, has quit the cast of Thomas Babe's play Taken in Marriage and Colleen Dewhurst has replaced her in the fivewoman cast of the comic drama. As a result, the start of previews was postponed from today to Feb. 19 at the Public/Newman Theater of the New York Shakespeare Festival.

title: Seoul Tries Hot Line to North and Gets No Answer
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 1  The South Korean Government tried to telephone North Korea today to discuss the possible reopening of political talks, but no one answered.

title: U.S.China Communiqu Contains Softened Criticism of Soviet Union
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  The United States and China issued a joint press communiqu today containing indirect criticism of the Soviet Union that had been softened at Washington's insistence.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets, buoyed by the small amount of Treasury financing expected early this year, advanced yesterday morning and early afternoon. Then the Federal Reserve disclosed a surprisingly large decline in the money supply, and fixedincome prices climbed still higher.

title: Music: Inspired by Keats
description: MOST composers nowadays do not believe, as Liszt and Strauss did, that musical notes are capable of conveying literary impressions directly to the listener. In practice, at least, they avoid linking musical and extramusical ideas except when forced to do so by the need to compose a song or an opera. Science is in the saddle.

title: Restaurants
description: FIFTYEIGHTH Street between Second and Third Avenues is one of the city's bestknown restaurant blocks, and one of the most felicitous additions, Bruno's, an Italian restaurant that opened threeandahalf months ago, will be welcome there.

title: Sonics Rally to Defeat Nets
description: The Seattle SuperSonics, trailing, 10299, scored the game's final 8 points last night to defeat the Nets, 107102. The Nets Eric Money scored a careerhigh 40 points. Story on page A18.

title: Merger of Citizens SavingsLoan Into Astoria Federal Is Ordered
description: State and Federal authorities quietly forced the troubled Citizens Savings and Loan Association in Queens to be merged into the Astoria Federal Savings and Loan Association after the close of business Wednesday.

title: Wage Plan: Labor More Amenable
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  Kenneth Young, the chief lobbyist for the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, told Congress today that although the federation disliked the Administration's proposal for real wage insurance, it would, nevertheless, work with Congress to improve the bill.

title: U.S. Aid Contradicts Tulsa's Image of Independence
description: TULSA, Okla., Jan. 25  When James M. Inhofe, a young Republican, was inaugurated as Mayor last year, he expressed concern because Tulsa was receiving $21 million a year in Federal aid, a dependence on Washington that runs counter to the city's image of itself as a center of free enterprise and independence.

title: Notes on People
description: The first American woman ever to be ordained a rabbi, Sally J. Priesand, has resigned as associate rabbi of the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, at 30 West 68th Street.

title: On Holding Poor People Harmless
description: We've been thinking about the criticism of President Carter's new budget for devoting too little to domestic needs, especially to people and cities in distress. On reflection, it seems hasty, even unfair. There are other things to be disappointed about.

title: Democrats Give Papp $125aTicket Dinner In Honor of His Work
description: Manhattan Democrats gathered last night to salute a theatrical producer with no direct ties to their party.

title: Art: A Sculptor In Grand Tradition
description: THE English sculptor Elisabeth Frink has not had a solo exhibition in New York since 1961, and so there are now a great many people hereabouts for whom hers will be a new name. It is a name that should be wellknown to aficionados of contemporary sculpture, and the new show of Miss Frink's work that has now come to the Terry Dintenfass Gallery, 50 West 57th Street (through March 9), gives us an admirable opportunity to see what this remarkable artist has achieved.

title: Business Records
description: BANK RUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Court Lets Sambo's Operate in Toledo
description: Sambo's Restaurants Inc. said it had won its fifth consecutive court case when United States District Judge Don J. Young in Toledo. Ohio, issued a permanent injunction barring the city of Toledo forever from denying the chain the right to use its trade name.

title: Curbing Lead Poisoning by Drivers
description: IRVINE, Calif.  United States drivers are destroying $7 billion worth of effective functional antipollution equipment  the exhaust catalytic converters on their cars  because of perverse economic incentives created by the. current high price of unleaded gasoline.

title: White Plains: Boom Town in Troubled Suburbs
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb 1  A huge mound of dirt roughly three stories high dominates this city's downtown area. It looks like a major archeological dig, but, in fact, White Plains has struck gold. It has become a boom town.

title: Rabbis Urge Plan to Aid ParochialSchool Pupils
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1  Delegates to the Rabbinical Assembly's convention in Los Angeles today endorsed a bill in Congress that provides tax benefits for the parents of children attending parochial schools. The 400 delegates, including 75 from the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut metropolitan areas, represented 1,100 rabbis from the Conservativebranch of Judaism.

title: Albany Credits For Businesses
description: ALBANY. Feb. 1  New York State will grant jobincentive taxcredits totaling more than $10.5 million to Philip Morris Inc.. the American International Group and Life Savers Inc. for expanding their office space in New York City, Governor Carey announced today.

title: Governor Grasso Told She Must Live With U.S. Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  Gov. Ella T. Grasso of Connecticut called on the state's Congressional delegation today to help restore President Carter's budget cutbacks, but she was told that the new reality in Washington meant the state would have to live with at least some of the cuts.

title: KHOMEINI THREATENS TO ARREST BAKHTIAR IF HE STAYS IN POST
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 1  On his first day back in his native land after almost 15 years, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini warned that his Moslem nationalist movement would arrest Prime Minister Shahpur Bakhtiar if he refused to resign.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Cattle futures traders on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange talked yesterday about an overbought market and cited growing consumer resistance to high meat prices. As a result, profit taking lowered the final quotations somewhat below those of the previous day when the market registered sharply higher prices.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a clerical error, times given in The Times last Saturday, Sunday and Monday for the rising and setting of the sun, the moon and the planets were incorrect. The correct times will he found on page A12.

title: Publishing: When a Small Press Becomes Popular
description: WILL success spoil Northland Press? That's not a question that troubles the buyers of Northland's handsomely printed books. It's a question that troubles the press itself.

title: For Children
description: CHILDREN'S MUSICAL THEATER, will Present Brooklyn Baseball Cantata and The Turtle Drum, under the direction of Mimi Stern-Wolfe, on Saturday at 7:30 P.M., and on Sunday at 2:30 P.M., at the Third Street Music School Settlement, 23S East 11th Street. Admission: children. 75 Cents: adults. S1.50. Ca II 7773240.

title: Bridge:
description: For bridge organizers, success can sometimes mean disaster. If, for example, a thousand players show up for a tournament and there are only tables, chairs, boards and directors for half that number, chaos results. Thanks to good planning, this practically never happens.

title: Mississippi's Black Mayors Intensify Efforts to Influence Elections
description: FAYETTE, Miss., Jan. 29  We blacks and poor whites will have to have some input in the decisionmaking in this state, said Robert Gray, the Mayor of Shelby, Miss. There are many districts we can win and many more in which we can decide who does win and who loses.

title: The Pop Life
description: IF you happen to be in the market for a good, oldfashioned gutbucket rock-and-roll record, there's one around. Furthermore, all by itself, it manages to unite at least four different strands of 1970's rock. But it doesn't look as if any American company is going to bother distributing it here, so you'll have to seek it out at an import store and pay premium prices.

title: Stage: Umbrellas Opens Beguilingly
description: HE innovative Rumanian director Andrei Serban is a master of disguises, but with The Umbrellas of Cherbourg, which opened last night in the Public Theater Cabaret, he may have performed his most magical trick. He has transformed the sweetly sentimental Michel LegrandJacques Demy movie into a captivating stage musical.

title: Wife of councilman Who Helped Defeat Steingut Scores Own Upset
description: The wife of Theodore Silveiman, the New York City Councilman who played a key role in engineering the upset defeat of Stanley Steingut, the former Speaker of the Assembly, put together an alliance of her own to win election this week as executive director of a coalition of community boards.

title: Joy Explodes in Teheran Streets As Millions Welcome Ayatollah
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 1  A young woman leaned against the wall and wept. I can't explain, she said as a haunting, piercing voice, singing verses of the Koran in praise of those who have died in holy wars, stilled the vaulted airport arrival lounge.

title: Ski Conditions
description: Figures in parentheses show total trails and number open at each area. Skiarea forecasts appear on the weather page. For information: New York, (212) 75.58100; New Jersey, (609) 2928456 Thursdays and Fridays from 2 to 4 P.M.; Pennsylvania, (717) 4215791; New Hampshire, (603)2242525; Vermont, (802) 2290531, and Massachusetts, (800) 6285030.

title: WHITE PLAINS AT A GLANCE
description: Ten square miles in the center of southern Westchester County, bounded roughly by the Hutchinson and Bronx River Parkways and the Cross Westchester Expressway. It is 25 miles from Times Square and served largely as a bedroom community for Manhattan until the past decade, when it became a hub of corporate and retail growth.

title: Sid Vicious Released From Jail
description: John Ritchie, the 21yearold punkrock musician known as Sid Vicious, was released from jail in New York City yesterday after serving a twomonth sentence for his part in a nightclub brawl. He still faces a charge'of murdering a friend, Nancy Spungen, 20 years old, in a Manhattan hotel last October. He was free on $50,000 bail at the time of the nightclub offense.

title: As Grace Paley Faces Jail With 3 Other Writers
description: In a number of wellrun countries it is the custom to put writers in jail whenever the writers say something the government does not wish to hear, or to have heard by the citizens.

title: Daths
description: MONROEKathryn (nee Lyons) of Rutherford. N.J. on Jan. 31, 1979, beloved wile of Thomas N., mother of Julia Sibbald, Kathryn Pieczonka, Mary Michael Keller. Thomas Patrick, Monica and Christopher Monroe. and sister of Marie Kiltilea. Memorial Mass at St Mary's R.C. Church, Rutherford. N.J., Sat, Feb 3. at 11AM. Memorial donations may be made to the Kathryn Lyons Monroe Student Loan Fund, c/o The Rutherford Rotary Club, 192 Woodward Ave. Rutherford.

title: Books of The Times
description: MEET William Dubin, the 56yearold protagonist of Bernard Malamud's wonderfully bittercomic new novel, Dubin's Lives. Meet William Dubin, if he can spare you a moment from his disciplines. For Dubin works.

title: Classic Saint Laurent: At the Top of His Form
description: PARIS, Feb. 1 Yves Saint Laurent cleared away all the trash today  the sweetheart necklines that plunged too low, the slits on skirts that gaped too high, the silly drapes and ruffles that other designers consider quintessential to the 1940's look. He turned up his nose at the trendy things going on at the couture shows here and presented a collection that was classic- in the best sense: The clothes are simple, flattering and enduring.

title: Retail Sales Up Sharply In January
description: Sixteen of the nation's largest retail chains reported yesterday that sales had advanced strongly in January, with almost all running to doubledigit gains over the corresponding month a year earlier.

title: At the Movies
description: FOR all the Singapore Government knew, the band of mummers led by Peter Bogdanovich and Ben Gazzara that arrived there several months ago was making an innocuous adventure romance called King of Hearts. But what they were really doing was filming St. Jack, an adaptation of an early novel by Paul Theroux. The reason for this not very elaborate subterfuge was the lack enthusiasm that the government, which is puritanical by the standards of the Massachusetts Bay Colony, let alone by those of southeast Asia, was known have for Mr. Theroux's portrayal of the prosperous citystate as a hotbed of amiable vice.

title: New 911 Trainees Aid the PanicStricken in Simulated Emergencies
description: Three weeks ago, Frances D'Amato, a 44yearold mother of four, was operating the cash register in a kosher meat market in Brooklyn. Yesterday she was in Police Headquarters, listening to the agitated voice of a man telephoning for help because his child had just been struck by a car and lay bleeding at 23d Street and Third Avenue.

title: 2d Token Clerk Dies From Bums In Subway Blaze
description: The second of two Transit Authority clerks trapped inside an IND subway token booth in Queens when it was deliberately set aflame two weeks ago died early yesterday of extensive burns.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: ACF Industries Inc., engaged in the manufacture and leasing of railroad cars and the manufacture of automotive equipment, has elected Herbert A. Borst treasurer.

title: B. G. Muzrukov, Maker Of the Soviet T34 Tank
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 1 (UPI)  Boris G. Muzrukov, the designer of the Soviet Union's T34 tank used in World War II, died yesterday after a long illness, the Soviet press agency Tass said today.

title: About Real Estate Construction Revival: Coop Apartments
description: A cooperative apartment building with a singular design and an allglass facade is about to start going up on East 50th Street. It is an example of the revival of new construction in the cooperative form in an improved market.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: DETROIT, Feb. 1 (AP)  The General Motors Corporation's long court battle to prove that the Toyota Motor Company stole the design of an antipollution device was rebuffed today by a Federal court judge.

title: New race: Laurie Kennedy
description: She is as impenitent and selfpossessed a young lady as one would desire to see among the best behaved of her sex. Her small head and tiny resolute chin, her haughty crispness and trimness of carriage, mark a personality which is as formidable as it is exquisitely pretty. Her voice might be the voice of a schoolmistress addressing a class of girls who had disgraced themselves as she proceeds with composure and some disgust to say what she has come to say.

title: Text of Joint Press Communiqu on Visit by Teng
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  Following is the text of a joint press communiqu issued today by the White House at the close of the visit to Washington by Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping of China.

title: Miss Lopez Ousted in Match Play
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. I  A 15foot downhill putt by Sylvia Bertolaccini on the second extra hole knocked Nancy Lopez out of the Triple Crown Ladies Professional Golf Association matchplay championship today when it seemed as if the world's No. I women's player had the match in her pocket.

title: G.M. Will Offer Repairs Insurance
description: DETROIT, Feb. 1 (AP)  The General Motors Corporation said today that it, too, would offer auto buyers an insurance policy against the cost of mechanical repairs beyond the normal warranty.

title: Deaths
description: BARNHARDMilt. Beloved friend, loyal companionnever to be forgotten.

title: Plucking the Strings of Japanese Music
description: Kneeling on the straw mat of a rehearsal room, Fusako Yoshida joined two American colleagues in an exotic chamber work  part of a program of traditional Japanese music that they will perform tomorrow night at 8 at the Alternative Center for International Arts. 28 East Fourth Street. Her deft fingers plucking, pressing and pulling the strings of a koto  a sixfoot long zither  Mrs. Yoshida sang of a lifetime spent awaiting a lover who never returned.

title: Pony's Illness Poses Unanticipated Problems
description: POUND RIDGE, N.Y., Jan. 31 When the family of John Schuermann purchased a pony last year for their daughter, Betsy, they never thought about what they would do if the animal died.

title: City Opens a Full Drive on Dog. Litter
description: Yesterday was a great day for Officer Anthony D'Onofrio of the New York City sanitation police, a relentless enemy of dogs that defile the streets. The city stopped issuing warnings and began handing out summonses to dogwalkers who failed to clean up after their pets  a no-more-Mr.-Nice-Guy stance that Officer D'Onofrio has favored all along.

title: Producer's Trial On 248 Counts Of Fraud Opens
description: Just four years ago, Adela Holzer was the toast of Broadway  the hottest producer  with three plays in production and a stillgleaming reputation from the $2 million profit she said she had earned from a $50,000 investment in an unlikely musical called Hair.

title: On Csonka's Fate, Maras Agree
description: Wellington and Tim Mara, who agreed on dropping Larry Csonka, are now nearing agreement on the successor to the man who signed the fullback three years ago.

title: CHURCH SAYS SAUDIS FAIL TO BACK PEACE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  Senator Frank Church, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, sharply criticized Saudi Arabia today and called for a fundamental review of American policy toward the oilproducing kingdom, including whether to go ahead with the sale of F15 jet fighters.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: MANHATTAN

title: Mortgage Rates Up for Business
description: Interest rates on mortgages to finance apartment and commercial buildings surged in January, posting the biggest increases since September 1974, Citicorp Real Estate Inc. reported yesterday.

title: Vietnamese Army Is Said to Face Vigorous Cambodian Resistance
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 1  The Vietnamese Army, having captured Cambodia's towns and roads and ousted the Government of Prime Minister Pol Pot, is facing serious resistance from units bypassed in the swift advance that began at the end of last year, according to Western analysts.

title: The City
description: The reins of P.S. 194 were given yesterday to an assistant principal from another school in District 5 as attendance inched up at the boycotted Harlem school.

title: Deaths
description: CONNELLEdith (nee Nash) on Thursday. February 1, 1979, of Westfield, NJ. Beloved wife of Clancy D. Connell. Devoted mother of Donald S., Sr. Grandmother of Do nald S., Jr. Funeral services to be held on Saturday, February 3 at 2pm from the Gray Funeral Home, 318 E. Broad St., Westtield, NJ Interment Fairview Cemetery. Westfield. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Hamilton College Trustees Fund, Clinton, NY.

title: Advertising
description: IF on these cold, bleak winter days you find it difficult believing there is a recently retired man who could be taking it easy in his house in Palm Beach. Fla., and instead continues to show up at his Eighth Avenue office at 7:30 every morning, make a date to meet Dick Deems.

title: Sonics Beat Nets, 107102
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 1 (AP)  Lonnie Shelton slapped the ball loose from Eric Money of New Jersey, and Fred Brown scored on a fast break to give Seattle the lead as the SuperSonics rallied in the final 30 seconds tonight to defeat the Nets, 107102, in a National Basketball Association game.

title: French Unit Lifts Bid on Korvettes
description: The Agache Willot Group, the French retailing and textile manufacturing concern, will acquire 100 percent of Korvettes Inc., instead of the previ ously announced 51 percent, the Arlen Realty and Development Corporation, parent company of Korvettes, said yesterday.

title: EARNINGS
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, the nation's largest defense contractor, reported yesterday a 65.4 percent jump in fourthquarter earnings, but said for the year it had a loss, its first in nine years.

title: Japanese Kills Himself In Plane Scandal Case
description: TOKYO, Feb. 1  An executive of a major Japanese trading company committed suicide today by jumping from the window of his seventhfloor office in Tokyo as Japan's latest corporate and political scandal continued to unfold.

title: Taiwan Lets Its Dollar Float
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 1 (UPI) The Government today unpegged the Taiwanese currency, the new Taiwan dollar, from the United States dollar to allow it to float against a basket of currencies. It will be held within a fixed margin, however.

title: New York Summons Up Snow for Central Park Ski Fete
description: New York City may have been a summer festival under the Lindsay administration, but Gordon J. Davis, the city's Park Commissioner, said yesterday that we're trying to make it more of a winter festival.

title: Building Up in 1978; Future Dim
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) Construction spending rose an inflation-adjusted 9.1 percent in 1978, but tighter credit conditions are expected to cause a downturn in new building this year, the Commerce Department said today.

title: DR. THOMAS F. MAGOVERN
description: Dr. Thomas F. Magovern, a retired orthopedist, died Wednesday at the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune, N.J. He was 77 years old and lived in Brielle, N.J.

title: News Summary
description: Ayatollah Khomeini, back in Iran for the first time in nearly 15 years, warned that his Moslem nationalist movement would arrest Prime Minister Bakhtiar if he refused to re- sign. Speaking at a Teheran cemetery where hundreds of victims of political turmoil have been buried in the last three months, the Islamic leader ex- pressed hostility to the Prime Minister, the exiled Shah and the United States. At least three million people lined the streets to welconie the Ayatollah. [Page Al, Column 6.]

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: 16 Killed by Bombs in El Salvador
description: SAN SALVADOR, Feb. 1 (UPI)  Six powerful bombs planted by leftist guerrillas exploded today in Government offices and police headquarters in El Salvador, killing at least 14 National Guardsmen and two civilians. authorities said.

title: Actors to End 7Week TV Strike
description: A spokesman for the Screen Actors Guild said yesterday that a tentative agreement on the production of television commercials had been reached between the Guild, the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists and the advertising agencies. The actors and actresses who perform in television and radio commercials have been on strike for seven weeks.

title: Music: Barenboim Plays Brahms Piano Concerto
description: THOSE optimistic souls who contend that things have been looking up at the New York Philharmonic this season, under the leadership of Zubin Mehta, had a persuasive exhibit to point to last night. The orchestra's music director led his musicians through a concert that could serve as a model and standard. This is what the Philharmonic should sound like, always, and this is what orchestral concerts should be.

title: Copper Price Extends Rise
description: The price of copper continued to rise yesterday, reaching 84.5 cents a pound, only a halfcent short of the domestic record of 85 cents set in June 1974.

title: Unruffled Over Guidelines
description: If you can keep your composure when everyone about you is in panic, someone once said, then you probably do not understand the situation.

title: Art: Charn Hendon's Worlds Out of Small Beakers
description: WHEN Marcia Tucker got together an exhibition called Bad Painting at the New Museum not long ago, the best bad painter on view was a young man from Wisconsin called Chain Hendon. Insofar as he took debased images from everyday life and worked hard to see what could be made of them, he had affinities with Pop Art. But his paintings did not have the deadpan look of Pop Art. His calendar doggies, comeon views of seaside resorts and widelens panoramas of impossibly luxurious motel bedrooms did not, in fact, look like paintings at all. They looked like something that came hot from the oven and had been done to a turn.

title: Reporter's Notebook: For Teng, Only Oblique Vision of America
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 1  Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping's schedule was obviously not arranged to allow him to drink in impressions of the social complexity or way of life of the United States. Like a politician on the campaign trail, he is necessarily more intent on shaping the impression he makes on his multiple audiences, Chinese and American, than on making spontaneous discoveries himself.

title: Taking Over New Jersey's Buses
description: New Jersey now subsidizes 22 private bus companies but they are all losing money. Bus service is redundant on some routes, spotty on others and totally lacking elsewhere.

title: SOVIET SAID TO TEST NEW CRUISE MISSILE WITH A LONG RANGE
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 1  The Soviet Union has begun to test its own version of the longrange cruise missile, Carter Administration officials said today. The step could have an impact on the Senate's view of the projected SovietAmerican treaty limiting strategic arms.

title: Boxer's Death Stirs Action on Physicals
description: More stringent physical examina- tions, designed to prevent a recurrence of the incident that took the life of a 25yearold amateur heavyweight on Wednesday, are planned for the Golden Gloves tournament.

title: The Region
description: MINEOLA, L.I.  The Federal Statistical Policy Coordinating Committee has killed a proposal that would have merged NassauSuffolk into the New York City Standard Metropolitan Statistical Area for purposes of collecting data, and planning officials said President Carter was expected to approve the committee's action.

title: 5 Americans Are Killed in Crash Of a U.S. Air Force Plane in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran. Feb. 1 (UPI)  A United States Air Force plane crashed south of Teheran last night, killing five of seven Americans on board, an American military spokesman said today.

title: A Meter Maid And an Officer Trip Over Law
description: Police Officer William Curtin and Parking Enforcement Officer Ada Fields had a confrontation over a noparking zone outside the Criminal Courts Building in Lower Manhattan yesterday, and before it was over:

title: The Rev. Robert F. Hurley, at 59; Brooklyn Diocese Tribunal Judge
description: The Rev. Robert F. Hurley, associate presiding judge of the Diocesan Tribunal of Brooklyn and Queens, died Sunday of a heart attack at St. James Rectory in Brooklyn. He was 59 years old.

title: A. Margaret Taylor, 33, Consultant to Architects
description: A. Margaret Taylor, director of marketing for Offices Limited Inc., consultants to architects, died Monday at her family's home in Rochester following a brief illness. She was 33 years old and lived at 1700 York Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Two Centuries of U.S. Pressure On One Pillar: Equality
description: WASHINGTON  Since the United States Supreme Court's decision in Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka in 1959, the principle of equality has occupied an increasingly central place in American public life. This unprecedented pressure of moral and intellectual attention on a single principle on a single word  has proved too great a strain, with the result that the concept has split up and yielded different meanings and values.

title: Screen: 'Train Robbery' Steams In on New Run:25,000 Caper
description: "THE GREAT TRAIN ROBBERY," adapted by Michael Crichton from his own best-selling novel and directed by him with great good humor, is based on the true story of what is alleged to have been the first train robbery in history. In 1855, a small band of extremely ingenious crooks made off with 25,000 in gold bars from the train carrying them from London to Folk-stone where, the authorities hoped, it would successfully be trans-shipped to the Crimea, there to pay the troops then fighting the Czar.Mr. Crichton's previous films as a director  "Westworld" and "Coma"  are skillful and, each in its own way, entertaining, but they give no hint of the amplitude he displays in this visually dazzling period piece. With Sean Connery as the gang's elegant leader, the sort of mastermind who denies his body nothing, Lesley-Anne Down as his magnificent moll, and Donald Sutherland as his locksmith "the best screwsman in England"  "The Great Train Robbery" is classy entertainment of the sort I associate exclusively with movies.The film, which opens today at the Criterion, Sutton and 86th Street East Theaters, has been written, directed and acted with intelligence, and it evokes its Victorian era with a completeness of detail that should satisfy the most finicky imagination.Mr. Crichton's screenplay displays what in an earlier time might have been called a saucy wit. The major portion of the film is devoted to the adventures of Mr. Connery and his associates as they seek the four keys necessary to unlock the safes containing the gold once they get aboard the train  this being in the days before nitroglycerin or combination locks.There is a prissy plain-Jane  very sweetly played by Gabrielle Lloyd  to be romanced by Mr. Connery, a prison escape to be arranged for the one catburglar in England who can pull off one phase crucial to the operation, and a con game to be played with a gullible bank manager in a brothel.The brilliant Alan Webb appears briefly but importantly as the elderly president of a bank, the possessor of one of the all-important keys. It is Mr. Webb who has one of the film's nicest lines when, explaining why his beloved dog lost a rat-baiting contest, he says with sadness, "He lacked bustle." Bustle is what this film is full of.Mr. Connery has both the humor and the dead-earnestness of purpose that are the method of the movie, which is to charm us as it keeps us on the edges of our seats. Mr. Sutherland, as the none-too-bright locksmith, and Miss Down, who must appear in several figuratively transparent disguises, have fun with what are, in effect, character roles. The three work together beautifully.As important as the contributions of the writer-director and the performers are those of Maurice Carter, the production designer, and the late Geoffrey Unsworth, director of photography. "The Great Train Robbery" gives us a panoramic view of early Victorian London, from its drawing rooms and luxurious private clubs to its gambling dens, its slums and its prisons. Its streets are alive with the kind of movement that only movies can afford. I've no idea what the picture cost, but it looks as if it must have been a mint.Additionally, the climactic heist of the gold, with Mr. Connery climbing atop the moving railroad cars, ducking under bridges just before a possible decapitation, is marvelous action footage that manages to be very funny as it takes your breath away."The Great Train Robbery," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some rude language of our period, some double-entendres of no great subtlety and a very little partial nudity.

title: At Ford Fund: Euphoria Over a New Chief
description: By all accounts, there has been euphoria at the Ford Foundation ever since it was announced on Monday that Franklin A. Thomas had been chosen to become president when McGeorge Bundy retires in June.

title: Koch Asks End to Confrontation And Rhetoric on Racial Relations
description: Mayor Koch called last night for a new language to deal with race relations in New York City and an end to the rhetoric, the posturing, the harmful language of confrontation.

title: L.I. MAN IS CHARGED WITH A 54 MURDER
description: Suffolk County homicide detectives, while recently reviewing old murder cases that occurred before the county's Police Department was organized in 1960, noted similarities between a 1970 case and the murder of Kathryn Ann Damm 16 years earlier.

title: 4 Escape Hackensack Jail Annex After Crawling Through Air Duct
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 2 (AP)Four prisoners at the Bergen County Jail Annex here escaped today by crawling through a ventilation duct leading to the roof of the facility.

title: Congressmen Hire Few Minorities, A Rights Activist in Hartford Finds
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 2  Of the 162 persons working for Connecticut's eightmember delegation to the United States Congress, only six fulltime employees are black or are from the Hispanic community, according to a survey by an activist for minority causes.

title: Manila Closes Harbor to. Refugees
description: MANILA, Feb. 2  The Philippines refused entry to, some newly arrived Vietnamese refugees today and set up a blockade of the 20milewide mouth of Manila Bay to prevent freighters carrying other refugees from entering.

title: Suit Against Shah's Foundation Seeks a Payment of $4.5 Million
description: A Maine resident yesterday sued the charitable foundation set up by the Shah of Iran for $4.5 million, contending that he was owed the money for work done in the acquisition by the foundation of a building on Fifth Avenue.

title: $1.5 Million Bonus for Fox Chief
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2  In 1976, Dennis C. Stanfill, chairman of the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation, made a deal with the company. If Fox's aggregate earnings per share surpassed $13.56 by the end of 1980, the 51yearold executive would collect a $1.5 million bonus to be invested, after taxes, in Fox.

title: Insurance Merger Backed
description: The board of directors of the Pennsylvania Life Company approved yesterday a previously proposed definitive merger agreement with Ticor, a title insurance concern. Ticor's board previously approved the transaction.

title: Rhodesia's New Antidiscrimination Laws Get Unenthusiastic Reception
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 2  Rhodesia officially became a nonracial society today as eight statutes barring racial discrimination went into effect, but the change offered little prospect of early improvement in the way of life of most of the country's 6.8 million blacks.

title: Soviet sells Its Periodicals in U.S. Through Madison Ave. Methods
description: The soviet Union has quietly adopted a bit of Madison Avenue technique to market several Governmentoperated pub ications in the United States.

title: 'Property,' at American Mavericks Film Festival
description: Penny Allen's "Property," which begins a three-day run today at the Entermedia Theater's American Mavericks Festival of independent films, is a folksy sort of movie, though the people in it are not types usually thought of as folksy, being random leftovers from the radicalism of the 1960's. They include a mid-30'ish male poet; a dwarf named Corky, who dreams of being a stand-up comedian on national television but who is appreciated only by his pals; a mild-mannered, silver-haired ex-con who lives with a younger woman  who hustles for money when necessary  and their small child, and various other people who seem less eccentric than emotionally undermotivated.What brings them together in this movie is a communal effort to purchase the block of rundown but substantial old houses in which they all live in Portland, Ore., after the owner decides to sell the property. The movie, written and directed by Miss Allen, is said to be based on actual events, with some of the original participants playing themselves. What we in the audience see is a movie without much pace or drive; rather it's a fond improvisation, competently photographed and adequately mimed. Experiencing it is like thumbing through somebody else's photograph album. The pictures are clear but the important associations are missing."Property" doesn't really dramatize the reconstructed events. It visits them after careful preparation, dropping in on block meetings, listening for a while, then moving on, once to a most tentative orgy whose three players look as if they're trying to remember what they're supposed to do. The block committee argues; members resign and return. Two people are appointed to visit the banks and various city commissions. For a while, the success of the endeavor is in doubt, but then, miraculously, all ends happily.I suspect, however, that the group's success in putting its hands on the necessary money and in establishing bank credit says less about the conscience of American capitalists than about the value of having solid, prosperous, middle-class parents if one wants to drop into the 70's after having dropped out of the 60's."Property" is a very, very loose movie, the kind that is best appreciated by friends and relatives of those who appear in it.

title: Knick Rally Beats 76ers, 105101
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2  The New York Knicks, struggling with just nine players the entire game, rallied from a 10point deficit in the final quarter and defeated the Philadelphia 76ers, 105101, tonight.

title: Vermonters Win Titles
description: WATERVILLE VALLEY, N.H., Feb. 2  Two members of the national Nordic skiing squad, both brought up in Vermont, captured titles today as the United States crosscountry championships were concluded.

title: About New York
description: At first there is darkness and no dimension in the old Nathan's hotdog stand, but then the lights are turned on, flooding the place with possibilities, and the architect is well pleased.

description: Silver futures prices jumped the daily limit yesterday of 20 cents an ounce, and gold, platinum and other precious metals also advanced.

title: Deaths
description: BARNETTArnold H Died February 2, 1979. Born in New York City December 11,1885. Graduated from City College of New York in 1906 and was admitted to the practice of law in 1909. He will be remembered as a Prominent attorney and trial lawyer who remained active almost to the time of his death. He leaves a son Henry and two daughters Rita, Kathryn, nine grandchildren and a devoted employee and friend Lucille Oliver. Services to be held Sunday Feburary 4 at Park West Memorial Chapel.

description: PROPERTY, directed by Penny Allen, and DARK STAR, directed by John Carpenter, at the American Mavericks Festival, Entermedia Theater, 189 Second Avenue.

title: Blast Destroys Coast Buildings
description: GLENDALE, Calif., Feb. 2 (AP)  An explosion and fire destroyed several buildings in a commercial complex before dawn today, forcing the evacuation of a nearby apartment house and injuring several persons, the authorities said. One man, identified as Ghoffam Haddad, was critically injured. Fire officials said the cause of the explosion was unknown.

title: Mrs. Carter to Testify Before a Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) Rosalynn Carter will appear before a Senate subcommittee Wednesday in the first Congressional testimony by a First Lady since 1945, when Eleanor Roosevelt testified in favor of building a home for the poor in Washington.

title: Son of Cult's Leader Retracts a Statement On Murdering Family
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Feb. 2 (UPI)  Stephan Jones, the 19yearold son of the Rev. Jim Jones, today formally retracted his alleged confession to murdering a People's Temple official and her three children.

title: Nets Drubbed by Blazers, 117100
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 2 (AP)  A tired New Jersey Nets team, playing its fourth road game in as many nights, was routed by the Portland Trail Blazers tonight, 117100.

title: Logan Hospital In West Harlem Is Shut for Now
description: The financially troubled Arthur J. Logan Memorial Hospital, which has served West Harlem for more than 100 years, was closed last night.

title: Ushers at the Rockefeller Service
description: Following are the ushers designated for the memorial service for Nelson A. Rockefeller:

title: Briton Sees No Change In Policy on Rhodesia
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  Foreign Secretary David Owen of Britain told a group of United States Senators today not to expect a change in the BritishAmerican poIicy calling for talks between Rhodesia's Government and guerrilla leaders.

title: Printing Reviving in New York
description: The printing business, a New York specialty since colonial days. is shaking off a decade of decline.

title: The Inside Word on Larry Bird
description: Around here, the voice said, mum's the word on Larry Bird, but I'll talk.

title: Parley in Strike At Paper Mills
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2  Negotiations toward a settlement of a sevenmonth strike of West Coast paper mills got under way yesterday in Portland, Ore., between the Boise Cascade Corporation,and the Association of Western Pulp and Paper Workers. About 15,400 of the 22,000 members of the union are now on strikesome of them since last July. The shutdown has caused shortages of newsprint and paper bags as far east as Kansas City, Mo.

description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 2 (AP) After saying they did not realize they were breaking the law, Eleanor and Samuel Elias were fined a total of $8,250 for falsifying campaign contributions to Milton Shapp's Presidential campaign.

title: Mrs. Carner Gains in Match Play
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 2  A couple of veterans of the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour reached the semifinals of the triple crown matchplay championship today. The defending champion, JoAnne Carner, who will be 40 years old in April, won from Sandra Post of Canada, 3 and 2; Donna Young, 34, came from two down after six holes to defeat Dot Germain, 3 and 2, on a cold day at the Mission Hills Country Club.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE CRIME VICTIM'S BOOK. By Morton Bard and Dawn Sangrey. 223 pages. Basic. $10.

title: Era Closes With Bankers Club
description: World leaders, including Charles de Gaulle, Winston Churchill, Nikita S. Khrushchev and Queen Elizabeth II, have dined in the intimate mahoganypaneled private dining rooms of the Rankers Club of America.

title: Fluor Reduces Role In Iranian Oil Deal
description: The Fluor Corporation, a participant in a joint venture for the construction of a refinery for the National Iranian Oil Company in Iran, said that although the project was 98 percent complete it had reduced its activities on the project because of the civil strife in that country.

title: Stewart Udall Says He's Shocked At Corps Chief's Waterway Data
description: GREENVILLE, Miss., Feb. 2  Stewart L. Udall, former Secretary of the Interior, said in Federal District Court here today that he was shocked at testimony given earlier this week by Lieut. Gen. John W. Morris, Chief of the Army Corps of Engineers, in a hearing on the legality of the TennesseeTombigbee Waterway.

title: Ivan Sandrof, 67, Editor Headed Critics Circle
description: Ivan Sandrof, former editor of The Worcester Telegram in Worcester, Mass., and first president of the National Book Critics Circle, died Thursday at the University of Massachusetts Medical Center in Worcester. He was 67 years old.

title: HighJump Mark Tied
description: BUDAPEST, Feb. 2 (AP)  Hungary's Andrea Matay, 24 years old, equaled the women's world indoor highjump record of 6 feet 4; inches yesterday at an international track and field meet.

title: Robin Yachting Victor
description: The St. PetersburgtoFort Lauderdale ocean race, a rugged one that took the life of one of the competitors, ended yesterday at the Fort Lauderdale port with Ted Hood's Robin, a 36foot sloop from Marblehead, Mass., declared the winner.

title: La Ronde, Seduction in Vienna
description: The Equity Library Theater, which can usually be counted on for workmanlike and occasionally inspired productions with limited resources, seems to have overreached itself in trying to stage Arthur Schnitzler's La Ronde, which will be seen through Feb. 18.

title: Cambodian Enigma: Silence And a Scarcity of Refugees
description: KANTHARALAK, Thailand, Feb. 2The road that leads south from this district seat grows more desolate as it nears the Cambodian border, and for the last three miles no people can be seen walking or working in the fields. Rocks, gravel and dead branches lie in the roadway, the signs of disuse.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BIG APPLE SLICES Shoppers at Macy's can enjoy a new photography show of 60 blackandwhite prints of changing Jewish neighborhoods, customs and life styles that are disappearing or being preserved, and new aspects of the city's Jewish life. The pictures, which have been set up in the fifthfloor camera department of the Herald Square store and can be seen tomorrow through Feb. 17, are the work of Bill Aron, Arnold Cohen and Meryl Meisler, camera experts of the American Jewish Congress C.E.T.A. Artists Project.

title: EARNINGS Kennecott's Net Off in Quarter Despite Sales Rise
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation yesterday reported a 46.2 percent slump in fourthquarter earnings. The nation's leading copper producer attributed the decline to higher production costs and lower market prices, although sales more than doubled. Its net income for the full year of 1978 was up sharply.

title: Auto Falloff Seen in Bonn
description: BONN, Feb. 2 West Germany's automobile industry had a record output of 4.18 million vehicles in 1978, but signs of intensifying competition are damping hopes for 1979.

description: Following are excerpts from eulogies delivered yesterday at a memorial service for Nelson A. Rockefeller:
