description: Cooper Laboratories announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Sterndent Corporation, manufacturers of specialty health care products.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 17.

title: Rare Election Con test Is Proposed For Two Seats in Soviet Parliament
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 2  Every schoolchild knows that an election in the Soviet Union offers a choice of only one candidate the Communist Party candidate. But today a small group of workers, Russian nationalists, religious activists and others announced an attempt to change that, an effort that may constitute one of Moscow's strangest political events in years.

title: 'Dark Star,' Space Film Send-up
description: John Carpenter, the director of "Halloween," made "Dark Star" in 1974, when "Star Wars" was barely a subatomic particle in George Lucas's eye. Accordingly, Mr. Carpenter's space-movie send-up toys with the conventions of "2001: A Space Odyssey" instead of trying to simulate intergalactic whizzing.Four astronauts have spent 20 years together on the spaceship for which the movie is named, and, with only the obligatory sexy-voiced computer to keep them company, they're bored. So they daydream about surfing, or sit at control panels that look like back-lit Scrabble boards, or play practical jokes that aren't often good for a laugh. Much of the movie takes place in the cinematic equivalent of zero gravity, just floating around. Even in the glow of hindsight, "Dark Star" doesn't contain many indications that Mr. Carpenter is a director about to turn the world on its ear.There are some funny routines here, though Mr. Carpenter doesn't seem to have cared much about integrating or sustaining them. At the finale, a bomb is timed to explode in a matter of minutes if one of the astronauts can't give it a brief lesson (the bomb is intelligent, or at least it talks) in phenomenology. The spaceship's mascot, also inexplicably alive, is a tomato-colored beach ball with little clawed feet. The opening credits are set to a country and western song about space travel, incongruous at the very least. One of the astronauts' silver-colored suits has a front panel that looks suspiciously like a muffin tin."Dark Star," which will be shown tomorrow through Monday at the Entermedia Theater as part of the American Mavericks series there, is a very low-budget undertaking. Although "Hardware Wars," a hilarious 13-minute sci-fi parody that played at the Film Forum several months ago, is clear evidence that an inexpensive film need not lack for panache, Mr. Carpenter makes his amateurishness unmistakable, especially when it comes to the film's four actors. Only one of them can act even crudely (fortunately, his is the largest role). The other three, neither photogenic nor particularly extroverted, look like well-meaning fraternity brothers helping out a pal with his class project.

title: Lake Placid Ski Jump Is Damaged by Fire
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 2 (AP) Fire did an estimated $25,000 worth of damage last night to the 90meter ski jump for the 1980 Winter Olympics here, hours after the first skier to use it called the jump fabulous.

title: Iranians Remove Secret Devices From F14 Fighters and Missiles
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (Reuters) The Iranian Air Force has removed secret electronic devices from the advanced warplanes and missiles that Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi bought from the United States, and has hidden them, American Government sources said today.

title: Iranian Prince Returns to U.S.
description: MARRAKESH, Morocco. Feb. 2 (AP)  Prince Riza Pahlevi, the 18yearold son of the Shah of Iran, returned to the United States today, apparently to resume military flight training at Lubbock, Tex. He was accompanied by Ardeshir Zahedi, former Ambassador to the United States and a close confidant of the Shah. The Prince arrived here last Saturday to join his parents.

title: Stevenson Plans Legislation to Aid U.S. Trade With soviet and China
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  A key Senator said today he would introduce legislation Monday to alter trade laws discriminating against the Soviet Government to make it easier for the United States to grant trade concessions to both the Soviet Union and China.

title: U.S. Study Questions Accuracy of Job Data
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  A national commission has found what it calls glaring weaknesses in the way unemployment statistics are calculated in states and municipalities and has proposed, as one remedy, that funds be set aside to train state officials in statistical reporting.

title: Five Cited in Mail Fraud Case
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 (UPI)  A Federal grand jury indicted four men on mail fraud and conspiracy charges today in a scheme involving the sale of $4. 5 million to set unties in oil and gas drilling programs.

title: Nixon to Visit China for 3d Time
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 2 (UPI)  Former President Richard M. Nixon has accepted an invitation from China's senior Deputy Prime Minister, Teng Hsiaoping, to visit China again, perhaps in March, a spokesman for Mr. Teng said today.

title: Sports News Briefs; Kelley, Giant Linebacker, Likely to Stay With Team
description: Brian Kelley, the outside linebacker who played out his option with the Giants last season, said yesterday: I'll end up with the Giants, after testing the freeagent waters.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Miami Beach Group Wants to Save Art Deco Hotels
description: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 1  Linda Gail Polansky, a former banker, decided a few months ago to go into the real estate business here. She does not sell condominiums or rent highrise apartments or find lots for real estate developers; rather, she looks for buyers for old, slightly rundown hotels and apartment houses, the streamlined modern or Art Deco buildings that fill Miami Beach.

title: Spoiled FalloutShelter Crackers Pose Disposal Task in New York
description: Survival rations stocked in thousands of New York City fallout shelters more than a decade ago are now considered a hazard because the highnutrition crackers that were the mainstay of the emergencyfood menu have turned rancid and could cause illness in humans who happen to eat them.

title: The City
description: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire approved the dismissal of a policeman whom the department reportedly regarded as its most'chronic abuser of sickleave privileges.

title: West Coast's Ports and Businesses Ready to Scramble for China Trade
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 2  West Coast busines people are scrambling for position and gearing up for the major expansion of trade that they expect to come from the United States recognition of China.

title: Hinkle Posts 68138 to Lead ProAm by 2
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Feb. 2 For five years Lon Hinkle, a slowmoving giant of 6 feet 2 inches and 215 pounds, lumbered through the lower depths of the progolf tour, bumming around and, with annual winnings of less than $12,000, getting nowhere. In 1977 he squeaked his way into the top60 list of money winners with $51,494, and last year he won $200,000.

title: First Fully Staged Mary Dyer Opera
description: In 1660, a Quaker named Mary Dyer was hanged in Boston for returning to the Massachusetts Bay Colony after having been banished for her religious beliefs. At the New York University Theater on Thursday night, the New York Lyric Opera Company gave the first fully staged performance of Richard Owen's opera based on this subject.

title: F.C.C. Head Predicts Abundant TV Choices
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said in a speech prepared for delivery tomorrow in Los Angeles that a future abundance of television program choices could create wider network competition and lessen the need for close Government regulation.

title: School That Banned Long Hair Now in Dispute Over Banned Book
description: BARRINGTON, Ill., Jan. 30  In 1969, officials at Barrington High school suspended a student because he wore his hair long, and that led to a Federal suit that established the principle that a student may not be denied an education because of his appearance.

title: Noranda to Mail Tender
description: Noranda Mines Ltd. reported yester day that it expected to mail its rently announced offer to exchange one No randa share for each 2 shares of Mattagami Lake Mines Ltd. about March 2. Mattagami sharebolders previously

title: World Gold
description: FRIDAY, FEB 2, 1979

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The nation's unemployment rate fell slightly in January to 5.8 percent of the work force, the Labor Department reported. The rate had been 5.1; percent in December and 5.8 percent in November. Total employment in January expanded by 915,000 jobs, indicating that a record 59.3 percent of the population was employed, the department said. [Page 1.]

title: First Big Bank Follows Chase Prime Cut to 11%
description: The First Pennsylvania Bank reduced its prime rate by a quarter of a percentage point yesterday to 11 percent and became the first major bank to follow the reduction in the key lending rate initiated last Tuesday by the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PPOCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday. Feb 2, 1979

title: Panel Told of Fear and Abuse in Adult Homes
description: A City Council hearing was told yesterday that many of the more than 9,000 New Yorkers who live in adult homes are subjected to substandard living conditions, get inferior food and fear abuse from the large number of former mental patients among them.

title: Letters; Wrong Plant for the Bronx
description: To the Editor:

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, FEB 2, 1979

title: Evacuation of Burning Jet Found Delayed by 3 Melted Escape Slides
description: Federal investigators said yesterday that evacuation of a burning DC10 jumbo jet at the Los Angeles airport a year ago had been greatly delayed by the melting of three escape slides.

title: U.S. Blocks Aid Sought By Chrysler
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 2  The ailing Chrysler Corporation will be ineligible for $250 million in Federal loan guarantees it has requested, according to Administration officials, because of an unannounced decision by President Carter to limit Federal credit assistance to any one company under existing programs to $50 million.

title: Japan Reports Record Balance
description: TOKYO Feb. 2 (UPI)  Despite the dollar's slide in value, Japan's 1978 balance-of-payments surplus surged 50 percent to a record $16.63 billion on its current account, official figures showed today. The 1977 surplus was $10.92 billion in the account, which covers goods, services and all financial transactions.

title: Hell Isle
description: As I left Pulau Bidong, an island about two and a half hours by fishing boat from the Malaysian resort town of Trenggenau, a Vietnamese refugee said; Please don't pity us in spite of what you saw here. We're alive, unlike our people who drowned trying to reach land, any land. But when you return to America, please try to make your people understand....

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 24.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday, Feb. 3 (AP)  United Airlines, the largest United States air carrier, reached a tentative agreement on a new contract with about 18,000 employees early today, averting a strike that had been threatened for one minute past midnight.

title: A Crescendo of Spanish Dancing
description: The Mara BentezEstampa Flamenca, which opened Thursday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is a capable Spanish dance company. And Mara Bentez herself is a beautiful, exciting dancer.

title: Brunswick Corporation
description: The Brunswick Corporation of Skokie, Ill., manufacturer of leisuretime and other products, reported yesterday that its profit in the fourth quarter climbed 8.7 percent to a record while sales advanced 17.9 percent, also to a record. The company said that sales and earnings for all 1978 rose to new highs, too.

title: The Region.
description: Seven privately operated New Jersey bus companies filed suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday in an effort to block further Federal subsidies of their state's masstransit program, saying that they were being cut off from full participation.

title: Betty Seifert, at 49, Deputy Head Of Library of the City University
description: Betty Seifert, associate professor and deputy director of the library of the City University of New York, died yesterday at her home on East 7th Street in Manhattan. She was 49 years old.

title: Judge Orders Reporter in Denver To Reveal Grand Jury Information
description: DENVER, Feb. 2 (UPI)  A judge has ordered a reporter who allegedly received secret grand jury information from a former state official to disclose that information in two weeks or possibly be cited for contempt.

title: Texas Greets Teng With Band, Backlash and Rain
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 2  The University of Houston Brass Band played Hey, Look Me Over as the short man in the gray Mao tunic alighted from Air Force One, the Presidential plane, here today.

title: Boy, 4, Survives SevenStory Fall
description: A 4yearold boy was seriously injured yesterday after he fell from a window of his mother's seventhfloor apartment in Brooklyn

title: Printing of Food Stamps Under U.S. Investigation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)  Possible wrongdoing in connection with $154 million worth of printing contracts for Government food stamps is being investigated by a Senate subcommittee and the Justice Department, according to Joseph Laitin, an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury.

title: Clashes Reported Along the ChinaVietnam Border
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 2  Armed border clashes between China and Vietnam have reportedly increased in the last few days, with each side accusing the other of intrusions and shooting incidents. Two Vietnamese and eight Chinese were killed in the various actions, according to the official press agencies of Peking and Hanoi.

title: The InflationWary Invest in Objects,. Not Dollars
description: Gerald Marker of Seattle has been buying gold jewelry but wants to get into silver bars. Robert Aduddell of Chicago likes art prints. Steven Malycke of Ohio looks for land.

title: Laurance Rockefeller Files Suit
description: Laurance S. Rockefeller filed a 550,000 lawsuit yesterday against Pan American Airlines, an antique company and a trucking firm, contending that they were responsible for damage to a cargo of porcelain birds shipped from England last June.

title: Letter On Merit Selection of Judges
description: The recent editorial and articles in The Times pointing out that merit selection of judges is not a surefire prescription for immediate change in the white male domination of both the state and the Federal bench should lead to healthy pressure on Federal selection panels and the New York State Commission on Judicial Nomination, which is now in the process of searching for an associate judge of the Court of Appeals.

title: Catherine Nimitz
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 2 (AP)Catherine Nimitz, widow of Adm. Chester W. Nimitz, died at the Oakland Naval Hospital yesterday at the age of 86. The cause of death of was not announced. Her husband, who was the head of the Pacific fleet in World War II, died in 1966.

title: Surfeit of Snowballs Turned Into a Gaggle of Geese
description: What started out as a landscape of windwhipped mounds of snow on a salt marsh in Mannington Township, N.J., became a nature study when the mounds stood up to take a bow. The geese  yearround residents  had curled themselves into fluffy balls to keep warm. Temperatures today are not expected to be much higher, but that won't bother these fellows. Nature has outfitted them against the cold  with jackets made of 100 percent goose down.

title: Tibetans in Exile
description: Tibet. Some said it was an Asiatic Graustark; that it was a semifeudal theocracy; but the concerned, civilized, cultivated and scholarly upheld Tibet as a conservatory of the unique artistic, religious and literary heritage dating from the 7th century A.D.

title: Swaying Smokestack Stalls Brooklyn Traffic Before Being Repaired
description: A 278foothigh steel smokestack at a Brooklyn hospital almost collapsed yesterday after three steel braces holding it in place came loose in strove winds.

title: Prize Days in New York: Not a Minute Alone
description: As the winners of the TridentNational Basketball Association Sweepstakes (Almost two million ballots cast in sports arenas and candy stores across the country! said a happy spokesman for the chewing gum) John and Gail Herzich were flown here from their home in Hartland. Wis., last week to claim their prizes.

title: Man Lunges Toward Teng
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 2 (UPI)  An unarmed man lunged in the direction of Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping in a hotel basement today Nit was quickly subdued by Secret Service officers. Mr. Teng, on his way to a waiting car, was about 15 feet away at the time and was not touched.

title: ADVANCES STUDIED IN CARTER BUSINESS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  Federal investigators are examining Carter Warehouse financial arrangements that permitted members of the Carter family to receive advances against the profits of the business, Charles Kirbo, the Atlanta lawyer and confidant to President Carter, confirmed in an interview today.

title: Leftist Union Leaders Becoming Focus of British Strike Criticism
description: LONDON, Feb. 2 On the wall of his office in downtown Birmingham, Gordon Will, a local union official, has a blue-andwhite poster celebrating the 25th anniversary of the Communist Government in East Germany.

title: Panel Backs Research Into Animal Embryos Created in Test Tubes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI)  Members of a Federal ethiCs advisory board generally agreed today that the Governinert should support animal research into testtube fertilization.

title: Dignitaries and Friends Honor Rockefeller
description: The famous, the powerful and people who were just friends, 2,200 of them, honored Nelson A. Rockefeller yesterday at a memorial service that lauded his faith and his efforts for the nation  and ended with an upbeat jazz recessional celebrating his buoyancy and optimism. President Carter, Vice President Mondale and Chief Justice Warren E. Burger flew in from Washington. Former President Gerald R. Ford and Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations led national and international dignitaries in Riverside Church, an edifice built largely through the philanthropy of Mr. Rockefeller's father.

title: Nehemiah Sets Another Record
description: TORONTO, Feb. 2  For the fourth time in four indoor meets over the last two weeks, Renaldo Nehemiah of the University of Maryland set a world indoor hurdles record tonight at the Toronto Star Maple Leaf Games.

title: Iowan Killed in Apartment Fire
description: SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Feb. 2 (UPI)  The body of an elderly woman was found today in the rubble of a burnedout apartment building, and firemen searched for another resident who was missing. The fire apparently was caused by an explosion in the boiler of the threestory, 65yearold Carroll Apartments in downtown. Sioux City. Forty tenants were evacuated, and nine persons were injured.

title: T. W. Copeland, 71; A Professor Emeritus At Massachusetts U.
description: Thomas W. Copeland, emeritus Commonwealth Professor of English at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst, died Wednesday in Northampton, Mass., fat the age of 71.

title: To China: Open Up Tibet
description: The following article, by the spiritual and temporal leader of the Tibetans, was made available to The New York Times by The Office of Tibet, in New York City. The Dalai Lama, a Buddhist, fled to India in 1959 after China's takeover of Tibet, and lives in Dharmsala, a Himalayan town.

title: Union Bars Pay Guides
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 2  The United Rubber Workers union announced plans today to ignore President Carter's voluntary wage guidelines in negotiations beginning later this month for a new contract covering 55,000 rubber workers. The U.R.W. negotiations are considered important in President Carter's antiinflation program, which must be backed by organized labor to be successful.

title: Mabel Taliaferro, 91, Star of Silent Screen Acted in 100 Plays
description: Mabel Taliaferro, one of the first stars of the silent screen and a veteran of more than 100 plays on the stage, died Jan. 24 in Honolulu, where she had gone to live several years ago. She was 91 years old.

title: McVay Accepts Post With 49ers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2 (AP)  John McVay, dismissed as head coach of the Giants after the regular season, was hired as director of personnel for the San Francisco 49ers today.

title: EDWARD A. GALL
description: CINCINNATI (AP)  Dr. Edward A. Gall, former president of the American Association of Pathologists and Bacteriologists. died Wednesday of cancer, a disease he sought to conquer in his research. He was 72 years old.

title: Brokerage In Florida Examined
description: MIAMI, Feb. 2  The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating a Boca Raton brokerage firm dealing with United States Government securities that filed a voluntary bankruptcy action four weeks ago, official sources say.

title: Jerusalem Suburbanites Feud Over Sabbath Traffic
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 2  As dusk fell and the Sabbath began, policemen took position along the Ramot Road on this city's barren fringe today to act as a buffer in a feud between Orthodox and secular Jews that has been going on for months and threatens to become more bitter.

title: Astronaut Teng Gets New View of World in Houston
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 2  Teng Hsiaoping, who is using his trip to the United States to dramatize China's eagerness for advanced technology, climbed into the cockpit of a space shuttle flight simulator here today to discover what it would be like to land this newest American spacecraft from an altitude of 100,000 feet.

title: They're Finding a Way Out of the Prescription Drug Trap
description: She seems a more likely candidate for a country club tea than for drug addiction. A delicate 60yearold who lives in Westchester, Margaret wears expensively understated clothes and speaks in a low, wellbred voice. Because she suffers chronic pain  from arthritis, severe migraine headaches and an agonizing pinched nerve, among other causes  she has long taken a regular dosage of analgesics. She hardly noticed when the amount began to creep insidiously upward.

title: BAKHTIAR PROPOSES IRAN UNITY REGIME; KHOMEINI IS HOSTILE Islamic Leader Exhorts the People to Destroy the Government Named Before Shah Left
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 2  Prime Minister Shahpur Bakhtiar made new overtures to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini today. The Islamic leader, however, issued a statement for mullahs to'read throughout the nation calling on the people to destroy the terrible monarchy and its illegal Government.

title: Deaths
description: PILOTHi. Of Bal Harbor, Fla., died February 1, beloved husband of Fanny, devoted father of Daniel, Richard. and Gloria. Proud grandfather of Kenneth. Services Sunday. 11:45AM, The Riverside, 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Three Peruvian Planes Missing
description: LIMA, Peru, Feb. 2 (Reuters)  The Peruvian Air Force said today that three of its planes had disappeared yesterday on a training flight. A brief statement said the planes had failed to return to base after a routine training mission near the Chilean border. It did not say what type of planes were involved and gave no other details.

title: G. &W. Buys 6.1% Of Uniroyal
description: Gulf and Western Industries, a giant conglomerate known for its aggressive acquisition policy, announced yesterday that it had purchased for investment a 6.1 percent interest in Uniroyal Inc., the nation's thirdlargest tire producer, for about $11 million.

title: Stocks Off 4th Time In Week
description: Stock prices drifted lower yesterday to register their fourth loss of the week as political uncertainties in Iran continued to dampen investor psychology.

title: Theft of 21 Cars Laid to Worker At Olins Agency
description: A 51yearold parking attendant for an Olins RentaCar outlet in Manhattan was indicted by a grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of having stolen 21 cars from his employer to set up his own carrental agency at home.

title: Miss Fratianne Wins FigureSkating Title
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 3  Skating strongly in a new, sequined hot red outfit, and putting what her coach caned sex into her routine, Linda Fratianne tonight captured her third straight United States women's figureskating title.

title: Jerseyan Awarded Second Permit in State for a Commercial TV Station
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  Donald C. McMeans of Willingboro, N.J., was awarded the second commercial television station in New Jersey today, making him only the second black person in the country to own a TV station, the Federal Communications Commission said.

title: Makers of Defoliants Are Sued On Behalf of Vietnam Veterans
description: A wideranging classaction lawsuit was filed Thursday on behalf of 4.2 million Americans who were allegedly exposed to cancercausing chemical defoliants during service in the Vietnam war, The Associated Press reported.

title: Rat's Nest, New Play, Limns Denizens of Bar
description: The strongest thing to emerge from Rat's Nest, an amiable but lax collection of sketches jostling to be a play, is the suspicion that a star has fallen into it.

title: Inquiry in Diggs's Case Is Urged by 15 in House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)  Fifteen junior House members called on the House ethics committee today to investigate the case of Representative Charles C. Diggs Jr., Democrat of Michigan, who was convicted of taking kickbacks from his employees.

title: Songwriter on Trial for Murder
description: Frankie Tucker, 45 years old, a rhythm and blues songwriter, went on trial before a jury in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday in the stabbing death of another songwriter on Feb. 8, 1978. Mr.. Tucker, also known as Dr. Sweetlove, is accused of killing Gordon Evans in the Brill Building, at 1619 Broadway.

title: New York Area Gained in Jobs Over Last Year
description: Unemployment rates for New York City, New York State and New Jersey declined in January from the levels of a year earlier, and the number of jobholders in the two states increased by more than 439,000 over the year, the regional office of the United States Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: A Pinpoint System Is Developed For Finding Voters for an Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  A new system of locating potentially favorable blocs of voters with sophisticated accuracy has been developed and tested positively by a team of two political consultants and a demographic research exDen

title: Bridge:
description: Opposite ends of the bridge spectrum meet today at the New York Hilton Hotel, At one end will be a group of tournament newcomers, all with less than 20 master points. The schedule will be: today, individuals at 1:30 P.M. and pairs at 7 P.M.; tomorrow, twosession Swiss teams at 12.30 P.M. and 6 P.M.

title: Building Managers Keeping Offices Warm in Strike
description: Robert Tanoff, a stocky man with a neatly trimmed moustache and a carefully pressed blue suit, did not look like an on-the-job operating engineer.

title: HolmesOcasio Bout
description: While plans were announced for Muhammad Ali to fight again, the two worlds of boxing continued yesterday with their plans for the postAli heavyweight era.

title: Columbia Rallies to Beat Dartmouth, 4540
description: One Columbia faculty member at Levien Gym last night said at intermission, Columbia looks like it doesn't have an offense or, for that matter, a defense. At the time the Lions were trailing Dartmouth, 3117.

title: UNEMPLOYED IN U.S. IN A SLIGHT DECLINE TO 5.8% IN JANUARY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  The Government reported today that 5.8 percent of Americans in the work force had no jobs. in January. The figure represented a slight drop from December but was about the same as that for the last six months.

title: The Politics of More or Less
description: Governor Carey's executive budget weighs six pounds and is bound in gold to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the state's first such document. Weight and color symbolize the Governor's prime problem: he expects the state to be too rich this year to inspire legislative prudence. Yet he believes prudence will be necessary because the good fortune will not last. The Governor is probably right on both counts.

title: Mexico and U.S. Spar on Gas
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 2  With energy expected to be the main topic during President Carter's visit here this month, Mexico seems eager to establish in advance that it does not depend exclusively on the United States either to buy its oil and natural gas or to supply its energy technology.

title: Interstate Bus Fares to Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)  The Interstate Commerce Commission said on Wednesday that it was granting a 5.75 percent increase, effective today, for passenger fares and freight rates for interstate bus lines. Commuter fares are not affected.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Kenneth L. (Tug) Wilson Dies; Headed U.S Olympic Committee
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Feb. 2 (AP)  Kenneth L. (Tug) Wilson, former president of the United States Olympic Committee and commissioner of the Big Ten, died last night at the age of 82 at the Presbyterian Home. Attendants said he had been in the infirmity since Jan. 4 and died from complications of pneumonia.

title: World News Briefs
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 2  The British High Commissioner, Sir John Thomson, was summoned to the Foreign Ministry in New Delhi today to receive a Government protest over a deplorable incident in which an Indian woman was reportedly subjected to a virginity test by the immigration authorities in London.

title: Boston Navy Yard Is Sold for Residential Complex
description: BOSTON, Feb. 2  Officials today unveiled a $200 million urban renewal plan for a residential complex on the site of the abandoned Charlestown Navy Yard in Boston Harbor.

title: REPORT OF MISDEED BY CARTER REJECTED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell has decided that no further investigation or prosecution is warranted into charges that President Carter or a White House aide illegally solicited political contributions at a White House luncheon last August, it was disclosed today.

title: Trying to Try the Letelier Killers
description: It is more than two years since Orlando Letelier, Chile's Foreign Minister and Ambassador to Washington during the Allende era, was murdered along with Ronni Moffitt, his American aide, by a car bomb in Washington. United States prosecutors believe the bombing was ordered by high officials of Chile's secret police agency, then known as the DINA. But these officials remain beyond the reach of justice.

title: A Lull in the Battle for Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 2  The Shah is gone. The Aga is home. Iran has lived through its day of rapture. Yet nothing has really been solved. After 13 months of struggle and strife, it is still unclear who will shape the future of this ancient land, with its strategic position at the junction of East and West and its vast wealth in petroleum.

title: Shah's Presence Causes Stir in Moroccan Pleasure Dome
description: MARRAKESH, Morocco, Jan. 29 Politics has taken precedence over pleasure in this popular winter resort since the arrival last week of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran, his family and part of the royal court. The Shah has settled in for the duration  at least the next three weeks, according to his confidant and former Am bassador to Washington, Ardeshir Zahedi.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1979

title: Sid Vicious, PunkRock Musician, Dies, Apparently of Drug Overdose
description: Sid Vicious, the punkrock musician, died yesterday, apparently of an overdose of heroin, about 13 hours after he was freed on bail in the stabbing murder of a friend, Nancy Spungen.

title: Memorial Expresses Rockefeller Spirit
description: The overriding concern was to create a service that would express something of father's spirit and give those who loved him the opportunity to express that spirit.

title: Corporate Earnings Are Reported for the Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Excnange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: L'Orfeo Sung at Juilliard
description: The first great opera. Monteverdi's L'Orfeo, is more read about than heard and more heard, through concert performances, than seen. On Thursday night at the JuiHiard Theater it was given one of the few stagings it has had in America by the Juilliard American Opera Center, and the result was both delectable and affecting.

title: Suit Heard in Stoppage at Times
description: A judge reserved decision yesterday after hearing a motion by The New York Times for a preliminary injunction to bar the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union from continuing a limited work stoppage at the Times printing plant in Carlstadt, N.J. The judge, Robert W. Sweet, said he would make a decision on Monday in Federal District Court in Manhattan. The dispute is over a plan by management to use one man to monitor a conveyor belt carrying newspapers from a press to delivery trucks. The union wants tour men to be used.

title: OBSERVER
description: If the military draft is resumed, it will probably be broadened to include women. Secretary of Defense Harold Brown said the other day, for exam- ple, that Congress had better consider drafting women if it revives Selective Service. In the present state of equal- rights law, it is hard to see how Con- gress can avoid it.

title: Austria Foreign Minister Injured By Thieves on Strasbourg Street
description: STRASBOURG, France, Feb. 2 (Reuters)  Austria's Foreign Minister, Willibald Pahr, was knocked unconscious on a street here early today by two thieves.

title: Your Money
description: ASHARP increase in the rate at which consumers are letting life insurance policies lapse shortly after buying them has become a major bone of contention between Government regulators and the industry.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ACOUPLE of years ago, suite officials were saying privately that Interstate 287 through Bergen and Passaic Counties probably would never be built.

title: Dentist Will Marry Barbara L. Kaplan
description: Barnett Kaplan of Bayside, Queens, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Barbara Lynne Kaplan; to Dr. Mitchell H. Davich of Kings Point, L.I. Miss Kaplan is a daughter also of the late Rosalyn K. Kaplan.

title: Bard College Taking Over EarlyEntrance School
description: GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass.. Feb.  Simon's Rock College, which accepts its students directly from the 10th grade of high school, is being taken over by Bard College, a regular fouryear college in AnnandaleonHudson. N.Y. Simon's ROCK, the Only purely earlyentrance school in the country, is an extension of a movement in American higher education that has reaped praise but has never fulfilled the promise envisioned by Robert Maynard Hutchins, who, as president of the University of Chicago in the 1930's, began admitting students before they had completed high school.

title: Tax Cuts and Thrift Is Carey's Message to Local Governments
description: ALBANY  Few things delight a politician more than telling another politician how to do his jobunless it is talking about the virtues of cutting taxes and government spending.

title: Kathleen Moriarty Plans a Wedding in May
description: Kathleen MI Moriarty, an options specialist with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, will be married in May to James Phelps Thompson, a New York lawyer.

title: Singles Club Run in House Accused of Zoning Violation
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 3  Lyn Simon, a 41yearold divorced mother of three who said she could not cope with the swinging singles scene after she and a woman friend had been physically threatened by a man in a local nightclub, told a City Court judge this week that she had not violated any laws by operating a singles club in her home.

title: The Iranian Oil Gap
description: Shipments of oil from Iran, which had accounted for up to 10 percent of the nonCommunist world's supplies, have been halted for more than month now, and last week the effects were being felt around the world.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: I am a 13yearold girl writing after reading the article about the disco Guys and Dolls [ TeenAgers Pick Up Disco Beat, Dec. 31]. Ever since Guys and Dolls opened, my parents would not allow me to go there because they considered it a hangout place. After reading your article, I think they may have reconsidered that thought. I am sure many other parents have reamsidered that thought too. Thank you very much.

title: Elections Postponed in Ecuador
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Feb. 3 (Reuters) Ecuador has announced a threeweek postponement of elections that had been scheduled for April 8. The new date, April 29. was set yesterday after four parties requested more time to pick canclidates. The postponement was not expected to affect the surrender of power to a civilian government, which was scheduled for Aug. 10.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Five principals with the Martha Graham Dance Company  Diane Gray, Judith Hogan, Elisa Monte, Peter Sparling and Tim Wengerd  like so many young dancers, wanted to branch out and try their hand at choreography. In an effort to support her aspiring fledglings, Miss Graham has assembled a series of four concerts at Marymount Manhattan College Friday through next Sunday, in which all five will present new works and, in the case of Miss Monte and Messrs. Sparling and Wengerd, perform them. (See Dance)

title: Return From Exile
description: TEHERAN, Iran  At a news conference 10 days ago, Mehdi Bazargan, a close secular ally of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, was asked what he and his mentor had in mind when they spoke about an Islamic republic in Iran. He began his reply by saying what he did not want.

title: ANTIQUES
description: HARTFORD IN 1849, just 20 years after Daniel W. Kellogg opened the first Connecticut lithography shop at 119 Main Street, a reporter for the local paper wrote glowingly that the Kelloggs were receiving orders for colored prints from every part of the United States, and no village or hamlet in our land is without specimens from this establishment.

title: Mr. Teng's Triumph
description: No wonder Teng Hsiaoping did well among us. As the Chinese leader remarked to Shirley MacLaine, there were Olympic medals for political comebacks, he would have a strong claim on the gold. His words referred to his own rises, falls and rises, but like his presence in the United States, they also applied to the new state of relations between his nation and ours: a comeback within a comeback. And he moved through an alien world with a political dexterity that connoisseurs of such deftness in Washington admired.

title: Invitation to an Ordeal: When Some Uninvited Guests Arrive
description: WRILE stopped at an intersection, where my attention was focused on getting my bearings, I did not notice that the door had been opened until my two uninvited guests had settled themselv.

title: SprucedUp Herald Square to Assert Itself
description: Herald Square is undergoing major surgery. Several renovation and conversion projects are already in process and other significant public and private improvements are also planned in a combined effort to enhance the area's gateway function in the city. Despite the intusion of some new investments about decade ago, such as the Madison Square Garden complex, Korvette's and One Penn Plaza, the Herald Square area has maintained a rather drab and disheveled look, and this has led much of the city's growth in recent years to pass it by.

title: France Casts Industry Into Competitive Waters
description: PARIS FRANCE will test some economic theories in 1979 as the Government pushes ahead with its controversial campaign to modernize industry in preparation for the tougher world trading conditions it sees in the 1980's. we cannot pretend, said Prime Minister Raymond Barre when the program was initiated last summer, that the future of France depends on the number of ships we sell at a loss or the volume of steel and textiles we make and cannot sell.

title: REGIONS
description: TORONTO ABANKER rose to greet a foreign visitor in his skyscraper office here the other day: Welcome to the Balkans, he said. He was joking, of course, about the world's secondlargest nation, but it does often seem an apt description for the many economies of a troubled Canada.

title: LEGAL TANGLES MIRE CALIFORNIA CHURCH
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 3  The 46yearold Worldwide Church of God, which seems to go from one crisis to another, has in the last few weeks found itself entangled in more litigation, dissension and controversy.

title: Ann Edwards Betrothed to Donald Fragale
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Parker F. Edwards of Lahaina, Maui, Hawaii, of the engagement of Mr. Edwards's daughter, Ann Ferguson Edwards, to Donald Joseph Fragale, son of Emma Fragale of Joliet, Ill., and the late Joseph Fragale.

description: Article 10 -- No Title

description: Julius Erving, Phil., forward Rudy Tom la novich, Hou., forward Moses Malone, Hou., center George Gervin, S.A., guard Pete Maravich, N.O., guard

title: Letter TO THE EDITOR
description: Getting Back In Toads Anatole Broyard's sensitive description of his selfencounter through dance (It's Your Move, Dec. 17) captures the subtle yet profound impact of movement on the self, by describing how movement exploration can increase selfawareness and can begin and support the process of change.

title: China Glosses Over Visit's Flaws
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 3  Rodeo: It is one of the three American contributions to world sports, the others being baseball and basketball.

title: REGIONS
description: TEHERAN. IRAN AN Arab deputy minister of oil who attended the OPEC pricefixing conference at Abu Dhabi last December was asked his reaction to the turmoil that brought Iranian oil exports to a halt. lie reflected for a while and said. The one thought that keeps coming back is that it could have happened to any of us.

title: Sugar Refinery Reaches Accord For 7 Percent New Orleans Raise
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 3 (AP)  The Amstar Corporation, the nation's secondlargest sugar refinery, has reached a tentative agreement with the union representing workers at its refinery in New Orleans.

title: United Airlines Accord 1 Averts Machinist Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UPI)  Negotiators for United Airlines and the union representing 18,000 maintenance workers have reached tentative agreement on a new contract, averting a threatened strike that could have stranded up to 111,000 daily passengers, it was announced today.

title: What Parents Don't Say About Sex
description: MOST of the time, said Dr. John H. Gagnon, our focus on sexuality has been on the acute problems  venereal disease, teenage pregnancy. But the real costs of sexual ignorance are invisible. They're in relationships between husbands and wives in terms of sexual disfunction. They're in terms of the sort of anger you see in men about women and in women about men, which is partially. based on our sexual values.

title: A Sanctuary for Outsiders
description: LTITLE magazines - independent and often shortlived literary journals existing on small subsidies, small (sometimes almost nonexistent) circulation and large hopes - have been so much a part of the folklore of modern literature for so long that it comes as something of a surprise that their history has been so little studied and written about. The careers of certain writers now deemed central to the modern movement in literatureespecially the poets Ezra Pound, T. S. Eliot, William Carlos Williams and Wallace Stevens, to name only the most illustrious of large band - are virtually inseparable from the littlemagazine phenomenon. It was in these sometimes elegant, sometimes plain an often ephemeral journals that their work first appeared, and it was in the little magazines that it was first seriously discussed, praised and challenged. The journals may have perished it is in the nature of little magazines to do sobut they have left, along with a record of incredible foolishness, crankiness, vanity and innocence, a rich heritage of literary achievement.

title: U.S. and Iran Seeking To Cancel Arms Deals Of at Least $8 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3  High Defense Department officials said tonight that Pentagon envoys in Teheran were working out an agreement with the Iranian Government involving the cancellation or suspension of $8 billion to $10 billion in orders for United States arms and military hardware.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249, or to any of the following organizations:

title: United Press International
description: HANDS UP: Nets George Johnson, left, and Eric Money, and Portland's Maurice Lucas pursuing rebound In game at Portland Friday. Nets dropped fourth in four nights, 117100

title: Rex Redux
description: HERE is the end of the book of King Arthur, and of his noble knights of the Round Table. And here is the end of the death of Arthur. How wrong Malory was! Long after he wrote the conclusion of Morte d'Arthur, Tennyson and T. E. White, among others, miraculously brought Arthur's death to life again. Since 1973, when Mary Stewart published her popular version of the legend in The Hollow Hills, we have witnessed such a gathering of pages on the theme that were they Picts and Saxons they would form an army large enough to overwhelm even such a wellfortified castle as Camelot: Steinbeck's rendering of Matory: the recently discovered conclusion to The Once and Future King; Richard Monaco's questing Parsival ; Thomas Berger's brilliant Arthur Rex; and now The Pendragon by the English novelist Catherine Christian.

title: Correction
description: A production error garbled an anecdote in Michael Steinberg's review of Stravinsky in Pictures and Documents (Jan. 28). The sentence should have read: :.. Mr. Craft tells the story of how the Library of Congress received his [Stravinsky's] holograph of Apollo, and returned it with a request for the original, not a copy.

title: Number of Strikes in 78 Reached a 13Year Low
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP)  The number of strikes called by labor unions in 1978 fell to a 13year low, but the number of lost working days rose because of long coal and railroad strikes, the Labor Department has reported.

title: Agriculture College Enrollments
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Feb. 3 (UPI)  A survey of 2,382 students at 14 of the nation's largest agricultural schools indicates a lot of city residents want to become farmers. The survey disclosed that 35 percent of all agricultural students came from metropolitan areas of 50,000 or more population, while those who grew up on a farm or ranch represented 30 percent. The remainder were from small towns or cities with under 50,000 population.

title: Chuck Berry, Carl Perkins Perform With Sha Na Na
description: Sha Na Na is music from the 50's played by people who barely remember the 50' s for people who are too young to remember Simi Hendrix. When the group first got together at Columbia University, the idea of a bunch of college kids sporting 50's haircuts and singing Get a Job seemed quaint. Ten years later, the 50's are big business, and Sha Na Na is an institution. For the audience that packed Radio City Music Hall to see them Friday night, or at least for the majority of it that was preteenage, Sha Na Na is the 50's.

title: Of Cool Man and a Puddle of Steel
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Like modern knightserrant. traveling construction workers seek their fortunes alliony, the country's big Indust rial jobs. As a pipe welder working my way back to California after a visit in New York, I saw an especially attractive opportunity in the Zimmer nuceleat power plant that is going up in the Ohio River valley.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: MASS MARKET

title: ABOUT CARS Getting Started On Cold Mornings
description: FOR drivers, cold and snow are right in there with the rest of the fourletter words, and morning can be a time for nightmares. Windshields need scraping, locks are frozen, and cold metal and syrupy oil conspire to keep engines from starting.

title: Drama on Vietnam Broadway Bound
description: WASHINGTON  The play is dedicated to four soldiers  Dawson, Green, Miller and Morales  who were killed when an American tank shell misfired and exploded over their bunker in Vietnam.

title: Teng Speaks of Plans For Imports in Billions
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 3  Teng Hsiaoping, China's Deputy Prime Minister, arrived in Seattle this evening, on the last stop of his American visit, after having told a Houston audience that China would need billions of dollars in foreign exchange, possibly scores of billions, in the next few years to carry out its modernization plans.

title: William Stuchell 3d to Wed Jane C. Patrick
description: The engagement of Jane Celeste Patrick, daughter of Willis Warren Patrick of Morehead City, N.C.. and the late Mrs. Patrick, to William Torrence Stuchell 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuchell Jr. of Darien, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's father. The couple reside in Annapolis, Md., where a March wedding is planned.

title: How to Raise $30 Million, Fast
description: Issuing commercial paper has become almost a part of the daily routine for many corporate financial executives. So when Pepsico Inc. decided it wanted to sell about $a8 million in corninercial paper last Friday, no special preparations were necessary. Early that morning. Richard Leberman, assistant treasurer at Pepsico, called Michelle Kelly, a vice president at Salomon Brothers, the company's commercial paper dealers, to discuss market conditions and place the order.

description: Birth Notice 4 -- No Title

title: Hotel Cooling Towers Suspected In Legionnaire Disease Outbreak
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 3 (AP)  Air circulating through cooling towers for an airconditioning system may have carried legionnaires disease bacteria into six Dallas hotels last August, causing 18 cases of the illness, public health officials have said.

title: CARTER SCANS PLAN ON NEW U.S. AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3  President Carter is expected to decide next week whether to propose the creation of a Cabinetlevel department of development assistance, which would incorporate the economic development activities of several agencies.

title: Daytona 24 Hours: Money, Noise
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 3 When the socalled eagles of auto racing set forth on an endurance test, as they did here today in the 24 Hours of Daytona, money talks with a growl, whine and a scream.

title: The Region
description: It's Pruning Time As 3 States Get Their 1980 Budgets; The Fiscal Gap Closes a Little; Voting Isn't Like Drinking; A Jolting Reminder Of Earth's Frailty; Michael Wright and Alvin Davis.

title: Strike Wave Is Swamping Britain
description: LONDON, Feb. 3  With 17 London hospitals facing a walkout Monday and 95,000 British Leyland workers prepared to strike because disruptions by others have prevented them from earning productivity bonuses, no end to Britain's long wave of strikes is in sight.

title: Long Island This Week
description: EAST ISLIP - Watercolors, acrylics by June K. Ciancio; paintings by Dorothy Leitch Rowlinson; through Feb. 28; Library, 381 E. Main St. For hours, 5819200.

title: Mailbox: Politics and Boxing
description: ??? the Spurts Editor: I enjoyed Michael Katz's recent story, Is Holmes Too Good a Boxer? Along with other recent developments in heavyweight boxing, Katz's article reflects the reality that politics is very much a part of this sport (and others), and that the notion that politics should not be mixed with sports is farcical.

title: PEOPLE
description: Some 900 of Ma Bell's 950,000 employees  from the top brass to maintenance workers  were waiting to bid farewell to John D. deButts, A.T. & T.'s chairman, on the occasion of his retirement last week. Mr. deButts, who was hired as a telephone traffic student 43 years ago at $100 a month, leaves his post a year earlier than the mandatory retirement age of 65. He is succeeded by Charles L. Brown, the former president. William Ellinghaus, a vice chairman, becomes president. The fare. well festivities, at the corpbrate headquarters in lower Manhattan. were highspirited. As one of Mr. deButts's associates said, he is a very jovial person and it is difficult to be somber around him.

title: Ford to Redesign Transmissions Cited in 23 Deaths
description: DETROIT, Feb. 3  The Ford Motor Company, under Government investigation because of allegations that 23 deaths may have been caused by Ford automatic transmissions accidentally slipping from the park position into reverse. has confirmed that it plans to change the design of its automatic transmissions for 1980.

title: Contractor Halts Virginia Offshore Oil Facility Plan, Citing Lack of Success in Atlantic
description: CAPE CHARLES, Va., Feb. 3  A dispute over Virginia's promotion of a major offshore oil facility here appears to have ended with the withdrawal of a company tKat had planned a $45 million facility for ??bricating ocean drilling rigs.

title: Jensen Helps Kings Subdue Rangers, 49
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 3  Steve Jensen scored the tiebreaking goal for Los Angeles on a 30foot slap shot five minutes into the third period and the Kings held off every New York Ranger charge to score a 42 National Hockey League victory tonight.

title: Is the Dollar Sign A Sign of the Times For Our Schools?
description: OVER the last several months, much of the discussion concerning education in New Jersey has centered on financial matters. This is perhaps inevitable, given the climate of opinion in the state and in the nation as a whole.

title: Queens Women Defeat New Hampshire by 9269
description: Queens College defeated the University of New Hampshire, 9269, in women's basketball at Queens yesterday. The Queens squad broke open the game with 8 straight points in a span of 1 minute 24 seconds take a 3120 lead.

title: MAILBAG
description: To the Editor: Iadmire much of the work of my successor as chairman of the board of City Center, John Samuels ["Samuels: A New Force on the Art Scene, Jan. 28, by John Corry], along with the operating leadership president John Mazzola has given Lincoln Center.

title: REGIONS
description: JOHANNESBURG WHILE most of the rest of Africa struggles to feed itself, South Africa builds jet fighters, computers and, some say, even nuclear weapons. Yet 100 years after the first strike on a rocky ridge near here, the kingpin of Africa's most sophisticated economy is still gold.

title: ART VIEW
description: The art of sculpture is now so different from what it once was, it's now so firmly established in areas of visual discourse not formerly considered sculptural  or even esthetic  that we tend to forget the enormous distance this art has traversed in a matter of a decade or two. Living in a culture in which new artistic practices quickly acquire the status conventions has obvious advantages, of course  particularly for artists working to roll back the boundaries of the esthetically permissable  but it has the disadvantage of blunting the sense of surprise that used to attend every significant change in art.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: One of the great historic putdowns  in intention, at any rate  was the remark once addressed by King George III of England to the author of The Decline and Fall of Ancient Rome. Scribble, scribble, scribble, eh ? was  the royal assessment of Gibbon's activity. To people who value action above all things there is something absurd about a man who spends his whole life holding a pen and sitting in front of a piece of paper. Penpusher has long been an insult in AngloSaxon countries, and even the attempt to master a fine italic hand has now a rearguard quality. Writing for pleasure grows rarer year by year; and, like the householder who stuffs a pillow with down from his own geese, the penman is a member of a threatened species.

title: Epidemic Feared as Infant Deaths Mount in Naples
description: ROME, Feb. 3  An undiagnosed disease that has killed at least 56 Infants In the Naples area during the last nine months has touched off fears of a new epidemic in the dank, filthy and overcrowded slums of the city.

title: Wntd: Nice Apt for Yng Man, Reas  N.A.*
description: If the Island doesn't come up with additional rental housing, it could buffer an exodus of those residents who make up the Island's future.

title: St. John's Women Win
description: LingLing Hou, a junior forward, set an Alumni Hall record for a St. John's women's basketball player by pumping in 32 points as the Express rolled to 7256 victory over Boston University yesterday.

title: Upsala 96, York 68
description: EAST ORANGE, N.J. - Mike Booker's 31 points paced Upsala to a 9668 victory over York tonight. It was the ninth straight victory for Upsala and improved its record to 152. York, now 514. waS called for five technical fouls, three against Coach Norm Lefldcawitz, who was ejected from the game with 20 seconds 1.i:ft in the first half.

title: Sunday Observer
description: At 6:17 P.M. on the subway leaving Times Square I experience a wave of pain. It radiates up the left leg. I am careful not to show alarm, but keep my glassy stare fixed immobile on nothing.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 9:30 A.M. (Channel 9) Nine on New Jersey: New Jersey leaders forecast trends for the new year; a report on arson; a medical research institute in New Jersey where cellS with genetic diseases can be frozen and stored; treasurehunting club in New Brunswick.

title: WESTCHESTET Ruling A waited on Resale Warranties
description: REALTORS and their c.u:,,tni ers are awaiting a court derision that could give thorn something already available in adjoining states: vvarralities or, ru'sale houses.

title: Grotesques &
description: IN Mortal Consequences, his distinguished study of detective fiction, Julian Symons states that the best Victorian mysteries were those that assumed memorable characters and stories to be as important as ingenious puzzles. The Blackheath Poisonings, Mr. Symons own attempt at a Victorian mystery, makes the same assumption, with delightful results.

title: School Service Workers Vote Authority to Strike
description: Members of a union representing 4,500 cleaning, maintenance and heatingplant employees at New York City's 990 public schools voted by acclamation yesterday to strike at the discretion of the group's negotiating committee.

title: LETTERS
description: American Poets To the Editor: Many thanks for Denis Donoghue's hilarious article, Does America Have a Major Poet? (Dec. 3). To read of Robert Penn Warren's refusal to be great or Elizabeth Bishop's disposition to be minor, gives rise to a splendidly original critical conceit. The inevitable conclusion, of course, is that there are no major poets in America  only major critics, like Mr. Donoghue. What an elegant illustration of what John Ashbery has called a tongueandcheek attitude on the part of the perpetrators.

title: Cabby Is Fatally Shot In His Taxi in Queens; 22 Pistol Is Recovered
description: A 30yearold cab driver was shot and fatally wounded in his taxi on a residential street in Queens late Friday night, apparently by one of two men who tried to rob him but who panicked after the shooting and fled, leaving behind what was believed to be the murder weapon on the floor of the cab.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: WILL advertising on the outside of the new buses the county is acquiring make them esthetically less attractive and discourage the public from using them?

title: Why Profs Can't Write
description: IRVINGTONONHUDSON, N.Y. 1.ike most of my friends in book publishing I groan when I get a thick package from a university.

title: INTERVIEW
description: FOUR years ago, when Dr. Arthur Anderson, associate professor of sociology at Fairfield University, set out to put the town of Fairfield under the microscope for a study of the fragmentation of American society as seen through the flourishing of its multiplicity of churches, he hardly anticipated the degree of prejudice, resentment, hostility and selfcentered materialism that he says he found among church members.

title: New Jersey/ This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets) - Long Day's JourDey Into Night, in an Actor's CafTheater Production. Thursday through Saturday, 8 P.M $048.50; students. and the elderly, R. 5054.50 (201) 4297662. Westminster Theater.

title: Signs and Symbols
description: THESE are still the Banquet Years in France, though not everyone will savor the feast of books and essays produced there since 1945. One might have thought that JeanPaul Sartre. Claude lkviStrauss and Maurice MerleauPonty had exhausted a certain vein. Philosophy and literature invaded each other's realm; science mingled with cut. tural criticism. Yet Jacques Derrida, Michel FouEssays. By Roland Barthes. Selected and translated by Stephen Heath. 220 pp. New York: Hill and Wang. Cloth, $8.95. Paper, $4.95. cault, Roland Barthes and others are still taking on linguistics, semiotics, structuralism, sociology and psychoanalysis. New and fantastic words appear on the scene to express this mixture of disciplines: economimesis, anasematics, mimology. It a heady period of scribbledihobble.

title: Miss Bradley to Face Mrs. Carner in Final
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 3 With Nancy Lopez gone since round one, it will be the best of the old guard against the best of the new as JoAnne Carner, going on 40, faces Pat Bradley in the final tomorrow of the Triple Crown Ladies Professional Golf Association championship at Mission Hitic.

title: BUSINESS Will Higher Oil Prices Stand Up?
description: WHEN the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries decided on a series of price increases for 1979 that will add up to a hefty 19.5 percent, it was to some extent seizing an opportunity presented by the partial cutback in Iranian production. Then, exports from Iran halted altogether, depriving the outside world of some 5 million barrels of oil a day, or nearly 10 percent of the nonCommunist nations total needs. Now, with Iranian production still far from normal, a lot of experts have concluded that still higher prices may be on the way. A lot, but not all.

title: Paul Woodford to Wed Mary Jo Egan in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roger E Egan of Bloomington, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Jo Egan of New York, to Paul A. Woodford, a thirdyear law student at Catholic University in Washington. An August wedding is planned.

title: Art The Island's Artistic Discoverer Rediscovered
description: STONY BROOK THIS is a period in American art history when no radical new movement is preoccupying us and when many of the participants in past movements are being reevalUated. We are finding that, in addition to the wellknown luminaries of the major schools, a goodly number of letser likes - some quite celebrated in their., day - were making creative headway against a tide of indifference to native art and artists that persisted wellinto this century.

title: Medicine An Added Punishment Is Poor Health Care
description: WASHINGTONAll too often, a prison sentence carries with it an added form of punishment, not imposed by any judge and bearing no relation to the original crime. The extra penalty is the denial of adequate medical care.

title: That Women Be Themselves
description: Nits author's own words, This is an extremist book, written in a situation of extremity, written on the edge of a culture that is killing itself and all of sentient life. This is also a book with spiritual and intellectual history, its extremism earned by a process undergone and reflected upon; it did not sorinE rullIfeagen from nowhere, or come into being without a harsh and necessary journey, of which it is in part description. In a period in which the women's movement, or some aspects of it, has caught on enough to create a few instant if meretricious bestsellers, Mary Daly's new work stands in a different category: It never evades or compromises the complexity of extremism.

title: Boston College 71, Fordham 64
description: BOSTON, Feb. 3  Ernie Cobb and Mike Bowie led a 142 surge that helped Boston College rally to defeat Fordham, 7164, tonight. Fordham led, 4948, with 8 minutes remaining. Cobb then scored 6 points and Bowie had 8 as Boston College (184) took a 5251 edge.

title: Saucy Spring Suits
description: Remember when a suit used to be a tailoredtoatrimT sort of thing? Well, this season, designers have added some contradictions decollete blouses, legrevealing slashed skirts, tippy hats to wear with pants suits, and lace touches that give city suits a provocative new turn. Worn the right way, at the right time, in the right place, they're a decidedly attractive addition to the spring fashion scene.

title: Volunteers to Give Free Tax Tips
description: Forty volunteer counselors, many of them retired business people with experience in tax matters, will be offering free incometax advice to retirees beginning Tuesday at four locations in Westchester, according to George Slocum, coordinator for the TaxAide Proeram.

title: Recurring Strikes Last Week Could Influence Britain's Next Election
description: LONDON  Although most Britons are upset by the strikes of the past few weeks, which have disrupted the economy and last week interfered with such public services as schools, hospitals, and huhals, the idled ambulances, uncollected garbage and delayed truck deliveries were good news of a sort for at least one important group  the Conservative Party, which will challenge Prime Minister James Callaghan's Labor Government in a national election some time this year. All this mess has improved our chances, no doubt about it, William Whitelaw, the deputy leader of the party, said. Last fall we thought we could win, but just now we are sure of it. Mr. Whitelaw's optimism is supported by a recent Gallup Poll giving the Conservatives a 7 percent lead, and by many Britons, including some in Mr. Callaghan's own. Labor Party. If the Conservatives win, Britain's next Prime Minister will be Margaret Thatcher, a 53yearold tax lawyer who has been attacking the Government with increasing vigor in recent weeks, demanding, as she put it in one speech, that if Mr. Callaghan cannot do anything to end the crisis, he should step aside for a party that will.

title: Islanders Tie Bruins, 44, on Nystrom Goal
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 3  The Islanders and the Boston Bruins played you score, I score hockey tonight at Nassau Coliseum, and since the Bruins scored first, the Islanders had to catch up four times before the game ended in a 44 deadlock.

title: A Fable of Power
description: MAKING novels out of the holocaust has proved to be a hopelessly selfcontradictory enterprise for most writers. The conventional novel, with its formal coherence of beginning, middle and end, betrays this subject, which by its nature destroys coherence in our understanding of history, theology, moral choice and human character. Leslie Epstein's quietly controlled, eerily lucid novel (his third work of fiction; he is the author of P.D. Kimerakov and The Steinway Quintet Plus Four) is remarkable for choosing an aspect of the subject and developing a special narrative mode that overcome the intrinsic difficulty of coping imaginatively with genocide.

title: Births
description: Hollis and Ann (nee Kerr) Sobers joyfully announce the birth of their daughter Hollann JoII on September 18. 1978. Proud grandparents are Mrs Ena Sobers and Mr and Mrs John Kerr.

title: SMALLPDX IS NOT DEAD
description: We take off our watches, bracelets, rings and other personal possessions, and my host, Dr. James Nakano, locks them away. We walk clown a hall from his cluttered office to an unmarked wooden door. He unlocks it.

title: Depression Victim
description: TO one who, like myself, first experienced the excitements of politics following the New Deal, the very name of Herbert Hoover comes with bitter taste. We were learning, in 1932 and the years immediately after, what public life could be: an arena in which men and ideas were reshaping the world, and where each morning's newspaper read like the first chapter of Genesis. On the sidelines then was Herbert Hoover, bitter, reactionary, insensitive; and flocking to his banner were the tired men who seemed at odds with everything hopeful and creative in American life. Yet all things have their season; if there was a time assail Hoover there is also a time to look at him with fresh eyes. And Prof. David Burner's book is an excellent means to that end.

title: Education
description: Daniel Goodwin finished high school in Los, Angeles in 1969, moved to the East Coast and went to work at a succession of jobs. Two years ago, he decided to become a lawyer. He took the Law School Aptitude Test, attaining the highest score possible S00. Every law school he applied to turned him down because he had never attended college.

title: Ellen Ginder Fine, Buyer, Wed to Sidney Weinberg
description: Ellen Ginder Fine and Sidney Lawrence Weinberg were married yesterday in New York at the bride's home by Judge John Turret of the Family Court of New York.

title: The Library Starts Fund Drive With Ad Campaign on Buses
description: Faced with increasing shortages of money and personnel, the New York Public Library is starting this year's fundraising efforts for its research libraries by mounting an advertising campaign on the city's buses with the slogan: It costs a lot to keep the library free.

title: Last Week They Booed Teng
description: While United States officials, businessmen and journalists competed for the attentions of Teng Hsiaoping last week, another crowd jostled to denounce the Chinese Communist leader. Surprisingly, the most virulent among them had nothing to say about Taiwan.

title: Old and Worn These Things May Be, but Still the Heart Grows Fonder
description: Rudi Crespi is a welltailored Italian count, involved in fashion and editor of Brazilian Vogue. He isn't into garbage, but some situations require drastic action. One such situation arose the day his countess took his beige sweater and pitched it you know where.

description: Auto Racing The 24hour endurance race cars ends today at Daytona International Speedway in Daytona Beach, Fla. The $100,000 qualifying sprints for the Daytona 500 are scheduled there next Sunday.

title: AYATOLLAH STEPS UP PRESSURE ON REGIME TO BOW OUT IN IRAN
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 3  Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini said today that his revolutionary movement had drafted a republican constitution for Iran and that he would soon disclose the composition of an Islamic council in defiance of Prime Minister Shahour Bakhtiar.

description: NEWARK THE weather forecast said, Heavy rain starting at midday and continuing through the evening, with some flooding in lowlying areas. And that's the way it turned out.

title: Jill Fowler Fiance Of Matthew Dragiff
description: The engagement of Jill Courtney Fowler, a senior at Smith College, to Matthew A. Dragiff, a senior at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, has been announced by Miss Fowler's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Fowler of New York and Quechee, Vt. Mr. Dragiff is a son of Dr. and Mrs. David A. Dragiff of New Canaan. Conn. The wedding is planned for June in Quechee.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: ISLAND PARK LOBSTER tales. There's the one about the guy in the restaurant who orders a lobster and is upset when the waiter brings him one with only one claw.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: More than 100 examples of 28 calligraphers fine italic hand are on view at the Danbury Library, 170 Main Street. through March 17. Among the contributors is Jeanyee Wong, who has practiced the art since her graduation from Cooper Union in 1941. I don't know why I love to do it, or why it has become so popular in the last four years or soperhaps it's because people are going back to natural things. They are so impressed when they receive a beautifully handwritten letter, or even the address on an envelope.

title: Amateur Archeologists Turn Up Surprises
description: BONE chips, flaked stones and oystershell heaps may seem like dull treasures compared to the tombs of Tutankhamun, but for the members of Westchester's Museum and Laboratory for Archeology they are precious indeed.

description: A jury in Westchester County Court convicted a White Plains woman of murder yesterday in the death of her husband, a prominent physician who was killed with a shot in the head Sept. 24, 1976.

title: Looking Behind Lawyer's Image Turns Up Some Contradictions
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23  The credentials presented by Mark Lane to his client, the People's Temple, were impressive, judging from a biography that rested in the Temple's filesine olograpay quotea r rea J. ry Icnoi, a Federal judge from South Dakota. as describing Mr. Lane as the finest investigator in the country. It went on to note that Mr. Lane had been a member of the New York State Legislature, had managed John F. Kennedy's 1960 Presidential campaign in the New York City area and had been a professor of law at Catholic University in Washington, D.C.

title: REGIONS
description: NEW DELHI INDIA, once a symbol of poverty, is forging a place for itself among the industrialized nations of the 20th century. Industrial and agricultural production are up comfortably from a year ago, and the country is growing enough grain to feed its peoplebut not to feed them particularly well.

title: BUSINESS
description: Britain's average daily oil production, 1.1 million barrels; proved reserves, 18 billion barrels.

title: HOME CLINIC Protecting Yourself From Plaster Debris
