There is also the annoying job of getting out a vacuum to clean up the dust and chips:

title: Korea's tourism: Confidence in future
description: Kores's travel industry moved into 1977 with a feeling of accomplishment and excitement. Last year, the longsought goal of achieving one million tourist arrivals pet year was reached on November 27 when Mrs. Barbara Johnson, an American house. wife visiting Korea with her husband, Col. Arthur Johnson (Ret.), was surprised and delighted by the fanfare attending her arrival, including VIP tours of the country and the prize of a roundtheworld air ticket.

title: SYRIA
description: Low per capita income, social unrest, and political instability were the main characteristics that described Syria in the fifties and sixties. And although the distribution of income was better than what was prevalent in the Middle East it was considered bad compared to what was known in the developed economies.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Snow cover can be seen under mostly clear skies from western New England through the lakes region. Snow cover can also be seen In the Northern Plains States and in the northern Rockies. Mostly clear skies prevail over the South Atlantic States.

title: Iona 91, St. Francis 70
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. (AP) Iona outscored St. Francis of Brooklyn, 1710, during a fourminute stretch of the second half tonight and went on to a 9170 victory behind Jeff Ruland's 20 points and 14 rebounds.

title: Corporate Strategies for Global Enterprises
description: The world's largest steelmaker with $8.9 billion in sales, Japan's NIPPON STEEL, its mills running at only 70 percent of capacity and desperately trying to expand its export market in the face of protectionism in the United States, lower demand in Europe and rising competition from thirdworld producers, reached what was described as the biggestever trade agreement between Japan and China. The company announced a $2 billion contract to build near Shanghai, China's first fully modern steel complex.

title: Vilas, Borg Advance To Richmond Final
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 3 (UPI)  Guillermo Vilas, seeded second, moved into the final of the $175,000 Richmond World Championship of Tennis tournament tonight with a 63, 64 victory over Arthur Ashe.

title: Wayne Lawrence Is Fianc Of Elizabeth Brady Smith
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Philip W. Smith Jr. of Far Hills, N.J., and Tenants Harbor, Me., of the engagement of their daughter, Flizabeth Brady Smith, to Wayne Lawrence, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alex L. Lawrence of Valley Stream, L.I.

title: Definitions Have Changed, and So Have Goals, but There Are Some Successes
description: Thirty years after Congress opened the Treasury to the nation's cities for urban renewal, admiration and criticism abound for the programs that altered 100 cities and many million lives. What is undisputed is that urban renewal has traveled a tortuous path since Title 1 of the Federal Housing Act was passed and that the 1949 lawmakers would probably have difficulty recognizing what they wrought.

title: New York State Is Suing Officials in Catskills Over the Tax Exemptions for Ministers Ordained by Mail
description: Nearly two and a half years ago, more than half the property owners of the little Catskills town of Hardenburgh, watching their taxes rise with an influx of taxexempt churches and other institutions, became ordained ministers of a cnurcn mat confers degrees by mail so that they, too, could receive taxexempt status.

title: From Doowop to Shlock Rock
description: Every trade has its tools; a writer's tools are words. Most words are in common usage, and most of those that aren't are readily explained in any dictionary. But in the trade of rockmusic criticism, the dictionaries, timebound and stodgy as they are, aren't always of help. Yet the writer can hardly be expected to stop and identify every word he or she uses every time one comes up that may not be readily familiar to the reader.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: ONE of the truly original and beguiling books of 1978 was Bruce Chatwin's In Patagonia, which may be described as a travel book. Such a designation will indicate its place on library shelves but won't convey its charm.

title: Nancy Ireland Sets June Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Livingston Ireland 3d of New York and Millbrook, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Ireland, to William Warren Stahl Jr., son of Mrs. Stahl of Dalton, Pa., and the late Mr. Stahl.

title: New Vogue for Victorian Art
description: Twentyfive years ago, in the heyday of the Abstract Expressionist movement, who would have dreamed that we would one day witness the wholesale rehabilitation of everything in painting that represents the opposite of the avantgarde ideal? Yet this is exactly what is now occurring in the revival of Victorian painting and its counterpart in the art of 19thcentury French academicians - a revival that has been gaining serious momentum for more than a decade and that marks the most significant reversal of taste in art since the modernist movement first acquired a sizable public following several generations ago.

description: SEEDCATALOGUE brwsing opens up wide possibilities on what plants to grow. The catalogues offer all kinds of fascinating things. For instance, how many gardeners in this area grow house. plants from seeds? You can.

description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Feb. 3 (AP) Brig. Gen. Richard F. Petercheff, commander of the Indiana Air National Guard, was killed yesterday when his plane crashed on landing at Holman Field. auard officials said.

title: NEW JERSEY ROUSING
description: YOU'RE sitting around a glowing fireplace with some friends and feeling mellow. Pretty soon, the conversation turns to Soandso just paid $85,000 for that house down the block! or Soandso just sold his house for twice what he paid for it five years ago!

description: 1. Plunge of the dollar unsettles world monetary system.

title: Jobs Are the Major Concern for NuclearShipyard Town
description: KITTERY, Me., Feb. 3  The heart of this town is Alice's, a beery waterfront bar and restaurant profitably situated outside the main gate of the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard here. And Jack Conlon is Alice's husband. So when Mr. Conion leans ms oelly over the counter and says, I'm not moving out of here until my hair starts to fall out, that means something in Kittery.

title: Preparing a Young Child for Travel Alone
description: Getting off at the wrong station, losing tickets, finding yourself without money, not being met, encountering scary strangers  these are the stuff of nightmares. When such experiences befall a child, real damage can result.

title: Rodino Spurs Drive to Continue U.S. Aid
description: WASHINGTON REPRESENTATIVE Peter W. Rodin of Newark, with the support so far of SO colleagues in the House, has begun a new effort to revive plans for continued countercyclical aid.

title: Mary A. Daliman To Be Wed June 2
description: Col. James Howard Dallman, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Dallman of Lake Forest, Ill., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mary Arnold Dallman. to Robert James Boyer of Lake Forest, formerly of Newark. The wedding is planned for June 2.

title: Player's Quest Leads To Jazz Panorama
description: WESTHAMPTON THE best jazz musicians, like good wrestlers, are hard to pin down. They generally view standing in one place as singularly uninteresting, even artistically dangerous. They prefer to keep moving, extending triedandtrue musical techniques, looking for new openings.

title: Intensity of Blacks Pigmentation Is Seen as Factor in Blood Pressure
description: DETROTT, Feb. 3 (UPI)  For blacks, the darker the skin color, the greater the odds of having high blood pressure, says a social psychologist, Ernest Harburg, who conducted a 10year study of 1.000 Detroit residents in four segregated neighborhoods.

title: A Prophet Returns To His Own Land With Honor
description: Like Lenin returning to Russia after the overthrow of the Czar, Ayatollah Ruhollat iChomeini came home last week to complete his own very different form of revolution.

title: Defining Women's Issues Splits the Administration and Its Former Feminist Supporters
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  President Carter met today with Marjorie Bell Chambers, acting chairman of the National Advisory Committee for Women, and told her that he expected her panel to be independent but to stick to women issues.

title: $6 Million for Tobacco Interests Spent in Coast Drive on Smoking
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3 (UPI)  A record high for a California political campaign, $6 million, was spent by the nation's tobacco industry to defeat the smoking initiative last November, campaign records disclosed today.

description: REGIONS

description: HARTFORD Acourtordered revision of the way Connecticut finances its public schools, probably the most difficult problem facing the General Assembly this session, is encountering new difficulties that may make it even harder to solve than originally expected.

description: These poems and drawings are the work of elementaryschool students in the Creative Arts in Education program sponsored by the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford. The work is taken from a booklet titled 16 Toes, published by the center.

title: The Art of Watching Winter's Flock
description: Afriend from New York City stopped by recently. Always like to spend a little time in the country when I can, he said, meaning, I suppose, Connecticut. To a resident of the Big Apple, even Fairfield County seems like the outback. Later he looked the window and cried, Oh, look! What kind of bird is that? I've never seen that kind before!

description: DOBBS FERRY  Three oneact plays, produced, written, directed and acted by students of Dobbs Ferry High School Student Plays Group. Friday and Saturday at 8:15 P.M. Highschool auditorium. 6939462.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3  A mistrial was declared today in Federal District Court in the trial of Representative Daniel J. Flood on 11 charges of bribery, conspiracy and perjury.

title: If You Go
description: on Washington's Metrorail system, you will find that all entrances to stations are marked with a bronze pylon with an illuminated Mon all four sides. The station name is at the entrance.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: The Administration announced last week that the nation's trade deficit for 1978 rose to a record $28.45 billion, up from $26.7 billion in 1977. But Government economists clung to their predictions that the trade gap would narrow this year.

title: REGIONS More Soviet Energy Needed To Power The Economy
description: MOSCOW SOVIET production of oil and coal in 1479 is expected to fall short of projections for the second straiglft year, imposing limits on industrial growth and forcing the Russians to look to United States technology for help in finding and tapping new energy sources.

title: 5 Towns join in Opposing Con Ed's OverheadLine Plan
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR A COUPLE of months ago as Annette Theoharides looked out over the winter grayness that had settled over the small enclave of the $50,000to -$150,000 houses on Washburn Road here; she recalled recently, she began feeling smug. Although her home for 13 years had been just east of the Taconic Parkway and just west of the rightofway of electrictransmission lines running from Kent in Putnam County to Millwood just to the south, she and her neighbors were surrounded by ponds and trees that seemed to insulate them.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Tomorrow sees a big new production at the Metropolitan Opera  Verdi's Don Carlo. This great work has not been in the repertory since 197172, but up to that time it had been seen on a regular basis. It had been Rudolf Bing's first production after assuming command of the Metropolitan Opera, and he opened the season with it on Nov. 6. 1950.

title: Singers on Chamber Bill
description: For the second concert in its new vocal series at Alice Tully Hall this season, the Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society invited Heather Harper, soprano, and Donald Gramm, bassbaritone, to share the stage with its resident instrumentalists on Thursday night.

title: INVESTING
description: Some six years ago, glamour stocks moved from the market's penthouse to its doghouse to begin an uncomfortably long tenancy. The group once renowned as the Nifty Fifty wound up discredited. discomfited and depleted.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: This is the first of a twopart series on rentals. IN Wilton recently a studio apartment was advertised as being available for $275 a month provided the occupant was a working gentleman - a phrase more evocative of Victorian England than America in 1979. In Southport, a onebedroom luxury apartment is offered at $485, but the owners, a young couple from Stamford, acknowledged that they probably would not accept anyone who was recently separated or divorced because they're just too transitory.

title: Selection: Dear Volodya, Dear Bunny
description: Wellfleet Cape Cod, Mass. November 30, 1959

title: Jim Rice: LongBall Hitter in Golf, Too
description: If it's true, as Scottish shepherds first professed, that a person's character, for better or worse, is exposed on a golf course, then Jim Rice of the Boston Red Sox is a gentleman millionaire of a Quiet pride, silent determination and thoughtful thrift. He obviously is also a slugger with sense of professional values. As much as he enjoys golf, befitting someone capable of crashing a 400yard tee shot as well as a 400foot home run, Sports of The Times he had to decline an invitation to compete in the Bing Crosby national proam tournament this week with Bobby Wadkins, the touring pro, as his partner. Instead he will attend tonight's Baseball Writers Dinner at the Americana Hotel where he will receive the American League's Most Valuable Player Award.

title: Big Snow? Maine Shrugs
description: PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 3 January was the snowiest month ever recorded in Portland, the state's largest city, but no one seemed very concerned about it.

title: Barbara Ann Hart Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Bernard Hart of Middletown, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ann Hart. to Earl Frederick Reed 3d. son of Mrs. Clarence H. Gehman of New York and Mr. Reed Jr. of Princeton, N.J. A March wedding is planned. Miss Hart is director of patient activities at the Holmdel (N.J.) Convalescent Center. Her fianc is president of the Metaclean Company in Eat Brunswick, N.J.

title: Belinda, Winpenny And John Paris 2d Plan Bridal in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Winpenny Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Sea Pines Plantation, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Belinda Randall Winpenny, to John Wright Paris 2d, son of Mrs. David R. Roberts of Winter Park, Fla. and the late James Dickson Paris of Fla., Wis. A May wedding is planned.

title: My Mother Said
description: I said why! My mother said because you are deaf.

description: Although Jo Jo Walters, Manhattan College's senior guard, topped all scorers with 31 points, Manhattan fell to Fairfield, 8372, yesterday at the Jaspers Draddy Gymnasium.

title: If a Director Tells Me, I Follow Him
description: MONTREAL I was conscious I was making a very important film, of a quality one doesn't have the opportunity to do often. It's difficult to explain the mystery, the magic I felt as I watched the daily rushes. I always telt a certain anticipation, because there was a sense of hazard, of the unknown, about the characters and everything that happened to them.

title: FINANCE
description: WHEN Beatrice Foods, the large diversified food company in Chicago, wanted to raise money to finance its purchase of Tropicana Products last spring, it made a quick foray into the Euromarkets to issue $100 million in fiveyear notes.

title: DINING OUT A GermanSwiss Treat in Wayne;The Swiss Tavern
description: LIKE many of New Jersey's best restaurants, the Swiss Tavern in Wayne began life as a speakeasy during Prohibition. The family of the present ownerchef, Hans Alpsteg, turned the centuryold frame house into a fullfledged restaurant in 1934, but managed to retain the Victorian coziness of the small parlors and the Victorian splendor of the large bar and grill.

title: Helen S. King Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Pell of Old Westbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Pell's daughter, Helen Slack King of Providence, R.I., to Hilary Gaire Woodhouse of Providence and Little Compton. R.I.. son of Mrs. Thomas F. Woodhouse of Little Compton and the late Mr. Woodhouse. The wedding is planned for March 10.

title: Business Steel's Convulsive Retreat in Europe
description: EUROPE'S steel industry, faced with increased competition from the third world and pressure from the United States and Japan to control exports, is undergoing an upheaval that has caused unrest among workers and threatens to create serious social problems.

title: Other Ideas & Trends
description: The debate over the best way to treat breast cancer continues. Writing in the Journal of the American Medical Association, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology biologist, Dr. Maurice S. Fox, said last week that Radical mastectomy seems to have been generally accepted without convincing evidence of its superiority. In early, localized breast cancer, he said, there is abundant evidence supporting the proposal that more conservative procedures provide at least equal benefit with substantially less mutilation. Dr. Fox, who has been studying the findings of longterm surveys the United States, Britain and Denmark, does not suggest that his conclusions are the final word on breast cancer.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: You don't have to be Chinese to mark the Chinese New Year. If you're curious about Oriental culture  and who isn't these days?  all you have to do is get over to the East Meadow Public Library, where a monthlong celebration of the Year of the Sheep (or Ram) 4677  starts today at 2 P.M. with the opening of an exhibition of paintings contributed by the Suffolk County Chapter of SumiEast, A demonstration of brush painting at 3:30 P.M. and a performance of the traditional Lion Dance by members of the Chinese Cultural Center of Hempstead at 2:30 P.M.

title: Eleanor Provost Friend Is Bride
description: Eleanor Provost Friend, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter William Friend Jr. of South Norwalk, Conn., was married in Darien, Conn., last evening to Sanford Drake Hickok, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Sanford Hickok of Morristown, N.J., and Brewster, Mass. The Rev. Frederick T. Bender performed the ceremony in St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

description: Paul Schoenstein was the city editor of The New York JournalAmerican. In other words, he worked for Hearst and practiced tabloid journalism in the legendary manner. He also won a Pulitzer Prize and talked brash. You know, your old man is Mister New York, he told his son Ralph.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: Art Buchwald Art, do you mind if I get familiar and call you Mr. Buchwald? Be my guest. Formalities over, hardnosed reporting reveals that Mr. Buchwald's umpteenth collection of newspaper columns, The Buchwald Stops Here, has been hovering around, about and below the best seller list in recent weeks. This called for a walk down Broadway, past the Paramount Building, toward memory lane.

title: What to Do When You Meet a Dandelion
description: 1) Salute Krista McLaude

title: Letters: A Safe Bison Is a Long may Off
description: To the Editor: Having visited Yellowstone National Park twice in recent years, I was shocked to read that Skip Rozin, in Wintering in the Park: Fit for Man and Beast (Travel Section, Jan. 19), walked around a 2,000pound bison. at a respectful distance, about 15 feet.

title: McGrawHill Ignores an Amexco Sweetener
description: The American Express Company last week raised its offer for McGrawHill Inc. to $1 billion, but it wasn't enough for the directors on the McGrawHill board, who unanimously rejected it.

title: R.D. Patton Weds Christine Wheeler
description: Christine Thomas Wheeler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Wheeler of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married yesterday to Rodman Denison Patton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry H. Patton of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. John J. Albert performed the ceremony in All Saints Episcopal Church in Wynnewood, Pa. He was assisted by the Rev. B.A. McCarthy.

title: A Different Kind of Bar
description: No matter what they may think, New Yorkers are not always trendsetters. Take the matter of wine bars. London has 300 or so, Paris has a few dozen, San Francisco has one and is about to get another, but, until recently, New York had none.

title: ABOUT CARS Outwitting Winter
description: FOR drivers, cold and snow are right in there with the rest of the fourletter words, and morning can be a time for nightmares. Windshields need scraping, locks are frozen, and cold metal and syrupy oil conspire to keep engines from starting.

title: Goodman Urges Fight On Youth Alcoholism In City's High Schools
description: Asserting that 30 percent of all New York City high school students are potential alcoholics, State Senator Roy M. Goodman, Republican of Manhattan, yesterday called on the Board of Education to start an alcoholeducation program in the city's schools.

title: REGIONS
description: BUENOS AIRES LATIN America, faced with slow growth and protectionist tendencies in its markets in the United States and Western Europe, is being forced to reassess the premise of fueling its economic development with exports.

title: Black and White Issues
description: THE rationalizations white South Africans commonly employ to justify their system of minority rule often have a quaint ingenuousness. This is shown in the transparently circular quality their reasoning. There are no leaders, the outsider told, who can speak for the mass of black South Africans. The absence of leaders points to a lack of interest in political issues on the part of the majority, an absence of articulate demands. If there are no demands, how can white South Africa be charged with failing to hear black leaders?

title: Folk Musicians Keep an Old Era Alive
description: OLD BROOKVILLE BECAUSE he played folk music, someone once asked Jeff Warner if he knew any John Denver tunes. Mr. Warner was not pleased by the request.

title: Visiting the Pyramids and Pianos of Egypt
description: To quote the old adage: If a pianist doesn't practice one day, he knows it; two days, his colleagues know it; three days, the audience knows it. (It is said that on the fourth day the critics tins out.) in all moaesty, I think I could get away with taking off a week, but not perhaps four weeks in midconcert season to realize an ambition of long standing  to visit the archeological treasures of Egypt. The only solution would be to have a piano at my disposal during this projected holiday for at least occasional work.

title: International Economic Survey
description: A few years ago, an aggressive group of less developed countries began demanding a new world economic order. What they wanted was some formal restructuring to give poorer nations a bigger slice of the pie. This implied that world leaders had some rational control over events. It is now apparent that the old order is indeed crumbling  but amid such disorientation that the world is confronted not with a new order but a new global disorder.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: It is discouraging to observe in the recent signing of a new PhilippineAmerican Bases Agreement how little is understood about the political realities in that farflung island chain by leaders in Washington, who can draw on three generations of experience in dealing with Philippine affairs. Out of that lack of understanding President Carter has embarked on a course which can only be subversive of the best interests of both the American and the Philippine people.nant woman and the father work off the medical bill for the abortion.

title: City TV Stations Promise More L.I. News Coverage
description: LONG ISLANDERS will soon be seeing more and more of something unusual on television news programs: themselves.

title: Without Monkeys
description: IN his book Uncivilized Races of the World (1870), the Rev. J. A. Wood remarks upon the extraordinary variety of the native customs which prevail in that wonderful land [of Africa] how lull of incident is life in Africa, the great stronghold of barbarism, and how necessary it is to devote to that one continent almost half his pages.

title: Streams in East Flowed At Records in January
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP)  Eastern stream flows reached record levels in January and the water moving through the nation's five largest rivers was more than 50 percent above normal, the United States Geological Survey reported yesterday.

title: Sara E. Hanstein, Teacher, Fiance
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hanstein Jr. of Birmingham, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sara Ellen Hanstein, to Samuel B. Moyle 3d, son of Dr. Movie Jr. of West Union. S.C., and Mary Gilmore Moyle of Walhalla, S.C. An April wedding. is planned.

title: Unraveling the Case Of Chuck Fairbanks
description: The imbroglio among Chuck Fairbanks, the New England Patriots, and the University of Colorado gained further heat last week, and now is being studied by Pete Rozelle, the Commissioner of the National Football League. There will be no resolution for at least two weeks, according to Rozelle, but the Federal Court of Appeals in Boston on Tuesday may have something to say about who is Fairbanks's current employer, the Patriots, Colorado or neither.

title: Ade1phi 90, Livingston 70
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 3 Gordie McCrae scored 22 points and led Ade1phi to a 9070 victory over Livingston College tonight. The Panthers shot 57 percent in the first half in taking a 4327 halftime lead. Adetphi is now 137 and the losers are 512.

title: Army Engineers Under Attack For Their Dig We Will Zeal
description: ATLANTAThe Army Corps of Engineers is locked a battle over allegations that it exceeded its authority beefing up the TennesseeTombigbee Waterway through Mississippi and Alabama, and Lieut. Gen. John Morris, the Chief of Engineers, seems puzzled. Why would anyone believe the Corps would willfully deceive Congress, as the plaintiffs contend, just so it could build the waterway? Why would the Corps get involved in politics, misuse figures?

title: Park in New England Planned
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 3 (Reuters)  Rhode Island and Massachusetts have announced plans to form a 50milelong park on the shores of the Blackstone River. Rhode Island officials said yesterday that the park would stretch along the Blackstone from Grafton, Mass., to the river's confluence with the Providence River in Pawtucket, R.I.

title: The Lobby as an Art Form: It Earns Its Way
description: Philip Johnson, the architect, is making sure the lobby for 1001 Fifth Avenue will look like a lobby. He is designing himself, and it will have a Flemish tapestry, a blackandwhite checkerboard marble floor and a crystal chandelier.

title: TV VIEW
description: Backstairs at the White House, which is being telecast for four consecutive Mondays on NBC, is an intriguing project for numerous reasons, not the least of which are significantly sociological. The screenplay, written by Gwen Bagni and Paul Dubov, is based on the 1961 book My Thirty Years Backstairs at the White House, which Lillian Rogers Parks wrote with Francis Spatz Leighton. Mrs. Parks and her mother, Maggie Rogers, had worked as White House maids for a total of 52 years, from the Administration of William Howard Taft to that of Dwight D. Eisenhower. The book combined intimate inside glimpses of the Presidential families with the personal stories of Maggie and Lillian, as they shuttled between White House grandeur and their own dignified struggles for modest survival.

title: A Night to Remember in the Italian Alps
description: Like Siena, the little town of Bormio in the Italian Alps has its Palio, although it has nothing to do with horses. Bormio's Palio is a threeday skiing contest that pits the folk in the northern part of the town with those in the south, and includes a twomile race throUgh its narrow winding streets.

title: Finance The Dollar's Tough Road Back
description: LONDON THE Carter Administration has finally gone the rescue of the onceproud dollar, and the worst of its international embarrassment the dollar dropped 34 percent against the yen and 22 percent against the mark in the last two years  should be past.

title: Mixed Reactions at Home
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Feb. 3 Reaction here in Daniel J. Flood's 11th Congressional District in northeastern Pennsylvania to the mistrial in Washington ranged from unrestrained joy to disappointment that he had not been found guilty. The negative comment reflected Mr. Flood's dwindling stature in the district, where his margin of victory plummeted last November. He had won overwhelmingly in prior elections, sometimes with 80 percent of the vote. He got 55 percent in November.

title: Notre Dame 86, Dayton 71
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 3 (AP) Kelly Tripucka scored a careerhigh 37 points tonight, including 17 straight in the dosing minutes, as topranked Notre Dame wore down stubborn Dayton University, 8671.

title: Article 4 -- No Title
description: COUNTRY MATTERS"Joss Ackland and Pauline Collins star in a dramatization of Crippled Bloom, the first installment in a new fivepart series based on short stories by A.E. Coppard and H.E. Bates, which begins tonight at 9 on Channel 13.

title: Chamberlain Named To Basketball Hall
description: Wilt Chamberlain, whose 31,919 points are the most ever scored by player in National Basketball Associa. tion competition, was voted yesterday into the Naismith Basketball Hall of Fame.

title: The New York Times/Fred R. Conrad
description: The ski trails were flawless, the snow was pure powder and the resort was only a subway ride from home yesterday.

title: FILM VIEW
description: It's true, as many highly articulate women claimed, that for a number of years movies treated their heroines as secondclass citizens  as hookers or virgins, or as largerthanlife sexobjects or as homemakers (when they could have been housebuilders), always as vacuous supporting characters in the more important dramas of male egos. To anyone going to the movies these days it shOuld De quicKly apparent that the tide haS turned, mean ing the pendulum has begun to swing back. Today it's men who are getting the short end of the stick in the neck. It's men who are being condescended to and patronized by moviernakers, most of whom, it should be emphasized, are men.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: I am deeply puzzled that director Michael Langham should have let himself in for the muddle that is Julius Caesar at the Public. In agreeing to stage the initial production of a Shakespearean repertory company composed entirely of black and Hispanic performers  a longstanding dream of Joseph Papp's  he must certainly have known what the problems would be. Having served as artistic director of the Stratford Festival Canada with great distinction, and then come nobly to the rescue of the faltering Guthrie in Minneapolis, he is as aware as anyone on this continent that mastering the music and the meaning of Shakespeare  and both on the same sustained breath calls for special skills that relatively few actors, of whatever ethnic background, possess.

title: How a Corporation Turns Paper
description: A century ago, they trotted around the streets of New York, collecting merchants i.o.u.'s and stuffing them into their top hats and derbies for later resale to those with money to invest. Today, the middlemen in the commercial paper market are shirtsleeved professionals who sit at trading desks on Wall Street, ears glued to their telephones.

title: Millrose Games: A High School Remembrance
description: YOUR first Millrose Games, they say, is like first love. My only disappointment was that I never got. to go in the team entrance. That's the door of the stars, you see  Rangers, Knicks, Elton John and Billy Graham.

title: With its Metrorail The Capital Adds A New Attraction
description: The nation's capital, with its wealth of tourist attractions like the Washington Monument, the Lincoln Memorial, the Smithsonian Institution, the National Gallery of Art, the White House, the Capitol building, the Library of Congress and the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, is drawing visitors with still another attraction  Metrorail, the capital's subway system.

title: In the New World, This Pope Is a Long Way from Home
description: For some Catholics, the journey of Pope John Paul II to Mexico, which ended last Thursday, turned out to be something of a letdown. Those who wanted the Pontiff to issue a ringing call for political and social revolution found his expressions of concern for injustice too mild. And those who hoped he would rebuke social activists in the church found little comfort in his repeated appeals to Catholic laymen to fight for human rights.

title: Can TV Actors Make It In the Movies?
description: Some of the hottest actors and actresses on primetime television  not content with having become household names such as Shirley, Columbo and Rhoda  can't wait to cash in their Nielsen chips for a gamble at movie stardom. In the months ahead, a number of familiar television actors and actresses will be testing their appeal in movie theaters.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Germany's LongSought Upturn Takes Hold
description: BONN WEST Germany's longawaited economic upturn, has finally taken on substance. Consumer and business confidence are at their highest levels since 1973. Inflation, now at its lowest rate since 1969, is projected to remain below 3 percent, unemployment to keep below the politically crucial mark of 1 million jobless and real growth, which reached an estimated 3 percent 1978, to rise to 3.5 percent to 4 percent.

title: Demand for Cultural Services Found Outstripping Finances
description: More people and money are flowing into New York's cultural institutions than ever, but the institutions are so financially constrained, according to a study, that they cannot provide equitable salaries for employees and they find it hard to meet their esthetic goals.

title: Brooklyn Coll. 58. Buffalo 52
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 3   Brooklyn College won its fourth cnsecutive game tonight, beating the University of Buffalo 5852 at the losers court. Brooklyn led at halftime, 2823. Brooklyn's John Brown and Bob Requena combined to sink five foul shots in the final minutes to assure the Brooklyn victory. Ken Griffin of Brooklyn and George Mendenhall of Buffalo were high scorers with 16 points each.

title: Wagner 96, L.I.U. 82
description: Howard Thompkins scored 28 points and grabbed 14 rebounds to lead Wagner to a 9682 victory over Long Island University last night.

title: News Summary
description: Ayatollah Khomeini stepped up pressure on Shabpur Bakhtiar to quit as Prime Minister and said that his Islamic council had drafted a new constitution for Iran. The names of the council's members would be disclosed soon, the Ayatollah said. He appealed to Iran's military men to become free and independent and asked them to join his Islamic movement as brothers. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: FINANCE Commodities: As Volatile As the Dollar
description: THE already volatile world markets for basic food and industrial commodities are growing even more uncertain with international currency fluctuations. Most basic raw materials are priced in dollars, and as the dollar has plunged, producers have raised their prices to compensate.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Trends. What's in? What'll be in a year from now? Some journalists and social commentators, whose business it is to spot a fashion when it's only notion cherished by a few enthusiasts, find the popular response to books dealing with contemporary themes a useful way of predicting trendstocome. They watch particularly what's selling in bookstores in the youth centers - the university towns and other communities where there is a high concentration of trendsetting men and women under 35.

title: If You Go.
description: to the American Museum at Claverton Manor, it is open daily except Mondays from 2 to 5 P.M. from the end of March through the last Sunday in October. It is also open on British bank holidays (always Mondays) from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: Priscilla C. Collins Sets July Nuptials
description: Priscilla Catherine Collins, a registered nurse with the Onondaga Public Health Department in Syracuse, and Dr. Kevin Robert O'Hara, a resident in radiology at the Upstate Medical Center in Syracuse, plan to marry in July.

title: Best Sellers
description: FICTION

title: T.P. Bartle Jr. Weds Deborah Montgomery
description: Deborah Dale Montgomery, daughter of Mrs. Dale Esgate Montgomery of Fairlawn, Ohio, and the late Mr. Montgomery, was married yesterday to Thomas Preston Bartle Jr. of New York and East Hampton, L.I., son of Mrs. Bartle of Dallas and the late Mr. Bartle.

title: Theater
description: LONDON Only hours after reading the first highly favorable reviews of his play The Elephant Man, which opened last month at the Theater of St. Peter's Church in New York, Bernard Pomerance, acting instinctively, got the first plane out and headed for the anonymity of his north London home. And when finally cornered in the Hampstead Theater, where The Elephant Man was first produced, he managed to remain just as intriguingly enigmatic as the play that has now introduced him to Off Broadway audiences.

title: Tickner Stands Out, Takes Skating Title
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 3  Led by a performance of unrelieved speed and unequaled skill by Charles Ticlmer, the men skaters emerged as a dominant force in figure skating tonight as the United States championships ended.

title: Encompass Theater Presents 6 Operas
description: In the past, when the Encompass Theater has turned to opera, which it alternates with plays, it has dealt with fulllength dramatic works, by Virgil Thomson, Aaron Copland, Robert Ward and Marc 1311tZSteln. iurrentiy at its loft theater at 168 West 48th Street, it is occupied with six comedies of short length. Five of them make up the first half of the evening, giving the effect of a revue. In fact, two of them are by lyricistcomposers who have worked on Broadway, Charles Strouse and Sheldon Harnick. The second half of the program provides balance with an extended single piece, Tom Johnson's The Four Note Opera.

title: Associated Press
description: ROME, Feb. 3  Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy, who resigned earlier this week after the Communists withdrew their support for his Government, was asked by President Sandro Pertini today to try to form a new government.

title: Headliners
description: Klaus Fuchs, 67, has retired as head of the physical and nuclear science department of East Germany's Central Institute for Nuclear Research. No doubt he needs the rest. In 1949 Dr. Fuchs, then a British subject, was arrested for passing nuclear secrets to the Russians. He confessed, and implicated Harry Gold as his courier. Mr. Gold in turn implicated David Greenglass, who implicated Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, and so on. After nine years in prison, Dr. Fuchs was deported to East Germany where he resumed what, at his retirement ceremonies, was called professional and political education of the new generation of scientists.

title: Hinkle Leads by 5 At Crosby ProAm
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Feb. 3The radio report heard in the courtesy car had Lon Hinkle on the wrong golf course and gave an incorrect score and an inaccurate lead. But Hinkle knew he had shot a good three:underpar 69 and he figured that despite those broadcasted errors, he must still be leading the golf tournament. His first glimpse of a scorecard confirmed that he was indeed the leader after the third round of the 38th Bing Crosby National ProAm.

title: Big but Frugal, State's Budget Is a Bit Shaky
description: TRENTON TO BALANCE the proposed state budget of $4.655 billion a record high but still frugal budget that is likely to please no one but bankers and bond buyers state officials chose to forgo asking the electionconscious Legislature for new taxes. Instead, they raided every hidden state bank account, drawing on such unusual sources as interest on the Court Trust Fund.

title: For a Weekly Valentine's Day
description: YOU don't bring me flowers, sings a distraught Barbra Streisand in her hit of the same name, but the complaint is not confined to song. As Valentine's Day nears, nature lovers, romantics and even types usually unmoved by these matters are likely to feel something is missing if the heartsandflowers formula holds forth a promise of only hearts.

title: CRIME
description: There have been any number of studies and novels about the activities of C.I.A. agents inter. tering with foreign governmeets, even having a hand in their overthrow. (The biblioera. phy on Chile and the Central Intelligence Agency must be assuming monumental proportions by now.) Martin Walker's THE INFILTRATOR (Dial, $7.95) is a novel about an agent's efforts to swing the politics of one country into a bigger power's orbit. What makes this book somewhat different from the others is the fact that the agent is British.

title: From Tiny Spores Big Ferns Grow
description: Fern plants are fascinating. Involvement usually starts with purchase of a new plant or when a friend shares a division of a particular favorite. But the most rewarding venture is the propagation of ferns from spores, the way terns nave Merl reproducing themselves for nearly 400 million years. This method has the adantage of producing lots more plants. It often is the only way to obtain unusual species since the selection of ferns available in the market is relatively small.

title: Suspension of Driver's Licenses Urged for 19,045 in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 (AP)  The president judge of Philadelphia Traffic Court, Dominick lannarelli, has asked the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation to suspend the driver's licenses of 19,045 persons, a court spokesman, Abe Rosen, said yesterday.

title: States Seeking to Limit Salt Used on Highways
description: PITTSBURGH. Feb. 3 (AP)  Some states, worried about the detrimental effects of salt on cars, highways and water supplies, have begun to reduce the amount of salt used in the winter months.

title: League's Owners Approve Adding 2 More Teams
description: DETROIT, Feb. 3  The National Basketball Association owners voted today to expand by no more than two teams no later than the 198081 season. Commissioner Larry O'Brien said at least seven cities would be considered, all of which have had teams in the N.B.A. or in the defunct American Basketball Association. The league now has 22 teams.

title: Suzanne Ford Wed To J.R. Goldhagen
description: At St. Mary of the Assumption Roman Catholic Church in Katonah, N.Y., yesterday, Suzanne Ladd Ford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lawrence Ford of Bedford Hills, N.Y.. was married to Juergen Richard Goldhagen, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Martin Goldhagen of Hanover, West Germany. The Rev. Thomas A. Marinak performed the ceremony.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: PARIS  Do you know, mademoiselle, that you are sitting on 100,000 square meters of building constructed on the most expensive land in Paris? Land and stone never deceive.

title: U. of California Complex Charges Aluminum Dust Poses a Hazard
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 3  After years of complaints by students about the fine aluminum powder released into the air by a nearby factory, some scientists have challenged the traditional belief that aluminum is nontoxic and a suit has been filed by two former residents of Albany Village, a married students housing project operated by the University of California.

title: Rain Revives Calls for Flood Control
description: PARSIPPANY THE record 10inch rainfall last month has revived efforts by legislators, environmentalists, builders and homeowners to speed the development of plans for controlling the cascading water that has been a major problem after every storm in the state since the turn of the century.

title: THE MARKETS Dwelling on the Bad News
description: Stock prices slumped last week as the Dow Jones industrials fell 25.12 points to 834.63 after finishing the previous week at their highest level, since midOctober.

title: Italy's Rosy Figures Contrast With Life
description: ROME ITALY is showing astounding financial and commercial health, despite disruptions caused by political terrorism, kidnappings and the resignation of its president last year after widely accepted, although technically unproved, charges of corruption.

title: George de Vincent
description: George de Vincent

title: Realty News-
description: The Lefrak Organization has picked up two prime properties.

title: Russians Help Sturgeon Increase the caviar Yield
description: ASTRAKHAN, U.S.S.R.  With four ounces of caviar costing $42 in New York specialty stores, it may come as a surprise that the Russians say they are producing more than at any time in 40 years.

title: Troubled Trist ate Unit to Be Studied
description: THE Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, responding to criticism of the Tristate Regional Planning Commission as being wasteful, dilatory and lacking in leadership, have ordered a major new study of the agency that controls the spending of billions of dollars a year.

title: Sports Today
description: Highlights of the 24 Hours of Daytona auto race. (Television Channel 2, 4:15 P.M.)

title: But Brazil Finds It Costly
description: RIO DE JANEIRO BRAZIL, which for several decades has been the leading industrial power in Latin America, has in recent years of remarkable expansion also become one of the foremost manufacturing nations in the developing world.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Andree Brooks's article. Renaissance in Norwalk [Dec. 3] gave an updated picture of a vibrant community in Fairfield County. Regarding the rumor that the Norwalk schools are bad, perhaps the same realestate agents in neighboring communities who are investing in Norwalk properties have spread these rumors in the past to further sales in their own communities. To others, the problem may be its comprehensive schools that combine a multiethnic and a multiracial student body rather than the homogenized student body found in neighboring towns.

title: Ann Watson Plans June Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Symington of New Canaan, Conn., and Camden, Me., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Symington's daughter, Ann Carroll Hemingway Watson, to Richard Agnew Bresnahan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bresnahan of Scituate, Mass.

title: ABOUT CARS How to Handle Cold Weather
description: FOR drivers, cold and snow are right in there with the rest of the fourletter words, and morning can be a time for nightmares. Windshields need scraping, locks are frozen, and cold metal and syrupy oil conspire to keep engines from starting.

title: WASHINGTON A Rueful Lament
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 3 From Toronto to Mexico City, up and down the continent, one hears a rueful lament these days. It is that me politics have taken over; that personal interests and narrow commercial or social concerns are dividing the people and diverting them from the larger questions of the general good.

title: Regions In the West, a New Conservatism
description: PARIS LIKE prodigal sons, the Western industrial democracies are groping their way back toward the lost world of Bretton Woods, in the hope its stable exchange rates, free competition and low inflation, can provide the missing key to faster economic growth and full employment.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE BASS SAXOPHONE, by Josef Skvorecky. (Knopt,$8.95 )????????????? about life in Communist Czechoslovakia, resonant with political. ianantiL and musical undertones.

title: The Nation
description: The recession watch continues still slightly befogged. The Federal Government's index of economic indicators dropped by 5 percent in December, according to a report issued last week, due in part to a decline in the money supply and a falling off of building permits. There was an identical decline in November, but the Commerce Department's senior economist said it would be conclusionleaping to forecast an impending recession. Still, in the past, a decline over three consecutive months has generally been thought to be just that.

title: Utah SexOffense Law Revision Allows Rape Penalty for Woman
description: SALT LAKE CITY. Feb. 3 (UPI) Women can be convicted of rape under provisions of a bill passed yesterday by the Utah Legislature and sent to the Gov_ error.

title: DINING OUT
description: KAPPY'S used to be in Halesite, but a parting of the ways between two owners led to the opening of this sleek new place in Melville. With a location like this, just off Route 110, it has to do well at lunch.

title: Can Our Theater Learn From Kabuki?
description: Can the American theater learn anything from Kabuki, the popular theater of Japan which has continued in essentially unchanged form since it achieved maturity three centuries ago?

title: Diane P. Kirchner Affianced To James Bradford Godfrey
description: Diane Patricia Kirchner, an account supervisor for Perspectus Inc., a New York advertising agency, and James Bradford Godfrey of New York, a consultant on fine arts, plan to be married in May.

title: Israeli Says Iranian Crisis Means Sinai Pact Must Include Oil Deal
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 3  Pointing to the upheavals in Iran, Justice Minister Shmuel Tamir warned today that Israel must not yield the Sinai Peninsula to Egypt without guarantees for its oil supplies.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was erroneously reported in The Times on Jan. 28 that a meeting on Jan. 13 of Chinese and American officials preparing for the visit of Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping was chaired by Evan S. Dobelle, chief of protocol for the State Department. The meeting was chaired by Edith J. Dobelle, who replaced Mr. Dobelle, her husband, as chief of protocol last year.

title: V.M.I. 79, F.D.U. 77
description: LEXINGTON. Va., Feb. 3  Andy Kolesar converted two technical fouls with five seconds left to play tonight and lifted Virginia Military Institute to a 7977 victory over Fairleigh Dickinson University. Kolesar finished the game with 28 points on 9 of 13 from the field and 10 of 10 from the foul line. Ricky Gomez and Dan McLaughlin each scored 20 points for F.D.U.

title: Belle C. Blanchard Sets Spring Bridal
description: The engagement of Belle Carter Blanchard to Blake Tyler Newton 3d, both of New York, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Mercer Carter Blanchard of Columbus, Ga. The prospective bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Newton Jr. of Washington, formerly of Greenwich, Conn. The couple will be married this spring in Columbus.

title: CHESS
description: The great German theoretician Siegbert Tarrasch (18621934) exaggerated the value of a superiority in space  a misjudgment that served as one factor in the failure of his bid for the world championship in his 1908 match with Emanuel Lasker. But a little toning down of his habitual dogmatism by inserting the phrase, other things being equal, would have set his theory straight.

title: Zaire's Rich Mineral Area Is Racked With Poverty
description: LUBUMBASHI, Zaire  Giant billboards extolling President Mobutu Sese Seko, the incarnation of the central Government 1,500 miles away, loom at every major traffic circle. He is our only hope, the single man we all follow for unity, tranquillity, security, they say.

title: Marguerite Flues Fiancee of John P. Meade
description: Mr. and Mrs. A. Gilmore Flues of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marguerite Jamieson Flues, to John Patrick Meade, son of Mrs. Edward Meade of Memphis and the late Mr. Meade.

title: REGIONS Britain: A Showdown With Labor
description: LONDON THE map of Britain, someone once observed, looks remarkably like a man riding comfortably on the back of a fat pig. The country's economy looks a bit like that too, but now the pig is starting to trot, and the chances of an accident in 1979 are rising fast.

title: Bruce Edward Belmont Fianc of Elizabeth Kerr
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Kerr Jr. of Mantoloking, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Warner Kerr, to Bruce Edward Belmont, son of Dorothy Van Riper Belmont of Mantoloking and Paul Nicholas Belmont of Anchorage. Ky.

title: Toward Happiness at 35 and Beyond
description: THE gorgeous model, one arm draped elegantly over her chaise, flashes a look of challenge at the viewer to match the grabber line beneath: How do you impress them with your sexy, sweet, innocent skin now that you're over 30? The over30 heart catches. It was easy enough when you were 16 or even 25, the copy continues breathlessly, but now that you're neither 16 nor 25, perhaps the ??? ??? system is for you.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ANYONE who has tried to drill a hole in a ceiling or other overhead surface has certainly run across the problem of having plaster chips and dust or powder falling into his face and eyes, as well as all over the drill itself. There is also the annoying job of getting out a vacuum to clean up the dust and chips.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS The Risk China Faces
description: MADISON, Wis.  China's Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping sees Vietnam in a different light from the Carter Administration. Washington urges Peking not to reply to Hanoi's provocations. America fears that a Chinese response would invite a Soviet assault on China.

title: National Service  An Old Idea Gets New Life
description: WASHINGTON  Six years after the end of the draft, questions are again being raised, in Congress and in the military, about the future of the allvolunteer Army. Even those who believe that this professional Army has worked out well so far are worried about what lies ahead.

title: Christian Group Leaving a Town Over Alcohol and Tobacco Sales
description: BRIDGEVILLE, Calif.  A decision to resume sales of beer, wine and cigarettes in this northern California community means the departure of the Rev. Alvin M. Stevens and the last remnants of the small Pentacostal Faith Challengers group he led here nearly two years ago to begin a new life.

title: Judge, at Governor's Request, Puts Alabama Prisons Into Receivership
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 3 Federal District Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr. placed the Alabama prison system into receivership yesterday and named the state's new Governor, Forrest James Jr., as the court agent with full powers to onerate the prisons. The order came after a series or unpuolicized meetings between Judge Johnson and Governor James, who took office less than three weeks ago.

title: Dana Markover Plans to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Markover of Spring Valley, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dana Markover, to Howard Michael Sklarek, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Sklarek of Commack, L.I. The future bride is a senior at SUNY at Buffalo, from which her fianc graduated and where he attends the School of Medicine.

title: Female Stars Seeking Identity
description: IF OUR roots are here, we're going to stay here for a while. We planted some seeds and we're going to give them a chance to grow. It sounded like the arrival of a new Westchester homeowner, but the speaker was one of the three Female Stars Seeking Identity owners of the county's only representative team in professional sports, the New York Stars, a women's basketball team that is struggling to establish an identity and Attract spectators.

title: Ann E. Hedlund Is Bride Of Prof. Mario Domandi
description: In Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills, N.J., yesterday afternoon, Ann Elizabeth Hedlund, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hedlund of Short Hills, became the bride of Prof. Mario Domandi of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and Little Compton, R.I., son of Mrs. Santo Domandi of New York and the late Mr. Domandi. The Rev. Alfred Moring Niese Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Thomas J. Berger, Merrill Lynch Aide, Weds. Diane Levine
description: In All Souls Unitarian Church yesterday Diane M. Levine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Edward Levine of Fort Lee, N.J., and Westhampton Beach, L.I., became the bride of Thomas Jan Berger, son of Dr. Frank M. Berger of New York_ and the late Bozena Jahodove Berger. The Rev. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony.

title: Nigeria: A Commercial Beehive
description: LAGOS, NIGERIA SINCE the early 1970's, Nigeria has enjoyed an economic growthrate that averaged 8 percent a year. But for 1978, Nigerian and foreign statisticians have predicted real growth for the largest black nation in the world of only 2 percent.

title: World News Briefs
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 3 (AP)  Palestinians and United Nations security forces clashed in southern Lebanon today, and two members of the United Nations force were killed in gunfire and four others died in a related helicopter crash, it was reported here.

title: Author's Query
description: For a book on Mrs. Golding Bright (18591945), who published under the name George Egerton, I would like to know of papers, letters, etc., relating to her or to other authors in John Lane's Keynotes Series. MARGARET D. STETZ Harvard University Dept. of English and American Literature and Language 38 Kirkland St. Cambridge, Mass. 02138

title: Holding the Line On Blight in the Bronx
description: Just below the meticulously landscaped entrance to the Fordham University campus in the Bronx there is field of garbage and demolition rubble that marks the northernmost edge of the devastation and abandonment city and Federal planners now define as the South Bronx.

title: Two Conflicts of Interest
description: Representative Henry Waxman's upset victory over Representative Richardson Preyer for the chairmanship of a key House subcommittee is being hailed as a defeat for the seniority system, but the contest also has a deplorable aspect. It represents the triumph one form of conflict of interest over another.

title: A Work of Love For Boy Scout, 78
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK ON WEDNESDAY, 17 Boy Scouts, drawn from all over the United States, will make their way to the White House. There, the Scouts will present to the President, as they do annually in accordance with their charter, the organization's Report to the Nation_

title: Possibly Parables
description: MANY writers have tried to write like Donald Barthelme; it is said he has more imitators than anyone since Hemingway. Literary history shows that the avantgarde of one period is either the norm a few decades later, the way fourletter words are now the norm, or else the highly original writer, his imitators fallen away, is left in the isolation of his special gift  standing, one might say, in the altogether. This sixth collection is bare Barthelme at his best, quite inimitable, with a new kind of calm confidence, a new depth of subject, and no pictures. And, one hopes, his imitators in disarray; for it should now be clear to everybody that nobody can write a Barthelme story as well as he can.

title: Csonka Is Remembered Fondly
description: One forearm smash. Maybe it wasn't enough to get from a milliondollar fullback in three seasons. But if there was one vivid moment when Larry Csonka reminded Giant fans of how he used to play football, it was that particular perfectly legal forearm smash.

title: What's Doing in the VIRGIN ISLANDS
description: AMBIENCE  While many Virgin Islanders will not go near the water at this wintry time of year, the beaches and hotel pools on Si. Thomas, St. Croix and St. John are crowded with refugees from mainlana snowstorms. The yearround climate is generally agreeable, in the mid80s in the daytime much of the time.

title: Radio Gets a Voice in Drive To Gain Funds for Neediest
description: Although the annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is a wellestablished tradition  this is its 67th year  the current campaign marks the beginning of a new tradition. Appeals for the fund which used to appear only in The Times, were also broadcast over WQXR and WQXRFM, the radio stations of The Times.

title: A Book Of Parts
description: RANDALL JARRELL, a critic sparing of praise, claimed that The Man Who Loved Children was the unread masterpiece of our time. It was as plainly good as War and Peace and Crime and Punishment and Remembrance of Things Past are plainly great. he declared in the preface to a new edition of the novel issued some 25 years after it had first appeared in 1990. Jarrell's advocacy was in large measure responsible for the reputation The Man Who Loved Children has since acquired, and it remains the only novel of Christina Stead's that is widely read.

title: Births
description: Paul W. and Nancy (nee Nathan) announce the birth of their daughter Heather NathanAmborn, 7 lbs. 14 ozs., at 6:27AM, January 31. 1979. Proud grandparents are Ruth Ann and Elmer J. Amborn, Jr., of Bangor, Wisconsin, and Ida Wyman and Simon Nathan. both of New York.

title: Rachel Lampert and Dancers Appear
description: There are times when Rachel Lampert, the young choreographer, seems to fall short of being the Woody Allen of dance. Not that Mr. Allen is her model, or that her humor is even as effective. But she shares the same sharp ear and eye for the way Americans act and what they say. The unspoken attitudes that made Mr. Allen's Annie Hall so recognizable are reflected in Miss Lampert's pieces.

title: ART Judaica in a Dramatic Setting

title: Terrorists Kill Guard in Spain
description: ANDOAIN, Spain, Feb. 3 (UPI) Basque terrorists killed one Civil Guardsman and critically wounded another today with submachinegun fire from a car speeding past a barracks in this town in norinern Jpaltl. it was Spain's 15th political assassination since Jan. 1, and all but two of the killings were the work of Basque guerrillas seeking to expel the natonal police from the northern Basque county and establish an independent socialist state.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL

Purcell, the Nassau County Executive, ordered the closing of the Nassau County Museum of Fine Arts in Roslyn Harbor a year ago this month because of numerous firecode violations and the dilapidated condition of the threestory mansion, many museum supporters feared that the county would not spend the money to bring the museum back to But this week, Marcia O'Brien, director of Nassau County's Office of Cultural Development, said that work on the building's interior is scheduled to begin as soon as the weather breaks and that at least some of the building's galleries would be open to the public by next fall.

No injuries were reported. Special to The New York Times

title: Getting Realistic About Trains

He recommends that Amtrak trim its routes by 43 percent; that will become an order unless one house of Congress vetoes it within three months.

title: CAMERA

Input will also be sought from private industry, advisory panels in labor, public interest groups and academe.

According to the account, part of a 47page report listing recommendations for new state and county laws and issued by the Board of Legislators Committee on Legislation, which the Peekskill Republican heads, the pattern of serious crime committed by Westchester youths has been escalating.

title: THE RISING STAR OF MERYL STEEP

The name may still be unfamiliar to the general public, but soon it should echo from coast to coast, like those classic trains, the Super Chief and the Twentieth Century Limited, rocketing over their tracks. In glasstowerea talent agencies, Hollywood studios, and offices of Broadway producers  wherever deals are made and careers launched  people in the know are asking for Streep, more Streep. That's Streep as in sweep.

title: Rhodesia Fearful of A Descent Into Chaos
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia  As a black bagpiper led the crowd in a swelling chorus of Amazing Grace, the teenage soldier's mother started to cry. The soldier, blinded and burned in a landmine explosion, clutched her hand and sang on. After his commanding officer had castigated the dismal Jimmies who say black rule will sweep away everything Rhodesians have fought and died for, the young man walked forward with his stick to touch the statue of a white trooper that was dedicated in a ceremony last week. The statue, cast from spent cartridge cases, commemorates the nine officers and 90 men of the allwhite Rhodesian Light Infantry who have died in six years of combat with black guerrillas. After a moment's silence, the young man shook the hand of Salisbury's mayor and walked from the ceremony on his mother's arm. He was one of the lucky ones who have survived the wounds of war. At least 15,000, most of them blacks, have not, and that figure seems likely to rise at an accelerating rate because of political developments.

title: Airplane's Cargo Door Falls Close to a House
description: JACKSON. Yhch., Feb. 3 (AP) Dan Scott almost had an extra door put into his home  through the roof.

The party insisted that it would only return as a full partner in new Government. with Cabinet posts.

People buy a threefoot hemlock and can't wait until it gets to be 10 feet. In 10 years it's 30 feet high and you can see right through it  because they have been afraid to prune it. So the screening they wanted, they never got.

If they are part of your nostalgia, I'd advise you to skip the show  The Rise and Fall of the Andrews Sisters. In little less than two hours, including intermission, three excellent performers do 17 numbers made famous by the singing sisters. Obviously, everything and everyone around them, including the promised rise and fall, gets only passing attention.

title: HOME CLINIC Protecting Yourself From Plaster Debris
description: ANYONE who has tried to drill a hole in a ceiling or other overhead surface has certainly run across the problem of having plaster chips and dust or powder falling into his face and eyes, as well as all over the drill itself. There is also the annoying job of getting out a vacuum to clean up the dust and chips.

title: HOME CLINIC Protecting Yourself From Plaster Debris
description: ANYONE who has tried to drill a hole in a ceiling or other overhead surface has certainly run across the problem of having plaster chips and dust or powder falling into his face and eyes, as well as all over the drill itself. There is also the annoying job of getting out a vacuum to clean up the dust and chips. An easy way to prevent all this and virtually eliminate the need for cleanup is to use a lid from a coffee can or similar largemouth container as shown in the accompanying drawing. After punching or drilling a hole through the center of the lid, push the bit through and hold it over the chuck while drilling. All dust and chips will be caught by this lid instead of falling on your faceor on the floor.

title: Teng's Visit Seeks to Tap the Rich Lode of America's Technology

One worker in the Ford factory turns out 50 cars a year. His Chinese counterpart produces only one. This statistic underscores one nurnose Mr. Teng's extraordinary mission to the United States: to look over United States technology, which Peking badly needs to carry out its ambitious plan to make China into a fully modern industrial state by the year 2000. We in China are faced with the task of transforming our backwardness and catching up promptly with the advanced countries of the world, Mr. Teng, China's senior Deputy Prime Minister, told Southern political and business leaders. We want to learn from you.

title: Mitchell College Troubled by Fires in Iranian Students Dormitory
description: NEW LONDON FOUR small fires, which together caused less than $15,000 damage and were apparently not intended to spread, were set in recent days in two wooden dormitories housing 35 Iranian students at Mitchell College, a quiet twoyear institution on the banks of the Thames River here. The Iranian students, along with the rest of the 400 students, are disturbed by the fires, even though it seems nobody was trying to burn the buildings down. But Reza Mandavi, a secondyear engineering student who is chairman of a new Iranian Association on the campus, said: It was a warning; the next fire will burn the building up.

title: Big Bard
description: FOR whom is this large and expensive edition of Shakespeare intended? To judge by the jacket copy and the publisher's advertisements, it seems aimed primarily at the general reader, the nonspecialist who wants a readable, annotated text he can rely on. Or perhaps the most likely buyer is someone who wants to give a generous gift to such a reader - to a niece or nephew entering college, say. Anyone in this position is likely to be impressed by the publisher's claim that this is an authoritative edition. So it must be said at once that The Annotated Shakespeare is less accurate, less helpful and in a crucial respect less easy to read than many editions that cost onethird the price. And its claim to be authoritative is seriously misleading.
