description: When Jose Fierro bought a $3 ticket for Lotto, New York State's newest lottery game, he decided that he would ask his wife, Isabel, to join him in trying to pick all six numbers required for the top prize.

title: Concern Over Rape in Suburbs Is Growing
description: WESTPORT, Conn.  A young woman stands at the edge of a road in Fairfield County, shifting impatiently from one leg to the other, her thumb poised in the air. As she squints through the glare of each passing windshield, she hopes that her eyes will connect with a man who might be intent upon opening his car door, inviting her in and raping her.

title: Judge Says Transportation Dept. May Require Car Safety Devices
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP)  The United States Court of Appeals here has ruled that Transportation Secretary Brock Adams has the legal right to require that automobiles be equipped with either an air bag or an automatic seat belt.

title: Paperbacks:
description: New and Noteworthy THE HUMAN FACTOR, by Graham Greene. (Avon, $2.50.) Graham Greene ventures into John le Cart* territory with this novel about a British secret service agent, married to a black woman, who does business with the Russians; true to form, he engages the moral questions implicit in the situation. Simply, but not too simply, a good story, Denis Donoghue called it this Book Review; a novel about the void between thought and action.

title: Marriages
description: Mrs. Bernice Krasner happily arr nounces wedding of her daughter Kim Lee to Mr. Paul Stephen Plasclak cal February 14th. 1979 at the Pleasant Hill Country Club, Pleasant Hill, California. The couple plan a honeymoon in Hawaii.

title: Ban Proposed on Toxins That Polluted L.I. Wells
description: The New York State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, and Assemblyman I. William Bianchi Jr., Democrat of Suffolk County, yesterday proposed legislation to ban certain toxic chemical products used in the maintainance of cesspools and septic tanks.

title: I.B.M. Gets Tough
description: For decades, the International Business Machines Corporation has dominated the computer industry. Competitors have made significant inroads in one area  the market for small computers.

title: REGIONS Mexico's Oil Won't Solve All the Problems
description: MEXICO CITY THE excitement stirred by Mexico's new oil wealth has so far obscured the discomforting reality that it may mean less to Mexico, the United States and the world in general, than many optimistic analysts have suggested.

title: Wine War Scorecard: Veni, Vidi, Vici
description: Ten years ago. the Italian wine industry took a new look at the American frontier and liked what it saw. While the French and the Italians were drinking about 28 gallons per capita a year.

title: Bus Commuters: Will They Be Taken for a Ride by the State?
description: GOVERNOR BYRNE has announced his intention to take over 22 of New Jersey's privately owned bus lines, and Louis J. Gambaccini, the state's Commissioner of Transportation, has outlined the details.

title: Officials Criticize Regional Group
description: HARTFORD WHY are the cities dying? Senator Wayne A. Baker asked rhetorically in the middle of a discussion of the Tristate Regional Planning Commission. I don't know, he answered a little helplessly, but these guys will draw up plans until you''e blind.

title: A Health Center In Political Arena
description: MOUNT VERNON CROWDED into a cluster of 13 interconnected, prefabricated buildings on South Seventh Avenue here, the 80member staff of the Mount Vernon Neighborhood Health Center provides a variety of health services to not only the mostly toner and mostly black residents of the city's south side but also to many people who come from New Rochelle, Yonkers and the northern Bronx. What began in 1973 as a health facility financed under the Federal Government's old Model Cities program and designed to care for 2,000 patients a year, has expanded dramatically into a program serving 28,000 patients a year. Perhaps a measure of its success is the fact that it has become, to those it serves, an indispensable institution, an example of all the positive things that could flow from Federal aid as well as a symbol of black political power.

title: DINING OUT Jambalaya, Westport Style
description: WESTPORT THE decor is contemporary Connecticut, the menu is New Orleans, and the food itself is, well, somewhere in between. The Carriage House, long a Westport landmark, was out of business for a year while a new building was under construction, but it is now back in a handsome new complex called Carriage Hill. The building. of strong, simple lines and weathered wood, contains number of shops, as well as the new, smartly turnedout Carriage House restaurant.

title: Businesses Are Stepping Up Their Roles in Social Problems of Cities
description: If the business of America is business, as Calvin Coolidge said, the business of business is, increasingly, America's social problems.

title: Ford Foundation Picks a President
description: The biggest and richest of all American private foundations, the Ford Foundation, has chosen a new president. He is Franklin A. Thomas, a lawyer and a trustee of the foundation, who from 1967 until 1977 headed the BedfordStuyvesant Restoration Corporation in Brooklyn, considered one of the few ambitious antipoverty efforts of the 1960's to have made a record of solid achievement.

title: MUSIC
description: IT is not solely through their concerts that musical organizations in Westchester serve our county, and last weekend. I found myself fascinatingly involved with one of the community good deeds of the Music for Westchester Symphony Orchestra. That organization sponsors a competition for players up to the age of 22, and last Saturday six pianists (of the 28 who originally entered) each played a concerto movement at the final auditions. What a happy display of talent it was. Everyone had something to say, musically, and as a result the decision was exceedingly difficult to arrive at: in fact, I do not remember another competition where each of the three eventual prizewinners had at least one tirstplace vote from the panel of judges.

title: RESIDENTS DENOUNCE CLOSING OF HOSPITAL
description: The closing of Arthur J. Logan Memorial Hospital brought a demonstration and sharp criticism yesterday by Harlem residents and community leaders, who charged that it represented another example of the state and city governments attempting to balance their budgets on the backs of the poor. The board or trustees at Logan voted Friday night to close the 228bed hospital for two weeks, and all of its remaining patients were transferred to nearby institutions.

title: Notes: Brazil Changes Policy, Requires U.S. Travelers to Have Visas
description: United States citizens planning to visit Brazil are now required to obtain a visa from a Brazilian consular office before leaving home. The Brazilian Government, in a move described as a reciprocity action, adopted a regulation in December mandating that citizens of countries requiring visas of Brazilians must likewise have visas to visit Brazil.

title: Lack of Aftershocks
description: PALISADES, N.Y. NO AFTERSHOCKS from the earthquake that shook central New Jersey and parts of New York City last week have been reported by seismologists who studied the Cheesequake area in Middlesex County, where the tremor was centered.

title: A look at the Council
description: A look at the Council

title: BUSINESS Europe and Japan Challenge U.S. Computer Lead
description: FOREIGN computer manufacturers, backed by government subsidies and policies in Europe and Japan that encourage customers to buy domestic, are mounting a challenge to the worldwide market dominance of International Business Machines and other American companies.

title: DINING OUT Maybe the Best Chinese Food Around
description: GREAT cuisines respect tradition, defy convention, honor regionalism and thrive on imagination. China, whose cuisine is as varied and classic as those of France and Italy, may soon show Americans how diverse its master chefs can be, now that trade with it will be opening up. Meanwhile, New Yorkers can feel well satisfied with the myriad of fine regional Chinese restaurants in the area, and Westchesterites should be proud to have one as inventive and special as Hunan Village, possibly the best in the county.

title: REGIONS Kenya and Tanzania: Contrasting Blueprints For Economic Growth
description: NAIROBI, KENYA KENYA and Tanzania, neighboring countries divided by a common but currently closed border, are also divided by development objectives and strategies as different as those of any two states on this continent, and the question is often raised, Which is doing better?

title: L.R. Schatz Weds Carrie Schoenfeld
description: The marriage of Carrie R. Schoenfeld to Lawrence R. Schatz took place yesterday in the Cottage Room of Hampshire House. Rabbi Hillel Friedman performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Cantor David Rosenswcig.

title: Koch Tells Bay Ridge Residents Golf Course Won't Be Shut Down
description: Mayor Koch reassured residents of the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn yesterday that the popular Dyker Beach public golf course would not be closed by the city as part of a program to eliminate city recreational facilities that are too costly to operate.

title: Bolivia Sets Open Election and Return to Civil Rule
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 3  The decision of Bolivia's military regime to restore civilian government through fair elections without officially supported candidates has produced widespread satisfaction and a burst of activity by political parties.

title: Karen Gayle Weiss Is Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Frances Weiss of Roseland, N.J., of the engagement of her daughter, Karen Gayle Weiss, to Richard B. Ginsburg, son of Mr. and Mrs. David M. Ginsburg of West Orange, N.J. The future bride is the daughter also of the late Eugene Weiss. A June wedding is planned.

title: Americans Provide Many Reasons For Partiality to China Over Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3  From what our Government tells us, I get the impression that Russia is out to get us and that war is imminent, said Donna B. Stone, who sells real estate in Seal Beach, Calif. Our relations with China are improving and I'm delighted. I hope they become stabilized to balance the threat from Russia.

title: Corporate Giants Invade the Residential Market
description: SOUTHINGTON, Conn.  The JAnn Inc. realestate agency occupies a small, twostory house here along strip of fast food outlets. John Hill, the owner, is an earnest, husky man with graying brown hair tumbling over his ears. He wears a polyester jacket, the color of McDonald's yellow arches, with a plastic name tag over the breast pocket. One of his four lapel pins commends him for having boosted his sales by over 30 percent a year, and another, ovalshaped, says, Believe.

title: Stephanie Lazar Fiance Of Robert Wayne Bellish
description: Dr. and Mrs. Norman D. Lazar of New York and Amagansett, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Stephanie Diane Lazar, to Robert Wayne Bellish, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Bellish of the Bronx.

title: REGIONS
description: MANAMA, BAHRAIN SRIFTING political alliances and the fallout from the Camp David peace talks are forging a new direction for economic developments in the Arab Middle East. For the first time in nearly a decade Egypt has turned toward the West and away front its traditional Arab allies to fulfill the bulk of its aid requirements.

title: OTTO ZIPPER
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 3 (AP)  Otto Zipper, a Ferrari representative in the western United States and owner of a Ferrari Daytona model entered in the 24 Hours of Daytona endurance race, died last night on the eve of the race. He was 65 years old.

title: Arts Council Gets Favorable Notices
description: THE Council for the Arts in Westchester, which last year distributed a total of $200,000 to about 100 organizations in the county, has begun sifting through applications for grants that may total as much as $300,000 this year. Since the nonprofit organization's first full year of operation in 1966, its annual budget has grown from $5,800 to a projected figure of perhaps $900,000 for the 199780 fiscal year, according to Stephen Goldshore, the council's executive director.

title: Move to Raise Drinking Age Gains Strength
description: HARTFORD AMOVE to deny I8yearolds the right to drink or purchase liquor appears to be gaining strength in the Legislature.

title: Prof. Case Makes Some Political Waves
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THE setting was quite comfortable for Clifford Philip Case's first lecture as the Eagleton Institute's visiting professor of politics, even though Woodlawn, the sprawling Colonial mansion on the Douglass College campus of Rutgers University, was slightly disrupted for the occasion.

title: Ann Shellenberger, John A. Insalaco 2d Plan April Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Adamson Shellenbergea of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Leisenring Shellenberger, to John Anthony Insalaco 2d of Hampton, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio John Insalaco of Willimantic, Conn. An April wedding is planned.

title: The Economy: Interpreting the Indicators
description: Where is the economy headed? Based upon the figures of two key economic indicators issued last week, the answer is clear: upend down.

title: OUTLOOK Troubled Shipping Looks for Safe Harbor
description: AS one of the world's oldest and most troubled industries, shipping mirrors the state world commerce. Over the last five years has reflected the ferocious competition international trade and the sluggish pace of economic activity. In spite of a brief pickup last year and a slowly improving situation, the outlook remains grim.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Paging through this year's seed catalogues can be unsettling. Enticing offerings make traditionalists break rank and try new things. Here are a few of them:

title: VICTORIA OCAMPO, 88; WRITER IN ARGENTINA
description: Victoria Ocampo, the Argentine writer, publisher of the international literary magazine Sur and an exponent of cultural bridges between intellectuals in the Americas and Europe, died Jan. 27 at San Isidro, a suburb of Buenos Aires. She was 88 years old.

title: Curing Urban Ills
description: FOR several decades now observers of the urban scene have noted the declining fortunes of American cities, especially those of the Northeast and Midwest. Slums, increased welfare loads and unsafe streets have become the hallmark of the urban crisis. But the major element of this crisis must be seen as the gap between the amount of money a city such as Bridgeport receives in taxes and revenues, and the level of services it provides.

title: St. John's Registers 4th Straight Victory
description: Reggie Carter pumped in 19 points as St. John's rolled to an 8052 college basketball victory over Niagara before 4,527 fans at Alumni Hall in Jamaica, Oueens last nieht.

title: Ideas &Trend's
description: When he was not being serious, Pope John Paul II appeared to be enjoying himself hugely last week. He watched dancers in peasant and Aztec costumes, went to a rodeo, swept small children into his arms and sang a traditional Mexican song in Polish.

title: THE VIEW FROM
description: Four years ago, in Paris, I was shown a film by young Turkish director, Yilmaz Guney. It was called Umut, the Turkish word for hope, and I liked it very much. The film maker, also Umurs leading actor, was in jail - for a second time. He had been imprisoned at the age 20 because of a short story he had written which the Turkish Government of the time considered Communist propaganda. His second conviction was on a political charge: Guney had provided harbor for antiGovernment agitators.

title: RELIGIOUS MATERIAL GAINS ON AIRWAVES
description: Jim Bakker, the founder and chief personality of one of the country's leading evangelical television organizations, was almost in tears as he looked into the studio Cameras recently. Nineteen seventyeight was the year Jim Bakker died, he'said. Debts of $6 million had tnreatenea to cripple his PTL Television Network, whose budget was $40 million last year, most of it derived from small donations. The difficulties, Mr. Bakker said in a recent interview, were a result of extreme growth.

title: Events Today
description: Chi dram's Storytelling Hour: The author Robert Welber reeds from his own works to children from ages 3 to 6; refreshments for children and adults; 11 A.M.; Eeyore's Books for Children, 2252 Broadway. (For further information call 3620634.)

title: Radiation Reported in Northeast
description: SALT LAKE CITY. Feb. 3 (AP) densely populated section of the Northeast, including Boston and Albany. received heavy doses of radiation from atmospheric nuclear bomb tests in the early 1950's. a Salt Lake City newspaper reported yesterday.

title: FOOD A Butcher's Juicy Choices
description: NEW HYDE PARK THERE is no butcher block in the kitchen of Leon Lobel's New Hyde Park home, but that is less surprising than the fact that Mr. Lobel, one of Manhattan's bestknown butchers, eats meat or poultry only once or twice a week. He also can't stand the sight of blood oozing out of meat.

title: Ralph Gerson to Many Erica Ward May 20
description: Erica Anne Ward, special assistant to Lynn Coleman, general counsel of the Federal Department of Energy, and Ralph Joseph Gerson, special assistant to Robert S. Strauss, the President's special representative for trade negotiations,. will be married in Washington on May 20.

title: Elderly Reclaim Joys of Learning In Special Program in New York
description: Audrey Phillips was tired of speaking to her Spanish friends in brokerEnglish phrases punctuated with hand gestures. Determined to cross the language barrier, the 75yearold Mrs. Phillips enrolled in a course at her senior center in Brooklyn and was soon able to speak rudimentary Spanish sentences.

title: Mark Lane and People's Temple: A Cause to Back, Then Condemn
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Last September, Mark Lane was proclaiming Jonestown a socialist paradise and professing that he had found a conspiracy within the United States Government to destroy the Peopie's Temple and Its founder, the Rev. Jim Jones. By December, he was calling Jonestown a horror and Mr. Jones a paranoid murderer, insisting he had suspected as much all along.

title: Tristate Planners Face New Review
description: THE Governors of New Jersey, New York and Connecticut, responding to criticism of the Tristate Regional Planning Commission as wasteful, dilatory and lacking leadership, have ordered major new study of the agency, which controls the spending of billions of dollars a year.

title: An American Killed in a Coup
description: THE literature of paranoia is at flood tide. Scarcely a day goes by that a book or article does not warn of some fresh threat to our health, sanity or survival: saccharine, black holes, nuclear energy, the Central Intelligence Agency, children's television, COINTELPRO, Albania, aerosol sprays, the Moonies, U.F.O.'s, Operation Chaos, microwaves, French Canadians, the San Andreas Fault, the Bermuda Triangle, killer boes.

title: Hilary Gardner Sets June Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Wendell Gardner of Washington and Southampton. L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hilary Aylsworth Gardner, to Lars Erling Peterson. son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver A. Peterson of Washington. His mother, Ekher Peterson, is President Carter's special assistant for consumer affairs.

title: Literary Despots
description: THE title of this volume is somewhat misleading. Crane's letters to Winters are available, but not Winters's to Crane. Crane probably destroyed them, enraged by Winters's review of The Bridge in 1930; and even if they had survived that occasion, they could not be published, under the terms of Winters's will, until 1993. But Thomas Parkinson's book is extremely valuable. Only one of Crane's letters to Winters is published in Brom Weber's The Letters of Hart Crane 19161932 (1952). Nearly 50 are printed in Mr. Parkinson's book, with judiciously informative comment and elucidation. We are also given a pretty clear indication of Winters's response to Crane's letters, sometimes by reading istween Crane's lines, sometimes by referent to Wei ters's letters to Allen Tate.

title: China, 1979: The Ways And Means
description: Suddenly, China is emerging as one of the mostcoveted vacation destinations in the world. It is just about a year since the Chinese authorities began admitting Americans as tourists, rather than as politically approved members of scientific or friendship teams. And in that year, China has rapidly emerged, for those who can afford it (prices ascend steeply from a minimum of about $1,000 person for a brief barebones visit), as the in place to go.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Next Thursday at Houston's Jones Hall, the Houston Ballet will present the premiere of Ronald Hynd's version of Papillon, the only ballet tury Romantic ballerina who created the title choreographed by Marie TagBoni, the 19thcenrole in La Sylphide and the only work for which Jacques Offenbach composed a full ballet score.

title: Deluxe Crops Are Worth the Effort
description: Peas and lima beans, the herbs basil and French tarragon, currants, raspberries and quince are deluxe crops. Money can't always buy them in the market, at least not in their prime. Yet in the home garden, I find them easier to grow than carrots.

title: Moyers: A Regular Audience Is Better Than a Big One
description: From his office high atop the Henry Hudson Hotel, Bill Moyers surveys a wide. grey swath of urban decay. If it is not the most uplifting panorama, Mr. Moyers is not cornplaining. After twoyears in commercial television, he says the view from public television looks pretty good. His Bill Moyers's Journal returns to public television tomorrow evening at. 9 for series of 26 weekly conversations, essays, documentaries and at least one dramatic recitation  Jams Earl Jones reading from the works of South African dissident Nelson Mandl. la. (Tomorrow's program, a film called Harvest, documents the struggle of two young New York social workers to make a go of a family farm in North Dakota.)

title: GARDENING First Aid for Trees Damaged by Storms
description: THERE is a saying among groundsmaintenance people to the effect that storms are nature's way of pruning. With the ground littered with branches after a storm such as that of Jan. 24, which brought strong winds and heavy rainfall, there can be little doubt that this is true.

title: Taking Stock Of the City's Cultural Czar
description: No one can say that Henry Geldzahler, the city's voluble and visible Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, is a man of narrow focus. At lunch the other day, he put outin what seemed like one nonstop breatha fluent flow of information, ideas and proposals, including such notions as the possible usefulness of the Disney Corporation in the proposed redevelopment of 42nd Street; the employment of the oftenvacant top floors of the city's schools as artists studios, the establishment of a string of $12to$15aday pensions run by delightfully mad Czech landladies to lure less affluent cultural tourists to the city.

title: Television This Week
description: 8 P.M. (2) ROCKY. The TV premiere of the 1976 Academy Awardwinning film written by and starring Sylvester Stallone. 8 (13) TO MRS. BROWN: A DAUGHTER. A onehour documentary about the recent birth of Louise Brown, the first socalled testtube baby, including interviews with her parents and with other couples hoping to use the same technique of fertilization.

title: BOAT PEOPLE AIDED AT A MANILA CENTER
description: MANILA, Feb. 3  Tucked away in a remote section of Santa Isabel College here is an inconspicuous tworoom socialaction center that has done a big job in helping resettle Vietnamese refugees.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor: The Carter Administration is increasingly relying on persuasion in directing the allocation of the nation's economic resources. Persuasion as a tool to limit inflation may turn out to be effective as most people  whether rich or poor  understand that they can benefit from limitations in the rate of inflation. Thus the degree of success of the current voluntary wage and price controls depends upon the business community's understanding of the issues and compliance mechanisms involved.

title: Genre Items
description: ONE expression now forbidden to reviewers spy fiction is farfetched. What could be farther fetched than William Colby, the former director of the Central Intelligence Agency, having deny the charge that he is a Soviet mole? (My theory is that the socalled C.I.A. is a cover to distract the other side while the real spooks work out of the Bureau of Standards.) Anyhow, Edward Jay Epstein, who made reality resemble fantasy in Legend, his book about Lee Harvey Oswald, makes a fantasy out of reality in this flamboyant suspense novel.

title: That Women Know Themselves
description: IVIAN GORNICK is precisely the kind of feminist the world needs. She has worked with exemplary energy to rescue the Movement from the infighting that has plagued it from its beginnings. She has been equally valorous in her attempts to dispel its manhating image. In this new book - 22 [Met essays Written over a period 0110 years for The New York Times, Ms. and the Village Voice  Miss Gornick speaks out against any doctrines or dogma that could threaten the primary goal of the Movement: this she defines as women's increased selfknowledge. She is constantly on the alert for the false solidarity of ideological sisterhood, for the dogmatism of those feminist party hacks who tend to exchange one crude ideology for another. She does not oppose the institution of marriage per se, only attacks the societal myth that holds that marriage is the Francine du Piessix Gray's most recent book Lovers and Tyrants, a novel.

title: TestTube Baby Documentary
description: To Mrs. Brown, a Daughter, which will be shown from 8 to 8:50 o'clock tonight on WNETTV, is a firstrate documentary account of the birth of the first testtube baby in England last July.

title: Coast Guard 64, Queens 54
description: The unbeaten Coast Guard Academy outscored Queens College, 133. in the second overtime period and defeated Queens, 6454, tonight. Dave MacLeish scored 5 of his 13 points in the second overtime, including the winning shot with 2:15 left.

title: Panel to Examine Tristate Commission
description: THE Governors of Connecticut, New York and New Jersey Connecticut, responding to criticism of the Tristate Regional Planning Commission as wasteful, dilatory and lacking leadership, have ordered a major new study of the agency that controls the spending of billions of dollars a year.especially when it talks about the housing needs of the poor, the minorities and the elderly.

title: Blacks: Hardly Monolithic
description: PHILADELPHIA  Much too often, public discussion and press reports concerning the black community use the terms poor, disadvantaged  and black interchangeably. This terminology grossly distorts the reality of the contemporary black experience and suggests that blacks are a. monolithic socioeconomic group.

title: The Tax Issue and Smaller Class Sizes
description: THE recent controversy in Ossining over reducing the size of its elementaryschool classes to 15 children has served to highlight the problems and inequities of financing education through property taxes.

title: Philip Brandmeier, Architect, Fianc of Kathleen McNulty
description: Kathleen Kelly McNulty, manager of Bloomingdale's video studio in its New York store, and Philip A. Brandmeier, manager of the General Motors Building on Fifth Avenue, plan to be married in April.

title: THE CAMBODIAN DILEMMA
description: Fifteen years ago in Paris, Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia was explaining to a group of journalists the complicated situation of his country and his efforts to keep it out of the spreading war in Indochina. Seeing ignorance and confusion writ large on my face, he said, My dear friend, to understand what I am trying to achieve, just remember this: All of Southeast Asia is destined to become Communist. All that I am trying to do is this - when it happens in Cambodia. I want it to happen without breakage.

title: Carew Goes to Angels for 4 Players
description: Rod Carew changed teams yesterday, but he's not coining to New York to play for the Yankees. The Minnesota Twins traded baseball's best hitter to the California Angels, the team he wanted to play for all along. The Twins received four players in return  Ken Landreaux, Paul Hartzell and two minorleaguers.

title: Engineered For Living
description: To many interior designers, television sets, stereos and artificallighting equipment are disrupting intrusions in the home and so should be banished from view. To Robin Jacobsen, however, they are works of art, and he readily features them in his work, as is clear from the Jacobsendesigned apartment shown here. He treats the argon lighting and Advent television - as well as the view of the bridge - as decorative elements in his overall scheme. They take the place of accessories, says Jacobsen. Variety in this apartment is confined to subtle shifts in texture - from the marble of the tabletop to the wool velvet of the carpet to the quilted worsted of the banquettes. Visual confusion is prohibited; people provide the action.

title: GARDENING Art Nouveau Ladies in South Orange
description: SOUTH ORANGE WE SAW some of those Art Nouveau ladies recently. You know, the ones with the aloof, virginal look, the ones with their clothes about to fall off their lithe, young bodies.

title: A Saga of Power And a Hair Dryer
description: Anyone who has traveled abroad with a teenage daughter will recognize that there are certain necessities whose importance exceeds even that of passports and money  that must be taken along. Among these are hair dryers. But there is a problem: Hair dryers need electricity to drive the fan to force the hot air onto the hair.

title: Italy's Christian Democrats Are Masters of Survival
description: ROME  Italy's Christian Democrats are never more impressive than when power seems to be slipping from their hands and then doesn't. It happens all the time. There have been 39 governments, all of them headed by Christian Democratic prime ministers, since December 1945, when Alcide de Gasperi. the party's postwar leader, formed his first cabinet after the fall of Fascism. There were crises, some lasting many months, whenever a government fell, and additional crises when others did not fall, but always the Christian Democrats came out on top.

title: Alexandra Elmslic Engaged to Pastor
description: Jean Elmslie of Palm Beach, Fla., has announced the engagement of her daul:;liter, Alexandra Elmslie, to the Wayne Rodney Whitelock, both of Princeton, N.J. Miss Elmslie is a daughter also of the late William Grey Elmslie.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: FOR drivers, cold and snow are right in there with the rest of the fourletter words, and morning can be a time for nightmares. Windshields need scraping, locks are frozen and cold metal and syrupy oil conspire to keep engines fmm startimz.

title: Carew Traded to Angels
description: Rod Carew, seventime American League batting champion, was traded by the Minnesota Twins to the California Angels. Section 5.

title: Follow Up on the News
description: In February 1975, not long before the fiscal darn broke at City Hall, New York officials told of an international agreement to create 5,000 jobs in the South Bronx and thereby confer instant prosperity on that depressed area. The city and Renzo Zingone, described as a major Italian builder, had signed a letter of intent under which Mr. Zingone was to erect a complex of factories in the Penn Central's Harlem River yards.

title: Nebraska Sandhills Ranchers Battle Bitter Winter
description: MULLEN, Neb., Feb. 3  Down on the north fork of the Dismal River, In the snowlocked emptiness of northwestern Nebraska's Sandhills region, Roy Johns hunched his shoulders hard against the cold edge of the wind.

title: Fashion
description: The new spring suits are designed to be worn everywhere, from the office to a restaurant. Obviously one doesn't wear a suit with a strapless lace bodice to the office, but it's certainly a stunning look for evening.

title: Police Dispute Arises Again in Long Beach
description: LONG BEACH IN the last nine years there have been nine persons heading this city's Police Department, and on Tuesday the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association will try to make it 10.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: BY THE time that people reach the office of Delores Elaine Keller in the Bergen County community of Woodcliff Lake, they're more than likely tied up in psychosexual knots. And so Dr. Keller has to do two things.

title: Other National Events
description: One hundred and fifty million census questionnaires are to be printed this month; every residential address in the country is about to be listed; elaborate plans have been made to reach residents usually missed, particularly among blacks and other minority groups; at this critical moment, the United States Bureau of the Census is undergoing major changes. Three key officials have unexpectedly retired and the Carter Administration last week was seeking to remove the man at the top, Manuel D. Plotkin. No reason was offered, but dissatisfaction with his political talents, not proles sional capabilities, was suggested.

title: Place Settings
description: Long before we know what kind of food a new restaurant is serving, ambitious publicists tell us virtually everything about its decor and theme. For these days, it appears, the interior decorator is at least as highly valued as the chef.

title: Record Potato Crop Reported
description: SAN FRANCISCO. Feb. 3 (UPI)  The biggest American potato crop on record  31.8 billion pounds  was harvested last fall. That is about 93.6 billion mediumsized potatoes, according to the Potato Board, the promotional organization for growers nationwide.

title: To Cathay With Pen and Sketchpad
description: Our workshop was the first artists group to visit since China began to encourage tourism. Our number included several professional artists, a lawyer, a dentist, a realtor, an Indian princess from Oklahoma, two industrialists, millionairess and Mrs. Joseph Stilwell Jr, the widow of the muchrevered general. we visitea canton, nangcnow, Shanghai and Peking. In each city, exhibitions, seminars and visits to art schools were arranged for us. One of the two guides who accompanied us everywhere was a professor of English at the Second Foreign Language Institute in Peking and had formerly taught art; he soon began painting along with Dong.

title: REGIONS
description: SALISBURY, RHODESIA SIX years of internal war, a world recession and international sanctions have debilitated Rhodesia's economy to the extent that there is considerable doubt as to whether the country could meet a major escalation of the conflict from its own resources.

title: Poverty
description: I am poverty.

title: L.I. to Get More Air Time on TV News
description: Long Islanders will soon be seeing more and more of something unusual on tplpvicion news nroerams: themselves.

title: Fort Worth Stock Fair Has Western Tang
description: FORT WORTH, Feb. 3  Tom Peters, who has been selling his Shady Oaks Western hats at the Southwestern Exposition and Fat Stock Show here since 1929, can become a trifle offended if someone suggests that the late Archbishop Makarios of Cyprus might not have worn the beaverskin cowboy hat that Mr. Peters save him several years ago. Sure he wore it, said Mr. Peters, an 83yearold Greek immigrant who brings to his stockshow booth a bulletin board filled with snapshots of dozens of celebrities to whom he has given samples.

title: 2 Die in Philadelphia House Fire
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 (AP)  A grocer and an 1lyearold boy died today in a house fire in the city's Tioga section, the authorities said. They were were identified as William Harrison, 35 years t old, and Keith Steidham.

title: Discovery in Newark
description: NEWARK ABANDONED by his wife and children, afflicted with cancer, and With his painting arm paralyzed as a result of an automobile accident. Arshile Gorky  one of the great modernists of our time  hanged himself in 1948, lie was 44 years old. The fates have not been much kinder to Gorky's art than they were to the artist himself.

title: Connecticut ThisWeek
description: BRIDGEPORT  Christo: The Running Fence and Reichstag Projects, drawings, photographs and collages related to these projects, Monday through Feb. 27, weekdays 9 to 5, Housatonic Community College, 510 Barnum Ave. Telephone 5796400.

title: A New or an Old Home?
description: Should you marry a tall girl or a short one? A fat man a thin one? Should you buy an old home or a new one? Suit yourself. There are, as you may have heard, advantages and disadvantages.

title: Seton Hall Upset by St. Peter's
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J.. Feb. 3  St. Peter's continued as the No. 1 giant killer In Eastern college basketball tonight with a 7770 upset victory over Seton Hall before 3,200 surprised fans in Walsh Auditorium.

title: To Clone a Computer
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  Among the ranks of the high technology companies that dot the landscape of Northern California's Silicon Valley, the National Semiconductor Corporation is the prosperous giant of integrated circuitry, with 1978 sales of $494 million, a workforce of 28,000 in plants in 13 countries. But National is a perplexing neighbor.

title: Eastern Europe's Dilemma: It's in The Red
description: BELGRADE. YUGOSLAVIA FOR much of last year, McDonnellDouglas workers feasted on 200,000 Yugoslav hams that the company received as partial payment for two new DC10's that Jugoslovenska Aerotransport bought recently. MasseyFerguson, the AmeriEastern Europe's Dilemma: It's in The Red can tractor company, is selling skis made in Poland as part of a lucrative jointventure it is undertaking near Warsaw.

title: Third World Industrializes, Challenging The West...
description: TOKYO WITH South Korean steel being used California construction sites, television sets from Taiwan being marketed in Europe, tractors from India being sold in the Middle East and the China emerging dramatically as a major potential industrial force, concern is mounting over how far developing economies will undercut established industries in the advanced nations Japan, the United States and Europe.

title: Carlotta Shields Fiancee Of Robert W.W. Squire
description: Mrs. W. Lyle Thompson of Middlebury. Conn, and William Shields Jr. of New York and Sharon. Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carlotta Goodnow Shields, to Robert Wilson Welles Squire, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur Welles Squire of Boise, Idaho, formerly of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Questions/Answers
description: CAT BOX FILLER

title: Associated Press
description: FAST TRIP: Beth Heiden en route to winning 1,500meter event yesterday world speedskating championships at The Hague. Story, page 4.

title: New Station Puts Spotlight on Fairfield
description: AT 7:30 P.M. tomorrow, when millions of Americans start watching The Muppets, In Search of... or Hollywood Squares on the national television networks, Fairfield Focus on Sports will take to the airwaves from a nondescript basement studio in Fairfield University.

title: Lisa Connor, Fredric Postle Plan to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John T. Connor of New Vernon, N.J., and Cotuit, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Forrestal Connor, to Fredric Patton Postle, son of Doanne Young Postle of Inverness, III., and the late Merton French Postle.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ANCHORAGE (SeaLand). San Juan Feb. a and King sloe 17; sails from Port Elizabeth. N.J.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: Andres Segovia, the 84yearold classical guitarist from Andalusia, Spain, will appear at the Plaza for the Performing Arts, 30 Van BruntStreet, Englewood. The virtuoso, who will be 85 on Feb. 21, has had an enduring effect on the literature, technique, construction and public acceptance of the guitar, both in his homeland, elsewhere in Europe and in the Americas.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: AHARTFORD commuter told the story to the Legislature's transportation chairman, who found it hard to believe. But the chairman, Representative Thom Serrani, a Stamford Democrat, checked and discovered that the state was indeed buying $3,000 worth of bells for its new rail cars.

title: Teng Plays China's American Card
description: When Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping of China arrived for his tour of the United States last week, he proved himself tireless, amiable and shrewd, and in more ways than one he showed he was out for bear. Sounding like the ghost of John Foster Dulles, he warned the West against the Soviet polar bear and urged a recognition of the Soviet Union as a common enemy. The Carter Administration, which is seeking a new strategic arms treaty with Moscow, had gone out of its way to assure the Russians that its relationship with Peking was not directed against them. President Carter noted delicately that the new amity between China and the United States does not mean that the two countries see eye to eye on everything.

title: $100,000 in Garments Are Taken By Gunmen From Delivery Truck
description: Two gunmen held up a delivery truck near Manhattan's garment district early yesterday, taking clothing valued at $100,000, the police reported. two men were unloading men's and women's clothing from a truck parked in front of the Merit Dress Delivery Company, at 524 West 36th Street, about 5 A.M. when the two gunmen approached, spokesman said.

title: Beth Morgenstern Plans Wedding to A.J. Polsky
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nathan R. Morgenstern of Great Neck, Li., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beth R. Morgenstern, to Andrew J. Polsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Polsky, also of Great Neck. An August wedding is planned.

title: OUTLOOK Dilemma in Food: Getting It to the Hungry
description: CHICAGO WORLD reserves of grain the source of threefourths of all human energy  are expected to reach a record 236 million tons by the end of the 197879 crop year. But because of unusual market conditions that have driven grain prices upward, experts say the benefits of increased food stocks will be limited, insofar as the world's halfbillion hungry poor are concerned.

title: STAMPS
description: The United States, with a new commemorative coming out Feb. 15 at Philadelphia, Pa.; is one of the first nations in the world to mark the International Year of the Child.

title: Miisic in Review
description: Howard Prince brought impressive credentials to his trombone recital last  Sunday at Carnegie Recital Hall. A 24yearold graduate of Juilhard, he has already been principal trombonist for a number of orchestras, and played with the Metropolitan Opera orchestra for a season.

title: A Corruption Inquiry Into Onondaga G.O.P. Turning to Democrats
description: SYRACUSE. Feb. 3  A twoyear investigation of charges of political corruption by employees of the predominantly Republican Frvemment of Onondaga County is now also looking into cornniaints against members of the DemoCratdminated Syracuse city government, according to the deputy state attorney general heading the investigation.

title: The Russians Are Coming
description: THEY came in 1972, for the first half of a series against Team Canada, their goalies wearing cage masks that made the National Hockey League players snicker. They swigged Coke by the gallon. They had strange warmup rites in which they skittered over the ice like water bugs, each player with a puck. And they vi rtually changed the face of North American hockey, shocking Canada's nervous system, as they narrowly missed winning the eightgame series  winning three games, losing four and tying one.

title: Bulova Won't Fight Loews Takeover Bid
description: The Bulova Watch Company has disclosed that its directors had decided not to oppose the recent $10ashare takeover proposal by the Loews Corpo. ration and would not make any recommendation to its stockholders whether they should accent or reiect the offer.

title: Music: 25 Waltzes. At Kitchen
description: THE program promised 25 a temporary piano waltzes, a the composers were an impn sive lot indeed. They rang from Philip Glass and John Cage Charles Wuorinen and Milton Babb to Lou narrison ana Ross Lee r rimy Roger Sessions and Virgil Thorns( Most of them had never been heard the Kitchen, the downtown avantgar performance space. But then, most them had never published waltzes, ther.

title: Religious Groups Plan to Testify At Senate Hearing on U.S. Cults
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP)  A Senate committee investigating the growth of religious cults in America will hear testimony from major Protestant and Jewish religious organizations. without such representation, the hearing tomorrow on the cult phenomenon would obscure the delicate and complex issues that surround the activities of minority religious groups, said Barry W. Lynn, legislative counsel for the United Church of Christ.

title: A Child's Worth
description: PROVO, Utah  My threeyearold, Sarah, tiptoed into my study and thrust her clenched fist under my nose. Warms know what I got in here? My study is offbounds to the children but it is difficult for Sarah to understand normal boundaries, or anything else normal. You may know a child like her  no matter how hard you try, she always manages to amaze, confuse and frustrate you. This time, however, I vowed that I would not be angry; I would not be surprised; in short, I would not allow her to win.

title: Status of Pro Basketball Worrying Players Group
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Feb.4  For two days, during more hours of meetings here than many representatives of the National Basketball Association would care to sit through, the word passed along by Commissioner Larry O'Brien was good. O'Brien carefully reminded owners that, over all, the N.B.A. had more stability now than it had had in years.

title: Making a Deal With Mexico
description: As everyone knows by now, Mexico sits on a pool of oil and gas second only to the reserves of Saudi Arabia. Its leaders intend to raise oil production at a measured pace, selling enough crude in world markets (at world prices) to finance a long period of industrialization. What will happen to the natural gas has vet to be determined. Its sole potential foreign buyer is the United States. Last year, after months of haggling over price, the two countries broke off negotiations and the Mexican Government vowed to develop the gas for domestic use. But we doubt that will be the Mexicans last word.

title: Dance: Tandy Beal
description: ANDY BEAL is a miniaturist. The solos and duets seen in program of her work presented at the Theater of the Riverside Church on Saturday were like precise jottings or painstaking sketches of an elbow, the arch of a foot or the peculiarly disembodied look of a face turned to the side.

title: U.S. Mideast Policy Criticized
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.. Feb. 4 (AP)  The AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith called on President Carter today to stop applying pressure to Israel and instead apply diplomacy forcefully to convince Arab countries to suonort the peace process by making clear to them that Israel is a fact of life in the Middle East and that all countries in the region will be best served by living together in peace. The league ended a fourday conference with a resolution saying Mr. Carter's Middle East policy is contradictory and is jeopardizing Israel's security.

title: Advertising
description: TED BATES & Company, which has been on a kick of major acquisitions, has struck again. This time it's Sawdon & Bess, a 30yearold shop with billings estimated at $30 million a year. The cash deal has not yet been signed, but that's all that remains to be done. S.& B., specialists in national and regional retail advertising, will become an autonomous subsidiary. Jerome Bess, 56 years old, will continue as its president and thief executive officer and join the Bates board.

title: Kuhn Put Cash Ban On Trade
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn, who in recent years has stepped into deals involving a number of players, placed his mark on the Rod Carew deal as well.

title: Sporting Gear
description: A swimmer who spends hours practicing regularly in chlorinated pools or salt water may consequently be prone to eye irritation, outerear infection and dry skin. Metrosport has come up with three products to fight these problems. One is EyeLife, a halfounce bottle of drops (for $1.39) that feature an optical decongestant to take the red out bloodshot eyes, and added viscosity so that the drops remain in the eyes longer. Another is Swimmer's Ear Drops, which helps dry waterplugged ears, fight bacteria and fungi, and restore the pH (acidalkaline) balance. A oneounce bottle costs $1.79. Aqua Care, in cream ($2.47 for a twoandahalfounce tube) or lotion ($3.30 for an eightounce bottle), is a nonscented skin moisturizer. These products are available many sporting goods stores. Inquiries can be directed to the maker, Metrosport USA. The address is 5805C Chimney Rock Road, Houston 77081, and the telephone number is (713) 6647272.

title: Some St. Louis Schools to Open
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 4 (AP)  The Board of Education says it will reopen some of the city's 156 schools tomorrow, but there will be no classes for the district's 74,000 students. The schools will be open for athletic activities and preschool Head Start programs, officials said. Meanwhile, the board and striking teachers are to resume talks in a strike that began Jan. 16.

title: Effects of the 78 Newspaper Strike on Sales and Ads
description: While it is too early to assess the longterm effect of the New York newspaper strike of 1978, the results to date include a new Westchester County newspaper, increased circulation and strengthened advertising for a number of suburban papers, rower circulations for the Daily News and The New York Post and relatively little change for The New York Times.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times on Saturday misident if ied two of fIcials of the Bankers TS Club of America. John D. Baker is a governor of the club and Douglas H. Soutar to the president.

title: Teng's Barbs: Fiery or Mild?
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 4  The warnings of hegemony and the other antiSoviet themes that Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping has sounded in the week since his arrival in the United States had been widely interpreted as an embarrassment To a carter Administration bent on concluding an early agreement with Moscow on limiting strategic arms. But, on the eve of Mr. Teng's departure, it can be seen that nis language has peen carefully measured.

title: Test in Seattle Challenges MinimumIncome Plan
description: SEATTLE  For years economists have wondered what it would be like if everybody in the United States were entitled to a guaranteed minimum income. Now, Cheryle Graham of Seattle knows what it was like for her.

title: Peking Official Confident on Modernization
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4  If you ask me whether or not it is possible for China to be the first country to modernize without the ill effects of industrialization, I cannot say we are assured of success, said Fang Yi, China's Minister of Science. To say that, would be boasting. All I can say is that we are trying our best.

title: De Gustibus A Few Thoughts on Cold Foods and Preparing Wild Rice
description: Many long years ago when I was youth in search of a job, I was interviewed as a potential food writer by the editor of what was then described as a shelter publication, a magazine that dealt exclusively with family and home.

title: TV: Moyers Back, Looks at Farm Life
description: WHBEN it comes to agriculture, New Yorkers know a thing or two. For example, that migrant laborers are cruelly exploited, that agribusiness has removed the flavor from tomatoes, that cattle ranchers lose money on every head they raise but make it up on the volume, and that the family farm is rapidly disappearing. in this country.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Selfregulation of the scandalmarred $65 billion Ginnie Mae market may start within a month, when the new PSA Government Inc. hopes to open its doors. [Page D1.]

title: Computer Evaluation of N.H.L.
description: The relative strengths of the 17 teams in the National Hockey League, as evaluated by The New York Times's computerized team power rating system (T.P.R.), are listed in the table at the right. The table reflects this season's games through Jan. 28.

title: Company ShakeUp on L.I. Pits 3 Brothers in a Dispute
description: Last Dec. 28, the board chairman of Long Islandbased corporation suddenly dismissed its president, who was vacationing in Hawaii, and one of its vice presidents, who was vacationing in Florida.

title: Tax Complaints Growing in Rockland
description: NEW CITY, N.Y. Sheila Dunn, a _ nurse and the. wife of. a retired New Ybrk City police officer, looked unhappy the other day as she left the window marked Receiver of Taxes in the Clarkstown Town Hall. It's getting to the point where we're going to be taxed right out of the area, said Mrs. Dunn, who added that she and her husband paid nearly $3,000 a year in property taxes on their $60,000 ranchstyle house in New City, the Rockland County seat.

title: U.S. Film Box Offices Set A Record Gross in 1978
description: WASHINGTON  The 1973 boxy fice gross at ArnFricnn movie theate broke all dollar records, and the nut ber of tickets sold was the highest in years, Jack Valenti, president of tl Motion Picture Association of Ame; ca. has announced.

title: Soviet Dissident Gives Arms Treaty Priority Over Drive for Rights
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, although one of the most outspoken activists for democratic freedoms in the Soviet Union, says he believes that the human rights issue, however important, must not be allowed to obstruct efforts by Washington and Moscow to negotiate a new agreement curbing strategic weanone.

title: A Promotion For Lois Wyse
description: Marc A. Wyse, one of the prides of Cleveland advertising, has promoted his wife, Lois, one of the prides of the Big Apple. After 26 years as president and chief executive officer of Wyse Advertising. lately of both cities, ne nas mace the big step to chairman but has dragged the chief executive officer title along.

description: HALHUL, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, Feb. 4  Arab students, demonstrating against the military administration, clashed today with Israeli soldiers and policemen here and in other West Bank towns.

title: 45 Affirmed Scores
description: ARCADIA. Calif., Feb. 4 (AP)  Affirmed, the Triple Crown winner of 1978, burst out of his slump with a sub, stitute rider, Laffit Pincay, aboard and won the $232,500 Strub Stakes by 10 lengths at Santa Anita today.

title: Air Deregulation: City Problems
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  From early indications, mediumsized cities may stand in greater jeopardy than smaller towns of losing airline service as regulations are lifted from the industry, according to the chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board.

title: ESSAY Friedman Amendment
description: EASTON, Md.  A specter is haunting Congress: the specter of a Constitutional Convention.

title: The Rev. Andrew Seidler, at 76; Once an Aide to Frank S, Hogan
description: The Rev. Andrew Seidler, a former assistant district attorney in New York City and a newspaper reporter, died Saturday in Dallas at the age of 76. He had lived in Dallas since he joined the priesthood in 1964.

title: Opera: Garbis Boyagian Makes Met Debut as Amonasro inAda
description: THE cast for this winter's run of Aidas at the Metropolitan Opera is largely different from last fall's, and Saturday evening's perfarmance served in addition as the occasion of a debut with the company, that of Garbis Boyagian as Amonap.

title: FreezeOut in Refrigerators
description: The refrigerator, a luxury in many parts of the world, is standard equipment in the American kitchen, so common that fewer than two homes in 100 manage without one.

title: A Gilded Setting for the Winter Party
description: On the street, they call it smarts, but one doesn't talk that way about the upper crust. No, no, perish the thought. The people involved would have the vapors, and the Metropolitan Club, well, one can only imagine.

title: Islanders, Canadiens Sweep Player Poll
description: IF National Hockey League players were doing the choosing, instead of the fans, the starting team of N.H.L. allstars for the series against the Soviet national team would consist entirely of Montreal Canadiens and New York Islanders, three from each club. The players would pick Clark Gillies, Bryan Trottier, Guy Lafleur, Larry Robinson, Denis Potvin and Ken Dryden.

title: Music: The Kogans Play Beethoven
description: LEONID KOGAN has been a fixture on the international violin scene for more than 20 years, virtuoso whose reputation was made on the strength of impeccable technique, silky tone and a dignified reserve that he brought to everything he played, whatever the period or style. Those qualities were evident in the Soviet artist's recital yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, where he was joined by his daughter Nina, a strong if not infallible pianist, in a program of Beethoven sonatas.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores. Los Angeles, announced that George Townson, president of the Sunset House division, would assume the additional responsiblity of chief executive officer.

title: Walkout Averted at Exchange
description: A threatened strike by trading floor and backroom financial employees of the New York Stock Exchange was temporarily averted last night with an agreement by both sides to maintain the status quo during negotiations.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP)  The Postal Service may finally be headed for the first budget surplus in its history after failing throughout the 1970's to eliminate deficits.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Special Committee of 24 on Decoloni zation11 A.M.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Skating: World Title Goes to Beth Heiden
description: THE HAGUE. Feb. 4 (AP)  Beth Heiden, a 19yearold student from Madison, Wis., overcame a fall near the finish of the final event today and joined her brother, Eric, as a world speedskating chamnion.

title: Ginnie Mae Dealers Set Rules Body
description: The growing but tarnished market for securities guaranteed by the Government National Mortgage Association may start being policed by a selfregulatory organization this month if the plans of a securitiesindustry group work out.

title: Iowa Tied for First in Big Ten
description: Lute Olson was exultant after his Iowa Hawkeyes turned a 4525 halftime lead into a 9771 victory over Minnesota Saturday night that moved Iowa into firstplace tie with Ohio State in the Big Ten Conference.

title: Chess:
description: The former world champion Mikhail Botvinnik, in his introduction to the book The French Defense, by Svetozar Gligoric, Wolfgang Uhlmann and Anatoly Karpov, excludes the Sicilian Defense from a contemporary repertory because it is so worn out that in the near future it will turn into rags.

title: To a Lot of Sailors, Frostbite Means Delight
description: THE dinghies sail across the harbor, dodging ice floes. They bear names such as Frigid Bare, Chilly Willy, Joe Cool, Agony and Short Snort. Neither arctic breezes nor stinging spray chills the enthusiasm of the frostbite sailors. The competition, they say, generates enough heat. invanaoiy the trostbite fleets in waters around New York draw the most stubborn, aggressive sailors. Some race offshore yachts during the summer, while the majority compete in OneDesign classes. There are club champions and worldtitle holders, as well as beginners and weekend sailors. All have one thing in common: They would rather race through the winter thali not race at all.

title: Radio
description: 7Noon. WNYCFM: Mornings Pro Musics. Sinfonia in G, Richter; Adagio for Strings, Barber; Five Pieces, Holborne; Concerto grosso in E, Geminiani; Piano Concerto No. 6, Mozart; Oboe Concerto in D, Vivaldi.

title: Hope of Creating Perennial Corn Raised by a New Plant Discovery
description: In a remote mountain region in Mexico, a perennial plant that crossbreeds with corn has been discovered, awakening hopes for producing a perennial variety of that food crop with revolutionary implications for agriculture.

title: The New York Times
description: In Central Park yesterday, at least for a little while, a hint of spring was the air and winter's end seemed near. A runner was silhouetted against the skyline as he set his pace in a Road Runners Club meet. Youngsters played king of the hill on the melting ruins of an artificialsnow sculpture in the Sheep Meadow. And, in the middle of the drained pond near 59th Street, friend of the ducks brought them something good to eat.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON CONFUSION reigns over Saudi Arabia's plans for oil production and pricing, and much of the confusion appears to be of the United States Government's makina Loot week Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, let it be known that it intended to limit production to 9.5 million barrels a day, down substantially from the production pace of late last year. And the Saudis decided to charge a small premium on a million barrels of the output.

title: Chinese Scholars Arriving in the Metropolitan Area
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 1  For an hour today, one of China's leading mathematicians scribbled on a blackboard in the universal language of equations during the first lecture by a Chinese scholar at the Institute for Advanced Study since the Chinese Communists came to power 30 years ago.

title: Bank Holdups on Rise as Robbers See Easy Score
description: The robbery took place last Monday, 15 minutes after the bank opened, and later that morning a group of New York City detectives and two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation sat around table in a bank conference room and critiqued the crime.

title: Tennis: Borg Routs Vilas Again in Final
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 4 (AP)  Bjorn Borg, threetime Wimbledon champion, capped his comeback from a sixweek layoff by maintaining his mastery over Guillermo Vitas with a 63, 61 rout today in the final of a $175,000 tennis tournament.

title: Gerulaitis Takes Arkansas Tennis
description: NORTH LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 4 (AP)  Topseeded Vitas Gerulaitis defeated Butch Waits, 62, 62, in the final today of a $50,000 tennis tournament.

title: Market Place
description: THE Federal,N court order issued last Wednesday allowing United Technologies to complete a takeover of the Carrier Corporation presents United with some interesting problem'. That's because the order is qualified, requiring United to hold separate the Carrier assets.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: What happened to Bill Willoughby, the young basketball player signed in 1975 out of Dwight Morrow High School in Englewood, N.J.?

title: Milan Police Seize Four Persons Believed Linked to Red Brigades
description: ROME, Feb. 4 (AP)  The police have arrested three men and a woman and seized arms, ammunition and Red Brigades leaflets in a series of raids on suspected terrorist hideouts in Milan, the authorities reported today.

title: Dole to Form Campaign Group
description: EASTON, Md., Febs. 4 (UPI)  Senator Robert J. Dole, Republican of Kansas, who ran for the Vice Presidency with President Ford in 1976, said today that he would form a committee in the next few days to explore whether he should run for the Republican Presidential nomination. Mr. Dole said in an interview that he had scheduled an extensive speaking tour during the forthcoming Senate recess that would take him to New Hampshire, New York, Illinois, Michigan, West Virginia and Kentucky.

title: Farmers Group Predicts Few Problems in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP)  A spokesman for the thousands of farmers who plan to steer their tractor caravan into the nation's capital tomorrow in a demonstration for higher prices predicted today that the protest would go smoothly.

title: 5 Black College Officials Oppose Integration Order
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  The chancellors of the five traditionally black institutions in the I6unit University of North Carolina are due here Tuesday to urge Federal officials to keep hands off their state's current plan for meeting Federal standards for enhancement of the role of black schools.

title: Let's Put Life Into the N.B.A.
description: T HIS time of year is just a boring, drab time in the N.B.A. schedule, Paul Westphal of Phoenix said recently. Yes, indeed. Here we are at the AllStar break, and any number of conditions are clogging up the season's middle:

title: The City
description: A policy limiting new express bus lines carrying commuters into Manhattan has been announced by the chairman of the City Planning Commission.

title: Recital: Ohlsson Plays Beethoven and Chopin
description: G ARRICK OHLSSON's piano recital yesterday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall began boldly and brilliantly, with a sharply etched, pristinely executed account of Beethoven's Sonata No. 1 in F minor (Op. 2, No. 1). Mr. Ohisson shaped the music lightly but with invigorating verve, and his intelligence enabled him to accentuate such niceties as the sforzando flatted penultimate note in the descending figure that recurs throughout the first movement (F flat in the 23d bar, etc.) without sounding overobvious about it.

title: 7,000 WELFARE CASES ARE CALLED SUSPECT
description: ALBANY, Feb. 4  New York State's first crosscheck of virtually all its welfare recipients against a list of its wageearners shows 70,655 on both rolls, and ofI ficials estimate that about 7,000 of these !are receiving benefits fraudulently.

title: Laffite Wins Brazil Race
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. 4 (AP)  Jacques Laffite of France, driving a Ligier, started from the pole and was never challenged as he won the Brazilian Grand Prix auto race today.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Like a lot of club players, Frew McMillan is looking for a doubles partner. And he is accustomed to the best: Bob Hewitt, who will be sidelined at least three months because of a chronic shoulder problem.

title: Angry Vietnam Veterans Charging Federal Policies Ignore Their Needs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  Vietnam veterans, a relatively unorganized pressure group with little political power, are angrily challenging the Carter Administration's volicies toward them.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Maxie Anderson, left, named as the copper industry's Man of the Year with Ben Abruzzo, center, and Larry Newman after the trio successfully landed France after crossing the Atlantic by balloon last August.

title: A Building Boom in the Wrong Place
description: New York is a boom or bust town. After a decade of office building glut and no new construction, there is now an office shortage with rentals at record levels and a rush to build. The cycle is as predictable as the seasons.

title: Zaire Is Reported to Violate Shaba Refugees Amnesty
description: KAPANGA, Zaire  Zaire has violated a general amnesty granted last October to citizens of its Shaba Province who are returning home after fleeing to Angola during the rebel invasions of Shaba last year and the year before, wellinformed sources here say.

title: Track: PoleVault Mark in Peril
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Feb 4 (Reuters)  Dan Ripley set a world indoor polevault record last night at The Edmonton Journal international games by clearing 18 feet 5 inches, but it is unlikely that it will be recognized.

title: Joy Ann Lebow Is Bride Of Dr. William B. Cohen
description: Joy Ann Lebow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sylvan Lebow, was married in New York yesterday to Dr. William B. Cohen of Los Angeles, a vascular surgeon. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's brother, Mark Lebow, by Rabbi Howard A. Berman of Temple EmanuEl.

title: Shearson in Mortgage Broker Bid
description: Shearson Hayden Stone said yesterday that an agreement had been reached on a $16.8 million tender offer for the Western Pacific Financial Corporation, a leading mortgage broker based in Newnort Beach Calif.

title: Pravda Warns the U.S. On Tone of Teng's Visit
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 4 (AP)  Pravda, the Soviet Communist newspaper, accused the United States today of playing tricks in trying to disclaim the antiSoviet tone surrounding the visit of Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping of China. The paper warned the Carter Administration against thinking it was engaged in an innocent game.

title: 48 City High Schools Need to Change Staffs To Meet Racial Order
description: A total of 48 high schools  nearly hall of those in New York City  have been listed as needing changes in the racial makeup of their staffs in order to comply with Federal orders for school integration.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: LANGUAGE AND RESPONSIBILITY. By Noam Chomsky. Based on conversations with Mitsou Ronat. Translated from the French by John Viertel. 212 pages. Pantheon. $10.TWO years ago the French linguist Mitsou Ronat sat down in Cambridge, Mass., to have a long talk with Noam Chomsky. She spoke in French, he spoke in English, and what they said was taperecorded. Miss Ronat took the tapes back to Paris and, after translating Mr. Chomsky into French, published their conversation as a book. For this American version of that book, the admirable John Viertel had to translate everything back into English, without access to what Mr. Chomsky originally said in his own language. Mr. Chomsky then substantially revised the translation.

title: Commodities
description: PLATINUM, normally one of the dullest precious metals, is rapidly becoming a major attraction in the futures market. Indeed, the industrial metals, not gold, dominated trading last week as fears of a global shortage of platinum, silver and copper erew.

title: Poles in Deerfield, Mass., Protest Ethnic Remark in Wage Dispute
description: DEERFIELD, Mass., Feb. 4  Each year for the last four years, Police Chief John Skronski has asked for a pay increase. Each year it was denied by the town's Board of Selectmen, for reasons he believes were never made clear.

title: U.S. Pledge to Sell Advanced Jets To Taiwan to Be Sought in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 Several senators plan to seek a commitment from the Carter Administration to sell advanced jet fighter aircraft that were previously refused to Taiwan as part of the price for Congressional support for the termination of the mutual defense treaty with Taiwan.

title: Camp David Isn't Just a Retreat For the President It Is a Love
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  Franklin D. Roosevelt built it, Richard M. Nixon refurbished it in lavish fashion and Gerald R. Ford enjoyed occasional weekends there, but no previous President has spent as much time as Jimmy.

title: Outdoors: Staying Warm in Bitter Cold
description: ALLDAY traveling in the snowfilled woods can be an experience either uncomfortable even dangerous  or truly exhilarating. As long as you are in reasonably good physical shape, and whether you are 17 or 70, how your jaunt turns out depends almost entirely on whether you are knowledgeable enough to dress properly for the weather. Even in the most bitter cold, you can keep yourself comfortable. What follows are some ideas as to how.

title: Bride:
description: A New Jersey expert led the field into the two final sessions of the blue ribbon individual chanipionship here yesterdav afternoon at the New York Milton In the qualifying stage of this event, restricted to 36 experts qualified by past performance, Howard Hertzberg of Alpine, N.J., outdistanced the field. At the end of Saturday's play he was more than two boards ahead of his nearest rival.

title: Waterspout Injures 9 in Hawaii
description: LIHUE, Hawaii, Feb. 4 (AP)  Nine persons were injured yesterday when a waterspout  a tornado on water struck the southeast coast of Kauai Island and ripped through seven cottages of the Kauai Ssurf Hotel. The victims were released from Wilcox Hospital after treatment for cuts, scrapes and sprains, according to Becky Mumley, a nurse.

title: JOSEPH MAZER DIES; WAS ACTIVE ZIONIST
description: Joseph M. Mazer, honorary chairman and treasurer of the Hudson Pulp and Paper Corporation, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York of emphysema. He was 79 years old and lived at 900 Fifth Avenue.

title: 2 SIDES IN IRAN TAKE CONCILIATORY STEPS; CONTACTS REPORTED
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 4  The militarybacked Government of Prime Minister Shahpur Bakhtiar and the Islamic movement led by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini made conciliatory gestures today amid reports of secret contacts between the two camps.

title: U.N. Plan for Namibia Linked to Hope on Rhodesia
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  The United States and Britain are relying heavily on a peaceful evolution to independence for SouthWest Africa under United Nations supervision to reinvigorate the plan of the two Governments for a settlement in Rhodesia, according to American and British officials.

title: Smog Conditions Across Nation Are Seen Getting Slightly Woise
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  Smog conditions are improving in California but getting slightly worse over the rest of the nation, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: Sports Today
description: St. Francis, N.Y., at Queers College, women; Yeshiva at Queens, men, first game 6:30 P.M.

title: Friendship Pass No Longer Links Peking to Hanoi
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 4  Over the narrowgauge railroad between Nanning and Hanoi, China sent about six million tons of war materiel between 1971 and 1975 as part of its $10 billion aid package to help Vietnam fight American aggression.

title: Repos Key to Leak In U.S. Money Supply?
description: For 13 weeks now, to the growing puzzlement of banking and financial circles, the nation's money supply has been declining while the economy has continued to surge. How can that he? many moneymarket analysts are convinced that something is wrong with recent money supply figures, but most have been unable to identify the problem.

title: Opera: Galileo Galllei Has Premiere Upstate
description: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Feb. 4 Ezra Laderman is not one of America's more publicized composers, but he is one of the busiest, with a large number of published works, a sheaf of awards and honors and quite a few important commissions. One of those commissions came in 1967, when he composed a 90minute oratorio based on the life of Galileo for a CBS television special. A few years later, he and his librettist, Joe Darion, worked the material into an opera, which had its world premiere under the auspices of the TriCities Opera last night at the Forum Theater, a 1,500seat converted movie house.

title: Ballet: Eglevsky Offers Premiere of Pastorale
description: DANCE lovers who admire classical ballet's ability to absorb outside influences would have been delighted by the Eglevsky Ballet's weekend performances in Hempstead. L.I. Proarams at Hofstra University's John Cranioro Adams Playhouse included RussianAmerican tributes to Italy and Hungary and an American ballet based upon Italian poetry. Moreover, Friday night's program offered the premiere of a British choreographer's ballet inspired by French folk songs.

title: Santucci Asks a Judge To Abolish the Office Of Special Prosecutor
description: In a legal move growing out of a minor Queens misdemeanor case, John J. Santucci, the county's District Attorney, is seeking to have the courts abolish the office of John F. Keenan, the special state prosecutor for criminaljustice corruption.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The Jan. 16 issue of The Times featured an article on happiness. It states that the results of recent scientific scrutiny suggest that many traditional beliefs about happiness are incorrect. I didn't realize that my ideas on happiness are a result of traditional beliefs, but they may well be, for they certainly are not in agreement with recent scientific scrutiny.

title: Gotham's Shrinking
description: There is a simple but as yet unrecognized basic cause of all of New York City's fiscal woes: There has been a sharp population decline that has undermined the source of funds available to government and reduced the need for governmental expenditures. But the city government continues to act as if it were dealing with the needs of 7.8 million neonle. It is not.

title: U. S. Men Skaters Liberated
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 4  They have blended athletics and grace to a degree that gets spectators jumping out of their seats as if they were watching bodycontact sport. And so it was apnarent early this morning. during the finale of the United States figure skating championships, that the men had become the dominant force in this country and had surpassed the traditional role reserved for women skaters.

title: Diane Eisner Is Wed to Edward R. Korman
description: The marriage of Diane R. Eisner to Edward R. Korman, United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, took place late Saturday evening at the Bay Ridge Synagogue in Brooklyn. Rabbi Michael D. Shmidman performed the ceremony.

title: West Wins N.B.A. AllStar Contest. 134129
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Feb. 4  David Thompson turned in a spectacular performance today and won the mostvaluableplayer award for his role in leading the West to a 134129 victory over the East in the 29th National Baskethail Assocition All Star Game.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)School: Alive and Well! (5)New Zoo Revue

title: IV.A.A.C.P. Supports a Koch Recall
description: The head of the 25,000member Metropolitan Council of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday joined a move by the chairman of the state's Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus to mount a recall referendum against Mavor Koch.

title: Mrs. Carner Victor
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 4 JoAnne Carrier, the master of match play, overpowered Pat Bradley, 4 and 3, today to take her second successive Triple Crown Ladies Professional Golf Accociation matchnlav tournament.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: IVYWALL ECHOES Following the success of its Songwriters Salute series, the Citicorp Center is featuring some of the East's major informal collegiate singing groups throughout the month in the free entertainment series at the Market Atrium. These vocalists carry on one of the oldest and most enjoyable of college traditions, many of the groups having been formed years ago (the Yale Whiffenpoofs celebrate their 100th anniversary this year) and pass on songs from year to year and group to group, although each unit is a distinct entity.

title: Music: James Galway Plays 7 Flute Sonatas
