description: JAMES GALWAY is a small, bearded man who is extremely Irish, extremely charming and extremely good at his craft, which is playing the flute. Somewhat resembling a younger. slighter Peter Ustinov, he comes out with his instrument at shoulder arms, as carefree as can be, and smiles his audience into instant submission. Last night at Carnegie Hall Mr. Galway had plenty to smile at, since the place was filled and seats were put onstage to accommodate the overflow.

title: Korean Textile Talks Off
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 4 (AP) The United States and South Korea have ended four days of talks without an accord on 1979 quotas for Korean exports of eight textile products.

title: Miss Grimes in Trick, New Comedy Thriller
description: IN the new comedy thriller Trick, the successive mild surprises do not so much clarify mystery as disarrange it. It is shell game of sorts, and frequently pleasant one; but somewhere along the way the peanut has got lost.

title: Michigan Accepts VAT As U.S. Debates Issue
description: LANSING, Mich., Feb. 4  In Washington, Senator Russell B. Long talks about a radical redesign of the Federal tax system centered on adoption of a Federal value added tax, plus repeal of the Social Security payroll tax and deen cuts in inenme taxes.

title: Glen Jorgensen, 64, Led ConsumerLoan Service
description: Glen Jorgensen, former chairman of the board of C.I.T. Financial Services, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital following a long illness. Mr. Jorgensen was 64 years old and a resident of Garden City, L.I.

title: Only Ones, NewWave Rockers
description: THE latest British newwave rock band to reach these shores is the Only Ones, which was at Hurrah this past weekend. Except that, as seems so frequently the case, it's a little hard to stuff the Only Ones neatly into the newwave pigeonhole.

title: U.N. Faces Rare Labor Turmoil And Fears the Unrest Runs Deer
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb.2 The United Nations has long had a reputation as a paternalistic employer with an international staff regarded as an elite and wellraid civil service.

title: Of Rod, George And Big Apple
description: ARADIO station in Boston telephoned Saturday night to ask what George Steinbrenner meant when he complained that Rod Carew didn't appreciate the privilege of playing baseball for the Yankees in New York. If those people up in the Athens of America thought they would get an informed answer, chances are they would also believe that Leon Spinks reads the Dead Sea Scrolls for amusement. Still, it is easy to understand why Rod and George might have contrasting views of the Bin Annie. carew was oorn in uatun in the Panama Canal Zone, went to school and played sandlot ball in New York and was domiciled in Melbourne, Fla., Orlando, Fla. and Wilson, N.C., before taking up yearround residence in Golden Valley, Minn. As a player in the American League, he has been making regular trips to New York every summer since 1967 and has reached the conclusion that it's a nice place to visit but he wouldn't live there again if George Steinbrenner gave him the joint. Instead, he has now realized the American dream of settling down in Anaheim, Calif., within walking distance of Disneyland.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 5, 1979

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The strong rally in the credit markets that has pushed rates sharply down in early 1979 has called into question the widely held view that yields will keep rising throughout most of the first half of the year.

title: Fund Drive by State G.O.P. Seeking $1.9 Million Yearly
description: Facing a debt of nearly $1 million and virtually shut out of the patronagerich Democratic state administration, Republicans are beginning the most ambitious fundraising effort ever by a state party organization in New York.

title: Teng Inspects Boeing 747 Factory On Last Full Day of His U.S. Visit
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 4  On its last full day in the United States, the Chinese delegation led by Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping concentrated on aviation, with Mr. Teng inspecting the Boeing plant near here that assembles the 747 jetliner and another Deputy Prime Minister visiting the McDonnell Douglas aircraft factory in Long Beach, Calif.

title: Skiing: Miss Nelson Triumphs
description: PFRONTEN, West Germany, Feb. 4 (AP)  Cindy Nelson, the 22yearold star of the United States women's alpine skiing team, won her first World Cup downhill race since 1975 today. She triumphed by two onehundredths of second.

title: Science Aide Arrives in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 4 (Reuters)  Dr. Frank Press, President Carter's special adviser on science and technology, arrived tonight in Moscow with his delegation for meetings of the United StatesSoviet Joint Commission on Scientific and Technical Cooperation. Deputy Prime Minister Vladimir A. Kirillin, chairman of the State Committee for Science and Technology, welcomed the Americans.

title: Datlis
description: APONOWSKYBoris. Beloved husband of the late Leah. Devoted father of Florence Lltvack and Emanuel. Cherished grandfather of Howard, Gail and Jay Librack, Shelly, Adrian and Karen Aronowsky. Adored greatprandfather of Lisa and Stacey. Loving brother of Beatrice Jorcaf. Services BoulevardPark West, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.1.. today, 1:00 P.M.

title: NEWARK FIRE KILLS FIVE IN A TENEMENT
description: Five Newark residents, including four children, were killed last night when a fire, apparently set by three young arsonists, swept through a condemned cityowned apartment building in the city's downtown section.

title: Chief of Technology: Durable Bureaucrat
description: A Deputy Prime Minister and secondranking member of delegation to United States  Key administrator in science and technology, giving major responsibility for exchanges with developed nations  Unusual in having survived cultural Revolution and its aftermath without being purged.. Elected to Politburo in 1977  Served in Hanoi from 1956 to 1960 as trade representative.. Born in Fukien Province in 1916  Said to have joined Communists in Kiangsi Province as teenager in early 1930's  Graying and stooped, with straightforward, pleasant manner and purplish patch over right eye that appears to be birthmark.

title: Striking Actors Reach An Accord on Radio Ads
description: Negotiators for advertising agencies and striking television and radio actors reached a tentative settlement last night on new contracts that, if ratified this week, will end the sevenweekold strike.

title: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS UP TO $35 MILLION FOR NEW YORK CITY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  The Carter Administration has quietly moved to channel $20 million to $35 million to New York City to help it close its budget deficit next year. The funds would be made available through unilateral actions that would not require Congressional approval.

title: ANTHONY J. DEL MASTRO
description: EDISON, N.J. Feb. 4 (AP)  Anthony J. Del Mastro, a former associate dean of the College of Engineering of Rutgers University, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 61.

title: 8% Yields Seen For U.S. Issues
description: The Treasury's new eightyear notes scheduled for sale tomorrow and the longterm bonds Wednesday are both likely to yield about 8 percent, give or take a basis point or two, Government securities dealers predicted Friday.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PARIS, Feb. 4 (AP)  Hadol du Vivier, the beaten favorite in the Prix d'Amerique last week, scored a convincing victory today in the second leg of the French triple crown of trotting the $93,000 Prix de France at Vincennes race track.

title: Associated Press
description: GARBAGE CONTINUES TO PILE UP IN LONDON: Refuse in Leicester Square yesterday. Garbage collectors, gravediggers and school custodians in many parts of the country have been on strike. London has been the hardest hit. Most workers are seeking pay increases  to $120 from about $80 a week.

title: For Elizabeth Taylor Warner, Yet Another Part
description: RICHMOND Elizabeth Warner, as she prefers to be called, breezed into the state capital of Virginia the coiner day in her new role as wife of a United States Senator. She wore a dark mink coat, some of her lesser jewelry, and had a secretary and a local hairdresser in tow.

title: AT HOME ABROAD Reason For Hope
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest AfricaIn just three weeks a United Nations force is due to begin flying in here for one of the most ambitious operations ever undertaken by an international body. If it works, one territory in southern Africa will move peacefully to independence and majority rule in the next year. And the signs here are that it just might work.

title: Getting Started
description: A number of yacht clubs on Long Island Sound offer winter memberships to frostbite sailors at reduced rates, often as little as $100 or $150 for five months of racing.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Adrninistration/UP;

title: Baryshnikov Is Orpheus In City Ballet Revival
description: FOR many years, Orpheus, created in 1948 by George Balanchine and Igor Stravinsky, was one of the New York City Ballet's signature works. Very sadly, it seemed beyond the reach of both its performers and its audience in its revival Saturday night at the State Theater.

title: Black Hawks Beat Islanders, 54
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 4  A sure sign of an Islander slump emerged tonight following a 5.4 loss: the coach would not talk.

title: Many Chinese Americans In Seattle Object to Peking
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 4  For Rita Wang, life is a parade of poor and bewildered people asking for help.

title: Restrained Optimism on China
description: Washington, Feb. 4  As Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping finishes his spotlighted tour of American industry, officials of the Carter Administration say they have what one called restrained optimism over the possibilities of Increased American exports to China.

title: Environmentalists Unafraid of Conservative Trend
description: Environmentalist leaders agree that their movement, rounding out a historic decade, is unfazed by the recent shift of national sentiment toward governmental and fiscal conservatism.

title: Golf: Hinkle Captures 3Man Play off
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Feb. 4 Call it the giveaway open. Lon Hinkle blew a fivestroke lead. Mark Hayes held a lead of three shots as late as the 14th hole, and he lost it with a fourputt triple bogey followed by a bogey. Both of them nearly gave the tournament to Andy Bean, who had sneaked, unnoticed, into a tie. Then Bean lost it.

title: China Seeks Major Loan
description: TOKYO, Feb. 4  A group of 20 or so Japanese banks are planning their first major Eurodollar loan to China, totaling about $2 billion, says Asahi Shimbun. Japan's bieefst daily newsnaner.

title: Shah's Plans for Buying Abroad Will Be Cut, Bakhtiar Aide Vows
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 4  Iran's Economics and Finance Minister said in an interview today that the Bakhtiar Government planned a critical review of all foreign contracts signed by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, similar to the review already promised by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini if the Islamic government he favors comes to power.

title: The Editorial Notebook What Price the Double Nickel?
description: In New Yoric City. the 55mile speed limit is no burning issue. Potholes and congestion enforce the speed laws on the Van Wyck. But out where the interstates are smooth, the distances great and traffic lights scarce, 55 is a dirty number.

title: Maxine Smith Is Married To Thomas Armstrong
description: Maxine K. Smith of Stamford, Conn., daughter of Mrs. Jacob Kaplan of Somerset, N.J., and the late Mr. Kaplan, was married yesterday to Thomas E. Armstrong, senior vice president of Riviere du Loup Newsprint Ltd. and the Bear Island Paper Company, both in Greenwich. Conn.

title: Juror Who Opposed Conviction Of Flood Assailed by a Colleague
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI)  The other jurors yelled at the lone juror who held out for acquittal in the case against Representative Daniel J. Flood, cme of them said today, but efforts to change the juror's mind were to no avail.

title: Notes on People
description: In his Who's Who listing, Eubie Blake approvingly notes Edward Young's aphorism, Procrastination is the thief of time and adds: I have always been punctual. The pianist and cornposer of more than 1,500 songs almost broke his own rule yesterday, however, when the limousine taking him from his Brooklyn home into Manhattan was held up in traffic on the way to a matinee performance of the musical Eubie and the celebration, three days in advance, of his 96th birthday. He was in the front seat pushing me all the way, his young driver said. And they arrived one minute ahead of schedule.

title: Republicans Would Curb Spending With a Constitutional Amendment
description: EASTON, Md., Feb. 4  Republican leaders called for a constitutional amendment to limit Federal spending today and said at a major but informal issues meeting that they hoped Congressional action on such an amendment would divert support from a drive for a constitutional convention.

title: Japan to Invite Carter to Visit
description: TOKYO, Feb. 4 (AP)  The newspaper Sankei Shimbun said today that the Government would invite President and Mrs. Carter to make a fiveday state visit to Japan this summer. The paper said it was hoped the President would arrive about June 19, just before the economic summit meeting scheduled to be held here in late June.

title: Police Have Nicknames for Repeat Thieves
description: Last year, the New York City Police Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested 161 persons in the city on charges of bank robbery  a total that enabled the department to solve nearly twothirds of the bank robberies committed in the city in 1978. The following are accounts of some of the robbers, all but one, still at large:

title: Rich Schools and Poor Schools
description: New York State's system of financing public schools largely out of local property taxes was declared unconstitutional last June. A State Supreme Court judge ruled that children in Levittown and other school districts which cannot match the expenditures of wealthier districts are victims of discrimination. Governor Carey now proposes to redress the imbalance by shifting some state education funds from richer districts to poorer ones. That will be politically unpopular and may be insufficient but it's a prudent start.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON  State Senator Steven P. Perskie, Democrat of Atlantic City, has been cleared of conflictofinterest allegations by the Joint Legislative Committee on Ethical Standards.

title: Communities Finding It Difficult To Curb Soliciting by Some Sects
description: They used to work the bars and the drivein movies, Diane Schiefelbein recalls. If there was a sign saying No Soliciting, they put the candybars in their purses and sold them one at a time. That is how they raised money for their religious group, the Unification Church.

title: Autos: Field Porsche Wins
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 4Zero added up to everything today for Ted Field and his colleagues in the 24 Hours of Daytona, but it took some lastminute bodyEnglish to keep their No. turbocharged Porsche from winding up with nc world points.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: West Virginia's Rockefeller Steps Up Pace
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Jan. 27 When John 10. Rockefeller 4th came to West Virginia at the age of 27 in 1964 as an antipoverty worker and a Democrat both of these sharp breaks with family tradition  he led his beleaguered charges in the construction of a baseball diamond and basketball court in a rural coal mine hollow.

title: Foes of Afghan Rulers Are Hoping Skirmishes Will Bring on Rebellion
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Jan. 31  Selfexiled Afghan resistance leaders in this Pakistan border city are striving to unify the scattered and sporadic armed opposition to the new proSoviet Government in Kabul, hoping eventually to widen the present regional guerrilla activity into a fullscale rebellion.

title: Guidelines Sanctions Held Illegal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  The General Accounting Office declared today that it would be illegal for the Government to make a company ineligible for a Federal contract on the ground that the company had failed to comply with the Administration's antiinflation pricewage standards.

title: Science Questions To Be Answered
description: Science Times plans to begin a column to answer readers questions,about science news.

title: Mexico Plants Cut Costs for U.S. Concerns
description: JUAREZ, Mexico, Feb. 5  Drawn by a carrot, pushed by a stick, two giant American auto makers, the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation, are quietly creating more jobs for unskilled and semiskilled workers of this Rio Grande border city.

title: Carew's First Hit 2 Tickets for Nixon
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.. Feb. 5 (AP)  The California Angels announced today that since signing Rod Carew they had sold 250 season tickets, including a pair to former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc., Deerfield, Ill., a company that develops, manufactures, markets and distributes medicalcare products, has elected to its board of directors, Clinton E. Frank, chairman of the Bridlewood Corporation.

title: Phone Festival Raises $305,740
description: The New York Philharmonic raised 1305,740 in its second annual phone festival, which ended on Sunday night. The event was carried by radio station WQXR for 56 hours, beginning Thursday night, and was broadcast from the chorus room of Avery Fisher Ball, with the phones manned by volunteers. The first festival last year raised 5277,000.

title: Jazz: Danny Gatton's Guitar Plays Redneck Style
description: DANNY GATTON is a guitarist based in the Washington area who has won some notable reviews from the press there and some extravagant plaudits from fellow musicians. The Washington Post called him The preeminent guitarist of the postWorld War II generation, for instance, and Lowell George of Little Feat wrote that Danny Gatton is the best player in any style I've ever heard.

title: NOW Assembly to Look at the Family
description: Innovation rather than confrontation will be the main thrust of the feminist movement in the 1980's, said Betty Friedan, the founder of the National Organization for Women. Mrs. Filedan. sneaking at a news conference yesterday at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, announced that NOW's Legal Defense and Education Fund will convene a National Assembly on the future of the family on Nov. 19.

title: Science Watch
description: British budgerigars, colorful birds better known to some as parakeets, are declining in fertility and increasing in hereditary diseases, including one anomaly that leads to such oversized feathers that the little birds look like feather dusters.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Inscrutable Is a TwoWay Street
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 5Americans have long thought of the Orient as inscrutable, seldom realizing how impenetrable they themselves seem to visitors from afar.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: An investigation of the New York City financial crisis was officially dosed by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which took no enforcement action against the city officials and institutions who were criticized in a previous staff report. But the S.E.C. restated its longstanding endorsement of legislation that would expand and standardize the disclosure requirements for marketing municipal securities. [Page A1.]

title: Physician Reports Drug Cured a Cancer Patient
description: The Journal of the American Medical Association will report Friday what is claimed to be the first case in which large cell lung cancer was cured by chemotherapy alone, United Press International reported yesterday.

title: S.E.C. ENDS INQUIRY ON CITY'S FINANCES; SAFEGUARDS SOUGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  The Securities and Exchange Commission officially closed its threeyear investigation into New York City's financial crisis today without taking any enfoicement action against the city officials and institutions that were criticized in a 1977 commission report.

title: Russell Gets Critics Prize
description: John Russell, an art critic for. The New York Times, has received the Frank Jewett Mather Award for Art Criticism, given annually by the College Art Association. The award, in the form of a citation, was presented in Washington on Friday evening at the 67th annual meeting of the association, the country's leading professional body of art historians, teachers, artists; museum curators and writers on art.

title: Harold A. Larrabee, 84; Professor of Philosophy
description: Harold A. Larrabee, a professor emeritus of philosophy at Union College in Schenectady, N.Y., died Friday of pneumonia in a retirement home in Austin, Tex. He was 84 years old.

title: Academy's Downtown Brooklyn Neighborhood Also in Rebirth
description: In a way, the Brooklyn Academy of Music is a microcosm of the surrounding downtown area. Like the milesquare commercial center in which it stands, the institution began its rejuvenation about 11 years ago and conducted effective promotion, receiving city as well as private financing.

title: Sara Jane Moore in a Futile Escape
description: ALDERSON, W. Va., Feb. 5 (AP) Sara Jane Moore, who was convicted of trying to assassinate President Ford in 1975, escaped from a minimumsecurity Federal prison here tonight but was recaptured about four hours later, the police said.

title: Bridge.
description: A mile runner who enjoys a 50yard lead going into the last lap and then finds a rival breathing down his neck must have much the same feeling as the winner of the Blue Ribbon Individual Championship at the New York Hilton Hotel last Sunday.

title: Restaurant Blast Kills 2 in Japan
description: TOKYO, Feb. 5 (UPI)  A gas explosion ripped through a mountain resort restaurant in western Japan today, killing two persons and injuring 19, police officials said. The restaurant, situated at Mount Tobone at Koda, near the city of Nagoya, served as a recreation center for workers of medium and small businesses. The blast reportedly occurred during a party attended by about 40 people.

title: Corporate Earnings Are Reported for the Quarter
description: For periods as shown (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: EDUCATION A College Overcomes Learning Disabilities
description: MILTON, Mass. UNTIL three years ago, Richard Shepherd thought he was stupid. Reading was painfully difficult, and his spelling was atrocious. He had trouble remembering facts in sequence, and he could not organize his ideas on paper.

title: U.S. Ends Charges in Dawe Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5 (AP) The United States attorney moved Monday to dismiss the two remaining bank fraud charges against Amos Dawe stemming from his purchase of three California banks in 1979. Last Friday. a Federal, judge dismissed two other counts against him.

title: Weakness of the Dollar Drives Up Interest Rates
description: Reacting largely to the weakness in the dollar in foreignexchange trading, the credit markets dropped sharply yesterday in a move that wiped out much of the gains of last week. It was the first pronounced increase in interest rates so far this year.

title: In Connecticut Schools, 6 Shots or Out
description: GREENV/MH, Conn., Feb. 5  Almost 200 students at public schools here were sent home this morning because they had not produced evidence of inoculation against six childhood diseases. The students had been warned since December that they would be excluded from school unless they either received the free shots or produced proof that they had been inoculated.

title: Canada Seeks Price Moderation
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 5  With the end of wage and price controls, the Canadian Government has been reduced to appealing to business and labor for moderation with little to back up the appeals.

title: Rev. Cyril F. Meyer, 78; Held Educational Posts
description: The Rev. Cyril F. Meyer, provincial director of education of the Eastern Province of the Congregation of the Mission, generally known as the Vincentian Fathers, died Sunday at the infirmary of St. Vincent's Seminary in Germantown, Pa., where he had been living. He was 78 years old.

title: Assembly Passes Bill for Ratifying An Amendment
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5  After two hours of debate, the Democraticled Assembly tonight approved a proposed amendment to the United States Constitution that would give Congressional representation to the District of Columbia.

title: KHOMEINI APPOINTS A DISSIDENT TO LEAD PROVISIONAL REGIME
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 5 - Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini named a 73yearold opponent of the Shah today to head provisional government and, warned that anyone who opposed it would be treated very harshly as a violator of Islamic law.

title: Pupofon, Puppetry Show, At La Mama Tomorrow
description: Pupofon, a production from Vienna that combines puppetry with live actors, will begin a limited run tomorrow at La Mama Experimental Theater, 74A East Fourth Street.

title: Deaths
description: BAKERLee. The Board of Trustees of the Youth Symphony Orchestra of N.Y., extend their heartfelt sympathy to Robert Hart Baker. their conductor, upon hearing of the death of his father. To Mrs. Lee Baker we extend our sincerest condolences.

title: Islamic Premier: Builder, Teacher and Foe of Shahs
description: A 73yearold constructioncompany executive who spent six years studying thermodynamics and textile engineering may seem an unlikely choice to be prime minister of an Islamic republic, but Mehdi Bazargan, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's choice to head his provisional government in Iran, has never been bound by stereotypes.

title: About Education
description: IN an unpublicized meeting at Williamsburg, Va., last week, 40 academic and corporate executives spent two days discussing the problems they share and the barriers between them. The session, organized by J. W. Peltason, president of the American Council on Education, was a trial balloon for the creation of a powerful businesshigher education forum.

title: Fink Drops 215 Jobs in Assembly; Expects $1.2 Million Yearly Saving
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5  Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink announced today that he had dropped 215 of the 750 people from the portion of the Assembly payroll under his direct control, a move he said would save $1.2 million a year.

title: Edison Bulb Turns 100; Research Flourishes
description: CLEVELAND TAKE a piece of cotton sewing thread, heat it until it is charred black, put it in an evacuated glass sphere and pass electricity through it. One hundred years ago, Thomas Alva Edison did just that, and the light cast by his filament signalled the dawn of the Electric Age.

title: Court Supports Death Sentence In Bhutto Case
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Tuesday, Feb. 6  The Supreme Court of Pakistan today upheld the sentence of death passed upon former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto and four others for conspiracy to murder a political opponent nearly five years ago.

title: A Delay by State Followed Word Of Bank Bilking
description: Three months before the American Bank and Trust Company collapsed in 1976, a supervising examiner warned officials of the New York State Banking Department that David Graiver, the missing financier, was involved in a credit raid on the bank through paper or phantom entities, according to state records that have been kept secret for two years.

title: Perry Injured in Fall
description: WILLIAMSTON, N.C., Feb. 5 (AP)  Gaylord Perry, the 1978 Cy Young Award winner in the National League, was injured in a fall at his home today. Perry fell down some stairs and cut his right hand on a television set at the bottom of the stairs. Doctors who treated him at Pitt Memorial Hospital said there was no muscle, tendon or nerve damage.

title: Velia Yedra, Pianist, Plays Granados
description: GIVEN the steady dose of Beethoven, Schumann and Chopin administered by young pianists at Carnegie Recital Hall, it was a pleasure to encounter Granados's Goyescas at Velia Yedra's recital there Sunday night. With its graceful curves and swirling colors. it is one of the landmarks of the Spanish keyboard literature, yet local performances of it are rare.

title: Emergency Proposals For Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI)  An energy official said today that although he did not anticipate drastic measures, the Administration was considering emergency plans ranging from issuing gasoline ration coupons to banning afterhours lighting to handle as possible energy crisis.

title: PoliceImpostor Crimes Increased 10% in 1978
description: The New York City Police Department reported yesterday that the number of crimes committed by people posing as police officers was more than 10 percent higher last year than in 1977.

title: British Air Orders Tristars
description: BURBANK, Calif., Feb. 5 (UPI) The Lockheed Corporation said today that British Airways had ordered two more L10I1 Tristar aircraft valued at almost $100 million including spare parts. The Tristars will be powered by RollsRoyce RB211524B engines. This brings to 23 the carrier's firm orders and options for Tristars.

title: Corro Title Bout Is Postponed
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 5  A training injury suffered by Hugo Corro of Argentina, the world middleweight champion, will require postponment of his scheduled title fight April 8 with Vito Antuofermo of Italy and Brooklyn.

title: RELEASE OF OFFICER IN KILLING IS UPSET
description: Reversing a ruling in State Supreme Court, the Appellate Division yesterday ordered Robert Torsney - the white pa lice officer acquitted by reason of insanity in the killing of a black youth  be kept in a state mental hospital. fivejudge panel was sharply critical of the state mentalhealth officials who had recommended Officer Torsney's release, terming their custody little more than warehouse'.

title: Shots and Stones Mark A Clash on West Bank
description: TEL AVIV, Feb 5  Shots were fired and stones thrown today in a clash between Arab high school students and Jewish settlers on the West Bank. Armed Israelis later stormed the Arab high school and detained the principal, Jalal Aref.

title: How Not to Balance the Budget
description: Now that the political pendulum is swinging to the right, economic conservatives are striving to keep it there. Some, led by California's Gov. Jerry Brown, seek a constitutional amendment to require that the Federal budget be balanced. So far, 25 state legislatures have endorsed this radical idea in one form or another and called for a constitutional convention to propose it as an amendment. Advocates of the idea would forbid deficit spending, leaving the nation with no ready way to fight recession or even depression.

title: Leonard to Face Marcotte As Junior Middleweight
description: Sugar Ray Leonard said yesterday that he expected to fight for one of the world welterweight titles by September, then capture one of the world junior middleweight crowns before moving into the middleweight division next year.

title: Vance Calls for Talks on Mideast Issues as a Whole
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the next attempt to break the impasse over peace treaty between Egypt and Israel would be a meeting at the ministerial level at which we will try to grapple with the issues as a whole.

title: Iranian Turmoil Impels U.S. Aides To Question Effects of Arms Sales
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  The Iranian upheaval has confronted the Carter Administration with some difficult questions concerning the future of American arms sales, and officials and members of Congress have begun to debate the lessons of the United States involvement in Iran.

title: First of Chicago Sets 11% Prime
description: The First National Bank of Chicago lowered its prime rate to 11 percent from 11 percent yesterday. It was the first major moneymarket bank to have followed the move taken by the Chase Manhattan Bank last Tuesday.

title: G.M.'s Quarterly Net Up 6.8% to $1 Billion
description: DETROIT. Feb. 5  The General Motors Corporation, the nation's largest automobile manufacturer, reported today that its profits in the fourth quarter rose 6.8 percent, while the gain for all of 1978 was 4.8 percent.

title: The New York Times/ Paul Hosefros
description: Mayor Koch and Terence Cardinal Cooke during a visit to St. Patrick's parish school on Prince Street. There, the Mayor read a prOclamation naming this week Roman Catholic. Schools, Week in New York City. The children responded with choruses of the tunes I Love New York and The Sidewalks of New York. After they both had spoken, Mayor Koch and Cardinal Cooke toured the school and visited with one sixthgrade class.

title: Appeals Court Backs Penalties for Officers In Texas Rights Case
description: NEW ORLEANS (UPI)  A Federal appeals court ruled today that a district court judge had gone beyond his authority in suspending prison sentences for three policemen in Houston, Tex., who were convicted of violating the civil rights of a MexicanAmerican who drowned while in their custody. But the appellate court refused to alter the lighter penalties.

title: On Streets of Teheran, Ayatollah's Move Is Hailed
description: TEHERAN, Iran Feb. 5  This city, which overflowed with excitement and joy on the warm bright morning last week when Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini came home from exile, was calm, grimly approving, but apprehensive tonight when it learned that Iran had two prime ministers.

title: Jacobus Pierot, Senior Partner In Ship Brokerage Firm
description: Jacobus Pierot, senior partner in the ship brokerage firm of Jacq Pierot Jr. & Sons, died Saturday at Jamaica Hospital in Queens. He was 75 years old.

title: Trial of ExF.B.I. Officials Raises Fears Over National Security Data
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  Sensitive national security information, including details of continuing counterintelligence operations against Palestinian terrorists, could be exposed at the approaching trial of three former Federal Bureau of Investigation officials, intelligence sources and others said in interviews.

title: 45 Gen esco Shops to Go To allied
description: The Allied Stores Corporation, one of the nation's largest departmentstore chains, will purchase for cash both the Bonwit Teller and Plymouth Shops specialty store chains from Genesco Inc., the two companies said yesterday.

title: Koch Backs New Juvenile Agency; 4 Centers Would Replace Spofford
description: Mayor Koch proposed yesterday that a Juvenile Justice Agency be created to coordinate all punishment and detention of the city's youthful offenders, to close the Spofford Detention Center in tne Bronx within two years and to build four new highsecurity facilities near the courthouses in every borough except Staten Island.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Variations on a ryroleon Thome. Bect hovers; Wrdmong Liszt; Excerpt from The 1 and of Smiles. Lethar. Meplast Waltz No. L An droll Ca tfanle, Tchasoysky.

title: Books: He Shot Actors
description: ON BROADWAY Performance Photographs by Fred Fehl. Text by William Stott with Jane Stott. 419 pages. Illustrated. The Dan Danciger Publication Series. University of Texas Press, Austin. $24.95.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Stocks and Dollar Slump
description: LONDON, Feb. 5 - Stock markets and the dollar were hit by heavy selling today, and precious metals prices soared as turbulence in Iran upset financial dealings around the world.

title: Northeast Appears to be Easing Restrictions on NaturalGas Use
description: Energy experts and utility executives in the Northeast, where natural gas advertising and sales have been controlled for as much as seven years, detect scattered but strong signals that the restrictions may be ending and that greater supplies and a freer market may be in the offing.

title: Walker Sees Runaway By Soviet Bloc in Games
description: John Walker of New Zealand, the Olympic 1,500meter champion and milerecord holder, lashed out yesterday at what he called apathy shown by the United States and other Western nations in track and field and predicted a medal runaway by the Communist bloc in the 1980 Moscow Olympics.

title: Algeria's New Rulers Favor Slow Change and Unity
description: ALGIERS, Feb. 4  Algeria's ruling National Liberation Front has produced the leadership and the guidelines for the postBoumediene era, and although some decisions have not yet been made public, it is clear that the late President Houari Boumediene's team will continue to govern and will be guided by the same blend of socialism and pragmatism.

title: Reliance Merger Is Off
description: The Reliance Group will not acquire the W. R. Berkley Corporation after all. Reliance agreed in principle on Jan. 23 to pay $23 a share for Berkley, a property and casualty insurance company. The agreement has been terminated, Reliance said yesterday.

title: Tulsa Bus Drivers on Strike
description: TULSA, Okla., Feb. 5 (AP)  City bus drivers staged a wildcat strike today, protesting an alleged failure by the Metropolitan Tulsa Transit Authority to provide a relief driver quickly after a driver suffered a stroke last week. Eugene Gooding, general manager of the authority, said that as far as he knew a relief driver was sent immediately. The drivers gave no indication how long they would remain off the routes.

title: Lawyers Pro Bono Duty
description: The legal profession has reached a crossroads on the issue of selfregulation. The issue is: Should lawyers be required to donate time or income to publicservice activities? Proposals are being considered by major bar associations about whether to put teeth into the ethical standard of serving the disadvantaged.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: A broad band of heavy cloudiness extends from the Southeast, through the Gulf States the Southern Plains States. A broken area of cloudiness is apparent over the Pacific Northwest. Bright snow cover and clear skies cover the Middle West, the Central and Southern Plains States and the northern Rockies.

title: Four Nurses Are Hurt As Package Explodes In a Bayonne Hospital
description: BAYONNE, N.J., Feb. 5 Four nurses at Bayonne Hospital suffered cuts and burns today when a package delivered to one of them exploded after it was opened in a thirdfloor corridor.

title: Study Finds FirstBorn Have Higher I.Q.'s
description: ROCKVILLE, Md. A NEW report from the National Institute of Mental Health here concludes that firstborn children in small families tend to be bright overachievers, and that the only child also scores well, although he may be less popular than others among his classmates and contemporaries.

title: U.S., China Agree on TV Satellite Project
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 5  With American technology, China plans to bring color television to almost all of that country's vast populaThe satellite would also be used to relay interurban communications, thus avoiding the cost and time required to improve China's landline capabilities.

title: Money Supply Stressed By Roos of St. Louis Fed
description: The Federal Open Market Committee must begin focusing its attention on targets for money supply growth rather than on controlling interest rates, Lawrence K. Roos, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday.

title: War of the Currents Had Profound Impact
description: THE development of electric power over the last century has been punctuated by doctrinal rifts sometimes as furious as those between rival religions.

title: SHERLEY W. MORGAN, ARCHITECT, IS DEAD
description: Sherley Warner Morgan, professor emeritus of architecture and director emeritus of Princeton University's School of Architecture, died Thursday at his borne, at 145 Hodge Road, Princeton, NJ., after a long illness. He was 86 years old.

title: Cities, Once Deaf to Rock, Turn On to Concert Revenues
description: CHICAGO  Rock concerts, once the bane of cityowned facilities because of the destruction they sometimes brought, are enjoying a new image of respectability.

title: Billy Carter Says He's Provided Grand Jury All Financial Records
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  Billy Carter, the President's brother, said tonight that he turned over all my financial records last week to a grand jury meeting in Atlanta and that he expected to be called before the panel next week.

title: Opera: New Production Of Don Carlo at the Met
description: 0NE of the biggeit hits in Metropolitan Opera history was the Don Carlo that Rudolf Bing staged for his inaugural as general manager in 1950. But the years do pass, sets do grow decrepit_ and all good things come to an end.

title: Israel Suffers Extensive Blackout
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 5  A chain of breakdowns in Israel's electricpower grid blacked out the entire country from the Lebanese border to the Red Sea today.

title: N.H.L. Curious About Soviet Strategy
description: The mystery still intrigued the National Hockey League layers yesterday: Just who are these Soviet hockey players, bow good are they, and what are they going to do to the finest allstar team the league has ever assembled?

title: Giants Still Fail to Agree On Man for Key Position
description: Nothing happened yesterday, the Giants announced.

title: 3 Escape From Schenectady Jail
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 5 (AP) Three men charged with burglary escaped from the Schenectady County Jail, sheriff's deputies said today. The disappearance of the three men, who apparently sawed through bars, was discovered after a bed check at 11 P.M. yesterday. The men were identified as Edward Karl 3d, 22 years old; Douglas Hyson, 23. and Jack Brandow Jr., 21.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Decline
description: Yields declined on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and 182day maturities.

title: United Press International
description: STRIKING STEELWORKERS STORM FENCE: Strikers outside the Newport News Shipbuilding Company, impatient to receive their pay for their work before the strike, scaling the fence at the plant in Newport News, Va. Others pushed their way through a gate. They were later paid. Strike's effectiveness is being disputed.

title: WheatPrice Conference Is Deadlocked in Geneva
description: GENEVA, Feb. 5 - The United Nations conference on an international wheatstabilization accord entered its final week today with the United States and the European Economic Community deadlocked on key issues.

title: Private Agencies to Seek StudentLoan Debtors
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP)  For the first time, the Government has hired private collection agencies to go after 99,000 former students in the South and West who owe $121 million on federally backed loans, it was learned today.

title: News Summary
description: Ayatollah Khomeini pressed plans for Iran's future. He named Mehdi Bazargan, a staunch opponent of the Shah, as Prime Minister of a provisional government and instructed him to form a cabinet and organize elections for a constituent assembly to promulgate. a new constitution to make Iran an Islamic republic. The Ayatollah warned that opponents of his action would be treated very harshly as violators of Islamic law. His followers reacted jubilantly. [Page Al, Column 1.]

title: The U.N. Today
description: Feb. 6, 1979 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Simple Simon, A Theater Opera
description: THE Quog Music Theater was founded nine years ago by Michael Sahl and Eric Salzman. But their Passion of Simple Simon, a new theater opera, is their first coproduction with the Hunter College Center for Lifelong Learning. After a run of previews, the opening was Sunday, with repeat performances scheduled for tonight through Sunday at the Theater for the New City, 162 Second Avenue.

title: Dividends
description: Pe sta of pat Pod Rate we'd Role

title: Why Underwrite Farmland Gambles?
description: Harvest season over, striking farmers have once again turned their energies from reaping grain to reaping tax dollars. The American Agriculture Movement, an agglomeration of unhappy farm owners, has brought the tractors back to Washington to tie up the capital's traffic and to lobby Congress for higher price supports.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation announced it had agreed in principle to sell its European lowdensity polyethylene operations to the Exxon Chemical Company, a division of the Exxon Corporation.

title: A Desire Named Streetcar
description: The clang, clang, clang of the trolley is more than a sweet memory for New York City's Planning Department. It believes that trolley cars (or, to be modern about it, a light rail transit system) should be restored to 42d Street.

title: Baruch Beats City
description: Baruch College rallied from an 18point firsthalf deficit to defeat City College, 6056, Sunday, at the 69th Regiment Armory. The upset victory was the third in eight City University Conference games for Baruch. City's conference wonlost record dropped to 33. Steve Postler led Baruch with 24 points. Dudley Biggs paced City with 17.

title: Stenmark Upset by U.S. Skier
description: JASNA, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 5 (AP)  Phil Mahre outsped Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden in a special slalom today and achieved the first World Cup victory of the season for the United States men's team.

title: Advertising
description: AT first glance, Lois Pitts Gershon's capture of the Reed Candy Company account would seem less than exciting, considering that it has been years since this subsidiary of H.P. Hood Inc. has put any advertising money behind its established brands, Reed roll candy and Clark chewing eum.

title: Purchases Up On Mortgages
description: Demand for residential mortgage credit showed signs of perking up yesterday.

title: Films: Women Picketing And Fighting for Custody:ABC-TV Plans 3 Hours For Hearst-Case Drama
description: "WITH BABIES AND BANNERS" is a gentle well-meaning and well researched short documentary about the role women played in the 44-day sit-in, at the General Motors factory in Flint, Mich., in 1937, a work stoppage that was instrumental in the formation of the United Automobile Workers. The occasion for exploring the subject is a 40-year reunion of the strikers, all of whom were men. The director, Lorraine Gray, worked with other members of the Women's Labor History Film Project to combine vintage footage of the strike with new interview material.To the tune of "Union Maid," the women recall what working conditions were like  and how much better they could be "if you were the kind of girl who would let the boss pat you." They talk of how unwelcome their participation was when the strike first began, and how they eventually began cooking for the strikers and equipping their children with placards  "My Daddy Strikes for Us Little Tykes." The presentation of this material is a little dull, and a lot like that of other labor movement chronicles, but informative on the whole.???ABC-TV Plans 3 Hours For Hearst-Case drama???ABC-TV has scheduled a three-hour made-for-television dramatization of the kidnapping and search for Patricia Hearst, the heiress who was released from prison last week after receiving a Presidential commutation of sentence. The program is to be presented on March 4.According to the network, the movie, entitled "Get Patty Hearst," has been in development for two years.The screenplay, by Adrian Spies, is based on the recollections of Charles Bates, the former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent who was in charge of the investigation of the kidnapping. Dennis Weaver will portray Mr. Bates, and the role of Miss Hearst will be played by Lisa Eilbacher."In the Best Interests of the Children," another documentary, is about lesbian mothers with sole custody of their children. It asks whether this can be a satisfactory arrangement for all concerned, and answers with a resounding "Yes!" before you've even heard the question.A couple of experts are interviewed, including a lawyer who explains that fathers who sue their lesbian wives for custody of the children often return the children once they've won in court. This point is not elaborated any further. None of the fathers is interviewed, and the children are asked only general questions, to which they give answers that are more affirmative than they are thoughtful or revealing. "Lesbians are people  I mean, so what, they're lesbians," one daughter explains." There is also a lot of footage of mothers and children playing or talking in the sunlight. The most memorable of these scenes shows a mother and son engaged in conversation while they feed the family duck, and it's fascinating. Honestly. Have you ever seen a duck eat?Why are these two films on the same bill at the Public Theater? The only common ground they share is that they're both about women and that each is earnest but a little slow. The pairing of these films presupposes that if you're interested in one kind of film about women, you ought to be interested in any other kind of film about women. This does not seem true. It also suggests that people who'll go see films about women don't mind being bored. This does not seem fair.

title: Jailed Minister, 73, Defies Court Over Silence on His Kidnapping
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 5  The Rev Maurice McCrackin, whose very name suggests the sharp and crackling qual ity of his conscience, has taken on the system again and has put his life on the line in a challenge to the powers of the courts.

title: Paris Couture Enhances The Past
description: PARIS, Feb. 5 - In the week of couture shows just past, the oldest of the world's fashion establishments seem to have been roused from their languor to take on some of the frenetic aspects of the younger, competing institutions, the readytowear industry. The music that fills the salons is symptomatic of the change, along with the photographers flashing their strobe lights along the runway and the crowds that rival those at the readytowear shows.

title: Gold Prices at Record In NearPanic Buying
description: Nearpanic buying of precious and base metals futures on both sides of the Atlantic yesterday raised the cash price of gold to a record level. Indeed, cash gold posted its biggest oneday rise in history.

title: Gourdine Back to School
description: Simon Gourdine, the deputy commissioner of the N.B.A., has taken a 14week leave of absence to attend an advanced management program at Harvard. He started Monday and will return in May, presumably better prepared to get involved in the negotiations with the National Basketball Players Association for a new labor contract.

title: Three Food Processors Lift Net
description: Despite the inflationary climate confronting food processors, higher sales and earnings were reported yesterday by three companies.

title: TV: CBS's Two Hours Of Monsters
description: THE HORROR SHOW, a twohour anthology on CBSTV tonight at 8 o'clock, is subtitled 60 Magical Years of Movie Monsters, Madmen and Creatures of the Night. Actually, in addition to offering some of the greatest scenes from the scariest movies of all time, this compilation offers several interesting speculations on the social, cultural and even political aspects of the horror movie.

title: Atlanta Is Castinc a Covetous Eye on Seventh Avenue
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 5  Stimulated by the construction of a $91 million apparel mart and an aggressive recruiting effort, Atlanta and the State of Georgia are making a strong bid to lure significant portions of the nation's $38 billion apparel industry to this city.

title: On Knowing the Past
description: ITHACA, N.Y.  Have we recently reached a critical juncture in our relationship to History? Abundant signs say yes. To judge by rising museum attendance, increasing book sales, successful television programs and historicalpreservation activities, nostalgia is surely in the saddle.

title: Letters
description: TO SCIENCE TIMES: Supplementing Jane E. Brody's excellent study on Who's Happy, [Jan. 16] I've found through study and living experience that a basic in achieving happiness is positive doing, not just positive thinking. Certainly there's no happiness in blaming parents or the past.

title: About New York
description: Jimmy Dell'Orto was born into sandwiches at Manganaro's hero shop, but he still ponders man's larger fate in the writings of Jacques Maritain, the philosopher. Mr. Dell'Orto once was a seminarian at a Benedictine monastery but came out, as he says, to go back to sandwiches at the family store on Ninth Avenue.the railroads desperately seem to need for their resurrection. Amtrak has become, in short, more like an airline. In place of the earlier system of a variety of sandwich contractors in local cities, the line divided the food contract into two national halves, and an airline caterer won the East. his mother, Nina, the name that stayed over the doorway after her forebears, the Petruccis, opened their first deli on Ninth Avenue in 1893. This was decades before the cheap bluecollar lunch of odd, thinly sliced coldcut heels on footlong hard bread escalated from a laboringclass bargain into an upperclass cravigg.

title: Events
description: WITH BABIES AND BANNERS: THE STORY OF THE WOMEN'S EMERGENCY BRIGADE, di rected by Lorraine Gray, and IN THE BEST INTER. ESTS OF THE CHILDREN, by the Iris Feminist Col. lectiye; at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, through Feb.11.

title: G.O.P. Presidential Race Shaping Up in New York
description: Taking advantage. of a leadership vacuum in New York State Republican ranks, a multitude of the party's presidential aspirants are already trying to enlist supporters in the state, and they are threatening to pick apart the secondlargest delegation to next year's Republican National Convention.

title: Japan Makes Protest To Soviet on Buildup On 2 Isles Near Coast
description: TOKYO, Feb. 5  A longstanding territorial dispute between Japan and the Soviet Union entered a new phase today:

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Permit me to dissent from your editorial Protecting Judges  and the Public (Jan. 22), which views proposals that Federal judges be removable by a judicial council as posing severe constitutional problems and considers that modern scholars, impatient with the purposely cumbersome impeachment process, have spun out defenses for the constitutionality of quicker removal. Your views seem to me mistaken.

title: Excerpts From S.E.C.'s Report on City
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  Following are excerpts from the report of the Securities and Exchange Commission on New York City's finances:

title: S.E.C. Says City Should Improve Its Bookkeeping
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  The staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that further improvements are necessary in New York City's accounting systems, despite progress it said the city had achieved since the fiscal crisis of 1075.

title: MSGR. EMIL F. KAPUSTA
description: Msgr. Emil F. Kapusta, pastor of the Church of St. Joseph in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., died Saturday in a car accident in Garrison, N.Y. He was 61 years old.

title: Straightforward Director
description: ONE of the most highly acclaimed events in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's long association with theater companies, both foreign and domestic, was the Royal Shakespeare Company's 1975 production of Maxim Gorky's Summerfolk. That production was staged by David Jones,viho now, at the age of 44, is expected to be appointed artistic director of the academy's future classicalrepertory theater company.

title: Demonstrator in 1978 Has a New Perspective
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI)  Last year, Donald Albosta was a grain farmer from Michigan who was in Washington with an angry group of farmers demonstrating and blocking traffic in hope of getting a better shake out of life.

title: Business Records
description: ALFRED MUENZER. 360 E rttl St. 14 v Liabolihes. 10166.646; assets. 8700

title: Notre Dame Turns Back Loyola, 8466.
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 5 (AP) Tracy Jackson, Notre Dame's outstanding sixth man, scored 18 points tonight to lead topranked Notre Dame to an 8966 triumph over Loyola of Chicago in college basketball.

title: Officer Fatally Shoots Girl Bystander in IND Tussle
description: A Transit Authority plainclothes police officer who was attempting to defend himself against a knifewielding assailant shot and killed a 17yearold high school student on a crowded subway platform at Herald Square yesterday afternoon at the height of the homebound rush hour, according to the transit police.

title: AIDE TO REP. RYAN WARNS U.S. ON CULTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  The Moonies wore red and blue polkadotted signs proclaiming, Senator Dole, this is a witch hunt as they into jammed the Senate Caucus Room this morning for a threehour inquiry into the cult phenomenon in America.

title: N.Y.R.A.
description: Jolly Hour, second from right, trailed Full Wish (6) at the clubhouse turn in the first race Aqueduct yesterday. But Jolly Hour, Ramon Figueroa up, surged down the stretch to win.

title: Why Penicillin Continues To Grow in Importance
description: ALTHOUGH it kills guinea pigs and thus might never have been approved for use on humans if it were developed under modern regulations, penicillin, which revolutionized the practice of medicine when it was introduced in World War II, remains a wonder drug almost 90 years later, and its importance is still growing.

title: 10Day Car Sales Up 13.3%
description: DETROIT, Feb. 5  Sales of new cars by the nation's Big Three auto makers rose 13.3 percent in the final 10day selling period of January from year earlier, the manufacturers reported here today.

title: Appeals] Court Backs Arthur Young in Fraud Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission lost another round yesterday in its battle to hold accountants more responsible for unearthing frauds by theirclients.

title: Books of The Times
description: BLOOD AND GRITS. By Harry Crews. 213 pages. Harper & Row. $10.95.

title: Mariners Hire McCammon
description: PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 5 (AP) Bob McCammon, dismissed last week as coach of the Philadelphia Flyers, was reappointed today to his former post as coach of the Maine Mariners of the American Hockey League, the Flyers ton farm club.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, Feb. 5 - Two young women on a motor scooter today shot and wounded female prison warden in Turin and then escaped, apparently with the help of two other women.

title: Mini MarshallPlan for China?
description: TOKYO. Feb. 5  With Deputy Prime Minister Teng lisiaoping of China arriving here tomorrow, the idea is growing among Japanese economic experts that international financial assistance, something on the order of a small Marshall Plan, is necessary to finance China's ambitious economic development program.

title: ROYNER C. GREENE
description: MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, Feb. 5 (AP) Royner C. Greene, former high school basketball coach at Middletown for 16 seasons and later basketball and baseball coach at Cornell University, died yesterday at a Crystal Lake, Ill., nursing home. He was 73 years old.

title: Arbitration Order in Times Case
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that arbitration was the appropriate remedy to resolve a labor dispute at The New York Times's printing plant in Carlstadt, N.J. The dispute involves an effort by The Times to use one man to monitor a conveyor belt carrying newspapers from printing presses to delivery trucks. The Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union refused to operate the conveyor belt with one man, contending four should be used. In a ruling in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the judge, Robert W. Sweet, said, The parties are directed to proceed to arbitration on any disputes arising out of the manning at the Carlstadt facility.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: What may be the largest age discrimination case in history is scheduled to be filed totnmorrow by disgruntled former employees of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. They were part of the mass dismissal late last year of an estimated 600 to 800 middlemanagement officials and their principal target is Coy G. Eklund, president and chief executive officer of the giant insurance company.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)School : Alive and Well (5) New Zoo Revue (13)Captioned ABC News

title: PLOTKIN IS QUITTING AS CENSUS DIRECTOR
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  The director of the Bureau of the Census, Manuel D. Plotkin, announced today that he would resign.

title: Texas Issue Shows Dip In Yield
description: Reflecting the rally in the taxexempt bond market this year, yields on highestquality state bonds were reduced sharply yesterday as Texas sold $3.5 million of tripleA securities. Investors were lukewarm to the lower rates.

title: Save Your Vision Week Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP)  President Carter today designated the week of March 4 as Save Your Vision Week. He urged Americans to consider what they can do to take care of their eyes and protect them from disease and injury.

title: Boston Schools Advance To Beanpot Hockey Final
description: BOSTON, Feb. 5  Boston Universit y defeated Harvard, 42, and Boston College muted Northeastern, 72, before 14,769 spectators at Boston Garden tonight in the first round of the 27th annual Beanpot hockey tournament. The winners will meet next Monday for the championship.

title: Cutbacks Cited In Pay Rises
description: In response to President Carter's pay stabilization program, 73 percent of the companies participating in a national survey have cut back their employee pay plans for 1979, according to a report yesterday by the Princeton, N.J., management consulting firm of Sibson & Company.

title: Dinosaurs Nest Is Found In Montana
description: THE skeletons of 15 baby duckbilled dinosaurs have been found in Montana, huddled toether in a mud nest where some unknown catastrophe befell them more than 70 million years ago.

title: Sears Will Be First Foreign Company to Float a Yen Bond
description: TOKYO, Feb. 5A Samurai named Sears, Roebuck? That would be a bit of a breakthrough, and, indeed, it is.

title: Pentagon Chief Plans A Mideast Trip Friday In Light of Iran Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  The Carter Administration is starting a diplomatic initiative in the Middle East this week, urging closer cooperation among proWestern countries in the region after the departure from Iran of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

title: The City
description: It acted after Deputy Inspector Joseph Borelli, who was in charge of the Police Department's investigation of the David R. Berkowitz Son of Sam investigation, told the committee: Give me a half a million dollars to give out as rewards, and I can solve most crimes in the city.

title: Waste Plan Passes in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 5  The Westchester Board of Legislators and the Peekskill City Council voted tonight to approve a plan to build a $90 million facility to generate electricity from the burning of solid waste and sewage sludge on land outside Peekskill, in the northern part of the county.

title: OBSERVER
description: What a great President he would have been, Henry Kissinger said in the funeral eulogy. But of course we had no opportunity to find out.

title: Carter Aides Defend China Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  The Carter Adininistration opened a defense of its new China policy on Capitol Hill today, urging Congress to avoid passing laws to strengthen Taiwan's security that would invite President Carter's veto.

title: Anita Ellis In Recital, Her Debut
description: ANITA ELLIS, whose public appearances have been spaced out to almost ridiculous extremes (she was heard in nightclubs for a couple of years in the mid1950s, then disappeared until she did an eightweek stint in the intimate, planthung Bird Cage at Michael's Pub four years ago), gave the first fulllength concert of her career at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday evening, a debut that had, reputedly, long been avoided because of a continuing case of stage fright that she describes as an illness.

title: Carter Names Envoy to Jamaica
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (Reuters) President Carter today nominated Loren Lawrence, a State Department official, as the new Ambassador to Jamaica. Mr. Loren, who is 53 years old, is a management and consular specialist and has been serving as a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for passport services.

title: Pattern Seen in 40 Building Fires
description: New York City finance officials have discovered that about 40 apartment buildings wheie suspicious fires occurred over a oneyear period owed more than $500,000 in delinquent realestate taxes and were all covered by the same insurance policy.

title: Taxes &
description: BANKS, insurance companies and mutual funds are all bumping competitive heads over the hottest new sales item in the taxdeferred pension field: the simplified individual retirement account. All the new marketing luster of the socalled I.R.A.'s comes from the new tax legislation.

title: Census Clock Records 220 Million in Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP)  This nation's population reached 220 million at 10:45 A.M. today, but nobody will ever know the identity of the 220millionth American, according to the Census Bureau.

title: New Troupe Will Stage Classics in Repertory At Brooklyn Academy
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music, focal point in the redevelopment of downtown Brooklyn, will announce today the establishment of a major classical repertory theater company. The troupe is scheduled to start performing next year.

title: Teng, Tired but Pleased, Departs After Tour of U.S.
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 5  Ailing from what was described officially as a slight fever but seemingly elated by his reception in the United States, Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping of China ended his nineday visit today by holding out a prospect of everexpanding cooperation.

title: T.V.A. Fights Order to Move Headquarters From Tennessee to Alabama
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 5 (UPI) Because of a Federal court ruling, the huge Tennessee Valley Authority may have to relocate its headquarters to Muscle Shoals, Ala., a move that could have an enormous economic impact not only for the two states but also for the American taxoaver.

title: Blumenthal For Study Of V.A.T.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  Secretary of the Treasury W. Michael Blumenthal offered modest encouragement today for a valueadded tax, a sort of national sales tax that has gathered important support on Capitol Hill.

title: Boom at Mall Creates a Dispute
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5  Beneath the 98 acres of glaring whiteness, the marbleencrusted monoliths and the esplanades and fountains of the new state mall, the bells are ringing for Ed and his Gal  cashregister bells, that is.

title: 3Power Talks Resume in Geneva On Underground Atom Test Ban
description: Geneva, Feb. 5  The United States, the Soviet Union and Britain resumed negotiations here today, after an eightweek recess, on a treaty to extend the 1963 nuclear test ban to underground explosions The talks began in October 1977 with the objective of completing a comprehensive accord on a nuclear test ban for presentation to the Disarmament Conference.

title: Helen Snow and China: A Renewed Relationship
description: Fortytwo years ago, when Mao Tsetung was commanding the Communist armies headquartered in Yenan in northwest China, he sent a young American journalist who had been interviewing him back to her home in Peking. In a handwritten note, he asked two of his top deputies at the front to help the young woman get through the wartorn countryside in northern China.

title: British Judge Orders Extradition Of West German Terror Suspect
description: LONDON, Feb. 5 (Reuters)  A British magistrate ordered today that Astrid Proll, a suspected terrorist, be extradited to West Germany.

title: Soviet Is Restrained in Criticism of Teng's Visit to U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 5  Whatever the Soviet Union's ultimate reaction to Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping's reception in the United States may be, official press criticism in Moscow has been comparatively restrained so far.

title: EARNINGS
description: The Boeing Company, which dominates the nation's cdmmercial jet market, reported yesterday that its profits in the fourth quarter soared 92.8 percent and that, for the full year, the gain was 79 percent.

title: House Changes Panel's Name
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (Reuters)The House of Representatives changed the name of its International Relations Committee back to the Foreign Affairs Committee today. By unanimous vote, House members agreed to the change because the name International Relations Committee, approved three years ago, had failed to catch on.

title: Iran Jitters, Gold Surge Hurt Stocks
description: Stock prices broke sharply yesterday as political turmoil in Iran and implications of the reduced flow of oil from the Middle. East cast a long shadow across Wall Street.

title: Ballet: Baryshnikov Does Balanchine
description: EVERYTBING is light and bouncy in the third movement of George Balanchine's Symphony in C. From the first note of the music to the last, its dancers bound about with abandon.

title: Elikritchka and Comrades
description: In their blue jeans and windbreakers, they resembled large group of rock musicians with an insistent barber. But these were the hockey players on the Soviet national team.

title: Track Writers Elect Litsky
description: The New York Track Writers Association yesterday elected Frank Litsky as president and Jim Dunaway as secretarytreasurer, each for the 11th consecutive year. Litsky is an assistant sports editor of The New York Times, and Dunaway a senior editor of Track and Field News.

title: Stage: Of Fields, Lately, Son's Painful Memories
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y. A PAINFUL memory opens and closes Of the Fields, Lately, a play about the barriers between a son and his father, written by the Canadian playwright David French.

title: N.B.A. Will Expand, and There Is Some Interest
description: One of the decisions made by the National Basketball Association owners at the recent AllStar game was to expand by two teams no later than the 198081 season. Although seven cities have been mentioned, the ones most likely to get franchises are MinneapolisSt. Paul and DallasFort Worth.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: While watching Iran move towers; another fateful political showdown, we have been reading some history and learning, of course, that the roots of the upheaval run very deep. Finding illuminating parallels in the past can be just a game, but the bitter debates in Washington over who is to blame for losing Iran seem singularly uninformed by anything that came before the Shah and Ayatollah Khomeini.

title: Seton Hall Is Missing Its Blithe Spirit
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 5 The scramble for supremacy in metropolitan college basketball is a localized example of what is going on across the nation this winter. No team seems able to take charge and maintain the position as leader in the area.

title: Notes on People
description: Not at all heartened by the resurgence of fraternity and sorority life on campuses, as exemplified, perhaps, by the success of the movie Animal House and its television series clones, is Joyce Carol Oates, the novelist and shortstory writer. Interviewed in the next issue of The Paris Review, out next week, Miss Oates tells how much she regrets having been a Phi Mu sorority member at Syracuse University.

title: Youth Is Accused of Setting Newark Blaze That Killed 5
description: NEWARK. Feb. 5  An 18yearold youth was arrested here today and accused of setting last night's tenement fire that killed five people including four children.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON  Governor Byrne, a nonsmoker, opened an antismoking campaign yesterday in New Jersey. The Governor's staff will begin a course tomorrow on how to stop smoking. According to an aide, 20 to 50 percent of the employees in the Governor's office smoke cigarettes.

title: Exxon Still Holds No.1 Ranking
description: Based on annual results reported yesterday by the General Motors Corporation, the nation's largest auto maker, the Exxon Corporation, the nation's No.1 oil producer, remains the nation's largest company, using revenues as a standard.

title: Casino Licenses to Hinge On Battle of the Browns
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 2  Since Jan. 8, Raymond A. Brown has been trying to persuade the New Jersey Casino Control Commission that his client, Resorts International, should get a permanent license for its $600,000aday gambling casino here. Over the same period, G. Michael Brown, the assistant attorney general representing the Division of Gaming Enforcement, has been working just as hard to keep Resorts from getting that license.

title: Steel Output Rises in Week
description: Steel production for the week ended last Saturday rose to 2.63 million tons, up 2.7 percent from the previous week's total of 2.56 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Countries Owe U.S. $73 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP)  Foreign countries owed the United States total of $73.2 billion last year, including $27.5 billion of debt dating back to World War I, a Treasury Department official told Congress today.

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Seattle SuperSonics, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:30 P.M. (Television  Channel E, cable, 7:30 P.M.; Radio WNEW, 7:20 P.M.) Nets vs. Cavaliers, at Cleveland. (Television  Channel 9, 8 P.M.; Radio  WVNJ, 8 P.M.)

title: Market Place
description: Now that the put option is becoming a more familiar security, investors are beginning realize that at times it may make more sense to sell put options in their search for profits than to follow the more complex practice of buying the stock and selling the corresponding call option. In either strategy, the investor makes money if the price of the underlying shares holds steady or rises during the option period.

title: Who Lost Cambodia?
description: LONDON  Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former ruler of Cambodia, said recently: There are only two men responsible for the tragedy in Cambodia. Mr. Nixon and Dr. Kissinger. This seems a provocative analvsis but it requires examination. First because the Cambodians themselves deserve an explanation of the wasteland their country has become. Second because there is a popular belief, which Richard M. Nixon and Henry A. Kissinger naturally encourage, that their management of foreign policy was remarkably more successful than that of the Carter Administration.

title: 20 Farmers Arrested as Hundreds of Tractors Jam Traffic in. Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  Hundreds of farmers and their families moved into the nation's capital on tractors and in their camper vans and pickup trucks today, pressing their demands for higher farm price supports.

title: Bonn Surplus Rises
description: FRANKFURT, Feb. 5 (AP)  The overall West German 1978 balance of payments produced a surplus of $10.5 billion, up from a surplus of $5.5 billion in 1977, according to preliminary figures released today by the Deutsche Bundesbank. The figures showed declines in the December surplus, however. The currentaccount surplus, including the trade, transfer and services accounts, was $8.6 billion in 1978, almost double the 1977 surplus of $4.6 billion, according to Bundesbank figures.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP)  Representative Daniel J. Flood, whose Federal trial on bribery charges was ended Saturday when the jurors could not agree, was admitted to Georgetown University Hospital today for treatment of what was described as physical exhaustion.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HOME SWEET HOME There are few more enthusiastic historiams on Brooklyn, past and present, than Louis Singer. Along with some fascinating data, Mr. Singer invariably imparts his love of his native borough to passengers of his regular guided tours. A new series of weekly daylong trips starts this morning and continues each Tuesday. Wednesday and Thursday. At 10 o'clock a bus departs from Second Avenue. and 41st Street, adjacent to The Daily News building, and returns at 4 P.M. The day's tab is $10, plus The cost of lunch.

title: 21 Indicted for Fixing Races at Six Tracks
description: BOSTON, Feb. 5 (AP)  Twentyone persons, some with alleged ties to organized crime on the East Coast and in Las Vegas, Nev., were indicted yesterday on Federal charges of racefixing involving more than $1 million.

title: Mildred Gordon, 73, CoAuthor Of That Darn Cat, Other Books
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 5 (AP)  Mildred Gordon, who with her husband wrote 20 novels that sold an estimated 16 million copies, died of bone cancer on Saturday. She was 73 years old.

title: Driver Paton Probation
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 5  Bergen County Superior Court Judge Morris Malech placed Lew Williams, a harness driver, on six months probation today as a result of a fivecount indictment against him on a charge of possessing drugs.

title: Photograph for the New York Times by LARRY C. MORRIS
description: Winter's Reward for the Warm of Heart is a Sparkling Beach and Spectacular Sunset A couple of children had Far Rockaway Beach to themselves as they braved strong winds and temperatures in the 20's for a chance to race the tide yesterday.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: GIOVANNA COSTA (Costa Une Canxs Services. Inc.). Casablanca Feb. 15. Barcelona 17, Marseilles 18. Genoa 20 and Tripoli 25; sails from Kane Street, Brooklyn.

title: Canada's Jobless Rate
description: OTTAWA. Feb. 6 (UPI)  The number of unemployed persons in Canada increased slightly in January compared with December while the unemployment rate remained the same, Statistics Canada reported today. The Government agency said the se. 1st many adjusted unemployment level was 897,000 in January, up by 2,000 fmm the previous month. The unemployment rate during January remained at the December mark of 8.1 percent.

title: DR. GERALD PRATT, SURGEON, DIES AT 73
description: Cardiovascular Specialist Was an Author and Teacher  Active in New York Hospitals

title: Pan Am Halves Loss
description: Pan American World Airways Inc. reported yesterday a fourthquarter loss of $4.6 million, less than half the $9.5 million loss the carrier reported in the fourth quarter of 1977.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: A plan to forge a broad andInflation alliance of Federal, state and local governments and consumer groups to combat inflation was outlined by Alfred E. Kahn, chairman of the Council on Wage and Price Stability. lie said he wanted consumers to challenge price increases that they feel exceed the Carter Administration's guidelines. Mr. Kahn also released a list of 207 major corporations that he said had indicated they would amply with the guidelines program. [Page DI.1

title: China's Crash Hotel Program
