description: HONG KONG, Feb. 6  Anticipating a rush of foreign businessmen and record numbers of tourists. China has stepped up its crash program of hotel construction, utilizing foreign contractors and investors.

title: Consumer Borrowings At Record
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) Fueled by a heavy surge of Christmas buying, American consumers extended their use of credit to a record high in December and slowed down their repayments of old debt, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: Readers
description: FOR a good many years it was an annual custom of this newspaper to reprint the favorite recipes of the previous year. That popularity was not determined by a formal or systematized poll, but rather by generalization  requests for recipes by phone or mail; letters that indicated a special preference during the course of the year; casual conversations with friends, and soon.

title: ShortTerm Note Issue Of Up to $200 Million Weighed by New York
description: New York City expects to offer as much as $200 million in shortterm notes at the beginning of next month.

title: Canada Partnership On Wells to End
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Feb. 6  Canada's East Coast petroleum exploration will soon be halted again.

title: 2 SENATORS DISPUTE TAXPAR6EY FIGURES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  Two key rnocratic senators reported today that ly 14 or 16 states of the 34 required had bmitted valid requests that Congress 11 a constitutional convention to man_te a balanced Federal budget.

description: Father and Son Indicted in Queens

description: Justice for Inmates

title: State Will Take Torsney Ruling To High Court
description: New York State mentalhealth officials, saying that the Robert Torsney case pointed up their own warnings about insanitydefense pleas, will appeal court order that they keep the suspended policeman in a mental hospital.

title: Neighbors Uncertain Whether G.M. Revival Plan is Good for Them
description: DETROIT, Feb. 4  Most people may think of Detroit as the place where the big car companies live, but in fact only General Motors can still emboss Detroit on its letterhead. Ford, Chrysler and American Motors are out of town in Dearborn or Highland Park or Southfield, surrounded by nice lawns or at least buildings that they own, in neighborhoods where they are the only neighbors.

title: Andreotti and Communists: Pact May Not Be Dead
description: ROME, Feb. 6  In itself, the fall of the Government of Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti does not bring the formal alliance between Italy's Communists and Christian Democrats to an end. It may prove to be only an interruption.

title: The Rural Realities of Small Farming
description: WASHINGTON

title: Daimler Sales Up 4.4% in '78
description: BONN. Feb. 6  DaimlerBenz A.G. said today that its sales increased by 4.4 percent in 1978 to $13.5 billion from 1977 and its profits should be comparable to 1977's $235.8 million.

title: Civilian Mail to Iran Suspendec
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP)  All civilian mail service to Iran has been suspended. the United States Postal Service announced today. Airmail service was suspended Jan. 9.

title: E.F. Hutton Censured By S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  The Securities and Exchange Commission today censured E.F. Hutton & Company and sanctioned 13 present or former employees, charging that they had violated antifraud provisions of the securities laws by inducing dozens of unsophisticated customers to invest in the volatile options market.

title: Senator Accuses G.S.A. Of Suppressing an Audit
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP)  Senator Lawton Chiles accused General. Servicet Administration officials today of suppressing an eightyearold audit that said the Government was wasting $100 million a year.

title: SaverFare Rise Asked By United
description: United Airlines, the nation's largest air carrier, plans to apply to the Civil Aeronautics Board next month for permission to raise its most popular discount fares.

title: News of the Theater A Spate of Shows Awaits Cue to Enter
description: ABEHIND-THE-SCENES drama has been in progress all week in the offices of Bernard Jacobs and Gerald Schoenfeld of the Shubert Organization as producers of new shows have been meeting at their bargaining table above Shubert Alley in attempts to strike deals to book their shows into Shubert theaters.

title: Chess:
description: Combinations, striking as they often are, do not spring out of a clear blue yonder; they are prompted by a deeper-than-routine perception of the significant factors in a position.

description: Key Evidence Is Ruled Out In Computer Bank Theft

description: Youth Is Arraigned In Newark Fire Case

title: I.T.T. Tax Ruling
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said that the United States Tax Court ruled yesterday that the company's acquisition of the Hartford Fire Insu:ance Company in 1970 was a taxfree transaction_ The court overturned a 1974 decision by the Internal Revenue Service that the transaction was taxable. According to an I.T.T. spokesman, the ruling saved as much as $100 million for the company. At the time of the acquisition, I.T.T. had purchased 22 million shares, or 97 percent, of Hartford Fire for 5900 million.

title: EARNINGS Tenneco's Profit Up 13.4% in 4th Quarter
description: Earnings of Tenneco Inc. rose 13.9 percent in the fourth quarter as revenues climbed 28 percent, the company reported yesterday from its Houston headquarters. Net income for all 1978 was up 9 percent on a revenue gain of 18 percent.

title: Stocks Steady, While Dow Eases 1.13
description: Copper stocks, a longlanguishing group, moved higher yesterday, while the general market steadied after weeklong decline touched off by political turmoil in Iran.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a report in The Times yesterday on the farmers protest in Washington erroneously identified Representative Peter A. Peyser of Westchester as a Republican. Mr. Peyser. who formerly served in the House as a Republican, is now a Democrat.

title: AUTHORITIES HEM IN FARMERS'
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP)  Militant farmers vowed a return to the streets, but most managed to drive only in circles today as Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland assailed their demonstration as an unmitigated disaster.

title: 2 Riliers Officers Face Departmental Charges In an Inmate's Suicide
description: Two higherechelon officers in the Department of Corrections face departmental charges kw allegedly contributing to the suicide of a 37-year-old inmate at the Men's House of Detention on Hikers Island, Correction Commissioner William Gums Jr. anaourxed yesterday

title: 13 Food Places Cited by the City For Violations of the Health Code
description: The New York City Health Department released the names of 13 food establishments yesterday that it said had violated the Health Code, and it listed five places that had corrected earlier violations.

title: Television
description: 6:06(4)School: Alive and Well

title: HighGrade Utility Bond Yields 9.42%
description: The first issue of tripleA electric utility bonds sold in two years was priced yesterday to yield 9.42 percent, the highest rate of return for such an investment since March 1975, and yet investors were not particularly eager to buy the securities.

title: Blue CrossBlue Shield Moving To Curb Routine Hospital Tests
description: The Blue CrossBlue Shield Associations, which cover medical costs for 112 million Americans, plan to stop paying for medical tests now done routinely on nonsurgical patients admitted to hospitals unless a physician specifically orders them on an individual basis.

title: FluorChina Deal
description: The Southern California division of Fluor Engineers and Constructors Inc. said it had received an $11 million reimbursablecost contract from the China National Technical Import Corporation of China. Fluor Engineers is subsidiary of the Fluor Corporation. Under the contract, the Fluor subsidiary will provide management and technical advisory services and will procure equipment and materials for petroleumprocessing research facilities.

title: Kissinger Holds Hartford Parley On Senate Race
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 6  Henry A. Kissinger, former Secretary of State and possible candidate for the United States Senate seat from New York, has talked to the Connecticut Republican State chairman about the possibility of running for the Senate in Connecticut_

title: Property Values In City Climbing After 3Year Dip
description: Tne total value of taxable real estate in New York City was tentatively fixed yesterday at a figure that city officials said indicated the end of a threeyear decline in assessed valuations. They attributed the shift chiefly to the boom in Manhattan office rentals and in hoteloccupancy rates.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Record highs were posted again in silver and platinum futures prices yesterday. But gold and copper futures fell back before the expected profit taking that lightly swept all metals markets during the day. -

title: Peking Said to Promote Another Purge Victim
description: PEKING, Feb. 6 (Reuters) China's former chief of higher education, purged in the Cultural Revolution, has been appointed Minister of Education. diplomatic sources reported.

title: Met's Don Carlo Gets New Production
description: ONE of the, biggest hits in Metropolitan Opera history was the Don Carlo that Rudolt Bing staged for his inaugural as general manager in 1950. But the years do pass, sets do grow decrepit, and all good things come to an end. Monday night, the Metropolitan Opera presented a new staging of the Verdi masterpiece as produced by John Dexter, with sets by David Reppa and costumes by Ray Diffen.

title: A.M.C. to Drop V8 Engine in 1980
description: DETROIT, Feb. 6 (UPI)  The American Motors Corporation plans to drop the V8 engine from its 1980 passenger car lineup to help it meet Federal fuel economy standards, it was reported today.

title: Bundy Will Join N.Y.U. Faculty; Plans Studies on the Nuclear Age
description: McGeorge Bundy, who has been dean of Harvard. national security adviser to Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson. and president of the Ford Foundation, will become a history professor at New York University this fall.

description: GENERAL

title: Indiana State Drubs Drake
description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Feb. 6 (AP) - Larry Bird scored 33 points tonight, including 20 in the second half, as secondranked Indiana State pulled away from Drake for a 10079 Missouri Valley Conference victory.

title: Boston College Bows - Carter Is Star
description: St. John's basketball team does not qualify as a Big Red Machine yet, despite an impressive 8576 victory over Boston College last night.

title: Fannie Mae Rates Decline
description: Interest rates declined slightly yesterday in the Federal National Mortgage Association's latest auction of fourmonth commitments to buy both Governmentbacked and conventionally financed home mortgages.

title: WAR FILES SHOW U.S. RAN AXIS SPY RING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  In the final two years of World War II, and perhaps before, the United States Government controlled a major German spy ring passing information to Berlin.

description: OLD PHANTOMS by Gus Edwards. Directed by Heeacena J. Taylor. Presented by the Nedro Ensemble Corr any At the St. Marks Playhouse. 133 Second Avenue at B.

title: Regional Theaters Get Corporate Help
description: Between September and November of last year, 234 American corporations - most of them among the Fortune 500 - received letters of solicitation from the recently formed Corporate Theater Fund. They were asked to loin a $250,000 fundraising program to help maintain quality theater in this country, both for your employees sake and your company's sake.

title: NORTH KOREANS ASK A NEW JOINT PANEL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 6  North Korea has proposed that a new coordinating committee be set up to handle all future interKorean problems, raising what is interpreted here as a possible new impediment to a resumption of talks on ramification.

title: Frank McGuire Talks Basketball
description: He has been the basketball coach at South Carolina and before that at North Carolina for a total of 25 years now, but Frank McGuire is still a New Yorker by accent. He sounds it he just walked out of Greenwich Village, which he did when it was a tough Irish neighborhood half a century ago. Some coaches go South and they're saving. v'all by the time they get off the plane. Frank McGuire liisnit said, t'y'all yet. Instead he keeps saying, Get me some New York ballplayers. Tonight some of those New York ballplayers will be

title: Alternative Diploma Urged For Seniors Who Fail Tests
description: ALBANY, Jan. 6  Gordon M. Ambach, the State Education Commissioner, plans to recommend tomorrow that the', state approve certificates of achievement for those students who do not pass the new rigorous competency standards and would thereby be denied high school dinlomas.

title: Paulucci's Son To Guide Jeno's
description: Jeno F. Paulucci, who brought two packaged food companies to national prominence, has handed over the reins of his substantial corporate empire to his 30-year-old son, Michael J. Paulucci. Michael Paulucci, who had been vice chairman, will succeed his father as chairman.

title: Careers
description: AS long as books have been gathered in a place for widespread use, there has been a need for librarians.

title: Assembly Payroll Still Finds Room For Assembly Sons and Daughters
description: ALBANY, Feb. 6  Some things here change; some things don't.

title: International Paper And Sanyo Accord
description: Executives of Sanyo Hibiya Ltd., major Japanese paper sales company, said in Tokyo that they had signed contract with the International Paper Company to handle the latter's newsprint paper exports to Japan.

title: Chrysler to Build Vehicles in Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 6 (Reuters) The Chrysler Corporation and the Taiwan Machinery Manufacturing Corpo. ration agreed today to produce heavy. duty trucks and passenger cars in Taiwan.

title: British Pioneer Doctor Tells of Breakthrough In Fertility Technique
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6 (AP)  Dr. Patrick C. Steptue's team of researchers achieved success in the conception of an infant outside the mother's body only after they abandoned hormone therapy and let the mother's natural cycle do as much of the work as possible, the pioneering physician said yesterday.

title: Tokyo Stocks Off Again
description: TOKYO, Feb. 6  The Tokyo stock market plunged again today, losing an additional 54 points to close at 6,095 on the local Dow Jones average as fears grew that Saudi Arabia would cut back oil production and deal a further blow to Japan's lagre industrial economy.

title: A New Contributor Joins Others In Giving to Neediest Cases Fund
description: Among the 63 donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund recorded yesterday was one from a new contributor  Janet H. Clark of Somers. N.Y.. who donated S50 in memory of her oarents and brother.

title: Cleveland Quartet Plus 2 Plays Two by Brahms
description: THE Cleveland Quartet plus two offered a really glorious evening of chamber music Monday at Carnegie Hall. This was partly because of the excellence of the quartet and its guests, partly because of the repertory andpartly be- cause the performances had been especially well prepared: the six musicians had made a recording of the same program recently that will be released soon on RCA.

title: Snow Predicted For City Today
description: A storm that would drop three to six inches of snow on the metropolitan area was predicted to arrive at about noon today by the National Weather Service.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Sun Chemical Corporation, major producer of printing ink, disclosed yesterday in a 13D filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had purchased for $11.3 million on the open market 5.2 percent of the Chromalloy American Corporation, a multiindustry concern.

title: Philip Morris Sets Pact With China
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 6  Philip Morris AsiaPacific Inc., the Far Eastern branch of the United States tobacco concern, disclosed today that it had signed a contract in Peking three weeks ago to sell its cigarettes in China.

title: A Bit of Peck Slip Elegance, but It's All Trompe l'Oeil
description: Off South Street at Peck Slip there appears to be a Greekinspired arcade, with a view to the Brooklyn Bridge, adjoining a tasteful commercial building Federalist persuasion. Upon closer inspection, the curious stroller would run into a solid brick wall of Con Edison's South Street substation. The utility cosponsored a competition with City Walls Inc., and Richard Haas was com missioned to paint a scene to blend with the surrounding area. The whole mural was approved by the Landmarks Commission. Painted view of Brooklyn Bridge is what one would see if standing in front of real bridge, upper right.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: IT'S that time again when half the population goes all sentimenabout St. Valentine's Day and the other half snorts the equivalent of Bah, humbug. Since laVers make the world go round (at least on Feb. 14), we devote this segment to things fluttering with hearts and cupids and all that.

title: For Ayatollah, CutRate Food Is Big Weapon
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 6  In normal times, the Rafinee Kitchen Company on Mohlavi Street in downtown Teheran sells modern kitchen equipment. But now its displays include onions, potatoes, chopped chicken, lentils and beans, all at bargain prices.

title: Zuckert Promoted at Bates
description: Donald M. Zuckert, 44-year-old lawyer turned adman, continues his meteoric rise at Ted Bates & Company, where he's been working since 1960. Robert M. Jacoby, president, announced yesterday that Mr. Zuckert has been named president and chief operating Meer of Ted Bates Affiliate Companies, five subsidiary agencies with total billings of more than $150 million.

title: Fragmentation Threatening New Nation in Pacific
description: KOLONTA. Ponape  With its rutted Meets ot dark red mud and rickety. frame buildings with names like the Downtown Bar painted on them in block letters, this rambling old South Seas colonial town looks more like a set for a Western movie than the interim capital of a new nation in the Central Pacific. the Federated States of Micronesia.

title: An Insurance Man Pleads Guilty In a $5.5 Million Plot on 4 Unions
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  Joseph Hauser, a millionaire California insurance man charged with conspiring to steal $5.5 million from the health, welfare and pension funds of four labor unions, has pleaded guilty to three of the nine charges against him in Federal District Court in Tucson, Ariz., attorneys for the Department of Justice said today

title: Sears in Talks to Sell Colombia Holdings
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (UPI)  Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that negotiations for the sale of its holdings in Colombia still were being negotiated with potential buyers who preferred to remain unidentified.

title: Tests on Cancer Vaccine Encouraging
description: BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 6 (AP)  Doctors report very encouraging results in tests of a vaccine to improve the chances of surviving lung cancer, a physician said today.

title: It Will Be SlowGoing on the Deegan for Months To Come
description: Traffic was backed up northbound on Major Deegan Expressway near Yankee Stadium yesterday, and on its service road, as barriers were put up for construction crews. Yesterday was first day of a 30month project

title: Creating a Martyr in Pakistan
description: General Zia ulHaq, Pakistan's reluctant military dictator, is now facing a decision of capital importance. Zulfikar All Bhutto, the country's most popular politician and the man General Zia overthrew months ago, has been condemned to death for a murder arising out of a conspiracy against a political opponent.

title: Criticism of Chavez Takes Root in Farm Labor Struggle
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb: 6  Cesar Chavez, whose 17year battle in the fields of California produced better wages for many farm workers, is coming under increasing attack from others in the faint labor movement who charge that he is attempting to monopolize it and prevent them from receiving financial aid from the Government and private foundations.

title: Baby Is Frozen to Death at Heatless Home in Queens
description: A 9-month-old girl was found frozen to death and several other youngsters were hospitalized for exposure after the police answered an emergency call yesterday from a Queens house that has been unheated since July 1977.

title: Moscow Offers Conference Site
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 6 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union has proposed Moscow as the site for the second United Nations Outer Space Conference, which the General Assembly has decided should be held not later than 1983. The first such conference was held in Vienna in 1968.

title: Equitable Chief Rebuts Charges
description: Coy G. Eklund, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, responded sharply yesterday to allegations that he or Equitable had engaged in age discrimination when several hundred employees were dismissed from Equitable last fall. We have conducted our staff reduction with scrupulous regard for both our legal and social obligations, Mr. Eklund declared. A threatened lawsuit to the contrary was without merit, he said.

title: Cases of Measles Climb To 59 in Rhode Island
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 6 (AP) A measles epidemic in East Providence worsened today, and state health officials asked schools to bar from class thousands of children who have neither been immunized nor had the disease.

title: American Diplomats Are Said to Report Israeli Use of Torture
description: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Feb. 7 (AP)  In the past year. the State Department has received reports from diplomatic personnel alleging Israeli torture of Palestinian prisoners, according to an article in The Washington Post.

title: WASHINGTON New Focus on Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 6  These are busy days in Mexico City. Last month Pope John Paul II made his way here through the smog, to the applause of millions. Next week, President Carter will arrive for a state visit, and be will be followed by President Giscard d'Estaing of France.

title: Argentine Inflation
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 6  Argentina's inflation, which led the world with 160 percent last year, is still running strong. Prices rose 12.8 percent in January, the Ministry of Economy reported today. Last month's advance plus tne December rise of 9.1 percent virtually erased any real gain from the 25 percent wage increases that were decreed Dec. 15.

title: Javits Presses for Guarantees on Taiwan's Security
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York, the ranking Republican on the Foreign Relations Committee, said today he would press for adoption by Congress of legislation to give Taiwan the same protection it gets in the mutual defense treaty that is being terminated by the United States at the end of the year.

title: Letters
description: In Defense of Metric

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  A group of senators from sugarproducing states, including two influential committee chairmen, decided today to introduce legislation that would guarantee domestic cane and sugar beet growers 17 cents a pound on their 1979 crop and possibly more the following two years.

title: Jones's Son Freed in Cult Murder
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Feb. 6 (AP)  Murder charges against Stephan Jones, son of the founder of the People's Temple, were dropped today after a court decided he was apparently trying to take the blame for a friend.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: America! Corporation, the country's thirdlargest manufacturer of women's hosiery, has appointed Manny Oliveira to the new position of executive vice presidentsales and marketing.

title: Bekins Dividend Cut
description: Directors of the Bekins Company, nationwide moving and storage concern, have cut the quarterly common dividend to 71/2 cents a share from 15 cents, payable March 1 to holders of record Feb. 15. The company said the dividend reduction resulted from declining earnings. For the nine months of 1978 the company reported net income of $1.6 million, or 91 cents share, down from the $3.1 million, or 82 cents a share, the year before.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: American Resources And Tipperary Pact
description: The American Resources Management Corporation said it had signed firm option to purchase from the Tipperary Oil and Gas Corporation 140,000 net acres of oil and gas leases in Rio Blanco and Garfield Counties, Colo., together with 33 natural gas wells, now owned by Tipperary.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SMILES One of the joys of an informal, aftertheater lounge and showspot like Open Call is peoplewatching. Around midnight recently, this big, highceilinged room off the lobby of the Edison Hotel was packed with table-sitters, responding happily to a parade of young showbiz hopefuls introduced by a singing pianist and host.

title: 17 Win duPontColumbia BroadcastNews Awards.
description: Honoring 17 radio and television broadcasters for their outstanding news and publicaffairs programs last night, jurors of the Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University Awards praised commercial television networks for increasing international news coverage but criticized them for giving short shrift to documentary programming.

title: Top Jobs Shifted At Loeb
description: When Loeb Rhoades & Company merged with Hornblower, Weeks, Noyes & Trask a year ago to form Loeb Rhoades, Hornblower & Company, giant in the securities industry was born. The firm now has $130 million in capital and annual revenues of $450 million.

title: Widow of Heydrich Says `Holocaust
description: TODENDORF, West Germany, Feb. 5 - On the West German mainland, newspapers report the reaction to Holocaust  realization, anguish, catharsis. On this island in the Baltic, a mile off the coast, an elderly woman sits in her nearempty inn and shakes her head.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Treasury sold $2.25 billion of eightyear notes yesterday at an average yield of 9.01 percent, higher than dealers and investors had expected. The credit markets declined in price sharply yesterday for the second consecutive day.

title: Fordham Defeated as Galis Tallies 28
description: Fordham threw a scare into Seton Hall last night at the Rams Rose Hill gym before the Pirates tucked away 6560 victory and moved back into the Eastern College Athletic Conference Metro Division olavoff oicture_

title: $80 Billion in Saving Bonds
description: For the first time in the 37year history of the United States Savings Bonds Program the total value of outstanding bonds has surpassed 880 billion dollars. Through the third quarter of 1978, Series E and H issues totaled $6,148,000,000. After deducting for redemption duridg the same period, a net change of plus $3,196,000,000 pushed the total value of outstanding Bonds to 580,184,000,000.

title: Books of The Times
description: KING OF THE JEWS. By Leslie Epstein. 350 pages. Coward. McCann & GeoghegaA. $10.95.

title: Mrs. Simmons Heads Rape Unit
description: Mayor Koch appointed L'Judie Simmons, a career city manager and socialwork administrator, as head of his Task Force on Rape. The group's main function is to counsel and develop programs for women who have been raped. Mrs.

title: Banking System in Iran Ensnarled in Deep Crisis
description: TEHERAN. Iran, Feb. 6  The 30odd foreign banks with offices here have removed their names from buildings, doors, elevators and lobbies and most of their expatriate officers have left the country.

title: Texas International And Swissair Deal
description: Texas International Airlines, a regional carrier, announced an agree. ment with the Swissair Transport Company to purchase 10 DC-9-32 jet planes for $62.5 million.

title: Radio
description: 74 AAL, WNCN. Where the Cit. roes Bloom, J. Strauss, Jr.; Espana. Chabrier; Die Meistersinger Prelude, Wagner; Harpsichord Sonatas, Scarlatti.

title: Nets Suffer Fifth Defeat in Row, 119 to 100
description: RICHFIELD, OHIO, Feb. 6  After 119100 loss to the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight, the fifth straight and 15th in the last 21 games, Coach Kevin Loughery voiced the opinion that the problem with his New Jersey Nets was not the people who officiate their games.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: ON a downtown Lexington Avenue express, crowded with Wall Street brokers and others in the morning rush, writes Richard Barsam, a stylishly dressed young woman was loudly recounting the joys of having moved to Westchester to a friend, a less stylish woman who obviously had remained in the city.

title: Home Breweries: They're Legal Now
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI)  The Federal Government made it official today: you can now brew beer or make wine at home without telling anyone. You can even take the product out of them house so long as it's for personal or family use.

title: Jimmy Hoover?
description: Intended or not, Jimmy Carter's new budget, with its unprecedented $125.8 billion for the military, will intensity inflation and other economic decay. It reminds us that there was lesson in the inability of President

title: Notes on People
description: Ushers at St. Patrick's Search for a $75,000 Ring

title: 1,389 Applied for Swiss Asylum
description: BERN, Feb. 6 (Reuters)  A total of 1,389 people sought asylum in Switzerland last year, 304 more than in 1977, and more than twothirds of the requests were granted, the Justice and Police Ministry said today. Applications came from 240 Chileans, 181 Vietnamese, 174 Czechoslovaks, 165 Rumanians, 128 Hungarians, 104 Poles and 95 Argentines.

title: Waiting for Henry
description: The Responsible Republicans who last year rallied round the Panama Canal treaties had another meeting last weekend to deal, among other things, with the more difficult issue of a new arms control treaty with the Soviet Union. The result was a facile resolution, shaped by the Presidential politics of Senators Baker and Dole, that denounced the Carter Administration for the decay of American influence and the decline American military power. Its main point, however, was more serious and plainly inspired by the absent Ayatollah Kissinger. It demanded a debate that would link SALT and the total [SovietAmerican] military and foreign policy relationship.

title: Teng, Nursing Cold, Skips Dinner With Tokyo Official
description: TOKYO, Feb. 6  Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping of China arrived here today weary from his visit to the United States and declined to attend a dinner with the Japanese Foreign Minister tonight.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: Pots and Pans

title: A Chance to Choose a Judge
description: When Governor Carey elevated Lawrence Cooke from Associate Judge to Chief Judge of the New York Court of Appeals, he also gave himself another vacancy to fill on the state's highest court. The Governor's opportunity is also the people's, for under the state's new selection system, the Commission on Judicial Nomination is to provide three to five names from which the new nominee must be chosen, and the commission, in turn, has asked the public to assist in its search.

title: Economic Scene
description: PRESIDENT CARTER'S budget plan, as submitted Congress, calls for reducing the Federal deficit from $37 billion this year to $29 billion in the 1980 fiscal year and $1 billion in the 1981 fiscal year, with a $38 billion surplus to come in 1982. But that proposal is not good enough satisfy groups around the country, angry over inflation, who are calling for a constitutional convention and an amendment requiring that the Federal budget be balanced each year.

title: Subsidized Ship Barred
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  American ships built with the help of Government subsidies cannot be used for domestic service, even if the subsidy is repaid, the United States Court of Appeals ruled today.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weeds's at 1 PM National Oceanc and Atmospheric Adrnmistration/UPI

title: Pirandello and Beckett Scheduled by Ensemble
description: David Margulies and Stefan Met asch will star in a program of two one act plays  Luigi Pirandello's The Man With the Flower in His Mouth and Robert Pinget's The Old Tune, as adapted by Samuel Beckett  at the Ensemble Studio Theatre, 549 West 52d Street, beginning next Wednesday.

title: Real Estate
description: ONLY in unusual circumstances does a substantial Manhattan office building get a total internal overhaul all at once. with new thisesandthats from top to bottom. And at 11 West 42d Street the circumstances were unusual.

title: Carey Picks 12 for Panel to Study Casino Gambling
description: ALBANY, Feb. 6  Governor Carey named a 12member panel today to study casino gambling in New York State, move aimed both at determining how best to operate casinos, if they are approved, and at getting action on the matter from the Legislature, which seems lukewarm on the issue.

title: Copper Prices Surge to Records
description: With demand high, worldwide stockpiles being depleted faster than expected and fears that production capacity is insufficient, domestic copper prices have surged to record levels in the past month.

title: Technology
description: EXACTLY how potent is the Japanese computer offensive and what are its chances of success in the United States?

title: G.M. of Australia Posts Earnings Loss
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 6 (AP)  The General Motors Corporation's Australian division, this country's biggest car maker, said today it posted a loss of $1.4 million in 1978 despite improving auto sales.

title: Braths
description: ANDREWSIsabella B. on February 6th, 1979 of Great Neck, wife of the late John J. Andrews, sister of Florence Aitken and the late Margaret J. Cole, Grace D. Taylor, Alexander Jr and Ruth R. Aitken. Services at the Doyle B. Shatter Inc Funeral Home Little Neck Parkway at Northern Blvd Little Neck on Thursday at 1PM Interment Kensico Cenetery. Visiting Wednesday 2 to 5PM only.

title: A Stein Meeting on School Crime Is Turned Into a Shouting Match
description: A news conference called by Borough President Andrew .1. Stein of Manhattan to discuss crime in the public schools erupted into a shouting match between Mr. Stein and a district school superintendent and a parent. They accused him of unfairly attacking a school that had turned itself around and was improving.

title: Bhutto Is Preparing a Final Appeal After Sentence of Death Is Upheld
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Feb. 6 Lawyers for Zulfikar Ali Bhutto are preparing their final arguments to save the former Prime Minister from the gallows after a Supreme Court decision today upholding the death sentence given Mr. Bhutto and four others for complicity in a 1974 political murder.

title: Wine Talk
description: LAST week, we talked about wine cellar for these times. but white wines were not mentioned. One reason is the fact that hardly anyone cellars white wine. Oh, there are a few. The Comte de Lur- Saluces, who owns Chateau d'Yquem, does, but then, his wines, sauternes, are very special. They mature just like fine reds.

title: Union Ordered to Halt Times Work Stoppage
description: A court order was issued in Manhattan last night requiring the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union to end a limited work stoppage at a printing plant operated by The New York Times in Carlstadt, N.J.

title: Private Lives
description: THE organization has no money. By most American definitions, this should mean that the organization isn't serious. The organization has no clout; its shock troops  some hair here, some pudge there, a majority of weak eyes couldn't frighten a sixpack of Cub Scouts. The organization even finds it difficult to think about itself as an organization; its clerks are on loan from other organizations, and they go home alone at night. And yet every year the organization decides that four or five people have perpetrated an excellence, and the designated perpetrators show up at a party to receive scrolls and be congratulated.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: ONE of the most widely quoted debates or expositions on food was written many years ago by the American food researcher Waverley Root in his muchpraised book The Foods France. About 10 pages of that detailed and scholarly work were dedicated more or less to the question of whether you can make an honest bouillabaisse, the famed fish soup or stew, in any area far distant from Marseilles. His theory was that there are certain fish indigenous the waters around Marseilles that simply prohibit a dish that properly bears that name anywhere else.

title: A `Superutility Of 7 Companies Barred by P.S. C.
description: ALBANY, Feb. 6  The Public Service Commission today unanimously voted down a proposal by the state's seven investorowned utilities to create a supercorporation that would have been responsible for building and operating all future power plants in the state. The vote came at the end of more than four years of debate.

title: Tomlin Film Is Shrunk
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6  Universal Pictures announced today that it was suspending production on The Incredible Shrinking Woman, starring Lily Tomlin. which was to have started filming next month. The movie was to have been directed by John Landis, the director of Animal House Universal's smash boxoffice success of last summer.

title: Letters
description: The Brinkmanship of Teng Hsiaoping

title: U.S. Teacher Quits Bgrlin School In Reaction to NecNazi Slogans
description: WEST BERLIN, Feb. 6 (Reuters) An American has resigned from his teaching position at a school here because students greeted him with antiSemitic slogans.

title: U.S. Official Backs Kennedy Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  John H. Shenefield, Assistant Attorney General in charge of antitrust matters, has thrown the Justice Department's support behind a proposal by Senator Edward M. Kennedy for Federal Trade Commission action to piohibit oil companies from owning oil pipelines.

title: Rocky,
description: Rocky, the 1976 Oscarwinning movie with Sylvester Stallone, topped the television popularity ratings last week with a 52 percent share of the audience in its Sunday night presentation on CBSTV. Watched in 27A minim households by an estimated 66 million viewers, Rocky was the highestrated movie of the season and third highest ever on television, surpassed only by Gone With the Wind and Airport 1975.

title: Citicorp Auctions Notes
description: Citicorp sold $100 million of 91day notes yesterday at an average rate of 10.150 percent, down from 10.165 percent last week and well below the peak 11.102 percent in the bankholding company's sale of such paper on Dec. 26. Citicorp, which began auctioning 91day paper on Sept. 19, 1978, has seen its rate decline for six weeks in a row.

title: Hambletonian Shift Eyed as Sale of Site Is Slated
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Feb. 6  The impending sale of the Du Quoin State Fairgrounds, home of the Hambletonian for the last 21 years, is expected to touch off new efforts to have the trotting classic moved from its rustic setting_

title: PRESIDENT AFFIRMS SUPPORT FOR THAIS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  President Carter, in an indirect warning to Vietnam, told the Prime Minister of Thailand today that the United States remained intensely interested and deeply committed to the inviolability of his nation's borders.

title: Minter Outpoints Robles In London 10Rounder
description: LONDON, Feb. 6 (AP)  Alan Minter, Britain's No. 1 challenger for the world middleweight boxing title, gained a 10round unanimous decision over Mexicanborn Rudy Robles of Los Angeles at Wembley Stadium tonight.

title: Malpractice. Suit in Psychosurgery Case Goes to Jury
description: BOSTON, Feb. 6  A Superior Court jury began its deliberations today in lawsuit contending that brain surgery was performed on a 45yearold man at Massachusetts General Hospital in 1967 without his consent and that the surgery resulted in mental impairment.

title: Kahn Asks State Fight On Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  Alfred E. Kahn, bead of the Administration's campaign against inflation, outlined plan today to help his cause by forging a broad alliance of Federal, state and local governments and consumer groups.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Europe in Transition
description: BONN  Business is not as usual in the European Community. The appearance of , sometimes tumultuous disagreements and setbacks detracts from important changes in the internal character of the community that have been under way for some time.

title: TestTube Conception Clinic Stirs Norfolk Debate
description: NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 6  While a Government advisory panel struggles with the ethical issues of testtube insemination in Washington, a debate on the same question has opened here, the site of the first American clinic for laboratory conception of human life.

title: Kennedy Wins 600 In Nassau
description: UNIONDALE. LI., Feb. 6  Ben Kennedy of John F. Kennedy High in the Bronx was the surprise winner of the 600yard run tonight over a starstudded field on the first day of the twoday Nassau Relays in the Coliseum here. His time of 1 minute 13.9 seconds is the fastest for the distance in New York State this season.

title: Galanos: A Match for the Parisians
description: You don 't have to go to Paris to find beautifully executed clothes. James Galanos makes them in Los Angeles and brings them to New York twice a year to show them to store buyers who. invariably praise their fabrics, workmanship and concept. At yesterday's showing of his springsummer collection, Galanos proved he was on the same wavelength as the Parisians in terms of shape as well.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Action Is Urged to Stem Depletion of Salmon Catch
description: Speaking before the annual meeting of the Miramichi Salmon Association in Newton, Mass., a few days ago, J.W. Bird, Minister of New Brunswick's Department of Natural Resources, pledged a concerted effort to end the exploitation of what many consider the world's finest food and game fish.

title: Kahn's List of Companies Promising Compliance With Guidelines
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI)  Following are the companies listed by the Government today as having given assurances that they intend to comply with President Carter's wageprice guidelines:

title: WHITE HOUSE BACKS A HOUSING PROGRAM IN THE SOUTH BRONX
description: Administration Feb. 6  The Carter Administration today approved construction of the Charlotte Street lowincome housing project in the South Bronx and endorsed the goals of Mayor Koch's proposal to build 27,500 additional housing units there in the next seven years.

title: Women Gaining in College Fraternity Membership
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Feb. 6  College fraternities, traditionally the bastions of brotherhclod, are accepting women as full members in many small independent colleges in the Northeast.

title: Profits Rise For Dow, Cyanamid
description: Higher fourthquarter earnings were reported yesterday by two of the the nation's major chemical companies. The Dow Chemical Company said profits in the period increased by 34 percent and the American Cyanamid said its earnings were up 19.9 percent.

title: Toward Freedom
description: PIEDMONT, Calif.  Austerity was the keynote impression. The focus both of President Carter's budget message, and of the endless commentaries on it, was on what cannot be done. The speeches were sober, the faces unsmiling, the mood almost funereal.

title: Utopia Parkway Repair to Begin
description: A $669,234 project in Whitestone, Queens, to reconstruct a portion of the Utopia Parkway seawall damaged by hurricane in 1976 will begin next month, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: Further Rise Seen For Short Rates
description: Shortterm interest rates are likely to climb an additional 100 basis points above current levels and reach a peak around midyear, Donald E. Woolley, senior vice president and chief economist at the Bankers Trust Company, said yesterday.

title: Decaffeinated Coffee: Surprises for the Skeptic
description: MORE and more often, as desserts are being ordered in restaurants these days, one hears requests for decaffeinated coffee. To anyone who loves the rich flavor and aroma of coffee, the need or desire to abstain from caffein because prevents sleep or has other possible harmful effects may cause a strong sense of deprivation, if not downright de-

title: Carter Spurs Fuel Saving
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP)  Concernedover the cutoff of Iranian oil, President Carter has ordered Federal agencies to intensify fuelsaving efforts in a drive to head off mandatory conservation measures.

title: Advertising
description: BLACK & DECKER, well known to the handy man as the world's largest maker of power tools, is setting its sights on women consumers for the first time in its 68 years. It is introducing the first product from its new household products division  the Dustbuster  with its biggest introductory promotion budget ever.

title: Soviet Art Canceled at Michigan
description: DETROIT, Feb. 6  A scheduled exhibition at the University of Michigan of Russian art objects and paintings from the Hermitage Museum in Leningrad has been canceled by the Soviet Government, university officials said today.

title: Miller to Leave Stanford
description: When Arjay Miller was appointed dean of the Stanford Business School in 1968, no one could say that he had never met a payroll. Mr. Miller had been president of the Ford Motor Company, one of the world's largest corporations, for the previous five years and was about as well versed in the doings of business as anyone.

title: Music: Choir of the West
description: THERE are many superior college choral groups around the country, but not too many of them would probably care to tackle the demanding and musically rich program offered by the Choir of the West in Alice Tully Hall Monday night. Under the direction of Maurice H. Skones, these young students from Pacific Lutheran University in Taco. ma Wash. not only surmounted almost every challenge splendidly but also did so while singing the entire concert from memory.

There is a high professional polish to Gene Nve's stauinv The Lion company is one of the iitoi=e adept Off Off Broadway theaters, and it has proved its ability to do classics as well as new plays. However, there is relentlessly kinetic quality to the production that diminishes the nuances and subtleties of this artfully indirect masterwork.

title: Holdout Told Flood Jury He Had Confidential
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  During jury deliberations in the trial of Representative Daniel J. Flood, the lone juror holding out for acquittal told the others of information he said he had received from confidential source outside the courtroom.

title: Congo President Steps Down
description: DRAZZAVILLE, Congo, Feb. 6 (Reuters)  President Joachim Yhombi Opango has handed over his powers to the central committee of the Congolese Workers Party,the country's only political party, according to an announcement broadcast by the state radio station.

title: Mugabe, Sensing Victory, Declares He Ought to Rule Rhodesia Alone
description: MAPUTO, Mozambique, Feb. 6  Robert Mugabe, a major leader of the guerrillas who control much of the Rhodesian countryside, said today that his movement was heading toward military victory and was entitled to 'the reins of government

title: TV: A Profile of Perlman
description: IN the third of four Here to Make Music specials this season, the subject is Itzhak Perlman, the virtuoso violinist. Produced by Christopher Nupen, I Know I Played Every Note features Mr. Perlman at work and at home with his family, com- milting seriously and joking lightly. The program will be seen at 10 o'clock tonight on WNETTV.

title: Rockefeller's Attack Is Now Placed At 10:15, an Hour Before 911 Call
description: Contrary to earlier accounts by family spokesmen, Nelson A. Rockefeller suffered his heart attack on Jan. 26 at 10:15 P.M., an hour before emergency aid was called at 11:16 P.M., sources close to the Rockefeller family said yesterday.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 (UPI) The Sun Company announced plans today to keep its petroleum operation headquarters in Philadelphia and build a $40 million, 27story office building in the downtown area.

title: Seminary Cutting Investments Over Apartheid Issue
description: The board of trustees of the Union Theological Seminary in Manhattan voted yesterday to initiate a policy of selective divestment of its financial holdings in companies doing business with South Africa.

title: Three Children Die in Maine Fire
description: PRESQUE ISLE, Me., Feb. 6 (AP) Three young children were killed in northezii Maine this morning when fire destroyed their trailer home, the State Fire Inspector said. Their mother, Simone Albert, found in the front yard in the nearzero cold, was taken to the hospital in  critical condition. The children were identified as Carol Ann, 6 years old; Carl, 5, and Kitn, 1%.

title: China Says U.S. Shares Its Dim View of Soviet Aim
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 6  The United States shares China's view that Soviet hegemonism, or expansionist aim, the chief threat to world peace, a Chinese correspondent wrote in a long article wrapping up his impressions of Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping's visit to the United States.

description: I don't hold a grudge, Carlos Orsini said. But it was a mistake to shoot in public place in rush hour.

title: Can Happiness Be Formulated?
description: IF you were to believe the current dogma, happiness is getting rid of your erroneous zones, looking out for No. 1, asserting yourself, taking charge of your life and learning to love every minute of it. It is clearing your psyche by screaming, esting, rolling, encountering, hallucinating, meditating and levitating, tuning into your biorhythms, following your stars, getting in touch with your feelings, letting it all hang out and teleporting yourself into an extrasensory universe.

title: Fire Damages Nixon School
description: YORBA LINDA, Calif., Feb. 6 (UPI) A fire of undetermined origin burned through three rooms of the Richard M. Nixon Elementary School last night, causing an estimated $76,000 in damage. Five fire companies put out the flames in 30 minutes. No one was injured.

title: Sara Jane Moore Back in Prison After Capture While Hitchhiking
description: ALDERSON, W.Va., Feb. 6 (AP) Sarah Jane Moore, who attempted to kill President Ford in 1975, was returned to prison today after only hours of freedom, saying her capture represented a double failure.

title: U.S. May Suspend Communities From Flood Insurance Program
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP)  The Federal Government is threatening to suspend communities in more than 20 states from the flood insurance program unless they comply with Federal regulations.

title: Bill Would Reduce Tax On Airline Tickets to 6%
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  The airline industry and Congressmen who fought the industry last year over a proposal to have the Government subsidize airplane noise reduction have now agreed on a new bill to cut the airline ticket tax from 8 percent to 6 percent.

title: BOTH IRAN FACTIONS GIVE DEMONSTRATION OF THEIR STRENGTH
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 6  Thousands of supporters of the provisional regime proclaimed by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini marched peacefully through the streets of Teheran today as Iranian fighterbombers and helicopters flew by in an apparent show of support for the Government of Prime Minister Shahpur Bakhtiar.

title: Best Buys
description: AFTER five continuous weeks of steadily rising food prices, New Yorkers saw a small break last week when the cost of feeding a family of four fell more than a dollar, to $87.65, according to the City Department of Consumer Affairs.

description: ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 6  Resorts International reported today that its casino grossed $13.6 million in January, the lowest monthly total yet.

description: The Hyatt Corporation announced that its merger into the Elsinore Corporation had become effective following settlement of litigation challenging the merger in Delaware Chancery Court.

title: Market Place
description: THE prevailing attitude in Wall Street is that stocks are cheap, but that doesn't square with the view of one of the major managers of pension money in the East. Richard A. Crowell, senior vice president of the Boston Company, thinks stocks should be avoided at this time.

title: Providence Mall Renewal
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 6 (UPI) The Arcade, a shopping mall in business since 1829, will get a $2 million renovation, it was announced by a subsidiary of the Gilbane Building Company of Providence and Evans, Boom & Associates of Baltimore. The companies have acquired developmental rights to the Arcade. The Rhode Island Association for the Blind, the Arcade's owner, will retain ownership of the land and collect rent on the Greek Revivalstyle structure, believed to be the first indoor shopping mall in the United States.

title: Dr. Alfred W. Schwarz, Hospital Pathologist, 70

The United States Army Corps of Engineers, already charged in a civil suit with exceeding its authority and manipulating cost and benefit figures in constructing the TennesseeTombigbee Waterway through Mississippi and Alabama, is also accused in a pending action of deceiving land owners and creating massive flooding and erosion of prime farmland along the Ohio River.

Ambach, the New York State Education Commissioner, said today that students awarded certificates of achievement in place of diplomas for high school work would be able to return to school until the age of 21 for free public education to try to earn a regular diploma.

title: Los Angeles Reports Crime Rise
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7 (UPI)  The police said yesterday that the number of major crimes in Los Angeles last month was 20.5 percent higher than in January 1978. They issued statistics showing that 21,369 crimes in January this year, compared with 17,729 in January last year. The biggest increase was in homicides, which were up 65 percent. The second highest was in forcible rapes, which increased by 38.2 percent.

There are steepled churches of the whitest, most pristine sort, but you have to drive to get to see them.

title: Chavez's Won in a New, Bitter Strike
description: CALEXICO, Calif., Feb. 2  Four years after the nation's first collective bargaining law for ,farm workers was won following a decade of strife, the lush fields of California are a bitter labor battleground again. The outcome of the newest battle, like the last one, seems likely to have a major impact on the prices Americans pay for fruits and vegetables for decades to come.

title: Times Hearing Scheduled
description: A hearing is scheduled for 2 P.M. today to determine if the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union should be held in contempt of court in a dispute over the manning of a conveyor belt at the Carlstadt, N.J., printing plant of The New York Times. Federal Judge Robert W. Sweet, who will conduct the Manhattan hearing, issued an order Tuesday requiring the union to obey management instructions on manning until the dispute could be arbitrated. The Times moved yesterday for the contempt hearing on the ground that the union was not complying with the judge's order. Production began Tuesday night, but was halted because of what the company called union harassment; the union denied any harassment. Last night production was resumed and no problems were reported.

title: Excerpts From U.S. Report on Human Rights in Israel and the Occupied Lands

title: I.T.T. Sells Control Of Brazilian Unit

title: How to Conquer Collecting
description: IN an attempt to deal with the chronic acquisitiveness that threatens the moral fiber of American society, a new organization, Collectors Anonymous, has been established. Three years in the making, it is starting a nationwide campaign to alert people to the dangers of amassing collectibles, directing them to centers where trained personnel can assist in curing them of what psychiatrists now consider disease of epidemic proportions.

title: Snow and Plants: Some Suggestions
description: PLANTS and snow are made for each other, for the most part. Snow shrouds the evergreens in nature's ermine and etches shade trees in black and white outline. description: The Queens District Attorney's office said yesterday said that it would ask a grand jury to investigate the case of a baby who died Tuesday in a heatless house and who, according to an autopsy report, had been maltreated.

title: Soviet Positions Ships Off Vietnam's Shores, U.S. Officials Disclose
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 The Soviet Union has expanded its naval presence near Vietnam, Carter Administration officials said today, by stationing a small task force off the Vietnamese coast and sending two large warships to the region.

title: Piano: Gary Graffman, Still Surprising
description: GARY GRAFFMAN doesn't need an excuse to give a recital, and his admirers need no excuse to go to one, but the pianist happens to be 50 years old this season and that milestone is as good as any for celebrating an artist's staying power. Mr. Graffman, once one of America's great young hopes of the keyboard, has now been before the public for some 30 years, and his recital at Carnegie Hall last night was one more success in a long series.

The speaker is a salesman at a plush New York audio shop where, as he petulantly points out, one might expect the customers to be more discerning. Power, it seems, is the only specification his clients want for stereo receivers.

description: DUBLIN, Feb. 7 (AP)  Ireland's percent economic growth rate last year was the highest in the ninenation European Economic Community, Finance Minister George Colley said today in the annual budget speech. The trade deficit for this nation of three million came to $300 million, instead of an expected $800 million, he told Parliament.

title: Mary O'Malley Wins First Blackburn Prize
description: The Irish playwright Mary O'Malley, whose comedy, Once a Catholic, has been a hit in London and will soon come to Broadway, has been awarded the first Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, to be given annually to a woman for an outstanding contribution to the Englishspeaking theater. The $2,000 prize is named after Susan Smith Blackburn, an American actress and writer, who died in England last year at the age of 42.

title: GilidoeT
description: BEAUTY AND THE BEAT Take your pick, oryou can enjoy both in midtown. An attractive harpist, Eleanor Fell, is playing show tunes, operetta numbers and classics for diningroom patrons at the quietly elegant Tuscany Hotel, 120 East 39th Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues. Slightly farther uptown, near the hurlyburly of the theater district, a rhythmic pianist and singer, Doc Rupert Johnson, is leading his trio with such lilting exuberance that even the waiters and bartenders of Joe's Pier. 52 Lounge are smiling and swaying.

title: Kahn Maps Plan to Stop Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  The Administration's antiinflation staff is exploring with several agencies the idea of making grants of Federal money available to local consumer groups to help them monitor prices and cbal- lenge increases tnat appear to violate President Carter's price standards. The grants, if made, would be funneled through consumerprotection agencies of state and local governments. They would be earmarked to hire consulting economists to put local price monitoring on an objective and systematic basis, according to.aides to Alfred E. Kahn, chairman of the Council on Wage and Price Stability.

description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 7  A surge of support for the interim government proclaimed by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini was reported from across Iran today as thousands of his followers marched peacefully in the major cities and Government employees showed a growing reluctance to serve ministers now in office.

title: Dollar Off, Gold Soars On Oil Fear

According to the police, two officers responding to a call that a robbery was in progress entered Westbury Farms, an enclosed stand on Old Country Road, at about 5:45 P.M., and found two armed men.

title: Critic's Notebook: California in Color
description: LET'S talk about interior decorating, at least insofar as it pertains to West Coast hotelroom comedies that star Alan Alda. Same Time, Next Year and California Suite both feature the actor, and they both take place in close and very carefully appointed quarters. Yet there's a world of difference between the way each of these films uses its confined setting to reflect on its characters and their comic entanglements.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday, on a trustees meeting at Union Theological Seminary, incorrectly identified the professor who resigned as a member of the faculty committee on appointments in a dispute with the trustees over the promotion of another faculty member. He is James Wasbington.

title: ESSA Y
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  Why do you suppose the name of Mrs. David Bruce widow of our first liaison officer to Peking, was stricken from the list of invitees to the White House state dinner for Teng Hsiaoping? To make room for Robert Abboud the Chicago banker whose 53.5million substandard loan to Bert Lance led to a Carter blessing for banking in China? And why do you suppose the President during a twohour talk with Billy Carter Sunday night, never sought to dissuade his brother from lending the Carter name to a Washington reception the next day by the Libyan Government  a radical Arab foe of the Camp David accords  where press release containing the standard Zionism and racism propaganda was distributed?

title: Heavy Showstorm Clogs Ground and Air Traffic
description: A heavy storm traveled up the East Coast yesterday, dumping up to nine inches of snow in some states and up to seven inches in New York City and surrounding areas. Many schools and colleges were shut, slippery roads helped snarl rushhour traffic, airport operations were slowed and power lines snapped in sharp winds.

title: American Variations On Italian Glass
description: WHEN is Italian Venetian glass not really what it appears to be? When it is blown in a factory in Italy by an American, Marvin Lipofsky, and then polished by hand in a studio in California. The stripes of red, yellow. blue, orange and turquoise thaf dance across the flowing shapes capture the vitality of traditional Italian glass, but the abstract forms, the edges folded back upon themselves, are the particular contributions of Mr. Lipofsky.

description: MOSCOW, Feb, 7 (AP)  Gen. Issa Aleksandrovich Pliyev, a prominent Soviet Army commander during World War II is dead at 75, Tass the Soviet press agency reported today.

title: Opera: Moldoveanu as Pinkerton
description: THE role of Lieut. Benjamin Franklin Pinkerton in Puccini's Madam Butterfly is far from the most arduous in opera and does not tell everything about the capabilities of the tenor who sings it. In Tuesday night's performance at the Metropolitan Opera, it was at least agreeably filled by Vasile Moldoveanu, who was making his New York debut with the company. He is a Rumanian, who is a resident member of the Stuttgart Opera and performs with other German and Austrian companies. He sang with the Met during its 1977 spring tour.

title: Mrs. Carter, in Capitol Debut, Praised by Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  Rosalynn Carter testified before a Congressional committee in support of the cause of the mentally ill today in the first such appearance by a President's wife since Eleanor Roosevelt testified in the 1940's.

title: Unity Talks in Canada Founder Despite Pleas for Urgent Action
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 6  Despite widespread pleas to act urgently to resolve Canada's crisis of national unity, the 10 provinces and the federal Government ended another conference on constitutional reform last night with little practical agreement.

title: Texaco Set To Reduce Oil Sales
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it expected to restrict sales of its Middle East light crude oil to its customers by as much as 8 percent during February and March as a result of the interruption of oil imports from Iran.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  Years ago, L. Mendel Rivers, the imperious chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, told a ranking military officer, Look here. If you ain't got a friend on this cornm um ain't grit a friend.

description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 7  The Israeli Government approved the establishment today of a colony of American Jews in the Hebron area of the occupied West Bank.

title: Spacecraft Orbiting Venus Finds, a Vast Chasm on Far Side of Planet
description: The Pioneer spacecraft orbiting Venus has discovered a vast chasm extending hundreds of miles across the planet's equatorial region, and project scientists said that the discovery suggested that the kind of crustal movements that cause earthquakes and seafloor spreading on Earth may have also been at work on Venus.

title: Jersey Court Sets Rules for Advertising by Lawyers
description: TRENTON, Feb. 7  They still are not permitted to predict success or call their services super or colossal, but lawyers in New Jersey will soon be given greater leeway in advertising their services.

title: Celtics Assail Barnes, Put Him on Waivers
description: BOSTON, Feb. 7 (AP)  Marvin Barnes, the Boston Celtics controversial forward, was waived by the National Basketball Association team today, making him available to other clubs for the price of 51.000.

title: Russians Cancel U.S. Art Exhibit
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 7 (UPI) The Soviet Union has canceled a traveling art exhibit at the University of Michigan because the work of dissidents was associated with the show, university officials said yesterday. Moscow called off the exhibition because of a planned poetry reading by Iosif Brodsky, the university's poetinresidence who left the Soviet Union in 1972, and because of the inclusion in a brochure of a quotation from the work of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn.

title: Community's Plowing Plan Goes Awry
description: VERPLANCK, N.Y., Feb. 7  By .3 P.M. today, Walter Kelly's elaborate plan for clearing snow from the 125 miles of roads in the Town of Cortlandt had been plagued by one mishap after anoth- er. Clockwork and precision were out by then and pure ad lib, as Mr. Kelly put it, was the order of the day.

title: Strong Profit Gains Worry Economists
description: The glittering corporate profit making of the fourth quarter of 1978, which most economists expect to continue at least through the first half of this year, may be gladdening corporate executives, but some economists are beginning to worry.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Gerard Helps New York On Its Financial Affairs

title: PRESIDENT PROMISES TO ASSIST NEW YORK; SENATORS DOUBTFUL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  Mayor Koch and Governor Carey won a commitment today from President Carter to do everything possible to assure New York City of at least $100 million in additional Federal aid in the next fiscal year.

title: Memorial Service Set Saturday For ExTutor to Japanese Prince
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 (AP) memorial service is scheduled Saturday for Esther Biddle Rhoads, who tutored Crown Prince Akihito of Japan and other members of the royal family for a decade.

title: Dr. Henry Goldberg, 68, Manhattan Pediatrician
description: Dr. Henry P. Goldberg, an attending pediatrician at New York Hospital, died Tuesday at the hospital from an injury he sustained in a fall on Jan. 29. Dr. Goldberg was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Nets Acquire Rebounder
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 7  In an effort to get badly needed rebounding help, the New Jersey Nets traded Eric Money, their third highest scorer and the leader in assists, and Al Skinner, another guard, to the Philadelphia 76ers today.

title: The Big Picture: Life With TV
description: 'WHEN I come home, I switch on one of the TV's for the news. I like to eat watching TV. I can only go to sleep with the TV on, and when I invite people over it's to watch TV. That how Allen Schwartz, a partner in a junior clothing company, describes his atborne life, adding, I find TV the most relaxing thing I know.

title: G.A.O. TO BACK TRIM IN STUDENT FUNDING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 The General Accounting Office says that a study of Social Security benefits to college students supports President Carter's request that the program be ended.

title: Engelhard And Phelps Net Gains
description: Sharply higher fourthquarter earnings were reported yesterday by two of the nation's major metals companies.

title: Energy Audits: New Fuel Saver
description: ALONG ISLAND homeowner saved about $120 on his heating bill last year by adding $700 worth of insulation to his home. This year, he installed a $480 wood stove and hopes to save another $100.

title: Rarely Heard Dohnanyi By Guarneri Quartet
description: OUTSIDE last night the snow was mantling New York. Inside Tully ItaII all was cozy and secure, with the Guarneri Quartet addressing itself proficiently to Mozart, Schubert and Dohnanyi before a capacity audience.

title: Two Seized in Bank Holdup
description: Two armed men believed to be members of a gang that New York City detectives have called real bad guys were captured yesterday morning shortly after they allegedly held up the Citibank branch at 79th Street and First Avenue. A third man escaped.

title: Systematic Torture
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 8 Edward M. Mezvinsky, the United States delegate to the Human Rights Commission, said today that Red Cross authorities in Israel told him in July they had found no evidence of systematic torture of Arab political prisoners.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 8 (AP) Tracy Caulkins, the teenage swimmer currently under suspension by the Amateur Athletic Union for a curfew violation, received the A.A.U.'s prestigious Sullivan Award tonight as the nation's top amateur athlete for 1978..

title: Art Sale by Museum at Harvard Opposed
description: A number of paintings regarded by many anthropologists as valuable documents on vanished American Indian cultures are being considered for sale by Harvard University's financially pressed Peabody Museum, one of the country's major repositories of artifacts and records of North American Indian,.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE Merszei, Dow Chairman, Quitting Unsatisfying Job
description: The great reward that awaits many a battlescarred chief executive is that special lofty place known as the chairmanship. But Zoltan Merszei of the Dow Chemical Company did not particularly like it up there. A vigorous 56, Mr. Merszei announced yesterday that he was leaving the company, where he started 30 years ago after fleeing Hungary.

title: East Harlem's Troubled Taino Towers Set to Open
description: Taino Towers, an expensive glass-andconcrete Federal housing project that has stood vacant for more than three years, gracing the skyline of East Harlem and tarnishing the image of government, is finally expected to open its doors to its first residential tenants sometime this month.

title: Budget Cuts Are Sought In Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 8  The Israeli Cabinet agreed today to cut Government spending by 3 percent and to raise some taxes in a bid to slow down the alarming rate of inflation in this nation.

title: Knapp Publishes the Good Life
description: Cleon Knapp has no background in home decorating. He was not raised to be a master chef. From the time he was relatively young, however, he has regarded himself as an entrepreneur. He wanted to make money, and he wanted to have fun.

title: Death of Infant Brings A Gas ShutOff Protest
description: In the wake of the death by freezing of an 8-month-old Queens child, about 70 religious, labor and political groups joined yesterday to demand an end to utility shutoffs for those who cannot afford to heat their homes.

title: Issue and Debate Supreme court Getting Question of Warrantless Arrests.
description: The plights of two New York City men, one arrested for murder, the other for illegal drug possession, are now before the United States Supreme Court in a crucial test of a policeman's right to enter a home to make an arrest, without a warrant, in a nonemerRency situation.

description: Friday

title: Grumman: No Evidence Of Any Japan Payment
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 The Grumman Corporation has no evidence that one of its sales representatives made payments to any Japanese Government official on the company's behalf, according to a company audit committee report filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Gulf and Western Raises Dividend
description: Directors of Gulf and Western Industries have increased the quarterly common stocl dividend to 183 cents share from the previous rate of 171/2 cents, payable April 1 to holders of record March 12. This action increases the indicated annual dividend rate to 75 cents a share from 70 cents.

title: United Pre Internatsons
description: BERGLAND MEETS WITH FARMERS: Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland, left, making a point as he met with leaders of the American Agriculture Movement yes- terday in Washington. Both sides described the 98minute session as pleasant and productive. About 3,500 farmers are in the capital to demonstrate for higher crop prices.

title: View of Bhutto: Two Extremes
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. S  In the highly volatile political climate of Pakistan, conflicting emotions swirl around the case of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto as the deposed Prime Minister, under sentence of death by hanging for a political murder committed nearly five years ago, waits behind prison bars for the disposition of his case.

title: Market Rises Weakly
description: The stock market mustered a feeble rally yesterday in the wake of prolonged selling pressure touched off by the political crisis in Iran.

title: Film: 'In Praise of Older Women' Arrives Breathily:Loutish Lover
description: "IN Praise of Older Women" details the adventures of Andras Vayda, a Hungarian writer, as he grows from dirty young boy to dirty old man. The movie follows Andras from an early, clumsy encounter with a middle-aged countess, whom he tackles and almost knocks over, to his latter-day sexual frolicking with a Canadian housewife, who is more of an enthusiast than an acrobat and hence almost breaks his neck. "In Praise of Older Women" isn't supposed to be a comedy, but its sex scenes are so close to slapstick that they're funnier than the screenplay, which is full of howlers.Teen-age coquette, rebuffing Andras's pass while dressed in a see-through negligee, which she says is a gift from her dad: "Hey . . . I just wanted to show you my new nightie!" Older Woman No. 1, finding Andras on her doorstep in the middle of the night: "Well, come on in. I've been sleeping too much anyway." Andras, delivering his second best come-on: "I decided to throw myself in the Danube if I didn't ask you to make love with me tonight." Andras's very best come-on: "Come with me to the Casbah, ha ha."As Andras, Tom Berenger has a handsome, bony face and an idiotic petulance that suggests he may hold his breath till he turns blue if he doesn't get his way with the ladies. Nevertheless, he wins the hearts and loosely clad torsos of Karen Black, Susan Strasberg. Alexandra Stewart and several other actresses who should have stayed in bed, or out of bed, or in any case out of the way of George Kaczender, the director. Only Miss Stewart adds a soupon of class to the proceedings.The story, from a novel by Stephen Vizinczey, must surely read better than it plays. It would be hard and senseless work for an author to make his hero as loutish as Mr. Berenger is when, seeing a man collapse in a drunken stupor at a party, he turns to the man's wife and observes, "I guess that leaves you free for the rest of the evening."Mr. Kaczender directs talky scenes a tiny bit better than he directs scenes of amour, which is too bad, since amour is everything in a movie with nothing else going on. (To be fair, the Hungarian revolt of 1956 is mentioned several times, but it hardly interferes with Andras's activities on the home front.) The sex scenes, which are uniformly uncomfortable and soft-core, have either been shortened after the film's completion or deliberately edited with a shiv. The film opens today at the RKO Cinerama and other theaters.

title: Play: Old Phantoms, A New Gus Edwards

The images and the performances are so precise that even before the dialogue is spoken, we know the time, place and character. These are brothers and sister, separated in a lonely house. There has been a death in the family, death that has a different impact on each of the survivors.

title: Art: >Designs for the Dream King,
description: LUDWIG II of Bavaria is widely thought of as a lunatic, an alienated freak and a monarch as bereft of substance as of stability. But in point of fact he was one of the great choosers. He saw from the first that Richard Wagner, for all his faults, was a man of supreme genius. He left his mark upon architecture and the decorative arts. And he was one of the very rare autocrats of taste who in recent times have expressed themselves almost entirely in terms of the new_ He could have filled his castles and his palaces with oldmaster paintings, Greek and Roman antiquities and firstrate 18thcentury French furniture. But Make it new! was his motto, and be lived up to it.
