title: Screen: Mystery Writer as Heroine in 'Agatha':Who Done What?
description: IN December 1926, Agatha Christie, then newly famous as a writer of mystery stories, disappeared from her house outside London. Some people thought she had committed sucide  when last seen, she was said to be distraught. Other people suspected she'd been murdered. There were those who suspected a hoax. All theories were given prominent play by the press. When, 11 days later, Mrs. Christie was found, alive and well, in the English resort town of Harrowgate, registered under the last name of her husband's secretary, she would give no explanations. Her husband, Col. Archie Christie, suggested somewhat ingenuously that she'd had amnesia.That was that  almost. Two years later, the Christies were divorced, and the colonel married his secretary. Four years after that, Mrs. Christie married Max Edgar Mallowan, the archeologist, and lived, we can assume, successfully ever after until her death in 1976."Agatha," which opens today at the Cinema 1, stars the surprising and beautiful Vanessa Redgrave as Mrs. Christie and a comically inventive Dustin Hoffman as a fictitious American newspaper columnist named Wally Stanton, a Lucius Beebe sort of dandy-journalist, who uncovers the real story.The real story? Well, it's the story that Kathleen Tynan, who had the idea for this film and wrote the screenplay with Arthur Hopcraft, has imagined, given the few verifiable facts of the case. The result is a handsome, rudder-less sort of movie that isn't quite a mystery story, not quite a love story and certainly not a biography. "Agatha," like most speculation on minor matters, would be immediately forgettable if it weren't for the resourcefulness of the two stars.As Mrs. Tynan and Mr. Hopcraft tell it, Agatha and Archie Christie (Timothy Dalton) are living a lie. Archie, bored with being known as Agatha's husband, and bored with Agatha, has taken up with his secretary, Nancy Neele (Celia Gregory), whom he wants to marry. This news so unhinges Agatha that she hatches a diabolical plan that (not to give the plot away) will kill two birds with one stone. When Nancy goes to Harrowgate to take the waters and lose a little weight, Agatha follows, staying at a nearby hotel and waiting her chance for a most particular revenge.It's the revelation of "Agatha" that Mrs. Christie's trail is picked up by the American journalist, who also goes to Harrowgate, suspecting that something not very nice is about to happen. While trying to sort it out, Wally Stanton falls in love with Agatha. Since we know that Mrs. Christie never did marry anyone named Wally Stanton, the outcome of this nonaffair tends to leave us slumped back far from the edges of our seats. The only mysteries in the film are what Agatha has up her sleeve, and the manner in which it will go wrong.Agatha's plan is really quite ingenious, but it's a very small portion of the (by Michael Apted), still seems unfinished. Miss Redgrave's performance as an abandoned wife in the early scenes is so vivid and honest that the narrative that follows hardly does justice to the character. Mr. Hoffman finds a good deal of humor in a role he appears to have made up  his mannerisms, anyway  though you never for a moment believe he could have fallen in love with such a desperate character.It's not the acting that's at fault Agatha and Wally have several quietly funny and serious moments together, including one when, after Wally has coached her to a brilliant success in a game of billiards, he asks her for a lance in the hotel dining room. They walk onto the floor and begin to fox trot, he holding her as if she were an elf, while she is so taken by him, she doesn't appear to notice that she towers above him. This may well be a movie breakthrough  the first time that a leading man has been so dwarfed by his leading lady without damage to either reputation.The period details are lovely enough, but the movie makes nothing of them. It is dcor that at best reminds us of the fun we had watching "Murder on the Orient Express" and "Death on the Nile." I have no idea whatever what Mr. Apted's contributions were. He seems to favor tight close-ups, but so do a lot of other directors. Vittorio Storaro, the man who photographed Bernardo Bertolucci's "Last Tango in Paris" and "1900," among other things, pulls off some tricky lighting effects that look just like tricky lighting effects."Agatha" is not a mess, but it's not much of anything. It's pleasantly endurable and aimless."Agatha," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains nothing that could obviously give offense to the young.

title: On the Constitutional Drawing Board
description: Article V of the Constitution includes a failsafe: If the states think Washington is ignoring the will of the majority, it allows them to call for a convention to propose amendments to the Constitution. The failsafe has never been used, which is hardly surprising. As elected officials, Presidents and members of Congress can be depended on not to ignore the will of the majority. Nothing in American history has brought forth a constitutional convention  not the taming of the continent, not the Civil War, not two world wars, not the economic convulsiong of the 1930's.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON, Feb. 8  Governor Byrne issued an executive order imposing an 18month building moratorium on one million acres of the New Jersey Pine Barrens  a semiwilderness area that covers most of the southern part of the state. He also created a sevenmember planning commission to draft a landuse plan for the area, which is considered to be New Jersey's greatest natural resource. Developers and some farmers have opposed state and Federal efforts to limit development of the area, which contains 17 trillion gallons of pure water in an underground reservoir and the nation's largest stand of dwarf pines and oaks.

title: Film: Altman Offers Apocalyptic Fantasy:End Game
description: ROBERT ALTMAN'S "Quintet," which opens today at the Embassy, Beekman and Paramount Theaters, is, I suspect, exactly the movie that this very talented, wildly erratic director wanted to make  an apocalyptic fantasy about the end of the world, set in a new ice age that will follow the last great war when the earth has been thrown off its axis.The landscape is snow-covered, frozen. Almost all wild-life has vanished. Women, like the landscape, are barren. They no longer conceive. Packs of dogs gnaw on the bodies of those who have died of cold and malnutrition. No one pays much attention.The main pasttime in this lost world is a game called quintet, which is played with five players and looks sort of like a primitive backgammon, though it also involves its players in bouts of hide-and-seek in which one player must murder another. Although we're never told the rules of the game, it appears to be no more complicated than Old Maid played with death penalties.The city where the survivors live and play looks as if it might once have been Kennedy Airport, before the big blast. One particular apartment block suggests the Trans World Airlines terminal reduced to its principal structural components. The walls have collapsed. Stairways are escalators that no longer move.As you might suspect, "Quintet" is an art director's field day, though the sets sometimes make even less sense than the screenplay. The casino where citizens come to play quintet is part Alaskan cave, part Museum of Modern Art, photography gallery, the walls hung with large photo murals of the depressed and dispossessed of an earlier (our) era. Because we can make anything of this we want, the movie functions mostly as an animated Rorschach test.At its least boring, "Quintet" has a dream-like quality that is very soothing even when the movie means to be stern and scarifying, if only because nothing seems to be very important. Like its characters, "Quintet" is passionless, to such a degree that when one person stalks another with murder in mind, there is absolutely no suspense. Such total apathy is not easily attained without the help of chemicals.At its worst, which is most of the time, "Quintet" discovers a lot of small ideas that sound as if they'd been borrowed from "Tomorrow," the shrilly dreadful song from "Annie" that reveals there's always another day.Some excellent actors move through the movie looking chilled to the bone, like guests at the end of a costume ball when the heat has been turned off. They include Paul Newman, a Life-Force character who refuses to be defeated by the game of quintet; Fernando Rey, the grand adjudicator who supervises the games and seems to have come to the party dressed as Christopher Colombus; Vittorio Gassman, who plays a character named St. Christopher but looks like Marco Polo; Bibi Andersson, a woman named Ambrosia who says such things as "Death is always arbitrary. At least, that's been the principal complaint," and Nina Van Pallandt, a quintet player who appears to have lost her luggage while touring the North Pole. Brigitte Fossey appears briefly as what some writers might call a child-woman, meaning in this case that she sucks her thumb as she drifts into sleep.All great directors must be arrogant to the extent that they will follow their dreams through to the bitter, sometimes banal end. This time Mr. Altman's faith in himself has led him over the brink he was skirting in "Three Women." It's not a movie for his admirers but for members of his entourage.

title: New Face: Vicky Frederick
description: THIS is the toughest show I've ever done. The show is Dancin', Bob Fosse's extravagant tribute to fancy footwork, and the speaker is Vicky Frederick, who has inherited the central role crafted for Ann Reinking. Not only does Miss Frederick have an even dozen numbers that range from ballet through buck-and-wing to disco, but also, she says: In this show, we leave the stage for only one reason  to change costumes. And we're all doing such grueling work, eight times a week, that injuries are sustained. People have bad knees and bad necks, but we keep on going.

title: Screen: George C. Scott Stars in Nighttime World of 'Hardcore':Pilgrim's Descent
description: "YOU like showing me this, don't you?" snarls Jake VanDorn, the hero of Paul Schrader's brave and chilling "Hardcore." "I hate it," replies the private eye Andy Mast, with conviction. VanDorn is a stern Midwestern businessman, whose teen-age daughter has disappeared, and Mast has been hired to find her. All he's found so far is an 8-millimeter peep-show movie featuring VanDorn's daughter and two men. There's cause to wonder why he's forcing VanDorn to watch this abomination.Yes, the early sequence in which VanDorn looks at only a few seconds' worth of film and then goes to pieces, makes for one of the most powerful moments in an already electrifying movie. But are there broader, less sensational reasons for "Hardcore" to include the episode? There are. Mast, played beautifully by Peter Boyle, may be something of a sadist, but he also senses VanDorn's crippling inability to look at whatever he doesn't choose to see. Mast is doing more than inflicting pain: He's helping VanDorn begin a journey that may provide him with a brutal  but perhaps necessary  education.VanDorn's shock isn't wholly centered on his daughter, any more than "Hardcore," which opens today at the Loews State II, RKO 86th Street and Trans-Lux East theaters, is wholly about pornography. This is the anguish of someone who's devoted all his energies to controlling and limiting experience, only to fear that his efforts have cost him his resiliency and also been in vain. This is the grief of a devout man, a Calvinist, whose religious conviction has begun to look like smugness and may no longer afford him comfort. As he walks past the porno parlors of Los Angeles in search of his daughter, everything conspires to humiliate someone who has formerly been unassailable.An early scene of VanDorn at work, one of Mr. Schrader's most compact, establishes that his interest in women is at best guarded (he asks a pretty employee if she still has her boyfriend, she answers that she does, and he counters with a crisp, "Nice fella, you don't want to lose him"); it also shows that he's habitually in control of situations even when he pretends not to be, and that he hates bright colors. A later, oddly parallel confrontation with an insolent employee in a lurid bookstore shows that for VanDorn, losing command may be the worst affront of all.The role of VanDorn is played by George C. Scott, but Mr. Schrader has written it as a part for John Wayne. There's a lot of "The Searchers" in the story of this strict, cruel, self-denying man, trying to find a woman who's fallen into odious circumstances and refusing to acknowledge the things he sees along the way. Mast often calls VanDorn "Pilgrim," a nickname as reminiscent of Wayne as it is suggestive of VanDorn's religious zeal. But the insistence upon a John Wayne toughness eventually becomes the movie's undoing, even if the character retains his grit and his principles to the very end. The story line leads VanDorn to the breaking point, but Mr. Schrader won't let him even bend.Mr. Schrader's insistence that VanDorn can search for his daughter, in bars and brothels up and down the California coast, for a period of months without being changed by the ordeal is dramatic suicide: The ending of the movie is disastrously unrewarding and dishonest in several ways. Mr. Schrader can't get the surprise he wants by playing fair with the audience, so he makes the beginning of the film deliberatly misleading.By the time VanDorn teams up with a pretty young prostitute (played energetically by Season Hubley) who's desperate for his affection or anyone else's, Mr. Schrader has backed so far into a corner that he must choose between making VanDorn a cad or a sentimental sap; simple kindness has no place in the film's scheme. Neither does sex, despite the seamy milieu. Mr. Schrader, having paved the way for a story about a man who is forced to consider his own sexuality after being confronted by his daughter's, can't bring himself to explore this idea. There's a quick, funny and highly implausible subplot about VanDorn's posing as a porn film maker to find the men who acted with his daughter. But if a fiercely repressed character like VanDorn were to make a film revolving around sex, it might be just as perversely provocative, and yet as unyielding, as "Hardcore."Mr. Schrader, who also wrote "Taxi Driver," has assembled enough ingredients of that film (including the superb cinematographer Michael Chapman) to make one mindful of what's missing this time. Once again, the action erupts into a violent and bloody conclusion, but the explosion makes less sense because the character is so incomplete. The sexuality of Travis Bickle in "Taxi Driver" was mysterious, too, but it was accounted for and linked inextricably with violence  if only in Robert De Niro's tiny gestures, as when, while watching television, he casually styles his thumb and forefinger like a gun, points it at the screen and pulls the trigger.And unlike "Taxi Driver," "Hardcore" never gives in to the rhythm of its nighttime world, never swoons; Mr. Schrader doesn't seem capable of the perversely rhapsodic style his subject demands. But he does work with speed and intelligence, paying sharp attention to detail and making the movie as funny as it is quick and frightening.

title: Beginning to Deal With Peking

A joint committee will supervise cooperation The Chinese will buy an American communications satellite and ground stations for intercity telephones and educational television, thus knitting their country closer together and giving our aerospace industry some business. A joint agricultural program will help the Chinese toward selfsufficiency and give our scientists a chance to study unique strains of food plants.

title: Ohio State 63, Michigan 60

title: The Day After the Snow
description: In yesterday's bright sunshine and crisp air, a father and his son looked for a good spot to do some sledding in Dix Hills, L.I. On roads and city streets, however, motorists and pedestrians were warned against slippery conditions as falling temperatures froze slush left over from Wednesday's snowstorm.

title: Film: 'Murder by Decree' in Foggy Old London:Ripper Redux
description: NIGHT. Fog. A dingy alley in London's East End. A woman wearing a ratty boa, the symbol of her profession, flees into the darkness followed by a hard-breathing camera. The woman turns, looks pleadingly at us, suddenly screams in terror  and we're back in familiar Jack-the-Ripper land, which is the territory explored yet again in "Murder by Decree," the new English film that opens today at the Ziegfeld Theater.The film, directed by Bob Clark, based on an original screenplay by John Hopkins, makes use not only of the theory that Jack the Ripper was actually the Duke of Clarence, son of Queen Victoria, but also of Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson, who are apparently in the public domain, or at least available for assignments outside the works of Arthur Conan Doyle.With Christopher Plummer as a charming, cultivated Holmes, a fellow who reveals himself to be a man of unexpected social and political conscience, and with James Mason as an especially fond and steadfast Watson, "Murder by Decree" is a good deal of uncomplicated fun, not in a class with Nicholas Meyer's "The Seven Percent Solution," but certainly miles ahead of many other current movies that masquerade as popular entertainment.Mr. Hopkins's screenplay is funny without being condescending, more aware of history, perhaps, than Conan Doyle's mysteries ever were, but always appreciative of the strengths of the original characters and of the etiquette observed in the course of every hunt. It's one of the nicer touches, I think, that the interest of Holmes and Watson is first drawn to the Ripper murders by the very fact that Scotland Yard, though baffled by the case, has not sought their help. Clearly something unusual is a foot.The something unusual involves a secret brotherhood of Freemasons, a possibly unwed mother (the script seems to equivocate on the woman's marital status), a famous psychic (played by Donald Sutherland in makeup that gives him the appearance of death), enough saucy London tarts to staff Piccadilly Circus for a month, as well as a conspiracy reaching  as they say in the movie  possibly to the throne itself. If you're someone who shares Watson's feelings about the monarchy, the suspicion of such wrong-doing is shattering.It is, of course, Holmes who gets to the bottom of the mess, meeting along the way some of England's best character actors, including John Gielgud as Lord Salisbury, the Prime Minister, and Anthony Quayle as a Scotland Yard commissioner, as well as Genevieve Bujold as a sweet woman wronged for security purposes. It is, however, Watson in the person of Mr. Mason who captures our affections and gives the movie character it would otherwise lack.Mr. Mason's Watson is a splendidly staunch and reliable friend, as well as loyal subject to Her Majesty, a dignified man capable of sacrificing his dignity, as when he must hobnob with hookers to obtain information, and utterly at the mercy of his idiosyncracies. In one of the funnier moments of the movie he solemnly explains to Holmes why he is trying to spear the last pea on his plate with a fork, instead of mashing it. "I like the pea whole," he says, "so it pops when I bite down on it."The ultimate resolution of the mystery is no more or less convincing than those of dozens of other Holmes cases you've probably enjoyed, though this one makes some slight attempt to draw analogies to Watergate. However, the resolution to any Holmes case has never been as important as the chase itself, and when the chase is as entertaining as this one, there's not much point in looking back."Murder by Decree," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), indicates that women who walk the streets are not always selling vegetables. The violence is handled with a fair amount of discretion.

description: Dr. Curtis J. Lund, retired chairman of the University of Rochester Medical Center, in Rochester, N.Y., died yesterday at the University of Minneapolis Medical Center. He had lived in that city since his retirement in 1972.

description: ROME, Feb. 8  Italy's Communist Party, in a move that was expected to sharpen the government crisis, joined other major political groups today in demanding a fullscale parliamentary investigation of the kidnapping and killing of former Prime Minister Aldo Mom last year.

title: Art: Elegiac Works Of Lee Krasner
description: THE paintings of Lee Krasner have lately acquired a place in the history of the New York School they did not have 20 years .ago, or even 10 years ago. The reasons for tn1S revised status are in no way obscure; It is no secret that her marriage to Jackson Pollock  the most famous artist of his generation had the (then) inevitable effect of overshadowing Miss Krasner's artistic career. Until Pollock's death in 1956, moreoyer, the conditions in which Miss Krasner worked apparently precluded the production of largescale paintings, and this was a further handicap at a time when size began to be equated with artistic ambition, at least in popular thinking about the New York School.

She began her career as a solo performer and went on to choreograph for the popular theater and concert hall before the long involvement with Doris Humphrey and Jose Limon, with whom she is most readily associated.

title: S.E.C. Chief Calls Profits Inadequate

description: With the election behind her, it is back to business as usual for Connecticut's Gov. Ella Grasso. That means a return to the frugality that has marked her administration. The proposed $2.4billion budget contemplates a spending increase of only 5.1 percent, less than the inflation rate, and a modest rate of growth.

title: ISRAEL OFFERS IDEAS ON ARAB SELFRULE

title: Peru to Raise Its Oil Output
description: LIMA, Peru, Feb. 9  Peru has achieved an oilexport capacity of about 60,000 barrels a day and will increase output from new Amazon fields, the Government said today.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: IN THE BEGINNING The walls of the Bayard Gallery, 456 West Broadway, are covered with cave paintings  or what looks like such prehistoric art. The 60 serigraphs depicting the hunter and the hunted, wild bison and. wondrous dancers and life in caves up to 30,000 years ago, are the results of 20 years of study, travel and silkscreening work by Douglas Mazonowicz. In Mr. Mazonowicz's efforts to reproduce the haunting originals found in the caverns of Altamira, Spain, as well as in France, North Africa, Arizona, Utah and Colorado, he has adapted a variety of techniques. The original wall and ceiling paintings are photographed often the most difficult task of all and later the images are projected on a screen so that he may trace the outlines and prepare each for the silkscreen  process. Prehistoric Paintings  The First 30,000 Years remain on view through March 31 and for sale (from $75 to $25,000). The gallery is open Tuedsays through Saturdays 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: Legislators in Iowa Back Constitutional Convention

title: The War Over the War on Poverty
description: Reassuringly, whole days have now gone by without Mayor Koch and minority leaders calling each other names over his plan to restructure the city's troubled antipoverty program. All their overheated rhetoric obscured two central facts. One is that the excesses in the $35million antipoverty program nave invoivea Hispanic and white as well as black groups. Second, the new plan, which has Washington's approval, is a reasonable compromise solution. It preserves substantial participation of neighborhood groups and allows good programs to continue, yet provides a better handle for the city to curtairabuses.

Mr. Gerdes and Mr. Hardy are still local phenomena, but on the basis of their threenight joint engagement at the Other End that ended last night, it's open to question whether they can still be called folk musicians.

title: Movie: 'Warriors' Creates Visual Style That Is Stark:The Cast
description: The Warriors are the artiest street gang you've ever seen. And what a surprise they'll be for anyone who's misled by the ads for "The Warriors," which opened yesterday at Loews State and other theaters, and goes to the film expecting good old-fashioned head-bashing on a grand scale. There is head-bashing, of course, but it tends to be oddly fastidious. And the Warriors, when they aren't getting into fights, stand around very solemnly and only speak one at a time. Their diction is impeccable.But Walter Hill, who co-wrote and directed "The Warriors," is onto something, provided an audience is willing to meet him halfway. The film is as handsome to watch as it is preposterous to listen to, full of gorgeous nocturnal city images that splash blaring neon colors against filthy, rain-slicked gray. Mr. Hill uses subways, jukeboxes, spectacularly eerie costumes and deserted streets to create a stark yet extravagant visual style, and a grimy little world in which everything looks curiously brand-new. Thanks to a lot of wipes and slow-motion shots, you are never in danger of forgetting that somebody clever is at the helm.Mr. Hill, who was a screenwriter before directing his first film, "Hard Times," with Charles Bronson, can be exasperating in his fidelity to genre-movie conventions  last year, he worked so hard at making a film noir out of "The Driver" that he came up with film gris. This time, Mr. Hill has by no means relinquished his pretensions, but he is far more attentive to the demands of his story, which comes from a novel by Sol Yurick. Were it not for all those pregnant pauses, "The Warriors" might pass for a swift, streamlined adventure film in something like a futuristic cowboys-and-Indians mode.At the start of the movie, The Warriors and a hundred other gangs have each sent nine delegates to a rally in the Bronx. Each group of nine wears its own set of matching outfits, making the rally sequence the most stunning of the film's inventive set-pieces.At the rally, the leader of the Gramercy Riffs is assassinated; this is most unfortunate, because there are about 200 Gramercy Riffs and they're all impassive-looking blacks who carry hockey sticks and know karate. The Warriors didn't kill him  a lunatic named Luther, with a cry like a banshee's, did  but everyone thinks they're guilty and everyone's after them. The subway trip back to their home turf of Coney Island is a long one, punctuated by ingeniously plotted fights with other gangs and tight, portentous shots of the mouth of a woman disk jockey, who taunts the Warriors and plays songs like "Nowhere To Run" in their honor.Along the way, Mr. Hill stages some wonderful-looking encounters, including a confrontation with a gang on roller skates and a love scene in the path of an oncoming train. A particularly strong sequence is set in Riverside Park, where the Warriors are attacked by the Furies, who wear baseball uniforms and carry bats. The Furies also wear black and brightly colored face makeup reminiscent of "Clockwork Orange," but when a Warrior punches a Fury, he doesn't get paint on his fist. That's the magic of movies.Most of the actors in "The Warriors" seem likely to have given wooden performances even if Mr. Hill hadn't directed them to. But a few of them  notably Michael Beck, James Remar and Brian Tyler  hold the screen even when they're affecting the most stoical of attitudes. Deborah Van Valkenburgh, as the obligatory pouty pick-up, and David Patrick Kelly, as crazy Luther, lend an unexpected humanity to Mr. Hill's glossy scheme. Thomas Waites is a promising actor who's as miscast here as he is in "On The Yard." Mr. Waites plays tough guys in both films, and in both he seems much less formidable than his surroundings.

title: Peanuts Holland, 69; Trumpeter Who Also Sang Oh, MissJaxon
description: Herbert Lee (Peanuts) Holland, a noted trumpeter and singer who left the United States to live in Europe in 1946, died Wednesday in Stockholm, according to The Associated Press. He lived in Sweden and was 69 years old.

Revenues of the latest quarter were $311.9 million, as against $247.1 million in the 1977 period.

title: A Local Approach to Curbing Juvenile Crime
description: WASHINGTON  In the mid1960's, Philadelphia, plagued with youthgang violence for several decades, bad the unenviable reputation as the youthgang capital of America. Each year an average of 39 black youths died on the streets and hundreds more were left maimed for life. As gun warfare raged, the general crime rate continued to soar upward and innocent bystanders were often felled by stray bullets.

description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 9 (AP) David Friend, the former jaialai promoter, wept and hugged supporters today after a jury in Superior Court acquitted him of perjury in connection with the Bridgeport fronton.

description: In response to recent suspicious fires in the metropolitan region that have taken the lives of at least 50 persons in New Jersey alone, Governor Byrne yesterday asked law enforcement officials and insurance experti to join a task force to combat arson.

Rockefeller left the bulk of an estate estimated by his office at $66.5 million to his wife and their two young sons, with the Museum of Modern Art, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the National Trust for Historic Preservation named in his will as other primary beneficiaries.

title: Barbara Cook Varies Moods In Stint at Club
description: A court order issued last month limiting Reno Sweeney, the nightclub and restaurant at 126 West 13th Street, to musical groups consisting of no more than three stringed instruments, one of which may be a piano, because it is in a site that is not zoned for cabaret, has forced a rethinking of its entertainment policy that may be the best thing that has happened to the room since its early success six years ago.

title: Your Money
description: WHEN interestbearing checking accounts were introduced in New York State last November, they were hailed as an innovation that would greatly benefit consumers. But now that the financial institutions offering the NOW (negotiable order of withdrawal) accounts have figured out their pricing strategy for the new service, is clear that the biggest beneficiaries are those depositors who regularly maintain balances in excess of $1,000.

description: HAWTHORNE. N.Y., Feb. 9  An embarrassed Soviet hockey squad worked on new puckmoving tactics today in the wake of its flat performance last night in the opener of the Challenge Cup series against the National Hockey League team.

description: YONKERS, Feb. 9  Fire destroyed an apartment complex here early this morning, two weeks after it had been condemned by the city and only hours after the last tenants had been moved out.

Kosygin has complained to highranking Americans that much of what Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping had to say during his visit to the United States was outrageous and should have been refuted by the Carter Administration, an . authoritative Western diplomat disclosed today.

title: PALESTINIANS IN U.S. ACCUSE THE ISRAELIS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9  Palestinians now living in the United States charged today that Israeli police and military officials had tortured them while they were awaiting trial for security violations. They also said that while in Israeli prisons they met other Arab prisoners whose bodies showed marks of beatings.

title: Daniel Starch, Ad Analyzer, at 95
description: Dr. Daniel Starch, a psychologist whose marketing research techniques had a major influence on advertising, died Thursday at White Plains Hospital. He was 95 years old and lived in Scarsdale. N.Y.

title: Cognac Sales at Peak
description: PARIS, Feb. 9 (AP)  The Cognac Manufacturers Association reported today that 1978 was a boom year for the brandy, with world sales reaching a record 136.1 million bottles, up 17.5 percent from the 115.6 million bottles sold in 1977.

description: BOSTON, Feb. 9  A Superior Court jury today found that two physicians were not negligent in their treatment of a 45yearold man with brain disease who later become a paranoid schizophrenic.

title: Rescued From River
description: Nancy Paulus, below left, and Andrea Tinch scrambled to the roof of their car yesterday after it crashed through a guardrail and plunged from a bridge 65 feet into the icy waters of the Mad River near Fairborn, Ohio. Capt Paul Gehringer, a firefighter from nearby Wright Patterson Air Force Base, was lowered to the car by a cable, right, and wrapped the women in blankets. A small boat rescued them.

description: Oil, gas, coal and energyrelated stocks from Canada to Mexico were the stars of Wall Street yesterday. The market's emerging rationale, analysts said, was that these issues could become beneficiaries of the oil cutoff from Iran.

description: LONDON, Feb. 9 (AP)  Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger says that the United States should learn the lesson of Iran and change its policies toward Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf states to account for political and social changes there.

title: Chinese Options for Any Move on Vietnam
description: A punitive military operation into northern Vietnam is probably the most attractive option open to China if it decides, in Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping's words, to teach the Vietnamese a lesson.

title: China Finds Tungsten
description: TOKYO, Feb. 9 (AP)  China, the world's largest producer of tungsten, said today that it had found a large and rich deposit of the mineral in the southern part of the country. According to the official press agency, Hsinhua, the new deposit is in the Kwangsi Chuang autonomous region. Hsinhua said the tungsten content of the ore was more than 1,000 percent richer than the minimum requirement for opening a mine. Tungsten is used primarily for electric light bulb filaments and as an ingredient of certain steel

title: Topics
description: Jimmy Carter, it will be recalled, ran against Washington and promised a newcomer's fresh approaches. He committed himself to upgrade the Cabinet and open its weekly meetings to the public. He urged officials to put aside workaholic schedules and go home for dinner to their families. And he promised an open Administration, tolerating internal dissent and broadening public access to government.

title: He's a Small Boy With a Big Voice
description: When Patrick Sturgis was 2 years old, he used to put on a show at home that delighted his parents. He would swathe himself in a sheet, pretending it was a choir robe. Then he would mimic the booming voice of W.S. Denby. choirmaster of the Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Vicksburg, Miss., singing Holy, Holy, Holy.

title: Heating Complaints Grow as City Goes Through Coldest Day of Year
description: Yesterday was the coldest day of the year in New York, and the city's index of suffering  the number of calls to the central heating complaints number rose steadily as the mercury slid further below freezing.

title: Princeton Fortunes Sag Despite Victory
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 10  Pete Carril, Princeton University's basketball coach, is a reporter's dream. The round, little man with the big cigar is always affable, courteous and direct.

title: Not No. 1 or No. 2 but They Do Rent Wheels
description: I wish it might be otherwise, but I am not the type who goes bounding through airports dressed in a natty threepiece suit, magically plunking down behind the wheel of a sleek new automobile. Rather, I tend to arrive in an unfamiliar city wearing jeans and an old sweater, looking tired, disgruntled and decidedly budget conscious. The pert smiles at the checkin counters of No. 1 and No. 2 turn to frosty stares as I approach.

title: DINING OUT
description: SINCE nostalgia is as strong a tug on the palate as it is on the heart, most people return from a trip to France with romantic memories of an underpriced bistro where good food was prepared simply and lovingly. Given the value of the dollar these days, one is more likely to find such a place on these shores than on some Paris boulevard, and The Colony in Larchmont, while it just misses being memorable, is a creditable substitute for those French restaurants that linger in the mind.

title: The Real McCoy at the Met
description: The day after his first stage rehearsal in The Magic Flute at the Metropolitan Opera, Seth McCoy was asked how it went. I'm sore. was his reply. The tenor was not only making his debut with the company, he was acting in a theatrical production for the first time since be had been a student in opera workshops some 30 years before. H was not used to the ordeal of standing around while explanations and directions came from the producer or to having to repeat simple movements such as kneeling. Moreover, he was taking this major step in his career at the age of 50, which is considered advanced for a singer.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: BETHEL  Quilted tapestries by Molly Upton and Susan Hoffman, sculpture by Jean Steig and Shaw Stuart, porcelains by Ursala Michaelis, through March 4, Bethel Gallery, 186 Greenwood Ave. Wednesdays through Sundays noon to 5:30 P.M. 7436644.

title: GARDENING Sugar Snap Peas Take the Cake
description: SIX garden vegetables have received AllAmerica Awards for 1979. That is an unusually large number, but some of them have been waiting in the wings for two or three years while the necessary plentiful supply of seeds was being built up.

title: Legislature Is Expected to Reject Carey's EducationAid Formula
description: ALBANY  Reports of the demise of the socalled save harmless provision in the state's education formula appear to be greatly exaggerated.

title: Elizabeth Rose Plans Nuptials
description: Elizabeth Rosetta Rose and L. Lee Stanton 3d of New York, who received Masters of Architecture from the Columbia University Graduate School of Architecture and Planning, plan to be married in New York in May.

title: He Takes the Throttle of Key L.I.R.R. Union
description: GARDEN CITY WHEN Francis S. Gabreski took office last year, everyone took notice, since he is supposed to be able to make the trains run.

title: Side Effects
description: THERE are some interesting new words  new to me, at any rate  in the history of the drug thalidomide written by the Insight Team of The Sunday Times of London. One of them is teratogenic, which means monstermaking. Another is phocomelia. from the Greek words for seallimb. Phocomelia was the principal monstrosity that thalidomide made. Doubtless everyone remembers photographs of smiling children with ungainly square torsos and little flippers where arms and legs ought have been. There are no photographs in Suffer the Children, for which we may be grateful, and which makes a good deal of sense, because the shock of discovery was only the first, not the worst of what has been suffered over 20 years by the victims of thalidomide and their families.

title: The jazzstarsWhen Leaders Get Together
description: The Milestone Jazzstars, who performed at New York's Beacon Theater last October near the end of a 20concert tour and have already released an album, In Concert, are the first imported jazz combo to have debuted at the White House. They don't exist as a unit any more  they assembled for last summer's White House jazz festival and for the special tour that followed a few months later  but the album preserves the music they made. It also raises some questions that one did not feel compelled to ask in the middle of a Jazzstars concert. Why were Sonny Rollins, McCoy Tyner, Ron Carter and Al Foster playing together instead of with their regular groups? What was gained and what was lost?

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The Federal Gonernment's most widely followed barometer of future economic activity  the index of 12 leading economic indicators released each month  seems once again to be suffering from nearsightedness.

description: Engagements

title: BreadandButter Gifts for Foreign Friends
description: Fortunate the traveler who will be staying with friends while abroad in this age of inflation and the shrinking dollar. But the question of breadandbutter gifts can be a baffling one. Flowers or candy, bought on the spot are a copout; I like to give hostess presents that are in some way American. What to take to a friend in Switzerland or Japan? Here are a few suggestions.

title: The Region
description: That Senator William Proxmire would badmouth New York City's poormouthing was predictable. But last week, Mayor Koch and Governor Carey, who made appeals to the Senate Banking Committee and at the White House, heard discouraging words from one of 1978's saviors Senator Richard Lugar, a Republican from Indiana whose compromise last year in the Federal loan guarantee program may have been the city's salvation.

title: The Other Florida: A Turfman's Tour
description: Florida is not all gators and glades, citrus, sun, sand and surf  it is also horse country. And it owes much of its prestige to a horse with the unlikely name of Needles.

title: GOV. BROWN TERMS BALANCE KEY ISSUE
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 8  Balancing the Federal budget is deeper than a green eyeshade concept, according to Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California; it is a symbolic way for the American people to start to balance our accounts across our whole society.

title: POLITICS
description: EUGENE R. KELLEY, the former Suffolk County Police Commissioner who was a central figure in a twoyearlong scandal that cost the taxpayers $1 million and threatened to paralyze law enforcement in the county, is at the center of another controversy following his appointment to a $26,000 patronage plum in the county government.

description: Bruce Hall, baritone, and ChiuLing Lin, pianist, shared a program in Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday afternoon. Both musicians were making their New York debuts as cowinners of the eighth annual East and West Artists young performers auditions.

description: Laying off workers is not as effective a way for state and municipal governments to save money as attrition, according to a study sponsored by New York State.

title: When in Rome, How to Attend a Papal Audience
description: The weekly general audiences of Pope John Paul II are stirring charismatic experiences to some, vivid multilingual happenings to others. The first nonItalian pope since the Renaissance and the first Polish pope in history, John Paul has in a few months developed a new framework for his periodic encounters with the crowds that flock to the Vatican to obtain the papal blessing or simply to gawk.

title: G.D. Krumbhaar Jr. And Anne B. Keiser Are Wed in Capital
description: In St. Albans Episcopal Church in Washington yesterday afternoon, Anne Blossom Keiser, daughter of Mrs. George Camp Keiser of Washington and Wilton, Conn., and the late Mr. Keiser, became the bride of George Douglas Krumbhaar Jr., son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Krumbhaar of Princeton, Mass. The Rev. Charles P. Scott, chaplain at Middlebury College, performed the ceremony.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: APROBLEM that apparently recurs persistently in houses with walls and ceilings of gypsum board (also called plasterboard, wallboard or drywall) is that of nails popping, or working loose.

title: Refugee Aide for U.S. Ousted In Hong Kong Over Morals Charges
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 10  The Indochinarefugee coordinator at the Anierican Consulate here was suspended today following charges by Vietnamese refugees and international refugee officials that he had solicited sexual favors from female refugees at a transit camp here in return for favorable consideration for visas to the United States.

title: Newspaper Damage Suit Settled
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 (AP)  The Philadelphia Building and Construction Trades Council has agreed to pay $15,000 to Philadelphia Newspapers Inc. as settlement in a damage suit brought by the company as a result of a 1976 blockade of the its Inquirer and Daily News Building. Under the settlement, approved yesterday, the union is permanently barred from using mass picketing, intimidation, coercion, violence or threats of violence to block the building.

description: PHOENIX, Feb. 10 (AP)  Dash Alone closed strongly to post a halflength victory in today's $3,000 feature ??ace at Turf Pardise. The 5furlong race was timed in 1:03 35.

title: Wastefulness Is Laid To Education Board By Comptroller Audit
description: The New York City Board of Education has built up more than $680,000 in surplus inventories because of wasteful and inefficient supply control procedures and procurement practices, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday after an audit of the board's Bureau of Maintenance.

title: Cost of Needed Sewage Plants Placed at $106 Billion by E.P.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI)  It will cost $106 billion to build sewage treatment plants needed to clean up water pollution from the nation's cities, the Environmental Protection Agency estimated today.

title: U.S.SOVIET STUDIES OF QUAKES GAINING
description: NUREK, U.S.S.R.  Up from the valley of the Vakhsh River, a gravel road climbs in a series of serpentine switchbacks, rising precipitously on what feels like a steep mountainside. Heavy trucks nimble upward, loaded with earth and stones, and come down empty.

title: Katharine Keresey Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Keresey of Palm Beach, Fla., formerly of Mill Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katharine Anne Keresey, to Andrew Mitchell Ault, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Burchenal Ault of Santa Fe, N.M., formerly of Oyster Bay, L.I. A fall wedding in Palm Beach is planned.

title: Political Parlor Game: Moffett vs. Dodd
description: WASHINGTON THE next United States Senator from Connecticut, or perhaps its next Governor, is a handsome, darkhaired young Democratic Congressman now in his third term, currently biding his time and building his political reputation in his office in the Cannon Office Building here, according to the conventional politicial wisdom of Hartford.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING
description: WE'VE all heard a lot about how the traditional American family (husband, nonworking wife and two children) has shrunk to a small proportion of the nation's total population.

title: Beautiful Poet
description: ELINOR WYLIE, the reserved yet sensual beauty whose career as poet, novelist and editor flourished in the 1920's, is the subject of this finely written biography. Stanley Olson describes the widespread reproach of the socially prominent woman whose three marriages occurred in the first three decades of the century, when divorce was still discredited.

title: Robert Klein Tries On Neil Simon For Laughs
description: LOS ANGELES To a TV viewer, the name Robert Klein conjures up images of the very sharp standup comic who does occasional guest spots on the Johnny Carson show or Saturday Night Live (Nooo talking! Now take these dogtags. They're to be used in case you're burnt beyond recognition in a nuclear holocaust. And remember  nooo talking during the holocaust. I'll be taking names.) Some moviegoers may recall his filmstealing portrayal of a hilariously megalomaniacal director in the recent Burt Reynolds picture Hooper. In these and other showcases, Mr. Klein, a tall, darkhaired and deceptively normal looking comedian, has convinc ingly demonstrated his ability to metamorphose into whatever demented characterization his comedic instincts demand.

title: President's Wage Insurance Plan Wins Endorsement of Teamsters
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI)  The International Brotherhood of Teamsters asked Congress today to adopt President Carter's wage insurance plan. But the twomillionmember union said it still did not go along with the Administration's 7 percent ceiling on wages and benefits.

title: If You Go ...
description: ... to the British Virgin Islands, it is imperative that you plan well in advance. There are only 700 hotel rooms there and, in the smaller establishments, which sometimes seem be in the throes of a permanent house party, 50 to 75 percent of the guests from year to year are repeat visitors.
