description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets)  A Man for All Seasons, in an Actor's CafeTheater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. Opens Friday (through March 17). $3.50$5.50; students and the elderly, $2.5$4.50. (201) 4297662. Westminster theater.

title: LETTERS
description: I was appalled to read in David Lattimore's review of the The Sui Dynasty (Dec. 17) the following sentence: Arthur Wright wrote in English, not in the gullah of social science. Particularly shocking is that it came in a review that scorns Western prejudices about Asia. Mr. Lattimore seems to have retained a few of the white man's prejudices himself.

title: A Look at Filmmaking on the Cheap
description: LOS ANGELES The house looms over Highland Park, a neighborhood north and east of Los Angeles's downtown. It has gabled windows, a spacious porch and high shrubbery hiding the larger than average lot from probing eyes. At the turn of the century, this must have been the best house around.

title: Birth Notice 1 -- No Title
description: Births

title: Elizabeth Leys Sets Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. Dirck Fisher Leys of Hartsdale and Windham, N.Y., have annunced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Mitchell Leys, to Robert Everett Bostrom, son of Angelira Bostrom of New Britain and Old Saybrook, Conn., and the late H. Everett Bostrom. .A July ,14 wedding is planned.

title: Carolyn Otto, Steven Carter Plan to Marry
description: Announcement; has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Otto of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn Suzanne Otto, to Steven Duncan Carter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Duncan Carter of Rowayton, Conn., and Pompano Beach. Fla.

title: MUSIC
description: BEFORE diving into our customary concert concerns, let me tell you how delighted I was with the response of Connecticut musiclovers to WQXR's fundraising marathon for the New York Philharmonic. All through last weekend, I was busy with the telephone festival on the air and on the phone, and even though the Philharmonic is basically a New York institution, I don't think there was a town in Fairfield that was not represented on our list of contributors. We may not get the definitive totals for a while yet, but unofficially it is clear that well over 200 Connecticut listeners participated in the drive. To all of you who did, a bow of pride and appreciation.

title: INVESTING
description: Just heard you got out of the market, says the friendly voice on the telephone. Smart move. The sophisticated people are making it in diamonds.

title: Ruling Italian Party Rejects Idea Of ProCommunists in a Cabinet
description: ROME, Feb. 10 (AP)  Leaders of the Christian Democrat Party have rejected a proposal to give Cabinet positions to proCommunist politicians to win the support needed to form a new government, informed sources said today.

title: The Helpful Giant
description: EMERSON AND LITERARY CHANGE By David Porter. 232 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $15.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: It's Not Superman, It's Only Fly Williams
description: ASBURY PARK THEY called him Fly as youngster because, when he rose from the blacktop in Brooklyn, he would make fraud of Isaac Newton, spinning 360 degrees in midair before laying the ball into a netless hoop. And they still call him that because, as a college  and now a professional  player, he has way of flying off the handle.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: The Gaels of Iona College in New Rochelle have become a bigtime basketball team since Jim Valvano became their coach four years ago.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: Queens College Takes City U. Relay Event
description: The Queens College track and field team captured the second annual City University relay championships yesterday at Fitzgerald Gym in Queens. The Knights won with 62 points to 60 for Brooklyn College and 38 for Lehman.

title: Soviet Hints It Now Favors Moscow As Site for BrezhnevCarter Parley
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10  The Soviet Union. apparently wary, of appearing to compete with China for popularity in the United States, has begun to suggest privately that a meeting between President Carter and Leonid I. Brezhnev be held in Moscow rather than Washington.

title: Carter's Vow on Taiwan Is Demanded by Reagan
description: Washington Star

title: High School Coaches Get No Respect
description: The metropolitan area has a problem  actually, several problems  with school sports programs and physical education programs. Lewis Lyman's bleak view (High Schools: Fewer Coaches Means More Problems, Jan. 28) is accurate. As a coach of a minor sport in high school and college. I have a different perspective.

title: Fishway Project to Start in May
description: VERNON, Vt., Feb. 10 (AP)  Work on a $7.5 million fishway, to help Atlantic salmon and shad get around a dam on the Connecticut River at the New England Power Company's hydroelectric plant, is expected to begin in May, according to a company spokesman. Utility officials say Other fishways are being built by Northeast Utilities 20 miles down river in the Turners Falls section of Greenfield, Mass.

title: Cape May Keeps Eye on Breach in Dunes
description: CAPE MAY LOCAL officials in the southern tip of the state are keeping a close eye on the sky and the Atlantic Ocean these days. They hope there will not be a winter storm of the magnitude that could surge through a breach in the dunes and inundate four communities with floodwaters more devastating than the destructive onslaught of 1962.

title: Hlne Martin Plans May Bridal
description: Malcolm Van Dyke Martin of New York and Pembroke, Bermuda, and Mrs. Gifford Horton Stanton of Paget, Bermuda, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Helene Martin, to Seth McCormick Lynn Jr., son of Mr. and Lynn of Linden. Pa.

title: Headliners
description: Some people will go to great lengths to keep their sanity. That is what Sara Jane Moore said she had in mind when she went over the wall of the Federal Reformatory for Women at Alderson, W. Va., last weekend. Miss Moore was serving a life sentence for trying to assassinate President Gerald Ford in San Francisco on Sept. 22, 1975. At her sentencing the following year, Miss Moore read a 10minute statement in which she explained what she had tried to do. At the time it seemed a correct expression of my anger, she said, and besides it was meant to trigger an investigation of assassinations by the Federal Government itself. After her recapture, Miss Moore said she was ready to kill her partner in escape, if necessary, but changed her mind.

title: Margie Ann Moeller Is Bride Of Loyal Hobart Tingley 3d
description: Margie Ann Moeller Is Bride Of Loyal Hobart Tingley 3dThe Eden Church (United Church of Christ) in Chicago was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Margie Ann Moeller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred O. Moeller of Chicago, to Loyal Hobart Tingley 3d, son of Jane Tingley of Savoy, Ill., and Mr. Tingley Jr. of Fort Myers, Fla. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Gordon Collier.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: MEXICO CITY  Only by flying into Mexico City at night, when the smog has cleared and a bed of lights spreads in all directions below, does the visitor have any sense of the monstrous size of the Mexican capital. But only in the daytime, when visibility shrinks to a few blocks, can the visitor learn the true meaning of air pollution. Today, Mexico City is the world's third largest city, fated to surpass New York and Tokyo within a few years. It is already the world's largest poor city, combining the disadvantages of industrialization and underdevelopment and providing a grim warning to capitals in other developing nations whose growth outstrips planning.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: A PROBLEM that apparently recurs persistently in houses with walls and ceilings of gypsum board (also called plasterboard, wallboard or drywall) is that of nails popping, or working loose.

title: Constance Maria Cummings Fiance of Herman J. Miller
description: Mr. and Mrs. John B. Cummings of Bellport, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Constance Maria Cummings, to Herman Joseph Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Miller of Glen H??d, L.I. A June wedding is pl??ed.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A photograph of Picasso's Kneeling Woman was published in some editions of The Times yesterday with a caption stating incorrectly that the painting had been bequeathed to the Museum of Modern Art in the will of Nelson Rockefeller. The painting was not part of the bequest.

title: Thomas Hicks 3d, Elizabeth A. Nelson Plan July Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold F. Nelson Jr. of Mountainside, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Ann Nelson, to Thomas Edward Hicks 3d. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. A.C. Reeves Hicks of Princeton. N.J.

title: Law Professor Suggests Reform In Material Witnesses' Detention
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 10 (UPI)  In nearly every state of the Union, an innocent person may be legally jailed for an indefinite time, without compensation, because that person has seen a crime committed.

title: Stennis Says It Is Time To Reimpose the Draft
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP)  The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, never a champion of the volunteer Army, told his colleagues today that the time had come to reimpose a military draft.

title: MAKING IT RUSSIAN STYLE
description: No 16yearold has a very realistic image of the world that lies before him. In America, he is encouraged to see his future as if it were a broad sweep of unlimited opportunity to be shaped solely by his individual talents and hard work,new society. a pristine field on which he will leave his own distinctive footprints. In the Soviet Union, the cultural myth is something quite different, but no less appealing to the young: a future of multiple choices, each a wellmarked path of material security and comfort, each a noble contribution to the building of a new society.

title: SHOP TALK
description: OYSTER BAY IF you can't resist a penny candy counter, the Oyster Bay Cheese Store, 105 South Street, is the first place to go in Oyster Bay. Yes, a cheese store has an impressive oldfashioned penny candy counter where you can choose sweets from 42 different gleaming glass jars.

title: The Empty Cup
description: In a meeting room at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, the coach of the National Hockey League MIStar team, Scotty Bowman, waited for his players to assemble and then turned to the blackboard. He was about to diagram strategy to be used against the Soviet National Team in the current Challenge CUD series at Madison Square Garden, but when he looked for the chalk, there was none. Quickly, the call went out through the hotel for some chalk, but none was available. And so Scotty Bowman had to wave his fingers across the blackboard as if he were using chalk.

title: Suicides Among Young Persons Said to Have Tripled in 20 Years
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 9 (UPI)  Suicides among teenagers and young adults have tripled in the last 20 years, and children as young as 6 are now killing themselves, according to the director of a suicide prevention center.

title: IN BRIEF
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged William F. Buckley Jr. with violating antifraud provisions of the securities law. Mr. Buckley, the columnist and author, agreed to give up $600,000 of Starr Broadcasting stock and not to accept a directorship of a publicly held company for five years. The commission asserted that Mr. Buckley may have injured Starr Broadcasting in trying to save himself from bankruptcy. ... The S.E.C. censured E. F. Hutton & Company and sanctioned 13 present or former employees, charging that they had violated antifraud provisions of the securities laws by inducing dozens of financially unsophisticated customers to invest in the stock options market. The S.E.C. says the customers lost some $1 million from 1975 to 1978. ... The commission officially closed an investigation into the New York City financial crisis, taking no enforcement action against city officials and institutions criticized in a previous staff report.

title: Mom and Pop Are Landlords in the British Virgin Islands
description: Breakfast in bed? Sure, we'll be happy to serve you breakfast in bed if you're willing to bring your bed down here to the dining room.

title: The World
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  It was a gentlemanly coup, by all accounts, that returned Pakistan to military rule after five and a half years under the controversial, if nominally democratic, Government of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto. Shortly after the troops of Gen. Mohammad Zia ulHaq had surrounded Prime Minister Bhutto's house, the two chief protagonists in the drama were calmly discussing details of the changeover on the telephone. Nineteen months later, Mr. Bhutto languishes in a tiny, unheated jail cell under sentence of death while General Zia presides over a divided country with a hybrid Government of military and civilian figures. His is the third military regime in Pakistan, a country that has experienced 13 years of military rule in its turbulent 30year existence.

title: The Vitality of Hoboken
description: Somewhere between the tragedy of a tenement fire and the hopefulness a brownstone rehabilitation lies the real Hoboken. At the midpoint of the century, it was a tough, brawling pier city. The longshoremen are mostly gone now, but a pugnacious vitality remains. It shows up at a daycare center. where, on a hot summer day, kids cool off under a shower in the park, or on burntout piers, where they leap into the Hudson, or at lunchtime at Fiore's, where Tony serves salami and mozzarella with vinegar peppers. You can see it on River Street, where .the old Seamen's Mission has been torn down to make room for a new housing development. You can feel it at the Feast of St. Anna in the pride of the festival princess and the young parish priest It is what brings Smokey Stover, longretired from the Fire Department, to fires to help with doughtnuts, coffee and advice.

title: Court Rules an ErJudge Can't Sue Over Articles
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 10 (UPI)  A Federal court has ruled that a forrner county judge cannot sue United Press International and The Associated Press for libel because he failed to ask the news services to retract what he asserted we??e defamatory news articles about him.

title: Lincoln's Peekskill Address: Yes, There Was One
description: ON Feb. 19, 1861, a train carrying Abraham Lincoln from Illinois to his first inauguration pulled into the Peekskill station and halted. Coming out onto the coach platform, the Presidentelect listened to a brief introduction, said 138 words to the crowd of 1,000, and then headed off for Washington. It was the only time he ever came to Westchester. More than 100 years later, however, seems that many have little noted nor long remembered what he said there. Some don't know he was ever there at all.

title: Jazz From Leroy Jenkins
description: Leroy Jenkins introduced some new compositions for a mixed quintet of brass, woodwinds and strings at the Kitchen on Friday night, and the music represented something of a departure for him. He was making music that depended heavily on improvisation with bands that did not include a traditional jazz rhythm section more than 10 years ago in Chicago. But his Friday night concert at the Kitchen went beyond this early work.

title: Radio
description: 77:30 A.M., WBLS: Tenant Survival Program.

title: Pages From a Dramaturg's Notebook
description: Last year, when Marshall Mason, artistic director of the Circle Repertory Company, invited me to join the staff as dramaturg, or literary manager, I looked on the appointment as an opportunity to expand on the company's existing work with playwrights. The following report on my experience may shed some light on this relatively new job and function, which is appearing at more and more theaters in the United States.

title: 3,154 Standout Dogs Compete Tomorrow In 103d Westminster
description: It's Westminster time again.

title: The Winning Blow
description: There is no question about a value of a pin for a variety of purposes  defensive, offensive and positional. The late Al Horowitz liked to quip, The pin is mightier than the sword. Nevertheless, for every tactical device there is an antidote, and in the case of the pin, there is the unpin.

title: Holdouts Endanger Future of Tennis
description: ARTHUR ASHE was lecturing young John McEnroe before a nationwide television audience after their Grand Prix Masters final a few weeks ago, and millions of viewers wondered what the lecture was all about.

title: Eileen Ward, John Barrett Set Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence William Ward of Cincinnati have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eileen Mary Ward, to John Finn Barrett, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles M. Barrett, also of Cincinnati. Plans have been made for a June 16 wedding.

title: All of Shakespeare Will Be on TV
description: LONDON In the gymnasiumsized great hall of Penshurst Placeas fine an example of Tudor architecture as England possesses  the cast of Henry VIII is a little tense. An industrial dispute at the BBC has meant that vital time has been lost. Distant airplanes flying over the rolling Kent countryside keep adding their hum Shakespeare's words, maddening the sound technicians and making retakes necessary. What's more, Europe's bitterest winter for years is beginning to bite, and little clouds of steam are billowing from the shivering actors' mouths. And, as it that weren't enough, voice, whisoering and tittering, are wafting in from beneath a small balcony and inflaming the director. Kevin Billington.

title: Leakey Contends Fossil Isn't an Ancestor of Man
description: BOSTON, Feb. 10 (AP)  Richard E. Leakey, one of the world's leading anthropologists, says he has discovered new fossils that challenge a contention by two Americans that they have found a previously unknown species of early man.

title: Deaths
description: ABBEYElaine, beloved wife of Bertram L. Loving mother of Frederick, Michelle and Maida. Cherished daughter of Jennie Glassberg and daughterInlaw of Rose Abbey. Services Sunday 10:45AM at Gutterman's Nassau Memorial Chapels Long Beach Road at Greystone, Rockville Centre. L.I.

title: U.S. RIGHTS SURVEY FOR 115 COUNTRIES SEES SOME PROGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10  The State Department today reported both gains and losses in the observance of human rights during the last year by 115 countries that receive economic or military assistance from the United States.

title: Kim Baker Wed to Dr. Rolla D. Campbell Jr.
description: Kim Baker of Centre Island, Oyster Bay, L.I., and New York, widow of George F. Baker Jr., was married yesterday in Locust Valley, L.I., to Dr. Rolla Dacres Campbell Jr., an attending orthopedic surgeon at the Hospital for Special Surgery and New York Hospital. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony in the chapel at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church.

title: R.B. Graves Fianc Of Linda Jane Kelly
description: Mr. and Mrs. W. Thomas Kelly of Paoli, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Second Lieut. Linda Jane Kelly, Nurse Corps, U.S.A., to Robert Barclay Graves, son of Lieut. Gen. Ernest Graves, U.S.A., and Mrs. Graves of Arlington, Va.

title: Dynamo to Tour U.S.
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 10 (AP)  Moscow Dynamo, one of the world's premier soccer teams, will open its biennial United States tour Feb. 21 with an exhibition match against the San Diego Sockers of the North American Soccer League.

title: Sandra McFarland Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Chester R. McFarland of Montvale, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sandra Grover McFarland, to Lieut. Scott Alden Roberts, U.S.M.C., son of Mrs. Robert Humphrey of Boxford, Mass., and the late Alden Perry Roberts. A summer wedding is planned.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The films of Paul Schrader, who wrote the screenplay for Taxi Driver (directed by Martin Scorsese) and who both wrote and directed Blue Collar and the new Hardcore, are difficult to get hold of. They are not only about contradictions, they deal in them. As often as not they employ shock effects that appear to pander to what the moralists among us would call our baser instincts.

title: A Subjective Subject.
description: FEELINGS Our Vitat Signs. By Willard Gaylin, M.D. 254 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $10.

title: Fort Knox of 47th Street
description: What was for years a flaw on the street of diamonds has finally been repaired.

title: A Time of Change for the Y.M.C.A.
description: THE plight of 57 men who are faced with the prospect of eviction from the Greenwich Y.M.C.A. is the latest indication of changes that have come to the Y.M.C.A. over the years, particularly in the wealthier suburbs.

title: Crime In Street Perturbs Resort
description: ATLANTIC CITY SINCE the gamblingcasino era came to this shore city with the opening of Resorts International last May 26, street crime which had shown a decline in the previous year  has increased, but the city's police force is smaller now than at any time in the last three years.

title: CAMERA
description: Most amateur photographers soon learn that it is possible to make portraits of people which go well beyond simple snapshots of friends and relatives. However, all too often this means traditional, formaltype studio pictures to many people. Fortunately, many serious camera fans have discovered that they can simulate the indoor conditions professionals use with only a moderate investment in equipment and with some selftraining in how to use lights properly.

title: ART; At the State Museum, Inspiring Prints by Kaethe Kollwitz
description: TRENTON KAETHE KOLLWITZ saw he art as a means to express the tragic plight of humanity. She depicted the atrocities of war, the torments of poverty and the awfulness of death. She had an overwhelming compassion for the down

title: Vieques Seeking New York's Aid
description: The Mayor of Vieques and the head of a fishermen's association from the beleaguered Puerto Rican island flew 1,600 miles to enlist the aid of the New. York City Council last week in their battle to stop the United States Navy from using the small island for target practice.

title: ANTIQUES; Rediscovering the Bounty Of the Clipper Ships
description: CHESTER A handsome collection of the kinds of porcelains, bronzes and prints brought to New England from China in the 18th and 19th centuries can be seen at the Fine Oriental Arts Gallery owned by Betty Killam on Route 9A in Chester. Her special pride is that the antiques in her shop are not recent arrivals from the Orient but art objects that have been in America for generations more than long enough to be considered an authentic part of New England history.

title: Margarethe Aulehner Bride of James E. Daly
description: Margarethe Aulehner and James Edward Daly were married yesterday morning by the Rev. John G. Donohue at the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: I HOPE that our house is not the only one in New Jersey to suffer a visit from one of those cheery appliance servicemen.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: One of the few facets of ancient Egyptian life that has received little or no attention during the current epidemic of Tutankhamun fever is its literature. The Westport Library will remedy this oversight with a series of dramatic readings at 2 P.M. today. Five texts will be introduced by Dr. Karen P. Foster, an Egyptologist, and read by a group of actors under the direction of Albert Pia. The stories are reminiscent of the Arabian Nights, said Dr. Foster.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: Two highpowered Cabinet members spoke out last week on what the Iranian cutoff of oil meant for the United States. Secretary of Energy Tames R. Schlesinger took the dark view, saying that the cutoff was prospectively more serious than the Arab oil embargo of 197374. But Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal, whose duty it is to defend the dollar, seemed to differ as to the seriousness of the move and to suggest that Mr. Schlesinger's remark had unnecessarily triggered exaggerated reactions in the markets  though a Treasury spokesman later insisted otherwise.

title: Anita M. Barrett Plans to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Leo Barrett of Spring Lake, NJ., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Anita Mercedes Barrett, to Kevin James Fleming, son of Mrs. James Fleming of Boca Raton and Siesta Key, Fla.

title: N.F.L. Free Agents: Much Ado About Little
description: Suppose a team in the National Football League  a lesser one far from playoff contention, like the Giants takes a different tack this year and decides to try to improve itself out of the current pool of 141 free agents, players who have from now until April 15 to market their skills around the league. What could such a team do for itself?

title: Ambach, Under Pressure by Regents, Drops Plan to Award Certificates to Seniors Who Fail State Test
description: Under pressure by the Board of Regents, the State Commissioner of Education, Gordon M Ambach, has agreed to abandon his plan for granting certificates of achievement to all high school seniors who failed the state competency tests that are required for diplomas.

title: British Soccer Curtailed
description: LONDON, Feb. 10 (AP) More than 20 British league soccer games were postponed today as ice and snow hit northern England and Scotland. Two leading teams in the English First Division, Liverpool and West Bromwich, had their matches postponed, Liverpool against Bolton and West Bromwich vs. Chelsea. Everton, which defeated Bristol City, 41, slipped by the idle teams and took first place.

title: A New Beginning in the South Bronx
description: The South Bronx has, by now, become a national symbol of urban desolation, and the Charlotte Street housing project there was to be the first step in a joint FederalNew York City reclamation plan. So it might have seemed shocking when the city's Board of Estimate refused last Thursday to permit the closing streets running through the site. Mayor Koch acted shocked; worse, he took the board's disapproval as rejection of the whole Federalcity plan to help the South Bronx. Here, the Mayor was listening to his rage instead of his reason. His response should be charged against his tantrum quota, and forgotten.

title: THE MARKETS
description: Last week, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 12.30 points to 822.33 amid worries about imported oil, inflation and interest rates the three I's currently stalking the stock market.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: An inaccuracy appeared in the article, Hospital's Future Is Uncertain (Jan. 7). In the article, the Rutgers Medical School of the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey was described as having a twoyear course [and] in the process of becoming a fouryear institution.

title: Washington Seeking to Repair Schism With Now Powerful, OilRich Mexico
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 10  President Carter will journey to Mexico Wednesday in quest of a more durable and more realistic, relationship between the United States and its newly powerful, oilrich and wary neighbor.

title: Ethics Panel to Hear Intercontinental Case
description: TRENTON THE longsimmering dispute surrounding the operations of the Intercontinental Life Insurance Company of Newark could come to a boil Tuesday. That is when the Joint Legislative Committee on Ethical Standards reviews the activities of Senator Martin L. Greenberg's law firm in connection with Intercontinental's application for a stateguaranteed loan.

title: Pakistan Adopting Islamic Laws With Their Severe Punishments
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 10  In an effort to make all laws in Pakistan conform to the tenets of Islam, the national religion, President Mohammad Zia ulHaq today announced a series of measures providing for such punishments as stoning to death for adultery, amputation of a hand for theft and 80 lashes for drinking.

title: Singer Adds Band and Finds New Directions
description: HUNTINGTON I think Long Island  this part of the North Shore, at least  is like Greenwich Village used to be. There are so many good musicians out here now, and they all know each other. Really, there's quite a bit going on.

title: Around the Nation
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 10 (UPI)  Federal health officials inoculated more than 4,100 people in Pennsylvania and Maryland this week as the result of a case of paralytic polio in an Amish community in Franklin County, Pa.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Well, now we know one more thing about Andrei Serban. In addition to his talents as experimentalist  sending suicidal actresses plunging from high platforms toward apparently naked stage floors, turning whole auditoriums into mazes through which cloaked devils can scarcely find their ways, shooting underground torch flames up through the grillwork on which obviously endangered actors are performing  he can also direct musicals with balloons in them.

title: Finding Funds for Schools Isn't Easy
description: As it struggles to come up with an equitable system for financing public education, New York State's biggest problem is that it cares too much about schools. Both the state and local communities already spend at such a high rate that bringing the level of spending in poor districts .up to that of rich ones would take hundreds of millions some say billionsof dollars of new state funds. On the other hand, even the limited leveling down proposed by Governor Carey to redistribute funds from rich to poor districts is already meeting strenuous resistance from suburban districts whose identity is wrapped up in their quality schools.

title: Airlines Lining Up for Fare Increases
description: Take the controls off airfares, the supporters of airline deregulation used to argue, and lower rates will send traffic soaring, and revenues along with it. For a while the equation seemed to work. But now, the airlines claim, the bloom is off the deregulation rose: The gains in the number of passengers at rockbottom fares are beginning to level off, and they are no longer matching inflationfueled expenses.

title: Sunday Observer
description: I went into show business. Why not? Everybody said. You can never call yourself a writer until you've written a musical that never gets produced. Anyhow, it looked more interesting than politics, which had turned into accounting.

title: Millrose Prestige Exerts a Spell
description: Eamonn Coghlan said he could feel the excitement before he had even taken off his sweatsuit for the race.

title: Mayor of Akron Is Not Seeking Election to a 5th Term This Year
description: AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 10  John Ballard, Mayor of Akron since 1965, has said that he will not run for reelection this year.

title: A CORRUPTION DRIVE INTENSIFIED IN ZAIRE
description: KINSHASA, Zaire  At the start of an assault on rampant corruption in Zaire, team of foreigners brought in to run the central bank has cut off credit to some of the most flagrant violators of foreign-exchange laws.

title: Screening by Computer Cuts Education Grants
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP)  Fewer students are getting Federal grants for college this year and the average award is $100 smaller after a campaign in which a computer was used to weed out cheats and those giving inaccurate financial information, a Government official reported this week.

title: JERSEY MAY REQUIRE CASINO CONSERVATOR
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 10  The Casino Control Commission is running short of time to meet a Feb. 26 deadline on whether to give Resorts International New Jersey's first casino license.

title: Bernadette D. Seredinski Married to Navy Officer
description: Bernadette Dorothy Sereclinski, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Seredinski of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Lieut. (j.g.) Lewis Dundon Thompson, U.S.N., in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Josaphat in Philadelphia. The Rev. John Wendrychowicz performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Dr. Andrew McElwee of the First Presbyterian Church in Caldwell, N.J.

title: RaidersCowboys Tilt Set
description: OAKLAND (AP)  The Oakland Raiders and Dallas Cowboys will meet July 28 in Canton, Ohio, in the Pro Football Hall of Fame game, the traditional opening game of the National Football League exhibition season. The game will match the teams with the two best records since 1960.

title: Divorce: Growing Way of County Life
description: AT the Ninth Judicial District Courthouse in White Plains, Valentine's Day will be just another loveless day. Divorce is definitely increasing here, and it seems to be affecting people from every walk of life, every occupation and every age group, said State Supreme Court Justice Anthony Ferraro of the matrimonial section of the Ninth Judicial District Court. We've had people getting divorced here who are as young as 18 or 19 and as old as 75 or 80.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1979

title: Southern Cal President Quitting But Denies Any Link to Disputes
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10  Dr. John Hubbard, the president of the University of Southern California, who has been at the center of a controversy over the university's ties to Iran and the Arab countries, has submitted his resignation effective August 1980.

title: NEW ORLEANS POLICE BACK INTERIM PACT
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 10  Striking New Orleans policemen went back to work this afternoon, ending a twoday walkout after reaching an interim agreement last night to return to work for a week while city officials negotiate with union representatives.

title: Olympics Plans $1.5 Million for Arts
description: What will the Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra be doing at the Winter Olympics in Lake Placid, N.Y., next year? Performing, of course.

title: 22 Held in Raids on Gambling Ring
description: New York City and state police officers yesterday raided 10 apartments in four boroughs as part of an orchestrated sixstate offensive against a multimilliondollar gambling operation believed to be linked to organized crime.

title: Moscow Complains C.I.A.Distorts Military Budget
description: The Soviet press agency Tass has assailed a Central Intelligence Agency report estimating Soviet military spending last year at a level 45 percent higher than that of the United States. Tass also said the new American military budget of $122.7 billion was truly astronomical.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: The subject today is Pyrrhic victories, or, to mix mythology and metaphor, the Architectural Pathetic Fallacy.

title: TV VIEW
description: The bottom line is content. Programs are all. That is the message being delivered forcefully throughout A Public Trust: The Report of the Carnegie Commission on the Future of Public Broadcasting, more conveniently known Carnegie II. The report, released over a week ago, is far more detailed and specific, especially on funding mechanisms, than the 1967 Carnegie I study  Public Television: A Program for Action  which provided the abstract goals and ideals for the institution, partially financed with taxpayers' money, that became the present Corporation for Public Broadcasting. That first blueprint for the future was best distilled in the now famous E.B. White commentary, used by Carnegie Ito introduce its chapter on programming:

title: For Sideswiping Driver Education
description: OF ALL the casualties of cuts in school budgets and their attendant diminishment of educational programs, the demise of driver education is the least to mourn. Some mourners view this loss from the curriculum as driver education. Education?

title: Old Friends Now Rivals In Struggle For Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran Mehdi Bazargan, a 72yearold engineer, and Shahpur Bakhtiar, a 62yearold lawyer, have long been fast friends, bound together by their French educations, their high intelligence, their fluency in several languages and, most of all, their steadfast opposition to the rule of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi. At one time they even shared the same prison for their stand against the Shah.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: DO NOT FORGET THE NEEDIEST!

title: Editors' Choice
description: THE BASS SAXOPHONE, by Josef Skvorecky. (Knopf, $8.95.) Two novellas about life in Communist Czechoslovakia, resonant with political, romantic and musical undertones.

title: If You Go . . .
description: ... to the Edison National Historic Site, continuous guided tours of the West Orange Laboratory are scheduled from 9:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. daily. when the last tour starts. Advance reservations are necessary for groups of ten or more.

title: With Head and Heart
description: THE publication of Muriel Rukeyser's Collected Poems is an occasion for rejoicing. Not only is Miss Rukeyser one of those poets American literature would seem impoverished without, but, like William Carlos Williams, she has been an indestructible force for the good of poetry and poets for decades. This sumptuous volume gives us all her poems from the elaborate rhetoric of Theory of Flight (1935) to the tighter, franker  but no less generous  insights of Breaking Open (1973) and The Gates (1976). For all that the poems have changed over the years, it is impossible to say that there has been a technical development. Miss Rukeyser seems to have been born poetically fullgrown, and for this reason it is as rewarding to open the book at any point as to proceed systematically from beginning to end.

title: ART
description: STONY BROOK AS a figurative artist struggling to develop a personal mode of expression in an atmosphere dominated by Abstract Expressionism, Shirley Gorelick, an artist who lives in Great Neck, rejected both the extremes of nonobjectivity and photographic exactitude.

title: Accord on Violence Eludes Latin America Bishops
description: PUEBLA, Mexico, Feb. 10  Agreement on a unified approach to violence is one of the problems being faced by Roman Catholic bishops in the final days of the Latin Amgrican Bishops Conference here.

title: Questions and Answers on Carter Business
description: The finances of President Carter's family business in Plains, Ga., a peanut warehouse, have been the subject of number of news articles in recent months. The reports have said that Federal investigators are examining the operations of the business, its loans and its expenditures. The issues are complex and the reports at times have seemed confusing and contradictory.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SEA CLIFF THREE years ago the SeaCliff Chamber Players bad to cut their already modest salaries by 20 percent just to survive as a professional chamber group in the suburbs.

title: Miss Saland Is Swanilda in Copplia
description: Swanilda is the leading role in Copplia and it's a favorite role of many dancers. The New York City Ballet's Friday night performance at the New York State Theater suggested why.

title: FOOD
description: OCEANSIDE LIKE whether to marry or where to live, you are faced with another of life's difficult decisions at Stefan's Patisserie. There are two dozen or more different pastries, over half of them chocolate, among the daily temptations in this Oceanside pastry shop (with a branch in Rockville Centre).

title: Sears Will Float First Samurai Bond
description: A Samurai named Sears, Roebuck? That was the news out of Tokyo last week.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: The article U.S. Asks Why So Much School Lunch Is Wasted, [Jan. 21] was both informative and timely. The article describes a problem whose solution escapes most school districts. A new Nutrition Education and Training Program (NET) has recently begun operation out of the PutnamNorthern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services, under the general direction of Federal Department of Agriculture and the State Education Department. The program addresses itself to the problem of waste in the schoollunch program, as well as nutrition education in the classroom.

title: PEOPLE
description: Loeb Rhoades Hornblower & Company, which has been caught in postmerger confusion after last year's combining of Loeb Rhoades & Company with Hornblower, Weeks, Noyes & Trask, called a meeting last week of its finance committee, and emerged with some major changes in the top management.

title: SPORTS
description: EINSTEIN would have been a natural at darts. Anyone who could figure out the theory of relativity could probably learn the complicated math that is a major part of the growing sport of darts. Throwing them is the easy part.

title: Food
description: When is a stew not just a stew? As good cooks know, a stew can become both special and spectacular when it incorporates ingredients that give it an unusual flavor.

title: L.I. Engineers Wooed From Afar
description: ELECTRONICS and aerospace specialists, who only a few years ago were poor cousins in industry's labor force, now find themselves Cinderellas at the ball. And anxious recruiters are making sure their dance cards are filled to overflowing.

title: Notes: The Freighter Crunch
description: The idea of a freighter trip to an exotic South Sea island might be enough to spark fantasies in the most sedentary of armchair travelers, but at the rate that freighters are dying out, even the most avid globetrotters will have to be content with fantasizing  unless they have almost unlimited time and money. For example, how about a freighter trip around the world  for seven months at $7,000 a person?

title: I Always Wanted to Dance Like Astaire
description: Dan Siretta is never happier than when he is prowling around a junk shop or stirring up the dustier reaches of an old bookstore or library. The treasures he comes away with  fading photographs, crumbling portfolios  are the raw materials of his art, which is not collecting but choreography. Mr. Siretta's main base of operations is the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Conn., where his specialty  and the specialty of the house  is breathing new life into the creaky limbs of longforgotten musicals.

title: Excerpts From HumanRights Report
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10  Following are excerpts from the report on the condition of human rights in 115 countries, prepared by the State Department for the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and the House Foreign Affairs Committee:

title: The Widening World of Captive Insurers
description: For a growing number of American companies, the insurance subsidiary or captive is an idea whose time has arrived.

title: Martinelli Moves to Thwart Caputo
description: WHITE PLAINS THE murmurs, reported two weeks ago, that former Representative Bruce F. Caputo might run for Yonkers Mayor in November have turned into a roar. As a result, Mr. Caputo has promised the public some official word on his plans by next week. But Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli is not waiting that long and is expected to announce tomorrow that he will seek a fourth term.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: APROBLEM that apparently recurs persistently in houses with walls and ceilings of gypsum board (also called plasterboard, wallboard or drywall) is that bf nails popping, or working loose.

title: Nikolai S. Tiknonov, 82; A Leading Soviet Writer
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 10 (AP)  Nikolai S. Tikhonov, a prominent Russian writer and chairman of the Soviet Peace Committee, died Thursday at the age of 82, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today. It did not give the cause of death.

title: Premieres by Martha Graham Center
description: In the most gracious of bows to the younger generation, the Martha Graham Dance Center has initiated a projected annual concert series devoted to the proposition that its talented emergent choreographers deserve professionally produced showcases. Dancers from the Graham school and company, all technical and administrative assistance and full financial support were given to five Graham principal dancers in this first program of a new Choreographers Series.

title: Mary M. Duplain, George M. Cheever, Lawyers, Are Wed
description: Mary Margaret Duplain, daughter of Mrs. Charles Joseph Duplain of Boston and the late Mr. Duplain, was married yesterday to George Martin Cheever son of Dr. and Mrs. Francis Sargent Cheever of Wellesley, Mass.

title: Roth, With Nine Strikes In Raw, Wins P.B.A. Title
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 10 (AP)  Mark Roth rolled nine strikes in a row today in the final game of a $100,000 Professional Bowlers Association tournament at Dick Weber Lanes to defeat Marshall Holman, 279227, and capture the $15,000 first prize.

title: A Professor Develops His Hobby Into Photographs as Big as Life
description: ST. JOHNSBURY, Vt., Feb. 10  It may have been the campus agitation of the late 1960's that sent Harold Holden to the seclusion of his oldfashioned laboratory to try to invent a better film developer. Or it may simply have been his aversion to the graininess of his photographic prints.

title: Food and Gasoline Lead Wholesale Prices to Largest Monthly Increase Since 1974
description: The Government last week jolted Americans with a report that wholesale prices in January rose by 1.3 percentthe biggest increase in four years. Sharp gains were widespread  in gasoline, fuel oil, autos, machinery and food. The increase for beef and veal prices alone was 13 percent.

title: Coghlan Beaten by Nyambui
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 10  For the second time in two nights, Eamonn Coghlan found himself a step short of where he wanted to be at the finish line tonight.

title: Head Shop Sparks Protests in Cedarhurst
description: CEDARHURST DOES a head shopl encourage drug use? Or is it simply a shop for hobbyists and no more dangerous than a record store or a store selling provocative Tshirts?

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Two recent Opinion Page articles. Dear Pen Pal: I'm From Suffolk..., by Michael Dorman, and Who Said Suffolk? I'm From Peconic, by Richard Cummings, drew a number of letters from Suffolk residents, including the following:

title: A Wealth of History at Harpers Ferry
description: There is a look of innocence about the village of Harpers Ferry that makes it difficult to imagine how so much history could have been recorded there or how so many tragic mistakes could have been made over such a modest piece of real estate.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: As the New York City Ballet season draws to a close this week, some thoughts come to mind. One is that the company has been dancing at a particularly high level of ensemble strength. Another is that Mikhail Baryshnikov's ups and downs during his first season with the City Ballet were to be expected. Finally, one premiere instead of the customary two proved that the company can rely upon the body of its work  its repertory  and does not need the stimulus of novelty to deliver a successful season.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS Continued
description: WASHINGTON  Could it be that radioactive fallout from the nuclear weapons tests of the 1950's and 1960's maimed the brains of millions of children and lowered their I.Q.'s? Could it be that several hundred thousand shipyard workers servicing nuclearpowered vessels have been exposed to too much radioactivity over the past 20 years, causing leukemia in some of them? Could it be'that thousands of workers in the nation's nuclear weapons plants have been exposed to levels of radiation that induced cancer?

title: Iran's Military Find a Target Their Fellows
description: In the three brief weeks since Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi was forced from Iran, behind the political turmoil has lurked the shadow of the armed forces. What would they do? The generals have indicated support for the fragile Government of Prime Minister Shahpur Bakhtiar, installed by the Shah. But many of the rank and file support Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who last week named a government of his own headed by another veteran politician, Mehdi Bazargan.

title: Steven Schragis to Wed Donna Reservitz in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. George B. Reservitz of Lexington, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Joy Reservitz, to Steven Michael Schragis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin I. Schraais of Scarsdale. N.Y.

title: WASHINGTON
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 10  It has been 30 years since Octavio Paz wrote The Labyrinth of Solitude  the classic study of life and thought in Mexico. Now we find him in his cluttered, noisy penthouse in the very center of Mexico City, speculating about the visit of President Carter and musing about the differences between our countries.

title: Hoffa Investigators Pin Hopes on Assertions by an Underthorld Informer
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10  The Federal authorities looking into the disappearance of James R. Hoffa say they are hopeful that Charles Allen, who has confessed two underworld murders and who was once a friend of Mr. Hoffa's, can help them shed new light on the fate of the former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: What do collectors of decoys do when they meet? Show, tell  and sell, of course. So today, when the Long Island Decoy Collectors Association holds its third annual meet at the Museums at Stony Brook, there will be hundreds of working and ornamental decoys from 40 exhibitors along the Eastern Seaboard on display and an auction for those who like to do more than just look. The meet will be open from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., with the auctions scheduled for 2 P.M. Admission, which will benefit the new decoy gallery of the History Museum, is $1.50 (75 cents for children under 12) and includes admission to the entire museum complex on Route 25A. 7510066.

title: Kim to Defend Title
description: SEOUL, South Korea (AP)  Kim Sang Hyun, the World Boxing Council superlightweight champion, will make his first title defense against Esteban DeJesus of Puerto Rico in San Juan March 17, the Korean Boxing Commission has announced. Kim won his title from Saensak Muangsurin of Thailand on a 13thround knockout last December.

title: STAMPS
description: An interlude in the sequence of new issues that always mark the opening weeks of every year provides an opportunity to examine the new catalogues that are the essential reference tools of the stamp collector.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: One of India's greatest tourist treasures, the gleaming, whitemarble Taj Mahal, was reported stained brown by industrial pollution in April 1938. A Government committee, appointed to protect the 300yearold royal pavilion at Agra, called for the removal of offending industries. Two thermal power stations, a railway yard and 250 small iron founderies were deemed the main threats.

title: Places That Give Reality to Edison, Eccentric Genius
description: It is a hundred years since Thomas Alva Edison contrived the first practial electric light, and countless tributes are being paid to the eccentric genius whose invention electrified the world.

title: Farm Policy Is Destroying Cropland, Study Warns
description: BOZEMAN, Mont., Feb. 10  The Federal farm program is contributing to the poisoning of the soil and the destruction of fertility in dryland grain areas of the Northern Great Plains, according to a report by two researchers at Montana State University.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: State of the staple. Once upon a time, before the age of blockbuster reprints with multimilliondollar price tags, movie tieins and women's historical romances, paperback publishers lived mostly on two staples  mystery stories and Westerns. How are those staples doing today? Herewith a quick checkout.

title: DINING OUT
description: ADD Pappagailo in Glen Head to the rapidly growing roster of elegant new North Shore restaurants. Actually, only the elaborate setting is new. Until a few months ago, Pappagallo was in a small house, but now it boasts a onestory redbrick pavilion with two airy, spacious, extremely comfortable octagonal dining rooms, decorated in quiet beige tones.

title: Longden to Receive Cake That's a Furlong Long
description: ARCADIA, Calif. Feb. 10 (UPI)Santa Anita will give Johnny Longden, the retired jockey, something unusual at his 72d birthday party Wednesday a furlonglong birthday cake.

title: Case Against the State's Drug Law
description: THE Committee Against Life for Drugs is a singular organization of women in Westchester. Each of its officers and members is a first offender serving sentence of life imprisonment in the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, with a minimum term up to 25 years before parole is possible, for the possession or sale of a controlled substance.

title: ART
description: WHITE PLAINS ANYONE who has walked in the last few months through the plaza near the Westchester County Courthouse must have noticed a conspicuously large addition: two immense pyramids atop each other. The larger pyramid soars to a height of 22 feet and the smaller one inside it to 10 feet, giving the plaza an unusually exotic, provocative Egyptian aura. It's a little bit of Egypt and a little bit of Westchester, said one bystander gazing up at the rustred steel structure...

title: Radio OrchestrasA German Tradition
description: The fact that an orchestra called the NDR Symphony of Hamburg, under a conductor named Zdenek Macal, is performing a concert Friday night at Carnegie Hall may not seem of enormous interest to jaded New York musiclovers. Most of them probably aren't exactly sure what NDR means or who Mr. Macal is. The reason is that, although this is the ensemble's third tour of the United States, it has not made many records, and Mr. Macal  who is an interim principal guest conductor, not the group's permanent music director  is not very well known in this country at all.

title: A Police Study Challenges Belief Family Fights Are Riskiest Duty
description: The belief of many New York City police officers that the most dangerous assignment they can get is to be sent to stop a family quarrel has been disputed by a study by a faculty member at the Police Academy.

title: Gifts to Neediest Involve a Range Of Contributions and Impetuses
description: Recent donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ranged all the way from $1 to more than $12,000.

title: Fresh Clues to a Green Antarctica Found Under Ice
description: Underneath Antarctica's Ross Ice Shelf, a region the size of Spain, the water is perpetually dark, cut off from the world by floating ice almost 1,900 feet thick.

title: Officials Disagree on Impact, but Costly Disruptions Seem Certain
description: WASHINGTON  Nothing may be more important  or more confusing than the international oil trade. The Arab oil embargo of 197374 amply demonstrated the key role of oil in American life, and more. It also illustrated that yesterday's tranquility can almost instantly become today's crisis. Now comes Iran.

title: MEASURE TO CURTAIL SMOKING IS OFFERED
description: ALBANY, Feb. 9  A bill to curtail smoking in public places was introduced this week by a Manhattan Assemblyman who said he hoped the recent Federal report on the links between smoking and disease would improve the measure's chances of passing.

title: Deaths
description: CAPOBIANCOGrace, on Feb 9, 1979, of Tarrytown, N.V. Beloved mother of John, Angelo, and Gerardo Capabianco, and Mrs. Anna Rendale. Also survived by 15 grandchildren and 7 greatgrandchildren. Reposing Coffey Funeral Home, Inc., 91 North Broadway (Route 9), Tarrytown, N.Y. Funeral Mass Tuesday. 9:30 A.M., Church of the Transfiguration, Tarrytown, N.Y. Friends may call Sunday and Monday 24 , 79 P.M. Interment Sf. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, N.Y.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Corn is the largest single crop grown in the United States, and much of the work of growing it consists of planting it every spring. What if it just came up by itself, like daffodils? Agricultural scientists have undertaken. a crossbreeding project that might lead to just such perennial corn.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THOSE people who kept saying last month as the rain kept falling that we should be thankful it isn't snow were not really looking at the puddles through foggy rosecolored glasses. Had all that rain been snow, Long Islanders would have had to dig themselves out of nearly eight feet of the stuff.

title: Kathryn H. Worth Fiance of Student
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donn Hamilton Worth of Canton Center, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Hamilton Worth, to John Ernest Hoffman 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hoffman Jr. of Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: World News Briefs
description: PARIS, Feb. 10 (Reuters)  Industrial conflict disrupted France again today after a series of protests yesterday against rising unemployment.

title: Dome Petroleum Is Gambling on an IceBound Bonanza
description: CALGARY, Alberta  On these bitter winter days in Canada 's far north, daylight is nothing more than a thin band of pink that briefly dabs the southern horizon around noon. In an inlet on the frozen Beaufort Sea, more than 1,500 miles north of Calgary, $250 million worth of ships stand empty, locked side by side in ice. But come June, the redfunnelled Vessels will be bashing through pack ice toward their drilling sites.

title: Heiden Double Victor, Nearing World Title
description: OSLO, Feb. 10 (AP)  Now I'll go for a new 1,500meters world record Sunday, said Eric Heiden after the American star won the 500 and 5,000meter races today in record times at the opening of the 73d world speedskating championships.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: HAD we made a mistake? Suddenly, our decision to move into a retirement home seemed awfully final.

title: MUSIC
description: LET me start by telling you how delighted I was with the response of Westchester music lovers to WQXR's fundraising marathon for the New York Philharmonic. All through last weekend, I was excitingly embroiled with the phone festival  on the air and on the wireand even though the Philharmonic is theoretically a New York City institution, I don't think there was a town in Westchester that wasn't represented on our list of contributors.

title: Energy Agency Is Bound for Podunk
description: SOMEONE on the staff of Joel R. Jacobson, Commissioner of the state's Department of Energy, posted a sign reading Podunk City on the wall of his office recently. It was a reference to a remark that Mr. Jacobson made during a recent discussion with a group of mayors about who should have the final word about where energy facilities should be situated.

title: Los Angeles Assured of Games
description: The United States Olympic Committee approved an agreement yesterday with the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee that cleared the way for the 1989 Summer Olympics to be held in this country.

title: ANTIQUES
description: The tools that built America  the planes, hammers, drills, axes, travelers, braces, calipers, wrenches and saws  were frequently tailormade to suit both the task and the man who would perform it. No wonder, then, that heavy use over a long period left the imprint of strong hand, one of many qualities collectors of tools covet in what they seek. In other cases, the artisan who forged the iron, routed the wood or bent the steel into a drill bit, and added a design detail that became recognizable as a signature. Even so; most of the tools that were produced before Washington crossed the Delaware are very like those the Romans wielded. They remain virtually unchanged to this day.

title: Rise in WhiteCollar Jobs Seen for New York Area
description: A new Federal study of employment in the area of New York City and northeastern New Jersey predicts an increase in whitecollar and service jobs and a decline in the bluecollar sector.

title: Collins of 76ers Out for Season
description: PHILADELPIIIA, Feb. 10 (UPI)  Doug Collins of the Philadelphia 76ers will be out the rest of the season with a bone spur in his left leg, it was announced last night.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9 00 A M. TO 4 30 P M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900. WESTCHESTER CO AND NORTHERN NEM YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 669180 CONNECTICUT (203)3487767.

title: Borg Tops Vilas by 63, 63
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Feb. 10  Bjorn Borg stretched his domination over Guillermo Vilas to eight straight matches with a 63, 63 victory today and set up the expected confrontation with Jimmy Connors to determine who is No. 1 in the world.

title: $150,000 ART THEFT IS REPORTED BY MET
description: In what officials of the Metropolitan Museum of Art described as the first major theft in the institution's 110year history, an ancient Greek marble head valued at $150,000 was stolen Friday, the museum said yesterday.

title: Waldheim in New Bhutto Appeal
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 10 Secretary General Kurt Waldheim has sent a third appeal to President Mohammad Zia ulHaq of Pakistan to spare the life of former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who has been sentenced to death for complicity in a political murder. Mr. Waldheim sent two appeals last year.

title: Taiwan, Tonkin and the Truth
description: If Congress is to be a serious partner in bigpower diplomacy, it had better learn to talk straight as well as tough. The power to declare war carries the burden defining the provocations to war with restraint and precision. Otherwise the bombast of today will be the Tonkin of tomorrow.

title: Prize Winners Visit Chamber Society
description: The Avery Fisher Prizes go each year to young musicians who need and deserve a boost in their careers, and part of their award includes appearances with various Lincoln Center organizations. On Friday night, two of the latest winners took part in the concert by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in Alice Tully Hall. They were Yo Yo Ma, cellist, and AndrMichel Schub, pianist.

title: Britons, Shaken By Labor Rifts, Ponder Future
description: LONDON, Feb. 10  A young lawyer named Carey Wilson sat in his neighborhood pub in Chelsea the other night, musing, like millions of other Britons these days, about the labor crisis.

title: South Bronx Renewal Also Renewed Old Disputes
description: No area in the nation, let alone in the City of New York, has frustrated planners in the last decade as much as the South Bronx. It is urban desolation at its worst: 35 percent of the population on welfare; 20 to 30 percent of the workforce out of a job; 1,500 vacant buildings; 500 acres of abandoned land, 6,900 buildings in tax arrears, and a percapita income of $2,340  60 percent below the national average. There are serious problems with crime and drugs, and there is nowhere the degree of social cohesiveness that helps offset similar troubles in other poor parts of the city such as Harlem and BedfordStuyvesant.

title: Shows and Events
description: Next Sunday  Antiques show and sale, Temple Emanuel, 56 East Broad Street, Westfield. Hours: 11 A.M.6 P.M. Donation: $1.50. Benefit for the Westfield chapter of ORT (Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training).

title: 3 Ohio Officials Freed From Jail After Rejecting Judge's Budget
description: CARROLLTON, Ohio, Feb. 10 (AP) Three Carroll County Commissioners were freed from jail today after serving one day of a contempt sentence imposed by a judge whose budget request they had rejected.

title: Billy Carter Breaks Date With Face the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI)  Billy Carter, whose finances and dealings with Libyan officials have come under question, has canceled his scheduled appearance tomorrow on the CBS interview program Face the Nation.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON  Several sparsely populated communities in New Jersey get minions of dollars each year in tax revenues because they have power plants within their borders. Around the Legislature, these communities are known as sheikdoms. Lower AllowPys Creek Township, population 1,400, gets more than $8 million a year in taxes because two nuclearfueled plants are located there.

title: Carter Doubts That U.S. Could Eliminate OPEC
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10  President Carter feels that it would be an idle hope to think that the United States could destroy the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and its control over international oil prices.

title: BRIDGE
description: Contract bridge and yachting are linked in two rather unusual ways. First, the late Harold Vanderbilt contributed greatly to both activities: In bridge, he codified the game in its present form, invented the first bidding system (which was ahead of its time) and won the famous trophy that bears his name; in yachting, he codified the rules for sailing ships and led his crew to victory in the America's Cup.

title: U.S. Sues to Keep HighRises From Capital's Sight
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10  A legal battle over architecture and the esthetics of the capital has pitted the United States Government and key figures in the arts against Virginia developers and the Board of Supervisors of Rosslyn, a communityjust across the Potomac from the parks around the city's historic monuments.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING Condominium Prices: Ceilings Rising
description: THE news in condominium sales is good for the sellers and bad for the buyers. It doesn't matter whether a condominium is new or an older unit being resold  the price now is about 12 percent higher than a year ago. And unlike used cars or almost any other used item, a used condominium now commands the same price as a brand new, identical model.

title: SHOWDOWN NEARING FOR CHURCH COUNCIL
description: The Council of Churches of the City of New York appears to be headed for a showdown Thursday in a dispute over its executive director that could seriously Jeopardize the council's continued existence.

title: Big Racing Day for Petty Family
description: Today will be a big day for the Petty racing family at Daytona International Speedway.

title: Files Reveal Japan Sought HitlerStalin Peace in '44
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9  In August 1944, as the Allied forces closed in on the Axis powers, Japan began a major diplomatic effort aimed at bringing about peace between Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union.

title: The Lessons of Declining Enrollment
description: AT a time when we are hearing more and more about school closings as a result of declining enrollment, the question which may need to be answered is whether a correlation exists between school size and quality education. Is there a point, for example, when a school's population becomes too small for efficient operation?

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: Today

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: WOMEN'S groups appear to be losing the battle over preferences accorded to veterans of the armed forces when it comes to filling Civil Service jobs in the state.

title: APPALACHIAN TRAIL GAINING SOME LAND
description: STORMVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 8  Federal and state agencies have acquired land in Dutchess and Putnam Counties as the first step in moving stretches of the Appalach an Trail back into the woods, where they were before roads and housing developments destroyed much of the trail's wilderness quality in New York State.

title: Swiftly Changing Political Currents Lead U.S. to Ponder a New Kind of Foreign Alliance
description: WASHINGTON  The Carter Adniinistration has discovered that the problems created for United States foreign policy by old friends can sometimes overshadow the challenges posed by traditional enemies. Last week, Administration policymakers watched helplessly as one old friendIran  continued in the throes of revolution. Meanwhile, on Capitol Hill, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee agonized over the plight of another longstanding ally, Taiwan, and debated ways of ensuring that the United States could continue to protect the security of the island after a defense treaty with Taiwan expires at the end of the year.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Lost in Translations
description: If all the Russian players spoke English (as the National Hockey League stars suspect they do) it would be easier to discern the undercurrents in the Challenge Cup hockey series that ends today at Madison Square Garden.

title: T.R. Drake Fiance Of Anne Albright
description: The engagement of Anne Ridge Albright to Trevor Richardson Drake has been announced by her parents, Archie E. Albright of New York and Mrs. Suzanne Albright of Akron, Ohio. Mr. Drake is a son of Carl B. Drake Jr. of St. Paul and the late Frances Boynton Drake.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Confrontation in Congress Over Carter's Trade Pact
description: WASHINGTON  After five years of preparations and five years of negotiations, President Carter formally notified the incoming 96th Congress last month that he would sign a massive new trade pact. Thus the scene was set for what promises to be one of the most intense struggles in 50 years between advocates of protectionism and freetraders.

title: ART VIEW
description: WASHINGTON About the exhibition called Berenson and the Connoisseurship of Italian Painting, which David Alan Brown has organized at the National Gallery of Art (through May 13), we are told straightaway  in a foreward to the catalogue  that it is unlike any previously held at the museum. It represents, this foreward continues, an attempt to display an intellectual process. The exhibition thus acknoviledged to be openiy didactic, yet it is also said to have relatively little to do with biography  a claim difficult to sustain unless we are prepared to conceive of biography in the narrowest possible terms.

title: Cancer Patients Found to Meet Hostility on Returning to Jobs
description: LOS ANGELES. Feb. 10 (UPI)  A study at the University of Southern California has found that many bluecollar workers stricken with cancer return to their jobs facing hostility from employers and coworkers.

title: Nouveau Philosophe
description: IN May 1968 France was shaken by a wave of demonstrations. Originally launched by students at the Sorbonne, the demonstrations quickly passed beyond the universities into the streets. Workers joined students, and eventually the whole of Paris came to a standstill. The disturbances spread to other cities in France, and for a while the de Gaulle Government seemed about to topple. But the rebellion fizzled out  in part because the Communistcontrolled unions, fearing that the workers might become caught up in the general spirit of revolt and stray too far from the paths of party discipline, pulled them off the streets.

title: Miss Frawley Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Joseph Frawley Jr. of Los Angeles have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eileen Josephine Frawley, to Dudley Edward Callahan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Dudley Callahan of Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

title: At Home: Coming Of Age
description: YEARS ago, when I was a bachelor in New York City, I saw a little boy of 3 or 4 pedaling a blue plastic automobile along the sidewalk of 57th Street between Lexington and Park Avenues. It was about 9:30 on a weekday morning and the street was dense with people going to work. The day was dark and wintry and the sight of that solitary little boy threading his way through the crowd, unaccompanied by a parent or friend, filled me with such sadness that I followed him around the block. Watching him begin a second tour, I said to myself that I would never let this happen to my son.

title: Sports Thews Briefs
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 10 (UPI)  Hubert Green made a strong move toward becoming the first player to win the S300,000 Hawaiian open in consecutive years when he tied a course record with a nineunderpar 63 today to grab the thirdround lead by four strokes.

title: Realty News
description: The St. Regis Paper Company will build a 120,000squarefoot office building in West Nyack, N. Y., which will house about 450 of its employees, many of whom now work at its headquarters at 150 East 42d Street in New York City.

Berkley's (pronounced Barkley's), has five other wine bars in England, but this first American one has been ensconced in Pickwick Plaza just four months.

title: Letter
description: Blake Fleetwood's faith that gentrification will spark an urban renaissance (The New Elite and an Urban Renaissance, Jan. 19) rests on the hoary American fallacy that the fate of cities is shaped by downtown development and luxury housing booms. In the 1950's, another small but highly visible luxury housing program  urban renewalwas similarly hyped. It also dispersed the poor (as it turned out, only into other slums). Mr. Fleetwood's belief that gentrification may reduce the pathology of welfare dependency, unemployment and crime is, thus, illusory.

title: Picturesque ($3) an Easy Victor In the Lucky Draw at Aqueauct
description: Picturesque of the Harbor View Farm, a promising 3yearold colt who finds it difficult to get interested in a stakes race until it is halffinished, perked up on time again yesterday at Aqueduct to score an impressive triumph in the $53,050 Lucky Draw Stakes.

title: Carey Faces Fight On Schools Plan
description: ALBANY THE saveharmless provision guaranteeing that no school district in the state will lose state aid, no matter how rich it is or how much its school population shrinks, is not dead, despite Governor Carey's proposal to change the formula.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Manager George Bamberger of the Milwaukee Brewers says his club can win the American League East pennant from the Yankees: On the field, we feel we're stronger than they are. We feel our pitching is on the way up and theirs is on the way down.

title: Agricultural Research May Give Corn Back to the Indians, Only Better
description: The recent discovery in the remote mountains of Mexico of a wild, distant cousin of domesticated corn, suggesting the hope of someday transferring desirable genes from the wild plant into cultivated varieties, has inspired renewed interest in one of man's most important traditional crops. In the United States, the importance of corn as a human food staple is little appreciated. Grown on more than a million farms, totaling more than 60 million acres, corn is this country's biggest and most valuable agricultural crop. The annual American corn harvest exceeds 6.3 billion bushels, and accounts for almost half the world's production. That crop is worth well over $12 billion annually, and provides 70 percent of the corn In world trade; it is a large factor in this country's foreign exchange account. But as much as 90 percent the United States crop is feed corn, consumed by animals, ultimately to be eaten by people in the form of meat, milk, eggs and other animal products. To most Americans, says Dr. Ernest Sprague, director of corn research at the International Center for the Improvement of Maize and Wheat, corn is popcorn and cornonthecob.

title: Is a Custom Home Best? Or One in a Development?
description: There is, as you may have heard somewhere, no free lunch in the housing market. Everything you get costs something, and everything has both advantages and disadvantages. New homes are no exception.

title: Job Help For Women
description: MINEOLA WOMEN seeking jobs in work areas traditionally held by men will now have an opportunity to obtain information about the trades and professions from which they have virtually been excluded.

title: A Warning Against Youth Crime
description: New York State now has the toughest laws in the country for juvenile crimes. Thirteen , 14 and 15yearolds arrested for certain crimes will not to Family Court. Instead, they will go to the same criminal court used adults.

description: In past years when you spoke of bigtime women's collegiate basketball in the metropolitan area the first team mentioned was Queens College. Now, with Queens rebuilding, it seems Rutgers is the first team to come to mind when one speaks of metropolitan powerhouses.

description: MARGARET SOTER, the county Republican Party's new vice chairman, comes from a family of Democrats, or at least from the deep Democratic South. I'm not sure how my parents voted; we never talked politics at home, she said.

title: Celtics Turn Back Knicks by 106 102
description: Nate Archibald played 38 minutes last night. In the first 35plus minutes, the 6footlinch Boston Celtic guard took 10 shots and made only one. In the final 2 minutes 12 seconds, Archibald was turned loose, and he responded with 10 of his 18 points that led the Boston Celtics to a 106102 victory over the Knicks before a crowd of 16,238 at Madison Square Garden.

At the age of 53, he has served quietly for 18 years as a Congressman from a conservative, middleclass section of southern Queens. where he began his political career as a loyal servant in the Democratic Party organization.

title: ITS ALL RIGHT TO TALK DEFENSE AGAIN IN JAPAN
description: Gotemba, a town that is about 60 miles southwest of Tokyo, is the starting point for the ascent of Mount Fuji. Here, every autumn, the SelfDefense Forces, as the Japanese armed forces are known, put on a livefiring display. Heavy machine guns rattle, 155millimeter howitzers let fly with heavy thuds, and 1974type Mitsubishi tanks obliterate target mounds of black earth on the slopes of Mount Fuji 500 yards away.
