title: Fresh Perceptions by Realist Painters
description: LOCUST VALLEY AN exhibition of contemporary realists at the Country Art Gallery is eloquent proof of the diversity that realism continues to offer. In this show there seem to be as many aspects or realism as there are painters. Although most of them share a devotion to the recognizable image, their esthetic approaches as well as their techniques are decisively dissimilar.

title: Painter to the Mind
description: MARCEL DUCHAMP is the selfappointed court jester of 20thcentury art. We have had many eccentrics, fanatics and experimenters but only one astute wag who understood that he could mix enigma and spoof in approximately equal proportions and still be tolerated as an artist. He shuttled between Paris and New York; his act had two parts. Until he died in 1968, Duchamp devoted his 50year career to saying a prolonged ritualized goodbye to painting  ostensibly to play chess. Yet he never succeeded in getting out the door. Compared to this old musichall routine, the other part of Duchamps act looks very sober. He described it in an interview with James Johnson Sweeney: I was interested in ideas not in merely visual products. I wanted to put painting once again at the service of the mind.

title: AMERICAN INDIANS STRUGGLING FOR POWER AND IDENTITY
description: American Indians gave up beadsandblanket capitalism on Jan. 31, 1975, in Billings, Mont. That day, at a meeting in a small college planted on a frigid escarpment of the Rockies, a group of tribal leaders got a look at the generous contracts under which American energy companies now do business with oilrich thirdworld nations. For the Indians, it was an instant education in the real value of their worthless reservations. They learned that, unlike the canny oil merchants of the Middle East, their tribes were still being ripped off with Colonialera prices for the vast mineral wealth that lies under the feet of this nation's most impoverished minority. Prophetically, the meeting in Billings was entitled Indian Tribes as Emerging

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy

Centering on the multiple rape of an English nurse and the tribulations of a spinster school mistress, its illumination of the nature of the British Raj recalls E. M. Forster's A Passage to India.

title: London Delights in the Artifice of an Early American Play
description: LONDON Eight years ago the Royal Shakespeare Company, at London's Aldwych Theater, struck out in a new and  as it proved  profitable line. The RSC unearthed a forgotten comedy by the Victorian playwright Dion Boucicault entitled London Assurance, and the title seemed an apt description of the style with which the company brought the play to the stage. The production ran the entire season at the Aldwych, played for a further year in the West End, and finally came to New York  where it lasted a mere couple of weeks.

description: Just three weeks ago the St. John's basketball team was struggling to stay over the .500 mark. Its wonlost record was 98 and the Redmen appeared to be on their way to finishing the season on a low note.

title: RHODESIAN DISPUTES VIEW OF GUERRILLAS
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 10  A white farmer who spent nine months as a captive of black nationalist guerrillas returned here last week and offered a view of the guerrillas that contrasted strongly with the Government's representation of them as ruthless killers bent on driving the white minority from the country.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Williams Winner

title: Budget Keynote Is Caution
description: HARTFORD SIGNS of a possible economic slowdown sometime next year and the political reality that the electorate was in no mood for big new spending programs or higher taxes dictated the relatively modest 5.1 percent increase in state spending that Governor Grasso proposed to the General Assembly last Wednesday.

title: Serkin's Unusual Approach to Brahms
description: Nothing but Brahms Friday night in Carnegie Hall, with Mstislav Rostropovich leading the National Symphony Orchestra in the Fourth Symphony and then collaborating with Rudolf Serkin in the Second Concerto. This is the season for the Brahms Piano Concerto No. 2 in Bflat; it has already been played several times, and next week Vladimir Ashkenazy will address himself to it.

title: Kathryn Lenahan Plans May Bridal
description: Kathryn Crowley Lenahan and Peter A. Roberts, who are with Morgan Stanley & Company, will be married in May. Their engagement has been announced by the bridetobe's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Patrick Lenahan of Locust Valley, L.I. Mr. Roberts is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Louis A. Rottenberg of Manhasset, L.I.

title: Professional Advertising: Who Will Profit?
description: WASHINGTON  Should professionals advertise? Two yeais ago, the Federal Trade Commission sued the American Dental Association over the question, charging that the association, through its rules against advertising, was engaging in a conspiracy that restrained trade and boosted prices.

title: Airport XRays Pose Problems For Photographers
description: Earl Dibble is a photographer who, with his wife, Eloise, prepares and presents travelogs. Two summers ago, they spent three weeks traveling 20,000 miles through the Soviet Union. Since then, they have been pursuing a frustrating quest for compensation for probably the biggest disaster of their professional careers.

title: DINING OUT
description: THERE'S much to be said for a dinerrestaurant at which you can order a Rusty Nail and a short stack, or a Singapore Sling and Nick's Athenian souvlakia, at virtually any time of the day or night.

title: Dia Takes Top Prize At Chihuahua. Show
description: A creamcolored, longcoated Chihuahua, Ch. Terrymont Marsubri Dia Ruff, celebrated her fourth birthday yesterday by being named best of breed at the Chihuahua Club of Metropolitan New York specialty in the Hotel Taft. Dia. owned and bred by Marcia Greenburg of Springfield, Mass., and her sister, Ruth Terry, of Wilton, Conn., was handled by the former.

title: Gains Are Found Across New York A Decade After the Clean Air Act
description: Nearly a decade ago, in the beat of the newly born environmental movement, the Federal Clean Air Act was passed, committing the Government to making the nation's air healthy by reducing pollution.

title: Letters: There's Never a Dull Moment in India
description: To the Editor:

title: BROWN PLEDGES AID TO SAUDIS' DEFENSE
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 10  Defense Secretary Harold R. Brown today pledged firm American support for Saudi Arabia against external threats, and he began laying the groundwork for a stronger security relationship with the Saudis and with other proWestern nations in the Middle East.

title: Horsemen Ride Into Florida
description: The Florida Winter Circuit, which in the last decade has developed into one at the major equestrian extravaganzas in the United States, gets under way Tuesday with the Palm Beach Masters and continues through March 18.

title: College Head Gets U.S. Post
description: CHICOPEE, Mass., Feb. 9 (AP)  Dr. Edward R. D'Alessio announced his immediate resignation as president of the College of Our Lady of the Elms today to become deputy education commissioner in the Department of Health. Education and Welfare. Dr. D'Alessio, 46 years old, became the fifth president of the 51yearold Roman Catholic liberal arts college for women in 1976. He was the first layman to head the 400student school.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Associated Terrier Clubs specialties, 102d Engineers Armory, Fort Washington Avenue and 168th Street; 522 dogs; 8 A.M.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: William Hiltz Weds Judith H. Bingham
description: Judith Helen Bingham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theron A. Bingham of Douglas Manor, Queens, and William Otis Hiltz, son of Harry B. Hiltz Jr. of Palos Verdes, Calif., and the late Marilla Otis Hiltz, were married yesterday.The Rev. Raymond Webster performed the ceremony in St. James Episcopal Church in New York.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: BIRDY, a first novel by a hitherto unknown writer, William Wharton, about a man who becomes physically and metaphysically involved with birds and flight, has made the kind of publishing debut that authors only dream about. The reviews have been bursting with praise, one reviewer hailing it this early in the season as the year's best novel. There are 25,000 copies in print. Avon paid a halfmillion dollars for the paperback rights and it is a selection of the BookoftheMonth Club.

title: In the Air Over Midtown: Builders' New Arena
description: Imagine huge skyscrapers towering above  or replacing altogether  Bergdorf Goodman, Saks Fifth Avenue, B. Altman's, the University Club, the skating rink at Rockefeller Center, the New York Public Library, possibly the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, the St. Thomas Episcopal Church, even St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: LITTLE IMPACT SEEN IN COAST TAX SLASH
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10 With the California Legislature wallowing its way toward new legislation to bail out local government from the effects of Proposition 13's property tax cuts, Gov. Edmund G. Prown Jr's. administration has come forward with the judgment that city and county programs have been cut remarkably little.

title: Guyana Files Lawsuit To Recover Damages From People's Temple
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Feb. 10 (UPI)  The Guyana Government has filed suit against the People's Temple and two of its surviving members who are still in Guyana, seeking to recover thousands of dollars in damages.

title: What's Doing in VERONA
description: OVERVIEW  Shakespeare though there is no proof that he ever visited Verona  is responsible for most people's main impressions of the city. As a result its principal tourist attractions are sites dedicated to the story of Romeo and Juliet; and postcards and souvenirs recalling their tragic romance are on sale everywhere. If that were all there was to Verona it would explain why it does not enjoy the prestigious reputations accorded other Italian cities such as Rome and Venice. It is in fact one of the most beautiful of Italian cities, a city of great architectural and historic distinction. As the gateway to northern Italy, it is surrounded by fortification walls dating to Roman times, and its Arena, which is used for opera in summer, and its Roman Theater both date to the first cenury A.D. Verona blends Roman, medieval and Rennaisance art, and it is a center of good food and wine.

title: Deaths
description: FREEDMANNina (nee Goldstein), on Feb. 9, age 02, of 737 Perk Ave.. NYC, formerly of Springfield. Mass., loving sister of Rae Michaelman of NYC, and Solon Goldstein of Stamford, CT, and several nieces and nephews. Funeral today at 12:30PM at the Ascher Memorial Chapel, Springfield, Mass. Burial in Beth Israel Cemetery, West Springfield. Mass.

title: Carnegie II: How Public Television Can Fulfill Its Promise
description: The 1967 landmark report by the Carnegie Commission on Educational Television, Public Television: A Program for Action, was blessed with exquisite timing: It arrived in the midst of the Great Society initiatives of the Lyndon B. Johnson Administration. In short order, elements of the Carnegie proposals were translated into legislation as the Public Broadcasting Act of 1967.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: JOHANNESBURG  If there is no peace in Rhodesia, this can not be blamed on any shortage of men of God involved in both politics and the guerrilla war there.

title: She Has the Stature For Nuclear Research
description: JILL KAUFMAN of Coram is the first to admit that her looks are something of a professional drawback. The 24yearold Miss Kaufman, who is 4 feet 10 inches tall and weighs 85 pounds, is a nuclear engineer and deeply involved in research into nuclear reactor safety at the Brookhaven National Laboratory. If people have a stereotype for the role, Miss Kaufman does not seem to fit it.

title: U.S. Tells of Evacuating 250
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10  Government sources familiar with the situation within the Iranian military said today that the air force was considered loyal to the Government and that the technicians and air cadets who rebelled at the air base in Teheran represented only a small percentage of the air force.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: PERSON/PLANET The Creative Disintegration of Industrial Society. By Theodore Roszak. 347 pp. New York: Anchor Press / Doubleday. $10.95.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: STATE SENATOR Joseph R. Pisani of Mount Vernon was one of two Republicans to vote against the socalled Rockefeller drug law when it was enacted in 1973. Last week he joined in offering study bill, or draft measure, to revise the statute branded as disproportionately severe by two United States Supreme Court justices and a Federal District Court judge.

title: Enjoyable Cleveland
description: CLEVELAND  My adrenalin always rises when I hit Cleveland, though it was inevitable that on this trip I would be talking with friends and area movers about a downer: the city's $15.5 million fiscal default last December, and the prospect of total bankruptcy unless it raises $30 million to $40 million to meet 1979's debt payments, operating expenses and assorted other problems.

title: UNDER THE AUCHINCLOSS SHELL
description: In his autobiography, A Writer's Capital, Louis Auchincloss described his reception at literary gatherings 25 years ago: The fact that I was a Wall Street lawyer, registered Republican, and a social registrite was quite enough for half the people at any one party to cross me off as a duckbill platypus not to be taken seriously. And then, too, I was inclined to be stiff and formal.

title: The World
description: It is bad manners for a guest to criticize his host, so through most of his visit to the United States, Teng Hsiaoping confined his remarks to oohs and ahs at American technology and occasional jibes at that hegemonistic power, by which, everyone knew, he meant the Soviet Union.

title: CRIME
description: A big, detailed privateeye book, THE SIXTH COMMANDMENT by Lawrence Sanders (Putnam's, $10.95) is completely different from The Tangent Objective, the only previous Sanders book to have come this way. The Tangent Objective, a cleverly written book about contemporary Africa, was a combination of adventure and sociology. The Sixth Commandment takes place in a decaying New York town on the Hudson River, and the only thing it has in common with its predecessor is a snappy writing style.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: This is the second of a twopart series on rentals.

title: Treejackers Seeking Firewood
description: STONY BROOK IT was a classic firewood heist. Frances Kennedy had arranged to have a cord of firewood delivered to her Sag Harbor home and then went away for the weekend, expecting to return and find a stockpile of Wood.

title: 3 Giant Acquirers Still Seek That Elusive Sweet Smell of Success
description: Caught up in acquisition fever, three sophisticated consumer goods companies gambled that they could successfully cross over into the glamorous $8billionayear beauty business. Each company purchased a glittery cosmetics company for sums in excess of 20 times earnings as a sign of their confidence. Today, halfadozen years later, there's more than a touch of tarnish on the glitter, and the parent companies have learned some painful management lessons.

title: Belgium Dispatched New Troops Last Week to Help Keep Order
description: KINSHASA, Zaire  Several years ago, during his authenticity campaign to wipe out the colonial past and help Zaire rediscover its African heritage, President Mobutu Sese Seko outlawed Christmas. Nationalistic symbolism was meant to disarm leftist intellectuals at home and make African nations forget that General Mobutu came to power with the aid of white mercenaries, the United States Government and the Central Intelligence Agency. But, like much else in Zaire, authenticity failed. So, last December, President Mobutu reinstated Christmas. Zaire's 26 million people had little to celebrate.

title: Greek Leaders to Combat Terror By Bolstering the Police Forces
description: ATHENS, Feb. 10 (Reuters)  The Greek Government has decided to combat terrorist activities by strengthening police forces throughout the country, an official announcement said today.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: APROBLEM that apparently recurs persistently in houses with walls and ceilings of gypsum board (also called plasterboard, wallboard or drywall) is that of nails popping, or working loose.

title: American Classics, American Readers
description: LIKE its famous predecessor, Virgin Land (1950), and the two books on Mark Twain that followed it, Henry Nash Smith's new book carries on his scrupulous survey of our national dreams, myths and fictions, and of the divisions of taste, sentiment and class they suggest. Although he is working here on the familiar issue of high culture and popular culture, what he does is fresh and new because he has extraordinary reserves of historical knowledge to bring to bear. He has always spoken with unmatched authority on writers such as James Fenimore Cooper and Mark Twain, who committed themselves to the public version of the world with an incau tious generosity and felt personally betrayed by the world's failure to live up to the values and principles it professed. Democracy and the Novel at first appears (like Virgin Land) a loose assemblage of topics, but, as in all Mr. Smith's work, the firm, judicious presence of the author provides the controlling form. Mr. Smith's power to epitomize, to make fresh and conclusive conjunctions of historical evidence, makes a short book long on content.

title: K.E. Crowe Fianc Of Lynn E. Curtis
description: Mrs. Mortimer J. Hammond of Rye, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Lynn Ellen Curtis, to Kevin E. Crowe, son of Mrs. Clark Beckett of Rochester and the late Timothy P. Crowe. Plans have been made for a May 19 wedding.

title: ANTIQUES
description: ATLANTIC CITY IN THE market for an old car? They might have just the one for you at an auction taking place next Friday and Saturday at Convention Hall.

title: Fred and Those Furs
description: Ann, Barbara, Emily. I've called lots of women to the Fur Vault at Alexander's. Here they are, my customers, in their beautiful new furs ... Susan, I'm still waiting for YOOOOODUU!

title: Criticism Is Leveled in Aftermath of Fatal British Smallpox Outbreak
description: A scientist, the World Health Organization and British health officials have been severely criticized in a report by a British Government committee for not acting to correct procedural lapses that led to the escape of potentially lethal smallpox virus from a university laboratory in England.

title: The Battle to Build the Thinnest Watch
description: In a rampantly inflationary era, at moment when economic storm clouds seem to be gathering, are there really consumers who care how thin their watches are? Two giants of the watch industry think so, and they're engaged in an allout race to produce the world's thinnest watch. What's more, watch retailers are seriously monitoring the race; they see evidence that sizable market exists for a fragile timepiece that sells for upwards of $4,000.

title: Interpol Prepares to Switch to Computer to Coordinate Police Work
description: ST. CLOUD, France, Feb. 10  Interpol, the international police coordination agency, is finally preparing to computerize its operations.

title: CHILDREN's BOOKS
description: SELF PORTRAIT: MARGOT ZEMACH

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: Arthur Hailey

title: Down to the Sea For Scuba Novices
description: BRIELLE SAY scuba diving to most people, and they will not envision a bleak, bonechilling early morning in the choppy, black Atlantic, where, even with an underwater light, you can see only about five feet ahead of you.

title: Marshack Friend Makes Statement on Rockefeller
description: Ponchitta Pierce said yesterday that, on the night Nelson A. Rockefeller died of a heart attack, she received a telephone call from Megan Marshack between 10:50 and 11 P.M., went to Mr. Rockefeller's town house at 13 West 54th Street, saw Miss Marshack administering mouthtomouth resuscitation and called the 911 police emergency number. The police said the call came at 11:16.

title: Marriage Announcement 7 -- No Title
description: Engagements

title: A Siren Song For Engineers
description: ONLY a few years ago poor cousins in industry's labor force, electronics and aerospace specialists now find themselves Cinderellas at the ball. And anxious recruiters are making sure their dance cards are filled to overflowing.

title: JOB LAW TO PROVIDE AID FOR PREGNANCY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP)  Pregnant women will gain wideranging medical, disability and job protection when a new law takes effect this spring, but some employers fear the costs will be astronomical.

title: Radio City Tower Urged
description: The construction of a mixeduse tower piggyback over Radio City Music Hall is recommended in a draft study done for the New York State Urban Development Corporation, Rockefeller Center Inc., and the Lieutenant Governor of New York.

title: Finn Takes PreOlympic Ski Jump Event
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 10 Pentti Kokkonen, the 23yearold performer who is considered Finland's most improved jumper, provided added proof today that he has become a top internationalist in the Nordic phases of the pretrials for the 1980 Winter Olympics.

title: Tale of a Publisher's Move to the County
description: FIVE years ago, Sol Stein realized the inconvenience of railroad commuting for his staff at the Stein & Day publishing house in Manhattan. So four years ago he moved the enterprise to Briarcliff Manor in Scarborough, and for himself found a home in Scarborough  near the main line of the railroad.

title: Rupert Emerson, Expert on Africa
description: Rupert Emerson, emeritus professor of government at Harvard University and a specialist in nationalism in Asia and Africa, died Friday at the Stillman Infirmary in Cambridge, Mass. He was 79 years old. He had been on the Harvard faculty for 43 years before his retirement in 1970.

title: Vote Report Cards Find New Patterns
description: WASHINGTON REPRESENTATIVE Jerome A. Ambro, thirdterm Democratic Representative from East Northport, says that Americans for Democratic Action, the liberal lobbying group, could render its best service to the country by simply going out of business.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today  Boulder Brook. Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale. New York local and children's working hunters, pleasure horses, equitation. 8 A.M.

title: Greene Wins 3,200, Loses 1,600
description: Joe Greene would like to have been in the Millrose Games schoolboy onemile run Friday night in Madison Square Garden. But he failed to get an invitation, and yesterday he had to settle for competition in the Long Island Coaches Association track and field meet.

title: Hilary Mandel Sets Nuptials on April 28
description: Marlynn L. Mandel of Rye, N.Y., and Robert D. Mandel of Edgewater, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Hilary Joan Mandel, to Stephen Gregory Krawczyk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore A. Krawczyk of Barrington, Ill.

title: A Season For Farmers To Represent Themselves
description: WASHINGTON  Denzil Lacy, a lean, tightlywound West Texan, was in Washington all last week, along with about 3,000 other supporters of the American Agriculture Movement, demanding increases in price supports for the wheat and cotton he raises. Denzil Lacy is a committee chairman of the Collingsworth County Farm Bureau, a unit of the American Farm Bureau Federation. The Federation is officially opposed to the higher price supports he wants.

title: Susan Laura Carney Wed To Lincoln W. Caplan 2d
description: Susan Laura Carney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Carney Jr. of Weston, Mass., was married yesterday evening to Lincoln W. Caplan 2d, son of Jane S. Caplan of Washington and Lewis E. Caplan of Philadelphia. Rabbi Sanford Seltzer performed the ceremony at the Vale, the former Lyman estate, now a museum in Waltham. Mass.

title: Ann Hague Fiance Of John Slemp 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Merl T. Hague of Atlanta, formerly of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Louise Hague, to John Calvin Slemp 3d, son of Sue S. Slemp of New Canaan, Conn. and Mr. Slemp Jr. of Rye, N.Y. A wedding in August is planned.

title: The Cartoon Creature as Salesman: Better Than Ever
description: LOS ANGELES  Mickey Mouse, never far from the public mind and eye, had one of his best selling years ever, helped by the hoopla over the worldwide tribute accorded him on his 50th birthday. Superman as salesman leaped tallerthanever buildings, the extra bound attributed to his new film biography. It was a dream of a year, 1978, for the multimilliondollar carwon licensing business, and  save for a Federal cloud still no bigger than a kid's hand1979 may be better yet.

title: Hood's Sloop Placed First; Crewman Feared Drowned
description: MIAMI, Feb. 10 (AP)  Ted Hood skippered his Class F sloop Robin to an unofficial firstplace finish today in a Southern Ocean Racing Conference event marred by the presumed drowning of one crewman.

title: Lonely Sharer
description: JOSEPH CONRAD

title: A New Look Comes To an Old Museum
description: RUTHERFORD THE Rutherford Museum has come a lung way since its move two years ago from overcrowded and improvised quarters above a store. Since then, the museum has occupied a handsome 18thcentury sandstone building, the socalled Yearanze House on the Meadows on Crane Avenue.

title: Thai Prime Minister Said to Plan Visit to Soviet Union Next Month
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 10 (Reuters)  Thailand's Prime Minister, Kriangsak Chamanand, will visit Moscow for talks with Soviet leaders on March 14, informed sources said today.

title: The Nation
description: The statebystate drive for a constitutional amendment that would require a balanced Federal budget has put Republican leaders on the spot. Even so strong a foe of Government spending as Nevada's Senator Paul Laxalt fears that the constitutional convention the states want could lose control and go beyond the budget question, perhaps changing basic provisions of the nation's charter. A convention has not been held since 1787, and no one knows what the rules would be. But the Republicans can ill afford to do nothing while state legislatures, not to mention Jimmy Carter and Jerry Brown, seize the issue of fiscal responsibility.

title: Fuel Tax Proposal Is A Boon for Boatmen
description: Representative Mario Biaggi, Democrat of New York, is planning to reintroduce a bill in Congress that would require the money raised by the Federal Marine Fuel Tax, about $30 million a year, be used to help support state boating safety programs and to build recreational boating facilities.

title: Inmate Gets Life Plus 110 Years In Escape Attempt by Helicopter
description: SPRINGFIELD, III., Feb. 9  Garrett B. Trapnell, a convicted hijacker, was sentenced today to another life prison term plus 110 years for his part in an escape attempt from the Federal Penitentiary at Marion, Ill.

title: Van Duser Rejected Giants Job
description: The compromise choice who turned down the Giants offer last week to become director of operations was Jan Van Duser, the 40yearold personnel director for the National Football League who began his football career 13 years ago working behind a desk in the basement of Atlanta Stadium.

title: CONDONING PERJURY STUDIED BY LAWYERS
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 10 What is a lawyer to do when his client says he intends to lie on the witness stand?

title: Phyllis D. Collins Becomes Bride
description: Phyllis D. Collins, daughter of C. Douglas Dillon, the investment banker who was Ambassador to France, Under Secretary of State and Secretary of the Treasury, and Mrs. Dillon of Far Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Richard M. Huber, executive director of the Center for Lifelong Learning at Hunter College.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: QUESTION: How much additional money did Governor Grasso propose in her state budget to the General Assembly last Wednesday to meet the first year's cost of additional school aid to the localities?

title: Elegiac and Lifeloving
description: THERE is a body of opinion that has it that Edna O'Brien is overrated as a writer; that her success is due to the sex and Irish blarney in her work, and that any serious criticism of her books is out of place. This view is most prevalent in Ireland, her own country, where some see the British and Americans as taken in by the apparent originality of a garrulous line of chat that in the old country is as common as potatoei. Her British critics see her as exploiting not so much her I rishness as her sexiness.

title: TWO KHOMEINI AIDES CONFER WITH YOUNG
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 10Andrew Young, the United States delegate, said today after a meeting with representatives of the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. tne Iranian opposition leader. that he had been assured the human rights of all Iranians would be protected.

title: An Era Ends Suddenly for Tomato Pickers in Ohio
description: NAPOLEON, Ohio, Feb. 10  Lee Diller sounded saddened but resigned to the prospect of change.

title: Senator to Try to Kill Big Waterway Backed By Corps of Engineers
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 10 (UPI)  Senator Gaylord Nelson, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that be would introduce legislation to kill what be called the biggest pork barrel boondoggle of them all  construction of a $1.8 billion water channel in Mississippi and Alabama.

title: American Reporter Killed by a Stray Bullet in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 10  Joe Alex Morris Jr., a correspondent for The Los Angeles Times, was killed early this morning after he was pinned down in a clash between Iranian Air Force cadets and soldiers.

title: Trucker Held in Threat on Carter
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 10 (UPI)  Secret Service agents arrested a Dade City truck driver yesterday and charged him with threatening to shoot President Carter. John William Heffron was accused of telephoning the threat on Mr. Carter's life to station WEFHTV in Orlando Thursday night.

title: Khomeini Converts Some Air Technicians
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 10  The Iranian Air Force has been the best equipped of the country's armed services and consequently was thought to be the most loyal. Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi gave it the latest in sophisticated combat planes and missiles and made sure its 100,000 men were comfortably quartered and well paid.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Mention the name of FrancoisAndr Danican Philidor to the average music lover, and the chances are that you will draw a blank. Mention the name to a musicologist, and you will get a learned lecture on Philidor and his contributions to the development of French comic opera in the 18th century. Mention Philidor to a chess player, and flags will be raised. Philidor was incomparably the greatest player and theoretician of his time, and in many ways he was the father of modern chess. Indeed, the Philidor Defense is still used in overtheboard play.

title: Baseball: Pay Time for National Pastime
description: Baseball, one player agent has said, is playing a very expensive game of leapfrog. In recent months and weeks, the highest leapers have been Pete Rose, Jim Rice, Dave Parker and Rod Carew.

title: For Yankee Hopefuls and Fans, Tomorrow Is 1st Day of Spring
description: You say you're bored with basketball and hockey? Your front walk is covered with ice, the car won't start and you can't stand another windchill factor like the last one?

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Beauty
description: There is no one, man or woman, whose skin can withstand the onslaught of winter without a lot of help. At this time of year, skin all over the body needs special pampering to keep it soft, supple and in good condition.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  It likes to call itself modestly the fact finder for the nation, just an impartial producer of neutral numbers for others to use. But the Census Bureau, an agency of statisticians that long labored in blissful obscurity, is suddenly finding that numbers are not neutral, facts, not always welcome.

title: Chavez Suggests the Possibility Of Nationwide Lettuce Boycott
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9  Cesar Chavez, responding to reports the Ku Klux Klan was trying to help lettuce growers involved in a strike with his farm workers union, threatened today to open a nationwide boycott of lettuce if violence in the struck fields grew.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Immigrant Cabdriver Is Arrested
description: An immigrant cabdriver from Yugo, slavia was arrested yesterday for possession of a forged medallion and driver's license and for resisting arrest. Investigators for the Taxi and Limousine Commission and a detective with the Police Department's Public Morals Division arrested the suspect, identified only as D. Trivic. 48 years old, of 3030 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn. on the Belt Parkway at the 65th Street exit about 10 A.M. Investigator William Love said Mr. Trivic, a registered alien in this country for eight years, at first refused to pull over and then pulled a pocketknife on the arresting officers.

title: Steelworkers' Strike at a Standoff as Shipyard Maintains Production
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Feb. 10 The Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company has maintained production schedules so far in an 11dayold strike by members of the United Steelworkers of America, turning a key test of organized labor's ability to overcome hostility in the South into a standoff.

title: Deaths
description: McMORROWCatherine (nee Ford), on Feb. 9, 1979. Native of County Leitrim. Ireland, beloved wife of the late Michael, loving mother of Mary Brennan, Catherine Savarese, and Margaret McMorrow, dear sister of Elizabeth Dolan. Also survived by eight grandchildren and tour great grandchildren. Reposing at Edward D. Lynch & Son Funeral Home, 4307 Owens Blvd, Sunnyside, LI. Mass of Christian burial Queen of Angels R.C. Church, Tuesday, 9:30 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Article 7 -- No Title
description: REMEMBER THE NEEDIEST!

title: INTERVIEW
description: FRANKLIN LAKES STORYBOOK endings are not just fiction at the Metropolitan Opera, where the bright lights, bouquets of roses and cries of Brava! somehow lend them credibility.

title: EDVARD KARDELJ 69, DIES IN YUGOSLAVIA;
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 10 Edvard Kardelj, who fought at the side of Marshal Tito in the political underground and on the battlefield to bring Marxism to Yugoslavia, died today of cancer in Ljubljana. He was 69 years old.

title: Students Protest Plan To Add Stadium Seats At William and Mary
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Feb. 10 More than 1,000 William and Mary students and professors and residents of this restored Colonial town rallied today to protest plans to double the seating at the college's football stadium. A celebration, of the 286th anniversary of the school's charter was boycotted.

title: Ottinger Puts Some Heat on Federal Energy Policy
description: WASHINGTON WESTCHESTER Representative Richard L. Ottinger, whose energy motto might well be Let the sun shine in, has been elected chairman of one of the two major House subcommittees preparing energy legislation. It is the first subcommittee chairmanship for a Westchester Congressman in memory, according to Ottinger aides.

title: 7 Women in Sicily Push Officials To Release the Man They Share
description: ROME, Feb. 10  Whatever else he may be, Giuseppe Scaffidi Fonte, also known as Pinuzzu, of the village of Sant'Agata di Milnello in Sicily, is quite a man. The carabinieri, who thought he was evil, put him in jail on suspicion of procuring and of selling a child. But his wife, Maria, his six concubines and his many children of all ages think he is lovely and loving. And they threaten a hunger strike to get him released.

title: Flutist and Guitarist Join Forces
description: The combination of flute and harp has been a felicitous forte, inspiring a good many worthy compositions. By extension, or perhaps diminution, considering the question of size, the flute and guitar should also go well together. That they do was neatly demonstrated on Thursday night, when Eugenia Zukerman, flutist, and Carlos Bonell, guitarist, gave a program of solos and duets at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. In fact, the more acidic tone of the guitar gave the pair a more flavorsome tonal palette than the sweeter fluteharp sound.

title: Laos Resists Newest Overlord, Hanoi
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 11 Vietnam's military campaign to establish dominance over Cambodia is giving Hanoi responsibility over a second dependent country. It already wields almost total control over another neighbor, Laos.

title: Gold Fixing: London Tradition
description: LONDON, Feb. 11  Twice every business day, five soberly dressed men gather in a low, modern building in St. Swithin's Lane, a nugget's throw from the Bank of England, to fix the international price of gold.

title: Dance: Yohn and Troupe
description: THE Robert Yohn Dance Company describes itself simply as the vanguard of the new Romantic movement. Dance could use a wave of new Romanticism right now, but unfortuntely Mr. Yohn and Richard Ploch, the choreographers whose work the company performed on Saturday at the Intimate Space Dance Theater, appear to be a doubtful source.

title: De Gustibus
description: It is a longknown tact that there are, in this country and elsewhere, sexist implications in certain foods. Perhaps the most obvious examples are the tendency to relate steak, the rarer the better, with masculinity and salads with femininity.

title: Concert: Babbitt's A Solo Requiem
description: MOST of the Performers' Committee for lothCentury Music concerts have a workable focus. But Saturday evening's Continuum program at Alice Tully Hall, entitled America's Architects of Musical Space, made little sense on a conceptual level. Joel Sachs's program notes were typically informative, but broke down when he struggled to impose logic on a program that was really a grabbag. Still, it was a mostly interesting grabbag, consisting of 11 short pieces by eight composers, plus one 24minute world premiere by Milton Babbitt.

title: Iacocca Says Ford Ousted 3
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11  Lee A. Iacocca, former president of the Ford Motor Company, told Federal prosecutors that top Ford executives, including Henry Ford 2d, decided at a meeting in September 1975 that three executives held responsible for an Indonesian bribery plan would be quietly eased out of the company, according to sources close to the Federal investigation.

title: TV: Best Short Subjects
description: MANY viewers skip the first hour or so of the annual Academy Awards show to avoid seeing Oscars being given out in categories like sound recording, imagepolishing and, of course, short subjects. Tune in 15 minutes too early and you see two fellows in rented tuxedos who put together 12 glorious minutes on Bessarbian folk dancing saying thanks to everyone and stumbling off the stage with one of the coveted golden statuettes.

title: Soviet Six Routs N.H.L. Stars, 60
description: For 72 hours in February, at least, the Soviet Union proved to have the best hockey team in the world.

title: Princeton Women Win Ivy Swim Title
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 11  Charlotte Tiedetnann won the 200yard breaststroke in an Ivy League record time of minutes 22.40 seconds in posting her fifth individual victory in the Ivy League women's swimming and diving championships today at Yale and heipea lead Princeton to the Ivy League team championship. heipea lead Princeton to the Ivy League team championship.

title: 69 Marines, 6 Copters Are Ready to Act
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11  The United States is sending a detachment of 69 Marines and 6 helicopters to Turkey for possible use in evacuating Americans from Iran and protecting the United States Embassy in Teheran, Carter ministration officials said today.

title: LINCOLN'S BIRTHDAY
description: Today, Lincoln's Birthday, is not a Federal holiday, but it is a legal holiday in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Following are services affected:

title: Coast Guard Helicopter Ditches
description: BARNSTABLE, Mass., Feb. II (AP) A Coast Guard helicopter on a search mission ditched in the ocean off the Maine coast today and all four aboard were rescued unhurt, a spokesman at the Coast Guard air station here said.

title: Burger Seeks Study of Bail Releases in Major Crime
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 11  Chief Justice Warren E. Burger called today for fresh examination of the conditions under which people charged with serious crimes are released on bail.

title: Carter's Latin Policy
description: GENESEO, N.Y. There is a quiet but significant change taking place in United States relations with Latin America. With little fanfare, the Carter Administration has altered the direction of American policy from conservative, semiinterventionist to one that supports progressive and even leftist governments.

title: Reserves Help Nets Triumph
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Feb. 11  The number 13 may be unlucky for some, but it didn't prove to be for the New Jersey Nets today. They came back from 13point deficits three times to defeat the San Diego Clippers, 10498, before a crowd of 6,121 in the Rutgers gymnasium.

title: Losers Impressed By Russians Talent
description: Awe Might be too strong a word. But something close to that emotion played on the faces of the National Hockey League AllStars last night in the wake of their rout by a largely unknown squad from the Soviet Union.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1979

title: Deaths
description: ROSENBERGHam (Duke), beloved husband of Belle. devoted father of Marc. dear brother of Jack. Services Tuesday, Noon, Garlick's Coney Island at Ave N, Brooklyn.

title: Paul Mackenzie Groetzinger Weds Andrea M.M. Szekeres
description: Andrea Margit Maria Szekeres, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Janos Szekeres of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Paul Mackenzie Groetzinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul G. Groetzinger, also of Stamford. Justice of the Peace Lome Jaffe of Stamford performed the ceremony at the Szekeres home.

title: Interpace Plans Sale
description: Canadian Pacific Investments of Montreal says an agreement in principle has been reached to purchase the Carey Salt and Wollastonite divisions of the Interpace Corporation, makers of products for the building industry. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Locusts From Horn of Africa Threaten Huge Area
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 11plague of cropdestroying desert locusts, breeding out of control in the Horn of Africa, has spread to neighboring countries and could threaten an area stretching from Africa's Atlantic coast to the Himalayas in Asia.

title: Around the Nation
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 11 (UPI)  Po lice officers, who won major concessions from the city as a result of their twoday strike, claimed another victory today with the disclosure that the city will restore all fringe benefits that had been reduced to pay for salary increases.

title: Track: Walker Takes 3:56.8 Mile
description: MONTREAL. Feb. 11  Just  years ago here, politics thwarted one of the most eagerly awaited confrontations of the 1976 Olympic Games. Today, at the Centre Claude Robillard, a 5,000seat arena just five miles from the Montreal Olympic Stadium, John Walker of New Zealand and Filbert Bayl of Tanzania met on the track for the first time in four years. The result  a victory for Walker in the mile was anticlimactic.

title: A Lincoln Divided
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Any convincing psychological interpretation of Abraham Lincoln must take into account his strong filiopiety  not toward his actual father, from whom be was estranged, but toward the our fathers of the Gettysburg Address, the Founders of the Republic, who still dominated American public life at the time of his birth 170 years ago.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: John Wilson's Savings Plan
description: As a shopper, John Wilson says he was never satisfied with trading stamps, centsoff coupons and other bargain lures. I didn't like savings stamps because the stamps always ended up stuck in my pockets, Mr. Wilson, a Sikeston, Mo., lawyer, said recently. And a 10 percent discount is really not that big a deal because you never see the money, he added.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  What would happen if a gentle, warmly human Harvard professor, beloved by his law students, was put into the job of chief of the Criminal Division of the Department of Justice? With Professor Philip B. Heymann as our top Federal crime fighter, the Criminal Division has become both a citadel of personal rectitude and a demoralized morass of prosecutorial ineptitude.

title: China Appeals to Pakistan to Spare the Life of Bhutto
description: PEKING, Feb. 11 (Reuters)  Chairman Hua Kuofeng of China appealed today to the Government of Pakistan to spare the life of former Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto, whose death sentence has been upheld by the high court.

title: Aluminum Prognosis: High Profits
description: Supplies of aluminum are expected to remain tight and little new production capacity is expected to go into operation until well into the 1980's, all of which should put the aluminum industry in a position to reap high profits.

title: Carving Up NationalAirlines
description: Some months ago, both Pan American Airlines and an aggressive regional carrier, Texas International, applied to the Civil Aeronautics Board for permission to buy National Airlines. Their interest is understandable. National has been drifting for years, yet the routes it flies are potentially very profitable, and its planes alone are worth far more than the market price of the company's stock.

title: Producer Sought Delay In Reviews of `Sarava
description: The producer of Sarava, Eugene V. Wolsk, protested last Friday at its being reviewed at this time. Mr. Wolsk asked that the critics wait until Feb. 23 to see and review the show, on the grounds that work was still being clone on it and that he considered it to have the status of a preview.

title: Manhattanization Fears Snag Crocker Bank Plan
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11Crocker National Bank, the nation's 13th largest, has run into hometown troubles with its plans to build a new headquarters here to accomodate an everexpanding staff.

title: Queens, Fordham Gain Women's Final
description: VALHALLA, N.Y., Feb. 11Queens College and Fordham won their semifinal games today and will meet for the metropolitan championship in the third annual invitation women's collegiate basketball tournament next Sunday at Fordham Prep.

title: Amtrak Train From New York Jumps Track in Georgia
description: McINTOSH, Ga., Feb. 11(AP)Thirteen cars of Amtrak's silver Star derailed in this southeast Georgia town today, injuring 38 of the 430 persons aboard, a railroad official said.

title: Dairy Queen Liquidation
description: Dairy Queen Stores, a chain of fastfood outlets, says it has made a 90centashare liquidating distribution to its shareholders and has transferred the rest of its assets to the First National Bank of Fort Worth as trustee. This completes the liquidation plan adopted by stockholders last Feb. 27.

title: Harriman to Lead U.S. Delegates To Yugoslav Ideologist's Funeral
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI)  W. Averell Harriman will lead an American delegation to the funeral of Edvard Kardelj, Yugoslavia's chief ideological theoretician, the White House announced today.

title: Shah Is Said to Follow Iranian News on Radio
description: MARRAKESH, Morocco, Feb. 11 (Reuters)  Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi has been listening to hourly radio reports about the turmoil in Iran, a Moroccan palace official said today.

title: Floods Sweep Portugal
description: LISBON, Feb. 11 (Reuters)  Portugal's worst floods in nearly 40 years, caused by violent storms yesterday, are feared to have caused at least three deaths, and damage is expected to be many millions of dollars, officials said today.

title: Jazz: Bob Cantwell Leads LaidBack Stompers
description: THE Saturday Night Stompers a sevenpiece jazz group that Bob Cantwell, a trumpet player, leads on Saturday nights at the Red Blazer Too, Third Avenue between 88th and 89th Streets, is in the great tradition of the Nicksieland bands that played at Nick's in Greenwich Village in the 1940's, and later at Eddie Condon's Village Club.

title: 5 Die in Chicago Fire
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP)  A fire possibly caused by a faulty stove swept through a South Side home early today, killing four sisters and a cousin as they slept, the authorities said. A sixth child was missing. A 17yearold brother and two sisters jumped from a secondfloor window. The police said the children's parents and grandmother were not at home at the time. The dead were identified as Margaret Johnson, 16 years old; Novella and Carmella, both 8, and Alicia, 10, and their 19yearold cousin, Crawford Raynard. The missing child was identified as Verdell Johnson, 15, a brother.

title: CARTER FACES FIGHT ON WATER AGENCIES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11  Key members of the House and Senate predict a bruising battle between Congress and the Carter Administration if the President goes ahead with a proposal to strip the Army Corps of Engineers of its authority to plan and economically justify billions of dollars worth of water projects.

title: Books of The Times
description: TO paraphrase Paul Dickson: there was a time, before sociology, when mathematics and the pure sciences held a monopoly on natural laws, principles and named effects, most of which were called after their discoverers, Boyle, Newton, Ohm and everybody. Then economics got its foot in the doorSay's Law, Gresham's Law  and pried it wide enough open to allow the admittance of Murphy. Murphy has been variously identified as a mythical figure on the order of Kilroy and as Capt. Ed Murphy, an Air Force development engineer, but whoever he was he promulgated the profound observation that If anything can go wrong, it will. Then in a rush carne Parkinson's Law and the Peter Principle. Today there are so many rules and laws applying to the nonquantitative aspect of life that one hesitates adding to the clutter with another one.

title: T. Robert Stumpf, at 69; Consultant on Graphics
description: T. Robert Stumpf, a graphics consultant and calligrapher, died Saturday in Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and had been ill for more than a year.

title: Alice Delysia, at 90; Popular Comedienne And Singer in Theater
description: Alice Delysia, a singer and comedy actress during the 1920's and 30's, died Friday in Brighton, England, at the age of 90.

title: Final to Miss Evert
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 11 (AP)  Chris Evert stayed on the baseline and outdueled Renee Richards, 61, 36, 63, to win her first tournament of the year on the women's tennis circuit today. She won $24,000 and the 44-year-old Miss Richards received $12,000. It was the first time Miss Richards had reached the final in a major tournament. And it was the third time she had lost to Miss Evert in three matches.

title: Jackson Forecasts Gas At $1 a Gallon in a Year
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI)  Saying that President Carter should tell it like it is, Senator Henry M. Jackson today predicted long lines at gasoline pumps and $1agallon prices within a year as a result of the upheavals in oilrich Iran.

title: Maras' Feud Leaves Giants' Kingdom Without a King
description: Their disagreements are out there for all to see, like still photographs from a combat zone. They are no closer now to agreeing on a director of operations for the Giants than they were 14 months ago when they began searching. Tim Mara, the 43yearold nephew  speaking for 50 percent of the stockholders  is convinced that the selection of a director of operations, is the top priority. Wellington Mara, the 62yearold uncle  speaking for 50 percent of the stockholders  has decided that since the D.O. situation is at a stalemate, the top priority is finding a coach.

title: Alien Pays in Loneliness for a Living Wage
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 11  Since 1972, between Luis Gomez's first illegal crossing of the MexicanAmerican border and his lonely existence today in a mobile home in Houston, he and his family have invested a full measure of struggle and sweat, tears and joy, in the United States.

title: Last Week's Active Issues
description: NNew York Stock Exchange. AAmerican Stock Exchange OOvertheCounter For the week ended Feb.9, 1978.

title: On Aggression in Politics: Are Women Judged by a Double Standard?
description: In the aggressive field of politics, growing number of women are troubled by what they see as a handicap: a double standard that often seems to reward men for the same qualities that are penalized in women. Many believe that in order to be effective, they are expected  both by the public and by maledominated political establishment  to restrict their behavior to traditional female stereotypes.

title: Boy Who Tried to Fly Like Superman Dies
description: A 4yearold Brooklyn boy who fell from a seventhfloor window on Feb. 2, apparently while trying to fly like Superman, died of his injuries early yesterday at Kings County Hospital.

title: Leftists May Cause Problems for Khomeini
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 11Tire massbased movement that has gathered behind Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini is a coalition of many forces, including small but important leftist and Marxist groups that do not necessarily share the 78yearold Moslem leader's vision of an Islamic republic.

title: It Was Work, Play and Heatless Homes On the Coldest Day Here in Two Years
description: The metropolitan area suffered its coldest day in more than two years  a low of 3 degrees  but life went on unabated for many who were faced with frigid temperatures. A sledder tried his luck at Riverside Park, while Pablo Olivares, below, sat in plastic booth as he watched stand on Broadway. In one of hundreds of homes without heat, left, Allison Chase did dishes in her coat while her sister, Regina, avoided her chores. Article on page B3.

title: Concert: Bach By Zola and Jane Shaulis
description: THE Celebration of J.S. Bach, put on Saturday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall by Zola and Jane Shaulis, sounded less celebratory than doggedly wellmeaning.

title: Donald Kirkpatrick, Former Queens Dean And a Noted Physicist
description: Dr. Donald E. Kirkpatrick, professor emeritus of physics at Queens College of the City University of New York, died yesterday at the North Shore University Hospital In Manhasset, L.I. He was 74 years old and a resident of Douglaston, Queens.

title: Saxophone: Two Styles at the Public
description: TWO tenor saxophonists named Frank played at the Public Theater on Friday and Saturday nights. They used to have more in common than their first names. but while Frank Wright is still honker and screamer, playing very much as he did in the 1960's, Frank Lowe has developed into a subtle, persuasively personal player who studiously avoids histrionics.

title: Deaths
description: WEISSWilliam. The officers. statt Executive Board and members of the Amalgamated Ladies Garment Workers Union, Local 10 ILGWU. mourn the sudden Passing of its Assistant Manager, William Weiss. He has served his union with cornPassion, understanding and commitment for over as years. His untiring efforts in uplifting the lives of those he served. not only for his union but for those in the community, will be forever remembered. He will be missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Miriam, end cherished family. Services will be held at Perkside Me morial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave. and Ave. U. Brooklyn. N.Y., on AM.

title: Review Set on Ruling That Drew Fire for Coast Court
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11  The California Supreme Court has scheduled a re hearing in a mandatory sentencing case in which the first decision brought an investigation of the court's procedures.

title: Birds and Environs Reported Harmed By Overzealous Throngs of Watchers
description: The tremendous growth in the numbers of American bird watchers in the last 10 years has meant harm in many cases to both the birds and their habitats, according to the National Audubon Society and several independent ornithologists.

title: About a Horse Named Levi
description: CHARLES Patrick swears this is a true story. Charles Patrick is an amateur of the running horse and a pro at tennis who moonlights as the entire athletic department of Bard College in AnnandaleonHudson. Bard is a college of the liberal arts and sciences highly esteemed in academic circles for integrity. It follows that if the athletic department at Bard says a story is true, then true must be. We now turn the typewriter over to Charles Patrick:

title: Chess:
description: A true gambit brings about and thrives on situations loaded with indefinite threats that bid to become definite and unanswerable at any moment. It must thus be distinguished from a spurious gambit, like the Queen's Gambit, where nothing is sacrificed that cannot be recovered almost at once and where real speculation is absent.

title: Report on Alien Agency Expected Within Month
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today that he expected a Justice Department task force to report within a month on a study of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which is part of a major overhaul of the agency that Mr. Bell has ordered.

title: JOHN T. BUNCH
description: John T. Bunch, president of the John T. Bunch Company, marketing consultants, died Friday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 60 years old and a resident of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Three New Collections of Soft, Easy Clothes for Summer
description: Except for a growing intensity in color, the clothes are all lowkeyed. The shapes are quite simple, flowing over the body, and the fabrics soft. The tendency is to narrower lines and shorter skirts, but nobody is taking a yardstick and measuring inches from the floor.

title: Women Cite Neglect In US. job Training
description: A number of prominent women's organizations are concerned that the Labor Department is doing little to place women in traditionally maledominated, highpaying skilled trade and construction jobs.

title: Millions of Mexicans View Illegal Entry to U.S. as Door to Opportunity
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 11  The Star Wars posters and the children's growth chart still bang on the walls of the mobile home that Luis Gmez rents in a trailer park in northwest Houston. They are there, he says, just in case his wife and three young sons are able to get out of Mexico and rejoin him.

title: Folk: Cuban New Songs
description: ALTHOUGH the United States doesn't officially recognize Cuba, Cuban music has been getting more of a hearing in America of late. On Saturday night, the Center for Cuban Studies presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music a concert by Silvio Rodriguez and Pablo Milanes, leading proponents of the New Song movement.

title: Carter News Conference To Be Broadcast Today
description: President Carter will hold a news conference in the White House at 11:30 A.M. today. The three major networks and their local affiliates, Channels 2, 4 and 7, have scheduled live coverage.

title: ARMY WITHDRAWS ITS SUPPORT FOR BAKHTIAR; IRANIAN PRIME MINISTER REPORTED TO RESIGN
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb.11  The revolutionary forces of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini broke the strength of their last oppponents and apparently pushed to final victory today. Prime Minister Shahpur Bakhtiar was reported by a close aide to have resigned after the Iranian Army, which had been supporting him, called its troops back to the barracks to prevent further bloodshed and anarchy.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Murder Charge in Cocaine Death
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 11 (UPI) A seconddegree murder charge was filed today against a man suspected of injecting a friend with a fatal dose of cocaine. The police said the suspect, Randall Gourley, 26 years old, was arrested last night. The authorities allege that he injected the cocaine into the arm of Pamela Lepper, 17, on Jan. 27. She collapsed at the suspect's home, the police said, and died two days later in a hospital.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: DEATHS

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Top managers of Ford Motor decided on quietly easing out three executives held responsible for an Indonesian bribery plan. Lee A: Iacocca, former Ford president, is said to have told Federal prosecutors. [Page D1.]

title: At Lake Placid, Optimism
description: THE picturepostcard little village of Lake Placid, deep in the Adirondack Mountains, has fond memories of the Winter Olympics of 1932. Now it hopes that the memories, and the profits, will be just as Rood after the 1980 Games.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The Bache Group has established a subsidiary, Bache Puerto Rico Government Securities Inc. to handle its municipal financing activities in the commonwealth. And to head the new unit, nacre has hire Mariano Mier, the man who has spent the last two years as president of the Government Development Bank for Puerto Rico.

title: Stewart, Miss Lear In Recital
description: EVELYN LEAR and Thomas Stewart, one of the opera and concert world's more durable married couples, have worked out an unusual jointrecital format for themselves over the years. It's a showbiz approach that either appeals or does not, depending on one's receptivity to such things, and they gave it the full treatment at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. on Saturday night.

title: Joan Little Wants to Move Here
description: Joan Little, who was acquitted in the death of a jailer in 1975 and is now serving time in North Carolina prison for breaking and entering and for escaping from prison, hopes to come to New York this summer if she is paroled and work for a churchrelated youth program in Queens, according to her lawyer, William M. Kunst ler. The 24yearold woman will become eligible for parole on June 9.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Most securities and commodities markets will be open today, which has been designated as Lincoln's Birthday. However, most banks in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will be closed, along with the Government bond market. The corporate and taxexempt bond markets will be open.

title: Put Thiamine in Liquor
description: SAN DIEGO  The man wanders from ward to ward, unable to remember where he is. A sign is taped on the back of his hospital robe:

title: MARTIN SCOTT DEAD; HEADED FIRE DEPT.
description: Martin Scott, Commissioner of the New York City Fire Department from 1964 to 1966 under Mayor Robert F. Wagner and chief fire marshal for 13 years before that, died Saturday of cancer at his daughter's home in Edison, N.J. He was 81 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, Feb.13

title: Franklin The Flier
description: ONE in a while I look at the muscles in my calves, and they're like a brick! says Franklin Jacobs, whose victory in the Millrose Games high jump Friday night was his sixth in six meets this indoor season. Very powerful. And most highjumpers front thighs are very flexible. Mine is like a board. Very tight. Some jumpers do exercises to stretch that muscle. I don't bother that muscle at all.

title: Iranians Turn To Their Past
description: The following article was written by the chief correspondent of The New York Times in London, who returned last week from two months in Iran.

title: Carey TaxCut Package in Trouble, Except Aid to Elderly, Top Brackets
description: ALBANY, Feb. 10  Governor Carey's taxcut plan faces a substantial revision by the Senate and the Assembly, with key portions endangered by opposition in both bouses, according to legislators and fiscal analysts.

title: The Region
description: JERSEY CITY (UPI)  A man and a 14yearold boy have been arrested and charged in connection with a Jan. 22 fire in a a dilapidated tenement that killed two adults and five children.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: The City
description: City Councilmen Henry J. Stern and Antonio G. Olivieri urged yesterday that the auxiliary police force be strengthened as a means of increasing the visible presence of uniformed officers on city streets.

title: Britain's Dissolving Social Contract
description: After three years of remarkable success, Britain's social contract, based on cooperation between a Labor Government and the trade unions, is now fast dissolving. The transport and publicservice strikes of the past month have wrecked all hope of keeping this year's wage increases down to 5 percent, the Government's goal. In the private sector, unionized truck drivers set a target for other unions to equal or exceed when they finally accepted their employers 20 percent offer. In the public sector, some demands go as high as 40 to 50 percent. And while these claims may verge on fantasy, it is a hard reality that union members are no longer willing to restrain their demands in the name of curbing inflation.

title: Outdoors: Wading for Oysters
description: WEST TISBURY, MASS. WHEN a companion and I arrived at Tisbury Great Pond small flights of greater scaup flashed by, and six Canada geese beat against the sharp northwest breeze along the shore, well within shotgun range.

title: Light Borrowing Plans
description: A relatively light schedule of financing activity is scheduled this week.

title: Eleazar Takes Trot
description: PARIS, Feb. 11 (AP)  Eleazar unleashed a strong stretch drive today and for the second straight year captured the $106,000 Prix de Paris, the third jewel in the French triple crown of trotting. The 9yearold son of Kerjacques beat Ejackval by a neck in the 3,150meter classic at Vincennes Race Track.

title: Iran's Crisis Disrupts Trade With India
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 11  To the despair of Indian officials and traders, the political disruption in Iran has broken a prosperous commercial association that started only recently.

title: Nancy Rankin Wed To Paul B. Bennett
description: Nancy Arlene Rankin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel M. Rankin of Greensboro, N.C., and Miami, was married at noon yesterday to Paul Bruce Bennett, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ivan L. Bennett Jr. of Bronxville and Kent Cliffs, N.Y. Rabbi Julius Rosenthal performed the ceremony at the Plaza Hotel.

title: Golf: Green Sloshes To Record in Hawaii
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 11 (AP)  Hubert Green reeled off a decisive string of three consecutive birdies, then slogged through rain squalls to a threeunderpar 69 today as he won the Hawaiian open golf tournament for the second straight year.

title: Blacks Ask Meeting With Botha
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 11 (Reuters)  Leaders of six black homelands today requested an urgent meeting with Prime Minister P.W. Botha to discuss what they called a new deal and fair dispensation for all South Africans. After meeting at a hotel here, the six announced they had reached a consensus solution for the future of South Africa, but they refused to give details.

title: Capital's Mayor, Once a Radical, Steers Toward Center of Power
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11  When he was sworn in last month as Mayor of the District of Columbia, Marion Barry Jr. was the first radical black leader of the 1960's civil rights movement to become the top elected official of a major American city.

title: Rape Case Dismissed on Ground Couple in Connecticut Cohabited
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 11 (AP) A judge has acquitted a 33yearold Bridgeport man of a charge of raping a 24yearold woman with whom he had lived on the ground that state law allows any sexual behavior between two cohabitating persons.

title: The Coldest Day Since Chilly '77 Grips New York
description: The metropolitan area suffered its coldest temperatures in two years yesterday when the mercury fell to 3 degrees in Central Park at 7:10 A.M.

title: A Chronology of Major Events in Iranian Turmoil
description: Following is a chronology of some of the major events that led to the departure of the Shah from Iran and the apparent fall of the Government appointed to rule in his absence:

title: Booms Heard Again, and Scientist Is Sure They're Sonic
description: For the second time within 48 hours, explosive booms along the East Coast from Massachusetts to Pennsylvania rattled windows and prompted telephone calls to police stations Saturday night.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Tennis Practice by Computer

title: Chinese Dance Company Of New York in Concert
description: THE Chinese Dance Company of New York has been performing since 1971. But its Saturday night concert at the Fashion Institute of Technology was something special. For the concert was the first event in a new year of expanded activities for the company.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets, which did a flipflop last week and lost the optimism they had built up in January, this week again face a relatively manageable amount of new financing. As last week proved, however, a moderate financing schedule is no assurance that bond prices will not fall.

title: Boston Paper Names Editor
description: BOSTON (AP)  James T. Dorris, publisher of The Boston Herald American, announced yesterday that he had appointed Don Forst as editor of the morning newspaper. Mr. Forst, 46 years old, has been executive editor of The Los Angeles HeraldExaminer since January 1978. He succeeds William McIlwain. who resigned to become deputy editor of The Washington Star. Mr. Forst was assistant city editor and financial editor of The New York Post, national editor and executive news editor at the defunct New York Herald Tribune, assistant metropolitan editor and culture editor of The New York Times and a managing editor at Newsday.

title: SUPPORT OF BISHOPS FOR ACTIVISM IS SEEN
description: PUEBLA, Mexico. Feb.11 The Latin American Bishops Conference will take a centrist position that will encompass, although not encourage, almost all current political thoughts and actions by clergy, advance documents obtained here indicate.

title: Commodities
description: The dramatic advances in prices of metals futures last week did far more than carry gold, silver, platinum and copper to record levels. It also exerted powerful upward pressures on all basic commodity prices.

title: 4 Killed in Colorado Plane Crash
description: DENVER, Feb. 11 (AP)  All four persons aboard a small private plane died yesterday after it crashed into a field near Denver, the authorities reported. Douglas County's coroner, John Andrews, said the names of the victims were being withheld pending notification of relatives.

title: Jazz: Jimmy Owens . . . Plus
description: JIMMY OWENS, the trumpeter and fluegelhornist whose appearances in New York are usually in the role of a sideman rather than as a leader. slaved five concerts over the weekend with his own quartet, Jimmy Owens ... Plus, at Black Beans Studio, 132 West 24th Street, a small, streetlevel hall that has just been opened by two Brazilian percussionists, Dom Urn Romao and Marcio A. Ferreira.

title: A Rich and a Poor District React to Carey School Plan
description: LAWRENCE, L.I.  There are visible signs of the financial strength of the school district in this Nassau County community just three miles from Kennedy International Airport.

title: India's Foreign Minister Leaves on Visit to Peking
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 11  Foreign Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee left today for China on the first visit to Peking by an Indian Government official in nearly 20 years.

title: Thousands Flee Prison Amid the Chaos in Teheran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 11 (UPI)About 11,000 Iranian political prisoners and common criminals and a handful of Americans and Europeans escaped from Iran's largest prison today at the height of the chaos in Teheran.

title: 103d Westminster Opens for 2 Days
description: A total of 3,154 dogs representing 135 breeds or varieties, the largest entry since the show was first staged in 1877, are scheduled to show off their fine points today and tomorrow in the 103d annual Westminster Kennel Club show at Madison Square Garden.

title: Election Laws Raise Problem For Strategists
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11  The quadrennial battle over how to change New York's welter of Presidential election laws is about to begin.

title: U.C.L.A. Beats Notre Dame
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 11 Tyren Wendell Naulls, a freshman at the University of California, Los Angeles, hit four straight foul shots in the last 13 seconds to assure the Bruins of a 5652 victory over Notre Dame today.

title: Wide Abuses Reported In Ads by Professionals
description: Divorce from $100. Try chiropracticit works! Dental care at astonishingly law cost!

title: Historic Flatbush Church Celebrates 325th Anniversary
description: Bathed in diffused light from original Tiffany windows, parishioners of the Reformed Protestant Dutch Church of Flatbush  described as the oldest continuous church site in the New World  celebrated its 325th anniversary yesterday. President Carter sent a congratulatory letter and Mayor Koch attended service and anniversary buffet for the community.

title: Benjy McDee Picked
description: NEWARK, Feb. 11  A blackandtan Gordon setter, Ch. BenWen's Benjy McDee, today was awarded bestofbreed honors at the 20th annual apecialty show of the Gorden Setter Club of America.

title: H.E.W. Program Collected Billion From Missing Fathers Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP)  The Government's Child Support Enforcement Program collected more than $1 billion from missing fathers in the fiscal year 1978 and enabled 19,000 families to get off the welfare rolls, the Health, Education and Welfare Department announced today.

title: OPEC Aid Steady at $5.5 Billion
description: OPEC aid to developing countries held steady at about $5.5 billion from 1975 through 1977, more than 2 percent of the gross national product of the oilproducing countries. This is a far greater proportion than the 31 onehundredths of 1 percent of output given in foreign aid by the industrialized nations.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Titl
description: Deaths

title: Jubilation, Anarchy and Sadness Mix as Teheran Erupts in Frenzy
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 11Frenzied scenes of jubilation, anarchy and sadness engulfed Teheran today as millions of Iranians poured into the streets to witness the violent climax of a yearlong revolution  the revolution that appeared to have ended tonight with the victory of the Islamic forces of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: North Koreans Piloting for Libya
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11  More than 100 North Korean pilots are in Libya flying advanced, Sovietbuilt fighters, American intelligence aides have disclosed.

title: Bridge:
description: The bridge population is rather like an iceberg  a small percentage in full view above the surface and the vast majority hidden out of sight. Some of the submerged players are happy to play the game socially with their neighbors and have no wish to compete in clubs or tournaments, but many who would like to play do not do so because they have no bridgeplaying friends and are nervous about venturing into the world of organized bridge.

title: 2 Former Aides  Called Heirs To Barnes's Heroin Empire
description: Two lieutenants in the narcoticstrafficking organization once headed by Leroy (Nicky) Barnes have emerged as New York's chief dealers in illegal heroin, according to Federal and city law enforcement officials.

title: Japan to Reduce Costs Of Foreign Stock Listing
description: TOKYO, Feb. 11  The Tokyo Stock Exchange is trying to discourage an exodus of foreign companies listed here by cutting listing costs and easing other requirements. The steep initial listing fees and annual assessments will be slashed by roughly 50 percent, effective March 1, pending final approval by the Ministry of Finance.

title: Advertising
description: AFTER a decade of more or less behindthescenes promotion for The New Yorker, Whit Hobbs goes public today as a radio interviewer of contented advertisers who have used the magazine. That makes two things that are news: Whit Hobbs on radio and the magazine's return to radio advertising just in time for its 54th anniversary. Hi there, Eustace Tilley.

title: Iranian Junior Diplomats Declare They Have Taken Over Embassy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI)  A group of Iranians describing themselves as junior diplomats said today they had taken over the Iranian Embassy in the name of Ayotollah Rubollah Khomeini's Islamic republic.

title: Israelis and Egyptians Going to Camp David For Talks This Month
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11  United States officials said today that Egypt and Israel had agreed formally to make a fresh effort to complete the drawnout negotiations for a peace treaty. The talks, at the ministerial level, will begin at Camp David about Feb. 21.

title: Inflation and Fair Taxation
description: Foreign governments beset by inflation have frequently turned to a palliative: indexing. Wages, interest rates, taxes, asset values are automatically adjusted for inflation. When the price indexes rise, wages may follow proportionately. With indexing, politicians hope to minimize the pain and economic disturbances that are caused by inflation. Some even argue, without convincing proof so far, that total indexation can speed the end of inflation. Only a few nations, like Brazil, have tried to index virtually their entire economies. Others, like Canada, Israel and some Western European countries, have settled for less comprehensive indexing.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON THE next tangible evidence of the continuing effort of the White House to clean up the regulatory tangle is expected to appear in early March when a proposed Regulatory Reform Act is sent to Capitol Hill. An interagency task force is at work refining the various proposals. Although some interesting ideas seem likely to emerge, other, more ambitious attempts to reform regulation are not likely to be included.

title: Events
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA. Licoin Center, Verdi's Don Carlo, 7:15.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Tennis: Borg Beats Connors
description: BOCA RATON, Fla. Feb. 11  Bjorn Borg was at his majestic best today, playing tennis with such consummate finesse that Jimmy Connors hardly seemed qualified to be on the same court.

title: Executone Favors Terms
