description: Directors of Executone Inc. have approved the terms of the proposed acquisition of their company by the Continental Telephone Corporation, which is to exchange 1.2 shares of Continental common for each share of Executone common.

title: Sports Briefs
description: ARE, Sweden, Feb. 11 (UPI)  Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden won his second slalom of the season today in a time of 1 minute 35.77 seconds and once again edged out Phil Mahre in the last World Cup race of the European season.

title: Supplementary OvertheCounter Listings
description: Week Ended Feb. 9, 1979

title: Law Firms Expand as Atlanta Flourishes
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 11  There is a vacant office with one of the best views of the city on the southeast corner of the 29th floor of the Trust Company of Georgia Tower. It belongs to Griffin B. Bell. the Attorney General, and the partners at King & Spalding, mixing deference with irreverence, call it the shrine.

title: World News Briefs
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 11 (AP)  A black leader of Rhodesia's biracial transition Government called today for the creation of a new army that would include nationalist guerrillas now fighting the regime.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Though followers of the football Giants don't know whether to laugh, cry or just give up, there can be no question that the confusion surrounding the team's operation has had elements of comedy that are right out of the Three Stooges. Littleknown example:

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BENVENUTO It's celebration time for the 20th consecutive year at Mama Leone's. Starting tonight, the pink stucco facade of the popular restaurant in the theater district will be adorned With multicolored lights heralding the preLenten fiesta inside, at 239 West 48th Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue. For 16 evenings, an assembly of singers, dancers, clowns and magicians will throng the various dining rooms as an entertainent bonus for patrons, serving up a potpourri of operatic arias, pop and country tunes and specialty acts.

title: Stage: They're Playing Our Song, Presented
description: NEIL SIMON'S book for the musical They're Playing Our Song is suspended from four standing jokes. It is about the emotional difficulties two song writers  a lyricist and a composerfind in loving each other, and it is very heavy. Pretty soon the standing jokes begin to buckle and before long they have collapsed altogether.

title: Court Blocks Offer by Tiger
description: A Federal judge has moved to block Tiger International inc. from effecting its tender offer for 638,000 shares of Seaboard World Airlines Inc., another big airfreight carrier. The shares would have raised Tiger's holdings in Seaboard to 25 percent.

title: Two NBC Newsmen, Murdered in Guyana, Receive Polk Awards
description: Don Harris and Bob Brown, the NBC newsmen murdered last year while covering the People's Temple cult in Guayana, were among the winners of 16 George Polk Memorial Awards announced yesterday by Long Island University.

title: Inquiry Expands On Relief Fraud In City Program
description: City, state and Federal prosecutors are investigating charges of fraud and corruption in the city's antipoverty programs with an eye toward initiating criminal prosecutions, Haskell G. Ward, the Deputy Mayor for Human Services, said yesterday.

title: Skating: For Heiden, A 7th World Crown
description: OSLO, Feb. 11 (AP)  More convincing than ever, Eric Heiden of the United States captured his seventh world championship title in speed skating in three years today by winning all four races at Oslo's Olympic Bislet Stadium.

title: Welsh Gains Terrier Honors
description: Ch. Copperboots Wee Blaste, a 3yearold Californiabred Welsh bitch who has gained 19 bestinshow awards in less than a year of competition, continued to impress the fudges as she went best of breed yesterday in the Associated Terrier Club Show at the 102d Engineers Armory in Manhattan.

title: Boxing: Leonard Stops Marcotte in 8
description: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 11 (UPI) Sugar Ray Leonard used his quickness and a consistent left jab to score a knockout over Fernand Marcotte, the Canadian middleweight champion, in the eighth round of a scheduled 10round bout at the Miami Beach Convention Center today.

title: Westernized Iranians Nervous About Islamic Rule
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 11I suppose the country will tighten up religiously and change in many ways, said All Naficy, a young Westernized businessman from a welltodo Moslem family, about Iran's future, as Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Islamic revolutionaries moved closer to power.

title: Text of Ayatollah's Statement
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 11 (AP)  Following is the text of a statement by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, read over television and translated into English by aides to the Ayatollah:

title: Letter: On the Letelier Murder
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M.'s Environmental Chief
description: Betsy AnckerJohnson, who will become General Motors first female vice president on Friday, and thus its highestranking woman, does not consider herself a symbol. I didn't know that until after I accepted the job, she said, but it's high time fora first.

title: Record Number of Aliens Caught Crossing Into U.S. From Mexico
description: SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 11 (UPI) Record numbers of Mexicans and Central Americans crossed the Rio Grande last month seeking jobs.

title: Uncle Is Accused of Killing Infant
description: A 17yearold Bronx youth who reportedly spent 16 years being shunted from one foster home to another was charged yesterday with beating his 7monthold nephew to death just three days after the baby's father had given the teenager a family home.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: NORMAN F. ARTERBURN

title: Deaths
description: WEISBERGMark M.. beloved husband of Edna, devoted father of Beverly Rudnick and William. Loving brother of Louis and Betty Notick. adored grandfather and great. grandfather. Services Tuesday, PM, Parkside Chapels, Queens Blvd. and 66 Ave., Forest Hills.

title: Thais Attack Guerrilla Camps
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 11 (Reuters)  Thai Government forces launched air and ground attacks against Communist guerrilla camps in southern Thailand and reported killing 50 insurgents, military officials said today.

title: The New Breed of Helicopters
description: STRATFORD, Conn.,  Helicopters are revving up for a long hop as a new generation of choppers is seeking to break into the lucrative market for small corporate planes.

title: Knicks Send McAdoo To Celtics for 3 Picks
description: The Knicks traded Bob McAdoo to the Celtics early yesterday morning, apparently sacrificing the rest of this season and gambling on the future by acquiring three 1979 firstround draft choices from Boston.

title: Clemency Pleas Criticized
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 11 Members of the family of the man killed in the 1974 political murder for which Mr. Bhutto is under sentence of death replied sharply today to pleas for clemency by world leaders for the onetime Prime Minister.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: What is the origin of the seventhinning stretch in baseball? Also, do rooters for a visiting team stand at the top of the seventh or the bottom?

title: Market Place
description: THE old antitrust exemption that permits a strong company to buy a weak competitor seems to be working in reverse in the current efforts to take over National Airlines.

title: Congress Again Trying to Solve Federal Lands Dispute in Alaska
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 Another attempt to resolve the dispute on the use of vast tracts of Federal lands in Alaska started last week in the House Interior Committee.

title: Northport High School Students Visit Their Ottawa Counterparts
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 9  Ten high school students from Northport, L.I., who may know more about Canada than most other Americans have just added to their knowledge after a week of close observation of the Canadian capital and its inhabitants.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: OGONGO, SouthWest Africa  The young intelligence officer, Lieut. Angus Ramsay of Pretoria, pointed at an area of the map just below the Angolan border.

title: Exxon Nominates 3 to Its Board
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, has three new names on management's slate for election to the company's board of directors on May 17.

title: Yemen, Sudan to Get Added Arms
description: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 11 Secretary of Defense Harold Brown told Saudi Arabian leaders today that the United States planned to increase sharply arms supplies to Yemen and the Sudan.

title: Notes on People
description: James Cagney interviews are about as rare these days as James Cagney movies (the last film was One, Two, Three in 1961). So whenever the 79yearold actor has something to say, the occasion is an event, and this one will be spread across four days, starting tomorrow, on the Good Morning America television program.

title: Theater: Sarava, a Musical Version of Dona Flor
description: SARAVA has character. It is an elusive character, a cheerful, wandering character; not very substantial and not in the least pretentious. Its inherent form is to have no particular form; to Msplay some very lovely things, others that are simply pleasant, and others that are quite flat; but without forcing any of them.

title: Notre Dame's Magic Weekend
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 11 The Notre Dame band was shaking down the thunder from the sky for the sixth time last night when Tim Andree joined hundreds of students in the rhythmic clapping. By now a big smile was spreading across the face of the 6foot10inch high school senior from Detroit.

title: Columbia's Anglican Cousin Sends a Bill for $460 Million
description: Whether they admit it or not, college presidents know that their most important task is raising money.

title: Union Lettuce Worker Shot Dead In Clash With Nonstriking Pickers
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11  A striking member of the United Farm Workers of America was shot to death yesterday in a riotous clash between strikers and nonstrikers in the Imperial Valley of California.

title: Governor Ends Alabama's Rift With Judge
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala. Feb. 9  When Gov. Forrest H. James Jr. slipped off last week for a secret discussion of this state's junglelike prisons with Federal District Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr., Mr. James traveled only six blocks from the Capitol to the Federal Courthouse.

title: Winter Sports: U.S. Revolution Aimed at 1980
description: LAKE PLACID. N.Y.

title: Iran Faces Major Economic Difficulties
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 11  On Aug. 3, 1974, at a meeting in Rarnsar, a town on the Caspian Sea, Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, in a typically extravagant gesture, doubled the targets for Iran's new fiveyear economic development plan with a stroke of his pen.

title: Weekly Lotto Numbers Drawn
description: The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly Lotto drawing were 25, 23, 20, 26, 1 and 21. The supplementary number was 5.

title: Backers of Khomeini Take Control of Embassy in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  Supporters of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini took control of the Iranian Embassy here yesterday, and the former deputy chief of missiton said he was in charge but awaiting instructions from Teheran.

title: Giants Talk to Rhome on Coaching Job
description: Darryl Rogers, Dan Reeves and Jerry Rhome emerged as the leading candidates to become head coach of the Giants whenever the Maras stop feuding and agree on a choice as director of operations, which Commissioner Pete Rozelle apparently thinks can still happen.

title: McAdoo Frets Over Family, Back Pay
description: There is the house in Ramsey, N.I. that Bob McAdoo bought two years ago, after he had been traded to the Knicks. There is a wife in her final semester of law school, hoping to find a job in the metropolitan area. There are two children, both in kindergarten and starting to make friends.

title: Dr. Harry G. Jacobi, 81, ExChief Of the Lenox Hill Diabetes Clinic
description: Dr. Harry G. Jacobi, a consulting physician to Lenox Hill Hospital who specialized in diabetes, died Saturday in a nursing home in Denver after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: Sports Today
description: Nets vs. Kansas City Kings. at Piscataway. N.J., 8 P.M. (RadioWVNJ, 8 P. M.)

title: Efforts to Free Ship Continue
description: CONNEAUT, Ohio, Feb. 12 (AP)  The United States Coast Guard cutter Westwind is continuing her efforts to free the Roger Blough, an iron ore and taconite carrier, stuck in the thick ice of Lake Erie's Conneaut Harbor. The Coast Guard said that the Roger Blough, bound from Minnesota with a full load, became stuck in the ice Saturday. It said that the Westwind, an icebreaker, reached Conneaut Harbor early Sunday and began its efforts to dislodge the freighter.

title: Roasters Cut Coffee Prices
description: Major coffee roasters cut wholesale prices on ground coffee by 5 cents a pound yesterday to $2.48, in a move that should reach supermarket shelves within a month.

title: 20 at Bishops' Meeting in Mexico Back Two Embattled Colleagues
description: PUEBLA, Mexico, Feb. 12  A group of 20 Latin American bishops issued statements tonight supporting the actions of colleagues in striferidden Nicaragua and El Salvador.

title: Mayas' Fall Linked To Decline of Elite
description: Two American scientists have produced evidence that the longmysterious collapse of the classic Maya civilization of Central America took place without any great decline in population.

title: Secretary of Defense Is Accused Of Rash Weapons Offer to Yemen
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP)  Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal has accused the Secretary of Defense, Harold Brown, of trying to boxin the Congress with a public offer to sell warplanes, tanks and other weapons to Yemen.

title: U.S. LINKS TO SAUDIS TAKING A NEW TURN
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 12  Secretary of Defense Harold Brown said today that United States relations with Saudi Arabia had now taken a new military and econimic turn as a result of the chaos in Iran.

title: Automakers and U.A.W. Initiate LowCost, Prepaid Health Plan
description: DEARBORN, Mich. Feb. 12  The country's three biggest automobile manufacturers and the United Automobile Workers have established a new prepaid health care plan designed to combat the medical inefficiencies that get much of the blame for rising medical costs.

title: U.N. Aide and Lebanese Meet on Southern Zone
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 12  Lebanese leaders urged the United Nations today to try to obtain the cooperation of Israel in a program to restore Lebanese authority in the southern border zone.

title: 2 Killed as Plane Flips on Takeoff in West Virginia
description: BRIDGEPORT, W.Va., Feb.12(AP) A passenger and crew member were killed today when a twinengine Allegheny Airlines propjet plane with 25 persons aboard flipped over and crashed while taking off from an airport here.

title: Justice Dept. Will Center Control Of Illegal Wildlife and Plant Trade
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP)  The Justice Department announced today an effort to centralize attempts to control illegal trade in wildlife and plants, a business estimated at millions of dollars annually.

title: Young Says Students From Iran Sparked Revolt With U.S. Ideals
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP)  Andrew Young said today that the Iranian revolution was brought about largely by thousands of Iranians who learned about democratic processes as students in the United States, then applied their new perceptions in Iran.

title: Steel Output Up in Week
description: Steel production in the week ended Feb. 10 rose to 2.65 million tons, up eighttenths of 1 percent from the 2.63 million tons produced a week earlier, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Fog on Coast Closes Airport
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 12 (UPI)  Los Angeles International Airport opened about 9 A.M. today after being closed for the fifth night by heavy coastal fog. Flights were curtailed late yesterday and all operations were halted shortly before 5 A.M. Commercial flights heading to Los Angeles were diverted other airports.

title: Boston University Wins Beanpot Hockey by 43
description: BOSTON, Feb. 12  Daryl MacLeod scored the winning goal in the third period tonight as Boston University defeated Boston College, 43, in the title game of the 27th annual Beanpot hockey tournament before a crowd of 14,456 at Boston Garden.

title: Time Is Eroding Harbor Fishing Fleet
description: As dawn approaches over the black waters of Mill Basin in Brooklyn, Capt Jimmy Marinello steers his 68foot boat, the Hunter. out to sea for another day of fishing. And while hundreds of others along the East Coast do the same, Captain MarineHo pilots one of the few boats remaining in New York City's small commercial fishing industry.

title: Vagrant Found Raped and Slain Off E. 42d Street
description: A shopping bag lady who apparently roamed New York's streets as a vagrant despite having thousands of dollars in savings was found slain early yesterday in an entrance to the Grand Central subway station on East 42d Street.

title: Opera: A New Nathan the Wise
description: ATHAN THE WISE is not now just the name of the bestknown drama of the German Enlightenment. Golden Fleece Ltd., a chamber opera company, ended last night a series of premiere performances of an opera of the same name based on Gotthold Lessing's play by Sam Raphling, a 68yearold composer from Fort Worth with eight oneact operas to his credit. The performances took place at the Drama Ensemble Space, 108 Wooster Street; this reviewer saw the opera Sunday afternoon.

title: Reporters' Hotel Is Attacked
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 12 Several hundred reporters who are covering the revolution in Iran were the target of two assaults today when the InterContinental Hotel, where they are staying, came under fire.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 12  A group of 68 Soviet Jews from eight cities appealed today to the United States Congress not to change legislation that bars favorable trade terms for Moscow because of its restrictions on emigration.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: MIAMI, Feb. 12 (AP)  Eastern Air Lines, seeking a better footing against a bidding rival, proposed new merger terms today that it said could bring National Airlines stockholders a price of $50 a share regardless of whether Eastern or Pan American World Airways got Federal approval for the merger.

title: I.R.S. Says Xerox May Owe More Tax
description: The Xerox Corporation said it had received a proposed additional tax liability of $88 million for 1972 and 1973 from the Internal Revenue Service. Xerox declared it would vigorously contest the proposed tax liability.

title: Ben Ticknor, Named AllAmerica Center And Hall of Famer
description: Ben Ticknor, an allAmerica center at Harvard and a member of the College Football Hall of Fame, died yesterday of cancer at a hospital near his home in Dublin, N.H. He was 70 years old.

title: The Inevitable in Iran
description: It ended up taking only three months for events in Iran to go from the unthinkable to the inevitable. In November, the Shah of Iran could still magnanimously proclaim to the demonstrators, Your revolutionary message has been heard. By midJanuary, the message was coming across in stereo; the Shah began his winter vacation. Now, the revolutionaries are the winners, and now, from an American perspective, the outlook is not necessarily either unthinkable or inevitable. But it is dangerous.

title: Price Council To Ease Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  The Council on Wage and Price Stability said tonight that it was liberalizing its price standard for wholesalers and retailers. Barry P. Bosworth, director, said the change would chiefly affect general merchandisers, such as department stores.

title: Music: Wheelock Students Play Wheelock
description: COMPOSERS, unless they are well known and well connected, do not often write orchestral works for the simple reason that the chances of performance are slim. Donald Wheelock, an associate professor of music at Smith College, decided to take a drastic, even heroic, step to remedy this situation with regard to three recent orchestral compositions of his own.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Easing of Exports to Be Sought On Alligator and Bobcat Skins
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) Federal officials decided today to ask an international convention on endangered species to allow limited export of alligator skins for the first time in 10 years and to ease restrictions on the export of bobcat pelts.

title: 15 Die in Bus Wreck in India
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 12 (AP)  At least 15 people were killed yesterday when bus plunged into a pond in Assam, in eastern India, United News of India reported today.

title: Arctic Air Continues to Chill Northeast, the Coldest Area in U.S.
description: An Arctic air mass remained over the Northeast yesterday, making it the coldest region in the nation. In the metropolitan area, snow began falling in the afternoon after the overnight temperatures reached single digits for the fourth straight night, reaching a low of 5 degrees in Central Park at 2:45 yesterday morning.

title: Bhutto Case Is Protested By Pakistanis in Russia
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 12 (Reuters)  Pakistani students demonstrated outside their embassy here today, apparently with Soviet approval, against the death sentence imposed on former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto.

title: Tito Returns for Aide's Funeral
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 12 (Reuters)  President Tito cut his tour of the Middle East two days short when he returned today for the funeral of his closest aide, Edvard Kardelj. Mr. Kardelj, 69 years old, had been the chief theoretician of Yugoslavia's Government. His state funeral was scheduled tomorrow. Diplomatic sources said that the scant reports in the Moscow press of Mr. Kardelj's death reflected Soviet displeasure with the aide's role in Belgrade's separation from the Kremlin's influence since 1948.

title: All 59 Die on Rhodesia Airliner Shot Down by Missile
description: UMTALI, Rhodesia, Feb. 12  An Air Rhodesia plane that military sources said had been hit by a missile fired by guerrilla forces crashed and burned shortly after takeoff from the resort town of Kariba today. All 59 people aboard were killed.

title: Bar Association Again Backs Ban On Television and Radio in Court
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 12  The American Bar Association's House of Delegates voted today against relaxing the organization's opposition to television and radio coverage of trials and other judicial proceedings.

title: Police Pinpoint Crime Suspects With Computer
description: The murder had occurred shortly before midnight at a social club in the South Bronx. Two men who had been annoying women patrons were being ejected by the bouncer. Suddenly one of the men pulled a gun and fatally shot the bouncer.

title: Valukevich Sets Record
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 12 (AP)  A 20yearold Soviet student, Gennady Valukevich, set a world indoor record for the triple jump today by jumping 56 feet 8 inches during the Soviet indoor track and field championships in Minsk.

title: Letters
description: TO SCIENCE TIMES:

title: Deaths
description: CHEPNICOFF  Beatrice Beloved wife of the late Ben, devoted moth of Irving and Lucille Cherne. Dear sister of Henry and Normen Butler grandmother of Mitchell and Loving grand mother of Mitchell and Shari Cherne and Arden and Avrorn Messing. Services today 11:30 AM Park side Chapels. Queens Blvd at to Ave Forest Hills.

title: Jurgy Hanover Captures $54,000 Su Mac Lad Final
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 12  Jurgy Hanover closed with his customary rush in the stretch tonight and won the $54,000 final of the Su Mac Lad trotting series as snow fell at the Mead owlands.

title: Recital: Canadian Wind Quintet
description: THE YORK WINDS, heard Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is a Canadian wind quintet based at York University in Toronto. From the youthful appearance of its members  they are Douglas Stewart, flutist; Lawrence Cherney, oboist; Paul Grice, clarinetist Harcus Hennigar, horn player, and Gerald Robinson, bassoonist  it hardly seems possible that the group is in its seventh year, but that's what the program said.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: When Jorge Daz Serrano was appointed director general of Pemex, Mexico's national oil monopoly, the Mexicans had just 6 billion barrels of proven oil and gas reserves. Today, their combined reserves stand at more than 40 billion and are rising fast. To many observers, that heroic show of oil strength is due in no small way to the faith, resolve and competence of Mr. Daz Serrano. I want to prove that we have sufficient reserves, he once told a reporter, so that even the most conservative and antagonistic will realize that it's absurd not to use them.

title: Yea, Team! Nay, Capitalists
description: Call it a found weekend. Some basketball and hockey people have seen the light. The Knicks obtained three firstround choices in the June draft and probably Tom Barker, a reserve centerforward, from the Boston Celtics in exchange for Bob McAdoo; the National Hockey League AllStars promised to look at our game after having been embarrassed, 60, by the Soviet national team in the decisive third game of the Challenge Cup series. The same lesson emerged for both the Knicks and the N.H.L.  that a new philosophy must be developed, that in a team game, a team concept must be maintained or the team disintegrates. Surely the Knicks were disintegrating toward the Atlantic Division cellar in the National Basketball Association despite Bob McAdoo's 26point aver age. Surely the N.H.L. AilStars disintegrated over most of the last five periods of the Challenge Cup series as the Soviet speed skaters not only outscored them, 90, in that span, but also prevented them from organizing clean shots.

title: Economic and Political Concerns Could Slow Tide of Mexican Oil
description: VILLAHERMOSA, Mexico  When reports spread two years ago that Mexico had made a staggering oil discovery in its southeastern states of Tabasco, Chiapas and Campeche, American oil circles were openly skeptical. Mexico was in serious economic straits at the time, and some suggested that the Mexicans were floating overblown estimates to improve their standing in the international financing markets.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Venezuela's Oil Output Up
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 12 (UPI)  Venezuela's crude oil production through Feb. 7 this year has averaged about 2.3 million barrels a day, the Ministry of Energy and Mines said. The figure represented an increase in production of 554,447 barrels a day, or about 32.8 percent, compared with output in the comparable period last year, the ministry said.

title: Queen Opens Tour of 6 Arabian States
description: LONDON. Feb. 12  Queen Elizabeth H flew to Kuwait today on the first leg of a threeweek trip to six states on the Arabian Peninsula whose political and economic equilibrium has been deeply shaken by the upheaval in neighboring Iran.

title: On the Waterfront
description: New York can only envy, not emulate, the announcement of a major rebuilding project for Boston's historic Charlestown Navy Yard. With the exception a small enclave at the South Street Seaport, New York has destroyed almost all of its 19thcentury waterfront buildings for wrongheaded renewal and streetwidening. This latest undertaking of Boston's astute planners calls for a large residential and commercial complex be housed in handsome granite buildings once devoted to shipbuilding and ropemaking, using $200 million in Federal and city contributions plus funds from foreign investors.

title: Finley Picks Jim Marshall To Manage Oakland A's
description: CHICAGO. Feb. 12 (AP)  For Jim Marshall, it's now just a 10block stroll from his home in Scottsdale, Ariz., to the Oakland A's training camp and a new managing job in the major leagues. The team finished next to last in the American League West last year.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Market Place
description: MOST retail bond customers are not aware that supply and demand factors are nearly as important as credit quality in determining prices in the muncipal bond market. As a result, it is sometimes possible to buy bonds that are undervalued. and thus offer superior yields.

title: CARTER IS CRITICIZED BY BACKERS IN IOWA
description: DES MOINES, Feb. 11  President Carter's chief political operative, Tim Kraft, flew out to Iowa a few days ago for a secret meeting to start laying the groundwork for a Carter effort in next year's precinct caucuses, and ran into a series of complaints about the Administration from early Carter supporters.

title: Lawyers Review Evidence at Letelier Murder Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  Lawyers for the prosecution and the defense summarized for the jury today the evidence presented in the monthlong trial of three Cuban exiles charged in connection with the murder of Orlando Letelier, the former Chilean diplomat.

title: 300 at a Hearing by P.S.C. Oppose New Power Line Into Westchester
description: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Feb. 9  A proposal by the Consolidated Edison Company to build a high voltage overhead transmission line through northern Westchester County has drawn strong opposition from residents of the area, who contend that the line would destroy their environment, their property values and the way they live.

title: KHOMEININI'S FORCES RULE IRAN; HE URGES AN END TO VIOLENCE; U. S. CONSULTING WITH REGIME
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 12  Armed supporters of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini seized the last centers of military resistance to the Iranian revolution here today, and with anarchy appearing to engulf much of the capital, he appealed for an end to the violence in a bid to prevent the uprising from slipping out of control.

title: Tiant, 38, Is Grateful and Ready to Serve Yankees
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 12  Peace, tranquillity and general good will ran rampant today as the New York Yankees opened an eightday early camp designed primarily for their top young prospects.

title: A Novel Windmill Challenges U.S. Policy on Wind Energy
description: THE bulbous device bears no resemblance to ornaments on Dutch landscapes or to the forlorn period pieces in W.P.A. photographic studies of the 30's. Least of all does it look like, perform like or reflect the priorities of the Federal Government's bigthinking efforts to harness the wind as a littletapped energy source.

title: West German Boom In Home Building
description: BONN, Feb. 12  Werner Gossling's new house on the outskirts of Bonn cost him the equivalent of $151,000, about double what the Americantrained economic analyst thinks a similar housein the United States would cost.

title: Lucie Arnaz the Morning After Opening Night
description: IT was the Morning after the night before, and Lucie Arnaz was happy; not just pleased, but immoderately, injudiciously happy. Actually, she said, she couldn't remember much in any sequential way; she said too much had happened for that. I only know, she said reverentially, it was the most romantic evening of my life.

title: Iran's Elite Army Guard Was Routed by Civilians
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 12  Iran's elite Imperial Guard suffered a stunning defeat at the hands of a mob of poorly armed civilians during 48 hours of savage Lighting that apparently led to the fall of the Government appointed by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

title: Appeals Court Rules ExG.I. Can Sue U.S. On Atom Risk Notice
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 (AP)  An appeals court says the Federal Government can be sued in an effort to force officials to notify servicemen of possible medical risks resulting from their exposure to a nuclear bomb test in 1953.

title: Conrail Cuts Loss
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation. the Governmentsponsored freight railroad serving the Northeast, reported yesterday that it had narrowed its loss to $60 million in the fourth quarter of 1978 from $76.8 million in the corresponding period of 1977.

title: Bank Loan Set For Venezuela
description: Banco Nacional de Ahorra y Pres tamo of Caracas, Venezuela, announced yesterday that it had signed a $300 million loan agreement with a group of 12 banks led by the Bank of America.

title: Music: Cole Porter Remembered
description: THE attempt to change the focus of the Lyrics and Lyricists series, which has been running for eight years at the 92d Street Young Men'sYoung Women's Hebrew Association, from living lyricists who are present discuss. ing their work to great lyricists who are no longer with us is proving difficult. An Evening With the Lyrics of Cole Porter, presented on Sunday and again last night, provided little insight into Porter as a lyricist and projected surprisingly little of the flavor of his songs.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: About Education
description: WHEN art teacher Gary Gaccione at the Jacob Gunther Elementary School in North Bellmore, L.I. announced auditions for the biannual play, the entire fifth and sixth grades showed up. All 98 of the youngsters wanted to be in the show.

title: Officials Debate Financial Ability Of City to Play Biggest Landlord
description: United States Representative S. William Green, Republican of Manhattan, said yesterday that more Federal money should go to New York City's program of taking over taxdelinquent buildings, if the program restores housing at reasonable costs.

title: Scare Talk About Welfare Reform
description: Last November, researchers delivered to a Congressional committee the disquieting news that guaranteed incomes may precipitate family breakups and dissuade recipients from working. Their findings were quickly seized upon by the Congressional foes of welfare as justification for scuttling even the modest reforms of the system proposed by the Carter Administration. In fact, the results of the studies have been misunderstood and misused.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. IN) indi cates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(AI the American Stock Exchange and (0) werthecounter.

title: Minority Candidates for Bench Rate Highly, Bell Says
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 12  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell sought to assure lawyers today that there was no need to despair over efforts by the Carter Administration to give deference to women and members of minority groups in filling vacancies on Federal trial and appellate courts.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: GERALD LANKESTER HARDING

title: ALBANY APPROVES MAJOR TRANSIT AID FOR NEW YORK AREA
description: ALBANY, Feb. 12  A bill that would provide the New York metropolitan area with $805 million in state and Federal masstransportation assistance, including $725 million for extensive subway rehabilitation and 500 new buses in the city, was approved tonight by both houses of the Legislature.

title: Stage: AvantGardists From Poland at La Mama
description: IF it is difficult in the contemporary world to define what it means to be a human being, that difficulty is bound to be reflected in the theater, whose business it is to make us believe that those bodies moving around on the stage are human. You cannot tell people to believe in spinach unless you tell them what spinach is.

title: McAdoo Gone, Knicks Set to Rebuild
description: The Knicks are no longer starstruck.

title: A New U.S. Attitude on Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  No more than six weeks ago, the possibility that Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini would' seize power in Iran struck most American officials as the worst possible out come of the Iranian upheaval. For the United States, the worst has come to pass and Government officials said today that the future prospects for relations with Iran were alMost totally up in the air.

title: Earthquake Jolts California
description: PALM DESERT, Calif., Feb. 12 (AP)  Residents of southern California's lower desert were jolted by an earthquake measuring 4.4 on the Richter scale last night, but no damage was reported, the authorities said. The quake was centered in unpopulated mountain terrain 17 miles south of Palm Desert.

title: Coup Is Apparently Thwarted in Chad
description: NDJAMENA, Chad, Feb. 12 (Reuters)  Troops loyal to President Felix Malloum of Chad today surrounded guerrillas trying to mount a coup in favor of Prime Minister Nissen Habre, military sources said.

title: Liberating Savings Bank Insurance
description: The life insurance sold by New York savings banks is a consumer's dream. It is about the cheapest available. What's more, it is sold by people who work on salary and have no incentive to push policies that yield large commissions for little real protection. Unfortunately, however, the indifference of the State Legislature is limiting the value of this worthy product.

title: Grace Paley, 10 Others Fined $100 Each for Protest
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 12  Judge Donald S. Smith, of the Superior Court here fined Grace Paley of New York, an author, and her 10 codefendants $100 apiece today, gave each a 180day suspended sentence and unsupervised probation of two or three years.

title: Controlling Imports Of Textiles
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  For all its efforts, the Carter Administration is having difficulty working out a policy of more comprehensive controls on textile imports.

title: Marines Are Not Going to Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  The State Department said today that it had suspended plans to send helicopters and a platoon of Marines to Turkey in preparetion for a possible evacuation of Americans from Teheran.

title: Advertising
description: HARPERATLANTIC SALES, the advertising sales arm of both Harper's and Atlantic magazines, is ailing, and, like a play doctor, G. Thomas Grenier been called in. He has come aboard as president and has inaugurated some strong measures aimed at turning things around.

title: Atlantic City Throbs to New Boom
description: ATLANTIC CITY  The familiar orange shingles that once marked the Howard Johnson Regency Hotel on Pacific and Arkansas Avenues here are being ripped away from the hotel that has become the Boardwalk Regency and could become whatever its new owners, Caesars World, want it to be. Up in the balconylobby restaurant called the Palm Court, the wheelerdealers table hop with blueprints and business cards and samples of siding and flooring and artists renderings of casinos yet unborn, oblivious to the hammers smacking up the temporary partitions.

title: Lakeland and Doberman Gain Westminster Final
description: A Lakeland terrier, a Doberman pinscher and a white miniature poodle were Chosen last night to be the first three finalists for tonight's top award at the 103d show of the Westminster Kennel Club in Madison Square Garden.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Romance No. 2 in F, Beethoven; Hungarian Rhapsody No. 5, Liszt; Excerpt from The Barber of Seville, Rossini; Rondo a capriccio in G. Beethoven.

title: Bridge:
description: The biggest pair championship played anywhere will reach its climax next month in Norfolk, Va., where 104 partnerships will compete in the finals of the Grand National Pairs. They are the survivors of about 60,000 pairs that have competed in club and district competition during the last six months.

title: New Quarks Stir Debate On Basic Laws of Nature
description: THE recent discovery of new families of atomic particles and the development of new theories to explain them have plunged the scientific community into a ferment of speculation over the nature of matter and the laws that have made the universe what it is.

title: TV: Views Of Africa
description: THE film crew that made The Africans was underexposed to the problems of the continent. That, at least, is the impression given by the three programs that will be shown from 9 o'clock to midnight tonight on WNETTV. They are part of a series of six produced by TimeLife and an Australian television consortium.

title: Ashe Is Forced Out of Tourney With a Stiff Neck
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 12 (UPI)  Arthur Ashe withdrew from a $250,000 tennis tournament today because of a stiff neck. He suffered the ailment while rising from a training table to take the court.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: THE new Federal tax law has paved the road for the expansion of flexible compensation plans the cafeteria plans, so called because they allow employees to choose from an assortment of different fringe benefits.

title: IN THE NATION
description: After two months in Africa and a month on vacation, a returning columnist finds Iran falling into unfriendly or at least nonaligned hands, while President Carter is coming under new attack from liberals for his war on inflation.

title: Notes on People
description: While she was fighting extradition to North Carolina last summer, Joan Little is said to have accepted Christ as her Saviour in the course of several conversations with a Baptist minister in Flushing, Queens. It is for that reason, it was learned yesterday, that Miss Little hopes to work for the Ebenezer Baptist Church's youth program next summer, depending on whether North Carolina officials grant her petition for parole when she becomes eligible on June 9. Miss Little, who received national attention when she was accused and later acquitted of killing a prison guard in 1975, escaped from prison in 1977 and was arrested in New York. After she was extradited she pleaded guilty to the escape charge and her prison sentence was increased by six months to two years.

title: Postal Service Acts to Cut Cost of ThirdClass Mail
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI)  The Postal Service, fighting to hold onto thirdclass mail volume against stiffening competition, announced today that it would strip away 75 regulations to save money for shippers of magazines, books and records.

title: Energy Stocks Lead Dow to 2.5 Point Gain
description: Stocks of energy companies continued to dominate buying interest on Wall Street yesterday as investors apparently sought to hedge against the effects of the oil cutoff from Iran. Canadian and the occasional Mexican company benefited along with American companies.

title: Westinghouse Solar Mirrors
description: PITTSBURGH. Feb. 12 (AP)  The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that it was ready to begin a??olar energy experiment that would ??e moving mirrors to track the sun ?? ross the sky.

title: Carter Says He's Prepared to Work With Teheran Leaders for Stability
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  President Carter said today that the United States was consulting closely with the new government in Iran and was prepared to work with it to protect American interests and tq restore stability to the region.

title: 40 Vietnamese Reach Malaysia
description: KUANTAN, Malaysia, Feb. 12 (Reuters)  A boat with 40 Vietnamese refugees was beached at the mouth of a river near here today. An official spokesman said they would not be allowed to land.

title: Holdup Victim in Fair Condition
description: A 44yearold teacher who resisted a holdup attempt by two men in a Manhattan subway station was in fair condition yesterday with numerous stab wounds. The victim, Eldred Williams, was accosted in the nearly deserted BroadwayNassau station at 7:42 P.M. on Sunday when he was accosted by two men who demanded money. When he refused they stabbed him and fled. Mr. Williams was taken to BeekmanDowntown Hospital.

title: Insurance Exchange Imperiled
description: ALBANY, Feb. 12  The Republicanled Senate Rules Committee is to consider a resolution tomorrow that could delay, possibly indefinitely, the setting up of the state's new insurance exchange, due to begin operating April 1.

title: Carey Asks Cut in Mandatory Drug Terms
description: ALBANY, Feb. 12  Governor Carey said today that he would support a reduction in New York State's tough mandatory sentences for the illegal possession of modest amounts of narcotics and dangerous drugs. But the Governor said he would not favor reducing the stiff penalties for illegal sale of these substances.

title: OBSERVER
description: A curious side effect of inflation is the psychological change that occurs in the human attitude toward money It is as if we have a builtin psychologi cal defense to protect us against the mental ravages threatened by declining currency.

title: 3 American Doctors Reach Italy As Death Toll of Babies Hits 64
description: NAPLES, Feb. 12 (AP)  A 4monthold died today in Campobasso, 50 miles northeast of Naples, of what appeared to be the same mystery disease that has been blamed for the deaths of at least 63 infants in the Naples area, officials said.

title: Maravich of Jazz to Miss Last 5 Games of Road Trip
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 12 (AP) Pete Maravich, the New Orleans Jazz star who has been troubled with an injured knee for most of the season, will sit out the remaining five games of a sixgame road trip because of a viral infection

title: Contemporary Fashions For HardtoFit Figures
description: It's easy enough for a woman who wears an average size like 8, 10 or 12 to pick up a new outfit in the current style. But those who are bigger, smaller, taller or shorter than their sisters often have considerable difficulty finding clothes that fit, let alone clothes that spell fashion. Big women are doomed to pullon polyester pants and shapeless tops. Petite women do well enough with jeans in children's sizes, but just can't face all those juvenile ruffles. Happily, there are shops catering to these women.

title: Worldwide Effort Is Proposed To Study Climate and Its Impact
description: GENEVA, Feb. 12  Faced with littleunderstood threats to world climate that could catastrophically affect food production and energy use, specialists from around the world convened here today to consider the creation of a World Climate Program that over the next 20 years would narrow the uncertainties.

title: EARNINGS
description: The General Telephone and Dectronics Corporation said yesterday that its profits in the fourth quarter rose by 12.7 percent, making the annual increase 15.5 percent, records for both periods.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  The Carter Administration will soon send Congress a bill designed to bring order, efficiency, continuity and greater justice to the admission and resettlement of people who have fled from persecution and oppression in their own countries.

title: Ben Ticknor Dies at 70
description: Ben Ticknor, Harvard's allAmerica football center and Hall of Famer, is dead at the age of 70. Page B19.

description: Around the city tomorrow, a number of perfectly lovable valentines will be curled up with their cats or out walking their dogs, all the while longing for a date with someone of their own breed.

title: Amtrak, the Caboose
description: Amtrak, which has  surprisingly  attained the age of eight, is an institution unique among the multitudinous enterprises established by our Federal Government It was deliberately designed by its proponents to be not selfperpetuating but selfdestructing.

description: YONKERS, Feb. 12  Bertha Heinlein, a 65yearold retired woman who receives $10 a month in food stamps, patiently explained to her Congressman this afternoon that the pending cut in her monthly foodstamp allocations would virtually mean starvation.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, FEB 12, 1979

title: PRESIDENT CONCEDES WARNING HIS STAFFS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  President Carter acknowledged today that he had admonished his top aides to be circumspect in their dealings with news organizations, but he denied reports that he had told them not to discuss disagreements within the Administration.

title: Science Watch
description: Ornithologists have recently determined that blue geese are genetically identical to snow geese, the only difference being the color of their feathers. The discovery has solved one longstanding mystery, only to have other gooserelated questions surface.

title: N.H.L. Is Starting to Ask Questions About System
description: Reluctantly, as if waking from a beautiful dream into a reality he did not want to face, Bobby Clarke conceded, We'll have to look at our gamethe Russians are better.

title: China and Vietnam Say Border Clashes Continue
description: PEKING, Feb. 12 (Reuters)  China and Vietnam have reported new border clashes that have killed an undetermined number of people.

title: Herzog Shifts His Role at 3M
description: Raymond H. Herzog, chairman and chief executive officer of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, announced yesterday that he was prematurely relinquishing the post of chief executive officer in preparation for an orderly transition when he retires in two years. His successor, effective March 31, will be Lewis W. Lehr, 57 years old, currently the president for United States operations. His new title will be vice chairman and chief executive officer.

title: RUSSIANS RECOGNIZE NEW REGIME IN IRAN
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 12  The Soviet Union recognized Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's appointees as the new Government of Iran today and said it was ready to develop a relationship based on equality, good neighborliness, and respect for national sovereignty and noninterference in each other's internal affairs.

title: How Is Occidental Run?
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  The fivemonth, multimilliondollar battle successfully waged by the Mead Corporation to fend off an attempted acquisition by the Occidental Petroleum Corporation has brought to light information that has touched off Federal and state investigations of the business practices of Occidental and its chief executive officer, Armand Hammer.

title: Ford Trims Warranty Cost to Beat G.M. Move
description: DETROIT, Feb. 12 (AP) The Ford Motor Company moved today to undercut the General Motors Corporation by slashing the price of its optional threeyear warranty en many of its new cars.

title: Carter Urges Voluntary Measures To Manage Nation's Oil Shortage
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  President Carter called on the American people today to adopt voluntary energy conservation measures, such as using car pools or taking public transportation to work, to cope with the oil shortage that has resulted from the political upheaval in Iran.

title: Books of The Times
description: EVERYBODY seemed to like him except his mother. His mother, alas, was Queen Victoria. She kept him waiting around for almost 60 years before, reluctantly, she died and he became King. Until he was 51 years old, he was not permitted to see Foreign Office dispatches and Cabinet papers that otherwise circulated freely among the various ministers and their secretaries. For most of his adult life, Bertie had nothing to do.

title: Cancer Cells in Experiment Give Rise to Normal Tissue
description: SCIENTISTS have demonstrated that certain deadly mouse cancer cells, grown for years in laboratory cultures, can be inserted into embryos and thereafter give rise to normal tissues in normal mice.

title: Leaded Gas Cited in Los Angeles Pollution
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 12  The National Commission on Air Quality was told today that the use of leaded gasoline in automobiles not designed for it was negating air pollution abatement in southern California and probably in other Darts of the country.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Allibert Inc., United States marketing organization for Allibert, manufacturer of bathroom furniture, cabinets and accessories, has appointed Ole SchultzPedersen as executive vice president and director.

title: Obituary 8 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Junior Wells Joins Stars
description: THE popular blues team of Junior Wells and Buddy Guy split apart last year, and one wondered what the results would be. Both men were firstrank blues artists at their best, but their shows had grown increasingly selfindulgent, so much so that the leading English blues magazine editorially advised its readers not to go see them.

title: Article 3 -- No Title:A Half-World
description: TIMELINESS has nothing to do with the worth of a film, though it can illuminate its values. "The Cycle" (Dayereh Mina), Darius Mehrrjui's Iranian film that opens today at the Public Theater, was made several years ago and was initially banned in its homeland. When it was released for export, the decision, I suspect, was made in an effort to demonstrate the freedom of Iran's artists under the Shah, who was receiving increasing criticism abroad for his repressive political policies at home."The Cycle" would be an interesting film under any circumstances, but to realize that it was produced when and where it was adds an extraordinary measure of interest. Here is an attempt to make a sort of Iranian "Shoeshine," and though it lacks the profound irony of Vittorio De Sica's work and is sometimes too pretty, it is a remarkably vivid indictment of the political order that made it possible.The film is the story of the wayward rise of Ali, a young man from the country, who comes into the city (Teheran, I assume) with his ailing father seeking medical help. The penniless pair  without a stated past and no future  is befriended by several members of the staff of a large, modern hospital. However, Ali can make ends meet only by becoming a member of the half-world that is the connection between the well-fed, rich and powerful, and those who are utterly destitute. Ali will do anything for money, most of it legal but none of it ethical or moral.I've no idea if "The Cycle" has been cut somewhere along its way to this country, so I can't be sure whether its narrative rambles and jumps by accident or for the purpose of an overly ambitious structure. The film is full of little digressions that are not always dramatic in themselves but are essential to the sense of the movie, which is a devastating picture of a country in the midst of a revolution it doesn't understand and cannot control.The physical squalor and emotional confusion look Dickensian, though the details are of the 20th century. A commercial blood bank where the sick and the destitute sell their blood looks like Bedlam. The hospital, though airy and clean, is staffed largely by people who are too busy leading their own comparatively affluent lives to give much thought to the patients. Bribery is everywhere.We see the manager of a chicken farm destroying hundreds of chicks because, as he says, the cost of feed has become so high he can't afford to raise them. When Ali goes into the country, the landscape is no less brutal than that of the city, only somewhat more desolate. In this world, as seen by Mr. Mehrjui, it's always dusk, night or dawn. Even sunlight seems to be out of the reach of these people.The credits do not identify which actor plays which role, but the performances are uniformly excellent, especially the young man who plays Ali and the old fellow who plays his ailing, ill-tempered father.It's impossible to respond to "The Cycle" in quite the same way one might respond to, say, a film from Bulgaria. I've a suspicion  based on this one film  that Mr. Mehrjui's highly developed social conscience is not going to be especially pleased in the religious state that Iran's new rulers are likely to set up. What will happen to him?

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: I have two or three brief statements I'd like to make before the questions. First of all, I'd like to say a few words about Iran.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI)  The nation has had a relatively mild time with influenza this winter even though cases have been reported in 37 states, a Government disease surveillance specialist reported today.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York
description: It turned out that Wally Slocum's death was makebelieve. The retired traveling tie salesman and lifetime bachelor, whose proudest creation was a bench he made in the crafts room of the Golden Years retirement hotel, came out ailive from behind the curtain when the audience was going home, five minutes after their strong final applause.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter called on the nation to conserve energy to cope with the oil shortage resulting from the upheaval in Iran. At a televised news conference, the President said that voluntary measures would suffice for now, although he conceded that the situation could get worse. [Page Al.]

title: Music: Jubal's  Delicacies
description: THE Jabal Trio, which won the Naumburg Foundation's Chamber Music Award for 1977, has been praised for the imagination and inventiveness of its programs. And rightly so, as Sunday night's concert at Alice Tully Hall amply demonstrated. Not often will you be faced, in one evening, with such improbably various works as were offered on this occasion. There was music by Bach and Stephen Foster, a world premiere and rarely performed pieces by 20thcentury masters  a whole menu of delicacies, in fact.

title: The City
description: State Senator Vander L. Beatty, a Brooklyn Democrat who is chairman of the state's Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus, denied a charge by an unidentified official of the Koch administration that employees of the disfranchised BedfordStuyvesant Youth in Action Community Corporation had been forced to work in Senator Beatty's election campaign.

title: Harpers to Set Up Bus Unit in China
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 12  Harpers International Ltd., as Hong Kong automobile distributor, said today that it had signed an agreement with China to set up a bus assembly plant across the border from Hong Kong.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: With Government securities trading shut down for Lincoln's Birthday, the rest of the credit market showed no significant price changes yesterday and trading activity was extremely light.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: ARTHUR A. SEIDMAN

title: Senate Panel Balks at Letting U.S. Shift Funds to New Office in Taipei
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  A key Senate committee has tentatively rejected a request to transfer government funds for setting up the new, unofficial American Institute in Taiwan to take the place of the United States Embassy.

title: Significance of Figures On Mexican Oil in Doubt
description: VILLAHERMOSA, Mexico  Just how much oil does Mexico have?By all accounts, an formidable amount, and, just conceivably, more than Saudi Arabia. But no one really knows, and the startling comparisons that have so captured America's attention of late have leaped far beyond what any oilman would be willing to venture.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 13, 1979

title: Trapped
description: The men and women who carelessly toss the furry skin of a wild animal across their shoulders  just as their ancestors did in the forests of Northern Europe and Asia several thousand years ago  may not know it, and if they do, surely prefer not to think about it, but with few exceptions what they're really doing is flaunting evidence of many hours or even days of torture suffered by each wild animal whose pelt they wear.

title: 400 Cats, Purring for Center Stage, Fill Lobby at Cast Call
description: They purred and wriggled as they winked large, longlashed eyes at the casting director. All newcomers to Broadway, they hoped to land that one special ingenue's role that could make them stars.

title: RollsRoyce Set to Pick U.S. Site
description: LONDON, Feb. 12  RollsRoyce Ltd., the aircraft engine manufacturer, expects to make a final decision fairly quickly on where to build its proposed American plant.

title: Gasoline Price Bound to Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  At one of those breakfasts that are part of the Washington scene, Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger was asked last week when the price of gasoline at the pump would get to a dollar a gallon.

title: Consumer Spending Tapers Off
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP)  The consumerspending boom showed signs of tapering off in January, the Commerce, Department said today. Shoppers are still increasing buying at department and furniture stores, but the gain was down sharply from earlier months, the department added.

title: FIRM WARNING GIVEN CHINESE PROTESTERS
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 12  Chinese officials issued a firm warning today against demonstrations like those by young people that have disrupted Shanghai, the largest city in China, in the last week.

title: Bogart Carlaw, Coiner Of Catchy Ad Slogans And Former Executive
description: Bogart Carlaw, a former advertising executive who initiated the slogan Lucky Strike green has gone to war in World War II, died of pneumonia yesterday at Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 74 years old and a resident of Southbury, Conn.

title: Fordham Typically Loses, 7170
description: What Coach Tom Penders called typical of about seven of our losses was a 7170 defeat for the Fordham Rams last night at their home court, the Rose Hill gymnasium in the Bronx. Army, which had trailed by 7 points with three minutes to play, won on a 10foot jump shot by Bob Brown with five seconds to play.

title: Events
description: THE CYCLE, directed by Darius Mahriui; at the Iranian Film Festival, et the Public Theater, through Sunday..

title: Carl Hoppl, 72, A Restaurateur On L.I., Dead
description: Carl Hoppl, a Long Island restaurateur, died Friday, altar a gallbladder operation at Syosset (L.I.) Hospital. He was was 72 years old and lived in Valley Stream, L.I., for many years.

title: EDUCATION
description: MANHASSET, L.I. FOURTEEN students sat in a high school classroom here last week deliberating over a Wordsworth poem in an English course identical to one at Syracuse University.

title: Goodyear Cites Oil Conserver
description: AKRON, Ohio (AP)  Richard Bauer, a scientist for the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, says a rubberlike liquid that makes clothes last longer could increase the nation's energy resources by revitalizing depleted oil wells.

title: 24 NeoNazis, Many in Uniform, Are Reported Seized in Hanover
description: HANOVER, West Germany, Feb. 12 (Reuters)  Twentyfour alleged neoNazis, many of them wearing uniforms of black shirts and jackboots, skull and crossbone badges, and swastikas, were arrested over the weekend, the police said today.

title: Commanding Presence, Political Past
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The voice remains unmistakable; resonant and commanding, with dignified cadences and rich timbre. It caught the nation's attention and fired its imagination  and prompted more than one listener to joke that if God is a woman, she must sound like this.

title: Gulf States to Add Central Utilities for $270 Million
description: The Gulf States Utilities Company, one of the largest electric utilities in the Southwest, and the Central Louisiana Energy Corporation jointly announced yesterday that Gulf States had agreed in principle to acquire Central Louisiana for an estimated $270 million in cash and stock.

title: Canada Increasing Oil Output
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Feb.12  Western Canadian crudeoil production is being raised again in an effort to help avert potential shortage at some American and eastern Canadian refineries.

title: '78 Floods Killed 125 And Cost Over Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) Floods killed 125 Americans and caused more than $1 billion in damage in 1978, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration reported yesterday.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: F.B.I. Agent Testifies G.S.A. Manager Paid For Undelivered Glue
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 12 (UPI)  A Federal Bureau of Investigation agent testified today that the former manager of a General Services Administration store paid a Maryland company nearly $25,000 for office supplies it never delivered to the Government.

title: The Region
description: YONKERS  Angelo Martinelli said he would run for a fourth twoyear term as the Mayor of Yonkers, the state's fourth largest city. The 51yearold businessman, a Republican, said he would seek the Conservative Party endorsement, indicating that he might run as a Conservative if he lost in the Republican primary.

title: Donald L. Curtiss, 74 Years Old; Consultant on Shopping Centers
description: Donald L. Curtiss, a former consultant to shoppingcenter developers in the United States and Canada, died Sunday at the Nathaniel Witherell Nursing Home in Greenwich, Conn., at the age of 74.

title: Koch, in a Reversal, Orders New Plan for South Bronx
description: Conceding that he was eating crow, Mayor Koch reversed himself yesterday and ordered a new redevelopment plan for the South Bronx that would not include the Charlotte Street project, which was. rejected by the Board of Estimate last week.

title: Another Louisville Heavyweight Has His Road to the Title All Mapped Out
description: It begins again. A heavyweight from Louisville, Ky., who can talk as well as fight makes his professional debut.

title: The Mideast Power Balance And Brown's Tour of Area
description: Secretary of Defense Harold Brown assessing the impact of two major changes in the power balance in the Middle East during his visit to Saudi Arabia, Jordan, Israel and Egypt, according to Carter Administration officials and United States and NATO defense analysts.

title: U.S. Consular Aide in Hong Kong Resigns Under Refugee Criticism
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 12 (AP)  A local employee of the United States Consulate General resigned today, three days after he was assaulted and accused by Vietnamese refugees of making advances to Vietnamese women seeking resettlement in the United States.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: A BOOK IS BORN As for just how  authors, editors, production managers and sales and publicity directors know best. Some key representatives will speak on the joys and tribulations of The Publishing Process in a series of seminars open to the public and starting tomorrow at 5 P.M. at the Grolier Club. 47 East 60th Street. The twohour programs are being presented by the American Institute of Graphic Arts.

title: Truck Sales Up for Month
description: DETROIT, Feb. 12 (UPI)  Retail truck sales totaled 282,788 units in January, up 22 percent from last year and a record for the month, preliminary figures showed yesterday.

title: Some Leaders of Shah's Regime Are Put on Display as Prisoners
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 12  The triumphant followers of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini displayed under hot television spotlights topight the first prisoners of the new regime in Iran, all of them leaders in the fallen Government of Shah Mohammad Riza Pahlevi.

title: Australia Defeats India In a Davis Cup Semifinal
description: MADRAS, India, Feb. 12 (AP)Australia defeated India by 32 in the Davis Cup Eastern zone semifinals today. The Australian victory was clinched when John Alexander scored a singles victory over Sashi Menon.

title: Music: Festival of Drums Offers a Variety of Styles
description: THE second of two concerts in Festival of Drums, held at the Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street, on Sunday, was an education. The hall, which seats almost 1,000 people, was sold out, and seems likely that just about everyone present learned something about Africanderived percussion traditions.

title: Capital Towaway Drive: No Immunity
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  After years of haphazard enforcement, the District of Columbia began a crack. down on parking violators last fall. Within the first two weeks, even the city's Police Chief had received three tickets.

title: 2d S.O.R.C. Yachtsman Lost Despite Rescue Try
description: The death by drowning off the coast of Florida last Friday of Tom Curnow, a 32yearold member of the crew of the yacht Pirana, was the second within nine days on the Southern Ocean Racing Conference, which in its 38year history had never before recorded a fatality.

title: Cut in Business Taxes Asked in 1980 Budget Is Defended by Carey
description: ALBANY, Feb. 12  Fending off attacks on the businesstax reductions proposed in his 1980 budget, Governor Carey said today the cuts were designed to have a clear, longterm effect to stimulate the economy and make jobs by inducing business to remain in New York.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: COZY CORNUCOPIA The spacious loft south of Madison Square was a snug haven in freezing weather. Jazz buffs, both couples and singles, didn't seem to mind climbing four flights of stairs the other night for the new weekly Jamarama sessions held on Wednesday and Thursday, when unknown talent gets a chance to sound off with the regular players of the Jazzmania Society.

title: SCHLESINGER ISSUES RENEWED WARNING ON IRAN'S OIL FLOW
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger warned today that although he expected the new leaders in Iran to ask oilfield workers to resume production, there is no assurance that the workers will do so.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCE EMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 354.3900 UNTIL 5.30 PM IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9.00 AM TO 4:30 PM MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 32900 WESTCHESTER CO AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300 NASSAU CO (516) 7470500 SUFFOLK CO (516) 6691800. CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767

title: Music: Spotlight on Flute
description: IN what seemed like an odd or, perhaps, oldfashioned manner, Ingrid Dingfelder was given star billing (in very large letters) in an orchestra concert in Alice Tully Hall on Monday night. The flutist was soloist in two concertos, yet the program had the Orchestra's services in other major works as well. The conductor's name, Richard Kapp, was missing from the program page, too, but that can be assumed to have been an oversight, since there was the customary biography of him at the back of the program book.

title: Giants and Restic Meet on Coaching Post
description: A second coaching candidate, Joe Restic of Harvard, was interviewed by the Giants yesterday, but all was quiet on the director of operations front after Commissioner Pete Rozelle asked the team's feuding owners to refrain from making public announcements.

title: Residences for Retarded Earn Wider Acceptance
description: VALLEY STREAM, L.I.  Gary Shaw did everything he could to prevent the opening of a community residence for the retarded next door to his parents home here.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: AS a straphanger, writes R.P. McCarthy, I have the dubious distinction of boarding near the beginning of the line and generally finding a place to sit. Once settled, I can amuse myself watching my fellow commuters scamble for the few remaining seats.

title: Viggiano Called Favorite to Win DeSalvio's Seat
description: Paul Viggiano, who was born three years after Louis DeSalvio entered the New York State Assembly in 1940, was considered by politicians yesterday as the likely heir to Mr. DeSalvio's seat.

title: Cocaine: Big Business in Lawless Bolivian Lowlands
description: SANTA CRUZ, Bolivia, Feb. 7  This longisolated region of eastern Bolivia was opened up by an oil boom 20 years ago. Then came cotton and cattle ranches. Now it's cocaine.

title: Mazda Sets Advertising For New Sport Coupe
description: Mazda, the Japanese auto line, is about to begin a new advertising campaign that will include the Mazda 626, new sport coupe introduced yesterday in Los Angeles. Foote, Cone & Belding/ Honig is the agency for this $15 million account.

title: Enforcement Lag Is Seen In Desegregation Efforts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  Stronger Federal enforcement and fewer harassing amendments from Congress are needed to end public school desegregation, the United States Commission on Civil Rights said today.

title: Renoir Was Movie Master Of the Ageless and the New
description: Jean Renoir, who died Monday night, had not made a film since he completed The Little Theater of Jean Renoir in 1969. Yet so vivid is his presence in the consciousness of all of us who share his appreciation of films  an appreciation that he made profound  that his death has a very real shock effect, as if we'd learned that someone we had just talked to on the telephone had suddenly vanished. Though Renoir's films do not turn up on television with regularity, and though the repertory cinemas are inclined to schedule more Marx Brothers revivals than retrospectives devoted to Renoir, his films remain so alive in our minds that it's difficult to believe that the master who made them is not still around somewhere, just off screen, prompting us to responses that are really explorations.

title: Anderson Attacks Carey Budget; Says Governor's Playing Games
description: ALBANY, Feb. 13  Accusing Governor Carey of playing games with taxpayers in his $12.7 billion budget, the Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson of Binghamton, said today that it would face rough sledding in the Republicanled State Senate.

title: Corporations Report Quarterly Sales
description: For perriods as shown. (N) indicates stocks is listed on the New YorkStock Exchange,(A) the AmericanStock Exchange and (O) overthecounter

title: Teamsters Back Wage Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  Frank E. Fitzsimmons, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, has sent a letter to the Congressional leadership endorsing the Administration's plan for real wage insurance.

title: Wine Talk: Rare and Risky
description: WHEN Roger Chauveron was In his heyday in New York, a dozen years or so ago, his restaurant, Cafe Chauveron, boasted an excellent wine cellar. But even in those relatively inexpensive times  compared with now  some of his bottles, mostly old bordeaux, sold for $250 each. I once asked him who bought these wines.

title: Knicks Keep Negotiating For Player
description: Sonny Werblin and John Y. Brown went to dinner last night. The last time the two were together was last Saturday night, and shortly thereafter Bob McAdoo was traded to the Boston Celtics

title: Bridge:
description: If your partnership has a substantial trump fit, it hardly ever pays to try to penalize the opponents at a low level. This was the moral of the diagramed deal, played Saturday in the final of the Knockout Team Championship in White Plains.

title: Best Buys
description: AFEW months ago, agricultural economists were predicting that 1979 could well become The Year of the Pig, with suggestions that American hog production would be up 17 percent over 1978, offering consumers some relief from skyrocketing meat prices.

title: Libyan Leader Warns Washington About Oil
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 13 The head of a Libyan goodwill mission warned today that his country might withhold oil exports to the United States if Libya could not obtain American imports more readily.

title: SCHOOL COOKS JOIN STRIKERS IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Feb. 13  The impact of strikes on schoolchildren increased today as parttime municipal workers who prepare school meals joined the walkout of state and municipal service employees now in its fourth week.

title: PROXMIRE CRITICIZES KOCH ON CUTBACKS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  Senator William Proxmire called on the Treasury Department today to deny New York City its next round of Federal loan guarantees this week unless Mayor Koch agreed to a series of deeper budget cutbacks for the next year.

title: EARNINGS
description: Strong demand by the automotive industry and in the tire replacement market helped the Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company to roll up a 68.9 percent rise in fourthquarter earnings and a 9.9 percent gain for the year, the world's leading rubber producer reported yesterday.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: THERE is a small magazine, edited and published in Manhattan, that is little known to the world at large, but is admired and respected by many chefs in the United States. It is the official publication of the Vatel Club, to which most of the finest French chefs in this country belong, and the editors declare that it is the only culinary review in the French language published in North America.

title: Bishops End Puebla Conference With Plea for Rights of the Poor
description: PUEBLA, Mexico, Feb. 13  The Roman Catholic bishops of Latin America ended a crucial conference on the church's future role in the region's affairs today by urging Catholics to press harder for the rights of the poor.

title: News of the Theater
description: J The controversial new black and Hispanic Shakespeare company, which made its debut Jan. 25 at the Public Theater, is making plans right into the summer. Despite the mixed reviews it received for its initial production of Julius Caesar, the producer Joseph Papp will present the troupe in Central Park in either The Merchant of Venice or Titus Andronicus. In either case, Andrei Serban will be the director.

title: Energy
description: Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger warned that oilfield workers in Iran might might not resume production even if asked do so by the new Iranian Government. He also said oil shortages could become as serious as they were during the Middle East embargo of 197374 if the situation in Iran does not change by the en of June. He noted that the Iranian facilities were in the hands of political radicals who resisted an earlier plea to pump just enough oil to meet Iran's own needs. [Page A1.]

title: Richard Applegate; Correspondent Jailed In 50's by Red China
description: Richard Applegate, a former war correspondent for The United Press and the National Broadcasting Company who was a captive of the Chinese Communists for 18 months in the 1950's, died yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston after a long illness. He was 66 years old and lived in Boston.

title: Cecil B. Moore, 64; a Councilman And Philadelphia Rights Activist
description: Cecil B. Moore, a lawyer and civil rights leader in Philadelphia, died yesterday of a heat attack at West Park Hospital in that city. He was 64 years old.

title: Kosinski's Being There Will Star Peter Sellers
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13  Being There, Jerzy Kosinski*s metaphorical novel about surface and substance, is rile,inspiration for a new movie starring Peter Sellers and Shirley MacLaine and directed by Hal Ashby

title: Iran's Communists Back Regime
description: EAST BERLIN, Feb. 13  Iran's Communists are ready to support the new Government created by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini but have not established official contact, according to statement today by Nurreddin Kiannuri, head of the Communist's party.

title: Top '78 Underwriters
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company came in first as the leading underwriter of taxexempt bonds last year, the Public Securities Association reported yesterday. The firm managed the sale of 385 bond issues totaling almost $2.6 billion.

title: U.S. Housing Study Finds Displacement of Poor in Slums Is Minimal
