description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 The Department of Housing and Urban Development said today that displacement of poor people by the private revitalization of slum neighborhoods was minimal, but it promised to do something about it anyway.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Ernest Schwiebert, whose book Matching the Hatch in 1955 catapulted him into the first rank of flyfishmg authors, has produced a monumental twovolume work entitled Trout (E. P. Dutton, 1,745 pages, illustrated, $75).

title: COMMODITIES Precious Metals Tumble; Soybeans Also Decline
description: Precious metal futures prices dropped sharply yesterday, with traders talking of a reaction to the recent price surge, the development of a large an?? of stoploss selling. Weaksister holders of long positions decided to sell, one market researcher explained. They wanted to take profits.

title: General Foods Cuts Coffee 5
description: The General Foods Corporation, the country's leading coffee roaster, cut the wholesale price of its Maxwell House coffee by 5 cents yesterday, to $2.48 a pound.

title: Should Presidents Bend the Rules?
description: Who should have the final say in determining how clean the air will be, or how safe the workplace? The regulatory agencies established to achieve those and other social goals? Or the President, with his broader national responsibility?

title: Acrobatic Gunmen Steal $15,000
description: Two gunmen, described by the police as real acrobats, robbed a factory and its employees of $15,000 in cash, jewelry and credit cards in the diamond district yesterday after climbing along narrow, icy ledges from the 14th to the 17th floor until they found an open window.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Brown Company, a producer of paper and building products, announced yesterday that Gulf and Western Industries had advised Brown management that it was interested in acquiring the remaining approximately 19 percent interest in Brown not owned by Gulf and Western.

title: IRAN'S NEW PREMIER NAMES 7 TO CABINET; KHOMEINI ASKS CALM
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 13  Iran's provisional revolutionary Government took shape today as seven ministers were hurriedly named in an apparent effort to help bring order to the country. At the same time, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini went on television and radio to demand anew that his followers lay down their arms and end tumult that could undermine the projected Islamic republic.

title: Moynihan Says U.S. Will Remain In Bronx Despite Charlotte St. Loss
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan reassured New York City officials yesterday that the Federal Government is in the Bronx to stay despite the rejection of the Charlotte Street plan by the Board of Estimate.

title: Notes on People
description: At a reception yesterday in Lincoln Center, the famous theater collection of the New York Public Library got a new name  the Billy Rose Theater Collection, in recognition of the fact that the Billy Rose Foundation, created by the late impresario and songwriter, has given the theatrical archive $1.25 million.

title: Advertising
description: FORGET about junior or sister becoming doctors, mother dear. Have them go into business, because if they get to be a company president (and why shouldn't they?) they'll make more, and in most cases have more, than not only the average physician but also the average dentist, lawyer or accountant.

title: Music: Boehm Quintette
description: WOODWIND quintets have to beat the bushes more than most chamber groups in order to refresh their repertory with novelties. The Boehm Quintette deserves some sort of an award for enterprise in this respect the ensemble's program at Carnegie Recital Hall Monday night uncovered several unusual items.

title: Alaska Reports Earthquake
description: PALMER, Alaska, Feb. 13 (UPI)  A strong earthquake measuring 6.5 on the Richter scale struck in the Pacific 225 miles southwest of Kodiak last night, the Alaska Tsunami Warning Center reported. Some coastal villages were rocked, but there were no immediate reports of damage or injuries.

title: How to Buy Shoes That Fit
description: Rule No. 1 is shop for comfort, not fashion. If you have normal feet, you should not have to buy ugly, clumsylooking shoes to get ones that fit. But you do have to pay careful attention to factors other than style.

title: Theater: Loose Ends, By Weller, in the Capital
description: MICHAEL WELLER'S Moonchildren, first presented in the United States at the. Arena Stage in 1971; became a pivotal play of its period. It caught, as if for a time capsule, young people of the 1960's escaping from the demands of their lives by putting on their friends and spoofing strangers

title: The City
description: Following a twoyear search, the New York City's Board of Higher Education appointed Flora Mancuso Edwards, a dean at La Guardia Community College, to be president of Hostos Community College in the South Bronx. Mrs. Edwards, 38 years old, succeeds Anthony Santiago, who has served as acting president of the bilingual college since September 1977.

title: Quinella Betting At Aqueduct
description: Aqueduct Race Track will introduce quinella wagering today, increasing combination or exotic betting to eight of its nine races daily.

title: The Oldest Freshman in the Assembly
description: ALBANY, Feb. 13  When Harry Smoler was campaigning for a seat in the State Assembly last fall, his campaign manager told him to shave off his white beard. Mr. Smoler was, after all, 66 years old and running against three young candidates  ages 24, 25 and 26. His backers felt that there was no point in stressing the fact that he was old enough to be the grandfather of his opponents.

title: Florence Connell, 54, Chairman Of a Manhasset School Division
description: Florence Connell, chairman of the foreign language department of the senior and junior high schools in the Manhasset, L.L., school system, died of cancer yester. day at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhat. tan. Mrs. Connell was 54 years old and a resident of East Norwich, L.I., for more than 25 years.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 14, 1979

title: Iran Regime Is Expected To Insist on Total Power
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 13  At the high gates outside the Prime Minister's office, a band of armed irregulars kept watch today over the complex of buildings where the new provisional revolutionary Government put in its first day of work.

title: Real Estate
description: THE International Business Machines Corporation has had a manufacturing presence in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn since 1968. The presence has grown more formidable by far since last September, when the operation moved from the fivestory commercial warehouse it had occupied at Nostrand and Gates Avenues into a new battleship of a building that it put up a few blocks away, at Nostrand and DeKalb.

title: After Victory, Flood of Tasks
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 13  Now that Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini has won the country, what is he going to do with it?

title: Professional Schools Read Mixed Signs in Bakke Decision
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  Professional schools are now selecting their entering classes for next fall, and many administrators are finding that last year's Supreme Court decision in the Bakke case sent out decidedly mixed signals.

title: Cigarette Output Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI) Cigarette production rose 13 percent from 1972 through 1977, the Census Bureau said today. According to its preliminary report, the value of cigarettes made in that period grew to $6.1 billion from $3.6 billion. The industry's payroll climbed to $567.7 million from $344.7 million, while the number of employees rose 2 percent to 39 million from 38.1 million.

title: Insurer Plans To Meet on Offer
description: James D. Koehnen, president of the American ReInsurance Company, said that the company's board would meet next Tuesday morning to consider the recently announced proposal by the Lincoln National Corpoation to acquire American ReInsurance for stock valued at about $295 million.

title: G.A.O. Checks Jones Cult Links to Welfare
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13  The General Accounting Office of Congress has subpoenaed records of welfare payments made by the California Department of Social Services in an attempt to discover if significant amounts of public funds were siphoned into the People's Temple bank accounts.

title: U.S. to Seek a Hearing By Full Appeals Court In the Case of Mandel
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  The Justice Department said today that it would seek a rehearing before the entire bench of Federal appeals court whose threejudge panel last month overturned the mail fraud and bribery conviction of former Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland in a 2to1 ruling.

title: Credit Card Directory To Be Published
description: One of life's embarrassing moments can be trying to pay for a meal with a credit card and finding out that the restaurant does not take them, a situation you could never imagine by watching American Express commercials.

title: BUSINES5 PEOPLE
description: Jumping from the frying pan into the fire may not be the precise words to describe Stuart M. Reed's impending move from the American Motors Corporation to the Consolidated Rail Corporation, but there can be little doubt that both the automobile manufacturer and Conrail have had more than their share of financial problems. The 53yearold Mr. Reed is moving to Conrail headquarters in Philadelphia as president and chief operating officer, the No. 2 person in the heirarchy of the Governmentsponsored railroad behind the chairman, Edward G. Jordan.

title: New Yorkers, etc
description: ALMOST no one in New York is on time for anything, which is very strange, because apparently the city is populated by punctual people. The punctual people can be divided into two groups, those who do, in fact, show up when they're supposed to, and those who don't, but only because circumstances have conspired against them.

title: Aid to Neediest Characterized By Compassion
description: Donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which is now in its 67th year, come in almost every day, sometimes in large amounts, sometimes in small, with requests to help the elderly and requests to help the very young, in memory of a relative or a friend, sometimes from individuals and sometimes from businesses.

title: Jean Renoir, Director of Grand Illusion Film, Dies
description: Jean Renoir. one of the great international film directors of the 20th century, best known for his 1937 antiwar drama, The Grand Illusion, died of a heart attack Monday night in Los Angeles. He was 84 years old.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Chess:
description: Can a leopard change his spots? In this game, you cannot rule out anything.

title: U.S. Is Said to Reject Bid Of Saudis for Iran's F14's
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  Carter Administration officials said today that Saudi Arabia had recently raised the possibility of buying advanced Americanmade fighter planes from Iran, but that the idea had been turned down by the Defense Department.

title: Added Rise In Oil Price Predicted
description: Oil analysts are predicting that another general increase in world oil prices is in the making because the cutoff of Iranian exports has tightened the market, forcing openmarket prices to a record $23 a barrel.

title: State Aide Says Koch Must Apply Contingency cuts to 1980 Budget
description: Calling Mayor Koch overoptimistic about Federal and state aid to New York City, the special state comptroller for the city said yesterday that he believed contingency cuts in the 1980 budget plan must be made to close the budget gap.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I recently found a recipe for macaroons, and one ingredient was almond paste. Can this be purchased or is it necessary to prepare the almonds in a food processor?

title: Toronto's Soccer Team Is Renamed the Blizzard
description: TORONTO, Feb. 13 (UPI)  The Global Television Network, which recently took control of the Toronto franchise in the North American Soccer League, renamed the team the Blizzard today.

title: Economic Scene
description: THE revolution in Iran will mean enormous losses for a host of American companies. Among the military contracts canceled are $3.2 billion for 160 F16 fighters from General Dynamics, $1.1 billion for seven Airborne Warning and Control Systems (AWACS) from Boeing, more than $700 million for two destroyers from Litton Systems, $500 million for 20 F4 Phantom reconnaissance aircraft from McDonnell Douglas and a long list of other contracts. bringing the total to about $12 billion.

title: Met Switches 2 Operas
description: The Metropolitan Opera was obliged to switch operas last night, giving Verdi's Don Carlo in place of Strauss's Ariadne auf Naxos. The change was caused by the illness of Leontyne Price, who was to have sung the title role for the first time with the company, as well as the illness of her standby, Teresa Kubiak.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: F.W. Woolworth is a century old this year, which gave us an excuse to visit the fabled Woolworth building and see what bargains the stores will have for spring and summer. Anyone with an eye for fashion will find it worthwhile to browse through the surprising buys in the stores that used to be known as the fiveanddime. A Lycra swimsuit with a very tow back, for instance, is priced at $11.99. Bikinis are $6.99. Allcotton jeans in lovely colors such as pink, yellow, light blue or ivory are $13.99. Don't miss the terry cloth sports things: strapless beach rompers with elasticized tops ($6.99); a camisole and jogging shorts outfit ($7.99); handsome batwingsleeved tops in deep, brilliant colors ($10.99); a striped terry sundress ($4.99). Woolworth's still carries the famous landlady's shoe made of rubbersoled canvas and has imported scads of woodsoled mules, which are a current fad ($5.99 and $7.99). The store on 39th Street opposite Macy's and the one on Dey Street near the World Trade Center are the best branches for clothes.

title: The Region
description: JERSEY CITY  A threealarm fire of undetermined origin swept through a fourstory school in Jersey City shortly before midnight last night. No one was injured, but damage to the building, Public School 30, was said to be heavy by the time the fire was brought under control, shortly after 1 A.M.

title: Islanders Set Back Rockies
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb 13  I'm convinced that hockey players should only take a vacation during the summer, said Bill Torrey, general manager of the Islanders, tonight.

title: Miller Sees Continued High Rates
description: G. William Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said in New York yesterday that interest rates would remain at historically high levels for an extended time and that the United States would continue to mount a strong defense of the dollar.

title: Valentine's Day Specials
description: When Emily Hahn was a child, people made their own Valentines. [Page Cl.] Today, there are treasures in the stores  a heartshaped diamond solitaire ring at Van Cleef & Arpels for $19,000; cookie hearts; candy hearts at the Hallmark Gallery, 56th Street and Fifth Avenue, and an antique Forget Me Not card at Bergdorf Goodman.

title: Citicorp Note Rate Up
description: The average rate in Citicorp's weekly sale of 91day notes yesterday rose for the first time in seven weeks. The bank holding company reported that it sold $100 million at an average rate of 10.213 percent, up from 10.150 percent last week. Accepted bids ranged in rate from a low of 10.195 to high of 10.215, with 88 percent of the orders made at the highest rate accepted; $584 million in orders for the notes were submitted.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Copper Price Cut
description: ASARCO Inc. announced yesterday that it was reducing the spot price on electrolytic copper to 88 cents a pound after raising it to 90 cents a pound last week. The move by ASARCO was to bring its prices more in line with world prices.

title: Illegally Dumped Chemicals Found in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 (AP) About 1,700 barrels of illegally dumped chemicals have been unearthed at a dump here, while in nearby Chester, a Congressman is asking the Federal Government to help clean up 3,000 drums filled with industrial wastes.

title: Disbursal of Olin Penalty Stirs a Wave of Criticism
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 13  The manner in which a $500,000 Federal penalty levied against the Olin Corporation last March for illegal sales of firearms to South Africa was allocated to 25 charitable groups in this city has provoked a wave of criticism by city officials and black leaden. They criticized disbursement of $60,000 of the money to two organizations headed by two members of a panel that was appointed to distribute the fine.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, Feb. 5, to Sunday. Feb. 11), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: Energy Issues Spur Market Advance
description: Energy issues led the stock market to a broadbased advance yesterday. Natural gas, coal and oilfield equipment issues shared in the gains, while more than 1,000 issues rose in price on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: St. John's Conquers Holy Cross by 8266
description: St. John's is playing the best basketball in the East

title: TV: Caesar Tailored to Small Screen
description: THE new BBC1V and TimeLife Television coproduction of Julius Caesar, which will be shown on Channel 13 at 8 P.M. this evening, begins the complete series of Shakespeare's plays that the Public Broadcasting Service plans to televise over the course of six Years. If Julius Caesar is indicative, these are not simple recordings of productions designed for the stage, nor are they even translated onto film in the usual way. These versions of Shakespeare will be vigorously adapted for television, with attention to the particular demands and drawbacks of the medium. The techniques used in filming Julius Caesar are very evidently  and often very successfully geared to the small screen.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: A tender offer involving two major aircargo carriers has been blocked by Judge Constance Baker Motley in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Dancing to a Middle Eastern Beat
description: They build much vaster high school auditoriums today than they did when the visitor had to attend assemblies and tardy study hall in theth, and this one was big enough to put him in mind of Radio City Music Hall. But when the performance began he was suddenly taken back in time not to the great golden palace or the movies on Avenue of the Americas, Manhattan, but to a far more modest house, the Gayety, at 9th and G Streets, Washington, D.C.

title: Leon and Bob Are Chums Again
description: Leon Spinks and Bob Arum made it up at the Waldorf yesterday. It was touching. The former heavyweight champion of the world and the man who promoted his major bouts had severed diplomatic relations last September after Muhammad Ali reclaimed the championship he had lent to Leon seven months earlier. At that time Arum attributed Leon's defeat to a liquid' training diet and Spinks responded with a defamation suit. So yesterday these starcrossed chums called in the press to witness their reconciliation.

title: Merger Proposal For Westchester Declared Invalid
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 13  A plan to merge the Westchester County Parkway Police with the sheriffs office, approved by a 2to1 vote in a referendum last November, was declared invalid and unconstitutional today by Justice George Beisheim Jr. of State Supreme court.

title: Market Place
description: WHEN a major takeover battle looms, one of the first things that often goes is a sense of humor. Instead of mirthmaking, each side grimly hires top legal counsel and one of the halfdozen investment bankers with a reputation for helping or defeating takeovers, whichever is called for. Then the fight begins in earnest.

title: U.S. Sales To Jamaica Are Studied
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (Reuters) The Agriculture Department said today that it was investigating United States Governmentfinanced commodity sales to Jamaica over the past three to four years to see if illegal payments had been made to Jamaican Government officials.

title: Mayor Opposes Teacher Accord A Second Time
description: Mayor Koch has rejected for a second time the contract negotiated by the Board of Education with the 65,000member United Federation of Teachers.

title: Califano Sees 10% Saving
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP)  The nation could save at least 10 percent on its projected health bill of $730 billion in 1990 by adopting a national health insurance plan with strict cost control, Secretary Califano said today.

title: U.N. Gives China $15 Million to Modernize
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 13 China will receive a $4 million computer and help in training technicians as part of a $15 million aid program approved by the United Nations Development Program

title: 3 Competing Films on TV Among Top 15 for Week
description: In the clash of powerhouse movies on all three networks last Sunday night, creating the most expensive programming competition in the history of television, a threehour madefortelevision film biography of Elvis Presley on ABCTV outpointed Gone With the Wind and One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest in the national audiencepopularity ratings.

title: Canada in Mourning Over Hockey Defeat
description: TORONTO, Feb. 13  A distressed and saddened store clerk raised his eyes to greet some arriving customers. Hello. they said. Isn't it awful? he replied.

title: Letters
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY. FEB. 13. 1979

title: Israelis, Looking to Egyptian Pact, Weigh a 25% Cut in Arms Outlay
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 13 Defense Minister Ezer Weizman told Defense Secretary Harold Brown today that Israel planned to reduce its military requirements by about 25 percent over the next 10 years because the Government expected to sign a peace treaty with Egypt soon, according to American sources.

title: Jury Begins Deliberations in Letelier Murder Case
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP)  A jury of seven women and five men began deliberations today in the Orlando Letelier assassination trial after a judge told them to ignore feelings or emotions or bias or prejudice in reaching a verdict.

title: Judge Johnson Studied For Appeals Court Post
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 13 Federal District Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr., whose decisions in civil rights and related fields have brought him national attention, is among five Alabama men recommended by a nominating committee for appointment to new seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

title: Revue: When Hell Freezes Over
description: RECIPE for an evening of theater that works well, even without a script: Take the works of two dozen poets and have them performed by seven attractive and talented young performers who recite, sing and dance, accompanied by a halfdozen good musicians. Stir well and you have a delectable feast that goes under the title, When Hell Freezes Over, I'll Skate.

title: William L. Staehle, 67, A Banker in New Jersey
description: William L. Staehle, president of the National Community Bank of New Jersey, died yesterday at the Passaic (N.J.) General Hospital. Mr. Staehle, who was also president and a director of the Arcadia National Bank in Secaucus, N.J., was 67 years old. He lived in Rutherford, N.J.

title: British Banks Set 13.5% Rate
description: LONDON, Feb. 13 (Reuters)  Major British banks raised their interest rates on loans by a percentage point today, to 13.5 percent, tightening up on credit but not by suite as much as had been expected.

title: Bronx Hospital Evacuated in Cold
description: More than 200 patients were transferred from the state's Bronx Psychiatric Center to other institutions last night because of what the hospital's director called a chronically inadequate heating system that had allowed temperatures in some wards to drop to as low as 20 degrees.

title: Making Prosciutto at Home
description: It always comes as a surprise to some people to learn that country ham (prosciutto type), French Rosette and even the Swiss Bunderfleish of the Grisons are just plain, uncooked, raw meat. The greatest hams in the world. such as Bayonne from the southwest of France, Westphalia from Czechoslovakia and Parma from Italy, are all uncooked country hams, served raw in very thin slices with bread and butter or with sweet fruits such as melon or figs.

title: Border Region Is Almost a Country Unto Itself, Neither Mexican Nor American
description: EL PASO, Tex.  Not very many years ago this was an obscure mountain village far from anywhere, a rough, mean little town flanked by an empty desert to the south and, to the north, fabled badlands that were braved only by wanted criminals and other desperados.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets reversed their field yesterday morning and made a fairly substantial advance after opening lower.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Visit to Canada Tested French Leader's Diplomacy
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 13  Prime Minister Raymond Barre of France returned home today from a delicate sixday diplomatic mission that required him to express solidarity with Frenchspeaking Quebec without upsetting the Canadian Government.

title: Watershed for Amtrak: Even More Cuts May Be Coming
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  A Carter Administration plan to cut the Amtrak railroad system nearly in half looms as more than a strategy for efficiency. It appears to mark a watershed for the eightyearold railroad, friends and foes of the network agree.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Kaiser Rebuilds in Smog Fight
description: FONTANA, Calif., Feb. 9  The Kaiser Steel Corporation, with the West's largest steel plant here 45 miles downwind from Los Angeles, has been caught up in the controversy over who should clean up the air.

title: Some Arabs Boycotting Parley
description: VALLETTA, Malta, Feb. 13 (Reuters)  Several Arab countries boycotted the opening of an international meeting or cooperation in the Mediterranean today because Egypt and Israel were present. Libya. Aleeria. Syria and Lebanor stayed away. Delegates from Morocco and Tunisia were also reported absent although there was no confirmation that they would not attend later sessions.

title: Careers
description: AMONG some management recruiters and employment experts, the belief is that 1979 will be a lively year in executive suites, with the usual musical chairs being played as top officials change jobs and with a few sour notes being sounded, mainly on middle management levels.

title: Car Recovered, but in Parts
description: When a police stakeout team saw a car with JSC license plates roll into an alleged auto chop shop in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn late yesterday morning they quickly traced the car to State Supreme Court Justice Julius A. Hellenbrand, who hours earlier had reported it stolen from outside his Plaza Street home in Brooklyn.

title: Hanoi MIG21 Patrols Increase ChinaBorder Tension
description: HONG KONG. Feb. 13  Vietnam has begun using MIG21 fighters to patrol its frontier with China after recent flights over Vietnamese territory by Chinese warplanes, analysts here say, raising the chance of an accidental encounter between the air forces of the two countries.

title: Brezhnev Reported on Vacation
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 13 (Reuters)  The Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, who has not been seen in public since Jan. 25, was officially reported on vacation. The press agency Tass, reporting on a telephone conversation that Mr. Brezhnev had with the visiting French Foreign Minister, Jean FrancoisPoncet, said today that the 72yearold leader was on leave outside Moscow.

title: Taking On the Moor
description: Tonight, public television features Julius Caesar, the first in the British Broadcasting Corporation's planned series of all Shakespeare's plays  to be shown in this country over a period of six years.

title: On Valentine's Day, A Buried Treasure
description: SOMEBODY in the family had lent me an alarm clock, set it for 5:30, and carefully explained how to turn it off so that I wouldn't wake up everybody else in the house when it rang. It was evening on Feb. 13, and I simply had to get myself ready before going to school next day, because we were to have a valentine box.

title: After Baby, Whither the Career?
description: WHEN she was pregnant. Marjorie Goldsmith had it all figured out. Her baby wotdd be born in the spring, and by Labor Day she would be back to tun swing at her position as director of a Queens daycare center. That's not the way things turned out.

title: A Chicago Valentine For Moran
description: CHICAGO  I suppose nearly every Chicagoan has a story that runs like this: Several years ago. I was making conversation with a guide through one of the Mayan ruins of the Yucatan. We were hunched in a steep dirt aisles that inclines to the top of a pyramid and he asked me where I was from. At the sound of Chicago, he trained two fingers at my face and, right before the Sun God, rattled his lips off like the ratatat report of tommygun fire. Sheecago, he said, Al Capone!

title: Many Plans,  la Sills, For the City Opera
description: Ever since the appointment of Beverly Sills as director of the New York City Opera was announced, the operatic world has been thick with rumors. Beverly was going to turn the company inside out. Beverly was going to make it an international house. Beverly was dickering with Montserrat Caballe to sing the three Elizabethan heroines of Donizetti. Beverly was going to get Sutherland and Pavarotti. Beverly was going to make the Metropolitan Opera weep.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, Feb 13, 1979

title: Arctic Air Mass Brings Hardship To New Yorkers
description: The arctic air mass that has brought extremely low temperatures and snow to the Northeast region continued to create misery yesterday. It brought death and hardship to the poor and to isolated elderly people, and it inconvenienced commuters, caused the closing of some schools and slowed business activity.

title: John Gilligan's Departing Message
description: John Gilligan, an energetic former Ohio Congressman and Governor, was appointed by President Carter to carry out his campaign promise to double development assistance abroad and to direct it to the poor. As A.I.D. Administrator, Mr. Gilligan fought hard for the funds and structure needed for a bilateral aid program. When the Administration changed its priorities and lowered its sights, he fought harder and now is being replaced. But the issues remain.

title: Court Blocks AirCargo Bid
description: A tender offer involving two major aircargo carriers has been blocked by Judge Constance Baker Motley in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Labor Dept. Asserts 150,000 Jobs In the CETA Plan Are Not Filled
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP)  The Labor Department, which has money to create more than a quarter of a million public service jobs this year for the longterm unemployed, says that 150.000 jobs are going unfilled because of problems in meeting tougher Government rules.

title: Black Leader Leans to Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP)  Representative Cardiss Collins, the new head of the Congressional Black Caucus, says that President Carter will have a hard time getting the black vote in 1980 and that she leaned to Senator Edward M. Kennedy for President. The Illinois Democrat said that Mr. Kennedy seems to be right on target when it comes down to things that affect minority people.

title: News Service Awarded SatelliteStations Permit
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI)  The Common Carrier Bureau of the Federal Communications Commission has approved an application by United Press International to build and operate up to 30 receiving stations in a test system for distribution of news by satellite.

title: Irish Water Spaniel Best at Westminster
description: A livercolored, curly coated Irish water spaniel, Ch. Oak Tree's Irishtocrat, better known as Dugan, stood alone in the center of a greenmatted ring in Madison Square Garden last night after capturing bestinshow honors at the Westminster Kennel Club event.

title: Another Group to Fly From Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 13 (Reuters) group of 144 Americans and Cuban dependents will fly to the United States from Havana tomorrow, the fourth such planeload in a year, the State Department said today. The latest group. which consists of 47 people holding both American and Cuban citizenship and 97 Cuban dependents, will fly to Miami aboard a plane chartered from Air Belize, Hodding Carter 3d, the State Department spokesman, said.

title: Concert: With Sollberger on Flute
description: LAST season the Group for Contemporary Music decided to move its chambermusic concerts at the Manhattan School of Music from the Hubbard Recital Hall to, of all places, the school cafeteria. Judging from Monday night's concert there, the new setting, far from seeming incongruous, provides an unusually friendly, comfortable forum for new music. And the music itself was well worth hearing.

title: 22 Hurtin Georgia Collision
description: MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., Feb. 13 (AP)  Twentytwo persons were injured when a school bus and a Baldwin County Sheriff's Department car collided on state Route 112 near here the authorities said. Norman Neder, administrator of the Baldwin County Hospital, said that 20 children and two adults were treated in the emergency room after the accident. Sheriff Louie Arrington said the bus was carrying about 30 children from the Southside Elementary School.

title: Manson Beats Borg In FirstRound Upset
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif., Feb. 13 (AP)  Bruce Manson, the world's 112thranked player, scored a 67, 75, 61 victory today over Bjorn Borg of Sweden in a firstround match of the $250,000 Tennis Games at Mission Hills Country Club.

title: Legalized Imperial Calendar Sought by Japan's Rightists
description: TOKYO, Feb. 13  The noisy little trucks seem almost everywhere, flying their risingsun flags, carrying heavy-lettered slogans, blaring out patriotic songs on powerful speakers and speeding through the streets of Tokyo with men in uniforms and helmets standing erect on platforms on the back, as if charging into battle.

title: World News Briefs
description: PARIS, Feb. 13 (Reuters)  Rebel forces in the African nation of Chad appeared to control most of the capital of Ndjamena and were reported to be advancing into the city's predominantly white suburbs, French Government sources said here late today. Attempts to bring about a ceasefire had so far been unsuccessful, the sources added. [Agence FrancePresse reported from Ndjamena that fighting had died down during the night.]

title: COMMENT ON P.L.O. STIRS ISRAELI FUROR
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 13  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan said here today that while the Palestine Liberation Organization was not a state, we cannot deny their position or their value in the Middle East conflict. The remarks drew Government denials that there had been any change in policy on the Palestinian group and it provoked calls by the opposition for a debate in Parliament.

title: GasolineStation Groups Split on Sunday Closings
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 13 (AP)  The leaders of the Illinois Gasoline Dealers' Association and other industry officials around the country have begun to urge that filling stations close on Sundays to conserve gasoline. But many others are saying that such a step is not needed yet.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Gateway Transportation Company of La Crosse, Wis., a motor carrier, has elected Emerson W. Swan vice chairman and chief executive officer. Howard M. Gregory was elected president.

title: 2 U.S. Jews Hold Talk With Khomgini Aide On Outlook for Rights
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  A prominent American Jewish figure reported today that he and a colleague had met privately Saturday with representatives of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in New York City in an effort to allay Jewish anxieties about the fate of Iranian Jews under the new Government.

title: Pippin Pye and Other Olde Recipes
description: N number of dishes and change of meat, the nobilitie of England (whose cookes are for the most part musicallheaded Frenchmen and strangers) doo most exceed, ex claimed William Harrison in his Description of England in Shakespeare's Youth in 1577. Now, thanks to a series of facsimile reprints published by Walter J. Johnson Inc., the cookbooks consulted in kitchens of Shakespeare's contemporaries are available to any modern cook with the desire to taste cartes of spinage and the patience to read recipes in old English type.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Books of The Times
description: THE BUNKER. By James P. O'Donnell. 399 pages. Illustrated. Houghton Mifflin. $13.95.

title: BUDGET BALANCERS WARNED BY MUSKIE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  Voicing the feelings of an increasing number of legislators on Capitol Hill, Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine warned today that if the states succeeded in amending the Constitution to mandate a balanced budget, Federal aid to the states would be the primary target of budget cutters.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Columbia's Rennie Resigns To Take Duke Soccer Post

title: Attack on Indian Official Foiled
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 13 (Reuters)  A young man lunged with a knife at Ram Naresh Yadav, chief minister of Uttar Pradesh, today in Lucknow, the states capital, but be was seized by security guards and Mr. Yadev was only scratched, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: Rosalind Browne, 62; Was Abstract Painter, Teacher and Historian
description: Rosalind Bengelsdorf Browne, whose career in art including working as a painter, art critic, teacher and historian, died Saturday of cancer in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Prague Tests Visits Abroad for Dissidents
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 9  Over the last two months, several of Czechoslovakia's leading dramatic artists, who had been on their country's political blacklist for a decade, have been allowed to go to Vienna in an experiment that their friends and associates back home hope may result in the opening of a small window on the Western world.

title: Missing Party of Scouts Is Safe at a Ski Resort
description: SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 13 (UPI)  Nine Boy Scouts and four troop leaders  missing for 26 hours in the high Sierra  walked into a ski resort today, ending a desperate search by dozens of rescuers braving blinding snow and the risk of avalanches.

title: WASHINGTON
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 13  The United States Government is getting a bad press down here on the grounds that it is trying to buy Mexican gas at cutrate prices. But although there are over 20 newspapers in this fabulous city, none of them have taken the trouble to explain Washington's side of the controversy.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: Death

title: Letter: On Costly Farm Land
description: To the Editor:

title: Kitchen Equipment The Chinois
description: YOU may have the impression that I am attracted to every dagadget that comes along. And I am  at least until I find out whether a new tool works. But that doesn't mean I am fickle. Over the years I have developed some enduring allegiances to various pieces of equipment. One of them is a chinois that I bought 30 years ago and for which I feel so much affection that I bought two similar ones in recent years as wedding presents for my daughters.

title: Carter Is Told Hospital Cost Plan Is Facing Hurdle
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI)  Representative Henry A. Waxman, chairman of the House Commerce Committee's Health Subcommittee, told President Carter today that his bill to contain hospital costs would have difficulty passing this Congress.

title: ARAB LEADERS CALL IRAN SHIFT HISTORIC
description: Arab leaders around the Persian Gulf agreed yesterday that the fall of the Iranian monarchy marked a historic turning point and a change in the regional balance of power. Their reactions ranged from profound apprehension to open elation.

title: Court Rules Arguing About Tips Isn't a Cabby's Job
description: ALBANY, Feb. 13 (AP)  It is not part of a taxicab driver's job to argue with passengers about the size of a tip, the state's highest court affirmed today.

title: TV: Dolly And Carol
description: DOLLY AND CAROL IN NASHVILLE, an hourlong television special to be seen tonight at 10 on the CBS network, is a relaxed, goodnatured affair. It is certainly no monument to serious culture, or even to serious popular culture. It doesn't begin to test the considerable talents of either Dolly Parton or Carol Burnett. But, on its own terms, it has its charms.

title: Simpson Paces lets Over Kings, 111102
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Feb. 13  The topic of conversation had been discussed in the past tense, in hushed tones, with sad shakes of the head. Not tonight.

title: Pakistani High Court Delays Bhutto's Death
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Wednesday, Feb. 14 The Supreme Court of Pakistan today granted former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto an indefinite stay of execution until it can consider his petition for a review of his case.

title: Climatologists Are Warned North Pole Might Melt
description: GENEVA, Feb. 13  There is a real possibility that some people now in their infancy will live to a time when the ice at the North Pole will have melted, a change that would cause swift and perhaps catastrophic changes in climate.

title: Albany Senate Rejects InsuranceExchange Bill
description: ALBANY, Feb. 13  The New York State Senate acted tonight to reject the proposed constitution and bylaws under which the state's new insurance exchange would have operated. The rejection came despite an agreement in principle between the Carey administration and Republican leaders over changes in the rules.

title: Swiss Bankers To Stand Trial
description: GENEVA, Feb. 13  A scandal that rocked the Swiss financial community nearly two years ago will get its first hearing in court when the two former chief officers of the Chiasso branch of the Swiss Credit Bank and three codefendants go on trial in the spring.

title: Technology
description: CONSIDERABLE controversy and no small amount of publicity have centered in the last few months on the efficiency of the 911 emergency telephone number. Yet most residents of large cities seem to take the system's existence for granted.

title: Algeria's Neglected Consumers Speak Out
description: ALGIERS  What good is all that oil ?? gas if we can't even find spare parts, ?? bulbs or potatoes at times? an Al?? an construction worker complained ?? other day. He has a job in France and ?? come to take his family back where ??e's something to buy for your ??ey.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: LOS ANGELES  Our political elites have for years measured the immensity of our military power in terms of the apocalyptic outcome of an attack on an adversary's population. One submarineload of missiles, only 2 percent of our strategic force, the State of the Union Message tells us, could destroy Soviet large  and mediumsized cities. It is tempting to think of that horror as an allpurpose deterrent. Secretary of Defense Harold Brown, however, in his recent Defense Report, recognizes that it is not, that our European allies, for example, do not regard it as a credible response even to nuclear threats against them.

title: Saying He Wrote Critical Paper, Italy Orders U.S. Citizen to Leave
description: ROME, Feb. 13 (Reuters)  The Italian Government tonight ordered the expulsion of Domenic A. Perrone, an American official said to have written highly critical report on Italy's secret service.

title: TV: New Here to Eternity on NBC
description: THERE is so much exposed male and female flesh and so little life in the television remake of From Here to Eternity that it might more aptly have been titled The Naked and the Dead. NBC will show it in three weekly installments of two hours each, with the first from 9 to 11 o'clock tonight.

title: Another Maloney Joins the Rangers
description: The Rangers called up Don Maloney, a rookie left wing, from their New Haven affiliate in the American Hockey League yesterday.

title: U.N. Work Stoppage Ends
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 13 (AP)  A United Nations spokesman said today that the work stoppage that started here Jan. 21 has ended with an agreement that Secretary General Kurt Waldheim would appoint an independent person of high international standing to look into the problems. About 250 translators and typists had refused to operate new computer terminals on the ground they emitted harmful radiation.

title: Injustice Against Bhutto In 2 Courts
description: Zulfikar All Bhutto, who faces execution by the Pakistani military Government on a charge of ordering the killing in 1979 of an obscure political opponent, is twice the victim of unfair judicial proceedings. Will he now be the victim of legalized political murder? spired  it was not he but his father who was killed in ambush  is so inconsequential a figure as to have hardly been a rival or a political threat.

title: Borg Upset by Manson
description: Bruce Manson upset Bjorn Borg in three sets yesterday in the first round of a $250,000 tennis tournament in California. Details on Page B6.

title: Around the Nation
description: HUDSON, Mich., Feb. 13 (AP)  Two southern Michigan school districts with a total of 2,546 students closed down today because of an outbreak of influenza that pushed absenteeism to about 30 percent.

title: Personal Health
description: IF the shoe fits, wear it. In principle, few would disagree with this sage advice. But judging from what many people, especially women, put on their feet, a more accurate description of the situation is, If the shoe doesn't fit, wear it anyway.

title: AMIC Ratifies Merrill Merger
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the largest and most diversified brokerage firm holding company in the United States, will move one step further into the insurance and real estate businesses today. The company said that it expected to consummate a previously announced merger with the AMIC Corporation, an insurance holding company, following the approval of AMIC's shareholders yesterday.

title: Bar Unit Backs Changes In Disciplining Members
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 13 Major changes in the way the legal profession disciplines its wayward members were approved today by the American Bar Association's House of Delegates, its policymaking body.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: MRS. EMILIO TOMMASI

title: Yanks Bring In Reinforcements: Masseurs
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 13  Question: What baseball owner whose club already had a trainer and an assistant trainer would hire three masseurs to help his players stay loose?

title: Kirbo Seeks Right Buyer For Carter's Warehouse
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  Charles H. Kirbo, who oversees President Carter's peanut warehouse operation in Plains, Ga., says he would like to sell it but has not found the right buyer.

title: Shivering a Useful Signal of Overexposure
description: Aside from alcoholics and drug abusers, the people most vulnerable to ill effects from cold are the elderly and very young children. At all ages, the remedy is as much to preserve the body's own heat as to avoid overexposure to cold.

title: The Indian Brunch: Fragrant Feast
description: JULIE SAHNI was raised to be an achiever. When she was growing up in New Delhi during the 1940's, it was not just hoped, but expected, that she would make something of herself. A life in the kitchen was the last thing Mrs. Sahni's parents, both professionals, had in mind for the second of their four daughters. And, in fact, her achievements are considerable. She spent almost a decade as a professional dancer. She earned one degree in architecture, another in city planning. For the past nine years she has worked as an architect and designer for the city of New York. But what Mrs. Sahni really wants to do is cook. And so, rebelling in her own quiet way, she maintains her professional life while keeping alive her culinary passion. She teaches Indian cooking in her home in Brooklyn Heights, as well as in the Culinary Arts program at the New School for Social Research. Although while growing up in India she rarely cooked an entire meal on her own, she spent many hours around the kitchen, watching her mother and the family cook prepare the daily fare. She stored up her impressions so that someday she might recreate the spicy keernas, the puffy pooris and the sweet almond desserts of her childhood. While Indian cooking is her speciality, she is equally comfortable with the Chinese, French and Italian cuisines. I once went through a whole year where I cooked nothing but Chinese five nights a week, she said with a laugh, noting that she has taken cooking classes in several other cuisines. Now, more often than not, she prepares French and Italian foods during the weekend her native Indian dishes on weekends, when she spends her time testing recipes for classes and an upcoming cookbook. Often, a weekend Indian brunch will serve both as recipetesting session and as time to entertain. What I love about Indian food is the fragrance, she explained. When people think Indian food, they think of hotness, of spices, but they forget that it is the most aromatic of cuisines. I find Indian cooking not a science but an art, she went on, noting that there is not a great deal of complicated technique involved in preparing Indian food. Basically, if you know how to fry, there are few tricks to Indian food, she insisted. Spices, she said, are the most misunderstood ingredients in Indian cooking. Instead of thinking of spices as simply flavoring, they should be treated as a vegetable, and most should be cooked before eating. The reason people sometimes have digestion problems with Indian food is that they are eating raw spices. And some raw spices are very hard on the system, Mrs. Sahni explained. She suggested that when adding spices, particulary cumin or coriander, late in the preparation of a dish, the spices should always be dryroasted first, over medium heat in a wellseasoned pan. Mrs. Salmi also suggested that for use in Indian foods, the spices should be as fresh as possible, preferably purchased whole and ground just before using. And when four or five different spices are used, they should all be measured out before beginning the dish.

description: TRACY RUST and Rick Kaufmann have been together for more than eight years, buying and selling all kinds of furniture and decorative objects  what Mr. Kaufmann calls the super stuff.

title: Insider Reports for Exchanges
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: Music: Ashkenazv With the Cleveland
description: IT was only last week that Mstislav Rostropovich and the National Symphony Orchestra came to Carnegie Hall with a Brahms program consisting of the Fourth Symphony followed by the Piano Concerto No. 2. Last night in Carnegie Hall Lorin Maazel and the Cleveland Orchestra came to Carnegie Hall with the identical program. But, just to show how different great conductors can be, Mr. Maazel conducted the Concerto as the first number on his program, while Mr. Rostropovich reserved it for last.

title: Children's Defense Fund Criticizes Carter Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  Children did not fare as well as the generals and admirals in the Carter Administration's proposed budget for the fiscal year 1980, Marian Wright Edelman, director of the Children's Defense Fund, said at a news conference today.

title: Pachucos in Musical Zoot Suit
description: ZOOT SUIT, which began rehearsals yesterday heading for a March 25 opening at the Winter Garden, will put the pachuco in the Broadway spotlight for the first time. Luis Valdez, the 38yearold author and director of this play with music, defines pachuco as a cool, sharp hepcat, the Chicano zoot suiter of the 40's, the possessor of pachuquismo or pachuco pride.

title: 3 Bond Issues Have Rates Set
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks set rates yesterday on three issues of bonds they sold to refinance $1.2 billion of securities coming due Feb. 26 and to raise $800 million of additional money to help finance the housing industry.

title: Five Florida Officers Suspended After Raiding the Wrong House
description: MIAMI, Feb. 14 (AP)  Five policemen who stormed the wrong house in a narcotics raid have been suspended, and the authorities are investigating a school teacher's contention that he was beaten while the house was ransacked.

title: Indonesian Store Moves to SoHo
description: You might say that life has come full circle for Gordon Bishop. More than a decade ago, in his bachelor days. he lived in a SoHo loft at Prince Street and West Broadway. From there, he embarked on a lengthy trip to such enticing places as Afghanistan and Katmandu, finally settling for a long spell in Indonesia, where he studied the country's dance, ritual and drama.

title: Russian TV LinksU.S. To Attack on Embassy
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 19 (Resters) Soviet television said tonight that the guerrilla attack on the American Embassy in Teheran was designed to provide an excuse for American military intervention in Iran.

title: McGraw Fight Held Doubtful
description: Prospects for a proxy fight over control of the board of directors of McGrawHill Inc. appeared to dim yesterday with the decision by Allen & Company, the investment banking firm, not to take on the battle.

title: Vast French TV Audience Sees Start of Holocaust
description: PARIS, Feb. 14  A record 72 percent of French television viewers watched the first episode of the Holocaust series last night, partly in response to the publicity the series received here during its showing in West Germany.

title: Young Innovator In Fabric World
description: IT'S strictly Horatio Alger. Only our hero is Taiwanese: small build, delicate features, slim. Expressive hands. Has all his clothes custom made. Because of my exquisite size I can't get anything off the rack. He laughs, puckish and selfconfident.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, Feb. 14,1979

title: End of Long Coast Strike At Paper Mills Is Near
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14  Final settlement of a sevenmonth West Coast papermill strike, the industry's longest, was assured last night when union members approved a Boise Cascade Corporation contract substantially on company terms.

title: Soviet Azerbaijanis a World Away From Iranian Cousins
description: BAKU, U.S.S.R.  If there is any place in the Soviet Union where the Communist authorities might fear contagion from the Islamic protest movement in Iran that swept the Shah into exile, this city not far from the Iranian border would be it.

title: Two OneAct Orton Plays Coming to South Street
description: Two oneact plays by the late Joe Orton  Funeral Games and, in its American premiere, The Ruffian on the Stair  will be staged in a work: shop production at the South Street Theatre, beginning next Thursday.

title: A NIGHT OF TENSION ACROSS WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  The death of the American Ambassador in Afghanistan and the siege of the embassy in Iran created a night of crisis for the Carter Administration and came close to postponing President Carter's trip to Mexico today.

title: Suit Names Vishay On Industrial Spying
description: The Societe Franaise d'ElctroRsistance, a French electrical components company, said'it had filed a coontersuit against Vishay Intertechnology Inc. of Malverne, Pa. with the United States International Trade Commission accusing the American company of industrial espionage.

title: Talks to Stabilize World Wheat Price Break Down
description: GENEVA, Feb. 14  A conference called by the United Nations to conclude an agreement to stabilize world wheat prices collapsed tonight.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: TURNING a small space into a useful bathroom  more than a powder room  requires some ingenuity. The owner of the bathroom pictured here literally turned a small closet into a shower by tiling most of the room, putting a drain in the floor and mounting a shower head on the wall. He then added a toilet and sink, so that one very small room provides what is usually put in a much larger space.

title: The Editorial Notebook Mr. Ma, Mr. Ding and Me
description: Recent editorials and letters urging the study of the Chinese language by Amencans have my fervent support. based on six months I spent as an Army second lieutenant in Asia in World War IT, editing an ostensibly official Japanese Army Chineselanguage newspaper. This journal's true publisher was my employer, the Office of Strategic Services, which arranged to distribute it to civilians in occupied China. I managed my share of this complex feat despite the fact that I knew no word of Chinese or Japanese.

title: Talking Business
description: Japan and the United States have often seemed to be working at cross purposes in recent years. When the Japanese trade surplus rose, the American trade deficit grew. When the yen went up, the dollar slid.

title: AN ARAB PRODUCER LIFTS OIL PRICE 7%
description: Abu Dhabi is raising its oil prices about 7 percent, effective today, and, according to an authoritative trade source, Qatar is also lifting prices the same amount.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar was little changed in markets abroad yesterday and slipped against most major currencies in quiet New York trading. Gold prices were steady.

title: ARMED IRANIANS RUSH U.S. EMBASSY
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 14  Armed urban guerrillas attacked the American Embassy today and trapped Ambassador William H. Sullivan and about 100 members of his staff inside for more than two hours.

title: Pacers Set Back Knicks, 10697
description: INDIANAPOLIS. Feb. 19  Tom Barker, the man the Knicks got from the Boston Celtics along with three firstround draft choices in exchange for Bob McAdoo, arrived too late to help prevent tonight 's 10697 loss to the Indiana Pacers.

title: Yield of Wheat Is Doubled
description: Farther west, on his cleared and level fields among the stony hummocks along the Jihari River, Mr. Abdulghani raises other crops besides wheat. For irrigation he uses a system of pipes with two diesel pumps, at different levels, to raise water from the lowlying stream. There are steel harrows and disc plows in his barnyard, and at harvest time his storehouse is always full.

title: Television
description: Afternoon

title: Computer Concern Holds Discussions
description: Raymond E. High, chairman and president of Computer Communications Inc., said that preliminary discus. sions had been held with more than one large company, from which a possible business relationship or merger might evolve.

title: Irrigation Expected to Stem Flowing of Rivers Into Seas
description: GENEVA, Feb. 14 Withdrawal of irrigation water needed to feed the world's billions in the next century will probably halt the discharge of major rivers into the seas, according to projections presented to the World Climate Conference here.

title: World Gold
description: WEDNESDAY. FEB. 14,1979

title: Bucks Win, 115 to 94, Ending Nets Streak
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 14  The New Jersey Nets played well in the first quarter but poorly thereafter tonight and the Milwaukee Bucks went on to record a 11594 victory in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Harvester Net Rises Fourfold in Quarter
description: Profits of the International Harvester Company jumped more than fourfold to $58.8 million, or $1.91 a share, in the first fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31, from $10.6 million, or 32 cents a share, in the same period a year earlier, the Chicagobased company reported yesterday.

title: Bridge:
description: For more than a quarter of a century, Canada, one of the world's strongest bridgeplaying countries, has been underprivileged insofar as international championships are concerned. In thecontests for the Bermuda Bowl, the bridge equivalent of tennis's Davis Cup, there has never been a Canadian team, although two Canadian stars have been a part of the North American team. They would have been much better placed in Europe, or in other zones, where representation is decided by the zonal championship.

title: Ford Head Predicts Worldwide Sales Rise
description: The president of Ford, Philip Caldwell, predicted in New York yesterday that combined car and truck sales in the United States would reach 17 to 18 million by 1985, compared with the present level of 14.5 to 15 million now.

title: Norfolk Keeps Its Eyes Fixed on Growth
description: NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 14  When tenthgrade students in Virginia Beach, Chesapeake, Portsmouth, Newport News and Hampton  five of the seven incorporated cities afloat here on creeks, inlets and swamps  scored significantly higher in a recent statewide scholastic achievement test than those in Norfolk and Suffolk, the two other waterborne cities of the Hampton Roads area, it set this city's tireless civic boomers to work figuring out how to find the redemption in the scores.

title: 12 Composers Win Awards
description: The first Goddard Lieberson Fellowships to be awarded by the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters have none to Gerald Levinson. 28yearold assistant professor of composition and theory at Swarthmore College. and Bruce MacCombie, 36, assist. ant professor of music at the Yale School of Music. The fellowships, worth $10,000 each, are to be given annually in memory of the late president of the CBS Records Group and vice president of CBS Inc. Mr. Lieberson was also a composer.

title: How Iran Unrest Affects Rug Trade
description: WRILE Teheran reels with political and religious unrest, in the hills outside Kerman, in the relative serenity of southern Iran, weavers quietly continue working toward the multimillionth knot, practicing the andent craft that will end in a fine Persian carpet.

title: Airline Will Offer LowCost Service
description: Trans International Airlines plans to begin in May what it called the first completely unrestricted lowcost scheduled service from the United States to Amsterdam, Paris and Frankfurt. The new service would mark the entry of the carrier, the world's largest charter airline, into the scheduled field.

title: 4 Rockefeller Children Say All at Hand Did Their Best
description: Four children of Nelson A. Rockefeller said yesterday that they believed that on the night their father died of a heart attack last month all the people who tried to help acted responsibly.

title: Weather Tightens Icy Grip on Region
description: The bitter cold tightened its grip on the metropolitan area yesterday, bursting water pipes, forcing schools to close, stranding motorists, delaying commuters and threatening the health of the elderly. The National Weather Service said today would be worse.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WRITE ON A series of lectures at Columbia University about the influence of urban life on modern literature starts today, as does a display at Barnard College of rarely shown Walt Whitman manuscripts and books. And this afternoon, a prominent executive discusses her career at the Mercantile Club. The events are free.

title: Judge Allows Students To Sing Holiday Carols
description: RAPID CITY, S.D., Feb. 14 (AP) A Federal district judge has ruled that public school students in Sioux Falls may sing Christmas carols at holiday programs.

title: Artillery Exchanges in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 19 (AP) Rightwing Christian militiamen and Syrian forces exchanged artillery fire in Beirut and the surrounding mountains today, spokesmen for the rightists said. Four people were reported killed and 10 wounded. The rightists said Christian residential areas came under sudden and unprovoked Syrian shelling. The Syrian command had no comment on the charge.

title: TV: Women in White
description: ABRIEF catchup course: When the heroines of Women in Whiteiwere introduced last Thursday, in the first installment of this threepart NBC miniseries, they were established as a fairly hardboiled and highpowered bunch. Dr. Rebecca Dalton (Susan Flannery), a gorgeous iceblonde with a perpetually quizzical frown, had just been appointed Biscayne General Hospital's chief of staff, even though newcomers always mistook her soontobeexhusband, the other Dr. Dalton, for the person in power.

title: Hanoi Asserts Chinese Occupy Vietnam Area And Fire on Villages
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 14 (Reuters) North Vietnam said today that a battalion of Chinese troops had moved into Vietnamese territory and was shelling villages every day.

title: MEXICAN CHIEF GIVES CARTER A WARNING
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 19  President Jos Lopez Portillo warned President Carter bluntly today that Mexico would settle for nothing less than being treated with dignity and respect, and he said that our peoples want defintive ag??ments, ?? ?? concessions.

title: Dispute Between Two Carter Aides Mires Economic Development Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 An intense, occasionally heated controversy between two senior. White House aides has led to an impasse within the Carter Administration on a proposal to place all Federal economic development activities in a single, Cabinetlevel agency.

title: U.S. Plans to Start Airlift of 7,000 From Iran When Airport Reopens
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  The United States Government, reacting to the attack on its embassy in Teheran, plans to begin evacuating most of the remaining 7,000 Americans in Iran this weekend, officials said today.

title: CALLAGHAN REPORTS A DEAL WITH UNIONS
description: LONDON. Feb. 19  Prime Minister James Callaghan announced today a sweeping economic concordat between the Government and the trade unions.

title: NEW DRUG RELIEVES ACNE IN FIRST TESTS
description: BOSTON, Feb. 14 (UPI)  Successful preliminary tests on a new drug have shown dramatic and impressive results in clearing up severe and unsightly acne, researchers reported today.

title: 15,000 Deer Lost to Starvation
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Feb. 14 (AP) Vermont lost 15,000 whitetrailed deer to starvation last year, one of the biggest losses in the nation's history, according to biologists.

title: Westchester Road Plan Said Ask 100% Toll Rise
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 14  The State Transportation Commissioner will recommend that the state take over five Westchester parkways and double tolls on two of them for 10 years to pay for improvements, legislative sources said today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Feb. 14 (AP)  Mel Purcell and Linda Siegel won singles matches in straight sets today to advance the defending United States team into the semifinals of an under21 tennis competition.

title: Duke Romps Over N.C. State
description: DURHAM, N.C., Feb. 14 (AP)Mike Grninski scored 21 ?? to lead Duke to a 6648 victory over Atlantic ?? oast Conference rival North Carolina ciAte tonight and tighten the Blue Devils grip on the conference lead.

title: U.S. Asserts Afghans Ignored Pleas Not to Attack Abductors of Envoy
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb.14  The United States Ambassador to Afghanistan, Adolph Dubs, was abducted today by a group of Afghans described as rightwing Moslem terrorists and then shot to death.

title: Car Explodes in Oklahoma City, Causing a Pileup That Injures 8
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 14 (AP)  A car exploded in dense fog at a busy intersection in the southwestern part of this city today, causing a 20vehicle pileup that injured eight persons, the authorities said.

title: TV Sequel to Roots': Inevitable Question
description: There has never been a program on television to compare with  Roots.

title: Zaire's Copper and Cobalt Mines Resume Production
description: KOLWEZI, Zaire  Recovering quickly from the dislocations of the invasion last May, the mines of Shaba Province are again operating at an impressive level, turning out the copper and cobalt that are the lifeblood of Zaire's economy.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Unmaking a Ghetto
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has won a court victory that sounds perverse but in fact is likely to have a major  and overdue  impact on national housing policy. At the behest of the N.A.A.C. P. and several local groups white and black  in the Stapleton area of Staten Island, a Federal judge has blocked construction of a Federally financed lowincome project because the area already has ton large a concentration of minorities and the poor. In other words, the court said that the Department of Housing and Urban Development cannot further segregate a community.

title: Sabres Top Islanders, 21
description: Ric Selling scored the deciding goal with 7 minutes 32 seconds to play as the Buffalo Sabres defeated the New York Islanders, 21, last night. Page B17.

title: Basque Rebels Kill Army Officer
description: VITORIA, Spain, Feb. 14 (Reuters) A gunman shot and killed an army lieutenant colonel today in this Basque regional center. Separatist guerrillas claimed credit for the shooting. The victim was the third senior military officer killed this year by the rebels.

title: Sound
description: SHAKESPEARE's request to lend one's ears has a special meaning for me because mine are constantly being borrowed. Speaker manufacturers ask me to listen to their wares before bringing them to market, and friends take me shopping with them to help them pick loudspeakers.

title: 140,000 Zaire Refugees Home
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 14 (Reuters) About 140,000 Zairian refugees have returned home from Angola, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said today. Poul Hartling told a news conference that the refugees returned to Shaba Province after President Mobutu Sese Seko granted a general amnesty.

title: The Region
description: ALBANY  A state hearing officer recommended today that the Long Island Lighting Company be granted a 6.6 percent increase in its electric rates  an increase that would provide about onethird of the $147.1 million the utility sought. The judge also said that the utility had justified a gasrate increase of 8.6 percent.

title: Couple Lose Bid in Laetrile Case
description: BOSTON, Feb. 14 (AP)  The state appeals court has left standing civil contempt citations and arrest warrants against Geraid and ?? Green who took their 3yearold son Chad to a clinic in Mexico three weeks ago for leukemia treatment with Laetrile. The court rejected on Tuesday a request for a stay filed by an attorney for the couple, who are under court order to return their son to Massachusetts for standard therapy.

title: Peru Novelist Warns Against Military Nationalism
description: LIMA, Peru, Feb. 14  Mario Vargas Llosa, Peru's leading novelist, has publicly attacked military nationalism in South America, which he says is generating huge arms purchases that could lead to war.

title: Taxi Panel Votes 52 To Allow Cab Leasing By Owners to Drivers
description: Over the objections of the Taxi Drivers Union, New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission voted 5 to 2 yesterday to allow taxicab owners to lease their vehicles to individual drivers, a move that some say will stabilize the industry. The union maintains, however, that the practice, allowed in most major cities in the United States, will rob the driver of benefits and put him at the mercy of the rental rates set by the person leasing the vehicle.

title: Ham Operator Relayed Details of Attack in Iran
description: An amateur radio operator in Orlando, Florida, said today that he had relayed details about the seizure of the American Embassy in Iran to United States officials in Washington.

title: Group in City Council Would Let TV, Radio Cover the Proceedings
description: The City Council President, Carol Bellamy, and 13 members of the Council introduced a series of rule changes yesterday that would include permitting television and radio coverage of its meetings.

title: A Spender Goes Conservative
description: ?? Mass., Feb. 14 (AP)  ?? the biggest spender in ?? told Harvard Business School student:, today that they should take ?? of our own in the outside world. Many in the audience wore Yankee ??

title: Iona Five Conquers Cadets
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 14  Army had Iona on the ropes tonight before the Gaels wriggled out from under the frustration of a slowdown and came back to gain a 5553 basketball victory over the Cadets.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: When John David Montgomery bought The Brazil Herald 33 years ago for about $40,000, he did it more as a favor to the Truman Administration than as a realistic business investment. But philanthropy proved to be good business, too. Mr. Montgomery, now the 75yearold publisher of 17 small newspapers in Kansas and Colorado, sold the Englishlanguage daily this week for the equivalent of $1 million, payable in cruzeiros in Brazil.

title: U.S. AND CANADA SET PACT TO SHARE FISH
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 14 Canada and the United States announced today that they had reached agreement for sharing fishing catches in disputed Atlantic areas, with the boundary dispute itself to be submitted to thirdparty arbitration.

title: T.K. Melvin Weds Nancy Halverson
description: The Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin in Chappaqua, N.Y., was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Nancy Halverson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Halverson of Chicago and New Delhi, to Thomas Kirk Melvin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell J. Melvin of Chappaqua. The Rev. Peter Floyd performed the ceremony.

title: Badillo Defends Koch on Charge Mayor's a Racist
description: Deputy Mayor Herman Badillo staunchly defended Mayor Koch yesterday against charges by a prominent black official that the Mayor was recalcitrant, insensitive and contemptuous to black people.

title: Stage: Whoopee!, Revival of 1928 Musical
description: THE songs, the dances and the painedbutterfly performance of Charles Repole are a series of brilliant green lights for whoopee! to whiz through. True, the lights turn red rather too often, so that gaggles of elderly jokes and bits of plot in wheelchairs can get by.

title: Consumer Poll Finds Unease
description: Consumer confidence fell slightly in January and there has been a deepening concern about the future course of the economy and a sharp drop in buying plans, according to the Conference Board 's latest survey released yesterday.

title: Benson Ford Seeks Bigger Role
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  In a move to put himself in a potentially commanding position in the Ford Motor Company, Benson Ford Jr., nephew of Henry Ford 2d, the company's chairman, is striving to get his late father's seat on the board of directors, according to sources close to the 30yearold greatgrandson of Henry Ford Sr.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Melody. Glazou?? Fantasie in A minor for Solo Harp, SaintSaens; Polonaise in A flat, Chopin; Ballets Music, Praetortus ; Goyescas Intermezzo, Granados.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP)  Traffic deaths in the United,States in 1978 exceeded 50,000 for the first time in five years, the Transportation Department reported today.

title: Council Ethics Unit Drawing Up Its Charges Against Mastropieri
description: The City Council's Ethics Committee directed its special counsel yesterday to draw up detailed charges and specifications against Councilman Eugene F. Mastropieri, Democrat of Queens, involv ing alleged misrepresentations, violations of state laws and conflict of interest.

title: Calendar: Antiques Show
description: The annual National Antiques Show will open Saturday at Madison Square Garden and continue through Feb. 25.

title: Christopher Tunnard, Authority On City Planning Taught at Yale
description: Christopher Tunnard, professor emeritus of city planning at Yale University, died of cancer Tuesday, after a long illness, at Yale New Haven Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 251 East Rock Road in New Haven.

title: U.S. Protests Role of Soviet Advisers in Kabul Affair
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  The United States strongly protested to the Soviet Union tonight about the role of Soviet advisers in the events that led to the slaying of Ambassador Adolph Dubs in Afghanistan.

title: Workers Decide to End British Leyland Strike
description: LONDON, Feb. 14  British Leyland's automotive workers voted at a mass meeting today to end their weeklong strike and return to work tomorrow.

title: Ancient Statue Taken From Met Found in Locker
description: The 2,500yearold marble sculpture snatched from its pedestal at the Metropolitan Museum of Art last Friday was found last night in a locker in Grand Central Termial, undamaged except for small Valentinelike heart that had been carved over the right eye of the $150,000 ancient Greek head.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Opera: Met Carlo Is Instant
description: THE best thing about Tuesday evening's performance of Don Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera was the performance itself, not thedramatic circumstances of its scheduling.

title: 5 Accused of Looting Lundy Assets Of $ 11 Million in Elaborate Plot
description: Systethatic pillage of $11 million in stocks, bonds, real estate and other assets of Frederick William Irving Lundy  the eccentric recluse who owned the Lundy Brothers seafood restaurant in Sheepshead Bay  took place in the eight months before Mr. Lundy died in 1977 at the age of 82, investigators in Brooklyn asserted yesterday. And, they charged, the butler did it  or at least helped to do it.

title: Maguire Charges H.U.D. Slurred ItalianAmericans and Jerseyans
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  A New Jersey Representative got into a dispute today with the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development over whether the agency was considering background checks of ItalianAmericans as a way of screening organized crime from its programs.

title: Tokyo Hears Statements on Lockheed
description: TOKYO, Feb. 14 (UPI)  The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation tried in 1972 to bribe Kakuei Tanaka, then Prime Minister, and six other Japanese politicians in its bid to sell Tristar jetliners in Japan, according to depositions read in a Tokyo court today.

title: Union Accord At Biz Board
