description: The New York Stock Exchange reached a tentative agreement on new contract with its unionized clerical employees late Tuesday night. No date has yet been set for a ratification vote by employees represented by Local 153 of the Office and Professional Employees Union.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The subject of a letter to the White House from Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, was incorrectly reported in Business Day on Monday. The letter appealed for the reappointment of John Evans, a Republican, as a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Anderson Will Oppose D.C. Vote Amendment
description: ALBANY. Feb. 14  Warren M. Anderson, the Senate majority leader, said yesterday that he would oppose the ratification of the District of Columbia amendment, thus putting its approval by New York State in jeopardy.

title: Phil Mahre Keeps U.S. Giant Slalom Title
description: COPPER MOUNTAIN, Colo., Feb. 14 (AP)  Phil Mahre, currently second in the World Cup standing, took a twosecond lead after the first run and held on to retain his giant slalom title today at the United States Alpine ski championshins.

title: South African Population Loss
description: CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Feb. 14 (Reuters)  Statistics Minister Hennie H. Smit told Parliament yesterday that South Africa's population loss through migration had more than doubled in a year. He said 18,104 people immigrated to South Africa in 1978, while 20,613 left, a net loss of 2,509. The net loss in 1977 was 1,178.

title: Advertising
description: BLUE NUN wine, one of the great radioadvertising success stories of this generation, is moving out of the medium and into television with its ad budget doubled.

title: The D in Detroit Is for Democrat
description: There was once a Republican in Detroit. He lived in my neighborhood, against his will. At the time, I thought he was the only white person in the neighborhood, but later I discovered that we were white, too. We were not Republican, though, so it never mattered.

title: Times Net Down in 4th Quarter
description: The New York Times Company yesterday reported earnings of $2.5 million, or 21 cents a share, for the fourth quarter of 1978, compared with $7.9 million, or 69 cents a share, in the comparable quarter of 1977.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Nervous latesession market talk about unrest in Iran and the Far East pushed silver, gold and platinum prices sharply higher yesterday on the nation's futures exchanges.

title: The Maras Valentine Gift
description: Roses are red, violets are bluo

title: Texas 102, Baylor 83
description: ?? IN Tex., Feb. 14 (AP)  Ty ?? Branvan dazzled Baylor with a career high 41 points tonight as 121hranked Texas maintained its lead in Southwest Conference with a 10283 victory over the Bears.

title: GARDENING
description: A RECENT trip to Los Angeles reminded me that many people in this country calmly dot their lawns and yards with those delicate houseplants that we in the Northeast so carefully nurture indoors. Lines of hedges covered with pale pink blossoms, rising through the smog like a mirage, turned out to be fivefoot jade plants all in a row.

title: Iranians Said to Hint Oil Resumption in 79
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  A senior official at the Department of Energy said today that the United States had received indications from the new Iranian Government that the country may resume oil production and exports this year.

title: Italy Expels U.S. Official Tied to Intelligence Study
description: ROME, Feb. 15  A political controversy has begun here in reaction to the expulsion yesterday of an American official named as the author of a confidential report to Washington sharply critical of the Italian intelligence services and their commanders.

title: Market Place
description: THE real estate investment trust has been out of favor for some time, but a number of insiders at particular trusts seem to find the trusts attractive.

title: Two Children Perish, Four Firemen Hurt in 122d Street Blaze
description: A threealarm fire swept through the upper floors of a tenement at 122d Street and Eighth Avenue yesterday, killing two children and injuring four firemen. The dead were identified by Harlem Hospital authorities as Victor Boyd, 2 years old, and Tangee Washington, 4, the children of Evelyn Boyd, of 253 West 122d Street. Fire Department officials said that fire marshals were investigating but nothing indicated that the blaze was suspicious.

title: Hunter Graduates of Stormier Days Get Their Diplomas
description: Gone were the picket lines, the cans of Chemical Mace, the antiwar posters, the armbands. No longer were there cries of protest in the halls. The days of student strikes and S.D.S. rallies had long become memories.

title: Around the Nation
description: CALEXICO. Calif., Feb. 15 (AP) Representatives of the nation's largest lettuce producer met independently today with Cesar Chavez, the United Farm Workers leader. in an apparent breakthrough in the fourweekold lettuce strike.

title: Tharp Dancers Leap Into Brooklyn
description: With a name like Twyla Tharp, a choreographer would almost have to be distinctively quirky, whimsical, tough and often impenetrably brainy. Miss Tharp  whose company will be seen this weekend and next at the Brooklyn Academy of Music  is all of this to critics and an audience that has been almost as adventurous as she has since she began Choreographing 14 years ago.

title: Braves Sign Mike Lum
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 15 (AP)  Mike Lum, a 33yearold free agent, may get his wish to end his baseball career in Atlanta, his hometown. The Braves announced today they had signed him to threeyear contract. Lum said he had turned down a $1 million, threeyear offer from a Japanese team, which contacted him after he had toured Japan with Cincinnati, his former team.

title: U.S. in Pact On Textile Protection
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  The Carter Administration and the textile and apparel industry agreed today on a package of measures to protect the industry against import surges and provide other assistance aimed at deflating the industry's opposition to a new international trade pact.

title: Sabres Defeat Rangers, 43
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 15  When it is lawofaverage time in the National Hockey League, there is little you can do about it. The Rangers, who had not lost to the Buffalo Sabres this season, lost to them tonight, 43. And after going 53 games without a serious injury, the Rangers lost Ron Greschner for at least two weeks.

title: IN THE NATION
description: TALLAHASSEE. Fla.  At 7:30 A.M. one recent morning, nearly a hundred Floridians, including a number of state legislators and former Gov. LeRoy Collins. turned up at the First Presbyterian Church on North Adams Street to demonstrate their concern about their state's criminal concern about their state's criminal justice system.

title: Aqueduct Has Races With Betting at OTB
description: A gathering  it could hardly be termed a crowd  of 2,661 wandered around. Aqueduct yesterday, gazed wistfully at the darkened ticket windows and settled down in some discomfort to watch the ninerace card without the enticements of parimutuel betting.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursday, Feb. 15, 1979

title: World News Briefs
description: WARSAW, Feb. 15 (AP)  An explosion ripped through a crowded savings bank in the center of Warsaw around noon today, killing at least 32 people and injuring many more, the state radio said.

title: Books of The Times
description: AS the dust jacket of his first novel informs us, David Hanly was born in Limerick City, Ireland, in 1944 and received a highschool education from the Christian Brothers. Thereafter, he worked at various jobs, including features man, television guide, and script writer for comedy series at RTE, the national radio and television station. After seven years at RTE, he became Public Relations Officer for the Irish Tourist Board with special responsibility for publicity in United States media. Then at Christmas time, 1976, it happened. He did what, according to his book, every Irishman talks about doing but relatively few actually accomplish (even though Ireland produces more writers per square mile than does any other country in the world): He quit his job and wrote a book. He sold his house, car, and furniture and took his wife and three children to the mountains, where, within a year, he produced In Guilt and in Glory.

title: Shah Quits Marrakesh For a Palace in Rabat
description: MARRAKESH, Morocco, Feb. 15 (AP)  Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi and Empress Farah left their temporary home in exile here today for Rabat, the Moroccan capital, where they will move into a new residence.

title: Chad's Leader Said to Step Down
description: PARIS, Feb. 15 (Reuters)  President Felix Malloum of Chad has abandoned the leadership of Chad and sought the protection of the French Army at the airport in Ndjamena, the capital, wellinformed sources said here.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: West German Accused of Spying Is Given Life Term in East Berlir.
description: EAST BERLIN, Feb. 15 (Reuters) An East German military court sen tenced a West German woman to life in prison today for espionage, the official press agency reported.

title: Contract Agreement Is Reached With Mailers by Times and News
description: Representatives of 1,600 mailers at The New York Times and The Daily News reached agreement yesterday morning with officials of the two morning newspapers on a new threeyear contract. The agreement includes benefits and a salary increase of $68 a week by the end of the contract.

title: The Region
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Drivers and mechanics of the De Camp Bus Company voted yesterday to end their fiveday strike of .the commuter bus line, which carries about 10,000 daily riders between New York City and Essex County communities.

title: Schenley Charged With Kickbacks
description: Schenley Industries and its parent company, the RapidAmerican Corporation, were charged in a Federal suit yesterday with having illegally spent $6 million on special discounts, kickbacks and gifts to promote purchases of Schenley liquor products.

title: North and South Koreans Agree To Meet at Truce Site Tomorrow
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 15  South Korea announced today that it would send four officials to the Panmunjom truce site Saturday for the first major meeting between the two Koreas in six years.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation moved a step closer yesterday to its first acquisition of an insurance company when the Indiana insurance commissioner announced approval of the company's proposed takeover of the Indiana Group.

title: Music: Clarion Valentine
description: CLARION CONCERTS valentine to its subscribers in Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night was a Viennese concert. The music was by Haydn, Mozart and a contemporary named Franz Krommer, and an enchanting program it was. It had gaiety, extrovert sentiment, intellectural wit and an almost implausible charm.

title: Nicole Alphand Dead
description: PARIS, Feb. 15  Nicole Merenda Al phand, wife of Herve Alphand, former French Ambassador to the United States, and once one of Washington's most successful hostesses, died here today at her Left Bank home after surgery for cancer six weeks ago. Her age was given as around 60.

title: The City
description: Mayor Koch has told the Secretary of the Treasury, W. Michael Blumenthal, that he would take whatever measures are necessary to balance his budget for fiscal 1980, including contingency cuts if sufficient Federal and state aid is not forthcoming.

title: Business and the Law
description: SALES executives know that their sales personnel will inevitably meet competitors. They know that some risk of pricefixing arises from this fact, no matter what precaution the executives take. They can explain the antitrust laws to their employees who nonetheless can break them without the executives knowing of it.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY,FEB 15, 1979

title: U.S. Is Seeking a Retrial for Flood
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  The Justice Department announced today that it would seek a retrial of Representative Daniel J. Flood, whose first trial ended Feb. 3 in a hung jury when a lone juror held out for acquittal on all 11 counts of bribery, conspiracy and perjury.

title: Coast S.&
description: The California Federal Savings and Loan Association, the largest federally chartered S & L in the country, raised $5 million in shortterm funds yesterday by selling commercial paper through A. G. Becker Inc. The notes are believed to be the first unsecured commercial paper of a savings and loan association to reach the market.

title: For Skiers, Holiday Is the Best of Times
description: With one of recreational skiing's most important holiday weekends approaching, resort operators throughout the ski country were anticipating large crowds starting tomorrow morning.

title: About Real Estate
description: At 400 Clinton Avenue in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn there is a sixstory building with a selfservice elevator and 35 apartments. When the Woodville Realty Corporation took it over in 1971 the building was already showing the effects of 10 years of deferred maintenance.

title: Obituary 6  No Title
description: Deaths

title: L.I. Girl Just Fine With Rejoined Leg
description: SMITHTOWN, L.I., Feb. 15  On the Sunday afternoon of Dec. 31, Elizabeth McFadden of Central Islip, L.I., was scampering across the tracks of the Long Island Rail Road when she was struck by a train. The 11yearold girl's right leg was severed above the knee.

title: Music: Barenboim Leads New Lutoslawski Work
description: DANIEL BARENBOIM'S basic musical orientation is German, whether the instrument he has in hand is the piano or the orchestra. So it should not be surprising that the manyfaceted Israeli ran brine off a wonderfully idiomatic performance of Schumann's First Symphony, as he did last night at the head of the New York Philharmonic. Less obvious is why he can conduct a thoroughly Gallic reading of Ravel's Daphnis and Chloe. as he also did on the same program, but no doubt his perfect French accent, musically speaking, helpS explain why he has had such a success as music director of the Orchestre de Paris, a post he assumed in 1975.

title: Ford Profit Fell 28.2% In Quarter
description: DETROIT, Feb.15 The Ford Motor Company today reported a 28.2 percent decline in its fourthquarter profits and a 4.7 percent decline in its earnings for all of 1978, despite higher revenues in both periods.

title: Corning Glass: Eye on Pricing
description: CORNING, N.Y.  The Carter Administration 's wageprice guidelines permit exemptions for certain products. This lets a company raise the price more than it otherwise could. But sometimes the company does not bother to claim an exemption because it prefers to keep things simple particularly if the product 's sales are relatively small.

title: Canada Borrows in Japan
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 15  Canada is raising $500 million in United States currency in Japanese money markets and an undisclosed amount in Switzerland in a continuing effort to bolster the relatively weak Canadian dollar.

title: U.S. DROPS INQUIRY ON LOCKHEED AIDES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  The Justice Department decided today not to prosecute two former top officers of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation who were subjects of a Federal grand jury investigation into illegal payments to overseas government officials by American companies.

title: Industrial Output Up Just a Little
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP)  The nation's industrial output rose last month by the smallest amount in a year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Continued turmoil in Iran and the report yesterday that two members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries were raising oil prices sent silver futures up the daily limit of 20 cents an ounce in most deliveries in early trading. Late in the session. silver prices fell on apparent profit taking but still closed higher for the day.

title: Guard Wounded in Basque Area
description: ZUMAYA, Spain. Feb.15 (Reuters) Gunmen believed to be Basque guerrillas shot and wounded a paramilitary Civil Guard in this northern town last night, the police said today.

title: Dance: Alum at Pace
description: PACE UNIVERSITY'S Schimmel Center, just south of City Hall, is certainly off the beaten track, but it happens to be a pem of a small dance theater. OnWednesday, the dignified intimacy of the Schimmel Center stage provided a perfect setting for one of the more appealing concerts of the season, when the Manuel Alum Dance Company presented six works by Mr. Alum.

title: Coast Court Rejects Portion of Law Easing Losses From Proposition 13
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 15  California's state government acted illegally when it gave local governments $5 billion last summer to help cover revenue losses under Proposition 13 but forbade them to use the funds to give pay raises to public employees, the California Supreme Court ruled today.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: SEA GULL AT YALE

title: 3 McGrawHill Suits Linked
description: Shareholder Suits against McGraw Hill Inc. inched forward yesterday when Judge Lewis Grossman of the New York State Supreme Court signed an order consolidating three separate classaction lawsuits filed by McGraw.Hill shareholders. All three actions are aimed at allowing stockholders to de cide whether to accept the American Express Company's offer to acquire the publishing company at $40 a share.

title: Dyson in Dispute With Albany Staffs Over Budgets
description: ALBANY, Feb. 15  New York State's Commerce Commissioner, John S. Dyson, today said sophomoric and fourth level legislative staff members were trying to cut the budgets of his department's I Love New York and business advertising campaigns.

title: Museum Curators Meet to Talk Security
description: NEWARK, Del., Feb. 14  This week, 62 museum curators, persons more at home discussing the beautiful, gathered here at the University of Delaware to talk about such mundane matters as locks and hasps, wiring and alarms. They were told that unless they paid more attention to mese aevices, there could be little beautiful left to muse on.

title: Auxiliary Policeman In Stamford Accused In Killing of a Girl, 14
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 15  A 26yearold auxiliary policeman who is the son of a city policeman was charged today with manslaughter and sexual assault of a 14year girl whose frozen body was found in a Wooded area along the Merritt Parkway. The police said the girl had apparently been lured by a caller posing as a doctor in need of a baby sitter.

title: Sponsor Withdraws Tennis Event Funds
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 (AP) The Insurance Corporation of North America has withdrawn sponsorship of the annual $250,000 United States Pro Indoor tennis tournament, citing deceptive financial practices by tournament directors.

title: Publishing: New Laurels for the Poet May Swenson
description: TWENTYFIVE years ago, reviewing May Swenson's first book of poetry Another Animal, John Ciardi wrote, May Swenson is not a promise, but a fact. Mr. Ciardi proved to be a good prophet. For it was not long before other books came from her pen; her poems were being anthologized, and critics were praising her for the way her wonderfully painted surfaces led to surprising and mysterious depths; for the way the sheer thingness of things is joyfully celebrated; for the way her inner and outer vision met. She is able to make her reader see clearly what he has merely looked at before, another critic wrote. Over the years she been honored with foundation grants and with membership in the National Institute of Arts and Letters, among other achievements.

title: Scientists at World Parley Doubt Climate Variations Are Ominous
description: GENEVA, Feb 15  This winter Chicago was paralyzed by snow. Last winter it was Boston. European Russia has just suffered its coldest December in a century. In Britain and Western Europe, the summer of 1976 was the hottest in 250 years. Droughts have recently killed 80 percent of the livestock in parts of Africa and have taken many human lives.

title: PEKING SAYS HANOI LAYS MINES IN CHINA
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 15  Peking charged today that in the first six weeks of the year 22 Chinese soldiers and civilians were killed and 20 wounded by mines planted by Vietnamese forces on the Chinese side of the border between the two countries.

title: ISRAELI SAYS TURKEY MAY FACE UPHEAVAL
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 15A high Israeli official has warned members of Parliament in a briefing that Turkey might be the next country in the Middle East to undergo a violent antiWestern upheaval, like that in Iran.

title: Ralph Alswang, Designer of Sets And Innovative Theaters, Dead
description: Ralph Alswang, the Broadway scenic designer who turned a stunning series of stage successes into a career as one of the nation's foremost designers of theaters. died of a heart attack yesterday at his apartment at 62 West 69th Street.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Associated Dry Goods Corporation, a department store chain, has named Joseph Montrone as president and chief executive officer of Robinson's of Florida and William J. Sander as chairman.

title: Auctions
description: EUGENE and Eleanor Gluck amassed in less than a decade a stunning assemblage of Louis Comfort Tiffany lamps, vases, desk accessories and candlesticks. Most of their collection will be sold in 90 lots at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow at Christie, Manson & Woods, Park Avenue at 59th Street, in what represents the most important private collection of the turn. ofthecentury designer's work ever auctioned, It's absolutely super in every way, commented Alastair Duncan, Christie's Art Nouveau specialist and the author of two books on the decorative arts style.

title: Radioactive Uranium Dump Discovered Under Denver
description: DENVER, Feb. 15 (AP)  A longabandoned site for disposal of uranium waste, emitting radiation in excess of Federal safety standards, has been discovered beneath a Denver brick and tile plant and officials believe there could be at least seven similar radioactive dumps in the city.

title: Women Hail Social Security Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  A Government study suggesting ways to erase sex discrimination from the Social Security System was hailed by women's groups today as a major breakthrough for both working and nonworking women.

title: China Oil Deal With Japanese
description: TOKYO, Feb. 15  Japan and Chira have reached a basic agreement on a joint project to develop oilfields in the shallow Bay of Pohai at an estimated cost of $2 billion, to be paid entirely by the Japanese, according to official sources today.

title: 5 Women Stars Mesh in Babe's New Play
description: Ladies of the theater their director, Robert Allan Ackerman pronounced them, and indeed, ladies of the theater they are, all five members of the cast of Thomas Babe's new play, Taken in Marriage, which can be seen in preview this weekend at the Public's Newman Theater. Among them, the women could donate enough acting awards to fill a trophy case in a highschool gymnasium. The cast includes, in alphabetical order, Dixie Carter, Colleen Dewhurst, Kathleen Quinlan, Meryl Streep and Elizabeth Wilson.

title: Exploiting. Natural Gas
description: ELIZABETH. N.J.  The decision of the United Arab Emirates and Qatar to hike oil prices about 7 percent. coupled with the announcement last December that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would increase its prices almost 15 percent in 1979, gives added incentive for America to encourage development of more desirable alternative energy sources.

title: Play: An Evening In New Jerusalem
description: ON the basis of New Jerusalem, which opened Wednesday at the Public Theater, and of a previous work, Gogol, a Mystery Play, which was not about Nikolai Gogol, it is apparent that Len Jenkin writes conundrums. Mr. Jenkin deals in apparitions and enigmas, and New Jerusalem seems about as difficult to decipher as a Japanese war code. Either one is tuned in to Mr. Jenkin's wavelength or one is at sea.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: In Saranac Lake, Readings Are Below Imagination
description: SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Feb. 15Once it gets past 35 below, there's not that much difference, Charlie Smith was saying judiciously over his morning coffee.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: Prices of gold jumped as much as $7 an ounce on major European bullion markets yesterday, while the dollar slipped a bit in trading abroad and closed narrowly mixed in New York.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: LUCY L. PULLING

title: A Stage Lab For West Side
description: ATHEATRICAL pot is aboil on the Upper West Side, at 236 West 78th Street, unlikely as the site may seem. Starting tonight, the 78th Street Theater Lab will open with three plays and a cabaret bubbling away in newly renovated quarters just east of Broadway.

title: Screen: 'Tracks,' Anti-Vietnam War Movie, Opens:Cross-Country Trip
description: "TRACKS" is Henry Jaglom's heretofore "invisible" film that attempts to dramatize intellectual and moral outrage against American involvement in the Vietnam War. The film, which stars Dennis Hopper, was made four years ago. It has been shown at festivals around the world and has had a few commercial engagements here and abroad, but it is only today having its regular New York theatrical premiere at the Quad Cinema. That distributors should find it a chancey item is not difficult to understand.Though "Tracks" takes place in 1973, when President Richard M. Nixon was announcing the signing of a ceasefire to end the war, the movie has the stoned, improvised look of an artifact out of the 1960's, having less to do with considered opposition to the war than with a vague sort of dissatisfaction with everything, and no idea what to do about it. "Tracks" is an inarticulate flower movie.The setting is a transcontinental train. Army Sergeant Jack Falen (Mr. Hopper), escorting the body of his dead war buddy home for burial, meets a cross section of middle America aboard the train. There are a pretty, essentially decent college girl Taryn Power (the late Tyrone Power's daughter), an elderly hippie (Dean Stockwell), who turns out to be a member of the militant left in flight from the law, an older woman (Barbara Flood), who rides trains for the casual sex that's available, and assorted types of businessmen, all of whom, it seems, work for the Central Intelligence Agency or the Federal Bureau of Investigation.Mr. Jaglom, whose first feature, ("A Safe Place"), was shown at the 1971 New York Film Festival, is sometimes very good at catching his actors (including Alfred Ryder, the film director) in moments that have a crazy sponteneity. Particularly funny is a chess expert played by Michael Emil and a real estate salesman played by Zack Norman. Mr. Norman has what are the film's best moments as he explains why he likes to eat the skin of a chicken instead of the meat. The insides of a chicken he says with the authority of a fanatic, are not exposed to "the reality of the land."This sort of thing is colorful, but it's not enough to make a movie. That "Tracks" lacks any real center is, I suspect, the joint failure of Mr. Jaglom, who wrote and directed it, and Mr. Hopper, whose sergeant seems less like the victim of the horrors of war than an actor playing with mannerisms. The mechanics of the performance are so apparent they subvert the film's claims to serious purpose and turn it into a cross-country ego trip. It is interesting to compare Mr. Hopper's performance here with the beautifully controlled one he was to give a couple of years later in Wim Wenders's "The American Friend." Same actor, entirely different results.As he did in "A Safe Place" Mr. Jaglom here displays a fondness for demonstrating fantasies, but in "Tracks" they are either superfluous or confusing and, finally, they utterly destroy what should be a shattering climax. One nice touch: Mr. Jaglom's use of mostly terrible World War II songs, which the sergeant plays on his portable tapedeck. It's not especially realistic, but it says more about the difference between Vietnam and other American wars than anything else in the film.

title: Yanks Trade Gary Thomasson
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 15  With baseball's interleague trading period only hours old, the New York Yankees reached out for some catching insurance today by obtaining 22yearold Brad Gulden from the Los Angeles Dodgers in exchange for Gary Thomasson, one of the Yankees many surplus outfielders.

title: Text Excerpts From Toasts By 2 Leaders
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  Following are excerpts from the texts provided by the White House of toasts made at a luncheon in Mexico City yesterday by President Jos Lopez Portillo and President Carter.

title: Carter, Despite Strains in Mexico, Says Things Are Going Very Well
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 15  President Carter sought today to counter an impression of coolness and divisiveness that resulted from his opening round of talks with President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico yesterday.

title: Coop City to Get Home Box Office in Spring
description: Home Box Office. the pay television service. will be made available to residents of Coop City in the Bronx next spring.

title: Beckett on a GermanMusic Program
description: We usually don't do very much in the field of music. After all, German music, certainly classical German music, is well represented in New York. The statement came from Christoph Wecker, director of Goethe House New York. It came as a preface to the announcement of a concert of 20thcentury German compositions being presented by the city's German Cultural Institute in Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday night.

title: 80,000 Students Are Stranded by School Bus Strike
description: More than 80,000 publicschool children, many physically and mentally handicapped, were stranded, yesterday, unable to get to school because of a wildcat strike by their bus drivers.

title: Joel Dean, Business Professor, 73
description: Joel Dean, a financial consultant and professor of business economics emeritus at Columbia University, died Wednesday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center after a heart attack. He was 73 years old and lived in HastingsonHudson, N.Y.

title: Art: Long Neglected, Jawlensky Returns
description: As of the summer of 1909 one of the most interesting painters in Europe was a Russian in his mid40's called Alexei Jawlensky. Like many another cultivated Russian, he was living in voluntary exile in Munich, which at that time was a capital of art that ranked second only to Paris. He knew everything and everyone. He knew the new French painting and the new French painters. He had come to know Diaghilev when Diaghilev was just a fat young man from the sticks who was very good at organizing exhibitions. He was in contact with gifted people all oven Europe, and in 1909 he and his fellowpainters, Wassily Kandinsky and Gabriele Mnter, founded a select society of artists that still lives in the history books. It had taken a long time for Jawlensky to find his true personal style, but as of 1909 he was where he had always aimed to be: somewhere near the top.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: Deaths

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 16, 1979

title: Notes on People
description: It wasn 't the first time such a call went out. Get Ruth, cried Natalia Makarova. There the ballerina was, in San Francisco, scheduled to perform in Swan Lake yesterday at the War Memorial Opera House, and she was without a partner because Anthony Dowell was laid up with a bad cold.

title: Windfall in New Haven
description: Thanks to the transgressions of the Olin Corporation, a group of New Haven residents got a chance play philanthropistforaday. They are the directors of an ad hoc Community Betterment Fund, whose odd chore, now concluded, was to disburse a half million dollars in reparations assessed by a Federal judge last March after Olin was convicted of illegal arms sales South Africa. We were troubled then by the judge's decision. The mishandling of the reparations fund confirms the folly of the original decree.

title: Clinton Relies on a Team Effort
description: Arty Epstein knows how to go to his bench.

title: S.E.C. Asks Overhaul On Options
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  A Securities and Exchange Commission staff report, asserting that the nation 's stock exchanges and brokerage firms had failed to protect the investing public by adequately policing trading in stock options, today recommended a thorough overhaul of option trading rules and procedures.

title: Broadway
description: JOLEY will open on Broadway on May 2, and Larry Kert will be its star. Mr. Kert is something of a professional's professional in the musical theater, and although you probably associate him mostly with the lead role of Tony in West Side Story and with Company, he has run around and done other things, too. This is just as well because in Joley he will be playing Al Jolson, who may or may not have been the world's greatest entertainer, but was easily one of the most energetic; also, he was married four times. Mr. Kert will be on stage for all but about 10 minutes of Joley, and he will sing 10 original, or book, songs, as well as bits and pieces of some 20 songs that Jolson once sang. Mr. Kert will dance, too.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Ontario and the European Investment Bank raised $550 million in the capital markets here yesterday as fixedincome securities held relatively stable in price.

title: San Juan Racing Talks
description: The San Juan Racing Association disclosed yesterday the termination of discussions with a group of private investors who had proposed to acquire the outstanding stock of the race track operator. No reason for the termination was given. The company said that discussions were under way with other interests regarding the sale of the stock.

title: New Face: Harry Hamlin
description: THE plot goes like this: The handsome young man quits his job and buys a ticket for a charter flight to London. He has a few weeks to kill before the plane leaves, so he decides to visit Hollywood. One day he goes to a big movie studio, where he happens to catch the eye of a famous director. As things turn out, the young man misses the plane to London. Ht is too busy doing something elsestarring in his first film.

title: Starting a Lloyds of New York
description: When an airline buys a new 300passenger airplane, it must insure itself against millions of dollars claims that would be made in case of a crash. But no single insurance company would be willing to gamble on so great a liability from a single disaster. One company might issue the policy, but it would share the risk (and the premiums collected from the airline) with other insurers in a syndicate formed for the purpose. The most famous such association of insurers is Lloyds of London. It has developed a nearmonopoly, worldwide, as the place to which those who need highrisk insurance turn. Now Governor Carey wants to provide Lloyds with competition in New York.

title: Abbott to Exercise Takeover Option
description: Abbott Laboratories Inc. said it intended to exercise its option under its contract with C. H. Boehringer Sohn of Ingelheim, West Germany, to acquire as of Dec. 31,1979, Boehringer's halfinterest in Deutsche Abbott G.m.b.H. of Ingelheim.

title: KREMLIN DISMISSES ACCUSATIONS BY U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 15  The Soviet Government's press agency, Tass, today issued an indirect denial of United States charges about the behavior of Soviet advisers in a Kabul gunbattle that resulted in the death of Adolph Dubs, the abducted Ambassador to Afghanistan.

title: Sadat Has a Dream: $15 Billion Carter Plan in Aid
description: CAIRO, Feb. 15  The latest idea being offered by President Anwar elSadat to solve Egypt's economic ills is what he calls a Carter plan, modeled after the Marshall Plan that helped Europeans reconstruct their countries from the ruins of World War II.

title: Advertising
description: CONDE NAST, PUBLICATIONS, whose domestic operation is entirely dedicated to publishing magazines (especially fashion magazines) for women, has reached an agreement with Esquire Inc. to acquire Gentlemen's Quarterly, a fashion magazine of a different gender. Details of the sale are not being released at this juncture.

title: Dow Slips By 0.69
description: The rising trend of world oil prices sent airline issues lower and oil and gas exploration stocks higher on Wall Street yesterday. The general market, meanwhile, held within a narrow range.

title: BROWN WILL PRESS SADAT ON A TREATY
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 15  Defense Secretary Harold Brown is planning to inform President Anwar elSadat of Egypt that it will be difficult for the United States to enter into a militarysupply relationship with Egypt as long as a peace treaty with Israel remains unsigned, United States defense officials said tonight.

title: Fun for Children
description: THE LITTLE ENGINE THAT COULD, and other movies presented by the Columbia Greenhouse Nursery School and Kindergarten, on Saturday at 1.30 P.M., at the Horace Mann Auditorium, northeast corner of Broadway at 120th Street. One hour. Contribution S1 Call 6664796.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Grasso Calls, For Amendment To Restrict Connecticut's Spending
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 15  Gov. Ella T. Grasso called today for a constitutional amendment to limit state spending, an action sure to rekindle the longsmoldering debate over growth in spending.

title: Single Agency Planned for Managing Foreign Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  President Carter plans to establish an independent Government agency called the International Development Cooperation Administration to consolidate and coordinate United States foreign assistance programs, the White House said today.

title: Robert J. Shea, News Assistant
description: Robert J. Shea, a news assistant at The New York Times, collapsed and died yesterday on his way to work. Mr. Shea was 63 years old and lived at 452 West 44th Street.

title: Steel Trigger Prices Unchanged
description: The Treasury Department announced yesterday that base trigger prices for steel in the second quarter would be unchanged from the first quarter. The move is expected to help keep imported steel from having its competitive position erode further.

title: Hot From Detroit: Service Warranties
description: DETROIT, Feb. 15  One hot product in the automobile business this year is not a vehicle but an insurance policy.

title: Billy Carter Dismisses Criticism by U.S. Jews With a Vulgar Phrase
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb.15  Billy Carter, the President's brother, directed an obscenity at critics in the American Jewish community last night at a reception given by the Libyan delegation to the United Nations.

title: Money From Iran Held Up, Students in U.S. in Distress
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  I sold my gold jewelry, and now I have enough money for one month, said Shanaz Anjadi, a 24yearold Iranian majoring in art at American University in Washington. After that, I'm not sure. But I don't want to go back.

title: Winded Financial Analyst Wins Run Up Empire State
description: No selfrespecting marathon runner would consider a race of a mere 350 yards worth lacing up one's scientifically designed, wafflesoled shoes for  unless perhaps it meant sprinting up the 1,575 steps of the Empire State Building.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: How many gradeB movies have we all seen about the mad scientist who experiments with a dangerous organism, only to have it break loose and threaten a global epidemic? Now there is fear that such a scenario might unfold in some of the world's_ leading laboratories.

title: WASHINGTON
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 15  President Carter must feel from time to time that he is back in the austere classrooms of the Naval Academy in Annapolis, for some big shot always seems to be lecturing him these days, telling him to shape up or shout out or shut up.

title: Toyota, Nissan Production Off
description: TOKYO, Feb. 15 (AP) Japan's two largest auto manufacturers reported today that motor vehicle production declined in January but that exports increased.

title: Economic Scene
description: THE United States economy is caught in a tug of war. Business is still booming at home, but things are going to pot abroad. Iran threatens to become another Lebanon, with radical factions seeking to shoot their way into the new Government.

title: Possible Leakage of Chemical
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 15  The Federal Government today challenged the Dow Chemical Company's contention that highly poisonous chemicals found in fish near its plant in Midland, Mich., had come from natural sources and not from the plant.

title: Globetrotters at Garden
description: The Harlem Globetrotters will dribble their way onto the basketball court this weekend at Madison Square Garden, Seventh Avenue and 33d Street. The learn, which has presented its blend of athletic prowess and comedy in 97 countries, will perform tomorrow at 2 P.M. and Sunday at 1 P.M. Tickets are $5 and $A 50. Information: 5644409.

title: The Pop Life
description: PITY the poor, white. male singersongwriter: it would be hard to think of anyone less hip at the moment. Disco reigns right now, which means either toothy. blowdried androgynes or blacks (especially black women) or mustached foreign producers. And if it isn't disco, it's such women singers as Nicolette Lar son, Valerie Carter or Carlene Carter, or raving punk rockers who look as if they've just dropped in from another planet. Earnest, guitarstrumming, sensitively sincere singercomposers in a folk idiom are about at the very bottom of the hierarchy of hip.

title: Events and Openings
description: TRACKS. directed by Henry ??; Starring Dennis Hooper and ?? Power, at the Quad Cinema.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Deaths

title: SOUTH AFRICAN BIDS RHODESIAN BOW OUT
description: CAPE TOWN, Feb. 15  South Africa's Foreign Minister, R. F. Botha, indicated today that he thought Ian D. Smith should leave politics when Rhodesia transfers power to its black majority after an elec tion in April.

title: Proposed Convention on Balancing Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  Twentyseven state legislatures have called on Congress to summon a constitutional convention to draft a constitutional amendment requiring the Federal budget to be balanced except in emergencies. If seven more states join them, Congress may be obliged to call the first such convention since 1787.

title: Market Place
description: THE antitrust laws, which are designed to make the economy more productive, don't always work that way.

title: Boeing Review Ends
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP)  The Boeing Company has made a complete disclosure of payments to foreign officials and no further investigations are required, a review committee of outside directors reported today to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Leaders of U.S. Angry at Soviet Over Crises Role
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  As plans went ahead for evacuating Americans from Iran, the United States accused the Soviet Union today of efforts to help foment antiAmerican actions in Iran and of having played a decisive role in the shootout that led to the killing of the American envoy after his abduction in Afghanistan yesterday.

title: Lietzke, on 63, Leads Tucson Golf by Shot
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 15  Jim Nelford, one of four Canadians on the PGA Tour, is nothing if not adaptable. When he started playing golf at age 13 at the urging of his golfing parents, he had no clubs of his own; he played with his parents sticks. His father was lefthanded and his mother was righthanded. That was how he learned to play with whatever clubs were available.

title: U.S. Offers a $200 Million Plan for TransitUrban Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  Transportation Secretary Brock Adams announced a new $200 million program today to finance transitrelated projects and said that his department would welcome applications for participation from all cities.

title: H.E.W.'S Chief Declines to Ban Drug in Darvon
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 15 (AP)  Joseph A. Califano Jr.. Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. refused today to ban the key ingredient in Darvon, a popular prescription pain reliever. But he announced steps that he said would insure the public's welfare while the product was studied.

title: Shades of Jeanette MacDonald and Nelson Eddy
description: The ultimate in camp, it appears, is no camp at all.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times yesterday about a compromise between the United States and Canada on sharing fishing catches from disputed areas of the Atlantic incorrectly reported the percentage of the scallop catch from Georges Bank that the Canadian fleet would be allowed to keep. Under the new agreement the correct amount is 73 percent.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Harold P. Hornaday, chairman and president of the Cannon Mills Comany, was in New York yesterday for the traditional ceremony that accompanies the listing of a stock on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: New Pope Stirs Czech Church's Hopes
description: PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia  We have in our archdiocese only 308 priests for 508 parishes, Frantisek Cardinal Tomasek told Roman Catholics in a recent pastoral letter read from every pulpit. Each year, 15 of them die but many fewer are coming to replace them. The solution? We must pray.

title: Reporter's Notebook: The Guff in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 15 The communications gap between the United States and Mexico was apparent as soon as President Carter landed here yesterday. I have never had a welcome like this, he read from a prepared text. Yet probably never before has Mexico given a cooler welcome to a prominent visitor.

title: Washington, D.C. and the Six Too's
description: Grudgingly, the United States has in recent years come to accept a startling idea: that even people who live in its capital are entitled to political rights. It was not until 1964 that residents of Washington could even vote for President. Then the tempo of reform picked up. In 1971 came a nonvoting member of Congress. In 1974 came the first election for mayor. And last summer, Congress passed a constitutional amendment to give the District of Columbia full representation in the House and Senate.

title: Washington's Famous Help Germaine's Restaurant Make a Name for Itself
description: WASHINGTON  The tourists have not gotten wind of it yet. It's in an unfashionable part of town. But the name Gennaine's Is beginning to be bandied about by Washington insiders as the new place to eat in the capital.

title: Church Group Acting to Oust Potter as Chief
description: The board of directors of the Council of Churches of the City of New York took steps yesterday to replace the Rev. Dr. Dan M. Potter as executive head of the ecumenical body.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The prospect of another round of oil price increases has heightened the risk of recession and of a further spiraling of inflation, according to Government and private economists. The prospect emerged following the confirmation of new increases by Abu Dhabi and Qatar, although the largest Middle East producer, Saudi Arabia, did not immediately follow. [Page A 1.]

title: Bowyer and Bruggeman
description: The Black Cockroach Pas de Deux and Poison Ivy and the Young Girl will be two of the dances performed by Bob Bowyer, Jo Ann Bruggeman and company this weekend at the Riverside Church, Broadway and 120th Street. Mr. Bowyer and Miss Bruggeman, who have been performing comicdance routines together for six years, will be joined by Marianne Claire and Scott Bryant. Performances are at 8 P.M. tomorrow and 4:30 P.M. on Sunday. Tickets are $4.50 ($3.50 for students, $3 for the elderly); Theater Development Fund dance vouchers (plus $1) accepted. Information: 8642929.

title: Launching of Gondolas by Hand Is Banned at Sugarbush Ski Area
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Feb. 15 (AP) State officials have ordered the Sugar bush Ski Area to stop launching gondolas by hand after an accident in which one of the cars plunged to the ground, injuring three passengers.

title: Sugar Rise Backed. By Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  President Carter finally gave in today and agreed to sponsor new sugarprice support legislation that could cost, consumers about $180 million next year.

title: Two Escaped Killers Hunted
description: MARION, Ill , Feb. 15 (AP)  Hundreds of law officers and search dogs trudged through thick woods in dense fog today hunting two convicted killers who escaped from the Federal prison. A Government helicopter also joined the search for Al Garza, 38 years old, of El Paso, Tex., and Howard Zumberge, 28, of Minneapolis, who escaped from the prison last night while on kitchen duty.

title: Bridge:
description: An unusual institution disappeared last fall, when the Card School closed its doors after a quarter of a century of service in the cause of bridge education in New York City. Among the faculty members in that period were such international stars as Edgar Kaplan, Peter Leventritt, Boris Koytchou and B. Jay Becker.

title: Music: Stephanie Jutt, Flutist, at the Y
description: IN the usual recital, which concerns itself with a soloist and an accompanist, one can learn a great deal about a musician. But that great deal, while it may go deep, does not cover a wide range of abilities.

title: Wall St. Broker Pleads Guilty in $6 Million Fraud
description: A Wall Street broker pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of defrauding hundreds of investors of $6 million in the sale of London commodity options, commodity pools and gold contracts.

title: Abortion Clinic Set Afire on L.I.
description: A man with a can of gasoline and a torch set fire to a crowded abortion clinic in Hempstead, L.I., yesterday afternoon, sending 40 to 50 staff members and patients fleeing into th,e cold as flames heavily damaged the twostory, 12room clinic and burned the arson suspect.

title: F.C.C. Clears ABC on Staging
description: The Federal Communications Commission has ruled unanimously to dismiss a complaint against ABC News for allegedly staging parts of a documentary televised last June. Youth Terror: The View From Behind the Gun. on the violent ways of urban street gangs. The complaint had been been brought by the Black Producers Association of New York. which had charged that there were misrepresentations in the documentary that breached professional ethics.

title: New Jersey Tests 55 for Mercury Near Dump Site
description: WOOD RIDGE, N.J., Feb. 15  People who live and work near an old mercury dump here were tested today by state health experts for contamination from the tons of potentially toxic metal discharged on the land for 36 years until 1973.

title: Evelyn M. Britton, 60, Artist. Did Logos for Broadway Shows
description: Evelyn Mathews Britton, a New, York artist and the wife of Jeff Bri ton, a Broadway producer, died of leukt mite Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital she was 60 years old and a resident of Mathattan.

description: ANNOUNC MENTS OF DAY ATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M FOR ?? ?? ?? UNTIL 7:30 P.M ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION IN REGIONL OFFICES 9.00 A.M TO 4.30 P.M MONDAY ??
