title: World Gold
description: THURSDAY. FEB 1 1979

title: Bowie Impresario of New Jazz Concert
description: Minor earthquake tremors were reported in New Jersey and some outlying New York City boroughs in recent weeks, and a sizable portion of New York's jazz community knows just where those tremors have been originating. In a tiny theater on the Lower East Side 15 trumpeters, 17 saxophonists, 10 trombonists, 3 pianists, 3 guitarists, 7 bassists, 5 drummers, and an assortment of percussionists  well over 60 musicians in all  have been packed tightly together, rehearsing almost daily for a concert that will take place at the Symphony Space, 95th Street and Broadway, Saturday night at 8 and 11 P.M. Tickets are $10 and are available through Ticketron or at the Symphony Space box office between 4 and 8 P.M. daily.

title: Mildred C. Jay, Leader In Antiques Field, at 78
description: Mildred Canfield Jay, a New York antiques dealer, died of pneumonia Tuesday at the New York Infirmary. She was 78 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Piano: Alfred Brendel Plays at Carnegie Hall
description: ALFRED BRENDEL is thought of as an intellectual pianist, and that he most certainly is. But in his recital last night at Carnegie Hall he suggested that intellectualism can have more dimensions than it is sometimes realized.

title: Strong Roots Continues Black Odyssey
description: ROOTS: THE NEXT GENERATIONS begins in 1882, some 12 years after the narrative of television's first Roots serial ended. This continuation, stretched over 14 hours and in several respects better than its predecessor, will be presented by ABC (Channel 7) on seven evenings next week, starting this Sunday at 8 P.M. with the first two hours.

title: Art: Variety of Styles at Whitney Biennial
description: THE Whitney Biennial Exhibition, which surveys current work by American artists; can usually be counted upon to arouse strong feelings. Its tendency to include a little of this ana a Little of that, to strike a balance between the new and the established, to satisfy a wide variety of taste without committing itself to anything in particular, is guaranteed to offend as many people as it pleases

title: Two Sentenced in Bank Thefts
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Feb 15 (AP) Two men convicted of stealing thousands of dollars in plastic bags that they stuffed into night deposit boxes of banks around the Southeast have been sentenced to 15 years each for bank larceny and conspiracy. But attorneys for Graham Franklin Anderson, 46 years old, of Atlanta, and Claude Francis Cooley, of Youngsvil le, N. C., said today that they would appeal the convictions.

title: Trusting Khomeini
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Part of the confusion in America about Iran's social revolution involves Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. More even than any thirdworld leader, he has been depicted in a manner calculated to frighten.

title: Blessed Is the Peacemaker
description: There was this estranged couple in Milwaukee who kissed and made up and threw a party to celebrate the recoil.. cilation. It was during the Prohibiton Era when gin came direct from the bathtub and whisky was sometimes allowed to cool before serving. At the height of the celebration a fight broke out and a guest who intervened as peacemaker got shot dead.

title: Young to Seek Disciplinarian, Teacher as Giant Coach
description: The people who know George Young think the Giants new general manager will hire a head coach sometime next week; that the man is likely to come from a list not very different from the list the Maras were composing, and that it is apparently headed by Dan Reeves and Jerry Rhome.

title: Children Do Musical By Swados
description: There are several things you should know  although it should not at all affect your appreciation one way or the other  about the First All Children's Theater even before you run to get tickets for its new production, The Incredible Feelines Show. The musical. adapted by. Elizabeth Swados from her book, The Girl With the Incredible Feeling, is scheduled to start public performances this weekend, on Saturday and Sunday, at the theater, 37 West 65th Street.

title: Army's Entrance Rules Held Biased by Women
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP)  Six women filed a classaction suit in Federal District Court today charging that Army entrance requirements were more stringent for women than for men and asking that the regulations be declared unconstitutional.

title: Japan to Finance Fulbrights
description: TOKYO, Feb. 15 (Reuters)  Japan agreed today to contribute $1 million to Fulbright scholarship funds next year, the Foreign Ministry said. Under an agreement signed here, the United States will put up an equal amount. The United States had been the sole contributor to the funds, which have allowed nearly 4,300 Japanese to study in America and about 1,000 Americans to study in Japan.

title: Corporate Earnings Are Reported for the Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Birth Control Parley Shaken as Protesters Display Two Fetuses
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 15  A peacemaking effort by opposing sides of the abortion issue to establish common ground on alternative means of birth control suffered a sharp setback today when three women interrupted a news conference and displayed two human fetuses.

title: A Balmy Day for a Change: 26 Degrees
description: At first, the cold kept the customers away from Diamond Lil's bar on Canal Street, Pam, the barmaid, said yesterday, and the few thinkers would keep their coats on. But now, no, she said as she prepared the bar for a normalsized crowd. People are getting used to the cold, they accept it. You know New Yorkers, they just adapt. They have to get used to it. Everybody just has to go about their business.

title: Webster Disabled
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 15  Marvin Webster, ailing for more than a week with tendinitis in his right knee, was placed on the injuredreserve list today. That means the New York Knicks 7foot1inch center will have to miss at least the next five National Basketball Association games, including tomorrow night's contest here against the Bulls.

title: At Fashion Parties, a Debut for Spring
description: The first .spring fashions from Europe were introduced to New Yorkers this week in an atmosphere of fun and good works, sometimes reminiscent of the happenings of the 1960's.

title: New York Is Blocked in Move of 12 Disturbed Children
description: ALBANY, Feb. 15  The parents of 12 severely autistic and retarded children today won a temporary Federal court order blocking New York State from bringing the children back from Rhode Island's Behavior Research Institute, which uses a controversial regimen of physical punishments and food rewards as part of its treatment.

title: Whitman MSS. at Barnard
description: Manuscripts, letters, poems and first editions of Walt Whitman. all collected by Charles E. Feinberg of Detroit, will be on view through March 9 at the Barnard College Library, Broadway and 116th Street. The exhibition includes material from the Library of Congress FeinbergWhitman Collection, Mr. Feinberg's private collection and the Rare Book and Manuscript Library of Columbia University. Hours this weekend are 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. today, noon to 5 P.M. tomorrow; closed Sunday. Admission is free. Information: 2803953.

title: Soviet Entrants in Chess Meet
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 15 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Soviet Union's last two places in the elimination tournament for the world chess championship will be filled by grandmasters Vitali Tseshkovsky and Gennady Kuzmin, Radio Moscow announced today. Tseshkovski and Kuzmin finished first and second in a threeman qualifying group which also included Oleg Romanishin.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: Rock: Robert Gordon
description: ROBERT GORDON, who opened a twonight stand at the Lone Star Cafe Wednesday night, with the late show broadcast live on WHN, emerged into his present rockabilly format in mid1977 Before that he was the lead singer of a New York punkrock band called the Tuff Darts, and hence his rockabilly image is mixed with a touch of hip urbanity, as opposed to raveup rural abandon. At the early show on Wednesday he appeared in a floppytrousered tuxedo with leopardskin coat, flared 1950's pompadour and all the looselimbed moves associated with the genre.

title: Irish, Rutgers Fives Triumph at Garden
description: Notre Dame unleashed its full fury in the second half last night and battered Manhattan, 8663, in the second game of a college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.

title: Film: 'Pryor in Concert':Mime and Mimic
description: JUST about nothing Richard Pryor has to say in "Richard Pryor in Concert," a film recording of one of his 1978 performances, can be reprinted here, but in a way that's just as well. It's not Mr. Pryor's individual lines that make his show so wickedly funny, nor are the comic conceits that launch his various routines automatically uproarious. Mr. Pryor is a superb mime and a fabulous mimic, and he can use almost any topic, intrinsically funny or not, to introduce the brand of physical comedy that is especially his own.Prowling the stage impishly, slipping effortlessly from one hilarious impersonation to the next, he radiates an intensity that isn't often visible in even his very best feature-length acting performances. And his stage routine is so dependent on grimaces and gestures that his concert albums don't capture its full vitality. If you don't like Mr. Pryor's vocabulary  and it would take a lot of imagination to come up with a saltier one  then you may not find him funny here or anywhere else. But if you're even remotely well disposed toward what he does, then this is a whale of a show.Performing after a three-year hiatus in his concert schedule, Mr. Pryor has a calmer, more assured delivery than he sometimes has on record (where his routines have sometimes had a hysterical edge). He makes no bones about the difficulties he has had in the intervening time, even giving an uproarious account of the well-publicized incident that got him arrested. (He shot his car.) A lot of his material is personal, including an imitation of his father and a version of what his grandmother did when she found him snorting cocaine. When he jokes about sex, he's as disarmingly self-deprecating as Lenny Bruce.Perhaps the funniest section of the show, which was performed before a mostly white audience in Long Beach, Calif., has Mr. Pryor moving effortlessly from an account of how black people behave in the woods, to speculation about what a deer would do if it saw Leon Spinks, to the comedian's thoughts about boxing, which apparently came to a head when he stepped into a ring with Muhammad Ali during a benefit and wondered whether the Champ would remember this was supposed to be all in fun.When Mr. Pryor toys with a physical activity such as boxing, he suddenly divides himself into pieces, explaining that the mind will say this while the legs do that, and so on. This gambit is at its most biting in a routine about the heart attack Mr. Pryor suffered, an account of what his heart told his body as it dealt each murderous blow.

title: OIL PRICING WORSENS RISK OF A RECESSION, ECONOMISTS DECLARE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  The prospect of still another round of rises in oil prices, touched off by the announcement of increases by Abu Dhabi and Qatar, heightens the risk of a recession this year and increased inflation, Government and private economists said today.

title: Obituary 5  No Title
description: Memorial to Joe Alex Morris Jr.

title: Kahn to Study an Offer by Meany For Labor to Help Monitor Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  Alfred E. Kahn, President Carter's chief adviser on inflation, has agreed to look into a proposal by George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., that the labor federation's local organizations help monitor retail prices around the country.

title: At the Movies
description: OUTSIDE, the north wind is whistling through the streets, but within, on the sound stage of the Astoria Film and Television Center in Queens, the sliding glass doors of the Bel Air mansion that has been built there amid glades of palm and jacaranda are open to catch the Pacific zephyrs.

title: EARNINGS
description: R. J. Reynolds Industries, the nation's largest cigarette maker, which recently acquired the Del Monte Corporation, producers of canned fruits and vegetables, yesterday reported a 7.5 percent decline in net income for the fourth quarter, its first such decline in more than a decade. For the year, however, its net was up 4.3 percent.

title: Taipei to Set Up New Organization To Continue Its Ties With the U.S.
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 15  President Chiang Chingkuo said today that Taiwan had agreed to set up a new organization to carry on TaiwanUnited States ties.

title: Art People
description: DOUBLE exposure has come to Jackie Winsor this month. Her spare but infinitely painstaking sculpture, composed of well  basic materials, not only appear in a fullscale exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art (through March 6), but she also has a piece in the Whitney Museum's current Biennial Exhibition.

title: Mexican Press Pleased With Lecture to Carter
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 15 (AP) Mexican newspapers were full of praise today for the way President Jose Lopez Portillo lectured President Carter at a state luncheon.

title: Indian Premier Is Invited To Pay a Visit to Peking
description: PEKING, Feb. 15 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Hua Kuofeng invited Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai of India to China today, saying that more contacts between India and China will help deepen mutual understanding.

title: Music of the East At Alternative Center
description: The sound of Indian and Japanese bamboo flutes and Persian dulcimer can be heard this weekend at the Alternative Center for International Arts, 28 East Fourth Street, between Lafayette Street and the Bowery.

title: Obituary 7  No Title
description: Deaths

title: A Bridge Between Two Worlds in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 15  A senior Western diplomat here commented yesterday that he and many of his European colleagues were greatly relieved to learn of the appointment of. Karim Sanjabi, leader of the National Front, as Foreign Minister in the Government of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: New York Areas Cited in a Study On Fatal Cancer
description: A study by the New York City Health Department says the city's highest death rates from respiratory cancer have been found among people residing on Staten Island and along waterfront stretches of Brooklyn and Manhattan's Lower West Side that are exposed to prevailing westerly winds from New Jersey.

title: SECRET POLICE HEAD AND 3 OTHERS IN IRAN SAID TO BE EXECUTED
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Friday, Feb. 16Iran's revolutionary Government executed four of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi's generals, including the head of Savak, the secret police, before dawn today.

title: CARTER VULNERABLE IN NEV HAMPSHIRE
description: MANCHESTER. N.H., Feb. 15  A year before the first 1980 Presidential primary, Jimmy Carter seems to be in trouble with the perennially skeptical voters of New Hampshire.

title: In Iran, Fears of a Revolution Within a Revolution
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 15  Only days after the Islamic movement of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini swept to power in a popular uprising without precedent in the modern Middle East, the specter of a revolution within the revolution stalks this divided nation.

title: Restaurants
description: WALKING back into the small dining room of Les Petites Gourmandes is like taking a step back in time to an intimate supper club of the mid 1930's or early 40's. This threeandahalfmonthold French restaurant on 56th Street, between Madison and Park Avenues, has a menu as stylish as its dcor and just enough decently prepared dishes to satisfy those who would enjoy the setting.

title: New England Strives for Compromise in Energy Conflicts
description: BOSTON, Feb. 15  Harold J. Keohane, a representative of the Department of Energy in New England, can see the dimensions of this nation's energy problems from his office here in two ways.

title: Screen: Nabokov's 'Despair':A Cousin of Lolita
description: IN the 1965 preface to his revised edition of "Despair," his novel first published in 1936. Vladimir Nabokov described the original Russian title, "Otchayanie," as being "a far more sonorous howl" than the English word he had chosen. But "Despair" will do for both the novel and for Rainer Werner Fassbinder's elegant, comic, purposely precious film version, adapted by the playwright Tom Stoppard, who has been inspired by Nabokov to attain new heights of splendid lunacy, and acted by Dirk Bogarde, who gives one of the wittiest performances of his entire career. The film opens today at the Gemini II.Though Nabokov wrote "Despair" almost 20 years before "Lolita," the two novels share something more than the author's very original sensibility, "Despair's" Hermann Karlovich is Lolita's indefatigable suitor, Humbert Humbert, somewhat younger, perhaps, and a tiny bit less polished, but equally blind and self-defeating in his obsessions. Like Humbert (and Nabokov), Hermann (Mr. Bogarde) is a Russian emigre, this time in Berlin in 1930. Hermann, who owns a small chocolate factory where everything is painted a soft lilac hue, from the delivery trucks to the gift boxes, is disassociated not only from the land where he grew up, but also from his wife, his business associates and, finally, from himself.When Hermann makes love to Lydia (Andrea Ferreol), his plump, pretty wife who has a fondness for baby talk ("intelligence" says Hermann, "would take the bloom off your carnality"), he mentally separates himself from the scene, sitting in the living room of their flat while he watches and stage-manages their play in the bedroom.Hermann is truly impossible  dandified, sarcastic and dishonest even about the details of his background. But, as he says at one point, "All the information I have about myself is from forged documents." With that acute sensitivity that often heralds approaching illness, Hermann responds to all of the world's vulgarities as if they were a kind of physical torture. An eyebrow twitches involuntarily when Lydia makes one of her egg-and-mild toddies, which she calls "moggy-woggies." He flinches as if threatened with a crowbar when Ardalion (Volker Spengler). Lydia's cousin and sometimes lover, a fat slob of an artist, appears before him dressed in nothing but a towel, his belly hanging over the top.But Hermann does love Lydia for all her sillinesses, probably because she loves him and finds him ever fascinating. "How dare you come into the room partly clothed," he yells at Lydia when she enters their bedroom dressed only in a black slip. "Off with it!"They do have fun, but they need money. It's to mend this need that Hermann devises a crazy insurance swindle, a scheme that is based on his use of a drifter named Felix (Klaus Lowitsch), who, Hermann is convinced, is his physical double, but who, as all the rest of us can see, bears little, if, any resemblance to him. Only a man so recklessly possessed could make such a mistake.Like the novel on which it is based, the film loses momentum as the machinery of the plot must be tended to near the end, but it's at this point one can fully appreciate the contributions by Mr. Fassbinder, Mr. Stoppard and Mr. Bogarde.Unlike some of his European colleagues who've not been able to make the transition to English-language films (I think especially of Alain Resnais and the late Luchino Visconti), Mr. Fassbinder succeeds brilliantly, with the great help, of course, of Mr. Stoppard. The baroque movements of the camera  it never sits if it can stand, and never stands if it can swoop and soar  produce a visual equivalent to the comic fussiness of the prose style of Nabokov's first-person narrative.Mr. Bogarde's prissy gestures, mixed with expressions of alarm and lust that are always conscious, as they are with someone a little beside himself, beautifully illuminate this seminal Nabokovian hero. Miss Ferreol is dainty, bovine, vulgar and always sweet, and Mr. Spengler, a red-haired German actor, is a mountain of unredeemable second-rateness.The Stoppard script is a joy for anyone who likes the English language. There are very few puns here. Instead, he has miraculously turned Nabokov's exposition into spoken dialogue that matches the tone of the original. "A line has length but no breadth," says Hermann. "If you could see it, it wouldn't be a line." That's pure Stoppard, inspired by Nabokov, and the result is perfectly seamless.

title: Iran's New Leaders Vow To Help U.S. Evacuation
description: TEHERAN, lien, Feb. 15  Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan expressed regret today that the United States had decided to begin evacuating most remaining Americans this weekend, but he promised protection and facilities to enable 1,000 a day to leave by air.

title: Waldheim Complains Countries Ignore U.N. Until They Are Losing
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 15 Secretary General Kurt Waldheim today gave what for him was an unusually pessimistic assessment of the world situation, complaining that world leaders often lacked the political will to settle a growing number of conflicts. He also stressed concern about a very serious oil crisis.

title: A Gain of 25,000 Jobs In New York Reported
description: The total number of employed persons in New York City rose by 25,000 between December 1977 and December 1978, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Strong Action Hinted By Rhodesian Forces For Attack on Airliner
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 15 Rhodesia's military commander strongly hinted today that his forces would avenge Monday's downing of an Air Rhodesia airliner, probably with strikes against black nationalist guerrilla bases in neighboring Zambia. But he said that any action would not necessarily be carried out immediately.

title: Money Supply Figures Are Up in Latest Week
description: The two most closely watched measures of the money supply rose in the week ended Feb. 7, marking the first increase since Jan. 17, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: Bostonians Offer Chamber Bill at Y
description: There was the time a violist's bow flew out of his hand into the audience and he kept on fiddling in mime, terrified that Maestro Serge Koussevitsky would notice. Or the time the conductor's more genial successor, Charles Munch, scowled and said in his French accent I never get nervous, but when I get nervous, oh!.

title: More House Campaigners Finding Easy Victory Brings Cash Windfall
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  More and more candidates for the House of Representatives have recently found themselves in the enviable position of enjoying a free ride, with no major party opponent in the general election.

title: Excerpts From Joint Communiqu by the Presidents
description: At the invitation of the President of the United Mexican States Licenciado Jos Lpez Portillo, the President of the United States of America, Jimmy Carter, made a visit to Mexico from the 14th to the 16th of February, 1979.

title: Clippers Sign Taylor
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 16 (AP)  Brian Taylor, a freeagent guard, has been signed by the San Diego Clippers for the remainder of the National Basketball Association season. The 27yearold Taylor will replace Bob Bigelow, who recently retired,

title: Fire Kills Ship Worker In Bronklyn Navy Yard
description: Martial Florestant, a 42yearold ship worker, was killed yesterday in a fire that broke out in a bilge tank of a containership under construction at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: Carey Opposes a Rise In Nassau's Sales Tax, But Is Silent on Veto
description: ALBANY, Feb. 16  Governor Carey said today that he opposed Nassau County's request for a 1 percent increase in the county sales tax, and warned that if it were enacted into law it may become permanent. But he declined to say whether he would veto the increase if was passed by the Legislature.

title: The Torsney Tangle
description: The case of policeman Robert Torsney has taken another bizarre turn. The white officer was acquitted on a controversial plea of insanity by an allwhite jury for the murder of a black Brooklyn youth. Now he finds himself locked in by the very laws he used to his advantage. They permitted an insanity defense but also require that he be committed to a mental hospital until he can prove that he is sane and no longer dangerous. An appellate court has now ruled that he must remain in the custody of hospital psychiatrists who don't think he is sick.

title: First Mardi Gras Parades Canceled As New Orleans Police Walk Out
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 16  Mayor Er nest N. Mortal canceled Mardi Gras pa rades for tomorrow, Sunday and Monday after city policemen resumed their strike tonight.

title: Miss Alcott, at 70140, Leads Florida Golf by 2
description: NORTH MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 16 Amy Alcott's second straight round of twounderpar 70 gave her a twostroke lead today over Sandra Post, who scored her second 71, in a $100,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament at Country Club Aventura.

title: Entertainment Events
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA. Lincoln Center, Mozart's Die Zauterfloete, 2; Strauss's Ariadne eut Naxos, 8.

title: U.S. Steel Sets Price Rise April 1
description: The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it would raise prices from 4 to 6 percent effective April 1 on onefourth of its more specialized steel products.

title: Japanese Groups in Race For Overseas Projects
description: TOKYO. Feb. 16 Japan's three big industrial groups  Mitsui. Mitsubishi and Sumitomo  are racing to build rival $1 billion petrochemical complexes off Singapore, in Saudi Arabia and in Iran.

title: Experimenting With TestTube Babies
description: The birth last July of Louise Brown, the first baby to be born from a human egg cell fertilized in the laboratory and then implanted in a mother's body, touched off immediate controversy. Critics questioned the ethics and morality of the artificial fertilization procedure. The British researchers responsible for the feat. Drs. Patrick Steptoe and Robert Edwards, were criticized for the unorthodox way in which they announced their success through the general press. Questions also were raised about their failure to reveal full details in a scholarly publication.

title: Suspect Seized by F.B.I. on Charge Of Extortion Against Grain Agent
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  A 26yearold man was charged late yesterday with attempting to extort $2 million from a wealthy shipping agent here on the threat of exposing allegedly illegal foreign bribe payments, the Federal Bureau of Inyestigation announced today.

title: City Ballet in Balanchine's Midsummer Night's Dream
description: The New York City Ballet gave its audience a Valentine's present on Wednesday night by offering the first in a series of performances of A Midsummer Night's Dream. George Balanchine's adaptation of Shakespeare's comedy will be at the New York State Theater through tomorrow.

title: Military Medical Chiefs Tell of Doctor Shortages
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) The medical chiefs of the Army, Navy and Air Force told Congress today that they were unable to recruit and retain all the doc, tors they needed.

title: About New York
description: The first time Pete Seeger heard the folk song, John Henry, he was a little boy and it was being played on a harmonica in Greenwich Village by Thomas Hart Benton, the artist. Pete 's father, Charles L. Seeger, had brought the boy along to meet his friend and to hear this music, and the father plucked alone with the tune on a guitar.

title: A.T. &
description: A court order temporarily blocking the new Iranian Government from emptying a S30 2 million New York bank account was obtained yesterday by a subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Nets Beaten
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Feb. 16  Bernard King, the New Jersey Nets scoring leader, had cause to feel relieved this morning after emerging with a $50 fine from a Criminal Court. hearing in Brooklyn held to review three charges against him.

title: Alberta's Natural Gas Potential Being Revised Sharply Upward
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Feb. 16  Estimates of western Canada's naturalgas reserves are now being raised by hundreds of trillions of cubic feet as a result of changing economics wrought by rising wellhead prices and improved field technology.

title: 30 Tourists Hurt in Bus Wreck
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 16 (Reuters)  About 30 Japanese tourists were injured today when a tour bus bound for Los Angeles ran off a highway south of here. Highway patrol officers said the driver apparently suffered a fatal heart attack at the wheel and the bus plowed through guard rail. Four of the injured tourists were hospitalized.

title: Schools Are Facing New Walkouts As Strike by Bus Drivers Continues
description: A wildcat strike by school bus drivers over job security moved into its second day yesterday, as the public school system braced for a walkout by custodial firemen and cleaners next week that could seriously impede classroom learning for the city's 1,000,000 students.

title: U.S. Is Investigating Florida's Environmental Deals
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 16  For decades Florida had a reputation as the home of unscrupulous real estate salesmen who cold useless swampland to unsuspecting mailorder buyers.

title: West Germans Sentence Terrorist Gang's Lawyer
description: BONN, Feb. 16  Klaus Croissant, former chief defense attorney for West Germany's BaaderMeinhof gang, was convicted today of aiding a criminal conspiracy by participating in an information network for the radical organization.

title: Ozawa, Ill, Unable to Play Boston Chamber Concert
description: Because of illness, Seiji Ozawa will be unable to appear with the Boston Symphony Chamber Players in their concert at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. tomorrow at 2 P.M.

title: 5 Persons in Louisiana Indicted  On Charge of VoteBuying in 1978
description: ALEXANDRIA, La., Feb. 16 (AP) Five Leesville residents were indicted by a Federal grand jury today in alleged votebuying in the election of Representative Claude Leach last year.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DeWitt Clinton defeated Taft, 7560, and Columbus downed Monroe, 5951, in Bronx borough semifinal games yesterday of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball playoffs. The teams will meet next weekend for the borough title and a berth in the P.S.A.L. citywide semifinals.

title: Concern Grows on Iran's Debt
description: FRANKFURT, Feb. 16 Nervotisness over the change of government in Iran is increasing; among European hankers, but any call for default on Iran's debts to the West is still expected to be a last resort.

title: Southern Says It Plans Payout
description: A spokesman for the Southern Company of Atlanta said yesterday that the company would be able to pay the rest of its quarterly dividends this year despite doubts raised by published reports of a statement by a company executive.

title: Yemen Fears Iranian Upheavals May Encourage Its Foe in South
description: SANA, Yemen, Feb. 14  On the craggy summit ridge of the 10.000foothigh Jebel Sabir, a turbaned tribesman straddled the rampart of a decaying Turkish fortress and pointed southeast to where the mountains spilled into the desert flatland of Southern Yemen.

title: Kuhn Upholds Sale Of 2 A's to Yankees
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn has allowed the Yankees to buy two minor league players from the Oakland A's for $500,000, but he indicated yesterday that he would soon issue new, more stringent guidelines for the purchase of players.

title: Merger Loans Are Questioned
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP)  The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board has told a Congressional committee that the use of bank credit to finance giant corporate takeovers raises important public interest goestions

title: Inquiry Begins on NearCollision at O'Hare
description: Federal investigators began an inquiry yesterday into the nearcollision of two aircraft Thursday in Chicago. A cargo jumbo jet was badly damaged in the incident after its pilot veered off the runway to avoid crashing into another airliner that was taxiing across the strip.

title: 96 Americans Return From Iran
description: The first Americans evacuated from Teheran, Iran, since the attack on the United States Embassy Wednesday reached Kennedy International Airport last night after a flight that began witn convoy of blackedout cars through series of checkpoints in Teheran's streets and ended 15 hours later in the glare of television cameras at the Pan American World Airways terminal.

title: Italian Skier Advances
description: ZAKOPANE, Poland, Feb. 16 (AP)  Giulio Capitanio of Italy won a 15kilometer ski race today and advanced from 11th place to fourth in the World Cup crosscountry standing. His time was 43 minutes 44.08 seconds. Lars Erik Eriksen of Sweden took the overall lead. He has 76 points and leads Oddvar Braa of Norway, who has 69.

title: Your Money
description: MANY people feel that wills, like life insurance, are an unnecessary provision for an inevitability that is far off, and in any case are only for the wealthy

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: 1. One American Ambassador was killed and another American Ambassador's life was endangered when mobs surrounded the embassy. Identify the diplomats and the countries in which the events occurred.

title: Court Rules Mayor May Not Vote On His Budgets in Estimate Board
description: The City Council President and the five Borough Presidents won a State Supreme Court ruling yesterday barring the Mayor from voting on budget modifications as a member of the Board of Estimate.

title: Farmers Stage a Protest Over Newspaper Reports
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) Farmers drove more than 100 tractors to The Washington Post today to protest newspaper editorials critical of their demonstrations and demands for higher crop Prices.

title: OBSERVER
description: It was not surprising to read in the papers that winter had tightened its icy grip on New York. I had suspected something of the sort during breakfast the other morning when I discovered myself wearing overcoat and scarf while spooning the oatmeal.

title: Inflation Rate Rises in Britain
description: LONDON, Feb. 16 (Reuters) Prices rose 1.5 percent last month in the biggest increase in a year. the Employment Department said today.

title: Duke Upset By Maryland
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Feb. 16 (AP)  Greg Manning hit a jumper with three seconds remaining, giving Maryland a 7068 Atlantic Coast Conference victory over fifthranked Duke tonight

title: WellEndowed Suriname Still Leans on Dutch ExRulers
description: PARAMARIBO, Suriname  A few weeks before the third anniversary of independence last November, a wild rumor swept this sparsely populated former Dutch colony on the northeastern coast of South America. According to the rumor, Queen Juliana of the Netherlands was going to abdicate and any Surinamese who was in the mother country when she did so would recover Dutch citizenship. Such citizenship had been retained by the third of the population that, out of economic or ethnic fear, left for the motherland in the two years preceding independence.

title: Senator Says 17 Foster Children May Be Among Jonestown Dead
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16  Initial inquiries show that perhaps as many as 17 foster children that the California authorities had placed with members of the People's Temple may have died in the mass deaths in Jonestown, Guyana, Senator Alan Cranston said here today.

title: The City
description: A state commission recommended yesterday that the foodprocessing industry be exempted from $5 million of the sales taxes it pays annually and that other manufacturing businesses be given a similar break as soon as the state can afford the loss in revenue.

title: ABC Plans to Acquire Chilton for $86 a Share
description: The American Broadcasting Companies announced an agreement yesterday to acquire a 44.6 percent interest in the Chilton Company, a publisher of magazines and books based in Radnor, Pa.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 19.

title: Coghlan Sets Record In 3:52.6 Indoor Mile
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 17 (AP)  Eamonn Coghlan patiently stayed back in the field until there were 2 laps to go to the finish, then went quickly to the front and shattered the world indoormile record tonight with a time of 3 minutes 52.6 seconds at the San Diego Invitational track meet.

title: Columbia Tops Yale On Final Shot, 6462
description: With just three seconds remaining, Alton Byrd, the shortest player on the Columbia squad at 5 feet 8 inches, popped in a onehanded set shot to enable the Lions to defeat Yale, 6462, in an Ivy League basketball game last night in the winner's gymnasium.

title: Precision Rubber Sale Set
description: The Signal Companies announced yesterday that it had entered into a letter of intent to sell its wholly owned subsidiary, the Precision Rubber Products Corporation, to James Carroll, the former president of Parco, a West Coast seal manufacturer. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Precision Rubber, of Lebanon, Tenn., is one of the largest manufacturers of specialty seals and custommolded rubber products.

title: EARNINGS
description: Genesco Inc., a large producer and retailer of footwear and apparel, reported yesterday that its earnings before extraordinary credits, in the second fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31, fell 25 percent to $4.5 million, or 28 cents a share, from $6 million, or 40 cents, a share, in the similar quarter a year earlier. The yearearlier result also included an extraordinary credit.

title: 6 Debutantes Introduced at Ball
description: Six young women, all descendants of men who served in the American Revolution, were introduced to society last evening at the 44th Colonial Ball and Debutante Presentation, at the Pierre Hotel. The event benefits patriotic education and scholarship funds of the New York City Chapter of the Sons of the American Revolution, sponsors of the annual event. The debutantes were Patricia Lidia Bales, Lisa Lee Foster, Elsie Allegra Harris, Mary Elizabeth Isaacson, Ellen Marie Jacovic and Susan Elizabeth Utley.

title: Celebrities Pack a Party to Honor Twyla Tharp
description: Everybody, it seems, loves Twyla Tharp. Lester Persky, the producer, pronounced her our greatest national resource at the postperformance party at La Boite to celebrate the opening of her new dance works at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this week. Miss Tharp, sharing a banquette with Woody Allen, bowed modestly and blew Mr. Persky a kiss.

title: Onondaga's Executive And a G.O.P. Senator Charged With Felony
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 16  State Senator Martin S. Auer, Republican of Syracuse, and Onondaga's County Executive, John H. Mulroy, and an insurance agent were indicted here today on felony charges in connection with an alleged kickback scheme to obtain political funds from insurance agencies. A second insurance agent was to be arraigned in the case.

title: Spot Commodity Index
description: Source Bureau of Labour StatistIcs

title: BAR UNIT CRITICIZED ON DISCIPLINE ROLE
description: Once the envy of bar groups across the country for the way it disciplined errant New York lawyers, the City Bar Association has reached the point where many association officials are urging that it get out of the business of disciplining lawyers entirely.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, Feb 16,1979

title: Twyla Tharp's Dancers Perform 4 New Works
description: Twyla Tharp and Dancers opened their engagement at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Thursday night with four new works that demonstrated that Miss Tharp remains an unusually inventive choreographer. All four dances were also dances that probably could not have been choreographed by anyone other than an American.

title: Billy Carter's Problems
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 16  Who, really, is Billy Carter, and why is he saying all those outrageous things?

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: American Stores Starts Talks on Skaggs Merger
description: The American Stores Company, one of the country's major supermarket chains, and Skaggs Companies Inc. jointly announced yesterday that they had started preliminary talks on a possible merger.

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 16 (AP) Thousands of Cambodians lined the highway to Pochentong airport in Phnom Penh today to great Prime Minister ?? Van Dong of Vietnam, according to ?? dio report.

title: John F. Falvey, Former Reporter, Founder of PublicRelations Firm
description: John F. Falvey, a retired financial writer and publicrelations man, died Wednesday at his home in Carle Place, L.I. He was 76 years old.

title: Carter's Leadership: Questions in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  The slaying of the American Ambassador in Afghanistan and fears about the fate of 7,000 Americans remaining in Iran have sharpened sentiment in Congress that President Carter has not acted forcefully enough to project American power abroad.

title: Mexican Percussion Piece
description: The notion of an extended piece for percussion by a Mexican composer may suggest a fairly splashy concoction, with exotic instruments and spicy ethnic rhythms. But the ?? ?? Chavez's Toccata for Percussion Instruments (1942), which led off a program of Contemporary Music of the Americas on Thursday night at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A., sticks closely to the most familiar orchestral drums and keyboards. And, though vigorous Latin rhythms turn up in spots, the Toccata is more remarkable for its decorum.

title: Klauss Conducts Pierrot Consort
description: The Pierrot Consort, a chamber ensemble in residence at the School of the Arts of the C.W. Post Center on Long Island, presented a concert in Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night under the direction of Walter Kla uss. Although the program of mostly 20thcentury music looked promising on paper, the evening as a whole proved to be something of a disappointment.

title: Aqueduct Limits Betting as Dispute Persists
description: With only 103 sellers and 36 cashiers on duty because of a labor dispute and with only win and daily double betting available at the track, Aqueduct staggered through another ninerace card yesterday.

title: Italian Effort to Form Cabinet Seems to Fail
description: ROME, Feb. 16  Acting Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti appeared today to have failed in his efforts to form a new government, making early elections all but inevitable.

title: Bus Strike Is Causing Most of Handicapped To Miss Their Classes
description: Joan Moret pointed out yesterday, and Susan Linzer agreed at once, that the wildcat strike by schoolbus drivers had produced at least one significant benefit.

title: Attack on Oil Sharing Stirs Concern in Industry
description: Ottawa's sharply negative reaction to the Exxon Corporation's cutback of oil deliveries to Canada was interpreted in United States oil circles as a disturbing irony that suggests that the oilsharing provisions of the International Energy Agency may prove unworkable if those provisions are ever actually triggered.

title: Page Knocks Out Martin in 2d
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 16  Greg Page, a 20yearold Louisville heavyweight, made his professional boxing debut tonight at the Commonwealth Convention Center and stole a page from ring history.

title: Carter Ends Mexico Visit
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 16  President Carter's troubled visit to Mexico ended today with an announcement that he and President Jose Lpez Portillo had agreed on the start of governmental negotiations for United States purchase of Mexican natural gas. The two Presidents also agreed to meet in the United States in the summer to assess progress on this and other issues.

title: 3 Officials Hold Initial Meeting On Bronx Plan
description: The first meeting of officials involved in blueprinting an overall redevelopment plan for the South Bronx was held yesterday in the office of the Bronx Borough President, Stanley Simon.

title: Kingpin of the Bowling Tour
description: Like most bowlers, Mark Roth came out of the back end  back where the pins are. Years ago they were known as pinboys. Automatic machines spot the pins now, but kids are still needed back there to clean and recoat the pins. When the alleys are empty, those kids bowl themselves. Growing up, Mark Roth was too small for other sports. ism ne WAS ins. enough to bowl. To make up for his lack of size; he had to throw the ball as hard as he could to generate the speed that would make the pins scatter. When he joined the Professional Bowlers Association tour, skeputa predicted he would never make it. He just rears back and throws, they said. No style. His tight grip also used to tear the skin off his right thumb: He has learned to protect his thumb. But he's stilt ?? the fastest bowling ball. After three consecutive years as the bowler with the highest earnings and the highest average, Mark Roth again is making money faster than anybody else on the P.B.A. tour. So far this year he has earned $36,895, not much by the financial standards of other sports, but Mark Roth is one of the most dominant performers in any game.

title: Radio
description: 67A.M WNYCFM. Gregorian ,Chant from the Abbey of Encalcat in France; Works by Dufay; Luce degli occhi mIel, Pergolesi.

title: Costa Piano Interpretations
description: Pianoplaying that is brilliant, exciting or powerful is not difficult to come by nowadays. Indeed, there are currently so many pianists who qualify in one or more of these categories that it is hard to find enough engagements to keep all of them busy. But how often do we hear a pianist whose playing keeps making us think of the word beautiful? Beautiful, that is, in terms of caressing tone quality available in many colors, of a subtle command of dynam??cs including many variants of softness but no raucous fortissimos, of phrasing and sensibility that almost invariably catch and project the essence of a poetic mood. Well, there are not many pianists of this sort, and for that reason sequeira Costa's recital at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night was especially welcome.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: U.S. Seeks Meeting With Bazargan In Effort to Solidify Ties With Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  The United States announced today that it would maintain normal diplomatic relations with the new Iranian Government and sought an early meeting between Ambassador William H. Sullivan and Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan to discuss future ties.

title: Shah Said to Consider Abdicating as a Way To End Battles in Iran
description: RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 16 (AP)  Shah Mohammad Riza Pahlevi is considering abdicating in hopes of ending the bloodshed between his supporters and backers of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, sources close to the exiled Iranian ruler said today.

title: NBCTV Network Names Executive Vice President
description: Arthur A. Watson was named executive vice president of the NBC television network Thursday, a position that will put him in charge of network sales as well as administration of NBC's coverage of the 1980 Olympics.

title: A.T.&T. Delay On Network
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  The American Telephone and Telegraph Company told the Federal Communications Commission today that it would be delayed in filing a tariff for its new digital network system.

title: The Electric Bill
description: MONTGOMERY, ALA. Everybody from President Carter to Willie Randolph is talking about how we can cure the problem of inflation.

title: OilGas Issues Strong, But Dow Slips 2.08 Points
description: Wall Street's oilandgas rush continued in force yesterday with some issues selling at their highest lev. is in response to the latest price increases by Middle East producing nations. Elsewhere, takeover developments touched off gains in a number of stocks.

title: U.S. Plans Chad Evacuation as an American Is Killed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  The State Department has set up a special task force to direct the evacuation of scores of Americans from Chad, where one American has already been killed in the political strife.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Prices of silver futures ended a spectacular week of up and down movement with a dramatic threedirectional swing yesterday.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: New home construction fell to its lowest level in two years in January and personal income grew by only 0.4 percent last month, the smallest amount in a year, according to the Commerce Department. Both reports reflect the economic slowdown that many economists predict will lead to a recession. Last month's housing starts dropped to an annual rate of 1.7 million units, 20 percent below the 2 million starts in December. Those figures are regarded as significant because home building is usually the first industry hit by an approaching recession. [Page 1.]

title: 20 MORE SHAH AIDES SAID TO FACE DEATH IN START OF A PURGE
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 16  Iran's revolutionary authorities, announcing what appeared to be the start of a purge of leading supporters of Shah Mohammed Rita Pahlevi, reported today that four generals had been put to death. But the new leadership warned against any private, unauthorized acts of vengeance.

title: Head of Burned Abortion Clinic Trades Charges With Opponent
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 16  The founder of the Bill Baird abortion clinic on Main Street here and the president of a Long Island Right to Life organization have blamed each other for the fire that destroyed the clinic yesterday when a man barged into the corner storefront with a lighted torch and a can of gasoline.

title: Jersey City Synagogue Ruined by Fire
description: Congregation Ohab Shalom, a 73yearold building on Warner Avenue, was heavily damaged yesterday by a fire that broke out shortly before noon. There were no injuries. The blaze, which was not considered suspicious, was one of three that occurred within an hour of each other, forcing the Jersey City Fire Department to call in units from nearby Bayonne and Kearny.

title: Tate and Bobick On Mark
description: Duane Bobick fights John Tate today in Indianapolis, and the bout is either the first of a tournament leading to world heavyweight title or the championship of American Olympic boxers who have been knocked out by Teofilo Stevenson, the Cuban who dominates the amateur heavyweight scene.

title: Ford Motor Recalls 62,000 Vans To Replace Faulty Steering Part
description: DETROIT, Feb. 16 (AP)  The Ford Motor Company recalled 62,000 fourwheel drive vans and light trucks today for inspection and possible replacement of a steering component that might break and cause loss of control.

description: Deaths

title: Confidence Games Cheated New Yorkers of Reported $2 Million in 1978
description: Beware of attractive young women who want to share parcels of found money, men from South Africa who do not trust banks and policemen who offer their assistance but refuse to divulge their telenhone numbers.

title: Coquelico to Open New Broadway House
description: A new Broadway legitimate theater, 22 Steps, will open Thursday with Coquelico, a multimedia production by the National Theater of Prague.

title: Lockheed Tells of Payments
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP)  The Lockheed Corporation disclosed more details today about at least $30 million in what it called questionable payments to foreign governments, including a $1 million gift to a member of the Dutch royal family.

title: Cold Means Feverish Work For City's Boiler Inspectors
description: Jose Lopez, the building superintendent, frowned as the boiler spat out foul fumes, black smoke and sparks but refused to ignite. Only after his handyman, Hilberto Quinones, had repeatedly stuffed burning newspapers into the boiler's oilsoaked base did a flame appear and the people in the 13 apartments above begin to receive heat and hot water.

description: Afternoon

title: Roc, a New Hard Rock Quintet
description: In Oriental myth, the roc is a bird of fabulous strength, not to be confused with the simurgh, a fowl possessed of extraordinary wisdom. Appropriately, a new local band named Roc plays with a good bit of spirit and power but not, if their performance at the Other End on Thursday evening was any indication, with exceptional intelligence. The victor in a battle of the bands sponsored by Manhattan's Borough President, Andrew J. Stein, Roc won an engagement at the club and a contract with fledgling Infinity Records to make a single. As for an entire album, well, at this point they have nearly the professional polish but by no means the distinctive personality to,pull one off.

title: Renaissance of the Milliner's Art
description: Once upon a time, in fact up until the 1960's, a woman didn't consider herself dressed unless she was wearing a hat.

title: High Auto Prices Spur Leasing Boom
description: DETROIT, Feb. 16  Faced with rising prices of new cars and high interest rates on auto loans, individuals are turning increasingly  with some help from eager dealers  to leasing as a means of getting behind the wheel of a newmodel car.

title: World Gold
description: FRIDAY FEB 16. 1979

title: H. Andrew Dudley, 68, A Public Relations Aide
description: H. Andrew Dudley, a 68yearold public relations consultant, died in his apartment at 235 East 57th Street Sunday night.

description: Deaths

title: MiddleoftheRoad Pop Dominates 21st Grammys
description: The big winner at the 21st annual Grammy Award ceremony Thursday night  televised from the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles by CBSTV was good, oldfashioned middleoftheroad pop music. Disco made a few apparent inroads, but not as many as expected. And what disco there was, predictably enough, was of the softly middleoftheroad variety.

title: Japan Color TV Output
description: TOKYO, Feb. 16 (AP)  Japanese production of color television sets last year totaled 8.55 million units, a drop of about 11 percent from 1977, the Electronic Industries Association of Japan said today. It attributed the decrease to sluggish exports. particularly to the United States. The association said shipments in 1978 totaled 8.72 million units, down 2.6 percent from 1977, and exports totaled 3.61 million units, drop of 18.4 percent from the preceding year

title: Iran Evacuation Plan Ready for All Contingencies
description: The air evacuation of American citizens and the removal of sensitive electronic equipment from Teheran and other Iranian cities involves a number of contingencies for the Military Airlift Command and the Department of Defense.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: LUCY L. PULLING

title: Soviet Writers' Project Scuttled As Second Class, Pornographic
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 16  The 23 Soviet authors who thought they might challenge the authorities to publish a literary almanac full of their censored works are finding out that they cannot get away with it.

title: Suit Alleging Forced Sterilization Of Deaf Woman Rejected by Jury
description: BANGOR, Me., Feb. 16 (AP)  A Federal jury absolved all five defendants of liability today in a $1.5 million damage suit filed by a deaf mother of two who said she had been sterilized against her will.

title: Coop City to Get Home Box Office in Spring
description: Home Box Office, the pay television service, will be made available to residents of Coop City in the Bronx next spring.

title: Howl
description: CHELSEA, QUE. Were the threefifths of the electorate who ignored last November's election trying to send Washington a message?

title: Louise Allbritton, Actress, Dead
description: Louise Allbritton, an actress active in movies in the 1940's, died yesterday of cancer at a hospital in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, according to reports from the Columbia Broadcasting Company. Miss Allbritton was the wife of Charles Coilingwood, CBS correspondent. She was born in 1920 and had a resort home in Mexico.

title: CANCER DRIVE SEEKS TO CUT BLACKS' TOLL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  Citing the growing disparity of cancer levels between blacks and whites, the American Cancer Society today announced a campaign to educate both the general public and the minority community in cancer prevention and early diagnosis.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Singer Company announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle, without admitting liability, to a settlement of three classaction lawsuits brought against Singer, the Rockwell International Corporation and Textron Inc. The suits were filed in Federal court in Philadelphia by three Pennsylvania utilities, alleging price fixing in the sale of gas meters.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: UPTOWN, DOWNTOWN A 50piece band is considered a whopper by any standards, today or yesteryear. Better still; tonight's soundoff by the large ?? Orchestra of Lester Bowie, the trumpeterleader, includes some firstrate jazz names and groups. Mr. Bowie was praised by both John S. Wilson and Robert Palmer of The New York Times, and his The 5th Power was named the disk of the year by Record World Magazine.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Cautious on Soviet Deal
description: TOKYO, Feb. 16  The Soviet Union has received a lukewarm Japanese reaction to its proposals for three major joint projects in Siberia, including a giant integrated steel mill, made at a threeday meeting that ended here today.

title: The Region
description: The Unification Church of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon filed suit yesterday against nine towns and villages in Suffolk and Nassau Counties that have ordinances against solicitation that the church says violate its constitutional right to religious freedom. Two civil suits were filed in United States District Court in Brooklyn, citing the First and 14th Amendments.

title: Help and a Smile at a City Bus Terminal
description: You're new in town, just off a bus at the Port Authority terminal. Miles of corridors stretch before you, walls of windows, hurrying men and women with thousandyard stares. Outside the cars crawl, six abreast, up Eighth Avenue. Who can you turn to?

title: Letter: On Savings Bank Life Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: She's Ready for College Now  But This Time as President
description: Ursula Schwerin was already deep into her work when a visitor arrived at her office at 8:30 A.M. on a recent day to watch how the new president of financially beleaguered college in the city university system functions.

title: John Gallup Laylin, 76, ExOfficial at Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  John Gallup Laylin, an international lawyer and senior partner at Covington & Burling here, died this morning after he was struck by a falling tree branch on his farm in Great Falls. Va. He was 76 years old.

title: Kim, Eschenbach Get Together For Five Mozart Violin Sonatas
description: YoungUck Kim, violinist, and Christoph Eschenbach, pianist, two of the more striking of the younger performers around now, got together for a program of five Mozart violin sonatas at Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Thursday night. The combination was a??potent one, drawing an audience that overflowed onto the stage.

title: Baby in Malpractice Suit Was Put Up for Adoption
description: The Long Island couple who sued their doctors for the cost of lifetime care of their retarded baby, and won a landmark court ruling holding that doctors could sometimes be liable for such costs, gave up their daughter for adoption during the course of their lawsuit.

title: China Posts a New Target: Bureaucratic Ossification
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 16  A small rural county in the mountains of Szechwan Province printed over a million pages of documents last year, a recent investigation by a reporter for the Communist Party newspaper, Jenmin Jih Pao. showed.

title: Slain Envoy to Receive Full Military Honors
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP)  Full military honors are planned Sunday when a special White House plane lands at Andrews Air Force Base with the body of Adolph Dubs, the United States Ambassador to Afghanistan who was slain Wednesday.

title: Bertrand A. Gramelspacher, 49
description: The Rev. Bertrand A. Gramelspacher, a Roman Catholic Maryknoll missionary priest, died Wednesday in Shizuokaken, Japan, after a stroke. He was 49 years old.

title: New Face in Giants' Hunt: Ray Perkins
description: Dan Reeves, heretofore believed to be the leading candidate for the Giants coaching job, mentioned a new name yesterday as one of his leading opponents  Ray Perkins, who as a collegian caught many passes from Joe Namath at the University of Alabama and who as a pro caught some from Johnny Unitas with the Baltimore Colts.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON A PROFESSOR of engineering at George Washington University here has patented a method of storing solar energy underground so that heat from the summer sun can be used to warm buildings in winter.

title: Around the Nation
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16 (AP)  A 3yearold boy who had been in a coma since being struck by a car three months ago died tonight after doctors disconnected a respirator on his parents orders.

title: 2 Killed in Raid on Poker Game
description: GREENWOOD, Miss., Feb. 16 (AP)Three masked men raided a poker game at a country club today and killed two players with shotgun blasts before escaping with $300 to $400 from the table, the authorities said. There was no provocation whatsoever, said the Leflore County chief deputy sheriff, Ricky Banks. They just shot them with shotguns.

title: Indictments Say 3 Tried to Cheat On Sewer Work
description: A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn has indicted a contracting concern and three individuals on a charge of conspiracy to manufacture and supply substandard concrete pipe for Suffolk Cdunty's Southwest Sewer District.

title: Bridge:
description: An expanded novice program, for players with less than 20 master points, will be a features of the Greater New York Bridge Association's twoday sectional tournament beginning today at the New York Hilton.

title: Lietzke Stays Hot on 66 for 129
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 16 For Bruce Lietzke this is where he began winning two years ago. He had been on the progolf tour a couple of years and, while he had won $69,229 in his second year, his name was no household word on the circuit.

title: Staff of Nuclear Panel Sees No Need to Close Any Plants as Unsafe
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP)  The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission says that the commission does not have to shut down any nuclear reactors or change any of its policy decisions despite its repudiation of a safety study.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Rise
description: Yields rose on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and 182day maturities.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, FEB 16, 1979

title: Tanner Tops Connors
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. (AP)  The upsets in the $250,000 tennis games event at Mission Hills Country Club caught up with topseeded Jimmy Connors today, and he fell to Roscoe Tanner by 46. 63. 76.

title: Ultimate Questions of the Middle East
description: WASHINGTON The Lebanese, Syrians and Palestinians have been living as neighbors and brothers in peace and creative interaction since the beginning of time, and are destined to such a relationship until the end of time.

title: Delaware Blaze Kills 7 in Family Days After They Fled Home Fire
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 16 (AP)  A refuge turned into a fiery deathtrap today for seven members of a Wilmington family, including six who were burned out of their own home just two days earlier.

title: Bulls Hand Knicks 5th Straight Setback
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 16  On one of those days when nothing seemed to go right for anyone, the Chicago Bulls dismissed their coach, Larry Costello, and replaced him with his assistant, Scotty Robertson, and the Knicks were caught making an illegal roster move by trying to put Marvin Webster on the injuredreserve list without replacing him with another player.

title: Spring Comes to Central Park
description: It is almost as hard to believe in spring right now as it is to believe that the New York Parks Department is about to begin rehabilitating Central Park. And yet, the longawaited repair plan that has appeared and disappeared through two administrations is at long last going forward.

title: Books of The Times; Exhaustive or Exhausting? Symbolism and Irrelevance Hustling to Eat
description: If you are not put off by Frederick R. Karl's style, his biography of Joseph Conrad will tell you almost everything that is known about one of this centurv's better and more colorful writers.

title: Hospital Group Backs Carter Cost Goal, Not Limits
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 16  Alfred E. Kahn, President Carter's chief inflation fighter, called a news conference today to accept with genuine appreciation a hospital group's endorsement of the President's guidelines for hospital cost restraint.

title: Canada Protests Oil Supply Cut
description: OTTAWA. Feb. 16  A decision by the Exxon Corporation to divert Venezuelan crude oil from its Canadian affiliate has created fear in the Atlantic provinces about their supplies and has brought an angry reaction from the Government in Ottawa.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar gained slightly against most currencies markets abroad and in New York yesterday in quiet trading that showed little reaction to United States recognition of the Government in Iran.

title: 2 REPORTS INDICATE ECONOMY IS SLOWING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  Two reports by the Commerce Department today produced new evidence that the nation's economic activity was slowing.

title: Corporations Report Their Sales and Earnings Results for the Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock. E xchange and (O) overthecounter

title: 1,000 Workers Evacuated in Fire
description: WARREN, Mich., Feb. 16 (AP)About 1,000 employees were evacuated after a fire broke out today in a solarium at the General Motors Corporation Technical Center today. There were no injuries in the fire. The extent of the damage and the cause of the fire could not immediately be determined, the fire officials said.

title: An Embattled Esposito Stands Firm in Brooklyn
description: Put your hungry looks away, Meade H. Esposito, the Brooklyn Democratic leader, told a recent gathering of the 44 district leaders in his county organization.

title: Democrats Set Roadblocks Against Parkways Chief
description: WHITE PLAINS THEY want to shoot the piano player, but he's doing the best he can, said Robert Greene the other day as he sipped coffee and talked about the recent attacks on his fouryear stewardship of the East Hudson Parkway Authority.

title: The Children's World of E.B. White on Disks
description: Adebonair mouse, an industrious spider and a talented swan are the central figures in E.B. White's three books for children Stuart Little, Charlotte's Web and The Trumpet of the Swan  and if their adventures make for happy reading in the Harper and Row books that feature them, on records they are downright irresistible. Joe Berk, who owns and operates Pathways of Sound, a small record company in Cambridge, Mass., has committed all three books to disks, uncut and unabridged, in performances that are models of how to turn a visual text into a memorable auditory experience.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN a radiator doesn't get hot, or doesn't heat up all the way across even though all the other radiators seem to be working properly, chances are that the radiator in question is airbound and needs bleeding to get it working again. If a sizable bubble of air gets trapped inside a radiator, it keeps water or steam from filling completely, and as a result the radiator does not get hot all the way across. In some cases, particularly in a steam system, the radiator may not heat up at all.

title: Seattle Housing Boom Illustrates Dislocations Cited in Last Week's HUD Study
description: SEATTLE  When Lawrence and Ruth Campbell retired back in 1965, they left New York for a nice twobedroom apartment with a lovely view and reasonable rent Washington state's largest city, settled in for life  or so they thought. Then, says Mr. Lawrence, 79, along came the fast buck men. The elderly couple is facing eviction for the third time in two years, as one by one, their apartments have been converted into condominiums.

title: DINING OUT
description: IN restaurants, as in life, where there is little competition there is little excellence and much complacency, a condition that seems to describe German restaurants in Westchester generally and Maxl's specifically. Opened in 1931, Maxl's developed a reputation for good food, convivi ality and lively entertainment, but now the place suffers from a weltschmerz that encourages mediocrity. The dining room is still a jerrybuilt rathskeller complete with Bavarian murals, redcheck tablecloths and heavy wooden archways leading to a grand dark barroom serving a fine array of German beers  Beck's light and dark, and Weissbier from Munich (with lemon slice) and Berlin (with strawberry syrup).

title: Fastest Pen In Nashville Signs Off as Inquiry Grows
description: NASHVILLE  The politician a Tennessee newspaper called a Hillbilly Nixon has retired to Hillbilly Heaven. Forced from office by a paroleselling investigation and his own decision to sign 52 clemency documents in a single night, former Gov. Ray Blanton has moved into a $130,000 house across the street from Webb Pierce, the country singer who favors a guitarshaped swimming pool and steerhorn hood ornaments. There, the deposed Governor has attempted to veil the riddle of Ray Blanton in the kind of privacy that Music City's neighborhoods afford its stars.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The other day while watching Robert Altman's new film, the endoftheworld fantasy called Quintet, I could feel the blood rushing to my feet and my heart wanting to follow. The movie was both leaving me cold and giving me the sweats. At the same time I was thinking about Mr. Altman, hoping that he wouldn't take us critics too seriously. After all, we write for the general public, not for the makers of films who, we must assume, know what they have set out to do and how close they have come to achieving their goals.

title: Design
description: On a hill in the green Athens suburb of Ekali, overlooking a vista which stretches down to the town and on to Mount Parnis, Greece's leading artist, Yiannis Spyropoulos, 66, has Greek artist Yiannis Spyropoulos has built his dream house. Overlooking Athens, it is at once a home for himself and his wife, a studio and a gallery for the display of his large canvases. created a building which is a home for himself and his wife, a perfectly organized studio for him to work in and a gallery for the display of his huge canvases.

title: Looking East in Error
description: As I passed through security at Heathrow Airport, the guard, seeing this book, said meaningfully That looks interesting. This reaction will doubtless please the author, as confirms a part of his thesis. The ??

title: The High Cost of Economy
description: NORWALK WILLIAM A. Collins sits in the mayor's office at City Hall these days and wonders how he is going to make ends meet for Norwalk at a time when the state and Federal governments are becoming more frugal about dispensing aid to Connecticut's cities and towns.

title: U.A.W. CITES ISSUES IN CONTRACT TALKS
description: DETROIT, Feb. 17 (UPI)  Douglas A. Fraser, president of the United Automobile Workers, says that compensatory time and a call for a oneyear contract could be key demands in union negotiations with the automobile industry this fall.

title: Sociologist Urges Tying Loans to Federal Service
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP)  Congress should make national service a condition for receiving student loans instead of reviving the military draft, a sociologist has proposed.

title: Between Ego and House, A Highly Emotional Affair
description: Home is not just where the heart is, its also where one ??ds the ego, the imagination, the nerves, the spleen, ano sometimes cold feet.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: THE title of the book is Early Stages and its author is Anne Jackson, who is appearing at Theater 4 with her family (the Eli Wallachs) in The Diary of Anne Frank and is remembered for her roles in Luv, The Tiger, The Typists and The Waltz of the Toreadors, among other plays. In spite of this list of theater credits, Early Stages is not a reprise of Miss Jackson's theatrical career nor a gossipy peek behind the theatrical curtain. As Miss Jackson tells it, the book, which Little, Brown is bringing out next spring, did not even have a theatrical connection.

title: Hillers and Creekers
description: AS the 1960's drew to a close, a young writer named Paul Cowan  by then a veteran of the Peace Corps, the civilrights movement and the efforts to end the Vietnam War  published a precocious memoir titled The Making of an UnAmerican. The book was a monument to selfabsorp

title: Notes: Hobnobbing With the Stars
description: Once upon a time people went to the Bijou to watch James Cagney act tough or dance with equal skill, to see Clark Gable and Carole Lombard suggest what now is made specific and to enjoy Marilyn Monroe simply being poignantly beautiful.

title: Rhodesian Planes Strike in Zambia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 17 (AP)  Rhodesian planes attacked nationalist guerrilla camps in neighboring Zambia early this morning, five days after guerrillas shot down a civilian airliner.

title: Columbia Drubs Brown, 7354
description: With almost all hopes of contending for the Ivy League championship realistically gone, the Columbia Lions are now, according to Buddy Mahar, the coach, and to Ricky Free, their leading scorer, playing for our sense of pride.

title: Wine
description: Cordials and liqueurs have never been more popular. The sillier the combination of flavors and the more ridiculous the advertising and promotion, the more we drink them up. And the sweeter they are, the better we seem to like them.

title: Carter, Wary of Carey Ambitions, Is Courting Other State Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17  President Carter's political aides, expecting Governor Carey to chart an independent course in the 1980 Presidential election, have begun a quiet campaign to strengthen their ties to a variety of different influential Democrats in New York State.

title: Castellated Folly to Let
description: A castellated folly on a cliffside, a thatchedroof cottage alongside a wood, a fourstory stone water tower with one room on each floor  these are three of dozens quaint, quirky and, above all, quiet vacation properties that may be leased from the National Trust for England, Wales and Northern Ireland, which has renovated abandoned farms, schoolhouses, lodges and mills. Most have heat, hot water and kitchens.

title: Renewal Plan Falters in Glen Cove
description: GLEN COVE THREE years ago, Giuseppe Grella enthusiastically opened his haberdashery as the first tenant of the Village Square, the very model of urban renewal and future hope of this North Shore community's failing downtown business area.

title: GARDENING
description: LOOK to the yews for that hardtofill spot in the landscape. They are a versatile group of mostly slowgrowing evergreen shrubs and small trees that have been cultivated for at least 2,000 years. Nowadays, they are increasingly popular in New Jersey gardens.

title: The Beaux Arts Trio Is Still Pioneering
description: Most people still think of chamber music primarily in terms of string quartets. But in recent years we've seen a rapid expansion not only of the audience for chamber music, but of that audience's sophistication and its awareness that the genre also includes sonatas, piano trios, string trios, small vocal ensembles, quintets, sextets and indeed all manner of combinations.

title: Melissa Elfenbein Fiance of Engineer
description: Melissa Heidi Elfenbein and George Frederick Bockelmann plan to be married in June in Cliffside Park, N.J. Announcement of their engagement has been made by the prospective bride's parents. Dr. Iris M. Elfenbein of Washington and Richard Elfenbein of Fort Lee, N.J. Mr. Bockelmann is son of Joan Bader Bockelmann and Dr. John Burggraf Bockelmann, both of Tenafly, N.J.

title: John Christian, Lawyer, Fianc of Susan Davies
description: Dr. and Mrs. Fel Gale Davies of Utica, N.Y., have anounced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Merritt Davies of New York, to John M. Christian, son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Christian of New Carrollton, Md.

title: Judith Valentine Fiance of Robert Runyon
description: Mr. and Mrs. George H. Valentine of Chatham, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Anne Valentine of Corpus Christi, Tex., Agency, insurance administrators in Corpus Christi, is an alumna of Fairleigh Dickinson University. Her father, an insurance consultant, is a former special agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New York.

title: Miss Reid Fiance Of Dr. N.D. Ravin
description: The engagement of Claudia Reid of Providence, R.I., daughter of Mrs. Ernest Utterback of London and Maj. Gen. Spencer B. Reid, U.S.A., commander of the Seventh Army Medical Corps at Heidelberg, West Germany, to Dr. Neil D. Ravin, also of Providence, son of Louis H. Ravin of Bethesda, Md., and the late Jean Ravin, has been announced. The future bridegroom's father retired as special assistant to the Secretary of Labor. A May 13 wedding is planned.

title: FixedIncome Math
description: As interest rates have soared, investors again have become engrossed with Treasury bills, notes, bonds, debentures, money market certificates, and the whole world of fixedincome securities. The appeal of this world is yield, but yield mathematics are not easily understood.

title: ART
description: PURCHASE WHEN Julia Margaret Cameron saw a person she wanted to photograph, she would stop at little to have him sit for her. She would initiate a friendship by giving the person in question gifts, usually an Indian shawl that she had brought to England from the East. Then she often gave a second shawl, which was followed by jewelry, an assortment of bricabrac and ivories. Even the most recalcitrant subjects submitted to Mrs. Cameron's attentions and eventually sat for her.

title: Correction
description: In a story on the Census Bureau in the Week in Review of Feb. 11, a quotation from the March issue of American Demographics magazine was wrongly attributed. The author of the quoted matter is Bryant Robey, editor of American Demographics.

title: Who Knows How Much Rent You Can Afford? Hank Sopher, That's Who
