description: IN the first half of this decade two landmark studies Arthur R. Miller's Assault on Privacy: Computers, Data Banks, and Dossiers and the hearings of former Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr.'s Subcommittee on Constitutional Rights warned us, with chilling evidence, that government and private industry were teaming up to strip us of most of our privacy.

title: Tate by Knockout
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 17  Big John Tate, 229 pounds of fury, annihilated Duane Bobick in 2 minutes 15 seconds of the first round this afternoon at the Market Square Arena. It was a brutal, thrilling battle, the first boxing event ever in tnis arena, and it left the 4,800 fans gasping in awe at the destructive power in the fists of the 24yearold heavyweight.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BRONXVILLE  Shakespeare's The iempest, Don Bohl, director. Tuesday and Saturday at 8 P.M., next Sunday at 2:30 P.M. $2, students and the elderly, $1. Schoenfeld Hall, Concordia College. 3379300.

title: Transition in SouthWest Africa Remains the One Hopeful Possibility in the Region
description: CAPE TOWN  One diplomat speaks of the perils of Pauline. The United Nations plan for turning whiterun SouthWest Africa into blackgoverned Namibia is approaching the moment of decision, and there are obstacles at every corner. The next week two may decide whether the territory that South Africa has administered for 60 years can have a relatively peaceful transition to independence.

title: Greenwich Prepares For Putnam's Ride
description: GREENWICH THE Bicentennial lives on and is making a stand in Greenwich next Sunday. Between 1 and P.M. the Second Continental Light Dragoons (formed Dec. 12, 1776) will stage a reenactment of the British raid on Greenwich exactly 200 years ago, during which the salt works and much of the town were burned and looted. One hundred and fifty pounds of gunpowder will boom, redcoats in hot pursuit of the Contintentals will storm the brow of the hill (provided state authorities make the Post Road available), and camp followers will provide such aid and comfort as 20thcentury propriety permits.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an error in a National Weather Service report, a chart of January's weather in The Times last Sunday listed inaccurate temperatures. The correct normal mean for the month was 32.2 degrees and the actual mean was 33.6.

title: State Questions 2 Counties Costs
description: IN fending off a new effort by the Carey administration to control state taxes by controlling the expenditures of local government, the Island's two counties  particularly Nassau  will have to explain why it apparently costs them more to provide basic services like road maintenance and community college educathin than other counties in the state. Such expenditures were reviewed not long ago by the State Commission on Management and Productivity in the Public Sector in a report that shows Nassau County with substantially higher costs than Suffolk and Westchester or three other upstate counties reviewed in 1977 by the commission. The report describes as the most serious disparity Nassau's spending of $412 to administer each case of home relief or aid to families of dependent children in 1978, while Suffolk spent $180 and Westchester $178.

title: A Biographical Novel
description: BERNARD MALAMUD'S risktaking new novel moves into areas not usually associated with his art. In many of the famous short stories, in such novels as The Assistant, The Fixer and The Tenants, Malamud has depicted Jewish characters in confrontation with their neighbors

title: Deaths
description: LESTER  Maxwell, Jr. On February 16, 1979. Of Summit, N.J. Husband of the late Katherine (nee Libby). Lester. Father of Maxwell Lester of Summit, N.J. Also survived by 2 grandchildren. Memorial services will be at Christ Church, New England Ave & Springfield Ave., Summit, N.J. on Monday February 19, 1979 at 11 AM. It is the request of the family that donations be made to Overlook Hospital, Summit, N.J.

title: ANTIQUES
description: WOODBURY ONE job Harold Cole, an antiques dealer on Route 47 here, never expected to take on was that of running country auctions. But five years ago the accumulation of late Victorian furniture, old trunks full of just about anything you can think of  boxes of bottles, dinner plates, old tools  had grown so large that it was becoming difficult to close the doors of the storage barn.

title: Utah Reauires Abortion Details
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 17 (UP1) The Utah House has approved a bill requiring doctors to give women seeking abortions printed material on the medical procedure. According to the bill ap proved yesterday by a vote or 44 to 24, the material would contain details on what happened to aborted fetuses, the physical characteristics of developing baties and alternatives to abortion

title: What's Doing in the WHITE MOUNTAINS
description: OVERVIEW  On maps the White Mountains region is often colored green  to designate the national forests and state parks that blanket the 12,000 square miles of grandeur spread over northern New Hampshire. The mountains are among the highest east of tne Rockies, and they seem even higher than they really are because the valleys are so near sea level. Unlike Vermont's parklike Green Mountains, New Hampshire's white (for white rock) peaks are rugged, wild and scarred by landslides. They are, noted for such bold landmarks as the Old Man of the Mountains (Hawthorne's Great Stone Face), the Flume, the Lost River, countless tumbling streams and cascades, and, above all, the dense primeval forests. Only in winter are the mountains really white. Against the snow, the crags and trees are at all times stark and dramatic, and in the sun brilliant and dazzling. The views breathtaking.

title: Drunk, Judge Loses License
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 16 (AP) State Supreme Court Justice William Quinn pleaded guilty today to a charge of driving while intoxicated. Judge Henry LeClair of Glenville revoked Justice Quinn's license and ordered him to seek counseling with the Schenectady County Alcoholic Council. Justice Quinn may reapply for his license in six months.

title: Letters: Pillow Fight on Night Flight
description: To the Editor:

title: Tommy Trotter's Best Bets for 1979
description: Horses are running at such popular winter resorts as Hallandale, Fla.; Arcadia, Calif.; Bowie, Md., and East Ozone Park, Queens, but the races at this season do not absorb the attention of nice old ladies in Oconto Falls, Wis. Not until later in the year when the Kentucky Derby is approaching does the general public

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Jerseyans Pay. More, Get Less From U.S.
description: WASHINGTON NEW JERSEYANS pay $360 more in Federal taxes and receive $255 a person less in Government spending benefits than the average American, according to a new economic survey by the NortheastMidwest Congressional Coalition.

title: 2 Arrested in Robbery Of Millions at Airport
description: Two men were arrested yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in connection with the Dec. 11 robbery of more than $5 million from the Lufthansa cargo area at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Boy in Swimming Class Drowns; Call for Help Was Believed a Joke
description: COVERT, Mich.,Feb. 17 (AP)  Two classmates ignored the pleas of a drowning sixthgrader during a swimming class because they thought he was joking, the police reported today.

title: Two Orchestras on Long Island Plan Merger Into Philharmonic
description: If plans now under way go beyond the talking stage, the Long Island Symphony and the Suffolk Symphony will be dissolved this summer and a new orchestra  the Long Island Philharmonic  will be formed, thereby assuring that private and governmental support for serious music will be concentrated on one major orchestra.

title: BAKER SEEMS READY TO SEEK PRESIDENCY
description: CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 16  Pressing his twin themes of a strong national defense and fiscal austerity, Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. ended a week of preannouncement campaigning by sounding like a sure candidate in this state's Presidential primary next year, the first in the nation.

title: Commission Approves New Taxi Plan But the Decision Is Now Up to the Courts
description: The auditorium has filled with cab drivers, doing what are generally considered cabby kinds of things: arguing, shouting, even offering to hit one another over the head with blunt objects. Outside, a hundred of them marched with picket signs; in the hallway, two had to be pulled apart, their fists clenched, their faces contorted. The scene was Police Headquarters in Manhattan and the two officers standing outside the public hearing were bemused. I don't know what leasing is, one said, but I'm not sure they do either.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: In April 1978 the Rev. James Roy put his 15yearold daughter, Shirley our firstborn  across his knees and paddled her with a cedar shingle for being disobedient. He has been in trouble with the law ever since.

title: State Rebuts Criticism of Animal Shelter
description: YONKERS A RECENT report by the State Attorney General's office on the Yonkers Animal Shelter has rebutted many of the conclusions of an earlier report by the Humane Society of the United States, which said that the shelter was unsanitary, overcrowded and poorly staffed.

title: When a Nation Yearns for Action
description: It is hard to defend a President who begins a goodwill mission to Mexico by reminiscing about Montezuma's revenge. One slip does not make a calamity, but stylistically the Carter Administration's foreign relations seem to have lost all sense of class. No sooner did the Administration contain the unseemly debate among three secretaries of state  Vance, Brzezinski and Young  than there appeared two secretaries of the treasury  Blumenthal and Schlesinger  to bedevil the foreign dollar markets with conflicting estimates of the Iranian oil shortfall. Israel was pummeled by one wing of the State Department just as another was begging it for concessions to Egypt. And while the Secretary of Defense was selling stability to moderate Arab regimes, the President's brother was allowed, uncriticized, to plump for the unstable Colonel Qadaffi. with antiSemitic slurs to boot. Inconsistency may be the essence of politics but this is ridiculous.

title: Hanoi, Peking, Ancient Foes, At War Again
description: Ancient enmities between China and Vietnam, temporarily dormant during Hanoi's 30year struggle against French colonialism and United States involvement in Indochina, have been building toward hostilities since the end of the Vietnam War in 1975, fueled by mutual fears of expansion and sparked last month by Vietnam's invasion of Cambodia.

title: Rabbi's Japan Pulpit: 8 Years of Surprises
description: PEOPLE find their careers in many ways. Marvin Tokayer of Great Neck spent a summer as a comedian in the Borscht Belt. He had a scout for the White Sox express interest in the natural sinker he threw. In college, he thought he was going to be a doctor. Instead, he became a rabbi. And beyond that, a rabbi to a Jewish community in the Far East, an authority on the Jewish experience in the Orient and an interpreter of Judaism to 100 million Japanese.

title: Nancy Donohue Fiance of W. Mason Rees
description: Mr. and Mrs. Timothy Harney Donohue of Wellesley Hills, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Catherine Donohue, to W. Mason Rees, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Mason Rees of Greenwich, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: CHESS
description: Tournament winners get no more luck, by and large, than the alsorans  it's just that breaks favorable to them get more publicity. No one (except the player him self and his family) cares whether someone who took 16th place in a field of 18 might have been lucky or unlucky, but the firstprize winner often has to suffer the envious probing of his unsuccessful rivals. They have to show that he did not deserve to surpass them.

title: Jacqueline E. Zins Sets Aug. 5 Bridal
description: Dr. and Mrs. Eugene I. Zins of Maplewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jacqueline Ellen Zins, to Gerson Zweifach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Zweifach of Lawrence, L.I.

title: 4 Neville Dancers In 5 Works
description: The Phoebe Neville Dance Company, which performed Friday night at the Washington Square Methodist Church, consisted of four dancers. That, for Miss Neville, was a lot. Sometimes, in the past, she has appeared with only two dancers. She is also fond of solos. And, significantly, on Friday all four dancers never appeared together in one work.

title: Without A Doubt
description: FOR such a private person, Barbara Jordan reveals more of herself than I would have expected in this personal, intellectual history. The book fills out a picture of the woman I had already glimpsed during her triumphal march across the Texas political battlefield  a regal, somewhat forbidding loner with a fine sense of humor and nary

title: 62% in Poll Find Recession Likely
description: Sixtytwo percent of the American public believe it is likely that there will be recession in the economy during the next 12 months, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Alaskan Malamutes, Siberian Huskies and Sportsmen With Sleds Come Out of the Woods in Ridge, L.T.
description: Forget all that stuff about drivers draped in caribou skins yelling mush, mush at a team of huskies as they make their way across the desolate tundra. Dogsledding is no longer the sole province of Admiral Peary types.

title: Is a Boy Better Off Out Here?
description: YEARS ago, when I was a bachelor in New York City, I saw little boy of 3 or 4 pedaling blue plastic automobile along the sidewalk on 57th Street, between Lexington and Park Avenues.

title: Save the Montrealer!
description: WEDNESDAY, Jan. 31, 1979, was Pearl Harbor Day insofar as rail passenger service in the United States was concerned, as Secretary of Transportation Brock Adams all but bombed out of existence about onethird of the passenger trains now running in this country. Happily, like the United States Navy, the rail passenger fleet is still alive with a chance to escape relatively unharmed if, within 90 legislative days from the date of the Secretary's announcement, either the Senate or the House overrules these devastating recommendations.

title: Mayor of Kansas City Is Prone, Like Truman, to Plain Speaking
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 17 (AP) Kansas City's Mayor is a bit of a Harry Truman, a bit of a Jack Klugman, very unconventional and the proud owner of 400 hats.

title: Ski Tour Trails Wind a Long may For Californians
description: A few winters ago, tired of downhill skiing's Musakpolluted day lodges and halfhour lift lines, my husband and switched to what at the time seemed new and adventurous  crosscountry skiing. By now, of course, crosscountry has burgeoned here in nortnern California, as in the East, to the extent that in San Francisco the sports page's weekly ski roundup includes a report on crosscountry conditions. Marked and groomed trails have proliferated together with the sport's enthusiasts, and within a 200mile radius of San Francisco ski tourers now have a choice of several excellent areas.

title: Why the Bee Gees Sound So Good
description: The Bee Gees, who have done it all before, have done again. Their latest album, Spirits Having Flown, sounds immediately like a GreatestHits collection even though the material is brand new. The four most obvious blockbuster cuts  only two of them are top10 so far, but then only two have been individually, released  are very much in the mode of the group's four Saturday Night Fever singles, yet surprising for their variety, too. How does a group with no propensity for touring and little distinct personality manage to dominate the airwaves so tirelessly? What makes the Bee Gees formula so durable and yet so new?

title: Engagements
description: MANNGRABER

title: Births
description: SPIVAK

title: Notoriety Forces Shop to Close
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 17 (AP) The sporting goods store fired upon in 1974 by Patricia Hearst, then a captive of the Symbionese Liberation Army, has closed its doors. The store was plagued by curiosity seekers, bomb threats and burglaries, the owner said.

title: Ford Expresses Concern
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 17 (UPI)  Former President Gerald Ford said today that he is concerned about the potentialities and ramifications of the Chinese invasion of Vietnam, but said the United States should remain in the background of the dispute.

title: Realty News
description: The American Express Company is expanding significantly in Lower Manhattan.

title: OFFICIAL OF GUYANA TELLS OF AID OFFER
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 17  Guyana's chief medical examiner, Dr. C. Leslie Mootoo, said today that although he had been offered the assistance of American pathologists in doing autopsies and toxicologic tests on the 913 members of the People's Temple who died at Jonestown last November, no such help came.

title: Changing Face of Record Distribution
description: Remember a mellow tune called Love Letters in the Sand, sung by a whitebucksshod Pat Boone 25 years ago? And the early recordings of Ray Charles, whose rendition of Georgia on My Mind was just one of his blues hits that soared to the top of the sales charts? These artists and hundreds more, including Johnny Cash, Diana Ross and the Supremes, Buddy Holly and Chuck Berry, began their careers with small, socalled independent record companies whose fortunes were made by searching out and popularizing both new music styles  from country and western and rock and roll to rhythm and blues  and the fledgling musicians playing them.

title: State Mediation Head Predicts Long Strike By SchoolBus Drivers
description: The chairman of the State Mediation Board, Msgr. James A. Healy, said yesterday that it appeared that the wildcat strike by 2,200 schoolbus drivers affecting 133,000 New York City public school children will be long.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary
description: China invaded Vietnam. The attack followed what Peking described as incessant armed encroachment. The Chinese press agency, Hsinhua, stressed that China did not want a single inch of Vietnamese territory. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Fellini's Latest Creates A Ruckus In Rome
description: ROME It is evening when the orchestra musicians arrive, their meals halfdigested. They're professionals, almost artists, but they dream of becoming soloists. Some are frowning and in bad temper; most have their thoughts elsewhere ...

title: G.S.A. Head to Brief Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP)  Testimony dealing with continuing Government efforts to rid the General Services Administration of corruption will be offered to a House panel next week. Jay Solomon, administrator of the G.S.A., the Governments purchasing agent, has been asked to brief the House Government Operations Committee on the status of a new office of inspector general at the agency.

title: Spring Training: 1979
description: Sandy Koufax will be there, after 10 years of privacy. Lorinda do Roulet will he there, running her team from the cabin of a 53foot boat. A dozen players will get there by bicycle after pedaling 1,700 miles for charity. Two Japanese teams are already hard at work there, two weeks before their American host

title: The Ins and Outs of New Housing
description: MY first exposure to suburban middleclass provincialism was about 15 years ago. It took place at a public hearing in the Town of Hempstead in connection with a rezoning of land to permit the construction of a federally subsidized apartment project for senior citizens. A few similar earlier rezonings had taken place without incident and no one, including the town authorities, was prepared for the verbal onslaught that greeted the proposal.

title: Arthur Nichols 4th, Constance Wootton To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip Henry Wootton Jr. of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Constance Barron Wootton, to Arthur Boylston Nichols 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nichols 3d of New Canaan, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Two strains of Canadian brook trout that are unusually longlived and grow to giant size  the assinica and the tmiscamie  are gaining a foothold in this country.

title: Hispanics Lead U.S. Minorities In Growth Rate
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17  In MinneapolisSt. Paul. MexicanAmericans have replaced blacks as the largest minority. In Los Angeles, 35 percent of public school students are of Hispanic descent, but the figure is almost 50 percent for kindergarten pupils. In Seattle, the Hispanic

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Texts of Hanoi and Peking Statements
description: Following are the texts of the Chinese Government statement on the border conflict with Vietnam, as provided by Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, and relayed from Hong Kong by Reuters, and of a broadcast by Radio Hanoi as monitored and translated by the United States Government. Words in parenthesis were indistinct in Hanoi's broadcast.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: MASS MARKET

title: Z.B. Lane Jr. Weds Josephine S. Ailing
description: Josephine Smith Ailing was married yesterday afternoon to Zebulon B. Lane Jr. The Rev. Gary Fertig performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: TV VIEW
description: The CBS Morning News has been given a new look. In fact, it has been given a new name. There now is Monday Morning, Tuesday Morning and so forth. And there is a completely new edition called Sunday Morning, a 90minute Magazine Out Of a Tube, using the time period long occupied by religion series and the awardwinning Camera Three.

title: SHOP TALK
description: ISLIP IF you want to buy or sell old furniture, Islip is the place to go. Along the Montauk Highway, which is called Main Street as it winds its way through the downtown shopping area, there are shops door to door where you can spend as little or as much money as you want.

title: A Lover of Bowling Finally Comes Out of the Volvo
description: I am going to embarass a lot of people  my wife, my kids, many of my friends But I am going public anyway

title: ON THE ISLE
description: Back in the days before seamen crossed the oceans in pursuit of whales, the industry floUrished on the Island on a smaller scale. Using sloops, schooners and brigs, local sailors rode the Atlantic after their plentiful prey. It's a period almost forgotten, surpassed by the more romantic travels of the larger whalers, said Robert D. Farwell, director of the Whaling Museum in Cold Spring Harbor. And to recreate the era, the museum has mounted an exhibition of models and prints that tell it as it was. Except for this week, when the museum on Main Street will be open daily, the exhibition can be seen weekends from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. through March 18. Admission is 75 cents; for children 6 through 14, 25 cents, and under 6, free. 3673418.

title: Group Moves to Bar Nazi Rally
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 (AP)  The Association of Jewish New Americans, an organization whose members say they are survivors of Adolf Hitler's Holocaust, filed suit in Federal District Court yesterday in an attempt to stop an American Nazi Party rally a block from Independence Hall. In seeking a temporary re straining order, the association said the proposed rally in Independence National Historical Park on Feb. 25 would cause serious physical and psychological harm to its members.

title: Why Record Prices Are Climbing
description: To Jeanne Parker, a 25yearold dancer from Manhattan, it made little difference that the Rod Stewart Blondes Have More Fun album she was buying in a midtown store cost 50 cents more than just a week earlier. I figured it was more because it was a No. 1 album, she explained with some resignation. If I wanted this record I had to pay the price.

title: A Ghost Town In Old Mexico
description: We sat on a patio in San Miguel de Allende talking of the great days of Real de Catorce. The city was rich, very rich, said my host, Dr. Gerez de la Maza, a retired Spanish physician who looks like a grandee. A cousin on my mother's side, Don Santos de la Maza, owned Mexico's biggest silver mine in Real de Catorce, about the middle the 19th century. He even owned his own mint, the Casa de Moneda. It is still there.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: Q. I JUST purchased a 1979 Chevette without undercoating, primarily because 1 have read that undercoating, although good as sound insulation, is not effective as a rustproofing measure, which is what I want. A few of my. friends have told me that I should have had the undercoating. Who is right and why? JOSEPH RIGBY Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: Melnick, of Columbia, Takes a Film to Warner
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17  Daniel Melnick, who resigned last October as president of Columbia Pictures but who still has a contract as an independent producer with that studio, is taking his newest movie project to Warner Bros.

title: Can Indians Overcome Old Images and New Prejudice?
description: SAM BEELER is willing to tell you the truth about his people's plight, but it hurts. Those seeking a reinforcement of the schoolbook image of American Indian life should turn away before he hits you with statistics like these:

title: As Maestro Nears 80, Philadelphians Contemplate PostOrmandy Era
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16  As happens, Eugene Ormandy will reach 80 years of age on Nov. 18. That he is still remarkably lithe of mind and movement astonishes men and women when they meet him for the first time. This season, however, critics who have long loved his powerful steering of the Philadelphia Orchestra have begun, if somewhat reluctantly, to describe certain diminution in Mr. Ormandy's grasp.

title: Archives Offers Genealogy Data
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17  The National Archives has prepared free family history research packets in anticipation of increased interest in genealogy sparked by the television serial Roots II. which begins tomorrow on ABC. Re search requests at the Archives Jumped 70 percent following the broadcast of Alex Haley's Roots in 1977. The agency has such items as census schedules, military records and passenger lists. The research packets are available from the Correspondence Branch of the National Archives in Washington.

title: Ronnie Weiss Betrothed To David Parker, Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bertram D. Weiss of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ronnie Beth Weiss, to David Parker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Parker of White Plains.

title: North and South Meet At Panmunjom Site; First Talks in 6 Years
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb.17  Ranking officials from North Korea and South Korea met at Panmunjom today for the first time in nearly six years.

title: Clive Davis: An Outspoken Independent
description: With A&M moving to RCA Records for its distribution, Arista Records has become the largest independently distributed record company in America. and its veteran president, Clive Davis, insists that the company will remain so, despite rumors to the contrary.

title: Gelston Hinds Jr. Marries Amy Ling
description: Amy Ling and Gelston Hinds Jr were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gelston Hinds of Tuxedo, N.Y. The bride is a daughter of Leah Ling of New York and Theodore Ling of Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: THE POSSESSED
description: The he captain of Alitalia's Flight 133 from Palermo to Milan studied the group coming up the ramp  the two carabinieri with their submachine guns, the bearded prisoner in handcuffs, the two extra armed guards.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: IN THE event that you're looking for Pasadena  Pasadena, NJ., that is  it's hard to find. This erstwhile industrial community, which once had 200 residents, now consists of a few clusters of private homes and an occasional rodandgun club.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: THE state, it appears, is still out to get Bordentown. But little does it realize that the place where Thomas Paine was during much of the Revolutionary War; where Francis Hopkinson, a signer of the Declaration of Independence, lived; where Clara Barton began her first public school; where the first steam locomotive was tested and where Napoleon's brother lived will not be had that easily.

title: 2 Share L.P.G.A. Lead at 212
description: MIAMI, Feb. 17 (AP)  Sandra Post scrambled in with a twounderpar 70 today and tied a faltering Amy Alcott after 54 holes in a $100,000 Ladies' Professional Golf Association tournament at the Country Club Aventura.

title: Vietnam Stories
description: SOMETIMES the bitterness still jumps out at you as many of the principal figures of the Vietnam War era tell their stories in this collection transcripts of a 1977 BBC Radio series.

title: TOW TRUCKS VANISH FROM SAN FRANCISCO
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17  For seven weeks that dreaded vehicle, the rushhour tow truck, has disappeared from the scene in San Francisco, and there are signs that it may not return. Things have gone so well without the trucks that even if they are brought back, they will not be used as they were.

title: Marina Made of Used Tires Placed on Ice in Michigan Lake
description: CHARLEVOIX, Mich., Feb. 17  A new marina, resting on used tires filled with urethane foam, is being put into place on the ice of Lake Charlevoix in northwestern Michigan.

title: YEMEN INVITES ROLE FOR U.S. IN ECONOMY
description: SANA, Yemen. Feb. 14  President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen says that American business investment could be as important as military aid in insuring stability in his country and in the rest of the Arabian Peninsula.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP)  A Congressional panel asserted today that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization lacked the means to defend Europe and called the alliance's capacity to fight a protracted war almost nonexistent.

title: E.B. Wood to Wed Melissa Dent July 7
description: Melissa Dent and Edmund Brandt Wood, graduates of the University of Pennsylvania, plan to be married July 7.

title: Jonathan Goldman Weds Miss Throne
description: Adrienne Throne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Jaffee of New York, and Jonathan Goldman of Brooklyn, were married yesterday in International House. The ceremony was performed by Wayne C. Olson, a leader in training with the Society for Ethical Culture.

title: Official Who Was Denied a Post Because of Criminal Record Dies
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 17 (AP) William H. Bailey, a South Providence Democrat whose political hopes were wrecked by a criminal record, died at his home today.

title: GARDENING
description: A MIDWESTERN professor once told his horticulture students that the highestquality seedlings from his potato breeding program were the first to be discarded. They met the criterion for good quality by having a high starch content rather than high sugar, but flunked on the basis of another important characteristic  consumer appeal.

title: Federal Judge William Frey, 59; Settled Arizona Busing Dispute
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 17 (UPI) Federal District Judge William C. Frey, who presided over a desegregation case against the state's largest school district, died yesterday while he was on a vacation on an island off Honduras. A spokesman said the judge, who was 59 years old, had died of a massive heart attack.

title: The Nation
description: It is a rough ruleofthumb that for each 10 percent increase in the cost of imported oil, fourtenths of 1 percent must be added to consumer prices. With the most optimistic projections of 1979's inflation rate at 7.4 percent, economists have been apprehensively warming up their calculators in expectation of the news that finally came last week  Arab oil producers have started jacking up their prices.

title: Return of the Dance Theater of Harlem
description: Aresurrected Dance Theater of Harlem opens its first New York season in almost two and onehalf years on Tuesday night at the 55th Street City Center. For the second time in a decade, DTH founder

title: The Ageless Jazz of Mary Lou Williams
description: On Mary Lou Williams's The History of Jazz, a narrative record with piano illustrations that tells us as much about Miss Williams as it does about jazz, the pianist says quite casually and matteroffactly that she has played through all the eras of jazz.

title: Obituary 7  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY HE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5 30P M FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS UNTIL 2 30 P M ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION IN REGIONAL Of 9 00 AM TO 4 30 PM MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300, NASSAU CO (516) 7470500 SUFFOLK CO (516) 6691800 CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767

title: Scientist Says Shifts of Solar Gas Could Forecast Magnetic Storms
description: PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 17 (UPI) Huge upwellings of gases have been detected on the surface of the sun, and the discovery may provide a way to predict the solar storms that disrupt radio communications on earth, an astronomer at Hale Observatories has reported.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17  No wonder Carter Democrats have been assiduously passing the word that the President privately chewed out President Lopez Portillo of Mexico.for the latter's taunting remarks in a luncheon toast.

title: Death
description: LEON  Philip. Beloved husband of Sadie. Devoted father of Frances Spier and Barbara Bryck. Devoted fatherinlaw of Joseph Spier and Bill Brick. Adored grandfather of Karen Bloom, Ricki Cohn, Mindy Spier, Ira Bryck, and Andrea Bryck, and loving greatgrandfather of Aaron Cohn and Jacey Bloom. Funeral services Sunday, February 18. 11 a.m., Sunset Chapels. Northern Blvd., Manhasset, L.I.

title: The Governor's Budget: Two Views
description: GOVERNOR BYRNE'S budget request for the coming fiscal year is just the tune that the Legislature wants to play this year: No new taxes, no damaging cuts, no controversy.

title: THEATER
description: BY all the laws of construction and common sense, a musical called Gypsy should be about Gypsy Rose Lee. But it isn't, or at least it isn't until late in the evening when the shy, awkward child emerges as a burlesque headliner. Cer tainly the musical shouldn't focus on Rose, the mother of Louise (to become Gypsy) and June, who was determined to make her children vaudeville stars even'as vaudeville was dying. Rose is a monster stage mother, hardly the stuff that musicalcomedy heroines are made of. But because Ethel Merman was the star of the original production of Gypsy in 1959 and could rivet an audience to a villainess and make the audience care about the woman, Rose is the star of Gypsy.

title: The Scenic Overkill of Taormina
description: Taormina is a small mountain town on the east coast of Sicily. A narrow main street, scrupulously clean, opens onto a piazza, and if on a fine day the unsuspecting visitor strolls to the parapet to look at the view, cardiac arrest may be the reward. There, hundreds of feet below, is the Mediterranean coastline studded with white crescent beaches between rocky promontories. To the left is a monumental Greek theater, refurbished by the Romans. To the right, high on a snowcapped peak, thin trail of smoke pours from the volcanic mouth of Mount Etna.

title: Topics
description: ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? to become ?? there comes news of salvation ?? ?? nosporum, the small fungus that looks like a lump of coal, tastes elysian and has for centuries grown only in the wild, can now be cultivated. A French agronomist, whose picture will doubtless be enshrined in every kitchen, has developed a method of grafting germinating truffle seeds to the roots of sap lings, and viola! the cultivated truffle. Within a decade or two, there might even be a glut of the muff. No more $15 per delicacy.

title: New Episode In the 1166 Saga: Success at Last
description: Slightly more than two years ago, the empty 44story skyscraper known as 1166 Avenue of the Americas was auctioned off in a foreclosure sale. Between $80 million and $110 million had probably been lost on this enormous project by sophisticated banks, build ers, developers and others since 1970, when construction began. The building was known in some circles as the largest single real estate disaster in the country, and few industry leaders held any hope for its nearterm future.

title: The Guitar Enters Music's Mainstream
description: In the last five years, the classical guitar world has seen the beginning of a quiet revolution. It is a revolution in performance standards, programming philosophies, contemporary repertory expansion and, most significantly, it is the start of a kind of musicological exploration the likes of which the instrument has not seen since the early 1920's when Andres Segovia and Emilio Pujol began searching Europe's libraries for the lost music of the lute and vihuela composers.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: RIDELLAAttillo Jack. On Feb 15, 1979. of Cresskill, N.J..Beloyed husband of Catherine nee Squeri. Beloved father of Alfred and Mrs. Carolyn Schultz. Dear brother of Mrs. Mary Gattoni. Loving grandfather of 8 grandchildren. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from the residence, 158 Truman Drive, Cresskill, Monday, 9:00 A.M. Funeral Mass St. Theresa Church, Cresskill, 10:00 A.M. Entombment Madonna Mausoleum. Ft. Lee. Visitation 25, 710 P.M. at the residence. For further information, Clerici Funeral Home, Union City, N.J.

title: Recycling of Waste on Verge of Stopping
description: IN the past five years, the amount of materials recycled in the county has dropped by about a third, John R. Thornborough of Yorktown commented this month, joining other county officials who fear that a lessening of environmental copcern and a volatile market far used paper and metals are contributing to the death of recycling in Westchester.

title: Henry E. Utter 2d, Student, To Marry Nancy H. Stratton
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Stratton Jr. of Stamford and Falls Village, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Holmes Stratton, to Henry Edwin Utter 2d, son of Dr.and Mrs. Wilson F. Utter of Providence, and North Hampton, N.H.

title: THEATER
description: DARIEN BY all the laws of construction and common sense, a musical called Gypsy should be about Gypsy Rose Lee, but it is not, or at least it is not until late in the evening when the shy, awkward child emerges as a burlesque headliner.

title: Lietzke Falters but Holds Lead by 2 Shots
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 17  What looked like a cool runaway abruptly changed into a tightly contested golf tournament this afternoon on the back side of the third round of the Tucson open.

title: Infant Mortality Rate Deplored
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  A District of Columbia physician has termed the infant mortality rate in the nation's capital a public embarrassment. He is Dr. Arthur Hoyt, chairman of a health panel that has been trying to determine why the District has been unable for 10 years to lower its infant mortality rate. The rate is the highest for any city of its size in the nation.

title: Genaro Santoro, Pianist
description: Temperament and considerable technical force were evident in the playing of Genaro Santoro, a Juilliard School graduate and associate professor of piano at Johnson (Vt.) State College, when he gave a recital in Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday night. One of the central works in his program was the omnipresent Liszt Sonata  it turns up an average of once a week in the concert halls  and the pianist gave it a highly creditable reading.

title: Fashion
description: One of the highlights of this season's fashion comes from the juxtaposition of strikingly different textures. Designers are using surprising combinations of fabric linen with chiffon; suede with Mexican serape cloth; terry with cotton jute  to give an unexpected, and often luxurious, look to even the simplest outfit. Here, two of America's top designers show how its done.

title: Panchsheel Is Revived, But . . .
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  In South Asia, a tremor anywhere agitates political seismographs in capitals near and far. Even the slightest shift between such powers as India and China changes the balance of interests in the region and reverberates in Washington and Moscow. Thus there was an attentive audience last week, when India's Foreign Minister Atal Bihari vajpayee went to China to start nearing a breach between the two once friendly nations. They have been estranged since 1962, when a territorial dispute and a brief border war ruptured their relations.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: II Trovatore, the popular Italian opera that includes the famous Anvil Chorus, will be presented at Symphony Hall in Newark tonight by the New Jersey State Opera Company. The production stars Ruben Dominguez, tenor, of the New York City Opera, and Pablo Elvira, baritone, also of the New York City Opera, who will make his debut at the Metropolitan Opera later this season.

title: Once Again, Baker Pursues Daytona 500
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17 Like a drowning swimmer who time and again sees the life raft drift away from his fingertips, Buddy Baker will make another effort tomorrow  his 17th to grasp the most elusive goal of his life.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249, or to any of the following organizations:

title: Marguerite Dixon Affianced to Allan Ayers
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ben Franklin Dixon of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marguerite McPheeters Dixon, to Allan Winston Ayers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Winston Ayers of Baltimore. Plans have been made for a June wedding.

title: GARDENING
description: THE season for planting vegetable gardens is not too far away. The weeks of waiting will dwindle down to days in no time. And before we all know it, the planting day will arrive. Those who have planned ahead will be ready.

title: Recycled Settings Enliven Dining
description: AS long as there's room for few tables and a kitchen, restaurant is possible. Usually it is set up in a house, a storefront or a new building decorated according to the latest trend. Today's plants may be tomorrow's heavy Mediterranean.

title: Mailbox: Princeton Recruits a Dissenter
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: In a Throwaway Age, A Throwaway County?
description: ANATION where Bic markets plastic throwaway cigarette lighters; where General Motors markets throwaway cars; where the busiest architects are marketing throwaway buildings  for such a nation, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration now promises new cities in space. And as we work the earth, we somehow gain the technology to throw it away too.

title: Bangladesh Holding Elections to End Martial Law
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Feb. 17  After four years of martial law, voters in Bangladesh will choose a new Parliament tomorrow in elections that President Ziaur Rahman said last night would complete his nation's passage to democracy.

title: Small Fruits Are the Berries for Suburban Gardens
description: Bush fruits are best when planning for the small garden. A number of them grow well in the Northeast and homeowners who plant them can look forward to harvests of blueberries, raspberries, blackberries and the less common but equally delicious currants, gooseberries and elderberries. Most of them are orna mental with lovely blossoms in the spring or early summer.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets)  A Man for All Seasons,. in an Actor's CafTheater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through March 17). $3.50$5.50; students and the elderly, $2.50$4.50. (201) 4297662. Westminster Theater.

title: Vietnamese Seek Appropriate Measures by U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 17  Vietnam accused China today of having launched a war of aggression and asked the United Nations to take appropriate measures to force the Chinese to withdraw their forces

title: TWO RUSSIANS WRITE U.S.SOVIET HISTORY
description: The first Soviet history of relations between the United States and the Soviet Union to be published here  written from a MarxistLeninist viewpoint by two important Russian academicians  is a frank, frequently harsh condemnation of American policies from the beginning of the Bolshevik Revolution to the Cold War

title: MERCHANDIZING DISCO FOR THE MASSES
description: Steve Rubell's friends warned him he was asking for trouble if he chose the old Fortune Opera House on West 54th Street as the site of his discotheque. They said, Broadway? Eighth Avenue? All you'll get is the spillover from the theaters, and the hookers! Rubell recalled recently. A slight, hyperenergetic man not known for his attentiveness, on this one occasion Rubell took his friends' warnings seriously: When he and Ian Schrager opened Studio 54 in the spring of 1977, he devised an admission policy so restrictive that thousands of people began thronging 59th Street

title: Final Exodus of Americans from Iran Gets Under Way
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 17  The final exodus of Americans began at dawn, with 800 men, women and children, making their way in buses to Mehrabad Airport.

title: Renewal Effort For Glen Cove Near Standstill
description: Three years ago, Giuseppe Grella enthusiastically opened his haberdashery as the first tenant of the Village Square, the very model of urban renewal and future hope of the failing downtown business area of Glen Cove, L.I.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today and Feb. 25  Taconic Auto Sports Club ??cekhana, at Lake Osceola, behind Nino's Restaurant (Route 6N). Jefferson Valley, N.Y. Registration. 9:30 A.M., first car off 9.35 limit of 100 cars. Information: John Killian (914) 248 5514. Information on ice conditions: (914) 7372442.

title: Urban Revival
description: BALTIMORE  Curious about reports of an urban renaissance, I recently did what any other member of the new urban gentry might do: I took a walk one Morning around my neighborhood.

title: 65 M.P.H. Speed Limit Rejected
description: PIERRE, S.D., Feb. 17 (AP)  A bill that would have raised Interstate highway speed limits to 65 miles per hour in defiance of Federal guidelines was killed yesterday by the South Dakota Legislature. After hearing warnings that the state would lose Federal transportation aid by approving the measure, the South Dakota House rejected the bill by a vote of 4819.

title: Is the New Jersey Bound for Home?
description: JERSEY CITY ALTHOUGH the battleship New Jersey is still in mothballs on the West Coast, a man who dreams of seeing her berthed in New York Harbor as a monument to the blood sacrifices of Americans says that the Big J should be here and swarming with tourists by year's end.

title: Bus Workers Strike in Utah
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 17 (AP)  Despite a district court judge's order that employees return to work. Utah Transit Authority officials said today that they expected bus service to be interrupted in three counties through tomorrow because of a wildcat strike. About 65,000 daily riders are affected. A temporary injunction was signed yesterday, after the walkout began by drivers, mechanics and other employees.

title: 8 in Union Arrested In Flareups at Big A
description: There was violence at Aqueduct yesterday as parimutuel machine operators, members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Local 3, continued their contract dispute with track officials.

title: The Ribicoffs Find Their Dream House
description: A DRAMATIC contemporary house on the crest of a hilltop in Cornwall will soon become the new Connecticut home of Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff and his wife, Lois.

title: Higher Rates on the Horizon
description: After Citibank announced two weeks ago that it was cutting its prime rate by  percentage point to 11 percent  move already taken by several other large banks  hopes rose early last week that the move by the nation's secondlargest bank may have been a signal that interest rates could be approaching a plateau.

title: Soviet Terse in Invasion Report, Implying No Decision on Action
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 17  The Soviet Union gave no indication today of whether it intended to use its military forces to help Vietnam repel the Chinese invasion that began this morning.

title: Letters TO THE EDITOR
description: George Gilder (The Case Against Women in Combat, Jan. 28) wishes to return to the days of pure discrimination at the Pentagon. He wants male leaders and female assistants, even though he admits that women in the armed forces do better on tests. So women, as usual, are damned if they do and damned it they don't.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Other Ideas & Trends
description: Jean Renoir, son of the renowned painter, PierreAuguste Renoir, was a renowned artist in his own right, a maker of memorable and influential films. He was a cavalry officer and pilot in World War I, and. briefly, before turning to movies, a ceramist. He apparently developed a deep interest in movies while recovering from war wounds. Then he turned to making his own. His 36 fulllength films included The Rules of the Game, Grand Illusion, This Land Is Mine, The Woman on the Beach, and The River. He became an American citizen and divided his time between homes in his native Paris and Los Angeles, where he died last week, after a long illness, at age 84.

title: Other World Events
description: In the United States, supporters of the Nationalist Chinese Government on Taiwan are still reluctant to bite the bullet and accept a system of private institutions as a substitute for the full diplomatic relations which ended with the establishment of relations between Washington and Peking on Jan. 1. But in Taipei last week, James Soong, the director of the official information office, announced somewhat apologetically that Taiwan will swallow the bitter and create a Coordination Council for North American Affairs with qualities of of ficiality to serve as a counterpart to Washington's American Institute in Taiwan Mr. Soong said Taiwan considered the council to be an official Government agency.

title: An Oil Problem, Not a Crisis
description: With no warning and little explanation, the Arab sheikhdoms of Abu Dhabi and Qatar unilaterally increased their oil prices by about 7 percent last week, raising genuine fears that the cutoff of Iranian oil would now rapidly escalate from a problem into a crisis. The concern is not unfounded: With no oil comingout of Iran, the world market is tighter than at any time since the Arab embargo of 197374. Under these conditions, an increase by one producer almost invariably leads to similar increases by all the rest, as one by one the laggards become inundated with bids for their cheaper oil.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: The oboist Pierre Feit and three young musicians who call themselves the Trio d'Accordo merged forces Tuesday night for a debut under the name of the Pierre Feit Concertino. Mr. Feit, a Frenchman of German ancestry, has been touring the United States since 1975 with string trios, and qualifies as a specialist in the chambermusic literature for oboe and strings. Whether or not his newly formed Concertino is destined for more than a transitory existence, its first appearance could be counted a success, even though not an unqualified one. The concert was the first of four planned in rather grandly entitled International Chamber Music Series at Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street.

title: Looking Beyond the Assembly
description: THE State Assembly elections next fall do not figure to arouse a great deal of public interest, but they have an importance beyond deciding how the 80member house will be divided among Democrats and Republicans.

title: Debra Kaplan Is Fiancce Of Ronald E. Lichtman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Kaplan of Highland Park, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Debra Kaplan, to Ronald E. Lichtman, son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Lichtman, also of Highland Park. A June wedding is planned

title: 20 West Bank Youths Arrested
description: TELAVIV, Feb. 17 (Reuters)  Israeli security forces on the occupied West Bank of the Jordan have arrested 20 young people suspected of planning sabotage activity, a source close to the military Government revealed tonight.

title: Martin Halbfinger to Wed Lynn Brownstein
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Brownstein of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lynn Myra Brownstein, to Martin L. Halbfinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Halbfinger of Miami Beach. A June 3 wedding is planned.

title: Insurance Companies Unwittingly Motivate Arsonists, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17  The staff of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations charged today that the insurance industry had unwittingly encouraged arsonforprofit schemes by its laxity in fire insurance underwriting and adjustment procedures.

title: LaissezFaire And Pro Tennis
description: Last Sunday, on this page, Bob Briner wrote about the controversy surrounding the rules originally adopted for the men's pro tennis tour.

title: New York State Aide Protests RightonRed Rule
description: ALBANY, Feb. 16  The state's Energy Commissioner, James L. Larocca, protested today that proposed Federal regulations requiring the state to allow drivers to turn right at red lights after stopping would cause 284 additional injuries or deaths of pedestrians a year.

title: Paul H. Kolterjahn to Marry Linda Clare Kirchner in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ottmar Kirchner of Union, N.J., have announced the engagment of their daughter, Linda Clare Kirchner, to Paul Howard Kolterjahn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Kolterjahn of Westfield, N.J.

title: WASHINGTON'S BIRTHDAY
description: Washington's Birthday will be observed tomorrow as a Federal holiday, with all Government offices, banks, schools and public libraries closed. Sanitation collections will be made only in emergencies, and only specialdelivery postal service will be available. Some stores will be open for business. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's halffare policy will be in effect on subways and buses from today until 1 A.M. Tuesday and on commuter trains until 4 A.M. Tuesday.

title: Kogan Joins Cleveland
description: The Cleveland Orchestra continued its current New York visit with a concert in Avery Fisher Hall Friday night conducted by its musical director. Lorin Wiaazel. For this occasion Mr. Maazel chose to program two sturay staples of the standard repertory, Prokofiev's Fifth Symphony and Beethoven's Violin Concerto, the latter with the Soviet virtuoso Leonid Kogan as soloist.

title: Digital Recordings
description: As any weatherman or stockbroker knows, forecasting is risky business. But insiders in audio are laying heavy odds that the industry is in for sweeping changes. Reading straws in the wind and keeping their ears to the ground, they proclaim that we are now at the forefront of the digital revolution. If they are right, the way in which music is reproduced will soon be radically altered.

title: Baltimore Man
description: The introductory ceremonies had ended. George Young was now the Giants' new general manager and New Yorker walked over to him and shook hands. Nice to have you in the Rip Town, the New Yorker said.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today  Ox Ridge, Oa Ridge Hunt Club, Middlesex Road, Darien, Conn. Local, junior and children's working hunters, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: For LongTerm Plan in Downtown Yonkers
description: AFTER two decades of debate and false starts in reaching a solution to the rebuilding of Yonkers's downtown business district, a decision by city officials during the next several weeks should finally chart a clear course to settle the issue.

title: Doomed Huck
description: WHAT a strange animal the novel has become. You can have it thin or fat, with shrieks and silences in the very same book. How are we supposed to read the thing? Should we turn and turn the pages with some notion of suspense, or breathe the language in with a slow, lazy love images and the particular scratch of words? Every man can have his pick.

title: Psychic ExStudent's Influence Shakes Waldorf School
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 16  The Waldorf School, founded here 32 years ago on the philosophy that a teacher must nurture the intuitive and spiritual nature of students as well as their physical and intellectual needs, has been deeply split by charges that some staff members, including the former headmaster, came under the psychic influence of a former student.

title: House Where Army Family Was Slain in '70 Intact
description: FORT BRAGG, N.C., Feb. 17  The house at 544 Castle Drive is dark and locked tight, as it has been for the past nine years. There is a padlock on the front door and steel bands bar the windows, although some of the panes have been broken by neighborhood children.

title: Sunday Observer
description: In this nightmare, one of the children telephones and says, Dad, I want you to give me $350,000. At one time or another all the children have asked me for a nickel. Sometimes I gave it to them, sometimes I didn't. But $350,000 . . . . We all know inflation is here to stay, but this is monstrous.

title: Donna Bailey Fiance of M.J. McCarthy 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. William A. Bailey of Baltimore have made known the engagement of their daughter, Donna Mae Bailey, to Maurice J. McCarthy 3d, son of Mrs. McCarthy Jr. of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., and the late Mr. McCarthy. The wedding is planned for June in Philadelphia.

title: Scots and Welsh Appear Apathetic As Votes on Autonomy Approach
description: LONDON, Feb. 17  In less than two weeks, the voters of Scotland and Wales will decide the most important constitutional question in Britain since women got the vote in 1918: whether the two Celtic components of the United Kingdom should be given a limited form of home rule.

title: Homosexual Rights in Spotlight
description: HARTFORD THE State Legislature and the Hartford City Council are beginning another round of debate over proposed legislation to combat employment and housing discrimination against homosexuals.

title: Westminster Victor Is Off to Other Pursuits
description: An Irish water spaniel is this year's king of America's show dogs. While thousands of aficionados roared their approval, Anne Snelling's Ch. Oak Tree's Irishtocrat from Ottawa stood in the center of the huge greenmatted Madison Square Garden arena late Tuesday night as the supreme winner among 3,154 dogs. For this was Westminster, which to the fancier is the Super Bowl, the Kentucky Derby and the World Series.

title: Resorts Vows to Dismiss 2 Linked to Jersey Casino
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 16  Completing their sixth week of testimony before a state commission, executives of Resorts International today gave assurances that the casino's association with two employees considered disreputable by the state had been or was being severed.

title: Jane Lucey Is Betrothed To Joseph F. Deegan 3d
description: Dr. and Mrs. James J. Lucey of Perth Amboy, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jane Clarke Lucey of Boston, to Joseph F Deegan 3d of Providence, R.I., son of Superior Court Judge and Mrs. Deegan Jr. of Perth Amboy. An August wedding is planned.

title: 4 PROVINCES INVADED
description: HONG KONG, Sunday, Feb. 18  The Chinese Government announced last night that its troops had struck against Vietnam along much of their 480mile border.

title: Best Sellers
description: The listings above are based on computerprocessed sales figures from 1,400 bookstores in every region of the United States.

title: Couple, U.S. Vie Over a Fence
description: PORT WASHINGTON A COUPLE who like their privacy have taken on the United States Army Corps of Engineers in a battle over a fence. So far, the corps is winning.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN a radiator doesn't get hot, or doesn't heat up all the way across even though all the other radiators seem to be working properly, chances are that the radiator in question is airbound and needs bleeding to get it working again. If a sizable bubble of air gets trapped inside a radiator, keeps water or steam from filling completely, and as a result the radiator does not get hot all the way across. In some cases, particularly in a steam system, the radiator may not heat up at all.

title: Long Beach Aide Acquitted
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Feb. 17 (UPI) The former superintendent on the Queen Mary, the permanently docked former ocean liner now owned by this city, has been acquitted of charges of stealing $100,000 worth of equipment from the liner. A Superior Court jury returned the verdict yesterday in the case of John Oliver Smith, 68 years old, in connection with 18 counts of grand theft. The jury was unable to reach unanimous verdicts on two other counts after 4 days of deliberations.

title: Let's Uproot TV's Image Of Blacks
description: During an eightday period in January 1977, 130 million Americans tuned their television sets to ABC and, in so doing, contributed to a media phenomenon: Rootsmania. A recordbreaking 85 percent of the viewing public watcnea at least one episode of this dramatization of Alex Haley's bestseller Roots. Consistent with the television programming reflex of building on past successes, Roots: The Next Generations will have its premiere tonight at 8 on ABCTV. The sevenepisode series

title: Carlo Tomberli Plans to Wed Elizabeth Lane
description: Dr. George F. Lane 2d of Plainfield, N.J., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Elizabeth Richardson Lane, to Carlo Tomberli, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aldo Tomberli of Florence, Italy. A wedding this May is planned.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: The 16day conference of the Roman Catholic bishops of Latin America in Puebla, Mexico, ended last week with the publication of a 220page document intended to set the tone for the future of the church in the region. On matters of social justice, the tone was uncompromisingly militant. The document reaffirmed the position, adopted at the last such conference 10 years ago in Medellin, Colombia, that the church should take an active part on behalf of the poor and oppressed.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN a radiator doesn't get hot, or doesn't heat up all the way across even though all the other radiators seem to be working properly, chances are that the radiator in question is airbound and needs bleeding to get it working again. If a sizable bubble of air gets trapped inside a radiator, keeps water or steam from filling completely, and as a result the radiator does not get hot all the way across. In some cases, particularly in a steam system, the radiator may not heat up at all.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: With the introduction of a new 91pound wrestling class, the oncescorned skinny kid may have to be reckoned with after all. This year there are a dozen weight classes, up to 185 pounds and over.

title: On the Arms Sales Circuit, It's Business, But Not as Usual
description: CAIRO  On board the United States Air Force jet carrying Defense Secretary Harold R. Brown and his party from Saudi Arabia to Jordan last week, an Administration official said quietly, Believe me, we're very conscious of the lessons of Iran. We're not permitted by events to be as confident as we were in the early 70's when arms sales were meant to be pillars of strength.

title: Port Authority to Switch to Gas
description: To ease demand on the region's oil resources, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced yesterday a switch to natural gas at Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports. The au thority chairman, Alan Sagner. said the switch, effective immediately, would resuit in a saving of approximately 6.5 million gallons of fuel oil a year. That equals the heating needs of approximately 6,500 average size homes. The changeover will result in no significant cost difference because the authority's plants for supplying heating and refrigeration were designed to use either gas or oil, and will not have to be modified, Mr. Sagner said.

title: Carter Visit Gave His Hosts a Chance to Express Old Grievances
description: MEXICO CITY  Although no important agreements emerged, the unexpectedly frank words exchanged in public during President Carter's visit here last week reflected not only the Mexicans new view of their relationship with the United States but also a new view of their own country. Mexico, in the person of President Jose Lopez Portillo, felt a needand the stature  to unburden some of its pentup anger over past grievances. Among permanent, not casual, neighbors, he said, surprise moves and sudden defeat or abuse are poisonous fruit that sooner or later have a reverse effect.

title: New York State Is Studying Effect of iran Oil Situation
description: ALBANY, Feb. 16  The cutoff of oil from Iran has had only a modest effect on fuel supplies in New York State, energy officials here say, and as a result they do not foresee a need to expand The voluntary energysaving measures already undertaken.

title: Seekers After Endless Winter, They Sail Across the Ice
description: ICEBOATING is a quest for endless winter. Each weekend members of the Westchester Ice Sailing Club fervently search and often pray for the perfect conditions that make iceboating one of the most exhilarating winter sports.

title: PEDDLERS IGNORING GIVE RECEIPT LAW
description: Friday was the day street peddlers were supposed to start giving their customers receipts, posting prices and keeping full and complete sales records under new city regulations. But most of them were not buying it.

title: He's At Home Running Carnegie Hall
description: When he was in his teens, Stewart Warkow used to practice on the organ in Pietro Yon's studio in Carnegie Hall. In the course of his visits to the historic building, he discovered all its nooks and crannies and all the ways you could sneak into the main auditorium. There he heard Toscanini rehearsing the NBC Symphony and Bruno Walter the New York Philharmonic. He fell in love with Carnegie Hall. Today he is its executive director, which puts him in full charge of activities there.

title: A New Spy Case Last Week Is Just One of Many That Have Plagued Bonn
description: BONN  Klaus Schmidt telephoned his West German employer to say that he wouldn't be coming to work any more. Mr. Schmidt, sought by the police since late January on suspicion of espionage, called from East Germany.

title: Ilene Fennoy, Daulton Lewis Will Be Wed
description: Dr. Ilene Fennoy, a pediatric endocrinology fellow with the National Institute of Child Health and Development in Bethesda, Md., will be married June 23 to Daulton Joseph Lewis, a lawyer with WHET/TV in New York. Their engagement has been announced by the bridetobe's parents, Dr. and Mrs. David H. Fennoy of Silver Spring, Md. Mr. Lewis is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel B. Walker of Ridgefield, Conn.

title: Iran Likely to Demand Extradition of the Shah
description: RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 17 (AP) Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini has informally notified Morocco that he will demand the extradition of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi to face trial before a revolutionary tribunal for crimes against the Iranian people, diplomatic sources said here today.

title: The Region
description: The debate over how  or whether  to rehabilitate the South Bronx goes on but the battle lines are shifting.

title: ART
description: GREENWICH AN emigr from Cuba, Jose Piedra was 16 when he settled here with his family in 1961. He was 20 when he left his home again, this time going to the University of Bologna, where he had obtained a scholarship. While studying Italian literature there he attended lectures on esthetics and visited museums, eventually sustaining a kind of epiphany that led him to make art an avocation.

title: Another Film That's Out of This World
description: LONDON Athick haze shrouds the Shepperton sound stage. At British director Ridley Scott's command, the cameras begin to roll. Suddenly the actress Sigourney Weaver, perspiring heavily in her green fatigues and lugging a flamethrower, peers from a darkened corridor. She checks the intersecting passageway. It is clear. She darts across.

title: Marriages
description: GLICKSTEINMANN

title: It's Not Easy to Be The Jewish Bomber
description: TURNERSVILLE FOR Mike Rossman of this Gloucester County community, being The Jewish Bomber the lightheavyweight champion of the world  is no easy title to shoulder.

title: Personal Relations
description: DURING the violent spring of 1968, Celia Dupont, having reached the 45th year of her life, finds herself at that celebrated point at which all educated middleclass women arrive sooner or later. She is questioning the direction, the value and the meaning of her achievement. Mother of five daughters, wife of Philip. the editor of a liberal politi

title: The Borough President Is Still the Man to See
description: What exactly do the Borough Presidents do besides logrolling pork barrel projects through the Board of Estimate and playing petty politics with the Community Planning Boards? The question was asked a few days ago in the Gadfly, the new newsletter that the City Club, the presti gious political forum, puts out. It was part of an item suggesting that Stanley Simon. the recentlychosen interim Bronx Borough President, was something less than a statesman.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to the West Country in season June through September  or out, make reservations well in advance. In high season, hotels, guest houses and rental properties are packed; off season, many accommodations are closed. In London, the British Tourist Authority, 64 St. James Street, S.W. 1 (telephone: 6299191) will suggest lodgings for any time of year. In New York, the British Tourist Authority is at 680 Fifth Avenue, N.Y. 10019 (telephone: 2125814700), and can supply a free list of rentals throughout Britain, including listings of agents in the United States.

title: Ski Resort Mishap Is Reported
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Feb. 17  The State Labor and Industry Department plans to investigate allegations that the Sugarbush Ski Area failed to report a gondola accident two years ago. The authorities were told of the incident after a similar accident reportedly occurred this week, when a gondola fell off a lift line and was demolished, injuring three Sugarbush employees

title: An L.I. Philharmonic May Replace 2 Groups
description: IF plans now under way go beyond the talking stage, the Long Island Symphony and the Suffolk Symphony will be dissolved this summer and a new orchestra  the Long Island Philharmonic  will be formed, thereby assuring that private and governmental support for serious music will be concentrated on one major orchestra.

title: An Out of Season, and Unseasonable, Return to Tintagel
description: A rose by any other name may smell as sweet, but certain places derive no small portion of their magic from their names. Tintagel, in Cornwall, forever linked with Merlin, King Arthur and Lancelot, is one such. And beyond the lure of this ancient name, Cornwall itself, which lies a good sixhour drive from London, has the longest and finest coast of any English county. No wonder that between June and September there are 15 visitors for every native.

title: Bus Kills 4 in South Africa
description: CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Feb. 17 (AP)  A bus went out of control and went into a crowd at a terminal near Cape Town today, killing 4 persons and injuring 10, mostly farm laborers, the South African Press Association reported.

title: John Brock Fianc Of Pamela Smith
description: Mr. and Mrs. Procter Smith Jr. of Montclair, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Macy Smith, to John Biddle Brock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Brock of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Annisquam, Mass.

title: Texas Survey Reports 1 Out of 7 Abused or Neglected as Children
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 17  One person in seven who responded to a recent Texas survey has reported experiencing abuse or neglect in childhood.

title: A Guide to the FreshPasta Shops
description: EVERYONE likes noodles Italian manicotti, Chinese rice noodles, Hungarian goulash with noodles, German spatzle, Thai me krob or Jewish noodle pudding  delicious variations on what is basically boiled dough of flour, a little water acid maybe an egg. That is it, which is like saying wine is merely old grape juice: Great noodles  Italian pasta  differ from one another like tenors and oppranos.

title: Farmers Protest Raised Land Valuation by Albany
description: ALBANY, Feb. 17  A dispute has broken out between New York State farmers and the State Board of Equalization and Assessment over increases in the valuation of farm land for tax purpose.

title: Selection: The Habit of Writing
description: FLANNERY O'CONNOR, who died in 1964 at the age of 39, wrote two novels and many short stories of extraordinary power. Next month Farrar, Straus and Giroux will publish a generous selection of her letters, The Habit of Being, from which the four below are taken.

title: Richard Leakey: The challenger In Dispute on Human Evolution
description: It is no longer necessary to identify Richard Leakey as the son of Louis and Mary Leakey, the pioneering Kenyan anthropologists. In the seven years since his father died and his mother withdrew to her camp at Olduvai Gorge in Tanzania, the young anthropologist has emerged as one of the bestknown figures in science today.

title: From the Golden Age of Operetta
description: A warm welcome back to six of EMI's earliest complete Viennese operettas, recorded in London between 1953 and 1955 under the supervision of Waiter Legge. These classic albums were hailed on their original release and have reached legendary status  possibly because they were unavailable for so long, but more likely because all six starred Elisabeth Schwarzkopf (Mrs. Legge) and Nicolai Gedda. In a broad sense, they document the halfcentury history of the Viennese operetta from the first great goldenera hit Die Fledermaus. to one of the last of the silver age, The Land of Smiles.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: GOVERNOR BYRNE may be creating new troubles with the Legislature. Although it has been officially denied, some legislators believe it was the Governor whoprompted Assemblyman Christopher J. Jackman of West New York, th. Assembly Speaker, to remove a fel low Democrat, Kenneth A. Gewertz of Woodbury, from the Joint Appropriations Committee last week.

title: Hockey Enforcers: They Seem To Be Cast in Diminishing Role
description: They still don't like to talk about it in the National Hockey League. It remains a skeleton in the closet, a daft old relative. But after the exciting, clean hockey series between the Russians and the N.H.L. AllStars, people are beginning to ask questions again, and the role of the goon is being examined.

title: OREGON G.O.P. SPLIT OVER PARTY LEADER
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 18  It was well covered at last night's Lincoln Day fundraiser, but the ideological split in Oregon's Republican Party was plain to see for those who knew where to look.

title: U.S. Opposes Book Merger
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI) The Justice Department announced that it had advised Harlequin Enterprises Ltd. of Toronto that it will file a civil lawsuit to challenge the company's planned acquisition of Pinnacle Books Inc. of Los Angeles.

title: On Israeli Border: Learning When to Hide
description: QIRYAT SHEMONA, Israel  One morning as Merav Harari, a schoolgirl, was in first morning class, she heard a long whistling sound, and then a distant explosion.

title: Music: Ravel by the Clevelanders
description: The virtuosity with which Lorin Maazel conducts the Cleveland Orchestra can cut two ways. Sometimes, Mr. Maazel's conducting seems fussy, or overcalculated. Sometimes the apparent ease with which he molds phrases and blends colors yields fresh insights and unexpected nuances of feeling.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5.30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO A 30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900 WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW PORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300: NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO (516) 669-1800 CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Minority Groups Advised to Unite To Attain Power
description: ALBANY, Feb. 18  Decrying a lack of political power among New York State's black and Hispanic minorities, Assemblyman Arthur O. Eve, Democrat of Buffalo, called today for a political revolution among the two groups before state and Congressional district seats are reapportioned in 1981.

title: TV Makers In Germany Cutting Jobs
description: BONN, Feb. 18  At Christmas time. the West German color television market had the ingredients of a good oldfashioned price war: slow sales, bulging inventories and high prices.

title: News Summary
description: The Soviet Union demanded China's immediate withdrawal from Vietnam before it is too late, and said, as a loyal ally, it would come to Hanoi's aid. [Page A1. Column 6.]

title: Knicks Giving Behagen Tryout
description: Ron Behagen, a freeagent fcrward, worked out with the Knicks yesterday and will again today before a decision is made on whether he will be signed. If the Knicks sign the 6foot9inch, 28yearold Behagen, they can place Marvin Webster, who had been bothered with a sprained right knee, on the injured list.

title: SECURITY PACT CITED
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 18  Moscow warned Peking today to stop its invasion of Vietnam before it is too late and said the Soviet Union will honor its obligations under its treaty of friendship and cooperation with the Vietnamese.

title: Paley Bids Rivals Cooperate to Offer Quality Programs During Prime Time
description: William S. Paley, chairman of CBS Inc., said he intended to arrange a meeting next month with the heads of the two other networks to discuss his proposal that each network devote two hours of prime time every week to highquality programs for a special segment of the audience.

title: L.S.U. Coming Full Circle
description: Seven years ago the Louisiana State basketball program was in a state of disorganization. Aside from Pete Maravich's three successive national scoring titles and a couple of Southeastern Conference championships in the early 1950's when Bob Pettit was the star, there was no tradition of excellence. Like so many southern colleges, football was king and basketball was something to go between the football season and spring football practice.

title: More Refugees Reach Malaysia
