description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia. Feb. 18 (AP)  A boat carrying 103 Vietnamese refugees landed yesterday near Marang, 160 miles northeast of here, Malaysian officials said today. Guards ordered them to remain on the beach pending a decision to move them to refugee camps, it was said. There are 53,000 refugees in Malaysian camps.

title: Heinsohn's Complaint
description: IN sports, Jimmy. Cannon once. said, everything happens in front of you. That's not true anymore. Now there are all these managerial questions. Like whether the Giants wouldn't really be happier if they hired two general managers and two head coaches, one each for each faction of Maras. Whether, in fact, there should be two sets of Giants, which could play each other all year and wind up at 500.

title: John Soursourian Weds Judith Klein
description: Judith H. Klein and John A. Soursourian, both of Charlestown, Mass., were married yesterday at the Women's Club in Glen Ridge, N.J. Rabbi Roy Rosenberg of the Temple of Universal Judaism in New York and the very Rev. Houssig Bagdasian of St. Mary's Armenian Church in Livingston, N.J., officiated.

title: Florida Preference Vote Set
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 18 (UPI) Florida's Republican Party executive hoard has voted to hold a Presidential preference convention in November in a move to get the jump on New Hampshire, which will hold the nation's first Presidential primary.

title: SLAIN ENVOY IS BACK; CARTER STRESSES IRE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP)  The body of Ambassador Adolph Dubs was returned to the United States today, and President Carter, who met the plane, expressed his sadness and outrage at the murder of the Ambassador in Afghanistan last week.

title: Obituary 8 -- No Title
description: LAZARUSLeo. We mourn the passing of our dedicated Life Member.

title: Crisis in Iran Touches A 5th Ave. Skyscraper
description: Repercussions from the revolution in Iran have reached Fifth Avenue, where ownership of a new 36story office building built by the Pahlavi Foundation has been thrown into question.

title: Panama Canal Debate Reopened As U.S. Aides Defend Legislation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  The fight in Congress over the Panama Canal treaties erupted all over again last week as highranking Administration officials encountered heavy opposition to legislation necessary to carry out the treaties.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Indian's Visit to China Cut Off in Protest
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 18  A wave of protest swept Indian Government and political circles today as news of the Chinese invasion of Vietnam was received, and the Foreign Minister was told to end mission to China a day early.

title: Sports World Specials
description: At the age of 39  going on 49, in the minds of some suspicious souls  Rico Carty is the oldest free agent ever to gain a milliondollar contract. Carty, the Toronto Blue Jays' designated hitter. also holds another distinction: He has signed what is probably the buildest contract in the history of baseball. It is 31 pages long.

title: The Border Patrol, a Job Without End
description: EL PASO  It has already been a 10hour day, but at 7:30 P.M. Michael S. Williams, a senior agent of the United States Border Patrol, is still in his limegreen cruiser and heading for the railroad yards on the edge of town.

title: Televised Coverage of the House Begins Today on a Limited Basis
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  What may become the longest running television show in history will begin at noon tomorrow as a somewhat skittish House of Representatives goes on camera.

title: About Nostrand and Fulton, A Distinct Air of Excitement
description: The intersection of Nostrand and Fulton in Brooklyn is one of those distinct urban places  like 18th and Vine used to be for Kansas City, or 63d and Cottage Grove is in Chicago or 125th and Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard is in Harlem. They symbolize the black communities where they exist and help shape the quality of lives nearby.

title: Pause in the Vietnam Battle
description: The second day of battle between invading Chinese troops and Vietnamese defenders was apparently confined to reinforcement of the Chinese striking force and deployment of five to seven divisions of the Vietnamese Army in an arc protecting approaches to Hanoi from the north, east and south.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: States Get New Warning of Cuts In Funds Under a Balanced Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  A Congressman today warned state governments, of which 27 have called for a balanced national budget, that the Federal deficit could be eliminated by cutting Federal .grants to state and local governments to the amounts they were five years ago.

title: Mead Loses On Legal Costs
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 18  A Federal court has rejected efforts by the Mead Corporation to make the Occidental Petroleum Corporation pay for the law- yers' fees and litigation costs arising out of Occidental's recent tender offer for Mead, Occidental reported over the weekend.

title: Think It's Cold Here? It Snowed on Sahara!
description: (Agence FrancePresse)  Snow fell on the Sahara today for the first time in living memory.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: While I was shopping for eggs at an East Hampton poultry farm recently, the owner, Sal Iacono, told me that he had just killed half a dozen or so Muscovy ducks. I brought one of the birds home for dinner that evening, and during the meal the phone rang. By coincidence, it was an acquaintance calling to ask if I was familiar with Muscovy ducks and, more to his point, if I knew the origin of the name.

title: Bolivian Inyestrnent Bank Finds a Niche
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia  An investment bank formed by young financiers who learned their trade in big American banks has made an impact in the Bolivian financial market, placing nearly $100 million in loans during the first year of operations.

title: How Fritz Kraemer, the Enemy of Publicity, Shaped Kissinger's Thoughts and Actions
description: [Fritz] Kraemer [who retired last year as political analyst for the Chief of Staff of the Army and who had taught in the United States War College] largely made Henry Kissinger. He found him, he formed him, in fact he largely invented him.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Feb. 18 (AP)  Mel Purcell clinched the men's team tennis title for the United States today in the competition here for players under age 21, but the Swedish women scored a major upset in defeating the defending champion American women, 3.2.

title: Bridge:
description: Freezing temperatures did not discourage New York's bridge players from attending the Greater New York Bridge Association's sectional tournament at the New York Hilton Hotel during the weekend. The Swiss team

title: World News Briefs
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 18 (Reuters) Uganda and Tanzania have agreed to discuss how to end their border war at a meeting to be held here by the Organilation of African Unity, officials of the organization said today.

title: Miss Alcott Wins On Playoff Birdie
description: NORTH MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18  Four years ago Amy Alcott made, a 25foot putt on the final hole to beat Sandra Post in the Orange Blossom Classic. Today Miss Alcott didit again to Miss Post, sinking a 25foot birdie putt on the third playoff hole to win the $15,000 first prize in the $100,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament at Country Club Aventura.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: One ripple of the Iranian revolution has reached New York's Fifth Avenue, where the ownership of the Pahlavi Foundation's new office building is in question because the new regime in Teheran has issued a decree confiscating all the properties of the Iranian royal family. Prospective office tenants are wary. [Page A1.]

title: GOING OUT
description: CLOUD CARNIVAL Things should be humming festively tonight high above Rockefeller Center as the Rainbow Grill's longestrunning entertainment officially displays its new winter version. There's also a bonus a salute to Brazil by cast members of Broadway's Sarava, who will be commuting to the Grill through Saturday.

title: Limits Urged to Spying On Americans Overseas
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  As a compromise to resolve the dispute within the Carter Administration over the powers of the nation's intelligence agencies, the Attorney General has suggested giving Americans living abroad some of the civil liberties protections guaranteed them under the Constitution.

title: Events
description: SAYS I SAYS ME. by Ron Hutchinson Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street, 6:45.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: MAXWELL LESTER Jr.

title: TV: Robert Bly, the Poet, Is Interviewed by Moyers
description: The poet may well be the raconteur of our age, the artist on the mad to campus and literary society, reciting his lines and commenting on the times. Certainly Robert Bly is a raconteur, a standup poet who recites and acts and has much on his mind, as you will learn by tuning in Bill Moyers' Journal at 8 tonight on WNET-TV

title: Nets Beat Rockets In Overtime, 126124
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Feb. 18  It all started on Oct. 18 with free chicken. That was when the Nets lost by 52 points at Houston, when the Rockets scored 139 points and the fans won free meals. The Rockets won here in December, when Rick Barry went into the stands after a fan. Today, the Nets came from 8 points down in the last two minutes of the fourth quarter to win in overtime, 126124.

title: Radio City's Stage Becomes a Ballroom For a Benefit Party
description: There was nary a Rockette in sight, but Mickey Mouse was jitterbugging up a storm with Arlene Francis, John Lindsay was swinging and swaying with his wife Mary, and everyone seemed to agree that the stage of Radio City Music Hall was a thoroughly satisfactory place to dine and dance.

title: Radio
description: 7 A.M.Noon, WNYCFM. Concerto Grosso in A, Handel; Quintet in E minor for Guitar and Strings, Boccherini; Piano Concerto No. 16, Mozart; Sonata Octavi Toni XV, Gabrieli.

title: For Those Leaving Iran. the Way Home Can Be Agonizingly Slow
description: AKROTIRI ROYAL AIR FORCE BASE, Cyprus, Feb. 18  For the lumdreds of foreigners fleeing the anarchy and xenophobia unleashed by Iran's Islamic revolution, the way home is agonizingly slow, filled with petty humiliations, and sometimes is heartbreakingly cruel.

title: The Red Brotherhood at War
description: They are singing The Internationale on all sides of the Asian battles this week as they bury the hopes of the Communist fathers with the bodies of their sons.

title: Chinese Border Commander
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 18  During the Chinese Communists' epochal Long March in May 1935: the commander of the regiment that formed the vanguard of the Red Army arrived late at night at a hillside overlooking the swollen, swiftrunring Tatu River. His troops had marched 50 miles in the rain that day over mountainous, heavily forested terrain  an extraordinary achievement.

title: Books of The Times
description: ACCORDING to Peter F. Drucker, parttime statistician, economist, management consultant, philosopher, magazine writer, newspaper columnist, professor of social science and author of 15 books on almost everything, including pension funds: The monomaniac is unlikely to succeed. Most leave only their bleached bones in the roadless desert. But the rest of us, with multiple interests instead of one single mission, are certain to fail and to have no impact at all.

title: Theater: Fighting Bob By Milwaukee Troupe
description: MILWAUKEE COMMISSIONING plays for some motive independent of the playwright's creative impetus is a risky business. The risk is that the play will turn out to be mainly illustration; something like program music.

title: Dance: Comic Pair Convulse Audience
description: THE Theater of the Riverside Church rocked with laughter on Saturday when a madness called Bowyer and Bruggeman perpetrated itself on a willing audience.

title: Golf: Lietzke 2Shot Victor
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 18  Bruce Lietzke, nursing a painful torn stomach muscle, squeaked through to a twostroke victory in the 34th Tucson open this afternoon.

title: States Ranked by Tax Method
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  The following table ranks state tax systems by fairness. Tax systems that placed the heaviest burden on the poor and gave the most relief to corporations and the rich received the lowest rank.

title: Alberta Plans Diverse Economy.
description: CALGARY, Alberta  Flush with large fossilfuel revenues and reserves, this western Canadian province is planning a large economicdiversification drive for the day when its lucrative resources are gone.

title: Petty Wins Daytona After Leaders Crash on Last Lap
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18 There was Richard Petty in victory lane, king of all he surveyed, including a scoreboard that proclaimed him the winner for the sixth time of the Daytona 500mile race. And on the backstretch there were Cale Yarborough and Bobby Allison flailing at each other after a crash took Yarborough and Bobby's brother, Donnie, out of the lead and out of the race.

title: Corporate Board Study Finds New Priorities
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 18  As a resuit of shareholder demands, charges of bribery abroad, scandals at home, public pressure and concerns about Government regulation, the boards of directors of many of America's largest companies are changing their composition, according to a new study by the nation's largest executivesearch concern.

title: Tip on Slaying of Oswald Alleged
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 18 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Investigation received an anonymous telephone tip predicting that Lee Harvey Oswald would be killed as he was transferred from the Dallas city jail on Nov. 23, 1963, according to a retired F.B.I. agent.

title: WALDHEIM ASKS END TO INDOCHINA STRIFE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 18  Secretary General Kurt Waldheim appealed today for an end to the fighting in Indochina as members of the Security Council consulted privately on how to respond to the situation created by China's border attack against Vietnam.

title: Opera: Met's Ariadne Finally Comes to Stage
description: THE Metropolitan Opera finally managed to revive its production of Richard Strauss's Ariadne auf Naxos Saturday night, after having had to substitute Don Carlo for the originally scheduled first performance last Tuesday when its Ariadne, Leontyne Price, fell ill.

title: How-to-Do-It Holdup Plan Found on 2 Youths
description: To Police Officer Roy Zinkiewicz, it was a simple arrest: two teenagers, halted and searched on a midtown street corner, then taken into custody for possession of a gun and knife. But there were also some scribbled notes in the suspects' pockets  and the police said they looked suspiciously like a howtodoit guide to a robbery.

title: Skating: A Clean Sweep for Heiden
description: INZELL, West Germany, Feb. 18 Eric Heiden completed an impressive weekend's work here today by winning the 500meter and 1,000meter skating sprints for the second consecutive day and successfully defending his chanipion.ship with a worldrecord point total.

title: Pentagon Said to Exceed Its Budget on Manpower
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI)  Despite their failure to meet recruiting goals, the armed services ended 1978 with more people in uniform than the budget called for, Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: The Logic Of Bowie Kuhn
description: IT NEEDS a little sharpeningup, said Bowie Kuhn. I'm not at all satisfied with it. I should give the clubs some clarification on that. I don't know how I'll tion. do it but the $400,000 guideline needs some clarification.

title: Chronology of Events in Conflicts in Asia
description: Following is a chronology of some of the major events in Southeast Asia and on the SovietChinese border in the last 25 years:

title: Rangers Tied
description: There were no cries of defense last night at Madison Square Garden. Everybody was too busy counting the goals. When the shootout ended, the Rangers and Washington Capitals had played to a 66 tie.

title: Arafat, in Iran, Reports Khomeini Pledges Aid for Victory Over Israeli
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 18  An exultant Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, proclaimed here today that the Iranian revolution had turned upside down the balance of forces in the Middle East.

title: Obsession Yachting Winner
description: MIAMI, Feb. 18  Obsession, the yacht from Greenwich, Conn., aboard which a crew member was killed 18 days ago, today won the fourth event of the Southern Ocean Racing Circuit, the 135mile race for the Lipton Cup. After handicaps were computed, the fat maroon 46foot sloop belonging to Stephen Nichols was first in the fleet of 64 starters and also first in the most competitive of the six classes, Class B.

title: Japan to Lift Output Of Color Sets in U.S.
description: TOKYO, Feb. 18  Japanese manufacturers of color television sets plan to circumvent antidumping duties and quota curbs affecting their exports to the United States by increasing production in America sharply, according to trade sources here.

title: PanAlberta Plans Major Gas Export
description: CALGARY, Alberta  In one of the largest corporate export requests ever made in Canada, PanAlberta Gas is seeking to expedite the removal of some 6.4 trillion cubic feet of Alberta natural gas, most of which it would export to the United States.

title: Suspect Hunted In Airport Theft Is Believed Slain
description: A missing suspect in the $5.8 million Lufthansa robbery at Kennedy International Airport last December is now believed by investigators to have been murdered.

title: Bid for Refinery Will Test Endangered Species Act
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  Another test of the recently amended Endangered Species Act was started last week with a request for an exemption that would allow construction of an oil refinery near bald eagles' nesting grounds on the coast of Maine.

title: White Majority Found to Favor Affirmative Action for Blacks if Quotas Are Not Rigid
description: The majority of whites in America favor affirmative action programs for blacks in industry and in educational institutions, now that the Bakke decision of the Supreme Court has ruled out the concept of rigid quotas, according to a new survey by Louis Harris and Associates.

title: Around the Nation
description: BOSTON, Feb. 18 (AP)  Three persons were killed when a Coast Guard helicopter with five aboard crashed into the sea today while trying to hoist an injured Man from a Japanese fishing boat, the Coast Guard said.

title: Linda Alima Morse Bride Of Alan Bomser, Lawyer
description: Linda Mims Morse, daughter of Mrs. Marion Morse of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Philip S. Morse of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Alan H. Bomser. He is the son of Mrs. Harold Dundes of Jacksonville Beach, Fla., and the late Solomon Bomser, who was a musician. The ceremony was performed at the Lotos Club by Rabbi Zalman SchachterShalomi.

title: INCREASED U.S. ROLE IN MIDEAST IS URGED
description: CAIRO, Feb. 18  Defense Secretary Harold Brown has decided to urge President Carter to make substantial increases in military involvement in the Middle East, including stepping up arms supplies to prbWestern Arab nations and expanding the American naval presence in the region, United States officials said tonight.

title: New Era for NeimanMarcus
description: DALLAS, Feb. 13  Before the Dallas Cowboys and their cheerleaders existed, before there was a Cotton Bowl, before the East Texas oilmen came to town, there was NeimanMarcus.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: ALBERT STILLMAN

title: Fear Still Paralyzes Zaire Massacre Town
description: KOLWEZI. Zaire  Many of the bodies that were dumped in a common grave have been reburied now, in separate plots in a weeded patch the size of a football field at Mwangazi Cemetery, on the outskirts of town. There are no names, but each grave is marked by a steel post with a number.

title: Tomjanovich Is Coping With Injuries, Doubts
description: THERE were two white stripes across his face, one above the eyes and one below them, and another stripe running down the bridge of his nose. It was a protective mask, molded to his face, created to protect his nose, which was broken in December. Any professional basketball player would have needed one, but this was not just anyone. This was Rudy Tomjanovich, and since his face had been smashed apart and rebuilt the year before, this was more than a protective mask.

title: The Toyota in Our Past
description: The international trade news from Washington last week was mostly about White House concessions to domestic textile and sugar interests seeking protection. These maneuvers should not overshadow a far more important issue: our deteriorating trade relations with Japan. For nearly two years, the Carter Administration has been lecturing Japan on the need to reduce its massive trade surplus. The Japanese have listened politely, and expressed public agreement. But in fact the facade of Japanese goodwill is deceiving.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How did scoring originate in tennis? Why 15, 30, 40, deuce?

title: It Can Happen Only in Winter
description: People who don't go out in the winter just don't know what they're missing, said Basil Kamener, a sailskater, as he prepared to swoop out on

title: Stony Brook Professors Take Courses
description: STONY BROOK, L.I.  Marshall Spector is taking courses in chemistry, sociology and English at the State University of New York here, and he says the professors are much too tough.

title: Text of Declaration by Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 18 (AP)  Following is an English translation provided Tass, the official Soviet press agency, of the text of a statement made today by Soviet Government on the ChineseVietnamese hostilities:

title: Sporting Gear
description: The backpack has usually been considered ideal for conventional travel, inasmuch as it frees your hands for tickets, passports and other incidentals. But there's nothing ideal about checking it with an airline and finding later that the metal frame was bent when piled in with suitcases and trunks, or that the strap was shredded by the conveyor. Now. West Ridge Manufacturing of Los Angeles has developed a backpack whose welded aluminum frame and padded strap zip into a concealed compartment. The larger size thus converts into luggage suitable for checking purposes, and the smaller size into luggage that can be carried on board and stowed under the seat. Each size comes with or without side pockets, which are $5 extra. This luggagebackpack combination. called the Ultimate, is produced under the Dolt label and is carried by Paragon (867 Broadway, near 18th Street), which expects to have it back in stock in about a week. Without pockets. the prices are $63.95 for the smaller size and $66.95 for the larger.

title: Study Cautions F.B.I. on Using Voice Identification as Evidence
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  A study by the National Academy of Sciences has cautioned the Federal Bureau of Investigation against relying too heavily on voiceidentification findings as evidence in court.

title: DETAILS ARE SKETCHY
description: HONG KONG, Monday, Feb. 19  Vietnam said yesterday that its army had knocked out 60 Chinese tanks and killed hundreds of Chinese soldiers as it checked a Chinese invasion six miles inside Vietnamese territory.

title: The City
description: Negotiations are to resume this morning in an effort to head off a strike threatened for Wednesday morning by New York City school custodial employees. If that strike occurs, officials plan to trim school sessions to four hours and eliminate school meals.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON APPLICATIONS for export licenses have come cascading into the Commerce Department in the first six weeks of this year at an annual rate of 77,000 a year, which will be a record if it persists.

title: Laura Bent, Poet, 94; Sister of the Writers
description: Laura Bent, a poet and the sister of the late Stephen Vincent and William Rose Benet, the writers, died Saturday at the Village Nursing Home on Hudson Street. Her age was 94. Until recently she had lived in the Marlton Hotel at 5 West Eighth Street.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  To figure out what the next move in the SinoSoviet conflict will be, examine the series of recent moves as if on a chessboard.

title: New York Sales Up 8% In January
description: The spurt in sales that New York City's big retail stores enjoyed during the Christmas season continued in January, as sales rose 8.1 percent above those of the corriasvondinR month in 1978, according to a spot check last week. Sales in the greater metropolitan area advanced 8.7 percent.

title: Vietnam and Cambodia Sign a Group of Treaties
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 18 (Reuters)  Vietnam and Cambodia signed a treaty of peace, friendship and cooperation in Phnom Penh today, Radio Hanoi revorted.

title: President Zia's Party Takes a Strong Lead In Bangladesh Voting
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Monday Feb. 19  The Bangladesh Nationalist Party of President Ziaur Rahman pushed to a substantial lead today in early results of yesterday's election for Parliament.

title: Stage: Stevie Dramatizes Poet's Life
description: THE British poet Stevie Smith is an unlikely and unprepossessing subject for a play. Proudly middleclass, she spent most of her life living with her aunt in a suburb outside of London, working in an office and puttering in her garden of poetry. Wearing the most unstylish, brightly clashing clothes, she had limited experience in the area of romance, and died a spinster. Her life was in her poetry  a curious combination of the childlike and the knowing: death is familiar figure in her verse. This is perhaps the only thing that she had in common with someone as dramatic as Sylvia Plath.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: CAPE TOWN  When P. W. Botha became Prime Minister of South Africa last September, the world saw him as another in a line of Afrikaner extremists, totally unyielding on issues of race and color. That estimate appears to have been mistaken.

title: More Top Officials Arrested in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 18  The arrest of former Iranian officials, military officers and business leaders continued today, with more than a score of wellknown persons seized in Teheran and in the provinces.

title: SCHOLARS INTERPRET INVASION IN 2 WAYS
description: American university professors who study Chinese politics and history took two views of China's motives for invading Vietnam in interviews yesterday.

title: Tennis: Final Goes to Tanner
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif., Feb. 18 (AP)  Roscoe Tanner won the $250,000 Tennis Games tournament for the second year in a row today, beating Brian Gottfried, 64, 62, without the punctuation of his usual big serve.

title: Opera: Many Debuts in Flute at Met
description: NEW faces abounded at the Metropolitan Opera's first performance this season of Die Zauberflte Saturday afternoon. Four principal singers were making their debuts with the company and nearly everyone else was appearring in other major roles for the first time.

title: Days of Hope: A Rookie at 20
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, FLA. WHEN I got traded, the rookie pitcher with the blazing fastball was saying, it kind of hurt me. Then I thought: Hey, the Yankees! Wow! I've got a chance to play for the world champions. When you're barely 20 years old and can throw a baseball 96 miles an hour, you don't bother nibbling at the corners of any kind of plate.

title: Letter: On Italy's Political Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Deaths
description: ABELOVIrving. Beloved husband Of Helen (nee Herzog), adored father of Carol and Allen Fritz, loving grandfather of David, Michael and Susan Fritz. Dear brother Services Guttermar's Memorial Chapel, Woodbury, N.Y at 2 PM. Tuesday

title: Deaths
description: RUSSO  Joseph P., of West Caldwell, N.J., husband of Marie P. (Gam ma), tether of Mrs. Ruth Bender. Mrs. Marilyn Magala and Miss Carol Russo Brother ot Mrs. Irene D'Amico. Also survived by tsvc grandchildren. Funeral Mass Wednesday, St. Aloysius Church, CaIdwell, N.J., at 10 AM. Friends may call Monday and Tuesday, 24, 710 PM. at the GallagherHagelin Funeral Home. 66 Roseland Ave., Caldwell, N.J. In lieu of flowers contributions to the West Essex First Aid Squad, West Caldwell, N.J., or the Riverside Hospice Development Fund, Boonton, N.J. 07005.

title: Deaths
description: BLONDER  Jesse. Montammy Golf Club deeply grieves the untimely Passing of its esteemed member Jesse Blonder. Our heartfelt sym pathy to his wife Sylvia and his be reaved family.

title: The Region
description: NEWARK (AP)  The new chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board said excessively high landing and operational fees were limiting airline growth at Newark International AirPort.

title: Jazz: Bowie's Jamboree
description: LESTER BOWIE and some 60 musicians, drawn from the front ranks of contemporary jazz circles, made a joyful noise. at the Symphony Space, 95th Street and Broadway, on Saturday night. Never before had so many of the best younger jazz musicians been on one stage at one time, and the evening took on the air of a kind of official innauguration. We are the next wave of jazz innovation, the smiles on the musicians' faces seemed to be saying, and the wave has arrived at the shore.

title: Skate Sailing Makes the Frozen Lake a Speedway
description: THEY could zip past Eric Heiden, the speed skater, in a breeze, and they could put track's top sprinters far behind them. In fact the most proficient of them sometimes move at more than 50 miles an hour. Among athletes who strive for speed on their own two feet, only downhill skiers are faster.

title: Neighborhoods Gain New Power In Political Shift
description: In a littlenoticed rearrangement of political and governmental power in New York City, the 59 community boards are taking on new strength.

title: Vermont's Blue Law Ruled Discriminatory Against Large Stores
description: ST. JOHNSBURY, Vt., Feb. 18  A judge has held part of the state's Sunday blue law to be unconstitutional, a ruling that will allow the State Supreme Court to address the issue for the first time.

title: Study Sees Problems With FlatGrant Plan On Welfare Payments
description: ALBANY, Feb. 18  A study by the state's Department of Social Services warned that to combine the basic publicassistance grant and the separate rent allowance in New York State into a single flat payment  a consolidation contemplated in Federal welfare reform proposals  would either cost the state a great deal of money or significantly reduce the grants of some welfare recipients.

title: T.P.R.: Canadiens Pull Away
description: The New York Times's computerized team power ratings this week, based on National Hockey League games through last Monday, show the Montreal Canadiens pulling away from the secondplace New York Islanders. Two weeks ago, in the most recent T.P.R. evaluation of professional hockey, the Canadiens held the slimmest of leads over the Islanders, 1 T.P.R. point. The margin has now widened to 77.

title: Notes on People
description: Admittedly sensitive to how some might view his decision, Judah Gribetz, who was Governor Carey's counsel until last month, has joined the law firm of Mudge, Rose, Guthrie and Alexander. That, you may recall, is the old firm of Richard M. Nixon and John N. Mitchell, and as a prominent New York Democrat, Mr. Gribetz is well aware that there are those who might make judgments about him just because of a few people who used to be members there.

title: Police Capture a Man Suspected Of Don't Be Foolish Robberies
description: Acting on a up from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, New York City detectives yesterday arrested a 24yearold Manhattan man suspected of being the Don't Be Foolish Bandit, one of the most wanted bank robbers in the city.

title: Marriage Announcement 1 -- No Title
description: Susan Morrow Schadler Is Wed

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, Feb. 20

title: Dance: Juilliard Students
description: THE Juilliard Dance Ensemble does more than provide dance students at the Juilliard School with performing opportunities. It challenges them with new choreographic works that are real dances, not simply endofterm display pieces. Moreover, because the company can draw upon Juilliard's musical resources, it can be musically adventurous. It can even produce hybrids that combine dance with song.

title: Visit to Mexico: Strains in Open
description: MEXICO CITY. Feb. 18  President Carter's visit here last week was perhaps the first time that American and Mexican heads of state have met without waxing poetic about being good neighbors. But it was also the first time that the two sides have confronted the underlying tensions in their relationship.

title: Forecast for SnowCovered Iowa: A Flurry of Presidential Hopefuls
description: DES MOINES, Feb. 18  With more than its share of snow on the ground and a procession of Republican Presidential hopefuls slogging around purposefully in subzero temperatures, Iowa is beginning to take on the look of a flat New Hampshire these days.

title: Rev. Raymond Bragg, An ExUnitarian Aide And a Minister, Dies
description: The Rev. Raymond Bennett Bragg, former pastor of All Souls Unitarian Church in Kansas City, Mo. died of cancer Thursday at the Menorah Medical Center there. Dr. Bragg was 76 years old.

title: Amtrak Train Derails
description: ALTOONA, Pa., Feb. 18 (UPI)  An Amtrak passenger train traveling from New York to Chicago derailed late last night but none of the 133 passengers aboard was reported injured. One of the three locomotives on the Broadway Limited and eight of its 10 cars derailed, but all remained upright and in line, Brian Duff, an Amtrak spokesman, said in Washington. No immediate indication was given for the cause of the derailment. which occurred near the summit of the pass through the Allegheny Mountains between Altoona and Pittsburgh.

title: Parents, Not Their Children, Are the Focus of New Centers
description: It has been called The Battered Parent Syndrome. Dr. Robert B. Howard. a Minneapolis internist and columnist for Postgraduate Medicine magazine. professes to Know the symptoms as a father as well as a physician: bruised ego, fractured psyche, flattened pocketbook, oozing guilt from every orifice.

title: Our History's Lessons  For Us, For Others
description: Our painful racial past and our attempts to cope with its continuing consequences must not be lost on the rest of the world or on the European cities to which thirdworld people now immigrate.

title: Paying the Price for Heat
description: The New York City Council is studying a resolution authorizing an investigation into why heatingoil prices are going up. Instead of so duplicating work being done by other agencies, the Council might better consider the effects of the higher oil costs on city housing.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Outdoors
description: SHORTLY after World War II, seemed to me, every deer hunter I encountered had a knife nearly as big as a sword hanging from his belt. This has been changing perceptibly in the last decade, however, as American sportsmen, apparently increasingly aware of the real uses to which the various kinds of knife can be put, emerge from the Bowie syndrome.

title: A Study Ranks State Tax Systems on Basis of Fairness
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  The Coalition of American Public Employees, in a study ranking state tax systems by fairness, has asserted that Alabama has the worst tax system in the nation and Oregon the best.

title: WASHINGTON'S BIRTHDAY
description: Washington's Birthday will be celebrated as a Federal holiday today. Following are services affected:

title: U.S. Emphasizes That It Will Shun Involvement in the Fighting in Asia
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  Administration officials stressed today that the United States would not become involved in the fighting between Communist nations in Asia but would concentrate its diplomatic efforts on ending the conflicts and persuading the Soviet Union not to intervene.

title: Trailways Chief Pushing Deregulation of Buses
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  Transportation Secretary Brock Adams may have incurred the wrath of many rail passengers with his recent proposal to slash Amtrak's mileage nearly in half, but J. Kevin Murphy seems delighted.

title: Cooke Praises Restored Bronx Church
description: I have never seen a church renovated with such beauty, Terence Cardinal Cooke said Saturday night, gazing at the Byzantine glory of St. Anselm's Church.

title: Chess:
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. 14  Ulf Andersson, a 27year27old Swedish Grandmaster, got off to a great start with three victories and two draws in the third Sao Paulo international tournament here in the Clube De Xadrez. Andersson, who can stake a claim to being the world's most conservative player, taking every opportunity to exchange queens to enter into lengthy endings, is making this style work now.

title: Getting Started
description: You'll need two basic things: a pair of skates and a sail. For advice about making your own gear, as well as information on the new Swedish ice wing, speak to the American Skate Sailing Association, Basil Kamener, commodore, 14 Whitewood Road, North White Plains, N.Y. 10603. The telephone number is (914) 5924056.

title: Sharpening
description: Sooner or later  usually sooner  knives require sharpening. The butcher's steel is all right for touching up the edge on a relatively soft knife, but some of the harder materials won't respond to this treatment, and it really doesn't produce an ideal edge.

title: A New Seriousness in Washington's Approach to Mexico
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  President Carter's visit to Mexico last week, and his agreement to meet again this summer with President Jose Lopez Portillo, have been widely interpreted as evidence that the Carter Administration has finally begun to take Mexico seriously. The return visit this summer is viewed by United States officials as a signal to the diplo- matic bureaucracy here not to allow matters to drift.

title: Deaths
description: CLARKHarriet P., on Feb. 16, 1979, beloved daughter of the late Eugene P and Elizabeth M. Clark, dear sister of Eugenia A Graft and the late Elizabeth M. Clark, sister in law of Edward R. Graft, M.D., and also survived by four nephews and a niece. Funeral Tuesday, 8:30 AM, from the McLaughlin & Sons Colonial Home, Third Avenue at 97 St, Brooklyn, Mass of Christian burial 9 AM, St. Patricks Church

title: 5 Local Boards Ask City to Expand Project To Better Its Services
description: An experiment on a project to help New York City's community boards upgrade municipal services in their neighborhoods  tested by five of the boards has resulted in a recommendation that the project be expanded citywide.

title: Schindler Jailed In Fraud Case
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 18 (AP) Richard T. Schindler, a fugitive, has been jailed here in lieu of $1 million bond while awaiting transfer to Los Angeles to face Federal charges involving $12 million in allegedly phony investment deals.

title: Duke Outclasses Louisville, 8872
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Feb. 18 (AP)  Gene Banks scored 23 points and Mike Grninski added 22 as Duke, ranked fifth nationally in the writers' poll, rolled over ninthranked Louisville, 8872, in a nationally televised college basketball game today.

title: War Sounds Wake Border Town
description: HANOI, Vietnam, Feb. 18 (Agence FrancePresse)  On Friday night, the town of Lang Son was peaceful, with children playing badminton in the street. Only the presence of several solders reminded visitors that the town is only 13 miles from the Chinese border.

title: Aqueduct Hopeful of Ending Strike Soon
description: There was guarded optimism on both sides yesterday about negotiations in the dispute between parimutuel clerk; and the New York Racing Association at Aoueduct. The fourth day of the con-meeting between the two sides on Saturday night. frontation passed without any incident:: on the picket lines or in the racing plant.

title: Correction Panel Is Still Pressing Hongisto Inquiry
description: An extensive investigation of Richard D. Hongisto by the New York State Senate's Committee on Crime and Corrections has thus far found nothing glazing that would exclude Mr. Hongisto's being confirmed as Correction Commissioner, according to Senator Ralph J. Marino, the committee .chairman. But continuation of the appointment by the Senate is still in question.

title: Rock: The Clash Bows In
description: THIS has been a paiticularly scarce winter for major rock tours, and hence, Saturday evening's New York debut by the Clash at the Palladium Constituted the first major rock event of 1979.

title: Bronx Leader Acts to Close Breach in Democratic Party
description: In an attempt to end years of political warfare in the Bronx, and with the encouragement of Mayor Koch and his political advisers, the Bronx Democratic leader, Stanley Friedman, offered an olive branch to antiorganiza-

title: Nature Group Is Given Two Islands in Maine Visited by Bald Eagles
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Feb. 18  Two islands, described as ecologically significant as a feeding and resting area for the American bald eagle, have been given to the Maine chapter of the Nature Conservancy, it was announced here today.

title: Israel Selects Team for Camp David
description: JERUSALEM, Feb.18  The Israeli Cabinet named an eightman team today to assist Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan in the Middle East peace talks resuming this week at Camp David, Md.

title: Giants and Idzik Will Meet Today
description: John Idzik, who runs the New York Jets' offense, will be interviewed for the Giants' coaching job today. He will meet with the Giants' new general manager, George Young, with whom he worked at Baltimore and Miami.

title: East Bloc Seeks New Oil Sources
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 18 Eastern Europe has begun a desperate search for alternate sources of oil and natural gas. The countries of this re- gion expect the suspension of imports from Iran to last a long time, and they expect cutbacks over the next 18 months in supplies from the Soviet Union.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Stage: Threads Opens At Cleveland Playhouse
description: CLEVELAND THE Cleveland Playhouse is the oldest professional resident theater company in the United States, and it is celebrating its 63d birthday with a largescale rebuilding plan.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: In His Modest Way, Dan Wolf Stays a Source of Strength
description: Into Mayor Koch's office in the northwest corner of City Hall they file, the decisionmakers or the pleaders, the staff insiders or the visiting outsiders. Dan Wolf is there, silently sipping coffee, chewing a sandwich, smiling faintly.

title: ABC Buying 51% of Chilton
description: The American Broadcasting Companies are expected to buy a majority interest in the Chilton Company, not the substantial minority the company earlier reported.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: About New York
description: Angel Marquez sees through fake Puerto Ricans.

title: Israel Bars German Lawyer
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 19 (Reuters)  Israeli authorities denied entry today to a West German lawyer, Ludwig Bock, who they said had been a Nazi. A press statement by the Justice and Interior Ministers said Mr. Bock was one of the lawyers who had been systematically disrupting the twoyearold trial of former officials of the Maidanek concentration camp.

title: EDUCATION
description: IT is a truism in education that middleclass children have an edge on their less advantaged counterparts because they come to school with many of the verbal and other skills that contribute to academic success.

title: U.N. Debate on the Indochina Invasions Supported
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 19 The United States and other Western members of the Security Council agreed after private talks today to support a request for a Council debate covering both the Chinese attack on Vietnam and the Vietnamese invasion of Cambodia.

title: Frederic Winthrop, 72, Founder Of Organization to Aid the Deal
description: Frederic Winthrop, founder of the Winthrop Foundation for the Deaf at Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary, died of cancer Friday at his home in Hamilton. Mass. He was 72 years old.

title: Letter: On Income Maintenance Experiments
description: To the Editor:

title: Killing Coyotes
description: WASHINGTON  In recent months, the American sheep industry has been criticized strongly for its attempts to develop effective, economical and environmentally sound coyotecontrol methods. The issue revolves around one of four poisons, sodium monofluoroacetate  known familiarly to the sheep industry as 1080  that many feel is environmentally sound but that was banned by President Richard M. Nixon in 1972 for what he felt were sound environmental reasons  reasons that the sheep industry believes were highly questionable.

title: Italian Communists: and Most Eastern European Nations Rebuke Peking
description: ROME, Feb. 19  Italian Communist leaders, dismayed at the threat of a military confrontation between China and the Soviet Union, have issued a public rebuke to Pekine for its invasion of Vietnam.

title: More Talks Are Planned On AntiSatellite Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) American and Soviet negotiators failed at recent meetings in Switzerland to agree on controlling killer satellites, but another round of talks will be arranged, the State Department said today.

title: Taxes &
description: THE new Energy Act provision that allows and renters to claim tax credits for installing energysaving devices was expected to be popular, and figures from the Internal Revenue Service show that it is.

title: A SIXMILE INVASION
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 19  Intelligence reports suggested today that Chinese forces were preparing to pull back after having pushed six miles into Vietnamese territory, and some analysts said the withdrawal of some troops might already have begun.

title: Nicaraguan Combatants Report 37 Killed During the Last Month
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 19 (Reuters) Thirtyseven people have been killed and four wounded in clashes be, tween leftist guerrillas and National Guardsmen in the last month, according to statements from both sides today.

title: Eilberg Goes on Trial Today
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 (AP)  Former Representative Joshua Eilberg will go on trial tomorrow in Federal District Court on one count of criminal conflict of interest. A jury will be asked to decide whether Mr. Eilberg was paid as a private lawyer for representing Hahnemann Hospital in its bid to receive a $14.5 million grant from the Community Services Administration. It is a crime for a Congressman to receive private compensation for any business matter he handles before the Federal Government.

title: Bryant Out of Hospital
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Feb. 19 (AP) Bear Bryant. Alabama's football coach, was released today from a hospital where he had been under treatment since Feb. 9. Bryant fell in the bathtub at his home and cracked a rib Feb. 6.

title: LulaJean Elliott, 74, Consultant In State Department of Welfare
description: LulaJean Elliott, a welfare consultant with the New York State Department of Social Welfare for more than 30 years, died Sunday, following a long battle with cancer, at the Green Hospital of the Scripps Research Clinic in La Jolla, Calif., where she had lived since 1974. Miss Elliott was 74 years old.

title: Fear Grips Many Iranians, From Clerks to Executives
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 19  For most of last week, Eqwal, a short paunchy man with thinning dark hair, slept at the home of his cousin, sharing a small bedroom with his cousin's 76yearold fatherinlaw. But since Thursday, he has spent his nights in a crawl space reached through a camouflaged hole behind a battered Kelvintor refrigerator.

title: Treasury to Sell 2Year Notes
description: Even though it s holidayshortered week, activity in the credit markets will be heavy over the next several days.

title: Researchers Challenge Old Theories On Obesity
description: RECENT studies suggest that many of the factors thought to cause obesity are actually its results. The new research challenges the longstanding notions that most people who are fat get that way because of their genes, because they are lazy, greedy or weakwilled or because they are psychologically disturbed or cursed with a low metabolism.

title: Soviet Has Many Choices on China Border
description: The threat posed by Soviet forces along China's long northern frontier and vivid memories of Russia's blitzkrieg in Manchuria in 1945 may have constrained the Chinese offensive in Vietnam and led to the present static ground warfare.

title: S.E.C's Voice of Dissension
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  In her year and a half as a commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Roberta S. Karmel, a former Wall Street securities lawyer, has emerged as the most conservative member of the fivemember panel. A vocal critic of some S.E.C. regulatory actions, she has been an increasingly frequent dissenter from the commission's enforcement decisions.

title: China in Vietnam: A Matter of Honor
description: HONG KONG. Feb. 19  On the night American troops invaded Cambodia in 1970, President Nixon explained to a national television audience that he had acted because, when the chips are down. the United States could not ap- pear to be a pitiful, helpless giant.

title: Spectacular Bid Trounces Field In Florida Stop on Derby Route
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., Feb. 19  As far as Grover (Bud) Delp is concerned, Spectacular Bid has already won thoroughbred racing's Triple Crown.

title: President Quits At Grunar + Jahr
description: Charles C. (Jim) Randolph has quit the presidency of Grunar + Jahr U. S. A., due to policy differences with the West German parent company.

title: Tactics Used at Daytona May Result in Penalties
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19 Officials of the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing met today to decide if the driving tactics in the Daytona 500mile race yesterday. or the fisticuffs afterward between Cale Yarborough and Bobby and Donnie Allison, warranted disciplinary action.

title: Police Talks Resume, but Mardi Gras Still in Doubt
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 19 (UPI) Federal mediators reported progress today in the first face-to-face bargaining session between representatives of striking policemen and the city, but Mayor Ernest N. Morial canceled more Mardi Gras activities and Bourbon Street businesses reported a 30 percent drop in sales.

title: In an Old Amish Strobghold, a New Latin Accent
description: LANCASTER, Pa.  Somehow in the past few years the word got around Puerto Rican quarters in New York that this old town on the Conestoga was a good place to live. All of a sudden Lancaster County, the home of the Amish and the Pennsylvania Dutch for more than two centuries, became the home of a sizable Latin community.

title: Talks in Wake Of Iranian Crisis
description: BAHREIN, Feb 19, (Reuters)  In the wake of the loss of Iranian crude oil supplies, which is having a major impact on world prices, it was announced today that OPEC oil ministers would meet in Geneva on March 26.

title: Satellites Studied As Power Source
description: Government and industry officials in the space program are looking seriously at a concept that even some of the bolder space advocates tended to dismiss as too far out when a Czechborn engineer broached it in 1968.

title: Bronx Diet: Hold the Cottage Cheese
description: Richard Smith scrutinized the menu at Ralph's Restaurant in the Bronx until he was satisfied that nowhere did the words cottage cheese appear. Only then did he remove his parka and sink down into one of Ralph's pink banquettes. We're halfway home, he told a lunch companion.

title: The Bishops' Message for Latin America
description: The Roman Catholic Bishops of Latin America produced a remarkable document to conclude their conference in Puebla, Mexico, last week. While incorporating the arguments of Pope John Paul II and others who sought a denunciation of Marxist doctrines of class warfare, the bishops nonetheless issued a clear summons to social action. Their statement calls on the clergy and laity to accept and take up the cause of the poor. It proclaims the goal of ending physical and moral violence, abuses of power, the manipulation of money as well as sexual excesses and breaking the Lord's commandments. This definition of the church's mission was fully supported by the Pope. proving groundless our earlier fears that he would throw the weight of his office against social involvement.

title: TV VIDEO RECORDER IS COURTROOM ISSUE
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19  A curious legal battle with many billions of dollars at stake is under way in a courtroom here over an effort to ban an electronic device. the home video recorder, that has already changed the way many Americans live.

title: WorldNews Briefs
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 19 (AP)  About 300 Maldive islanders armed with handguns and axes boarded an Americanowned oceanographic survey ship Saturday in the Indian Ocean, kidnapped an American crewman and looted the vessel before releasing it, amateur radio operators reported today.

title: New Law in Greece Is Expected To Make Divorces Easier to Get
description: ATHENS, Feb. 19 (Reuters)  The Greek Government published a law today under which a spouse who has been separated for more than six years from a marriage partner can obtain a divorce, even if the other partner is unwilling to divorce.

title: 80 on Italian Train Hurt in Slide
description: NAPLES, Feb. 19 (AP)  A mudslide, caused by heavy rains, derailed a crowded passenger train in southern Italy overnight, injuring at least 80 people, three of them seriously.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The schedule of ship arrivals and departures in The Times yesterday incorrectly reported the time of the Oceanic's sailing from New York today. It is 4 P.M.

title: Fried. Krupp Sales Increase
description: BONN, Feb. 19  Fried. Krupp G.m.b.H., terming fiscal 1978 well fought, said that external sales of its world group rose a preliminary 6 percent in 1978 to 11.9 billion West German marks, the equivalent of about $6.43 billion.

title: The Tide in Foreign Affairs
description: On such a full sea are we now afloat. And we must take the current when it serves Or lose our ventures.

title: 2 Sides in Chad's Brief Civil War 1 Sign Agreement for a CeaseFire
description: PARIS, Feb. 19 (AP)  President Flix Malloum of Chad and his rival, Prime, Minister Hissen Habr, signed a ceasefire agreement today, halting a brief civil war that has left hundreds dead, diplomatic sources said.

title: A New Aide, an Old Friend at Koch's Right Hand
description: Mayor Koch's inner circle of advisers at City Hall the people who counsel, cajole, criticize, listen to and encourage him  includes both old friends and new. Dan Wolf, a $1ayear assistant without title and a confidant of Mr. Koch for many years, is a lowkey, behindthescenes taskmaster who helps him focus sharply on tough decisions. Maureen R. Connelly, the 31yearold, $47,000ayear press secretary who has known Mr. Koch only since his mayoral campaign, is a witty, tireless and protective assistant.

title: Entertainment Events
description: CHUQIAGO, by Antonio Eugino. at the Public Thea- ter, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: Charles Tyler Adds to Range
description: CHARLES TYLER, a saxophonist who was first beard in New York in the 1960's with the late Albert Ayler, has grown over the years. In those days he was a powerful but somewhat monochromatic soloist, given to either rich midrange lyricism or highregister whistling. Now he ranges all over his alto and baritone saxophones, projecting strongly in all registers, balancing melodious fanfares with machinegun bursts and high, singing melodies with basement rumblings.

title: SCHOOLBUS DRIVERS TO DEFY COURT RULE
description: Spokesmen for 2,000 striking schoolbus drivers said yesterday that the drivers would risk jail and fines rather than obey two court orders to return to work when the public schools reopen today. They said they were determined to preserve jobsecurity provisions in their contract, which the Schools Chancellor says is a contract too costly for the schools to tolerate.

title: 151 Arrested in Baltimore Looting
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 19  Widespread looting of downtown businesses after a 20inch snowfall led to at least 150 arrests here today and the imposition of a curfew in the city.

title: Bhutto's Son, in Britain, Fighting for Father's Life
description: LONDON, Feb. 19  Operating from a small borrowed mews cottage in the Kensington district, the 24yearold son of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto is campaigning hard to save his father's life. But like other supporters of the former Pakistani Prime Minister, who is now under a sentence of death, Mir Murtaza Bhutto is growing less and less hopeful.

title: Afghan Regime Shows Its Concern Over Growth of Armed Opposition
description: KABUL. Afghanistan, Feb. 18  As part of an effort to counteract their widespread image as godless men heading a nation of devout Moslems, Afghanistan's leftist rulers staged a big reception in the House of the People, as they call the Parliament, to celebrate the birthday of Mohammed last week.

title: Helmut von Erffa at 78; On Rutgers Art Faculty
description: Helmut von Erffa, former chairman of the Rutgers University art department, died Saturday in St. Peter's Hospital, New Brunswick, N.J., from complications following surgery. He was 78 years old and lived at 38 Juniper Lane, Piscataway, N.J.

title: Denver Uncertain Over Old Uranium Site
description: DENVER, Feb. 19  The employees of the Robinson Brick & Tile Company have been living with a considerable uncertainty since the discovery a few days ago that the company is sitting over an old uranium waste dump.

title: Mrs. Shcharansky Starts a Drive To Free Husband in Soviet Union
description: GENEVA, Feb. 19  The 28yearold wife of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the imprisoned Soviet dissident, said today she was very afraid for the health of her husband.

title: Trade Talk Called 98% Complete
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  The current trade negotiations, which could bring sweeping changes in the way the world conducts its business, are 98 percent complete. according to Robert S. Strauss, the President's special trade representative.

title: Italy Opens Kidnapping Trial
description: ROME, Feb. 19 (Reuters)  Thirtyeight members of Kidnaps Incorporated, a gang accused of some of Italy's most notorious abductions, went on trial today. They are charged with five kidnappings that netted more than $3 million. The victims included the head of an international electronics company and the son of one of Italy's largest coffee importers. The defendants include 12 women.

title: Sanitation Commissioner Passes Key Test  in Queens, of Course
description: The largest snowfall of his fivemonth tenure had just ended, and Norman Steisel was about to do what a Commissioner of Sanitation must do at such times  visit Queens. The only hitch was that Mr. Steisel couldn't lino a driver for his car right away, so while Paul J. Trautman, deputy director of the Office of Operations, cleaned the windshield, Mr. Steisel went to look for a driver.

title: Marchi Seeking Action to Raise Welfare Grants
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19  State Senator John J. Marchi, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said today that something must be done to bring welfare payments closer to the Federal Government's minimum living standard, and that the Legislature will make progress in that area this year.

title: Sunkist Diversifies With Orange Soda
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19  Who should know more about oranges than Sunkist, the nation's largest citrus cooperative, marketer of more than 40 million 40pound crates of oranges a year?

title: Snow Up to 20 Inches Leaves 13 Dead
description: A snowstorm that surprised forecasterswith its intensity cut a wide swath up the East Coast yesterday, pummeling New York City with 13 inches of snow and smothering other areas, including New Jersey, with up to 20 inches.

title: Sports Schedule Is Curtailed by Storm
description: The snowstorm that struck the Eastern Seaboard yesterday caused cancellations and postponements of many sporting events.

title: Man in Civilian Patrol Injured in an Attempt To Stop IRT Mugging
description: A 20-year-old member of a civilian patrol group seeking to curb subway violence was injured early yesterday while interrupting an apparent mugging on an IRT subway platform in the Bronx.

title: The City
description: Officials in Toronto began a public appeal yesterday to raise $5,000 for hospital care there for a Brooklyn baby now in the neonatal intensivecare unit at Brooklyn Hospital.

title: Rhodesia Announces New Attacks On Guerrilla Area in Mozambique
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia. Feb. 19 (AP)  Rhodesia said today that it had bombed a guerrilla storage complex in Mozambique. The attack appeared to be the start of a campaign designed to prevent black nationalists from sabotaging elections electrons scheduled in April.

title: Texan Says He Financed Assault On Iran Jail to Free 2 Employees
description: DALLAS, Feb. 19 (AP)  A millionaire Texas industrialist said today that an Americanled commando squad that he financed was behind a mob assault on an Iranian prison that freed thousands of inmates, including two of his employees.

title: TV: A Puerto Rican Boy Sings Some Irish Ballads
description: SPECIAL TREAT, scheduled for 4 P.M: today on NBCTV, features a Puerto Rican youth singing Danny Boy. An open confession: It is absolutely impossible for a lover of Puerto Rico named O'Connor not to find that combination irresistible.

title: James Blake, Pianist Who Wrote Joint, Letters From Prison
description: James Blake, a jazz musician and author of The Joint, died of cancer yesterday in Arlington (Va.) Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived in Arlington.

title: In the Privacy of Piscataway
description: Someday the Nets will come in from the cold. When they were winning American Basketball Association championships as the New York Nets, they pointed out that they were in the in the wrong league, where Dr. J did marvelous things for the edification of too many empty seats in Nassau Coliseum. Now that they're in the right league as the New Jersey Nets, they play out there in the privacy of Piscataway, out there in the Rutgers Athletic Center somewhere in the snowy fields between the New Jersey Turnpike and Interstate 287, and they're a much better team than the Knicks but they're too far away for most people to care. The difference between the Nets and the Knicks, says Phil Jackson, once a popular Knick and now the Net assistant coach, is 45 miles, 5,000 specta tors and 15 reporters.

title: President Gets Low Ratings In Survey of Georgia Voters
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 19  When Jimmy Carter returns to Atlanta tomorrow, he will hear some bad news on the home front: His Georgia neighbors continue to think he is making a bad job of his Presidency.

title: Washington Struck by Its Worst Storm Since 1922
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  The worst storm in half a century struck the nation's capital overnight with up to two and a half feet of snow and drifts up to seven feet high. The storm brought transportation, business and Congress to a virtual standstill.

title: L.I.R.R. Union Threatens Strike Early on Friday
description: EAST NORTHPORT, L.I., Feb. 19 The head of the largest union on the Long Island Rail Road said today that it would strike at 4 A.M. on Friday unless the railroad agreed to consider revised demands.

title: Fabled Boots Now a Fashion Fad
description: As his feet sank into a snowbank at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street yesterday, Tony Aylward, an actor, said that he was delighted we finally got a heavy snowfall because now I know for sure my Bean boots are practical as well as prestigious. Even as Mr. Aylward spoke, two other men, similarly shod, plunged into a nearby drift.

title: A Snowfall the Computer Didn't Exactly Count On
description: Yesterday's heavy snow was a result of a lowpressure system that moved up the East Coast and surprised forecasters by settling midway between New York City and Washington, D.C., instead of moving out to sea.

title: Today's Outlook
description: Transportation  The Metropolitan Transportation Authority predicted that service would be close to normal for subways, buses and commuter trains. Some delays were foreseen on the Long Island Rail Road and on Conrail trains, largely because of an increase in riders as commuters switch from private to public transportation. La Guardia Airport, Kennedy International and Newark International Airports reopened by midnight. Although flights today were expected operate on normal schedules, travelers were advised to check with airlines.

title: Redland Offer For Seasonall
description: The Redland Braas Corporation, which previously agreed to acquire Seasonall Industries Inc. for $17 a share, announced yesterday that it had revised the offer to $14.75 a share. The new offering price followed a weekend audit of Seasonall's 1978 earnings, which were down 24 percent from the year before

title: Negotiations Resumed On Aqueduct Strike
description: Negotiations resumed yesterday in an effort to end the labor dispute between the New York Racing Association and the parimutuel clerks, who have not worked at Aqueduct since last Wednesday.

title: Vietnamese Not Severing Diplomatic Tie to China, Their Envoy Says
description: PARIS, Feb. 19  Vietnam has no immediate plans to sever diplomatic relations with China and is ready to discuss all issues between the two countries, according to one of Vietnam's senior diplomats.

title: KHALIL AND DAYAN ARE ON WAY TO U.S.
description: CAIRO, Feb. 19  Egypt's delegation to the renewed peace talks at Camp David left today with instructions from President Anwar elSadat to make no concessions on a peace pact with Israel

title: Louisville Again Mines Rich Ore of Stage Talent
description: LOUISVILLE. ky. A NEWPLAY marathon such as the one presented this past weekend by Jon Jory's Actors Theater of Louisville is an exhausting experience  for actors as well as for the critics, producers. agents and other theatrical professionals in attendance. On the company's two stages, there were six productions, including one anthology of 10 short plays, plus several workshops of plays in progress. A week of repertory (continuing through Sunday in more leisurely fashion). all compressed into two days of nonstop theatergoing could send one spinning outside for fresh air. Or. as was the case in Louisville, it can be close to euphoric, demonstrating the vibrancy in the American theater and the creativity in our premier regional institutions such as the Actors Theater.

title: Blacks and Women Clash On Access to Jobs and Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  Blacks and women are fighting a quiet but fierce battle over access to jobs and public funds that have been earmarked for applicants who are disadvantaged or members of minority groups.

title: City Fives Ready for Title Event
description: The frantic week of basketball madness that annually fills City College's Nat Holman Gymnasium in late February begins tonight. And, during the nine games that make up the City University of New York championship tournament, the Dolphins of Staten Island will learn if they can add the tournament title to their regularseason league crown.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Amalgamated Bank of New York has elected Jacob Sheinkman, secretarytreasurer of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, as chairman, and Joyce D. Miller, a vice president of A.C.T.W.U., as a director.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: The American Symphony Plays Brahms, Haydn
description: THE American Symphony remained securely ensconced in Central Europe with its program in Carnegie Hall Sunday afternoon. Kazuyoshi Akiyama led the orchestra in three solid Germanic works, all classics of the standard repertory: Brahms's Variations on a Theme by Haydn, Haydn's own Symphony No. 104 and, with Justus Frantz as soloist, Brahms's First Piano Concerto.

title: Afghan Foreign Minister Rejects Protest by U.S. on Dubs Slaying
description: KABUL, Afghanistan. Feb. 19 (Reuters)  Foreign Minister Hafizullah Amin I of Afghanistan rejected as completely baseless today the United States Government's protest over the incident in which Ambassador Adolph Dubs was shot to death last week.

title: Will Naming More Judges Mean Trying More Cases?
description: A judgeship is a prize of great value to many lawyers and politicians, and so, naturally, they welcome an announcement that more judgeships may be created. Recently, a proposal to add 22 new $42,451ayear judgeships to the Criminal Court in New York City has given aspiring judges something to cheer about.

title: Advertising
description: HARCOURT BRACE JOVANOVICH, which started Human Nature, its only consumer magazine, in November 1977, quietly informed its staff last Tuesday that the coming March issue would be its last.

title: AGESOLD ANIMOSITY BEHIND BORDER WAR
description: While greatpower politics are involved in the current border war between China and Vietnam. mutual animosity of many centuries' standing is at least as important in the dispute, as Vietnam's Deputy Foreign Minister made clear in an interview last October.

title: Mass Suicide Possible In Moon Church, 3 Say
description: WARWICK, R.I., Feb. 19 (AP) Three former members of the Unification Church say that mass suicide among the followers of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon is a possibility and there is potential for a replay of the mass deaths of People's Temple members in Guyana last November.

title: U.S. Postpones Gold Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (Reuters)  The United States Treasury said tonight that a scheduled gold auction tomorrow, one in a series designed to improve the standing of the dollar, had been postponed because of the snow emergency in the capital.

title: Morrall Is Hired to Coach U. of Miami Quarterbacks
description: MIAMI, Feb. 19 (UPI)  Earl Morrall, former Miami Dolphins quarterback, was named quarterback coach at the University of Miami today by Coach Howard Schnellenberger, who used to help tutor the Dolphins.

title: Rutgers Defeats UMass By 9576
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Feb. 19  Rutgers shot consistently, took the lead early and Went on to beat the University of Massachusetts, 9576, at the Rutgers Athletic Center tonight.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: If the Environmental Protection Agency decides to extend its ban on fluorocarbons, the man in the middle will be George C. Eads, a 36yearold economist who has been recruited for the President's Council of Economic Advisers, but not yet nominated.

title: TV: Ball's Eye War, Latest in Weaponry
description: SOME of the fascinating complexities of what might be called postindustrial warfare are examined in The Bull's Eye War. It will be seen tonight at 10 on Channel 13, and persons with even a passing interest in international and military affairs will not want to miss it.

title: Islanders Rout Kings, 83; Bossy Scores 100th Goal
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 19  The New York Islanders routed the Los Angeles Kings, 83, tonight as Mike Bossy scored his 100th National Hockey League goal, the 47th of the season and his eighth in eight games. Clark Gillies and Wayne Merrick each scored two goals.

title: 2 From Hamburg Are Sentenced For Aid in East German Escapes
description: EAST BERLIN, Feb. 19 (Reuters) Two West Germans were sentenced today for organizing and helping carry out escape attempts by East Germans trying to Ret to the West.

title: New York Democrats Struggling To Meet PrimaryRules Deadline
description: New York State's Democrats are struggling against a deadline to bring their Presidential primary into compliance with national rules.

title: 2 Points  From 92 Feet Out
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 19 (AP)  Rudy Williams of Providence College may have set a world record when he dropped a field goal from about 92 feet in a game against the University of Rhode Island Saturday.

title: Haub's LongTerm Ties to U.S.
description: Erivan K. Haub, the mysterious German supermarket magnate who bought 42 percent of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company in January, is gradually becoming less mysterious and to a degree, apparently even less German.

title: Monte Carlo Seeks Investors
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco  American and other foreign investors will soon get a chance to obtain a large minority holding in the famous Monte Carlo Casino as well as in hotels and other properties in this tiny independent principality and tourist center on the Mediterranean.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Franklin D. Roosevelt had the New Deal. John F. Kennedy had the New Frontier. Jimmy Carter hopes to build a New Foundation. Henry Kaufman of Salomon Brothers warns of a New Pessimism.

title: New U.S. Satellite Is Monitoring The Ozone Layer for Pollutants
description: WALLOPS ISLAND, Va., Feb. 19 (UPI) A new satellite today was monitoring the stratospheric layer of ozone that scientists fear may be threatened by pollutants.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: A financial rescue effort for Turkey is under way, involving much as $1 billion in new loans from government agencies and private banks. American officials and bankers describe Turkey's plight as the most serious credit problem that has yet arisen in the realm international finance, reflecting an enormous volume of debt that must be rescheduled. [Page A1.]

title: G.O.P. Presidential Aspirants Tour Nation to Denounce Carter's Foreign Policy
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 19  Republican Presidential hopefuls traveled across the country in recent days to denounce President Carter's handling of foreign policy, saying he Invites trouble abroad with weak and vacillating leadership.

title: The Region
description: NEWARK (AP)  Teachers in Newark will vote today on a leadership recommendation for a strike on March 8 to protest the layoff of more than 1,100 school workers.

title: A New Space Museum Born Extraterrestrially
description: HUTCHINSON, Kan., Feb. 19 (UPI)  It was an unusual groundbreaking ceremony. A signal beamed to a Jupiterbound spacecraft on Saturday returned to Earth and today ignited small charge that tossed dirt and sand 50 feet in the air on the site of a proposed $2 million space museum.

title: Tiant Adding Special Zest To Yankees
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 19  Halfway through the dozen wind sprints that end every New York Yankee workout here, the players are gasping for breath.

title: Film: Chuquiago Shows The Real Look of Indians
description: CHUQUIAGO, Antonio. Eguino's fine Bolivian feature, the Indian name for the capital city that the Spaniards named La Paz. It appears to be such an eventempered film that one is well into it before recognizing the fury with which it is charged. Its dominant expression is of inscrutable calm, much the way Indians look to those of us who don't know them.

title: Two Cities In U.S. Plan Trade Link
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  To most people, the term Common Market means the European trading alliance. To some businessmen here and in Baltimore, the term usually refers first of all to a trade arrangement closer to home  a market embracing two of America's major cities, several of its richest counties, the country's thirdlargest seaport and the capital of the United States.

title: Steel Fights for Auto Market
description: John P. Thornton of the United States Steel Corporation, whose job is to oversee business with the automobile industry, the company's biggest customer, recalled recently that for years this largely involved the relatively placid task of seeing that no other steel producer cut into his employer's share of the market.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TO ETERNITY Yesterday marked a proud occasion for the Yale Whiffenpoofs, as several hundred past members of the country's oldest informal collegiate singing unit converged on New Haven to celebrate the ensemble's 70th anniversary. Traditionally raising their glasses high at Mory's, the Whiffenpoofs joined their alumni predecessors in a flow of the a capella music that wins the students new popularity every year  from the campus to the White House and in special engagements of crosscountry touring. In May, the singers embark on their first roundtheworld

title: Soviet Contends U.S. Shares Blame In the Chihese Invasion of Vietnam
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 19  The Soviet Union, while maintaining silence on the possibility of retaliatory action against China for invading Vietnam, said today that the West shared the blame for the invasion.

title: A Loan of $1 Billion Planned to Aid Turks
description: A major international rescue effort for the financially strapped Government of Turkey, which could involve as much as $1 billion in new loans from foreign governmental agencies and private banks, is moving toward completion. The money will be made available, American officials and bankers say, only if Turkey, perennially in financial trouble, adopts more stringent economic policies.

title: Italian Prosecutor Foils Bomb
description: LATINA, Italy, Feb. 19 (Reuters)  A sharpeyed bodyguard saved an. Italian prosecutor today by spotting a wire leading to a bomb that would have exploded beneath his car as he opened the door, the police said. The attempt to kill the prosecutor, Mario Bochicchio, wasbelieved related to the scheduled trial of a neo-Fascist accused of killin a Communist.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1979

title: New, Simple Technique Permits Quick Photos of Live Plankton
description: A PHOTOGRAPHIC technique so simple that it does not even require a lens has given scientists a new, rapid way of gauging the ebb and flow of microscopic life in the sea.

title: Deaths
description: SCHARFAnneBeloved wife of Philip. Adored mother of Frank and Sydney Spire. Dear sister of Harry Seiden and adored grandmother. Services, Thursday, 10AM at Schwartz Brothers Forest Park Chapels, Queens Blvd, and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Aides to Bush Served Both Ford and Reagan In the 1976 Campaign
description: George Bush, the former Director of Central Intelligence who is seeking the 1980 Republican Presidential nomination, will have a top campaign staff drawn from the competing Republican campaigns of 1976.

title: Marijuana Dropped From Plane Is Sought on South Texas Plains
description: COTULLA, Tex., Feb. 19 (AP)  Law officers are searching a 120mile stretch of the southern Texas plains for what is left of an estimated 5,000 pounds of highgrade marijuana dumped from an airplane.

title: Union at A.M.C. Plant Agrees to Rule Changes
