description: DETROIT, Feb. 19  The American Motors Corporation and its 8,000 automobile workers in Kenosha, Wis., have reached an agreement on new work rules that the company said would facilitate a major expansion of its Jeep production there.

title: Science Watch
description: The 13 member countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a United Nations agency, have announced plans to develop a threeyear program aimed at controlling the trade and use of chemicals among the member countries.

title: REMARKS BY MEANY SNAG CARTER TRUCE
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 19  Any political truce between organized labor and President Carter crumbled a bit today as George Meany showed open contempt for the Administration's domestic and foreign policies.

title: Saudi Blacklist Pared
description: Jidda, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 19 (Reuters)  More than 150 American and European companies have been taken off Saudi Arabia's blacklist, it has been announced. The statement did not say whether the companies, presumably blacklisted for dealing with Israel, had severed business relations with the Jewish state. The measure included companies from Scotland, Northern Ireland, Holland and the United States.

title: Invasion Is Expected to Complicate Approval of U.S. Links to Taiwan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  China's invasion of Vietnam has sharply increased the Carter Administration's problems in obtaining Congressional approval of its new relationship with Taiwan, senior Administration officials said today.

title: OBSERVER
description: Morgue photographs of the Shah's generals remind us again that tough guys may also finish last. Though exiled in somewhat wanner circumstances, the Shah himself has finished well out of the money despite considerable toughness.

title: China Bans Comment On Vietnam Fighting
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 20 (UPI) China banned all demonstrations, public gatherings and wall posters by citizens concerning the war with Vietnam, Japan's Kyodo News Service reported today from Peking.

title: President Elected in Transkei
description: UMTATA, Transkei, Feb. 19 (Reuters)  Chief Kaiser Matanzima was elected President of Transkei today. Chief Matanzima, who has been Prime Minister of the black homeland since it was declared independent by South Africa in 1976, is expected to be succeeded in that post by his brother George.

title: Eclipse May Help Tame Fusion Energy
description: WHILE millions of North American residents watch spellbound next Monday as the sun is blacked out over parts of the continent, scientists hope new eclipse observations will shed light not only on the furnace that powers our star but also on how to harness fusion energy here on earth.

title: About Education
description: THE revolution in Iran has thrown thousands of Iranian students in the United States into a state acute financial crisis. At the same time, their plight has raised serious Questions about the practices some American schools in enticing foreign students to their campuses. The situation, it is feared, may have farreaching effects on foreignstudent affairs.

title: Army Is Paralyzed by Dissent
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 19  Iran's armed forces, once a potent military power, have been paralyzed by dissent and a breakdown in discipline.

title: Duke of Westminster, the Head Of Landholding Family, Is Dead
description: LONDON, Feb. 19  Robert George Grosvenor, fifth Duke of Westminster and head of one of Britain's richest families, died today at his country estate near Enniskillen in Northern Ireland. He was 68 years old.

title: Forests For The Poor
description: WASHINGTON  Meeting the basic needs of the world's poor has become the overriding concern of the internationaldevelopment establishment. Most writings on the topic, however, have been flawed by an analytical blind spot: The fundamental importance of forests to human wellbeing has generally been ignored. Yet, because of the spread of agriculture, firewoodgathering and irresponsible logging, forests are receding throughout most of Africa, Asia and Latin America. Some forested areas are replaced by farms but many degenerate into unproductive wastelands.

title: Track Mushy, Sales Mixed As Life Slithers On in Snow
description: A determined party of United States marines digging out three private vans on West 41st Street during yesterday's snowstorm found themselves in the in- defensible position of having to return to Camp Lejeune, N.C., 576 miles south or Manhattan, before formation this morning.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P?? ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH?? FRIDAY NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516)7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516)6691800; CONNECTICUT (203)3487767.

title: Effect of Gas Spill Held Limited
description: NARRAGANSETT, R.I., Feb. 19 (AP)  A gasoline spill off Watch Hill last year killed a large number of fish eggs, but apparently had no longlasting effect on the fish population, according to a report being drafted by the National Marine Fisheries Service. An estimated 685,000 gallons of gasoline were spilled last March 16 when a barge went aground.

title: Biggest Saving Banks Listed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI)  A Los Angeles savings and loan association was the country's largest thrift institution in 1978 for the 24th consecutive year, the U.S. League of Savings As sociations announced.

title: Smoker Hopes Trip Won't Go Up in Smoke
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 19  The 50 or so ninth graders in the thirdperiod health sciences class at Scarborough Junior High School here were trying hard to keep their minds off the approaching lunch hour and on the antismoking film they were being shown when the nation's premier nonsmoker, Joseph A. Califano Jr., burst through the door of their classroom.

title: Deaths
description: BLONDER  Jesse. Of Tenafly. N.J. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Devoted father of Barbara Kopp and Laurie Levy and fatherinlaw of Larry Kopp and Michael Levy. Loving brother of Gail Grossman. Adored grandfather of Daniel and Sharon Kopp and Joshua levy. Services will be held at Temple Sinai, I Engle St., Tenafly, N.J. on Wednesday, February 21st at 10AM. (Note change of day and time). Should friends desire. contributions may be made to their favorite charity. For further information, please call GuttermanMusicantKreitzman, 2014893800.

title: F.T.C. Orders a Revised Warning For Labels on a Clorox Cleanser
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP)  The Clorox Company must put a warning on labels of its cleanser, Soft Scrub, that the product might cause scratching of surfaces, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

title: Sanchez Squash Victor
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 19 (UPI) Mario Sanchez of Mexico, the topseeded player, defeated Torn Page of Philadelphia, 1512, 157, 1512, today to win the United States squash racquets championship.

title: Commodities
description: A QUIET revolution is sweeping the wheat trade. It will eventually have a profound impact on the diet and pocketbooks of consumers as well as the markets for wheat. Flour millers are demanding wheat of much higher protein content from farmers

title: Works of 2 German Composers Rely on Spoken Song, Breathing
description: NOT every composer would think it possible to set the glum ironies of Samuel Beckett to music. And not every composer would imagine that music could be constructed out of nothing more than the amplified breathing noises of three performers. But those two unlikely ideas were the foundations on which a double bill of musictheater pieces rested Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. The works, which are being presented by the Goethe Institutes of North America on a national tour, were Wolfgang Fortner's That Time and Dieter Schnebel's Atemzge.

title: Cult Follower Pleads Not Guilty to Slaying
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Feb. 19 (UPI)  Larry Layton, a member of the People's Temple, pleaded not guilty today to charges of murdering Representative Leo J. Ryan and four other people who died in an .ambush at the Port Kaituma airstrip three months ago.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Market Place
description: THERE is an old rule in Wall Street that no one ever went broke taking a profit. And that may well be true in stocks where price changes are relatively eeee

title: Brian Taylor Back From N B.A. Exile
description: Brim Taylor played his first National Basketball Association game in more than a year Thursday night against the New Orleans Jazz. Wearing No. 14  the same uniform number he wore for Perth Amboy (N.J.) High School, Princeton, the New York Nets, the Kansas City Kings and the Denver Nuggets  Taylor was in the backcourt for the San Diego Clippers.

title: At the Root of Roots
description: The fact that Roots: The Next Generations is attracting millions of television viewers this week cannot be shrugged off as just another exploitation of a prior success, although it surely is that. About 130 million people watched ABC at least once during the dramatization of Alex Haley's best seller in 1977. The sequel, which carries the saga of Kunte Kinte's descendants through the 1960's, has been endowed with the best that the providers of popular entertainment can offer  big names, skillful production, heavy promotion. But none of that altogether explains the mass appeal of this tale of the black odyssey in America.

title: Justice Brownstein's Son Killed As Fire Sweeps Inn in Vermont
description: The 16yearold son of New York State Supreme Court Justice Irwin R. Brownstein of Brooklyn was killed early yesterday when fire swept through an inn in Salisbury, Vt., where the youth had been staying with friends on a ski weekend.

title: Notes on People
description: It is always nice to be honored for one's work, but Franois Truffaut was a little apprehensive nonetheless. On Sunday, the director was at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, where the American Film Institute opened the first full retrospective ever held of his films. I feel a little older because of it, the 47yearold Mr. Truffaut said. I wonder if one's first retrospective isn't comparable to one's first surgical operation.

title: Air Rhodesia Defies Rebel Missile Threat
description: SALISBURY. Rhodesia, Feb. 19  When Air Rhodesia's flight 827 from the resort town of Kariba landed here at 3:15 P.M. yesterday, 52 passengers erupted into three cheers for Capt. Donald Newton and his crew.

title: Books of The Times
description: DEFENDING MY ENEMY. American Nazis, the Skokie Case and the Risks of Freedom. By Aryeh Neter. 182 pages. Dutton. $9.95.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Then China, already angry because Vietnam was forcing ethnic Chinese to return to China, invaded Vietnam in support of its ally, the reprehensible Pot Pot Government in Cambodia.

title: Disaster Tolls Needlessly High, Conference on Climate Is Told
description: GENEVA, Feb. 19  Every year 250,000 inhabitants of the earth, 95 per cent of whom are in poorer nations, die in natural disasters that cause $25 billion in property damage, most of which is in developed countries. It is estimated that 85 per cent of the deaths and half the damage could be prevented with existing knowhow.

title: Australia Exploits Edge in Aluminum
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 19 Cheap and abundant electric power and huge deposits of bauxite have given Australia a competitive edge in the current expansion of the world's aluminum capacity.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: 13 LittleKnown Venereal Diseases Reported Becoming Major Threat
description: I ATLANTA, Feb. 19 (AP).  Three littleknown venereal diseases that often go unreported by public health agencies are becoming a major health problem, the national Center for Disease Control warned today. One of the diseases causes sterility in women.

title: Bridge:
description: A rare result provided the climax to the Greater New York Bridge Association's championships at the New York Hilton Hotel Sunday. The Swiss team championship, with an entry. of 60 teams, ended in an exact tie on victory points, something that has not occurred in New York City for many years.

title: Carter, at Camp David, Takes a Trip and a Fall
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) President Carter learned the difficulties of skiing unfamiliar paths this weekend, suffering a scrape on hi forehead in a fall.

title: Recital: Leonard Rose Performs Six Works From Cello Repertory
description: THERE were no surprises on Leonard Rose's program Saturday night at the 92d Street Young Men'sYoung Women's Hebrew Association. Mr. Rose permitted himself the luxury of playing six standard works from the cello repertory, and he gave them all the benefit of his familiar technical expertise and thoughtful musicianship.

title: Around the Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 (UPI) The dissident group Move, which had gunfight with the police in which a policeman was killed, apparently has resurfaced in a house not far from the one where it holed up for months before the police raid last August.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: LONDON, Feb. 19 (AP)  The dollar gained slightly on most world money markets today, surprising many dealers with its firmness despite fighting in Indochina and an unsettled international situation that normally, would have forced the currency lower. Gold prices rose.

title: Charles Moore Dancers Perform African Works
description: CHARLES MOORE, now teacher at Clark Center, had a long performing career on Broadway and with the ethnic dance companies of Katherine Dunham and Pearl Primus. The 10 dances presented Sunday afternoon at the Theater of the Riverside Church by his Charles Moore Dances and Drums of Africa showed that ethnic influence in their African. and Caribbean inspiration and the influence of the legitimate theater in the very professional look of the costuming and producion.

title: BANGLADESH VOTERS SUPPORT PRESIDENT
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Feb. 19  The Bangladesh Nationalist Party of President Ziaur Rahman won a twothirds majority in parliamentary elections yesterday aimed at restoring democracy.

title: Key Fund Sale Tool: TollFree Phone Call
description: BOSTON  These days the best mutualfund salesman is the telephone company.

title: A Women's Bank in Abu Dhabi
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, (AP)  No man can put his money into the bank on Bin Zayed Street, and a police guard will stop him if he tries. The small bank on the edge of this Moslem sheikdom is for women only, and in this Arabian Gulf oil state their accounts can run to a million dollars and more.

title: Syracuse Five's Success Reminder of '74'75 Team
description: Syracuse University, with one of the bestbalanced teams in the nation, appears headed for its seventh consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

title: For Some Suburban Families, City Living Has Become Alluring
description: The first baby is born or perhaps the second, and suddenly the apartment seems cramped, the air stale, the park too far and the number of prospective playmates insufficient. So parents migrate, by the thousands, to the suburbs, and, if they follow many of their predecessors, they will return to live in the city only when the children go off to college.

title: Rutgers Paper Stops Publishing
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 20 (UPI)  The Rutgers University student newspaper, The Targum, suspended publication today in a dispute over salaries for its editors, who traditionally work more than 40 hours a week without pay. The editor, Greg Sedlacek, a senior from New Milford, said publication could resume only if the paper were published independently of the university or if Rutgers agreed to a method of paying the editors. The Targum is seeking honorariums of $5,100 a year for its 12 editors.

title: Egypt and Israel to Meet Today At Camp David to Reopen Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI)  Representatives of Egypt and Israel returned to Camp David today in an attempt to complete the peace process set in motion last fall at the Presidential retreat.

title: Firestone Registers Profit Rise
description: AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 20 (AP)  The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company reported today that its firstquarter earnings were $39.8 million, or 60 cents a share, which was up from $7.9 million, or 13 cents a share, for the same period a year ago.

title: A Green Light for School Bus Bids
description: Every school day, New York City's Board of Education buses 132,000 pupils under contracts that have been renewed for eight consecutive years without public bidding. When Chancellor Macchiarola, with the support of Mayor Koch, recently sent out invitations for bids, he was greeted by a wildcat drivers strike. But if the Chancellor perseveres, as he should, he can save the school system as much as $10 million a year.

title: Stage: Irish Import, `Says I, Says He
description: IT is a Belfast Pub: distempered walls, scaffolding; mustiness and all. Three musicians in cloth caps saw away at folk tunes with an air of soured mockery. The drinkers drink and talk.

title: Market Place
description: THE Financial Accounting Standards Board, which has been restructuring the nation's accounting rules with dramatic effect. may soon make revisions that will make most corporate treasurers happy.

title: Concert: Ormandy Conducts the Creation
description: THE premiere of Haydn's The Creation was one of the major musical events of the 18th century, and soon after it was given in Vienna in 1798, cultural historians tell us. Europe was at his feet. Listening with a third ear to last night's performance of the oratorio by the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, one sometimes could deduce reasons for that flabbergasting success. Sometimes, that is, but not nearly so consistently as an admirer of the score would have wished.

title: Mobil Aids BulletVest Fund
description: Samuel DeMilia, the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, said that Mobil Oil had donated $50,000 to the union's campaign to provide police officers with bulletproof vests. Mobil's donation, he said, brought to $500,000 the amount raised in the campaign, which has a goal of $1.5 million.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: ONE of the most formidable tasks in French cooking is the preparation of pastry. There is a great deal of precision and delicacy required in the making of croissants, or a pate en crane or the patty shells called vol-au-vent. And good rolling pin is essential.

title: Washington, Helped by Farmers And Shovelers, Nearing Normal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  The nation's capital began to shake itself free of its heaviest snowfall since 1922 as all three airports reopened and cars began to trickle through the main streets, cleared by plows and 40degree temperatures.

title: The Charge of the Right Brigade
description: Ronald Reagan wonders if the symbol of the United States pretty soon isn't going to be an ambassador with a flag under his arm climbing into the escape helicopter. He joins the thought to a previous impression that during Jimmy Carter's State of the Union speech he heard the sorry tapping of Neville Chamberlain's umbrella on the cobblestones of Munich.

title: The Kingdom and the World: 1 Saudi Life: An Anvil
description: In the crucial newly rich oil country of Saudi Arabia, the basic threat to stability, rational development and fruitful international relations is superheated change.

title: Issues in School Unions Dispute
description: Parties: School and Library Employees Union 74 of the Service Employees International Union: Local 94 of the International Union of Operating Engineers; Local 891 of the International Union of Operating Engineers; the Board of Education. and the city.

title: Talks to Resume Today in Strike Of 37 Days by St. Louis Teachers
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 20 (AP)  The two sides in the 37-day-old strike by St. Louis. teachers agreed today to return to the bargaining table, a Federal mediator said.

title: Conference Is Told of Advances in Research and Therapy That Alleviate Chronic Pain
description: BETHESDA, Md., Feb. 20  For 10 years she had been in agony, suffering chronic and acute abdominal pain. By the time she was referred to the Pain Clinic at University Hospital in Seattle, the 54yearold matron had been treated by seven doctors and had undergone three fruitless operations.

title: OCCASIONAL LOOTING PLAGUES BALTIMORE
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 20  Scattered reports of looting continued today, and Mayor William D. Schaefer imposed a second allnight curfew to keep people off the streets.

title: Board Meeting Postponed
description: The American ReInsurance Company said that a meeting of its board of directors, scheduled for yesterday to consider an acquisition proposal of the Lincoln National Corporation, has been postponed until tomorrow because of Monday's heavy snowfall. The acquisition proposal, announced recently, is valued at about $295 million.

title: 6 Men and a Woman, All Slaying Victims, Found in Apartment
description: Seven persons were found slain in a Harlem apartment last night, according to the police, who said that the victims, six men and a woman, had all been slashed in the throat with a 13inch knife and that five of them had also been shot.police said the bodies were discovered when the building's landlord, Jos Crispin, and a woman friend, came from Brooklyn to visit Mr. Crispin's brother, Renato, who had been living in the apartment.

title: Back to Baseball's Bargaining Table
description: Baseball's basic aireement expires next Dec. 31. This the contract governing all employeremployee relations except for the pension plan, which expires March 31, 1980. The forthcoming season, then, will be the last under existing agreements.

title: Fed Plans A Policy Of Restraint
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP)  The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board said today that the institution would use restraint in its moneyman agement policies this year to relieve inflationary pressures while avoiding recession.

title: William H. Zinsser, 91, Is Dead; Headed ShellacImport Concern
description: William H. Zinsser, former president of William Zinsser & Company, the oldest importer, processor and seller of unbleached shellac in the United States, died at his home in Manhattan yesterday, after a brief illness. He was 91 years old and lived at 580 Park Avenue.

title: Bridge:
description: Measured in terms of instructional value and readability, the top bridge book of 1978 was certainly The Finer Arts of Bridge by Victor Mollo, published by Faber and Faber. Unfortunately, it was also the toppriced bridge book of the year, listing, thanks to British inflation, at $12.95 for 190 pages. It is available for $12 from The Bridge World, 39 West 99th Street, New York, N.Y. 10025.

title: Dance: Opening Bill By Harlem Theater
description: THE DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM opened a twoweek season last night at the City Center55th Street Theater. This is not quite the ordinary statement it appears, and, in many ways, the evening was an event of some rather special emotional implications.

title: Editor of Herald Tribune in Paris Is Named
description: The appointment of Mort Rosenblum as editor of The International Herald Tribune was announced yesterday by Walter N. Thayer, chairman of the Parisbased newspaper.

title: Insurance Mart Rules At Issue
description: ALBANY, Feb. 20  Leaders of the New York State Assembly, in an effort to breathe life into the state's new insurance exchange whose rules were dismantled by the Senate last week, introduced legislation today calling for two of three Senatesponsored amendments to the proposed constitution and bylaws. But they refused to accept a third amendment.

title: 3 Fined for Daytona 500 Incident
description: Three Grand National stock car drivers  Bobby and Donnie Allison and Cale Yarborough  were fined 56,000 each yesterday for a lastlap crash and fist fight that marred Sunday's Daytona 500mile auto race.

title: Senate in Jersey Votes 20 Million In New City Aid
description: TRENTON, Feb. 20  The New Jersey Senate, under heavy pressure from Governor Byrne, late today passed a bill appropriating an extra S20 million in state aid to cities.

title: Sandy Faison, Actress, Is Wed
description: Sandra Faison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Faison of Brooklyn Heights was married there on Monday in the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims (Congregational) to Robert Lee Brush Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brush of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Harry Kruener performed the ceremony. The bride, an actress known as Sandy Faison, originated the role of Grace Farrell in the musical Annie. Mr. Brush is a composer and writer.

title: The Perils of Dissent
description: The annual reviews by the State Department and Amnesty International of the condition of human rights around the world are not typically bundles of cheer, and the editions for 1978, the 30th year of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, run true to form.

title: Wounded U.S. Marine Held in Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  The State Department said today that a United States Marine wounded in an attack on the American Embassy in Teheran last week had been abducted from a Teheran hospital and was being held by the Revolutionary Committee of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: 3 New Radio Announcers Chosen for Jets Games
description: The New York Jets will have three new radio announcers when they switch to CBS from WOR next season. Ed Ingles will act as host on the threeman team, while Spencer Ross will do the play-by-play and Sam DeLuca, a former Jet, the color commentary.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Fundamental changes in bank regulation were proposed by the Treasury Department. The changes would reduce discrimination against small savers and enable banking institutions to compete more vigorously for customer deposits. The proposals are in a report being considered by an interagency study group known as the Regulation Q Task Force. But the Treasury did not call for the elimination of Regulation Q, which deals with the interest rates that thrift institutions can offer on deposits. [Page D1.]

title: Canadian Inflation Up
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 20 (Reuters) Higher food prices in January lifted the cost of living to an annual rate of 8.9 percent from 8.4 percent in December, Statistics Canada reported today. Food prices rose nearly four times as much as other consumer prices.

title: Texas Airline to Match Rival $50 Bid for National
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 20 (AP)  Texas International Airlines today renewed its bid for control of National Airlines with an offer that it said would be worth at least S50 a share to Nationa, stockholders.

title: SLAIN U.S. DIPLOMAT BURIED IN VIRGINIA
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) Adolph Dubs, the slain American Ambassador to Afghanistan, was praised today as a superb example of the best traditions of the Foreign Service and buried in Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Sorry, No Credit
description: BOSTON  Appearing before the Federal Trade Commission in Washington, Bloomingdale's departmentstore chain agrees to pay $50,000 in civil penalties for alleged sex discrimination against women in its evaluation of credit applications; in San Francisco, a Federal judge denies Standard Oil of California's request for dismissal of a suit brought up a woman who alleges denial of credit on the basis of sex and maritalstatus discrimination; Montgomery Ward faces credit lawsuits in Delaware and North Carolina. Despite passage of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act in 1974 and its amendments in 1976, the National Consumer Finance Association was told recently that new investigative hearings on consumer credit might be in the offing. What's up?

title: Private Lives
description: MONTHS go by, of course, when nothing happens about which it is possible to be affirmative, or even bittersweet. Those are the breaks. Then the world opens its clenched fist, and there on the palm is a gumdrop or a jumping bean. Consider a week, a single week, which it was possible to be affirmative and bittersweet twice, as if Walt Disney weren't dead.

title: Food Stores Without The Frills
description: LIKE supermarket shoppers throughout the country, consumers in Gainesville, Fla., have come to expect certain amenities with their weekly visit to the grocery store. Soft lights, wide, clean aisles, pipedin music, clerks to bag and carry their purchases to the car all serve to soften the blow of the ever-rising food bill.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petition Filed by:

title: Town Officials Given Reassurance by Regan On CostMandate Cut
description: New York State's Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, told town officials yesterday that Albany bore a large share of the responsibility for their high costs of government  and consequently high taxes  and that he believed the administration of Governor Carey would move to reduce expenditures mandated upon the localities.

title: Right-to-Work Measure Is Vetoed in New Mexico
description: SANTA FE, N.M., Feb. 20  Gov. Bruce King vetoed a right-to-work bill today, saying he was convinced that the measure will not help the people of this state, especially our working men and women.

title: Was It a Punch Or Just a Push?
description: LONDON, Feb. 20 (AP) Charlie Magri, British flyweight boxing champion, scored a disputed knockout in the third round against Mike Stuart of Los Angeles at Royal Albert Hall tonight.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS McCarthyism
description: MADISON, Wis.  Propped up by cane, the tall, 73-year-old president of China's Nanking University, Kuang Yaming, this week welcomed Irving Shain, Chancellor of the University of Wisconsin, and a 14member delegation from the university. Mr. Kuang has been out of jail less than two year;. He was imprisoned in 1966 and even kept from seeing his family for the next decade. In prison, he taught himself English by reading Karl Marx. His alleged crime: Taking the capitalist road. The proof: a quest for educational excellence expressed once as overtaking Moscow University.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Dollar copper became the rallying cry of bullish traders on the Comex in New York yesterday as both cash and futures prices for the vital industrial metal soared to record levels.

title: Chess:
description: SAO PAULO, Feb. 15  The sixthround battle between the leaders of the SAo Paulo International Tournament, Ulf Andersson of Sweden and Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland, shaped up as

title: LAW ON AIR QUALITY DEBATED ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20  The Clean Air Act was passed in 1970 and revised in 1977 after more than two years of Congressional discussion. But debate over its virtues and shortcomings continues unabated.

title: The Market For Uranium
description: The price for uranium began sharp climb five years ago, rising from less than $7 a pound to almost $44 currently and setting off a spate of exploration activity.

title: Manhattan Is Met Track Victor
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 20  Rutgers and Manhattan staged a back-andforth struggle for the team title in an exciting Metropolitan Intercollegiate indoor track and field championship meet in Jadwin Gym tonight. The Jaspers edged Rutgers for the crown, 64 to 58.

title: Text of Speech by President Carter at Georgia Tech
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 20 (UPI)  Following is the text of President Carter's address today at Georgia Institute of Technology:

title: Some New Cookbooks That Deserve a Try
description: BECAUSE autumn has proved to be the best season in which to sell books on food and cooking, publishers generally try to introduce new works during that preChristmas season. As a result, a deluge of books comes out at once, and too often a few good ones by newcomers either pass unnoticed in the shuffle or are overshadowed by the books of bigname authors. A few such worthy offerings follow.

title: Dividends Raised At Sears, Du Pont
description: Two of the nation's largest corporations have increased their quarterly common stock dividends.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 20 (UPI) Steve Cauthen is going to Britain to ride at the conclusion of the Arcadia track's 78day season on April 8.

title: F.B.I. Head's First Year in Post: Pitfalls Survived, Gains Recorded
description: Paul S. Conklin

title: U.S. Survey Team Going To Egypt on Arms Needs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  The United States is preparing to send a survey team to Egypt in the next six to eight weeks to assess requests by President Anwar elSadat for billions of dollars worth of American arms, Defense Department officials said tonight.

title: Master Charge Dropped By Chase Manhattan
description: The Chase Manhat tan Bank, blaming policies adopted by former Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz of New York State, has decided to stop issuing Master Charge credit cards.

title: A Correction
description: In an article on decaffeinated coffee that appeared in The Living Section Feb. 7, it was stated that Zabar's, 2245 Broadway, roasts its own coffee at Hena Inc. 383 Third Avenue, Brooklyn. The company is owned by Larry Tauber. The roasting is done at Harry Wolfe & Sons, a separate company at the same address owned by Mr. Tauber's father, Leonard. In the same article, it should also have been stated that all decaffeinated coffees tested were said to be from 97 to 99 percent caffeinfree.

title: Books of The Tirnes
description: INCANDESCENCE couldn't be more aptly titled; glows with brilliance, flashes with inventiveness and verbal energy, on every page re, veals itself as the work of a truly pyrotechnical writer. For me. Craig Nova is INCANDESCENCE. By Crate Nova 312 pages. Harper & Row. $9.95. already one of the true descendants of Celine. That is an advance comment from John Hawkes, author of Blood Oranges and other highly regarded novels.

title: Knicks Drop 7th in Row, 117107
description: The Knicks losing streak grew to seven games last night as they lost to the Phoenix Suns, 117107, at Madison Square Garden with Coach Red Holzman watching the defeat on television.

title: Des Moines Steel Offer
description: The Des Moines Steel Company announced yesterday that its board of directors had approved making an offer to purchase up to 200,000 shares of its outstanding common stock from its shareholders at 532.50 a share. with an option to buy additional shares if they were tendered. The company said it intended to make the actual offer not later than March 1. The offer would expire about three weeks after it was formally made unless extended by the company.

title: Cabaret: Nico Is Back
description: IT was a genuine, galeforce blast from the past Monday night at CBGB's when Nico gave her first New York performance in years. Born in Germany around 1940. Nico was an actress, model and aspiring singer when she arrived in London in 1965 and New York a year later. She quickly became a key member of Andy Warhol's Factory, starred in his Chelsea Girls film and collaborated with the Velvet Underground, the pioneering art-punk-rock band led by Lou Reed and John Cale. She ultimately made four solo albums, the last three produced by Mr. Cale.

title: Energy Issues Lead Stock Market Gain
description: Energyrelated and bluechip stocks led the market higher yesterday as investors displayed calm in their initial response to the Chinese invasion of Vietnam over the weekend.

title: Best Buys
description: WHEN a live, choice steer sells for about 42 cents pound, consumers often ask why they are paying $1.80 for a pound of ground chuck or close to $2.70 for a pound of sirloin.

title: Economic Scene
description: FROM California to New Hampshire, Democratic politicians are voicing doubts that President Carter can be reelected in 1980. Unless there is a dramatic improvement in the nation's economy, they say, he may not even be able to hold onto his party's nomination in the face of challenges from his right flank and his left. The President has hoped to straddle the broad center by seeking to pusn down the rate of inflation without causing a recession. But he may wind up failing on both counts.

title: News of the Theater
description: IN an effort to squelch rumors that Michael Bennett's Ballroom is closing, Bernard Gersten, a coproducer, assembled the cast last night at the Majestic to reassure them that the musical will run. Earlier in the day, Mr. Gersten said in a telephone interview: If they ask me how long, I'll say, We intend to run as long as we can pay our bills. If they ask how long will that be, I'll say, It beats me.

title: Robbery Biggest Crime Under New Youth Law
description: A New York State report indicates that 80 percent of the 596 youths charged under the state's Juvenile Offender Law were accused of robbery.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: H. Ross Perot, the Texarkana, Tex., cotton broker's son who dazzled Wall Street and intervened for prisoners in Vietnam some years ago, has been out of the news in recent years. Over the holiday weekend, however, he returned to public attention when he disclosed that he financed the Feb. 11 mob assault on an Iranian prison that freed thousands of inmates, including two of his employees.

title: New Battle in Rhodesia Is for the Votes of the Blacks
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 20  On television, in commercial breaks between segments of a 20-year-old soap opera, a deep African voice intones a refrain on which the future of this embattled nation could depend.

title: Survey Indicating Whites Favor Affirmative Action Is Questioned
description: Four civil rights leaders expressed doubts yesterday about a recent survey by Louis Harris and Associates that said most whites approved of affirmative action programs for blacks now that the Supreme Court's Bakke decision had ruled out racial quota systems.

title: U.S. May Request Debate at U.N. On Asian Fighting If Others Delay
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 20 The United States is prepared to call for a Security Council session on the Indochina crisis on its own if other countries continue to hesitate, diplomats said here today.

title: Javits Says President Doubts Public Support During Foreign Crises
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  Senator Jacob K. Javits said tonight that he believes the Carter Administration is troubled by a gnawing fear that the country will not back it if it gets into a posture involving risks in foreign policy.

title: Soviet Contends U.S. Knew Peking's Intent And Remained Silent
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 20 (AP)  The Soviet Union said today that Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping had told the United States Government during his recent visit that China intended to attack Vietnam, and the Americans had given the green light by not objecting.

title: Around the Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 (UPI) Federal officials granted a permit today for a Nazi rally Sunday at Independence National Historical Park, but Mayor Frank L. Rizzo and survivors of the Holocaust immediately went to court in an attempt to block the rally.

title: Compromise on Taiwan Security Reported Imminent in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  The Carter Administration was reported close to an agreement with key Congressional leaders today on legislation that will describe any attack on Taiwan as a matter of grave concern to the United States that could lead to appropriate action by this country.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Mapco Inc., an Integrated energy company, announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire ChemNuclear Systems Inc. The agreement calls for Mapco to exchange threefourths of a common share for each of the 2.1 million ChemNuclear shares outstanding. The transaction is valued at about $47 million.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: As bond prices moved skittishly lower yesterday, an issue of tripleA electric power company bonds was priced to yield 9.57 percent  the highest for such securities since October, 1974.

title: Bache Firm Shows Rise In Earnings
description: Bache Group Inc., the parent corn. pany of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., said yesterday that its earnings in the quarter that ended Jan. 31 climbed to $879,000 on revenues of $90 million, as against $191,000 on revenues of $75.1 million in the same quarter a year ago.

title: Steel Output Down in Week
description: Steel production fell 1.7 percent last week to 2.61 million tons from the previous week's 2.65 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: The Region
description: The Long Island Rail Road has asked its legal staff to determine whether trainmen were within their rights in adding new demands in their contract. If the railroad's contention that the United Transportation Union is out of line is upheld, a spokesman said, a court order will be sought to bar strike threatened for 4 A.M. Friday. Otherwise, the L.I.R.R. will consider the new demands, according to spokesman for the carrier.

title: Judge Rejects Request to Forbid HighRise Buildings Near Capital
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Feh. 20 (AP) The construction of four highrise buildings across the Potomac River from the District of Columbia would not visually intrude on the Washington Monument and other memorials in the nation's capital, a Federal district judge ruled in an opinion released today.

title: Tommy John Goes Right to Work at Yankee Camp
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 20  Tommy John didn't waste any time getting down to work for the Yankees today as New York's regular pitchers and catchers began spring training.

title: Justice Orders a Redoubled Effort To End SchoolBus Drivers
description: A State Supreme Court justice ordered redoubled efforts yesterday to make 2,000 defiant schoolbus drivers return to their job of carrying 130,000 students, many of them handicapped, to their public schools.

title: $150 Million Notes Offering By City Is Sold Out at 7.5%
description: A $150 million offering of New York City notes, marking the second time the city has entered the public credit market this year after a fouryear absence, was sold out yesterday almost as soon as underwriters set a 7.5 percent interest rate on the notes.

title: Radio
description: 74 A.M., WNCN. Concerto for Harpsichords in A minor, Bach; Quattro Rusteghi, Prelude, WolfFerrari; Concerti a Cinque, for Oboes, Albinoni.

title: Snow Turns to Slush, Causing Some Minor Floods
description: Temperatures in the metropolitan region reached an unseasonably high of 41 degrees yesterday, starting a transformation of Monday's heavy snowfall into slush and water that made life messy for many pedestrians and caused minor flooding in some lowlying areas.

title: James E. Magner, 80 Years Old; Retired Executive of Grace Line
description: James E. Magner, a retired executive vice president of Grace Line, died Monday in Rye, N.Y. He was 80 years old.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar turned in a mixed day on money markets at home and abroad yesterday as slightly more optimistic news about the American economy and from Iran balanced reports that the Swiss authorities plan to strengthen the already strong franc.

title: World News Briefs
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 20 (AP)  Three Americans are being held in the Maldive Islands in connection with the shooting of a local official aboard their survey ship, the United States Embassy in Colombo, Sri Lanka, reported today.

title: The City
description: A strike of 1,700 heating and airconditioning engineers in more than 200 office skyscrapers in Manhattan ended late yesterday, the 39th day of the walkout.

title: Personal Health
description: THE most encouraging thing to be said about persistent bedwetting among children is that, no matter what is done about it, 97 to 98 percent eventually outgrow it. This means, of course, that 2 to 3 percent reach adulthood without having achieved nighttime bladder control.

title: Iranian Premier's Office Expresses Surprise Over 4 Latest Executions
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 20  Prime Minister Medhi Bazargan's office expressed surprise today at the announcement by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Revolutionary Committee that four more generals had been put to death and that more executions would follow.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SARAH ELIZABETH (Atlantic LinesChester, B'ecktvre Fly Porker. ) Tortola March 3, G,,alevx,oe St. Vincent 5, and Georgetown 9; sails from 23rd Street, Brooklyn.

title: Amtrak to Increase Fares by 10% On New YorkWashington Route
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP)  Amtrak announced today that it would raise fares on most of its routes on March 5 by an average of 6 percent and on the New YorkWashington corridor by 10 nercent.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Making Every Step Count Did you really jog three miles today? Five times around the block comes to how many miles? If you'd like to find out how much ground you're covering in your Adidas, then you should have a pedometer. Bendel's has a good-looking one that measures the distance you run in both miles and kilometers. You measure your pace, from heel to heel or toe to toe, set a dial for pace, then clip the pedometer to one side of your belt  the movement of your leg activates the measuring dial. You'll find the pedometer in the Bailey / Heubner shop for $20.

title: Quebec's Liberals Offer Alternative That Stops Short of Sovereignty
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 20  The Quebec Liberal Party, the principal group opposing independence for this French-speaking province, said today that Quebecers could get the powers they seek without breaking un Canada.

title: W.H.O.Proposes Broad Immunization Campaign
description: GENEVA, Feb. 20  By 1990, if the World Health Organization has its way, every child born will be immunized against six ailments that now take an estimated five million lives annually.

title: Kansas City Southern To Add Pioneer Western
description: Kansas City Southern Industries, holding company for the Kansas City Southern Railway, announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire all the shares of the Pioneer Western Corporation, a life insurance and financial services concern, for about $35 million in cash.

title: Burlington Northern Sees Coal Load Rise
description: Norman M. Lorentzsen, president and chief executive officer of Burlington Northern Inc., said the railroad expected to transport 78 million tons of coal this year, up 24 percent from the record 63 million tons carried last ear

title: Ticor Board Halts Talks on Merger
description: Ticor, a diversified financial-services company, disclosed that its board has decided that it would not be in the best interests of the company or its shareholders to go forward with the unsolicited merger proposed recently by the American General Insurance Company.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: IT is my belief that almost every chef in the world could express preference for the type of cooking he finds more gratifying than any other. The reasons why would be as varied as the dishes he admired as a child; the dishes which personally gratify his own appetite, the kind of cookery to which he was first subjected as a professional.

title: Sports Today
description: City University of New York tournament, at City Colleges Nat Holman Gymnasium, Convent Avenue and 137th Street. 1.3,6 and PM. (Radio  WNYC, 6 P.M.) Admission is free to all games.

title: Uranium Hunters Comb Saskatchewan
description: MIDWEST LAKE, Saskatchewan This is the peak season for uranium exploration in northern Saskatchewan as an international crowd of prospectors takes advantage of temporary roads of snow and ice to comb virtually every square kilometer of the area for undiscovered deposits.

title: Rebels Attack Salisbury Airport For 1st Time in Rhodesian War
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 20 (Reuters)  Black nationalist guerrillas attacked Salisbury International Airport last night for the first time in the sixyear war, but a communique said there were no casualties or damage.

title: New Orleans Loses All Parades For Mardi Gras in Police Strike
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 2D  Declaring that we are not going to let Mardi Gras be held hostage's by the teamsters union that represents this city's striking policemen, the sponsors of New Orleans Mardi Gras parades announced tonight that all remaining parades for the 1979 carnival had been canceled.

title: INCURSION BY CHINA PLACED AT 10 MILES AFTER NEW FIGHTING
description: HONG KONG, Wedneiday; Feb. 21 Renewed fighting between China's invading army and Vietnamese defenders was reported yesterday after earlier indications that the Chinese advance might have halted about six miles inside Vietnamese territory.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: AS a parent. writes Sophia Del Favero, one of the aspects of child rearing that enjoy most is sharing with my daughter my interest in books and reading. I also take this role very seriously.

title: Women's NIT. Is Suggested
description: A women's National Invitation Tournament in basketball may be started next year to go along with the annual men's N.I.T., which is the oldest major college postseason basketball tournament in.the nation.

title: Lake Placid Anxiously Looks Beyond Olympics
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 19  A year from today, the XIII Olympic Winter Games will be in full slide here. There is already more excitement than there has been since, well, since 1932 when Lake Placid hosted the III Winter Olympics.

title: Boy Survives Air Crash and Trek in Snow
description: UPLAND, Calif., Feb. 20 (AP)  An 11yearold boy with a broken hand trudged two miles to safety through waistdeep snow and ice after surviving a plane crash in the rugged San Gabriel Mountains.

title: Going Out Guide
description: PIPE DREAM A while back, homebound workers and residents venturing forth early for an evening on the town had the excellent Interlude diversions at Town Hall. Today, a new kind of lateafternoon tonic starts at Lincoln Center: organ music of the classical masters, played by experts. And it's no run-of-the-mill organ.

title: On Retirement, Meany, 84, Says He'll Be Considering it for Years
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 20 George Meany is thinking of retiring as president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations. He said so himself. He always says so himself.

title: Turner Jones, in Portland, Me.; Was CocaCola Bottling Official
description: PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 20  Turner Jones, retired president, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the CocaCola Bottling Company of South Portland, which has seven branches in Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont, and Mexico, died Saturday in a nursing home here. He was 81 years old.

title: Westinghouse Import Filing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  The Westinghouse Electric Corporation filed a complaint with the United States International Trade Commission today seeking to bar what was termed the unlawful importation of certain high-voltage circuit interrupters.

title: Adult Homes to Get $1 Million Allocation For Mental Treatment
description: Nearly $1 million will be spent on better care for people in New York City adult homes who have chronic mental problems, state officials said yesterday at City Council hearing into alleged abuses in the homes.

title: Khomeini, for Many, Embodies Ancient Persian Virtues
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 20  We are going to follow Khomeini up to the end, said a rug merchant in Teheran's great covered bazaar. Three large men beside him nodded in assent. The first man continued: He only eats one bowl of yogurt at noon and a little bit of potatoes in the afternoon. He is truly ascetic.

title: 2 or 3 Billion Cubic Feet To Revel or Commute In
description: The stuff was everywhere, runny in the sunshine and more slippery than it looked. Children burrowed in it and reveled in its perfect texture for forming good, hard snowballs and sturdy snowpersons. Cars skidded and got stuck in it. Many suburbanites shoveled it for the second day, clearing new ground, and public officials threw men and machines into the battle to move around in less paralyzing patterns.

title: $3.2 Million Fee To Law Firms In Rothko Case
description: Four New York City law firms will divide more than $3.2 million in legal fees for their work in the complicated, nineyearlong litigation over the $40 million estate of Mark Rothko, one of the 20th century's leading Abstract Expressionist artists, who killed himself in 1970.

title: Suspect in Murder Case Begins Trial for Divorce
description: FORT WORTH, Feb. 20 (UPI)  The divorce trial of T. Cullen and Priscilla Davis opened today with attorneys vowing to discuss only money and avoid the sensationalism that arose in the Texas industrialist's two trials for murder and plotting to kill a divorce court fudge.

title: Turning Nairobi Into a Center for Art
description: When Alan Donovan first came to Nairobi 10 years ago, he couldn't find African art that he wanted to buy at any price. Today, thanks largely to him, tourists in Nairobi have the opposite problem; they can find a great variety of African art  but the price sometimes out of reach.

title: Life Term in 2 Albany Murders
description: ALBANY, Feb. 20 (AP)  Lemuel Smith, who faces two trials on two other murder charges, was sentenced today to a maximum life term in the deaths of two persons in a downtown religious shop here in November 1976. Mr. Smith is already serving a prison sentence for the, kidnapping and robbery of a Schenectady secretary.

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDERAbraham 2118 Ma mi. Surviving wife Eva, son Law rence, daughter Hannah Levin grandchildren Miriam, David, Bar bare, Elizabeth Alexander, Marc. Nicole, Danielle, Juliet Levin.

title: Questions Persist on China's Military Goal
description: The sporadic fighting in five of Vietnam's northern provinces may reflect a familiar military predicament: the inability of an army to disengage forces in close combat with an enemy. But a Soviet

title: Palestinian Guerrillas Assail China for Vietnam Strike
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 20  Officials of the Palestine Liberation Organization have strongly criticized China for its invasion of Vietnam, apparently ending a friendly relationship that had lasted for 19 years.

title: 3d Man Is Seized In Airport Theft; Bail Is Set for 2
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation last night arrested a second man on charges of participating in the $5.8 million Lufthansa robbery at Kennedy International Airport on Dec. 11.

title: Applicants Wait to Join Carpenters Union
description: Some of the hundreds of applicants, many in line since Sunday, stoodoutside the New York City District Council of Carpenters at 140 East 26th Street yesterday. About 150 of the applicants were women. Union, expecting an upturn in local construction, is opening its rolls for the first time in four years. About 30 percent of journeymen carpenters are unemployed at present.

title: Real Estate
description: DUNFEY HOTELS, since 1977 subsidiary of Aer Lingus, the Irish airline, is not pleased to be known in this country merely as the franchise operator of a string of Sheraton motor inns in New England.

title: Colombian Oil Hunt Being Stepped Up
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 20 (Reuters)  Colombia is digging millions of years into the past in hopes of wiping out its growing bil deficit.

title: Court of Appeals Lifts Ban on OilLease Sale In Area Off Cape Cod
description: BOSTON. Feb. 20  An injunction that has blocked the sale of offshore oil and gas exploration leases on the Georges Bank for more than a year was lifted today by the United States Court of ApDeals for the First Circuit here.

title: Carter's Foreign Policy: A Middle Course
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  In spite of a recent volley of criticism from Republicans and some Democrats that his foreign policy leadership has been weak and indecisive, President Carter would not be pushed into tough language today to

title: Publisher Leaves Esquire Magazine
description: David M. O'Brasky, publisher of Esquire since July 1976, has left the magazine because, he said, of philosophical differences on the role of publisher and on promoting and marketing. Clay S. Felker, editor and chief executive, who will also assume the publisher's role, declined to comment on Mr. O'Brasky's reasons for leaving.

title: Chemical Protests Loan Delay
description: The Chemical Bank and Talley Industries yesterday asked a Federal court to grant an expedited hearing on their appeal to overturn an injunction issued Feb. 16 that bars Chemical for 90 days from financing a takeover of Washington Steel Corporation by subsidiary of Talley.

title: German Trade Surplus With U.S. Rose in 1978
description: BONN, Feb. 20  West Germany said today that its trade surplus last year with the United States doubled from 1977 to a preliminary 2.6 billion marks, the equivalent of about $1.4 billion.

title: Stilton, After 300 Years, Faces a Threat to Its Future
description: THE future of Stilton, the blueveined king of English cheeses, is threatened for the first time in its 300year history. A rich seam of coal, estimated at 500 million tons  the biggest recover-

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesleuley's Weather at 1 P. M. National Oceanic and Atmosphre Administration UPI

title: Careers
description: MOST new liberal arts graduates applying for work say: No, I can't type. I don't want a secretarial job. Making such a statement is not wise, according to Irene Cohen, who operates the Irene Cohen Personnel Agency in New York. She contends that the secretarial approach is an excellent dooropener to good management positions later.

title: Women Balking 3t Joining Army Surrender to the PoIice in israel
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 20  Four women who had balked at serving in the Israeli Army. because other women were exempted on religious grounds gave themselves up to the military police today.

title: Notes on People
description: At the WaldorfAstoria yesterday, Broadway chorus lines were set aside for a Took at bottom lines. The business of theater was the principal subject at luncheon of the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and Gerald Schoenfeld, board chairman of the Shubert Organization, held forth with statistics showing that Broadway last season generated $379 million for the metropolitan area's economy, and $1.138 billion nationwide.

title: EARNINGS
description: The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday reported a 46.6 percent rise in its fourthquarter profit and a 40 percent rise in its profit for all 1978. The Rochesterbased company cited higher sales and interest income.

title: One Fight Too Many
description: Kallie Knoetze is a South African boxer and former policeman eager to make himself  and apparently many others  rich. His admission to the United States has been bitterly opposed by civil rights groups because in November 1977 he shot and wounded a black youth for throwing rocks at his police car. The youth claimed that Knoetze refused even to give him water while he waited for help: he eventually lost a lee.

title: Dr. Anthony N. Domonokos, 66; Was a Professor of Dermatology
description: Dr. Anthony N. Domonkos, professor emeritus of dermatology at Columbia University's College of Physicans and Surgeons, died Monday at the Harkness Pavilion of the Presbyterian Hospital in the City of New York. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: China Coke Sale Limited
description: PEKING, Feb 20 (Reuters)  CocaCola has gone on sale in Peking but not to the general public. Several weeks after China's first consignment was shipped from Hong Kong, the beverage has turned up in the Peking Hotel, where it is sold for hard currency only, meaning that few Chinese will get a sip. The hotel's bar offers one can, or two bottles, for one American dollar, five French francs or five Hong Kong dollars. No other currencies are accepted.

title: Oklahoma Stalls Vote On Rights Amendment
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 20 (AP) The proposed equal rights amendment has been dealt a severe blow in the Oklahoma Legislature, with State Representative Dan Draper, the House Speaker, announcing that he would not push for ratification in this session.

title: News Summary
description: Renewed ChineseVietnamese fighting was reported after earlier indications that the Chinese advance might have halted about six miles inside Vietnam. Analysts in Hong Kong said they believed that Peking's forces had now penetrated about 10 miles into Vietnam in two major salients along rail lines. But it appeared the Chinese may again have halted. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Entertainment Events
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Mozart's Die Za ober floete, 8.

title: Howard Schenken, Leading Player In World Title Bridge, Dead at 75
description: Howard Schenken, whose recordsetting performances over half century made him one of history's best contract bridge players, died yesterday in Palm Springs, Calif., at the age of 75. He had been suffering from a brain tumor.

title: Alcoa Acts To Increase Production
description: The Aluminum Company of America, which has suspended taking new orders for ingot because demand has outrun supply, announced yesterday series of steps to increase output.

title: Advertising
description: THE Knickerbocker Toy Company, acquired by Warner Communications a few years ago, this year has made extensive additions to its line and is raising its $1 million advertising budget to a healthy $4.6 million, all of which is going to be spent for network and spot television. The agency since last July has been Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson.

title: Optimism on Fuel Efficiency
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  The President's Council on Environmental Quality asserted today that the United States can do well, indeed prosper, on much less energy than has been commonly supposed.

title: Corporations Report Quarterly Sales and Earnings Results
description: Profits Scoreboard

title: Arms Pact Defended by Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said today that a failure of the Senate to approve a SovietAmerican treaty limiting strategic arms would be a prescription for nuclear disaster.

title: PRESIDENT AFFIRMS ARMSTREATY POLICY
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 20  President Carter made clear here today that turbulence in Iran and Indochina would not generate any basic revision of United States policy, particularly the effort to reach accommodation with the Soviet Union on strategic arms limitations.

title: Plastic Lamps For Lincolns
description: DETROIT, Feb. 20 (AP)  An allplastic halogen car headlamp for use on some of Ford Motor Company's 1980model cars was announced today by General Electric.

title: Piano: Recital by Schub
description: EVEN in an era rich in superbly equipped young pianists, it is rare to encounter such a sizzling display of virtuosity as AndrMichel Schub put on Sunday afternoon at Hunter College. And it is rarer still to encounter such virtuosity in conjunction with as much musicianship and lyric fervor as Mr. Schub had to offer.

title: Avocado: Fruitful Quest
description: SANTA PAULA, CALIF. WHEN I hurried myself across the United States to this region in the heart of the avocado country, it was with the express mission of learning how avocados are grown, harvested and  more importantly  how separate the great ones, the champions, from the mediocre and ordinary.

title: Trichinosis Has Declined, But Experts Still Concerned
description: Although its incidence in the United States has declined dramatically in the past generation, trichinosis is still regarded by the Government's Communicable Disease Center as a troublesome problem, particularly in the Northeast.

title: E.T.A. Abducts Plant Manager
description: MADRID, Feb. 20 (UPI)  The Basque separatist group E.T.A. said today that it had kidnapped Luis Abaitua Palacios, the 47-year-old manager of a Michelin tire factory in Vitoria who disappeared yesterday. It said it would soon announce its conditions for his release. The apparent kidnapping was one of many terrorist acts apparently intended to disrupt the campaign leading up to general elections on March 1.

title: Flu? Maybe. Set? No.
description: PHILADELPHIA  Our country's readiness to deal with publichealth calamities is poor. This is especially alarming in light of the observation by Dr. Edwin Kilbourne of the Mount Sinai Medical School in New York City that, since the 1940's, influenza pandemics (worldwide epidemics) have occurred every 11 years; we had them in 1957 and 1968  will we have one in 1979?

title: Citicorp Note Rate Down
description: Citicorp sold $100 million of 91day auction notes yesterday at an average rate of 10.188 percent, down from 10.213 percent last week. The hank holding company received offers totaling $622.5 million, accepting rates ranging from 10.158 percent to 10.210 percent, including 11.7 percent at the high rate. Next Tuesday, Citicorp plans to auction $100 million of 92day notes.

title: Italian Radiologist Is Attacked
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, Feb. 20 (Reuters) A group of leftists chained Giovanni Ruggero, a brain radiologist, to a railing last night and accused him of enriching himself in private clinics. The police identified the four leftists as members of a group calling itself the Communist Territorial Unit. In a communique, the group said Professor Ruggero had spent little time working as head of a department in a Bologna hospital, but had concentrated on making money from private patients.

title: Bossy Carries On His Record Assault
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 20 Mike Bossy's goal in his eighth straight game Monday night put the Islander sophomore in a class by himself. Bossy's secondperiod tally, his 47th of the season, set a National Hockey League record for the fastest 100 goals scored in a career as he needed only 129 games.

title: Baruch, Lehman Advance
description: Leroy Davis of Hunter missed a desperation shot with one second mauling as the Hawks lost to Baruch, 7574, in the opening round of the u nual City University basketball tournament last night at City College's Nat Holman Gymnasium.

title: Vietnam Celebrates the Signing Of Pact With Cambodia Regime
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 20  With unusual pomp, the Vietnamese Government today celebrated the signing of a treaty with the new regime in Cambodia that cements Hanoi's position as the controlling power in Indochina.

title: Carter and Georgia Foes Like Old Pals at Reunion
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 20  If you threw a net over the whole bunch, drawled State Senator Franklin Sutton as he surveyed the Georgia politicians gathered at the Capitol here today to honor President Carter, you'd catch the biggest bunch of hypocrites ever caught in one throw.

title: Oil Production Slows in Texas
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 20 (AP)  Texas oil production is likely to fall below one billion barrels this year for the first time since 1964, John Poerner, the Texas Railroad Commission chairman, said today. The Railroad Commission regulates the oil industry in Texas.

title: Heaven,
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20  With nominations for acting, writing, directing and best picture, Warren Beatty today became the 1978 Academy Award Renaissance Man for Heaven Can Wait, duplicating Orson Welles's four similar nominations for Citizen Kane in 1941. Strangely, another of the nominees for best picture in 1941 was Here Comes Mr. Jordan, the Robert MontgomeryClaude Rains comedy about an athlete plucked out of his body 40 years too soon, on which Heaven Can Wait is based.

title: Letters
description: Those exceptions to the British style, noted by retired Ambassador Sumner Gerard, of striped ties leading from left to right [Letters, Feb. 7], are those of the Royal Air Force, the Argyle and Sutherland Highlanders, and Trinity College, Dublin; they all go from right to left.

title: Banking Changes Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  The Treasury Department has proposed fundamental changes in Government regulation of banks, savings and loan associations and other financial institut:ons in order to allow them to pay more interest to small savers and to enable the institutions to compete more vigorously for customer deposits.

title: Choose fresh fish and don't overcook it.
description: 4 skinless, boneless fish fillets, about 1 pounds (flounder, sole, or cod will do)

title: Wine Talk
description: IN France, there are wines that are called teinturiers, which means, literally, dyers. In ancient times, cahors was the best known of these wines in Bordeaux, where it was used to add deep color to the thinner, paler wines of the Graves and the Mdoc.

title: Indonesia Volcano Said to Kill 155
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 20 (AP) A volcano in the Dieng Mountains of Central Java is erupting, spewing out poison gases and lava that have killed at least 155 persons and injured more than 100 since early today, a police spokesman re-

title: Young Will Name Coach Soon
description: After five days on a 9,000mile trip to interview candidates, George Young returned to his office yesterday and should be announcing his choice as the Giants head coach any day. It probably will be Dan Reeves or Ray Perkins, not necessarily in that order of preference.

title: `Roots II
description: The question of whether the television serial Roots: The Next Generations would be as phenomenally sucL cessful as the adaptation of Alex Haley's Roots was in 19n was answered with the twohour opening episode on Sunday night: It was not. In its sevennight run it promises to be large, but not enormous, hit.

title: Penn Gains Shate of Ivy Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20  Angelo. Reynolds, a 6-foot-2-inch freshman from this city's West Side, scored his only field goal of the game in overtime tonight to give the University of Pennsylvania a 9241 victory over Princeton. The triumph assures the Quakers of at least a tie for the Ivy League championship.

title: Letters
description: President, Polygon Corporation New York, Feb. 16, 1979

title: Q&A
description: Q. know that tomato pure, tomato paste and tomato sauce cannot be substituted one for the other in recipes. But I am curious to know the differences in each. Can you tell me?

title: Technology
description: IN a farreaching move to rid the state's air of nitrogen oxides, the California Air Resources Board recently ordered the Southern California Edison Company and a number of other utilities to drastically reduce the amount of nitrogen oxides produced their in the Los Angeles area. The ruling

title: Soap Operas: Men Are Tuning In
description: LAGUNA MIGUEL, CALIF. JUST before 12:30 every weekday afternoon, three Orange County building inspectors, Frank Wakeland, John Douglas and Bob Reese, leave their office and head for their respective homes. Then they sit down with their lunches before television screens and watch Days of Our Lives.

title: Young Tree Planters Win Award
description: There were 31 recipients of the Mollie Parnis Dress Up Your Neighborhood awards yesterday at City Hall: Among them were Cybele Zufolo and Russell Wolfson, foreground, Peter White and Sherna Safford. They are from P.S. in Brooklyn, and they were honored for planting trees there last year. The awards were begun in 1972 by Mollie Parnis, one of Seventh Avenue's best known dress designers. The awards are given for a variety of such projects.

title: Sears Bonds Approved
description: TOKYO, Feb. 20 (AP)  The Finance Ministry approved today an application from Sears, Roebuck & Cornpany, the largest retail chain in the United States, issue unmortgaged bonds, or debentures, in Japan, ministry official said. The acceptance broke a 50-year-old practice barring such bonds.

title: About New Rochelle
description: NEW ROCHELLE, Feb. 20 It seems another passive evening in an average family apartment with the television flickering and killing time, killing what is left of one more day in the case of the people of the State of New York v. Joseph Henry.

title: Fund Asks a Vote On McGraw Deal
description: The Ohio Public Employegs Retirement System, one of the nation's largest public pension funds, with 280,000 members, said in Columbus yesterday that as the owner of 280,000 shares of McGrawHill Inc., the fund urged that McGrawHill stockholders be given an opportunity to vote on a proposed merger of the American Express Company and the giant publisher.

title: Dow Loses Early Gain, Ends Level
description: Some of the stock market's recent favorites, from Dome Petroleum and Schlumberger to Boeing, encountered modest selling pressure yesterday as the general list pulled back slightly.

title: Corporate Earnings Are Reported for the Quarter
description: Fer rerkeis as shown. (N) indIcates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Ekchance.(A) the American Stock Exchange and (01 over thecounter.

title: Snow Job: Good Biz
description: These are great times for announcements out of Washington of economic indicators that don't indictate much of anything to anyone who knows as little about money as I do.

title: Kaiser Steel to Lift Prices
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it was raising prices on threefourths of its steel mill products by 1 to 6 percent with most of the increases going into effect May 1.

title: UMass Coach Retires
description: AMHERST. Mass., Feb. 21 (AP) Jack Leaman, who posted more victories than any other basketball coach in University of Massachusetts history, announced his retirement tonight after his 13th and worst season at the helm of the Minutemen. Leaman, who will remain at Massachusetts in an administrative capacity, announced his retirement after the Minutemen suffered their 11th consecutive loss in a 5442 Eastern Eight defeat by Penn State.

title: Expert Tips
description: Aside from keeping a careful eye on the ads, what should consumers look for when buying a bed and innerspring mattress? Here are some tips from experts:

title: Caesars World Bonds Yield 13.3%
description: Caesars World, which operates a gambling casino in Las Vegas, Nev., and is building another one on the Boardwalk in Atlantic City, sold $15 million of I5year bonds yesterday, priced to give investors a hefty yield of 13.3 percent. The securities are rated B by Standard & Poor's, which means the service regards them as speculative, and they are unrated by Moody's.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: TN Delaware Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the Tengelmann Group, West Germany's largest supermarket chain, said yesterday that it had completed the previously announced, privately negotiated purchase of 7.29 million shares of the common.stock of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company.

title: Obituary 8 -- No Title
description: Fie Dermatology faculty and staff at Columbia Preebyterian Medical Center maum the passing of Dr. Anthony Donionkos. Professor Emeritus of Clinical Dermatology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons. Corium. bia University and consultant for the dermatology service at Presbyterian Hospital. Dr. Domookos. who Joined the Dermatology staff at the Medical Center 29 years ago. died at the Harkness Pavilion on Monday. February It 1979. In 1939, after receiving his medical degree In Budapest he returned to the United States. interned at Conemarigh Valley Memorial Hospital. Johnstown. Pa. and entered the US. Army Au Form as a flight surgeon in 1942. rising to the sank of MMor. Upon his discharge in 1911. be became a resident in dermatology at Columbia Preebyterion Medical Center. where be remained an active member of the staff until the time of his death.

title: Locust Threat to Asia and Africa Appears Abated
description: HARGEISA, Somalia, Feb. 16  The immediate threat of a major plague of desert locusts emanating from the Horn of Africa has abated, according to field workers of international organizations set up to combat the insects.

title: Disks: Miss von Stade
description: IF there is anything to those old wives tales about prenatal influence, Frederica von Stade's child, Jenny Rebecca, ought to have a running start toward a musical career. We learn from a jacket note that the baby was born just 48 hours after the mezzosoprano finished making this recording. The album concludes most

title: Beaths
description: WoRANEctwere T. Reposing at Williams Funeral Home. Broadway at 232 Street. Bronx. until Friday, 9:30AM.

title: Michigan Sues Hooker Chemical To Force a Cleanup of Pollutants
description: LANSING, Mich., Feb. 21 (AP)  The state filed suit today against the Hooker Chemical and Plastics Corporation, demanding that the company clean up poisonious wastes dumped near its Montague plant.

title: Richard Kinney, DeafBlind Educator, Dies
description: Richard Kinney, president of the Iladley. School for the Blind in Winnetka, Ill., died Monday of a heart attack at Eyanston Hospital in Evanston. Ill. Mr. Kinney, a resident of Winnetka. was 55 years old.

title: Glass Blowing Thrives in Village
description: ALTHOUGH there is no sign on the door, you can tell you have arrived at the Experimental Glass Workshop by the blast of hot air that greets you at the entrance and the roar of the furnaces blazing inside. The two furnaces, focal points of most of the activity here, were custom built for the workshop at 4 Great Jones Street, which is believed to be the only glassblowing facility in Manhattan.

title: Independence Festivity On St. Lucia Imperiled
description: CASTRIES, St. Lucia, Feb. 21 (AP)  This Caribbean island planned a celebration when it becomes independent of Britain at midnight tonight, but problems threaten to curtail the festivities.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Treasury's new twoyear notes that were offered for sale yesterday were auctioned at an average yield of 9.85 percent, unchanged from the rate on twoyear notes sold a month ago but well above the levels dealers last week said they expected.

title: UraniuM Disposal Site Discovered in Denver, The Fourth Such Find
description: DENVER, Feb. 21 (AP) The State Health Department found a highly radio. active uranium disposal site today about a halfmile from downtown Denver. It was the fourth such site found by the department to be emitting radiation in excess of Federal safety limits.

title: 4 Gain In City Title Play
description: Staten Island, Brooklyn. Queens and City Colleges advanced yesterday in the quarterfinal round of the 1979 City University of New York basketball tournament.

title: Notre Dame Beats Oklahoma City Five
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 21 (AP) Orlando Woolridge scored 21 points tonight and Bill Laimbeer grabbed 14 rebounds as No. 3ranked Notre Dame defeated Oklahoma City, 8860, in college basketball.

title: Recital: Zara Nelsova Performs Lazarof Duo
description: IF there is one musical field that seems more than any other to have been virtually preempted by the young in the last few years, it is that of virtuoso celloplaying.
