title: Art. A1 Held Adds. Color to Geometry
description: IN painting, as in other realms of human endeavor, there are few iron laws that apply on all occasfrons, but there are, nonetheless, certain circumstances that recur with similar meanings. One is that when a painter abandons color in order to work exclusively in black and white for any protracted period, he is likely to be shoring up a new kind of structure for his work.

title: Aqueduct Sells Quinellas; Exactas Scheduled Today
description: Encouraged by the addition of quinella betting to yesterday's program, Aqueduct will begin selling tickets or exactas today. Exacta bets  selecting the precise older of the first two finishers  will be taken on the third, fifth and seventh races.

title: Screen: 'Ice Castles,' Skater's Story:Slush
description: THROUGH a flurry of figurative snowflakes, I was able to discern the following about "Ice Castles": It's about a pretty teen-age figure skater who wants to be a champion, has a terrible accident, and then becomes a champion just the same. This may not sound any too complicated, but its particulars are amazingly hard to follow.Donald Wrye, who directed the film and co-wrote its screenplay, has induced the cast to mumble any lines that stand some chance of advancing the plot. And his way of stringing scenes together invariably suggests that other scenes have been left out. When the story gets confusing, the ball is carried by Marvin Hamlisch's swelling score, which celebrates emotions the actors don't quite seem to be feeling. The score works like a bossy laugh-track on a television show.Lexie Winston, played by Lynn-Holly Johnson, is a small-town Iowa girl who at first does most of her skating at the town pond, or at a rink-cum-bowling alley run by hard-bitten Colleen Dewhurst, who is apparently Lexie's coach. Lexie lives alone with her father (Tom Skerritt), who acts like some kind of half-mad backwoods trapper for reasons that are not explained.Her farm-boy sweetheart, played by Robby Benson, doesn't behave for one moment as if he knew which end of a cow did the mooing, but let that pass. It's baffling enough that Mr. Benson seems to be having a hockey career that conflicts with Lexie's skating, and that all of their romantic problems are explained in one long-distance telephone conversation, which is only partly audible and full of long pauses.Never mind the warm-up, it's Lexie's accident that's supposed to put a lump in your throat. After she has become successful and celebrated, a change that is signaled by her ever more elaborate hairdos, she winds up at a cocktail party, staring morosely at the ice sculpture in the middle of the room. This prompts her to go out to a deserted rink and skate her troubles away, but she slips and hurts her head in slow motion.Cut to a stark, mostly white hospital room full of elaborate equipment and  such is the logic of Mr. Wrye's staging  one wall-sized mural of autumnal trees. The doctors are testing for brain damage, and their results are characteristically fuzzy. "This sort of thing usually gets better or worse in a few days after the injury," goes the diagnosis. "And after that, what you have is what you have."Mr. Benson, as the sentimental softie of the piece, has some nice moments after Lexie's accident, but the film's muddled beginning makes his a particularly incomplete character.It's too bad that Mr. Wrye's bungling renders the story sob-proof, because injured-athlete sagas are usually so hard to resist. But Bill Butler's handsome cinematography captures settings that aren't brought to life by the screenplay, and the cast's crisper, more straight-forward actors  Mr. Skerritt, Miss Dewhurst, David Huffman and Jennifer Warren, who plays Lexie's big-time coach  are hopelessly undermined by the choppiness of their roles.Miss Johnson, a screen newcomer who was formerly with the Ice Capades, has a role designed to make minimal demands on her acting abilities; for the most part, all she has to do is look uncomplicatedly sweet and skate. She seems to skate beautifully, but Mr. Wrye  who should have been forced to sit through "The Turning Point" until he got this right  captures skating scenes that are utterly without magic.By not showing any of Lexie's competitors on the ice, he makes it hard for an audience to appreciate her special talent. By cueing his stadium crowds to leap to their feet and applaud Lexie's performance unanimously, he creates an unreasonably stacked deck. By shooting her, inexplicably, from the ice's point of view, he sometimes makes her look like an oncoming sub-marine."Ice Castles" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), because of some moderately harsh language in its screenplay.

title: Auctions
description: WHAT is being billed by Christie, Manson & Woods as one of the great car sales of the century takes place Sunday at 2 P.M., in the Los Angeles Convention Center. The word is

title: Power to All the People
description: The town of Sherrill, N.Y., has found a better way. While New York City and Westchester pay about 10 cents a kilowatt hour for electricity, this little town east of Syracuse is able to buy pollutionfree power for about 2 cents.

title: Recital: Kiri Te Kanawa
description: IT cannot be said too often that Carnegie Hall is not really the place to hear lieder programs, especially when the singer is relatively inexperienced recitalist such as Kiri Te Kanawa. The soprano's suc- cesses there last night were genuine, though they did not come in an unbroken string by any means. What one had to wonder, however, was how much more effective she might have been all of the audience had been able to get within range of her gently captivating personality.

title: In SoHo Concert, Only the Musicians Get Chairs
description: At 6 P.M. tomorrow, Charles Wadsworth, artistic director of the distinguished Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, will stand on a piano bench to address an audience sprawled on foamrubber pads. He's done this sort of thins before.

title: Theater: Behrrnan's 1932 Biography
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Gas Leaks Injure 58 in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (UPI)  Ammonia leaks at an Oscar Mayer Company in the city and the GTE Automatic Electric Labs in suburban Northlake yesterday sent 58 employees to hospitals.

title: Recital: BaduraSkoda
description: CONCERT performances of Mozart's piano sonatas are often remarkably unrewarding. Part of the reason is the music itself, which was not written to be played in large public halls and is not as good as Mozart's greatest piano concertos in any case. But stylistic problems are also a major stumbling block, and the choice of an instrument can seem fairly problematic as well.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: I felt it would be better to have 10 people put in $1,000 each than have one person put in $10,000.

title: Suit on Fire Company Is Dismissed by Judge
description: A lawsuit filed by State Senator Vander L. Beatty of Brooklyn, aimed at forcing Mayor Koch to put a Crown Heights fire company back in the Bergen Street quarters it had occupied for 87 years, was dismissed yesterday, even as Senator Beatty was initiating recall petition aimed at throwing the Mayor out of office.

title: Utah Uneasy Over LeukemiaAtomic Tests Study
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 22  A scientific study, documenting high levels of leukemia deaths among Utah children during a period of atomic testing, was released today. It was the latest in a series of disquieting disclosures related to longterm effects of the tests, and served to heighten a sense of profound uneasiness among residents of the state.

title: Evans Appointed New York Administrative Judge
description: Herbert B. Evans, a highranking appellate judge, was named statewide administrative judge yesterday.

title: Csonka Back to Dolphins On a OneYear Contract
description: MIAMI, Feb. 22 (AP)  No. 39 returned to the Miami Dolphins backfield today as the National Football League team announced the signing of Larry Csonka, fullback, to a oneyear contract.

title: Paris Plans a Park at Les Halles
description: PARIS, Feb. 22  After a decade of hesitation, city planners have decided to establish a starshaped park on the site of Les Halles, the former market area.

title: West German Skier Wins US. Downhill
description: WILMINGTON, N.Y., Feb. 22 Irene Epple of West Germany became one of the few Europeans to earn a United States Alpine championship when she outsped a field of 50 this afternoon in an Olympic downhill test run on Whiteface Mountain.

title: 5 Teamsters Officials Are Indicted in Jersey In LaborPayoff Case
description: NEWARK, Feb. 22 (UPI)  Five New Jersey officials of the International Brotherhqbd of Teamsters, including four questioned about the disappearance of James R. Hotta, were indicted today for allegedly using their power to guarantee tabor peace in exchange for payoffs from trucking companies.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Uniform low level overcast is apparent from New England through the Ohio valley, the Southeast and the Texas Gulf coast. Bright thunderstorm clouds stretch along the Mississippi Valley. Thick layered clouds cover the Middle West, the Northern Plains States. the central Rockies and the Central Pacific States.

title: Russell Cowles at 92; Painter of Landscapes In the Lyrical Manner
description: Russell Cowles, a landscape painter who was the son of Gardner Cowles Sr., the late newspaper publisher, died yesterday at his apartment at 179 East 70th Street. Mr. Cowles, who also lived in New Milford, Conn., was 92 years old and had been in failing health for several years.

title: Small Quake Jolts Mexico City
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 22 (AP)  A small earth tremor shook Mexico City early today, but there were no casualties or damage, officials said. Tie quake registered 4.0 on the openended Richter scale, according to the Red Cross, and the national seismographic station said the epicenter was 65 miles north of the capital.

title: Around the Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 (UPI)The head of the National Park Service agreed today to withdraw a permit for Nazi rally on Independence Mall Sunday unless the applicant appears and explains himself.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Clowns of Silent Films Return
description: If silence is golden, then the place to prospect this weekend is on a plot of ground between Fifth and Sixth Ave: nues on Eighth Street in Greenwich Village.

title: High Court Rules on Gas Flow
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  An equally divided Supreme Court held today that the Federal Government lacked the regulatory authority to require producers of natural gas to keep their wells functioning at the greatest Dossible productivity.

title: Woodlawn, Bronx's Other Hall of Fame
description: WERE historya respecter of persons Bat Masterson would be buried in a sagebrushcovered back lot in Dodge City, Fiorello La Guardia under the Empire State Building and Herman Melville in the black earth of his Eneantada Island. Surprisingly enough, however, they are all buried in Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx, and on Sunday afternoon the Friends of Central Park will sponsor an unusual, coldweather tour of a burial ground Woodlawn admirers refer to as a real Hall of Fame.

title: Orders Down In Shipbuilding
description: LONDON, Feb. 22 (AP)  New orders received by the world shipbuilding industry dropped 31.3 percent last year, with total capacity of the ships declining 34.1 percent, an annual review of shipyard contracting activity reported today.

title: Brown Rejects Call for Use of Guard in Farm Strike
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. today rejected a request from Oren Fox, the sheriff of Imperial County, to send National Guardsmen to the county to help quell growing violence in a 34dayold strike by the United Farm Workers of America.

title: Soviet Said to Rule Out Intervention if War Is Limited
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 22  Soviet officials are reported to have told several Western and Asian diplomats that their country does not plan military intervention in the ChineseVietnamese fighting as long as the scale of hostilities remains limited.

title: EARNINGS Polaroid's Profits Up 15.1 % in Quarter
description: Profits of the Polaroid Corportion rose 15.1 percent in the fourth quarter and 28.3 percent in all of 1978, according to results reported yesterday by the photographic equipment manufacturer.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Update Set In Gasoline Allocation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)  The Energy Department announced today that it was updating the basis of its anocation system in anticipation of possible gasoline shortages stemming from the loss of Iranian oil production.

title: Business and the Law
description: AMONG sawyers, the phrase deep pocket refers to a company with seemingly limitless resources to fight a case, and to pay up if loses. While corporate executives increasingly complain aboitt the cost of legal Dills, they often dig deeply when they are involved in a takeover bid or antitrust action.

title: The Disgrace of the Wildcat Strikers
description: New York City's school bus drivers, on a wildcat strike, shocked the public this week by smashing the windows of taxicabs and threatening and assaulting the men at the wheel for daring to bring severely handicapped children to school. The bus drivers know the taxis are only a makeshift substitute to permit inadvertent victims of the strike to maintain daily contact with the world outside.Their tactics will surely strengthen public support for the Board of Education's position on new bus contracts. The board rightly believes these should be awarded only after competitive bidding and without any unusual job protection.

title: J. Kenneth Moore, 48, A Television Physicist
description: J. Kenneth Moore, vice president and general manager of the CBS Technology Center in Stamford, Corm., died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 48 years old and lived at 65 Westbrook Drive in Stamford.

title: McGraw Poll Prospect Dims
description: A plan to conduct a poll of stockholders of McGrawHill Inc. on a Si billion takeover bid appeared to dim yesterday as Maxwell Geffen, a major shareholder, said that he had withdrawn his support of the plan along with Donald C. McGraw Jr., another big investor and dissident member of the McGraw family. Mr. Geffen said that there was too much risk of lawsuits. Bache, Halsey, Stuart. Shields, the brokerage firm, and, as a big McGraw investor, the last remaining backer of the plan, declined comment.

title: Chairman Of Wallace Resigns
description: The Sam P. Wallace Company, the big industrial contracting concern, announced yesterday that Carl P. Wallace, its chairman and chief executive, had resigned and would be replaced by R. D. Bruckner, its president.

title: Stage: Czech Coquelico
description: EVER since the 1950's the Czechoslovaks have been working away at a mixedmedia theatrical form they call the Magic Lantern. Conceived and designed by Josef Svoboda  director of the Prague National Theater and best known here for his set designs for the Metropolitan and other major opera houses  the Magic Lantern made its international debut at the 1958 Brussels World's Fair and has been a popular hit in Prague and on tour ever since.

title: VOLCANO DEATH TOLL RISES
description: Smoke continued to billow from the crater of Mount Sinila in central Java as a member of a rescue team examined the bodies of some of the victims of Tuesday's volcanic eruption. Officials said that 175 people had died from poisonous gases and smoldering lava.

title: Senate Votes to Cut PostCloture Debate to 100 Hours
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  After five weeks of sporadic debate and compromise in which little other substantive legislation could be considered, the Senate tonight sharply curtailed the controversial tactics that have been used in recent years to keep filibusters going after cloture has been invoked.

title: Publishing: An Edwardian Album
description: WRITING a book about the rise and fall of a reallife Edwardian family usually follows standard procedure. One compiles the text and then illustrates it with the appropriate prints, photographs and the like. Colin Gor- don, a young English schoolteacher, has reversed the procedure, however, and come up with a perfectly charming and engrossing book, A Richer Dust: Echoes From an Edwardian Album. And the story about the book is as entrancing as the story in it.

title: TollCollectors Blame Bank Over Report of Shortages
description: The head of the Bridge and Tunnel Officers Benevolent Association in New York City called yesterday for a Federal investigation into the handling of the nearly $200 million a year in toll revenues deposited in the Community National Bank and Trust Company on Staten Island.

title: 59 Republican Assemblymen Tour the City
description: With friendship but making no promises, 59 Republican Assemblyman, most of them from upstate, took tours of New York City yesterday and had lunch with Mayor Koch at Grade Mansion.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Tickets are available at the public desk in the main lobby, United Nations headquarters. Tours: 9A.M. 4:45 P.M.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON  A bipartisan ethics committee cleared State Senator Martin L. Greenberg, Democrat of East Orange, of any conflictin the application by the Intercontinental Insurance Company of Newark for a statebacked construction loan. Mr. Greenberg is secretary and general counsel for Intercontinental. His law firm was listed on the application to the New Jersey Economic Development Authority for the $900,000 loan. State law prohibits legislators from representing private clients before a state agency.

title: East German Visits Mozambique
description: MAPUTO, Mozambique, Feb. 22 (Reu ters)  Erich Honecker, the East Ger man head of state, arrived here today for a threeday official visit and was wel comed at the airport with full military honors by President Samora Machel Mr Honecker has also visited Libya, Angola and Zambra.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Bond Prices Decline Sharply
description: Bond prices dropped sharply yesterday as their slowmotion slide early this week gave way to a more pronounced decline that coincided with the intensification of VietnamChina fighting and the spread of oil price increases.

title: ExPrisoners of Cuba in U.S.
description: MIAMI, Feb. 22 (AP)  Some 167 for mer Cuban political prisoners arrived in Miami yesterday, rejoining families some of them had not seen for more than 16 years.

title: Coast Judge to End Receivership Of the Worldwide Church of God
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22  The Worldwide Church of God won a major victory in its legal battle with the state of California yesterday when Judge Julius Title of LOS Angeles Superior Court said he would lift a twomonth receivership placed on the 46yearold Pasadenabased church. The date for the action is expected to be March 1.

title: Screen: Australian Hawthorne Romance:From Down Under
description: HORROR need not always be a long-fanged gentleman in evening clothes or a dismembered corpse or a doctor who keeps a brain in his gold fish bowl. It may be a warm sunny day. the innocence of girlhood and hints of unexplored sexuality that combine to produce a euphoria so intense it becomes transporting, a state beyond life or death. Such horror is unspeakable not because it is gruesome but because it remains outside the realm of things that can be easily defined or explained in conventional ways.It's also the fascination of "Picnic at Hanging Rock," the Australian film directed by Peter Weir, who was introduced to American audiences late last year by his moodily impressive "The Last Wave.""Picnic at Hanging Rock," which opens today at the Little Carnegie, is about three virginal young women and a school mistress who, on Valentines Day, 1900, disappear without trace while on an expedition to a splendid geological outcropping called Hanging Rock. The movie would like us to believe it's based on fact though it's really based on a novel by Joan Lindsay. Whatever the origins the story provides Mr. Weir with material for a kind of Australian horror-romance that recalls Nathaniel Hawthorne's preoccupation with the spiritual and moral heritage of his own New England landscape.In "The Last Wave" Mr. Weir made what seemed to me to be the grave mistake of attempting to provide answers for the mysteries he so beautifully set up earlier in the film. "Picnic at Hanging Rock" is different. It's a movie composed almost entirely of clues. Its methods are illusory, not necessarily to trick us but to force us to stretch our imaginations. Instead of exposition, Mr. Weir and his screen writer, Cliff Green, deal in moods.The opening section of the film, in which we are introduced to the students at Mrs. Appleyard's College for young women, dramatizes their innocence with such intensity that we are immediately aware of sexual longings everywhere: students for students, students for school mistress, school mistress for someone unknown, even the maid for the gardener. Exchanged with high giggles are Valentines that pledge eternal love. Quite arbitrarily one of the girls is prevented from going on the picnic. Why? The only explanation is that the head mistress. Mrs. Appleyard (Rachel Roberts), is a monster. Another girl, carried away by her anticipation of the glorious day and by her own intimations of immortality, remembers Poe's lines. "All that we see or seem / is but a dream within a dream."The heat of the day is as much of a presence during the picnic as the rock formation that provides shadow for the group. Mr. Weir makes us believe that the landscape is alive. When four of the girls set off to explore the rock, ignoring warnings of venomous snakes and poisonous ants, we have the impression that they are being called. As they climb higher and higher into the volcanic outcropping, one girl, the chubby one named Edith, panics and runs screaming back to the base. For some unexplained reason, the dry, spinterish teacher of geometry decides to follow the three who are climbing the rock. Later, after the disappearance of the group has been confirmed, a witness reports having seen the teacher at some distance, running across a plateau, in her pantaloons.I can't tell you how the story is resolved, though some people will feel cheated. That, however, will be to have anticipated a different movie. I'm not sure that Mr. Weir has succeeded in evoking his "dream within a dream" world without using one or two more red herrings than are absolutely necessary, but because the film has a hypnotic spell I accept its excesses."Picnic at Hanging Rock" is very nicely cast, beginning with Rachel Roberts and including Anne Lambert as Miranda, the beautiful girl who leads her classmates into oblivion; Karen Robson as Irma, the one member of the expedition who survives but remembers nothing; Dominic Guard as a young man who shares Irma's forgotten secret; and Christine Schuler as the chubby girl who complains when she's included in a plan and complains even more when she's left out.Though, "Picnic at Hanging Rock" has immense feeling for an interest in the Australian landscape, it is anything but a picturesque or provincial film. Among other things it knows that there are some romantic longings, especially in the young, that are so overwhelming they simply cannot be contained. The result is a movie that is both spooky and sexy.

title: A Computer Expert Pleads Guilty In Theft of $10.2 Million by Wire
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22 (AP)  Stanley Mark Rifkin pleaded guilty today to stealing $10.2 million from a Security Pacific Bank and transferring it by wire into a private Swiss account.

title: Deaths
description: ROSENTHALJerold L., of Roslyn Heights, on FebrtierY 22. Beloved son. of Irma Rosenthal Padrone and the late Arnold Rosenthal. Dearest brother of Larry. Bruce. Jess. and Lisa. Laving grandson at Florence Brown. Services will be held at the Rosiyn Heights Funeral Home, Inc., 75 Mineola Ave.. Roslyn Heights. 11AM Sunday. February 25th Intermeat, Beth El Cemetery, Westwood. N.J. Visiting. hours Friday 7. 9:30PM Saturday 2-4:30 and 79:30.

title: Chrysler Cuts Prices To Dealers
description: DETROIT, Feb. 22  Beset by swollen inventories and lagging sales, the Chrysler Corporation is cutting prices to dealers by up to $450 on various autos and light trucks ordered by the end of March  cuts that presumably will be passed along to car buyers.

title: 2 Groups Divide on Space Shuttle
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UPI)  An outside review committee told Congress today that another long delay was likely for the first flight of the space shuttle, but another advisory panel said the shuttle would probably fly in November as Planned.

title: A Wary Soviet Dissident Irritates Friend and Foe
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 22  One of the few spots in the Soviet Union where free inquiry takes place is a tiny, booklined study in a fifthfloor .walkup at the northern edge of Moscow, a 45minute drive from the Kremlin.

title: U.S. Bonds Sell In Germany
description: BONN, Feb. 22  The United State: Government today successfully sold it second public offering in West Germany of bonds denominated in German marks, although at a higher cost and with a less enthusiastic response than similar borrowing in December.

title: Diamond Shamrock Merger Approved
description: Shareholders of Falcon Seaboard Inc. and the Diamond Shamrock Corporation at special meetings have approved a merger of Falcon into Diamond Shamrock. Falcon shareholders are to receive 1.65 shares of Diamond Shamrock for each of their shares. Falcon is a coal producer and Diamond Shamrock produces industrial and specialty chemicals, natural gas and crude oil.

title: Money
description: THURSDAY, FEB. 22..1979

title: Princeton Inters Another Member of Its Fabled Alumni
description: Joseph N. Norden, a reclusive real estate investor, died last month in Tierra del Fuego, at the tip of South America, after he was allegedly poisoned by local protesters who objected to his plan to build beachfront condominium apartments there. He was 82 years old and a member of the Princeton class of 1918.

title: Chase Trust Files Under Chapter XI
description: One of the nation's largest real estate investment trusts, the Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust, filed voluntary bankruptcy petition yesterday in an effort to reorganize its finances.

title: Credit Demand Stays High
description: Demand for credit remained strong in the reporting week that ended Wednesday as business loans rose $190 million at the 10 major New York banks and as companies increased their borrowings from the commercial paper market by $800 million, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: Lloyd, Carr ExAides Convicted
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Feb. 22 (AP)  Five former employees of Lloyd, Carr & Company were found guilty tomaght of charges in connection with multimillion dollar commodity options swindle.

title: Advertising
description: WELLS, RICH, GREENE, nose to nose with Ogilvy & Mather right down to the wire, has won the Century 21 Real Estate Corporation account. But there is much more to this unusual story than just that. This time an agency has also won the right to acquire an agency.

title: QUICK MIDEAST PACT VIEWED AS UNLIKELY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)  The prospects for quickly completing an EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty were considered slim today as negotiators held second day of talks at Camp David, Md., under United States auspices.

title: Caricature of a General Curbs Future Generals
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Feb. 22 (AP) The entire senior class at the Air Force Academy has been restricted to the campus until the person who drew an unflattering caricature of the commandant comes forward and confesses.

title: Buffalo Gets Baseball
description: BUFFALO, Feb: 22 (AP)  Mayer James Griffin announced today that Buffalo will have a baseball team in the Eastern League during the 1979 season. The franchise, which had been located in Jersey City, N.J., is a part of the Pittsburgh Pirates organization.

title: Market Place
description: THE bonds of utilities in key metropolitan areas have long been suspect in investor circles because of the diminished rate of growth of their service areas.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, Feb. 22 (Reuters)  Union leaders representing striking hospital aides and ambulance drivers accepted new pay proposals today. But they said the strikes would continue until the rank and file agreed to the proposals.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AMF Inc., a manufacturer of leisuretime and industrial products, has formed a new unit, the AMF HartleyDavidson Parts and Accessories division, and has named Charles K. Thompson its president.

title: Art People
description: IN from Paris the other day was Dina Vierny, the French art dealer and collector, who as a teenager, posed for the sculptor Aristide Maillol (18611944) and later inherited his estate. Things having

title: Islanders Trounce Blues, 61
description: UNIONDALE, Li., Feb. 22  According to Coach Al Arbour, the New York Islanders slept for the first two periods, then woke up in the third.

title: Notes on People
description: Tempest Over Turbot Stirred at Lutece

title: On the Contrary, Quebec Independence Isn't Certain
description: MONTREAL  The government of Quebec has expended much effort to convince people of the inevitability of Quebec independence. More precisely, the government says that Quebec will be politically independent while keeping its economic links with Canada, an arrangement called sovereignty-association.

title: Drive for Recall In City Started; Mayor Is Target
description: A black New York State Senator began a petition campaign yesterday to amend the City Charter of New York to permit recall of the Mayor. It was the start of what could become a referendum in November on Mayor Koch's administration.

title: U.S. Asks Urgent
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 22 The United States, joined by three Western allies, asked today for an urgent meeting of the Security Council to consider the situation in Southeast Asia and its implications for international peace and security.

title: S.E.C. Lists Necessary Steps For Wider Options Trading
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  The Securities and Exchange Commission issued a plan today that would permit the expansion of options trading within six months if the stock exchanges took immediate and coordinated steps to improve surveillance over market trading and brokerage practices.

title: Britain Writing Off Part of Concorde Debt
description: LONDON, Feb. 22 (Reuters)  The British Government is writing off $320 million of the debt owed it by the stateowned British Airways in a bid to make service by the supersonic Concorde jetliner profitable, Trade Minister John Smith said today.

title: Service for Ralph Alswang
description: A memorial service will be held for Ralph Alswang, designer, at the Booth Theater on Wednesday at 12:30 P.M. Harry Belafonte, Gary Merrill, June Havoc and Alexander H. Cohen will speak.

title: Vic Dickenson Trio Brings Mardi Gras North
description: For Crawdaudy, the New Orleansstyle restaurant at 95th Street and Vanderbilt Avenue, Mardi Gras is an annual opportunity to show its affinity to the Crescent City. This is done by dedaring a Mardi Gras celebration, decorating the room in green, purple and yellow pompons and ribbons, adding the pianist Jim Roberts to the luncheon fare from noon to 2:30 P.M., and soliciting a telegram from the Mayor of New Orleans giving his official blessing to the event.

title: IN THE NATION Looking at The Other Guys
description: WASHINGTON  Since President Carter suddenly is being lowrated again by polls and politicians alike, maybe it's time for a look at the chances of the Republicans who'd like to replace him. Here's the scouting report of a knowledgeable party leader on what he refused to call the Big Five candidates:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch in Business Day yesterday incorrectly described part of the settlement of a suit brought by former shareholders of Airco Inc. against BOC International Ltd. BOC has agreed to make payments ranging from 15 cents a share to $2 a share to those who sold Airco shares on the open market during a specified period, with the precise amount depending on when they sold. The total cost to BOC under this provision cannot exceed $2.75 million.

title: Hobbits in Kentucky
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  In the sad list of things that will always be beyond me, philology is toward the top, up with my inability to drive an automobile or pronounce the word mirroring. The wellmeant efforts of two universities to teach me to read (and in a recurring nightmare, to write and speak) Old English, or AngloSaxon as they sometimes called it, I have no intention of forgiving. Some grudges are permanent. On Judgment Day I shall proudly and stubbornly begrudge learning how to abandon a sinking ship, how to crawl under live machinegun fire, and AngloSaxon.

title: Amtrak Insists on Its Right to Offer Fare Discounts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  Alan S. Boyd, president of Amtrak, took issue today with the Carter Administration's proposal to limit the passenger rail system's right to offer ticket discounts or reduced prices for its services.

title: Fed Chief Backs End Of Oil Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  G William Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that gradual removal of price controls on crude oil would have only a modest inflation effect and would probably lead to more production of domestic oil.

title: REPRESSION OF JEWS IN SYRIA IS CHARGED,
description: Wearing a black mask that he said was necessary for the safety of relatives unable to leave Damascus, a man who said he was a Jew who recently escaped froth Syria asserted yesterday that a new wave of repression had been imposed on the Jewish community there, signaling a retreat from human rights gains of the last two years.

title: Stockton Winning Money and Friends
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22  Dave Stockton, one of the frontrunners today in the opening round of the Los Angeles open, is a better-than-average golf pro. He has won 11 tournaments since he joined the PGA Tour in 1964, including two Professional Golfers Association championships. He is one of the 19 men on the tour Nho have topped $1 million in official winnings.

title: Basques Kidnap an Executive, Wound and Then Release Him
description: SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Feb. 22 (Reuters)  Basque separatist gunmen abducted a businessman near here last night and released him two hours later after shooting him in the leg, the police said today.

title: Mannes Merger Is Voted, But Opposition Remains
description: The boards of trustees of the Manhattan School of Music and the Mannes College of Music have voted to merge the two institutions, but two dissenting Mannes trustees have obtained a showcause order aimed at blocking the merger. A bitter campaign of opposi- tion has been mounted by many students and faculty members against what the boards called, in a joint statement yesterday, the unification of the two institutions.

title: Music: Organ Interlude
description: DESPITE its beauty as an instrument and its extraordinarily handsome appearance, the Theodore Kuhn organ installed at Alice Tully Hall has not had as much use as it deserves. Lincoln Center has tried presenting series of organ recitals, but they have not proved very successful in terms of public attendance. Now the center is trying once again, this time with five Organ Interludes, hourlong programs at the twilight hour of 5:30, priced at 52.50 each. (Subscribers will get a sixth, bonus concert of evening length.) The programs are devoted exclusively to the works of Bach and other Baroque composers, music that is particularly suited to the Tully Hall organ.

title: White House Is Cool to Charges Of Interference in Role of E.P.A.
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 22  President Carter's press secretary, Jody Powell, today dismissed as a little outburst complaints by some officials of the Environmental Protection Agency about white House interference in the reguldtory process.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: National Airlines disclosed yesterday that its chairman, L. B. Maytag, had sent a telegram to directors of Texas International Airlines asking for more detailed information about Texas International's renewed merger proposal.

title: Britain Asserts Soviet Is Building Weapons Beyond Defense Need
description: LONDON, Feb. 22 (UPI)  The British Government said today that the Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies were continuing to increase military spending and build up their air, sea and ground forces well beyond what they need for defense.

title: Jaspers (520) Conquer Fordham Five, 6452
description: In the Terminal and the Pinewood, the bars that sit in the shadow of the elevated subway station at 242d Street and Broadway in the Bronx, the Jaspers and Mounties have prepared themselves for the worst. The basketball team at Manhattan College has lost 20 games, far more than any previous Manhattan team. The Jaspers are Manhattan students and the Mounties, their adopted sisters at the College of Mount St. Vincent, know what can happen next.

title: World Jurists
description: GENEVA, Friday, Feb. 23 (Reuters) The International Commission of Jurists today proposed new ways of eliminating torture, which it said was becoming more cruel through the misuse of science.

title: K.G.B. Chief, in Speech, Defends Prosecution of Soviet Dissidents
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 22 (Reuters)  The head of the K.G.B., the Soviet Union's security police organization, said today that prosecution of dissidents for antiSoviet activities was just, democratic and had the full approval of the Soviet people.

title: R. Can, Former Head of Oberlin
description: Dr. Robert K. Carr, retired President of Oberlin College, died Wednesday at the Elyria Home in Elyria, Ohio. He was 71 years old and had been a resident of Oberlin, Ohio, before his illness.

title: PRESIDENT CAUTIONS FOREIGN POLICY FOES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  President Carter cautioned today against overly simple interpretations of complex international crises, such as the revolution in Iran and the fighting in Indochina. He

title: Always Hire a Guy You Know
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 22  One day in the Baltimore Colts offices long before taking command last week as the Giants general manager, George Young was talking with a Colts executive about a member of the staff who had not fulfilled the potential attributed to him at the time of his hiring.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201: MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 9-5300NASSAU CO. (516) 747-0500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUTCO (203) 348-7767.

title: Haiti Delays Till June Its New Passport Law
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 22 (AP)  Haiti, acceding to pressure from travel agents and hotel owners, announced today that it would postpone putting into effect a new requirement that all visitors from the United States and Canada have passports.

title: West German Defense Minister, In U.S., Sees 2 High Carter Aides
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (Reuters) Defense Minister Hans Apelof West Germany conferred with senior White House and Defense Department officials today on issues relating to EastWest security and the North Atlantic alliance.

title: Supreme Court Upholds A.&
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  The Supreine Court ruled today that a company that induces a supplier to give it favorable price cuts  normally violation of Federal antitrust laws cannot be prosecuted as long as the supplier believes it has to cut the price to meet competition.

title: U.S. to Slash Aid to Afghanistan, Partly Because of Death of Envoy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  President Carter has ordered that the American aid program to Afghanistan be severely reduced, in part because of the death last week of the United States Ambassador, Adolph Dubs, in a shooting battle between Government forces and terrorists.

title: Sunflower Plant for Cargill
description: Cargill Inc. announced yesterday that it would build a sunflower processing facility on a 42acre site in an industrial area of Riverside, N.D., at a cost of about $18 million. It said that the complex was the first in the nation specifically designed to process sunflower seeds into oil.

title: Teheran Students Demand Role in University Control
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 22  The revolution in Iran is far from over on one of the major sites of past battles, the campus of Teheran University. Though the school has been formally closed since last October, it fairly seethed today with hundreds of students fiercely discussing a purge of the faculty, while in the only occupied building faculty members, with no less animation, discussed how to appease their former charges.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: New Pricing Method
description: Washington, Feb. 22 (Reuters)The Government plans to establish new method of pricing gasoline next month that would increase the cost by cents a gallon, Energy Department sources said today.

title: Great Gray Owl Is Sighted In Parts of Nevi York State
description: ALBANY, Feb. 22  The great gray owl, normally a stranger south of the St. Lawrence River, has been sighted in increasing numbers lately in New York State, presumably because of lack of food in its normal habitat of the pine and soruce forests of the Arctic.

title: Stage: The Seagull That Went to Yale
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Coveted Homes In Tokyo Draw Many Suicides
description: TAKASHIMADAIRA, Japan  Recently a 26-year-old man plunged to his death from the top of an apartment building in Takashimadaira He was at least the 40th person to commit suicide by jumping from a high story at this huge complex of apartment buildings on the northeast outskirts of Tokyo since it was built in 1972, the largest apartment block in Japan.

title: California Legislators Defeat Move To Ask Constitutional Convention
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22  A resolution that would have added California to the 28 states petitioning Congress for constitutional convention, which had the allout support of Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., was defeated today in the State Assembly's Ways and Means Committee.

title: Interracial Couples Look at Life As Mixed Marriages Increase
description: When David Swanston told his mother he was getting married, she was afraid his reasons were more political than emotional. The product of a real WASPish upper-middle-class scene, as he put it, Mr. Swanston had served in the Peace Corps in Liberia, had been active in the civil rights movement, and then  at the age of 25  had decided to marry a black woman he'd met in college. My mother felt was using my marriage to make a definite statement to society on what I felt about the racial situation, and that that was a silly thing to do, Mr. Swanston said.

title: Two Enter Guilty Pleas to Fraud In L.I. InsurancePolicy Scheme
description: Two men who headed an insurancebrokerage company on Long Island pleaded guilty yesterday to a Federal charge of defrauding two credit companies of $8 million in a scheme involving loans on fictitous policies.

title: 62 Years at the Auction Block
description: Sixtytwo years ago, 19-year-old William J. Fischer caught his fingers in a rat trap on a shelf in the hardware store where he worked. The next day, with both hands bandaged and both arms in slings, he dr6pped in on an auction sale at Miller's, at the corner of University Place and 13th Street in Greenwich Vlllaee. Mr. Miller, startled by Mr. Fischer's bandages , interrupted his auctioneering to call out over the heads of the customers, I never saw anything like that beforewhat happened?

title: Illionis Bounds Sell Slowly
description: As taxexempt bond prices continued lower for the third straight week, Illinois sold $150 million of tripleA bonds yesterday that were priced to carry higher yields than topgrade bonds marketed earlier this month, and they met with only mildly enthusiastic interest from investors.

title: Berkowitz Says That He Faked Tales of Demons
description: Gives Interview in Effort to Scuttle Book Project ATTICA, N.Y., Feb. 22  David R. Berkowitz said today that there were no real demons, no talking dogs, no satanic henchmen who ordered him to kill six people as the Son of Sam. That story, he said, was just invented by me in my own mind to condone what I was doing.

title: RaceHorse Drug Rules Upheld by Jersey Court
description: TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 22 (AP) Regulations for administering a drug used to control bleeding in race horses were upheld today by the Appellate Division of Superior Court.

title: Iran Sees Oil Exports Soon
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 22 (AP)  A leader of Iran's new revolutionary Government announced today that the country's oil exports, cut off for months because of strikes, would resume very soon.

title: At the Movies
description: WITH me Magician, in which he plays the title role expected to be released the next couple of months, The InLaws, in which he plays a dentist, just completed, and Simon, in which he plays a member of the Columbia University faculty, scheduled to start production next week, Alan Arkin is in something very like actor's heaven these days.

title: Basques Accuse Spanish Police
description: MADRID, Feb. 22 (Reuters)  Fourteen Basque leftists have started a court action accusing the police of beating them during nine days in detention, legal sources said yesterday.

title: Premier Seeks to Build Authority Of the New Iranian Government
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 22  The Government of Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan moved today to expand its limited authority by formally establishing a national guard, completing formation of the Cabinet and initiating legislation to take over from secret revolutionary tribunals the prosecution of former officials now under arrest.

title: The Pop Life
description: RSO RECORDS, the people who brought you the film soundtrack for Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club, have unleashed a new album called Classic Rock. The principal artist is that hottest of bands, the London Symphony Orchestra.

title: Saks Expansion Set; Cost $200 Million
description: Saks Fifth Avenue, the nation's largest chain of fashion specialty stores, is planning to spend about $200 million in an expansion program over the next decade, includitg $22 million to remodel its flagship store on Fifth Avenue, its top officers said yesterday.

title: COMMODITIES Gold and Silver Futures React to Iran Oil Reports
description: Oil news from Iran had a strong impact on both gold and silver futures yesterday.

title: Legal Aid Lawyer Put in Handcuffs
description: A Brooklyn Criminal Court judge had a Legal Aid Society lawyer, who had objected to a court recess, handcuffed and jailed for an hour yesterday.

title: A Football Workaholic
description: He enjoyed calling himself just country boy from Mississippi as he reveled in his new role as coach of the Giants yesterday, but Ray Perkins perhaps revealed a truer side after the news conference had broken up and he

title: Marine, Freed By the Iranians, On Way Home
description: FRANKFURT, Feb. 22 (AP)  Sgt. Kenneth Kraus of the Marines, going home after a week of fear and uncertainty as a prisoner in Iran, flew here from Teheran today and went to a United States Army hospital for a medical checkup.

title: A MoscowPeking Pact Still Binds Antagonists
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 22  On Valentine's Day 1950, Mao Tsetung and Stalin signed a 30year treaty of friendship, alliance and mutual aid that included explicit provisions for joint defense. Despite the later falling out and

title: Rye and County Join to Develop Corporate Park
description: RYE. N.Y., Feb. 22  The County of Westchester and the Town of Rye signed an unusual agreement today to develop jointly a major corporate park on 300 acres below the main runway of the Westchester County Airport.

title: Syndrome Linked to Russian Flu
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 22 (UPI)  Federal health officials say that 100 cases of Reye syndrome, a rare but deadly complication of certain virus infections, have been reported this winter on the heels of Russian influenza outbreaks across the country.

title: U.S Lifts '78 Output Figures
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)A strong surge in consumer spending  at an annual rate of about $48 billion  advanced the nation's economy late last year even more rapidly than analysts previously believed, the Government reported today.

title: Shipbuilder Tells Court Union Election Is Invalid
description: RICHMOND. Feb. 22An attorney for the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company today told the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit here that a union election among the company's production maintenance workers 13 months ago was invalid because the National Labor Relations Board had not adequately controlled the balloting.

title: New Yorker Dividend
description: The New Yorker Maga;ire Inc. announced yesterday that its board of directors had declared a special dividend of $5 and the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share, both payable March 15 to stockholders of record March 8. A year ago, the company paid a $4 special dividend.

title: Most Rev. David F. Cunningham, Retired Bishop of Syracuse
description: The Most Rev. David F. Cunningham. the retired Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Syracuse, died yesterday at his home in Syracuse: He was 78 years old

title: Stewart Beach, 79; A Magazine Editor And Fiction Writer
description: Stewart Taft Beach, magazine editor and shortstory writer, died Wednesday at the Harkness Pavilion of Presbyterian Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Disabled Pupils To Get City Aid In Drivers Strike
description: Mayor Koch pledged the resources of the city yesterday to transport to school handicapped children stranded by wildcat strikers who have attacked and intimidated private carriers.

title: NEW ORLEANS POLICE REJECT NEW OFFER
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. M (AP) ing police officers rejected a contract proposal from the city tonight and continued a six-day-old walkout that had forced cancellation ofMardi Gras parades in the city.

title: Eugene Krarnon, 64; Was Injured in Crash In 1963 That Killed 5
description: Eugene Kramon, a New York businessman who was critically injured in 1963 in a three car-crash-in which five persons were killed and the son of a Bronx judge wa..4 indicted, died Wednesday of a cerebral hemmorrhage at the Latterday Saints Hospital in Salt Lake City. He was 64 years old and lived in New York City and San Francisco.

title: Topics Institutions
description: In 1965, J. Edgar Hoover assailed Martin Luther King Jr. as the most notorious liar in the country. Dr. King had dared to suggest that F.B.I. agents in the South were biased in favor of local sheriffs and against civil rights workers. There was some basis for questioning the bureau's racial credibility. Among 7,000 agents, only two dozen were black. There were not many more when Director Hoover died in 1972.

title: Less Peril Seen in Filter Cigarette
description: Scientists looking for precancerous cell changes in the lungs of cigarette smokers have found that such abnormalities have been far less common in the 1970's than they were in the 1950's.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1979

title: Associated Press
description: CARIBBEAN ISLAND GAINS INDEPENDENCE: A British Navy officer lowering the Union Jack for the last time in Castries, St. Lucia, Wednesday night. St. Lucia became independent after 177 years of British control.

title: Deaths
description: MAVERICKEdward of New York City, formerly, of san Antonio, Texas on February 21, 1979 offer a long illness. Uncle of Dexter Sammons of Wetherford Texas and Edward sammons of Scffner, Florida, Memorial service St. Thomas Episcopal Church. 5 Avenue & 31. Street. Monday. February 26 at 3PM. Fieese omit flowers. If desired, contributions may be made to Edward maverick Fund. New York Community Trust, 413 Madison Avenue, NY

title: Treasury Chief Off to China Today Despite Issue of Vietnam Invasion
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  The Carter Administration is going ahead with the scheduled trip by Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal to China tomorrow despite some strong reservations raised by officials who feared it would seem to substantiate Moscow's charges of American collusion in China's invasion of Vietnam.

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  The Su preme Court ruled today that foster children placed in the care of relatives must be given the same federally subsidized welfare benefits as foster children placed in the custody of strangers.

title: Ohira Defend,s Japan On Trade Record
description: TOKYO, Feb. 22  Expressing hopes of visiting the United States soon for meeting with President Carter, Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira today strongly defended Japan's economic and trade record.

title: Europe's Money Plan Is Pressed
description: PARIS, Feb. 22 (Reuters) France and West Germany reaffirmed their determination today to set up a new European monetary system as soon as possible. Their anterences over common Market farm prices have delayed the plan, intended to stabilize currency exchange rates. It was to have started Jan. 1.

title: Architecture of Last 20 Years Surveyed in Show at Modern
description: Very few years, the Mweurn of Modem Art, with a great heave, delivers itself of a Major Pronouncement on the state of architecture. Once, back in the 1530'S, the pronouncement was that the austere International Style was destined to take over the world; three years ago, the gospel according to the museum was that the ornate, classicisbr BeauxArts was back in favor.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: REDNECK MOTHERS, GOOD OL GIRLS AND OTHER SOUTHERN BELLES: A Celebration of the Women of Dixie. By Sharon McKern. 268 pages. Viking. $10.91

title: There's More in the Clubs Than Melancholy Baby
description: IT'S a woman's world in the cabarets this weekend. Women can be heard singing everything from blues to Broadway to soul. Li.lteners can choose among established stars who hold the spotlight firmly. others who are part of teams or who sing in conjunction with other talents, and still others who are working their way toward the top. It's all a far cry from the days when torch singers sang Melancholy Baby over and over again.

title: F.T.C.Chief Says Professional Groups Form Cartels, Inflating Fees
description: WASHINGTON,. Feb. 22 (AP)  Doctors, lawyers and other professionals set themselves up as business cartels that result in high fees to consumers, Michael Pertschuk, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said today.

title: Rhodesia White Tries to Ignore A Grim Future
description: KAROL Rhodesia  Peter wakhes dapper 50-year-old tobacco farmer who is doing police reserve duty, shook his head as the armored truck bounced along a dirt road in one of Rhodesia's remoter regions. I'm afraid I'm like the ostrich  head in the sand, he said. I've got to the point where I try not to think.

title: Finance Minister Quits, Surprising Australians
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 22  The Minister for Finance, Eric L. Robinson, resigned from the Cabinet last night. His departure marked the sixth time that a minister had quit since the conservative Government of Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser took office more than three years ago.

title: Ski Conditioris
description: For the first time in several weeks, skiers this weekend probably will not find natural powder snow topping surfaces at ski areas from the Poconos of Pennsylvania through New England.

title: Identity of Four Known Quickly In Airline Theft
description: Investigators of the $5.8 million Lufthansa robbery at Kennedy International Airport say they were informed soon after the Dec. 11 holdup of the identities of four of the six thieves who invaded the airline's cargo building.

title: March 11 Event to Honor Memory of Maude Brogan
description: Several artists who received grants from the Martha Baird Rockefeller Fund for Music will take part in a concert on March 11 honoring the memory of Maude Brogan, who died on Dec. 18. Miss Brogan had been director of the fund from 1971 until her death, and assistant director for 10 years before that.

title: For Children
description: DALTON SCHOOL MAGIC SHOW, with the Amaing Pandi, Marvin Park. and Irving Laurice. Saturday at 2:30 P.M.. in the school auditorium. 108 East 89th Street. Those younger then 7 must be accompanied by en adult. Admission, 52. Call 7725160.

title: The New York Times/D. Gorton
description: New Yorkers call them sewers, as in  the ball rolled down the sewer. Technzally they are called catch basins. what they are called after snowstorms is unprintable.

title: Reds Protest U.S. War Film
description: WEST BERLIN, Feb. 22  The Soviet Union and other Communist countries withdrew from the West Berlin Film Festival today to protest the showing of The Deer Hunter, an American movie about the Vietnam War.

description: A man who was repeatedly voted the world's best player died earlier this week in Palm Springs, Calif., and is being mourned throughout the world of bridge. Howard Schenken. a New

title: German Auto Output Up
description: FRANKFURT, Feb. 22 (AP) Motor vehicle production in West Germany rose 35 percent in January to 410,000 units from December's 302, 414 units, the auto manufacturers association said today. It attributed the increase to December cutbacks caused by a steel strike, holiday closings and rise in demand with the new year.

title: Guess Who Showed Up at Yankee Camp
description: FORT LAUDERDALE. Fla., Feb. 22  Billy Martin. Yankee superscout for 1979, showed up at the Yankees training camp today, still without a contract as Yankee manager for 198081.

title: U.C.L.A. Upset by Washington
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 22 (AP)  Stan Walker's 23foot jumper with three seconds to play tonight night gave Washington a 6968 upset victory over topranked University of California, Los Angeles, in a Pacific10 Conference basketball game at Edmundson Pavilion.

title: About Real Estate
description: On the brownstone streets near Prospect Park in the Park Slope area of Brooklyn, what one broker describes as the Brooklyn Heights phenomenon has begun. The housing market has grown sufficiently strong to tempt professionals into the rehabilitation held, competing with ownerusers for available houses.

title: Deaths
description: AMIDONBill, February 9, 1979 atter a long illness. Memorial service will be held at St. Mark's in the Bowery Church at 10th St & 2nd Ave, Satyrday, March 3 at 1PM.

description: THE fashionable trend toward lightness cooking is wholly desirable when it results sauces not overly thickened with flour, and preparations that are not overly contrived.

title: Japan Court Fines U.S. Executive
description: TOKYO, Feb. 22  Steven H. Hempel!, an American businessman, was found guilty today on charges of violating Japanese customs and liquor tax laws, fined $77,000 and given a susnended 18month orison sentence.

title: LABOR CHALLENGING THREAT OF SANCTION IN WAGEPRICE RULE
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 22  The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations announced today that it would attack in court the heart of the Carter Administration's voluntary wageprice control program, the threat of sanctions against companies that violate the rules.

title: Daomo
description: On the track, the curly blond hair and soft blue eyes seem angelic, giving him the look of a choir boy. But Len Miller. his coach, says that Steve Scott is more sauirrel than Sundayschool singer.

description: THE economists at Citibank attribute the weakness of the United States dollar and the strength of the German mark and Japanese yen to the different rates of inflation and monetary growth in the three countries and to the rational expectations of markets that weak monetary defenses a painst inflation here will continue. Unlike the

title: Wildlife Fund Predicts Better Chance for Tiger
description: MORGES, Switzerland, Feb. 22 (UPI)  The tiger, which was in danger of extinction 10 years ago, now has better prospects of survival, the World Wildlife Fund said here today.

title: AIR FORCE PLANNING STRATEGIC WEAPON
description: The Air Force is planning to modify a. mediumrange bomber into a new strategic weapon in the 1980's because senior officers do not believe that cruise missiles will be as effective in penetrating Soviet air defenses.

title: Transfer Rumors Surround Tonga
description: Dud Tongal, Fordham's 20yearold freshman center from the Sudan and the center of Coach Tom Penders's rebuilding program, said last night that there was still a possibility that he would transfer to Georgetown.

title: 2 Die in Navy Jet Crash
description: NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 22 (AP)  A Navy pilot and a bombadiernavigator were killed today in the crash of their jet plane at the Navy's Roosevelt Roads base in Puerto Rico, a spokesman for the Atlantic Fleet Air Force here said. Names of the victims were withheld pending notification of relatives.

title: Wagner Captures 16th Straight
description: Wagner College, which has been a Division I basketball team for only three years, completed the best regular season in its 58 years of basketball last night with an 8464 victory over St. Francis of Brooklyn.

title: Broadway
description: THERE is a theory that the problem with Broadway is not in its stars, but in its producers. Few producers produce plays season after season. Some, in fact, do not produce plays so much as they produce dates for plays. Therefore, it is nice to know that Frederick

title: Above the Battle in Asia
description: The only reliable information about Chinas invasion of Vietnam comes these days from reconnaissance satellites high in space. It is worse than watching a football game from a blimp. No American seems to know for sure how the battle is going or whither the Chinese are pointing. Peking has told the Carter Administration that the attack will be limited in time and scope, but nothing more. There remains a strong possibility that the Soviet Union will feel compelled to strike at China in ways that it, too, thinks are limited, or that Vietnam will dare to escalate the battle in ways designed to force the Russians hand.

description: HANKPUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursday, Feb. 22, 1979

title: $2.5 Billion Sale Of U.S. Notes Set
description: The Treasury will sell $2.5 billion of fouryear onemonth notes next Tuesday to raise new cash to help finance the Federal Government's budget deficit. The new notes will mature March 31, 1983.

title: Brown Asks Shoe Price Relief
description: Hundreds of companies have been asked to conform to Federal price guidelines, but only a handful have petitioned for relief.

title: Mets Will Begin Spring Training One Day Early
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 22 (UPI)  The New York Mets will get a oneday jump on spring training by holding a workout tomorrow morning, one day before the team's official reporting date for Ditchers and catchers.

title: Signs Appear That China's War Is Delaying Modernization Drive
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 22  There were several signs today that the sixdayold border war is beginning to have an effect on China's plans for economic modernization and its new outgoing diplomacy.

title: The New York Times/ Edward Hamner
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 22  Ray Perkins, who describes himself as just a guy who lives to work, went to work as 11th coach of the Giants today,.only 66 days after the 10th coach was dismissed and more thansix years since the National Football League team has had a winning record.

title: 45,500 Disabled Are Helped
description: New York City currently provides educational services to an estimated total of 95,500 handicapped youngsters at cost of $160 million a year.

title: $1 Million for a Goalie
description: LONDON, Feb. 22 (AP)  Phil Parkes, Queens Park Rangers goalkeeper, was sold to West Ham for about $1 million today and became the most expensive goalkeeper in British soccer. The figure is nearly twice as much as the previous record for a goalkeeper. That was the fee Nottingham Forest paid Stoke for Peter Shilton in 1977

title: Califano Seeks Approval for Plans To Trim Disabled Workers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, urged Congress today to approve changes in the Social Security disability program in an effort to reduce costs and increase work incentives.

title: A Musical on Evolution
description: The world, they say, is several mil lion years old. The Paper Bag Players have now reached the ripe old age of 20. To a young child, the difference is probably not such a great one. Time is an elusive element in daily life. This weekend, at the American Museum of Natural History, the Bags will celebrate the years with performances of Dandelion, their classic musical fan tasy based on Darwin's Theory of Evolution.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather et 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Utility Tax Is Challenged
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  A recent decision by the United States Court of Appeals here has challenged a Federal rule that permits utility companies to charge customers in utility bills for taxes the companies have not yet paid.

title: Benson Ford Faces Coast Drug Charges
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23  Benson Ford Jr., a part owner of the Ford Motor Company and a nephew of Henry Ford 2d, the company's chairman, will be arraigned on drug charges Monday in a municipal court in San Francisco.

title: Arraigned for Murder
description: Wayne Whaley leaving court after his arraignment in Mount Holly, N.J., yesterday for the murder of Dominick Gallucci. Mr. Whaley was arrested and charged with the murder along with Mr. Gallucci's wife, Lottie. and two their children. The family, authorites said, planned to collect his $20,000 life insurance policy. All are being held in custody.

title: Incentives Abound for Boys Five in Playoffs
description: If Boys and Girls High School's basketball team wins the Public Schools Athletic League Brooklyn championship tomorrow against Alexander Hamilton, it can be assured of three things-having a berth in the citywide semifinals, having the bestdressed coach, and having its cake and eating it, too.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON

title: Arbitrator Rules Against Murray
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 23 With no place to go but up after finishing last for two years, the New York Mets assembled their pitchers and catchers for spring training today and even scored a victory: a labor arbitrator upheld the management in a salary disoute with Dale Murray.

title: Around the Nation
description: DENVER, Feb. 23 (AP)  A Denver company must tear down or move its two buildings so that health officials can remove a radioactive dump abandoned more than 40 years ago, the Colorado Health Department says.

title: Ruling on Bias In Connecticut Is Held Invalid
description: A court order that imposed a racial tiliota on the hiring of firemen in Bridgeport, Conn., was dismissed yesterday by a Federal Appeals Court that questioned the sweeping affirmative relief.

description: The Disenfranchised 690,000

title: U.S. and China Open Ports to 2Way Trade Under Private Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  American and Chinese merchant ships are scheduled to begin sailing between Seattle and Shanghai without waiting for the United States and Chinese Governments to resolve legal issues or to negotiate a maritime treaty, officials here disclosed today.

description: Millions of barrels
