description: Nina Simone made her first appearance in a New York nightclub in 10 years on Thursday evening at the Village Gate, and she made it in what has become typical Nina Simone fashion.

title: Continental Pumps South China Sea Oil
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 23 (AP)  The Continental Oil Company has announced the start of the first commercial production of crude oil in the South China Sea.

title: Liquor Price Cuts Jolt Coast Market
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23  If a consumer can buy Chivas Regal for about the same price as Scorsky Scotch why not have the best, said a spokesman for a private labeler, Jay Ambrose of Santa Monica, Calif.

title: F.T.C. Permits Glass Unit Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)  The Federal Trade Commission withdrew its opposition today to the sale of a Columbus, Ohio, glass plant to the Lancaster Colony Corporation, also of Ca lumbus.

title: COMMODITIES Gold Futures Strengthen; Some Cite World Events
description: Gold futures ended this week's trading on the Commodity Exchange in New York at $253.70 an ounce for the March delivery, up from $248.60 a week before.

title: Fuel Oil Price Is Up 20% in New York Area
description: The price of homeheating oil in the New York metropolitan area has risen nearly 20 percent since the fall, from about 50 cents a gallon to 60 cents, an increase that will cost an average homeowner at least $100 this year and will add $200 million to the fuel bill for the entire metropolitan area.

title: Regional Postal Chief Hopes to Stay in City
description: The postmaster general for the Northeast region said yesterday that his inclination at this moment was to keep the regional headquarters in New York City rather than move it to New Rochelle and that his staff had narrowed their search for suitable office space here to one preferred building.

title: Chris Schwenk Drowns in Brazil; Was the Son of ExG.O.P. Leader
description: Chris Schwenk, the son of the former Suffolk County Republican leader, Edwin (Buzz) Schwenk, drowned Wednesday while swimming near the exclusive Sao Conrado Beach district in Rio de Janeiro, a family spokesman said yesterday. He was 26 years old.

title: Earthquake Jars Central Alaska
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska (UPI)  An earthquake measuring 4.6 on the Richter Scale shook east central Alaska just before midnight yesterday. No damage was reported. Seismologists at the University of Alaska's Geophysical Institute said the epicenter was about 10 miles outside of Fairbanks.

title: Schlesinger's Role in Gas Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  Energy. Secretary James R. Schlesinger, who angered the Mexicans by vetoing a 1977 naturalgas agreement, is expected to remain in the background during the forthcoming negotiations between the two nations on the pricing of Mexican natural gas, according to Administration officials.

title: Justice Official Named G.S.A. Acting Counsel
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)  Kurt W. Muellenberg, the head of the Justice Department's organized crime division, will join the General Services Administration Monday as acting special counsel, it was announced today.

title: Engineer in Fatal Train Collision Held Probably to Blame for Crash
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)  One of the engineers involved in the headon collision of two trains in Alabama last Sept. 18 is probably to blame for the crash, in which three persons died, according to the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: India Sees Slowdown, Rise in Unemployment
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 23  India's economy has slowed despite a sharp increase in industrial production.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: New Chief Sifts Options Of A.T. &
description: The new chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that he was ready without preconceptions to explore alternative futures for A.T. & T. in  order to resolve the various policy disputes touched off by the arrival of competition to the industry.

title: Bridge:
description: L. I. Qualifiers Dominate Grand National Team Play

title: Park Service Rescinds Permit for Nazi Rally At Independence Mall
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Allstate Financial Files for Offering
description: The Allstate Financial Corporation said it had filed a registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed public offering of 150 million of senior notes due March 15, 1986. The notes are not redeemable before March 15.1984.

title: 2 in a Hijacked Copter Rob Bank in Montreal
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 23 (AP) A man and a woman swooped into a Montreal shopping center today aboard a hijacked helicopter, held up a bank and then made their getaway by air and subway, the police reported.

title: Yanks Are Cheered by Progress
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 23 -To the surprise of virtually everyone but himself, Don Gullett threw a baseball for 15 minutes today. He simply walked into the Yankee camp, picked up a baseball and actually threw it, in the bull pen at Fort Lauderdale Stadiurn.

title: State Justice Arthur Aulisi, 71; Served on Welfare Inquiry Panel
description: State Supreme Court Justice Arthur C. Aulisi died Thursday at his home in Gloversville. N.Y. He was 71 years old.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HANDY WORK The Museum of Modern Art's current display of 24 pieces created by Jackie Winsor, the young sculptor, has been called an important exhibition by art critics. As a supplement to the show, this morning at 10 o'clock the museum is presenting the artist in a discussion of her work, a lecture especially geared for students and teachers. Museum visitors can then see the artist's sculptures in the firstfloor galleries. The show runs until March 6.

title: Modzelewski Quits Giants
description: Dick Modzelewski, disappointed that he was not considered for the Giants head coaching position, resigned yesterday as the team's defensive coordinator and was hired by the Cincinnati Bengals as defensive line coach.

title: Family Planning Unit Wins Court Aid Fight
description: ST. PAUL. Minn., Feb. 23 (AP)  A Federal district judge ruled today that Planned Parenthood, a nonprofit corporation that operates an abortion clinic in St. Paul, cannot be denied state money for prepregnancy family planning services.

title: New York's Administrative Judge
description: When Herbert B. Evans, the state's new administrative judge, was a student in the late 1930's at DuSable High School on Chicago's South Side, he was appalled that lowcost housing in the neighborhood was seeremted. It was then, he recalled yesterday, that he decided to become a lawyer. In his high school yearbook, he said he would enter the law to eliminate discrimination in housing.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Economy

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 44.

title: 2 Americans, Hurt by Explosion In Polish Bank, Called All Right
description: WARSAW, Feb. 23 (Reuters)  Two American citizens who were injured in a gas explosion that killed 49 people in a Warsaw bank last week are doing all right in a hospital here, a spokesman at the American Embassy said today.

title: CHINESE INCREASING PRESSURE ON TOWN IN VIETNAM ATTACK
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 23  Fighting continued near the Vietnamese provincial capital of Lang Son today as the Chinese invading army maintained its heavy pressure on Vietnamese defenders, Western analysts reported. An analyst said that Lang Son was probably in Chinese hands.

title: Why Prices Keep Rising
description: Heatingoil prices first started climbing last fall, after a year and a half of relative stability. Oil analysts said then that the sudden spurt was merely a catchup round of increases traceable to the steadily rising costs that heatingoil dealers had been absorbing all along.

title: Syria Denies Persecution of Jews
description: Syria's chief delegate to the United Nations denied yesterday that members of the Jewish community in his country were persecuted. He accused Zionist groups of spreading such reports to divert attention from recent charges that Israel had,abused Arab political prisoners.

title: Army Women's Five Wins
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 23 Kim Hall's bank shot with one second remaining gave the Army women's team a 5048 victory over St. John's in the opening round of the New York State tournament at Iona College's Mulcahy. Center.

title: Sheryl Sutton Speaks Tales As She Dances
description: Sheryl Sutton, who performed Thursday night at the Squat Theater, may want her dancing to resemble thinking. Thus her long and very fascinating solo, Who What Where When and Why, was more than bodily motion; it resembled thought processes made visible.

title: Success Not Spoiling Lighthearted Zoeller
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23  During a round of competition the orthodox golf professional looks as if he is undergoing rootcanal dentistry combined with a stomachpumping operation. He usually gives the impression he would rather be elsewhere.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: The Region
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  John De Poli, a restaurant owner reputed to have ties to organized crime, was indicted on two counts of incometax evasion. Richard Blumenthal, the United States Attorney for Connecticut, said that Mr. De Poli, 56 years old, of Greenwich, had reported a total of $22,861 in income for 1972 and 1973 while the indictment charged that that he had received $231,128. Conviction could bring a sentence of five years and a $10,000 fine on each count.

title: Greeks Put A Freeze On Prices
description: ATHENS. Feb. 23 (AP)  The Greek Government froze prices at yearend levels today and adopted several other restrictive measures in an attempt to prevent a sharp increase in inflation.

title: Jury Awards $617,535 to Mother Of Woman Slain by Police Officer
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 (AP)  A Federal jury has awarded $617,536 to the mother of a 19-year-old Bucks County woman killed by an Upper Moreland police officer when he was on duty Jan. 4, 1977.

title: German Trade Surplus
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, Feb. 2.3 (AP)  West Germany had a January trade surplus of $1.1 billion, down from December's $2.1 billion and up from the yearearlier $1 billion, the Federal Statistics Office reported today. Exports last month totaled $12.5 billion, and imports were $11.4 billion.

title: Concert of Contemporary Music
description: By their very nature, concerts of contemporary music tend to be chancy affairs, containing as much, if not more, dross than quality. The last two programs presented by the League of ComposersInternational Society for Contemporary Music in Carnegie Recital Hall had their fair share of marginalia, but several works did stand out as being a bit special and well worth any openminded listener's attention.

title: WELLS RICHARDSON
description: Wells Richardson, a retired actor featured in several Broadway theater productions including The Bad Seed, The Duke in Darkness and Between Two Worlds, died Thursday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital Medical Center.

title: Oregon City Feels a Difference as Outsiders Move In
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 21  This month the family that had owned the Blitz Weinhard Brewing Company for 123 years announced its sale to the Pabst Brewing Company of Milwaukee.

title: Victory by Columbia Bolsters N.I.T. Hope
description: Since the Ivy League title and the automatic berth in the National Collegiate tournament had already been secured by Penn, Columbia set its sights on a bid to the National Invitation Tournament last night and scored a 6452 victory over Princeton in Levien Gymnasium.

title: The Other Index Also Counts
description: The greater the inflation rate, the greater the likelihood that the country will resort once again to the traditional cure: higher unemployment. Confirmation yesterday that inflation in January had soared into the double digits only increases the chances of another recession eventually. An especially disturbing aspect of

title: Designer Labels For Girls
description: Motherdaughter dressing isn't what it used to be. The idea now is to match not the clothes but the label  if, that is, Mother is the type who wears Yves Saint Laurent, Anne Klein or Cacharel. All three are now making little girls clothes.

title: Prophet, Priest and King
description: Perhaps because I am an outsider, I can sympathize with the statement by Pope John Paul II to the Latin American bishops that the Roman Catholic Church's mission is religious and not social and political. In his speech, he

title: Ephemeral Design of an Immortal Theme
description: In the snow near Castle Garden at Battery Park, traced by the tracks of an admirer, is a fond tribute to Sonia. This fleeting message of a lasting thought, however, must soon succumb to inevitable rising temperatures. Perhaps Sonia has seen it, insuring that it will never fade away.

description: No one has ever figured out what creative inspiration is or what it is that causes artists to better work on some occasions than niters. in the case of opera composers, the clu,i,stion can become especially pemlex,n2 on occasion

title: Pizza Parlor Operator Is Accused Of Killing a Man in Harassment
description: A 47-year-old midtown pizzaparlor owner was charged with homicide yesterday after a man he shot for harassing him died at St. Clare's Hospital, the police reported.

title: U.S.Japan Trade Fight Grows on Nippon Phone
description: TOKYO, Feb. 23  A complex struggle between the United States and Japan over the procurement practices of the giant Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, which places orders worth $3 billion a year, is reaching a crucial stage.

title: Lincoln National On Merger Rejection
description: The Lincoln National Corporation said it was disappointed with the rejection Thursday by the American Reinsurance Company's board of directors of Lincoln National's proposal to acquire American ReInsurance.

title: Police Ask Public Help in Solving Murder of Tin Harlem Apartment
description: Chief Martin Duffy of the Manhattan Detective Area appealed yesterday to the public to report to the police any information that might help solve the murders of seven persons, whose bodies were found in a Harlem apartment last Tuesday nieht.

title: 2 Tellers Slain in Utah Holdup
description: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Feb. 23 (UPI) A short, chubby holdup man wearing a cowboy hat entered the Zions First National Bank and killed two tellers today. The Emery County Sheriff's office said the killer had used a .22caliber weapon and escaped with an undetermined amount of cash in a car with three other men.

title: An Die Musik Chamber Group at Alice Tully Hall
description: An Die Musik is best known as the  title of a Schubert song. But it is.also what an awkwardly named, oddly or-  ganized chamber ensemble calls itself. Formed three years ago, the quintet consists of players from all over the

title: British Customs Officers Strike, Making a Paradise for Smugglers
description: LONDON, Feb. 23  England was a smuggler's paradise for a day as customs officers stopped work today for 24 hours, along with thousands of other white-collar civil servants, in a bitter dispute over nay.

title: U.S., in U.N., Calls for Invaders To Quit Vietnam and Cambodia
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 23 The United States called in the Security Council tonight for a ceasefire in the fighting in Indochina and urged the parties involved to move the dispute to the negotiating table.

title: Al Cobbs Band Plays for Dances
description: A faint echo of the Jimmie Lunceford Orchestra, one of the more distinctive big bands of the 1930's and 90's, can still be heard in the Rainbow Room on the 65th floor of the RCA Building, where Al Cobbs's eightpiece band is playing for dances this week and next, Tuesdays through Sundays. The Lunceford

description: FRIDAY, FEB. 23, 1979

title: Cubs. Phils in 8Man Trade
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP) - The Chicago Cubs sent Manny Trillo. the second baseman, and two other players to the Philadelphia Phillies today in an eightplayer trade.

title: East Europe's Debt to West
description: BONN, Feb. 23 (Reuters)  The Communist countries of Eastern Europe owe Western industrialized nations about $54 billion, the West German Government said today.

title: Durang's Nature Purpose
description: Christopher Durang is one of our leading stage practitioners of collegiate humor, and sometimes he does it wonderfully well.

title: Associated Press
description: TWOPOINT SLAM: Nets Bernard King scoring 2 points as Trail Blazers Bob Gross attempts to defend during game last night at Piscataway, N.J. Nets won game, 11049.

title: Gov. Grasso to Press Plan to Limit State Spending
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 23  Governor Ella T. Grasso disclosed today details of a proposedconstitutional amendment to limit state spending. But she acknowledged that because of legislative opposition, the proposal was not likely to be enacted this year.

title: 10Day Car Sales Dip Slightly
description: DETROIT, Feb. 23 (UPI)  Domestic car sales by the Big Three auto makers dipped slightly in the middle of this month, with the Ford Motor Company reporting the only gain over the corresponding period a year ago.

title: Deaths
description: MOOREJ. Kenneth. Good friend and colleague, brilliant scientist, gentleman and scholar, your friends at ThomsonCSF Laboratories will miss you sorely.

title: City Officials to Help Drive Handicapped to School
description: City Commissioners, Councilmen and municipal employees, will begin driving 450 physically handicapped children to school Monday in an expanding program that is scheduled to continue until a wildcat strike by school bus drivers ends.

title: Ferstl Finishes Downhill Sweep
description: WILMINGTON, N.Y., Feb. 23 Sepp Fersti, the 25-year-old Alpine racer from the tiny village of Rupolding  near Berchtesgaden  completed today a West German sweep of the two United States downhill skiing championships.

title: Russians Cancel Party At Embassy in Peking
description: TOKYO, Feb. 23 (AP)  The Soviet Embassy in Peking canceled a party scheduled for tonight, saying it did not want to entertain officials of Chinese invader forces, Japan's Kyodo news service reported.

title: Books of The Times
description: Bruce Mason, the protagonist or wallace Stegner's Recapitulation, is a retired Ambassador. In returning to Salt Lake City after an absence of 45 years, he becomes an ambassador in reverse, someone going backward into his own country to negotiate there for peace and amicable relationships.

title: A Mississippi Boy, 14, Serving 48Year Term, To Be Tried by a Jury
description: BROOKHAVEN, Miss. (AP)  Robert Earl May Jr., a 14-year-old who pleaded guilty to four armed robbery charges and, without ever being tried, was sentenced to 98 years in prison with no chance of parole, was granted a trial and freed on bond today after serving a month in prison.

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDERAbraham. The Officers & Members of The West Washington Market Mens Club express their deep sorrow at the passing 01 one of its founding members. Our deep felt sympathy to his wife & family.

title: Wide Choice Is Offered To Aides of the E.P.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  While Jody Powell, the White House press secretary, was inviting officials of the Environmental Protection Agency earlier this week to resign if they were disgruntled, President Carter was telling the head of that agency that he was very happy with its work, according to Administration officials.

title: Police in Capital Ban Tractors After Seizing 4 Farmers at Rally
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI)  The arrest of four farmers during a demonstration at the White House today prompted the police to ban any further 1 tractor convoys through the streets of I Washincrtnn

title: CLASH OVER $34,900 OPENS EILBERG TRIAL
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 (UPI) The prosecutor in the trial of former Representative Joshua Eilberg told the jury today that Mr. Eilberg illegally received $34,900 in August 1976 for helping a Philadelphia hospital obtain a $14.5 million Federal grant.

title: OBSERVER
description: One of the deeds that progress will have to answer for sooner or later is its destruction of civilized travel. Thus, when Ayatollah Khomeini wanted to return to Iran to claim his triumph, he was forced to fly.

title: Otto
description: SHOHOLA, Pa., Feb. 23  The mystery of a chef's identity  a conundrum posed this week by a New Yorker magazine profile of an anonymous culinary genius who was said to create magnificent meals at an unknown restaurant somewhere within 100 miles of New York City  was solved last night.

title: Southern Industries And Dravo Pact
description: The Dravo Corporation and the Southern Industries Corporation announced they had signed a definitive merger agreement whereby Southern Industries will become a wholly owned subsidiary of Dravo. The companies had previously reached an agreement to mem.

title: United Press International
description: HISTORIC PAINTING VANDALIZED IN ITALY: The Virgin of Nicopeia, a 10thcentury Byzantine painting at St. Mark's Basilica in Venice, was damaged when three men removed jewels valued at over $1 million that adorned it, and fled with gems. Broken lines show area where jewels were removed.

title: Penn Wraps Up Ivy Title, 8572
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 23 - The University of Pennsylvania built a 4432 halftime lead, then scored the first 8 points of the second half and cruised to an 8572 college basketball victory over Come11 tonieht.

title: Striking the Mardi Gras
description: This is the time of the year when folks in New Orleans sing, Let your sweetest dreams come true, come to the Mardi Gras. There will be no sweet dreams on Bourbon Street this year. The festivities have been canceled because the city's 1,100 policemen are on strike.

title: JANUARY RISE 0.9%
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  Consumer prices rose by ninetenths of 1 percent last month, the Government reported today. The sharply higher prices indicated that the Administration's efforts to retard inflation had so far failed.

title: Soviet Military Men Assail China, But Shun Any Hint of Retaliation
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 23  Several of the Soviet Union's top military leaders spoke out strongly today against China's invasion of Vietnam, but carefully avoided any suggestion that Moscow might retaliate.

title: About New York
description: And now, for his retirement years, Paul O'Dwyer thinks: Why not bring down Jimmy Carter?

title: LEGISLATIVE TACTICS. MODIFIED BY LABOR
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 23  Organized labor is modifying its tactics in an effort to improve its weak showing on the political and organizing fronts. The new policies, made public today by the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations 35member Executive Council meeting here, seem aimed at depending less on Congress and more on local efforts.

title: Island Five, Queens in City Final
description: Topseeded Staten Island scored the first 10 points of the second half to break open a close game and defeat Brooklyn College, 7761, last night in the City University basketball tournament semifinals at City College's Nat Holman Gymnasium.

title: A Store Owner in Rego Park Kills Robbery Suspect, Shoots Other
description: The owner of a modeltrain store in Queens shot two alleged armed robbers yesterday, killing one and seriously wounding the other.

title: Blumenthal Defends Visit
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Feb. 23 Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal, flying to Peking for an official visit, said today that the Carter Administration believed it could lay the foundation for normal economic relations with China despite the fighting between Chinese and Vietnamese troons.

title: Harlem Troupe Dances de Lavallade
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem, directed.by Arthur Mitchell and Karel Shook, swept in an array of new works by a disparate group of choreographers Thursday night at the City Center55th Street Theater. The combined effect was a happy one. This second of three programs in the company's current season is well worth going out of the way to see. The dancers, too, this time around, were superb.

title: Corporate Earnings Are Reported for the Quarter
Woolworth's at 100: A Tuneful Bit of Five and Dime Nostalgia
description: The 600 or so people sipping champagne and nibbling hors d'oeuvres and raw vegetables beneath the vaulted ceiling in the marble lobby of the Woolworth Building on lower Broadway Thursday night weren't there to toast George Washington's birthday (he would have been 247). Rather. the noisy celebration was in honor of another bit of Americana, the 100th anniversary of the opening of Frank Winfield Woolworth's first 5 and 10 Cent store. It was in Utica, N.Y., and although it soon failed, the one that opened in Lancaster, Pa., the following June was a success. This being a party, the emphasis was on the fact that there are 1,419 Woolworth stores throughout the United States today.

title: News Summary

title: A Vast Interdisciplinary Effort To Predict Climate Trend Urged
description: GENEVA, Feb. 23  After exchanging views here for two weeks, the people who know more about climate than anyone else in the world have concluded that climate's future trends can be predicted in a meaningful way only after an interdisciolinary effort of unprecedented scope.

title: Files of Nixon White House Show Bid to Control Public Broadcasting
description: Efforts by the Nixon Administration to control public broadcasting, purge it of commentators considered hostile to the President and reorganize it so it might serve the Administration's aims are detailed in newly disclosed doctiments from files of the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy for 1969 to 1974.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: DETROIT, Feb. 23 (AP)  The General Motors Corporation is appealing its court loss to the Toyota Motor Company, which G.M. accuses of stealing its design of an antipollution device.

title: Iran's Power Goes to Those With Nerve or Connections
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 23  The hardest part of getting anything accomplished in Iran these days is finding out who has the authority to approve it. There is such a vacuum throughout the country that power is falling into the hands of anyone who has the daring and strength to seize it.

title: Ailey Repertory Ensemble at the Riverside Church
description: The Alvin Ailey Repertory Ensemble was formed in 1979 to develop performance skills in promising students at Mr. Ailey's American Dance Center, to bring dance to dancedeprived institutions and towns along the East Coast and to develop new choreoeraohers. On

title: Koch Names Capalino As New Commissioner For General Services
description: James F. Capalino, the 2S-year-old director of Mayor Koch's Community Board Assistance Unit, was named by the Mayor yesterday to the $54,000-a-year post of Commissioner of General Services.

title: City Opera, Now 35, Opens Season With Cheniee

title: New Yorker, 63, Is Found Guilty In T.W.A. Attempted Skyjacking
description: A Federal Court jury in Brooklyn yesterday found a 63-year-old New Yorker guilty of threatening to blow up a New York-to-Geneva Trans World Airlines jet last Aug.28 unless Rudolf Hess, Sirhan Sirhan and others were freed from. prison. No bomb was ever found.

title: Deaths
description: GREENBLATTMurry formerly of Bklyn. and Rockaway Beach. Died February 22 after BO M. His 3 children and 8 grandchildren. to whom he gave so much, will miss him. Services at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 9860 Oueens Blvd, Rego Park, N.Y., Sunday, February 25 at 12:30PM.

title: China's Lost Chance: No Quick, Easy Victory in Vietnam
description: Military sources in Washington, Tokyo and at NATO headquarters in Brussels believe that the Chinese Army has missed its chance for a quick and relatively cheap victory in Vietnam, largely because the irregular Vietnamese forces on the frontier evaded a major encounter.

title: Long Day's Journey Into Prayer
description: LONDON

title: Canada. Tells of Plans For $50 Gold Pieces
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 23 (AP) Canada announced today that it would produce $50 gold pieces for trading on the world gold markets.

title: Sales Chief At Chrysler To Leave
description: DETROIT, Feb. 23  The Chrysler Corporation, its newcar sales still trailing those of a year ago, announced today the early retirement of Robert K. Brown, executive vice president for sales and marketing, the company's highestranking sales official.

title: LEFTISTS IN TEHERAN HOLD DEFIANT RALLY
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 23  Turning their backs on Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's direct order to stay away, 70,000 to 80,000 Iranians attended a rally today staged by the People's Fedayeen, an extreme leftwing organization. For

title: Saudi Leader Drops His Visit to U.S. Amid Conflicting Explanations
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  With relations between Saudi Arabia and the United States already strained, Crown Prince Fand has canceled plans to come to Washington next month amid conflicting explanations for the decision.

title: G.M. Hopeful On Iranian Oil
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (UPI)  Thomas A. Murphy, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, said today that he was optimistic Iran would soon resume the sale of oil to the United States, heading off the likelihood of a serious energy shortage or other business crisis this year.

title: Douglas Dunn Presents Dances
description: Douglas Dunn is a protean choreographer. His dances are forever changing shape. They change so much that, even though they all have individual titles, one sometimes wonders whether they have individual identities.

title: Nets Top Blazers By 11099
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Feb. 23  Jack RamSay has coached college and professional basketball teams for 21 years, and his squads have won almost 60 percent of the names. He had the best record of any pro coach in the five seasons before this one. His 197677 Portland Trail Blazers won a National Basketball Association championship, which automatically qualified Ramsay for the title of genius.

title: Transit Officer Cleared In Killing of Girl in IND
description: A New York City transit policeman who shot and killed a 17-year-old girl during a struggle with a suspect on a crowded Herald Square subway platform was cleared of any wrongdoing yesterday by a Manhattan erand iurv.

title: 25 Food Establishments Cited in Code Violations
description: The New York City Health Department cited 25 food establishments it says have violated the Health Code. It also listed four food establishments and one pet shop it has closed for failing to correct earlier violations. The places listed were:

title: Officer Slain in Basque Region Is 24th Spanish Death of Year
description: DEVA, Spain, Feb. 23 (UPI)  Terrorists presumed to be Basque separatists shot a federal policeman to death when he stopped his car at a crossroads today. It was the 24th terrorist slaying of the year in Spain.

title: Market Registers A Retreat
description: The plunging price of stock of the Polaroid Corporation cast a pall over the entire market yesterday as virtually all sectors staged a retreat.

title: U.S. Gold Sale Brings Peak Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)  The Treasury Department said today that $378 million was raised yesterday by selling 1.5 million ounces of gold at record prices.

title: Suspects Routed in Carolina Violence Fatal to Five
description: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C., 5. 23 (,\P)  Fifty policemen lobbeJ tear gas into a secondstory motel room ear'.y today to rout two men suspected of murder, abduction, rape and robbery across 100 miles of coastal South Carolina.

title: Iran Urges That Swiss Freeze Assets of Shah
description: GENEVA, Feb. 23  The new Iranian Government has called for the freezing of all assets in Switzerland of the exiled Shah, Mohammed Riza Pahievi, and members of his family, the Swiss Foreign Ministry said today.

title: New Orleans Offering Blanket Amnesty to Police
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 23 (AP)  City negotiators offered a blanket amnesty today to 1,100 striking policemen in an effort to end a strike that has disrupted the Mardi Gras celebration and garbage pickups. The strike is now threatening to spill over to the city's port, the nation's second largest in tonnage.

title: Letter: On Con Ed's Pollution
description: Balancing Energy Costs and Clean Air

title: Rhodesia Bombs Base in Zambia; Hundreds of Casualties Reported
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Feb. 23 (AP) Rhodesian planes bombed a black nationalist camp 22 miles west of Lusaka today in what the Rhodesian Government said was its continuing effort to prevent guerrillas from sabotaging elections scheduled for April.

title: U.S. Accuses Associated Press With Jobs Discrimination Policy
description: The United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed suit yesterday against The Associated Press, charging the wire service with discriminatory employment policies against women, blacks and Hispanics. rapers tiled in United States District Court in Manhattan asked that The Associated Press be enjoined from such practices and be ordered to issue back pay to those against whom it allegedly discriminated.

title: Israeli Strategist Calls Iran A New Source of Instability
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 23  In a small, cramped room at Tel Aviv University, Aharon Yariv busily analyzes the military and strategic problems facing Israel. He confesses that his mood is gloomy.

title: Desai's Kin to Be Investigated
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 23 (AP)  The Chief Justice of India's Supreme Court will investigate corruption charges against members of the families of Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai and Deputy Prime Minister Charan Singh, the Government announced today. The ruling Janata Party and the opposition have been debatine the issue for months.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, Feb. 23 (UPI)  The Italian Communist Party, in a considerable moderation of its previous demands, said today that it would seek more power in a government led by Ugo La Malfa but would also consider supporting a cabinet in which it did not have seats.

title: Carter to Act if Arms Treaty Fails
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  President Carter is prepared to match any Soviet restraint on strategic weapons if the Senate refuses to approve a new strategic arms limitation agreement, the White House said today.

title: Miss Young, 16, Sets Indoor Hurdles Mark
description: A star was born in Madison Square Garden last night. Her name is Canzetta Young, but Candy will do just fine; she is 16 years old, lives in Beaver Falls, Pa., and set a world indoor record in the women's 60yard high hurdles_

title: Reporting the War: Facts Elusive
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 23  The terrain on which the Vietnamese defenders are meeting the Chinese invaders is mountainous, remote and closed to foreigners. The Governments involved have never felt an obligation to tell their own people or the world what they are doing and what is being done to them

title: Allen Ginsberg Gets Arts Medal
description: Allen Ginsberg, the poet, was awarded the National Arts Club's Medal of Honor for Literature in a ceremony Thursday evening at the organization's house on Grammercy Park South. Mr. Ginsberg was extolled by

title: Unitrode Suit Names Dynamics, Rooney
description: The Unitrode Corporation, a maker of semiconductor devices, said it had commenced its litigation against the Dynamics Corporation of America and Rooney Pace Inc., a New York brokerage firm, in connection with Dynamic's acquisition of a 9.7 percent interest in Unitrode.

title: Braniff Pays $100,000 Fine
description: SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 23 (AP)  Braniff Airways paid a $100,000 fine here today stemming from Federal criminal antitrust charges against Braniff and Texas International Airlines for trying to block service of a Texas commuter airline.

title: Hospital, Facing Review, Transfers Some Patients
description: Kings County Psychiatric Hospital in Brooklyn is transferring many of its patients to other municipal hospitals to avoid a finding of overcrowding and possible disaccreditation when a national hospital inspection team visits next week, city hospital officials confirmed last night.

title: Noted Elderly Mucks Honored by President At the White House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) - President Carter honored Jesse OwenS, the Rev. Martin Luther King Sr. and 15 other elderly blacks today for their contributions to society.

title: The Meeting at Panmunjom
description: After a sixyear hiatus, North and South Korea have resumed their peace negotiations. Even as Chinese troops smashed into Vietnam, representatives of the two Koreas met at Panmunjom. They shook hands and exchanged polite greetings for the benefit of photographers, and then held a meeting whose most important agreement was to hold another meeting on March 7.

title: Photos of Auschwitz Extermination Unit Produced
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  Using sophisticated, modern photoanalysis techniques on World War II aerial reconnaissance film, two Central Intelligence Agency analysts have produced the only known photographs of the Birkenau extermination unit at the Auschwitz concentration camp.

title: Beef, Fruits and Vegetables Key PriceRise Factors
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  Last month's rises in food prices, which accounted for nearly a third of the increase in the January Consumer Price Index, were attributed today to sharply higher prices for beef, fresh fruits and vegetables.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 19.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Come-to-Alaska Ad Is Called Sexist
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, Feb. 23 (AP)  A $150,000 advertisement display featuring a bikiniclad model extolling the glories of vacations in the frozen North has raised the temperatures of Alaska legislators and feminists.

title: Anna Lord Strauss, 79, a Leader With League of Women Voters
description: Anna Lord Strauss, a former president of the National League of Women Voters and a prominent supporter of various civic groups, died yesterday in her. New York City apartment. She was 79 years old

title: Jane Blalock, On 66, Leads L.P.G.A. Event
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 23 Stringing together three birdies over the last five holes, Jane Blalock carded a six-under-par 66 at Pasadena Golf Club today to match a course record and take a twoshot lead after the opening round of the 26th annual Orange Blossom classic.

title: Japan Removes Bond Curbs
description: TOKYO, Feb. 23 (AP)  The Finance Ministry said today that it would lift restrictions on foreigners purchase of Japanese bonds, effective tomorrow, ending emergency measures to limit flows of speculative shortterm funds into Japan.

title: Aaueduct Adds Exactas As Labor Talks Resume
description: Exacta wagering was added to the program at Aqueduct yesterday as negotiations resumed in the labor dispute between the New York Racing Association and its unionized parimutuel clerks.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: FairEmployment Agency Cleans Up Its Backlog
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 23  A year and a half after beginning an overhaul of the way it handles cases, the Equal Employrngnt Opportunity Commission has significantly reduced its backlog of 135,000 cases and shortened the average time for conciliating jobdiscrimination disputes from two years to 65 days.

title: Carter May Visit Home Of a California Family
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) President Carter is expected to spend next Friday night with a MexicanAmerican family when he visits Los Angeles for a Democratic fundraising dinner.

title: Yale Students Offer Tech
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 23  The hottest new course at Yale this term is not taught by a famous scholar. The 84 enrolled students receive no credit. There are no term papers. The course is auto mechanics.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a review of a Festival of Drums in The Times on Feb. 13, Julito Collazo was incorrectly listed as the leader of a drum ensemble. Although listed in the program, Mr. Collazo did not perform that evening. The performer was Gene Golden.

title: J.P. RICHARDS DIES; EXCONGRESSMAN, 84
description: James P. Richards, former United States Representative from South Carolina and chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, died Wednesday. He was 84 years old and lived in Lancaster, S.C.

title: 6 Big Oil Concerns Under State Inquiry
description: ALBANY, Feb. 23  Citing the apparent inability of the National Administration to come to grips with oilprice increases, New York State's Energy Commissioner, James L. Larocca, today ordered a fullscale investigation into the pricing and supply policies of six major oil companies.

title: The Thinking Fighter Thinks
description: Red Smith

title: Durbano Gets Suspension
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 23 (UPI)  Steve Durbano, the defenseman for the St. Louis Blues, was suspended for five games, and the Nick Fotiu of the Rangers was fined $300 today for a stickswinging brawl that cleared both benches in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last Wednesday.

title: The Region
description: Mayor Koch refused to apologize last week after calling schoolbus drivers who are staging a wildcat strike bastards and goons. As matter of fact, he said. I don't think my language was strong enough.

title: ART; Drawing on Their Talents
description: SOUTHAMPTON WHATEVER happened to drawing? This question is frequently heard in art circles these days, as if the artistic discipline had vanished forever.

title: World News Briefs
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Feb. 24 (UPI)  The lawyer for Zulfikar Ali Bhutto pleaded with the Supreme Court today to commute the former Prime Minister's death sentence because of the narrow split decision of the court in upholding his conviction.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: BALDWIN  Works by Anna M. Klein; through Wednesday; Library, 2385 Grand Ave. For hours,2236228.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS
description: DEER PARK ONCE a year, a couple from Ohio drive all the way to Matty T's Nashville USA, a little bar on Commack Road in Deer Park to hear the country music of Levi and Ruth and the Country Wranglers. Even more regularly, people show up from Brooklyn and Staten Island to mix with the truckers, firemen and dancecrazy locals of all ages who like a little twang and fancy guitarpicking with their weekend fun.

title: New Marine Mammal Facility
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP)  The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced today that it has established a research laboratory in Seattle for studies of marine mammals. The agency said the facility, the National Marine Mammal Laboratory, would take the lead in nationwide research as well as fulfilling United States commitments under international agreements on marine mammals.

title: States Trying a Variety of Ways To Reduce Taxes and Spending
description: State legislatures and governors around the country are engrossed in a number of proposals for limiting or cutting spending and taxes, proposals that are expected to result in a reduction of several billion dollars in revenues and a subsequent cut in services over the next few years.

title: Quarterback Is Major Problem for Perkins
description: The day last week that Ray Perkins was named head coach of the Giants. Joe Pisarcik was having a party, Randy Dean was thinking about Stanford Business School and Jerry Golsteyn was putting up fences.

title: Calendar of Events:
description: Art Exchange Auction, Roosevelt Hall, Hofstra University, Hempstead.

title: Designers: Where, Why and How Much
description: SITTING in her New Canaan office recently, Fran Wildon received a call from a client, the wife of an executive who had been transferred to the area. Be sure to find a prominent spot for grandma's clock in the master plan you're drawing up for the living room, urged the caller. It's very important to us.

title: Officiai Urges Tax Adjustment for Infiation
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24  The Assembly's minority leader, James L. Emery, today proposed relating the state's incometax brackets to the inflation rate, to prevent inflation from pushing taxpayers into higher tax brackets.

title: Alan Day Is Fianc Of Jane K. Crosby, A Mime Performer
description: Jane Kingman Crosby and Alan Ashley Day will be married May 30 in South Paris, Me., where they are members of the Celebration Mime Ensemble. Miss Crosby is a performer and her fianc is the business manager.

title: Minority Caucus Gets A New and Loud Voice
description: ALBANY  Senator Vander L Beatty, the recently elected chairman of the state's Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus, handed Governor Carey a report card last week at the caucus's annual dinner.

title: DINING OUT; In James Fenimore Cooper's Name
description: IN James Fenimore Cooper's novel The Spy, supposedly written at the lovely Colonial home that now houses a restaurant bearing the author's name, a country dinner is described that included turkey, ham, fried thicken, oyster patties, duck, pigeon, quail, flatfish, bass, woodcock, vegetables, rice, potatoes, tole slaw, pastry, wine and Madeira. Except for the wilder game, most of the same kinds of dishes are still available at the Fenimore Cooper Inn, a charming restaurant on the Sound in Mamaroneck, appropriately enough right on the old Post Road.

title: Democratic Governors Say Carter Faces Battle
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI)  A number of Democratic governors believe President Carter faces an uphill reelection battle next year, especially if there is not a significant improvement in the economy.

title: Is Martin On Trial By Club?;
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 24 Who said life with the Yankees would be dull this year? Apparently it won't be. not as long as George Steinbrenner and Billy Martin have each other to kick around.

title: Marriage Announcement 2 -- No Title
description: Dr. Laura Bachrach Is Wed to Physician

title: Iowa Joins the List of Those Supporting the Balanced Budget Amendment
description: WASHINGTON  A tug of war is taking place in the nation's federal system. The pervasive political movement for cuts in taxes and spending on all levels  dramatized last week by Iowa's becoming the 28th state to call for a constitutional amendment mandating a balanced Federal budget  has set off a fourway conflict involving the Presidency, the Congress, the states and local governments. In the process. the system's very structure has been called into question. and the already weakened states seem the most vulnerable to further erosion of their constitutional role.

title: Also Known as Dungyard.
description: THOMAS ALVA EDISON'S beliefs and habits were those of a crackpot and a bum. Rats lived happy and undisturbed in his laboratory; he often slept in his clothes, because he believed that changing or taking them off induced insomnia; he thought Richard Wagner was Jewish; he was a disastrous husband and father; he all but starved himself to death because he believed that food poisons the intestines; his own company in Europe coined the cable name Dungyard for him. But he invented or contributed significantly to the development of the telephone, the phonograph, the mimeograph, the incandescent lamp, the motion picture, the heavyduty electric generator, the storage battery and about one thousand other devices or processes. Beyond doubt he was the greatest inventor of the American Age of Invention, and it is scarcely fanciful to call him the chief inventor of the modern physical world.

title: Moscow Philharmonic Presents AllRussian Program of Staples
description: The Moscow Philharmonic, which performed here on Jan. 31, has been touring the country for the last few weeks and on Friday night the orchestra returned to Carnegie Hall for a second concert with its conductor, Dmitri Kataenko. The program was, not surprisingly, allRussian and predictably oriented around repertory staples. It would be interesting one day to hear a visiting Russian orchestra play something out of the ordinary by a native composer  or even a Beethoven symphony for that matter.

title: From Lange d'Oc and Langue d'Oil
description: THE LAIS OF MARIE DE PRANCE Translated, with an introduction and notes by Robert Hanning and Joan Ferrante. Foreword by John Fowles. 238 pp. New York: E. P Dutton. $14.95.

title: Allyson B. Bass Is Married To Dr. Walter A. Boyle 3d
description: Allyson Brackett Bass and Dr. Walter A. Boyle 3d were married yesterday at Brockway Springs, a resort at Lake Tahoe, Calif. The Rev. Alfon W. Larson 3d, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony.

title: IN THE NATION
description: The headline above first appeared over this column on July 9, 1975, but on numerous occasions before and since it could have been used to make an apparently unchanging point: In the attempt to meet the gathering energy crisis, the left hand of the Administration (any Administration) usually works against the right.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: HUMBUG MOUNTAIN By Sid Fleischman. Illustrated by Eric von Schmidt. 149 pp. Boston: AtlanticLittle, Brown. $7.95. (Ages 9 to 12)

title: Jane Mackenzie Engaged to Allen Dennison
description: Dr. and Mrs. Malcolm S. Mackenzie of Greenfield, N.H., and Providence, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Atkinson Mackenzie, to Allen M. Dennison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ethan Allen Dennison of Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: The Ballet World Has a New Impresario
description: There is money in culture if you give people quality. Dance is entertainment; that's what really is, and I expect that dance in America will get bigger. Americans are dreamers. It's the whole idea of living in another world that makes ballet so attractive.

title: Alleged Victim Identifies Rape Suspect for Police
description: A 27yearold rape suspect being chased by police officers yesterday ducked into a Manhattan bar and tried to lose himself in the crowd. But one of the bar's customers was one of his alleged victims, and she pointed him out to the officers, who arrested him.

title: The Chomsky Problem
description: LANGUAGE AND RESPONSIBILITY By Noam Chomsky. Translated by John Viertel. 212 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $10. Paper, $3.95.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Inguiry on Fire Called Futile
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 24 (UPI) Saying that nothing is to be gained from additional efforts, a legal consultant, recommended today that no furtliur grand jury inquiry be conducted into the Beverly Hills Supper Club fire that killed 165 persons. Cecil Dunn of Lexington, in a 122page report on his review of the evidence in the 1977 fire, said he doubted.. that criminal negligence convictions could be obtained again 5t club owners or building inspectors.

title: Swift Rise of Candy Young Defies U.S. Amateur Athlete Pattern
description: The amazing worldrecord performance by Candy Young, a relatively unknown teenage hurdler, during the National indoor track and field championships last Friday again dramatized the strengths and weaknesses of America's amateur sports system.

title: Reporters, Taken to Front in Vietnam With U.S. Legislator, Come Under Chinese Fire
description: The following dispatch was written by Alan Dawson, Bangkok bureau chief of United Press International, who went to Hanoi with a Congressional delegation headed by Elizabeth Holtzman, Democrat of Brooklyn.

title: SPORTS
description: WHO invented baseball? Officially, Abner Doubleday, but a lot of people still think it was Alexander Cartwright. Who wrote Shakespeare's plays? Well, some people think it has been proved that Francis Bacon did. And now they are saying the first runner at Marathon did not really run marathon.

title: Dispute Arises in Picking Leaders of 3 City Colleges
description: In a major dispute with the Board of Higher Education, the faculty of the City University of New York is objecting to its lack of a vote in the selection of college presidents, three of whom are to be chosen to fill vacancies at Brooklyn, City and Hunter Colleges.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IT'S a strange feeling for a Long Islander, sitting in a hotel room in Cincinnati or Kansas City watching the late sports on television Suddenly they start talking about the Island. Well, actually, they talk about the Islanders, the hockey team. It's the only time on the whole newscast you will hear the Island mentioned.

title: GlobeTrotting in Search of the Memorable
description: SOUTHAMPTON TWENTY years ago, a young New York decorator with a penchant for skiing in Switzerland and summering in Southampton decided to go into business for himself, and he started buying antiques in Europe and bringing them to the United States.

title: Jane Blalock Leads by 3 Strokes
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 24 (UPI)  Jane Blalock, battling the winds and a 29 on the front nine by Silvia Bertolaccini, shot a secondround 69 for a 135 total today and took a threestroke lead in the $75,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association Orange Blossom Classic.

title: Dragon's Teeth
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser, caused a flap at the State Department a little more than a year ago when he diagnosed the skirmishing between Cambodia and Vietnam as a symptom of the deeper SinoSoviet strueele. He has been proven right, with a vengeance. Cambodia threatens to become Vietnam's Vietnam. And a Chinese invasion force of 200,000 to 300,000 men last week prompted a Soviet military airlift to Hanoi, widespread uneasiness over more direct Soviet intervention and faint (so far) rumblings along the SinoSoviet border.

title: Endless Endless Endless February
description: WILMINGTON, Ohio  Snow yesterday, eight below last night. Dog creeps closer to the stove. Plants huddle in the south window. I'm feeling mean. If February is the shortest month, why does it go on and on? We know January for the wretch it is and nod in begrudging respect to such shamelessness.

title: For the DoItYourself Taxpayer...
description: Many of the sweeping tax cuts passed by Congress last. fall will not take effect until its time to pay 1979 taxes a year from now, but for taxpayers facing the chore of making out this year's return, there are some bright spots.

title: ART; The Eastville Story
description: EAST HAMPTON THE communities of Sag Harbor Hills, Nineveh Beach and Azurest, on the eastern edge of Sag Harbor Village, have been summer retreats for welltodo black families since the 1920's.

title: Recalling His Capture In Spanish Civil War
description: CARL GEISER'S old comrades in arms will hold their 42d reunion tonight in Manhattan. And before that gathering begins, Mr. Geiser, who is 68 years old now and makes his home in Smithtown, will think back to an April morning 91 years past, when he stood looking out over terrain that he said resembled one of the Long Island potato farms that we used to have out here years ago.

title: A Correction
description: The price of cookies at Stefan's Patisserie in Oceanside and Rockville Centre was given incorrectly in the Long Island Weekly of Feb. 11. The cookies are $2.50 a half pound.

title: JAPAN ASKS CAUTION ON INDOCHINA ISSUE
description: TOKYO, Feb. 24  Eight days after the Chinese invaded Vietnam, the Japanese Government is doing its best to defuse the situation by calling on both sides to find a peaceful solution to their dispute.

title: ART
description: KATONAH FOR a sculptor, combining the abstract and the representational in one work can be risky business, like tightropewalking or being a double agent. He must sometimes be of the stature of a Brancusi to carry it off.

title: Traveler's Bookshelf
description: Doldrum  a spell of listlessness or despondency  hence, doldrums of winter. What are we to do, then, trapped here at the end of February? Reminiscing about travel past, or daydreaming about travel yet to come, is one way of coping  and, by a stroke of good fortune, we have a number of new books to help. Some are mainly pictures, a boon for those too listless or despondent to read.

title: Sea Cliff Rarity: A Mayoral Contest
description: SEA CLIFF IT'S mayoral election time in this icebound North Shore village, and what's startling to many of the 6,000 residents is that there's a choice.

title: Connors, Gerulaitis To Meet for $100,000
description: DORADO Puerto Rico. Feb 24 (UPI)  Jimmy Connors maintained his unbeaten record in the World Championship Tennis roundrobin tournament today by defeating Andriano Panatta of Italy, 46. 65, 62.

title: Richard P. Abbott Fianc Of Patricia Anne Calvelli
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Vincent Calvelli of Port Washington, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Anne Calvelli, to Richard Patrick Abbott, son of Dr. and Mrs. Albert Abbott of Fairfield, Conn.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: One can agree with Governor Byrne when, in his State of the State message on Jan. 7, he called for a lowerprofile government and said that it's time New Jersey went on a legislative and regulatory diet.

title: Cancer Project Ended By Death of 500 Mice
description: MEMPHIS, Feb. 24 (AP)  Five years of cancer research were erased when 200 laboratory mice were killed by someone who placed a toxic chemical in their cages, according to Dr. James C. Carter, chairman of Memphis State university's chemistry department.

title: Birth Notice 3 -- No Title
description: Births

title: Andes Nations Edge Toward Democracy
description: LIMA, Peru  Military regimes are still firmly entrenched in much of South America  Argentina, Chile, Uruguay, Paraguay, Brazil. But after a decade of similar authoritian rule, the Andean countries Peru, Ecuador and Bolivia  are moving toward restoring civilian democracy. The transition is shaky. Rightwing groups and a minority among the military are resisting the change.

title: Clouds Over Storm King
description: After 16 years of controversy, Consolidated Edison's proposed power plant at Storm King Mountain may have become superfluous. Virtually all Federal and state agencies involved now doubt that the longstalled plant is still needed. They are recommending that the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission either terminate the project or hold yet another round of hearings to determine whether changed conditions have eliminated the necessity for it.

title: Kitchen Greenhouse Offers Nourishment To the Good Life
description: FAMILIES gain room to socialize, and good food and sweet flowers gain space in which to cohabit, in the greenhousekitchens that more and more are being added to country homes.

title: HOME CLINIC; Keeping Rooms Warm  and Thawing Frozen Pipes Thawing
description: DURING very cold weather, when temperatures often drop to zero or below, some homeowners (and many apartmentdwellers) find that their heating systems just cannot supply the heat required to keep the house at 68 degrees or more. For these people, as well as for anyone interested in conserving fuel, any step one can take to conserve heat or redirect it in the right direction is worth taking.

title: Questions/Answers
description: I have had an Episcia dianthiflora for about four or five years. Although it seems healthy, it has never bloomed. Any clues? Mrs. L.K., Fairlawn, N.J.

description: To the Editor:

title: Track Team Announced
description: Here is the Unined States team for the indoor track meet Saturday with the Soviet Union in Fort Worth:

title: CARTER HOLDS LINE IN ARMS STATEMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  Despite a plea from Senator Robert C. Byrd, the majority leader, President Carter added little clarification today to yesterday's White House statement about what action the United States was prepared to take should the Senate reject a new armslimitation treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: Attacks Reported on Border Between. the Two Yemens
description: ADEN, Southern Yemen, Feb. 24 (AP)  Planes and ground forces of Yemen and Southern Yemen reportedly fought each other today in new border clashes. Each accused the other of starting hostilities.

title: Mill Fabric Bargains Save Yards of Cash
description: TRYING to find inexpensive fabric by top designers and manufacturers is, to borrow the name of one of Angelo Donghia's prints, like shooting for the moon. But lunar shots are possible if you shop in mill outlets and discount fabric stores, which carry acres of cloth discounted 50 percent and sometimes more. Colors may be a touch off register or off shade from the pattern's standards, but this is usually of no concern to smalllot buyers. Sometimes. an inconspicuous thread is pulled, or nothing at all is wrong and the mill is merely closing out the line.

title: Mailbox: Blacks in Ivy League Athletics
description: To the Sports Editor: I am disturbed by the misleading comments in this section about the Columbia basketball program and black studentathletes (Princeton Fortunes Sag Despite Victory, Feb. 11).

title: Another Auto Inspection?
description: THE Transportation Coordinating Committee of Suffolk County; which determina capital allotments for transportation improvement, recently held a hearing on wnetner to institute an annual emissionsinspection requirement. The cost of this inspection would be $15 a year for the motorist.

title: CONCERN OVER CUTS RIDE AMTRAK ROUTE
description: ABOARD THE MONTREALER, Feb 24 (AP) Ten minutes out of New York's Penn Station, the sounds_ of a traveling birthday party, a second honeymoon and a card game fill the rolling bar of a train chugging through the night.

description: Gail Hartkopf to Be Wed in Fall

title: Thomas Mackie to Wed Margaret Hewit Aug. 11
description: Margaret Fitch Hewit and Thomas Alexander Mackie, alumni of HobartWilliam Smith Colleges in Geneva, N.Y., plan to be married Aug. 11 in Pound Ridge, N.Y. Mr. and Mrs. James Trippe of Pound Ridge, stepfather and mother of the bridetobe, have announced the engagement.

title: Helen Sharp Anderson Married
description: Christ Episcopal Church in St. Michaels, Md., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Helen Sharp Anderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Dunaway Anderson of Houston, to John Arthur Shaw, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. John J. Shaw of Philadelphia. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Donald Etherton.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: In celebration of its 900th anniversary, the choir of Winchester Cathedral is touring the United States and Canada and will make an appearance at 9:30 A.M. next Sunday in the Church of St. James the Less, on Church Lane and Crane Road in Scarsdale. The boychoir tradition, requiring 10 hours a day in a choir school, is what makes the difference in the English choir sound, said Martin Neary, who goes by the ancient title of Organist and Master of the Music.

title: MUSIC
description: CHAMBER MUSIC is becoming an increasingly popular indoor sport in Westchester these days. There is a remarkable array of talents and also a great diversity in programming scheduled this week.

title: Paint, Paper and a Bit of Confidence: At 73, She St?? a Mean Ladder
description: LOUISE SNYDER was in her mid50's when she began painting and papering other people's homes. Today,. in deference to her 73 years, she is cutting back on her work somewhat. But she still can't understand why anyone is surprised at her ease in handling an extension ladder or her skill in papering a ceiling.

title: Out of the Past, TwoFamily houses Are Coming Back
description: In newer, more exclusive neighborhoods, they are proliferating in the guise (for the benefit of neighbors and zoning officials) of houses with inlaw suites attached. In certain older areas, they are selling for more money if they can be legally altered in advance and marketed as a twounit duplex condominium.

title: Molloy Trackmen Retain Title
description: The Archbishop Molloy squad left the school in Queens yesterday morning with all of its equipment for the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association indoor track and field championships except for one important thing. The coaching staff forgot to take the team trophy, which the Stanners won last year, to the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: Traveling Light
description: IN the beginning of this book, Peter Jenkins explains his reasons for setting out to walk across America. It is 1973, and he has just graduated from college where, in true counterculture fashion, he studied pottery. His marriage to a high school sweetheart has ended, for reasons Mr. Jeakins never offers, and going home (to that worst of all fates, suburb) is unthinkable. In an admittealy narrowminded summary of the last decade, he invokes Vietnam, assassinations, drugs and drinking as the sources of his disillusionment. He plans, at first, split for Europe or South America. Then, enlightened  not for the last time in this book  by a bluecollar sage in the person of a school security guard, he decides to give this country one last chance. If he's going to leave the United States, he'd better know what he is leaving. So he and his dog Cooper embark on a rigorous training program (as if going to war) and then hit the road, on foot.

title: For Music Lovers, Some High Notes
description: CHAMBER music, chamber orchestras or sizzling piano virtuosity  you can take your pick today, and whatever your Choice you should come up with a win??er.

title: Anne R. Isaacs Becomes Bride Of Time Aide
description: Anne Richards Isaacs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth L. Isaacs of Boston and South Dartmouth, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to J. Gordon Merwin Jr., son of Mr. Merwin and Mrs. S. Newbury Merwin of Green wich, Conn. The Rev. Peter Moore per formed the ceremony in the Grace Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. James Munroe assisted.

title: Mark Edgerton Marries Maureen Dwyer on L.I.
description: St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City, L.I., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Maureen Dwyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Dwyer Jr. of Garden City, to Mark L. Edgerton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Edgerton of Elmira Heights and Penn Yan, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James P. Swaider.

title: Poor Being Squeezed by Inflation And Lack of Rise in Relief. Grants
description: MINEOLA L.I.  The slightly built woman, holding her two small children by the hand, walked into the basement cafeteria of the Nassau County Social Services building and gazed at the menu posted on the wall behind the serving counters.

title: Brown Stars as Penn Is Heptagonal Victor
description: HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 24  James Brown shattered the meet record in the long jump and later dethroned the defending champion in the sprint as he led the University of Pennsylvania to the team victory tonight in the 32d Heptagonal indoor track and field championships.

title: Higher DrinkingAge Law Gains Favor in Hartford
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 24  Support for a higher dring age is growing in Connecticut's State Capitol, but politicians are at a loss to explain the sudden surge of interest in banning 18yearolds from bars and liauor stores.

title: Design; RESTORATION FEVER: CRAFTSMEN WHO CARE
description: Some people can move into a Victorian house, knock down walls, paint everything white, hang up constellations of potted plants and let it go at that.

title: WNET to Documentary Makers: Be Bold. Be Independent. Be Controversial.
description: Viewers of public television with a taste for documentary programs  who might well feel that their taste had not been adequately catered to in recent years  can take heart. Beginning on WNET /13 tonight at 8, and running at irregular intervals for at least the next two years, is a new series called NonFiction Television, which promises to show the work of documentary filmmakers, untried as well as experienced, from around the country. And the filmmakers are actually being encouraged to be bold, independent  and, inevitably, controversial.

title: GARDENING; Blossoms That Don't Wait for Spring
description: HOW many times on a cold winter's day have you wished you were strolling along some palmstudded shore with the heady fragrance of tropical flowers in the air? While the Island is illequipped to provide such tropical splendors, having flowers in our gardens in the midst of winter is within the realm of possibility.

title: Young Lawyers, Old Law Firms
description: STAR WITNESS By Richard Kluger. 471 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $10.95.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: COUNTY officials, stung by a recent Westchester County Association survey indicating that top executives harbored reservations about the county as a busi ness location, have evidently taken one aspect of the controversial poll to heart

title: Andrew Kleinman To Wed Miss Allen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Allen Wofsey of Mamaroneck, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Robin Allen, to Andrew Young Kleinman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Hyman Jack Kleinman of Scarsdale, N.Y. A June 3 wedding is planned.

title: INTERVIEW
description: NEWARK ALTHOUGH fiscal statistics throughout the state are mostly grim, the facilities operated by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority continued to attract fans and bettors in sufficient numbers to enable the authority's chairman, William F. Hyland, to forecast that the return to the state this year will represent almost a onethird increase  a total of $8 million.

title: Mill Fabric Bargains Save  Yarks of Cash
description: TRYING to find inexpensive fabric by top designers and manufacturers is, to borrow the name of one of Angelo Donghia's prints, like shooting for the moon. But lunar shots are possible if you shop in mill outlets and discount fabric stores, which carry acres of cloth discounted 50 percent and sometimes more. Colors may be a touch off register or off shade from the pattern's standards, but this is usually of no concern to smalllot buyers. Sometimes, an inconspicuous thread is pulled, or nothing at all is wrong and the mill is merely closing out the line.

title: SkiLiability Bill Awaits Byrne Action
description: TRENTON GOVERNOR BYRNE has before him a bill that would sharply limit the liability of ski resorts for injuries suffered by skiers who, for whatever reason, were not fit to set foot  or ski  on the trails.

title: Functional, Well Made and Handsome, Classics Offer Great Value
description: SUPERBLY made furniture, custom design and craftsmanship are decorating criteria for the most discerning designers. But for the ordinary customer who walks in off the street, these qualities may be hard to find in stores. Distinctive finishes, special lacquer shades, unique ceramics and handwoven rugs, all sound expensive and to the trade only. However, they can be found at a reasonable price. Quality doesn't come cheap, but if the items are handsomely made. functional and appropriate, they do qualify as real bargains. Great value is in getting great workmanship and lasting design. The furnishings shown here are classics and cost less than $500. No matter what new trends sweep through decorating, they have the qualities to last and are meant for permanent household collections.

title: CHESS
description: Not all the old gambits are unsound  that's what Oleg Romanishin is discovering now that he has taken up the role of attempting to refute them. The 26yearold Russian grandmaster has suffered a few setbacks in switching from progambit to antigambit.

title: Eilberg Pleads Guilty; Bargain Sets Penalty At Probation and Fine
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24  Former Representative Joshua Eilberg pleaded guilty today to charges that he had illegally accepted money for helping his former law firm obtain a $14.5 million Federal grant for a Philadelphia hospital.

title: AT LAST, A LIKABLE UMP
description: Inspring training in Arizona a few seasons ago, the first pitch by Nolan Ryan  who has a wonderfully moving high fast ball and an unmovably low regard for umpires  was called a ball. Immediately, Ryan and his teammates began ragging and cursing the umpire, one Ron Luciano, a large and imposing figure (some players call him The Incredible Hulk). Luciano held up one hand and commanded attention. We, he an nounced ecclesiastically, are out here to get in shape for the season, just like you are. He spoke for a long moment of the difficulties of getting the senses adjusted after a winter spent squinting past iceglazed snowpiles in his native Endicott, N.Y. The adjustment was none the easier, he said, for the unpredictable gifts of Nolan Ryan. Wha'd ya think? he concluded, gesturing toward Ryan. I keep one of those In my backyard all winter?

title: Marcia Sullivan Will Be Bride Of Robert Cusumano Aug. 25
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leo Sullivan of Riverside, R.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Marcia Sullivan of Boston, to Robert F. Cusumano, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Cusumano of Montrose, N.Y. Plans have been made for a wedding on Aug. 25.

title: U.S. Predicts Water Shortages For Some Regions in the West
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP)  Some areas of the West may have water shortages later this year because of belownormal snowpacks, the Agriculture Department says.

title: Columbia Surprises Penn Five by 7472
description: Columbia's hopes for an Ivy League championship ended several weeks ago, but the Lions are still very much in contention for a berth in the National Invitation Tournament.

title: CORRECTION
description: The New York City Opera schedule in the Arts and Leisure section today is incorrect. The correct schedule appears on page 47 in the second part of this section.

title: How to Keep House With a Pet
description: ASKED how he protects his home from his many pets, a friend of mine replied, It's easy. I take up all the carpets and install lots of those accordiantype gates in all the doorways.

title: Califano Last Week
description: WASHINGTON  After a Baltimore carpenter in his mid40's broke both legs in an accident at home several years ago, they mended poorly, and he could get about only with the aid of crutches. He applied successfully for Social Security disability benefits, which are awarded only to persons deemed unable to do any type of work. Still unable to get around easily, but hoping to qualify for work in the flower trade, he enrolled in a fouryear training program in horticulture at the University of Maryland.

title: Tales and Stories
description: THE ACTES AND MONUMENTS Stories by John William Corrington. Illinois Short Fiction Series. 145 pp. Urbana, III University of Illinois Press. Cloth, $7.95. Paper, $3.95.

title: Jane Sper Engaged To T. G. Rosenthal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roy Sper of CrotononHudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Sper, to Thomas Gilbert Rosenthal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Rosenthal of Richmond.

title: Kitchen Greenhouse Offers Nourishment To the Good Life
description: FAMILIES gain room to socialize, and good food and sweet flowers gain space in which to cohabit, in the greenhousekitchens that more and more are being added to country homes.

title: Billie Sol Estes: The Wonder Boy of Texas Agribusiness Again Faces Federal Charges
description: DALLAS, Feb. 24  Men who started poor and made spectacular amounts of money almost through sheer force of will are ubiquitous in public life in Texas.

title: Ugandans Report Battle For an Evacuated Town
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 24 (Reuters)Tanzanian troops and mercenaries who have been reported advancing in southern Uganda reached the town of Masaka, and there is fierce fighting there, the Uganda radio said today.

title: Brooklyn Tech Girls Triumph
description: Brooklyn Tech, the threetime winner of the Public Schools Athletic League girls' indoor, outdoor and crosscountry track championships. scored the most points ever at P.S.A.L. indoor track event yesterday and won its fourth consecutive title at Pratt University.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: We all ride our hobbies, and one of mine is salon music for the piano. What is setting me off is an item on Friday's Chamber Music Society program in Tully Hall. Emanuel Ax and Charles Wadsworth have programmed the Suite for Two Pianos by Anton Arensky, a LateRomantic Russian composer who pretty much forgotten today. Mr. Ax and Mr. Wadsworth are going to play the entire Suite. The first and last movement will be Known only by a few piano buffs. But the chances are that many in the audience are going to recognize the second of the three movements  the graceful Waltz. It once enjoyed spectacular popularity and still figures as an encore on twopiano programs.

description: The question that confronts many people who are planning to buy a new 35mm single lens reflex camera is: Will a semiautomatic camera suffice, or is it worth paying the higher cost of a fully automatic camera instead?

title: Author's Query
description: For a book on Thomas Hardy, I wish to trace the papers of Harold Hoffmann, formerly of Mt. Kisco, N.Y. In 1940 he conducted what may be key interviews with Hardy relatives, but died later the same year. would be grateful for any leads to surviving family or friends.

title: Cleveland Voters Get Their Chance
description: CLEVELAND  The next, but hardly the last, chapter of Cleveland's fiscal saga begins Tuesday, with decisions on two issues crucial to maintaining the city's ability to chart its own course to solvency, decisions to be made not by the city's leadership, but by the city's voters themselves.

title: On Language
description: I am very vulnerable woman, Bianca Jagger told an interviewer in Munich. I am not strong, tough Bianca everyone imagines. I am little girl.

title: Blockbusters Tempt Museums
description: Critical financial pressures are tempting American art museums to increase profits by staging commercialized blockbuster shows such as the much celebrated Treasures of Tutankhamun, according to a report by the Twentieth Century Fund.

description: THERE must be some mistake, said the maitre d'htel, impatiently tapping his pencil on the reservation list. There is no table for a Mr. Ribera.
