title: US. Aide Meets Envoys From Soviet and China
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  Acting Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher spoke with the Soviet and Chinese Ambassadors separately this afternoon and urged restraint for all sides in the conflicts in Indochina, the State Department said tonight.

title: Iranian Leaders Consider Egypt Ripe for Islamic Uprising
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 24  The new Moslem rulers of Iran believe that the success of their Islamic movement will have a revolutionary impact on neighboring Arab countries and may reach beyond the Arab world to promote change in thirdworld countries where Islam is the dominant religion.

title: Camp David Talks Are Reported at Intensive Stage
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP)  The IsraeliEgyptian peace talks at Camp David were reported to have reached an intensive stage today.

title: W. A. C. Bennett Dies at Age 78; ExPremier of British Columbia
description: W. A. C. Bennett, the former Premier of British Columbia whose policies gave Canada's westernmost province the fastest economic growth rate in the nation, died in his sleep last night, according to provincial government spokesman. He was 78 years old.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: EDWIN (BUZZ) SCHWENK, dairyman, store owner and former Suffolk County Republican chairman, was also chairman of the New York State Sports Authority until recently, when Governor Carey dismissed him. Mr. Schwenk is also an inveterate writer of letters, one of which follows verbatim:

title: Realty News
description: The Great Bear Spring Company, a major water bottler, is relocating its corporate headquarters from 51 Madison Avenue to a new facility in Teterboro, N. J., and the marketing services division of Dun & Bradstreet is moving from Lower Manhattan to Parsippany N. J..

title: HOME CLINIC
description: DURING very cold weather, when temperatures often drop, to zero or below, some homeowners (and many apartmentdwellers) find that their heating systems just cannot supply the heat required to keep the house at 68 degrees or more. For these people, as well as for anyone interested in conserving fuel, any step one can take to conserve heat or redirect it in the right direction is worth taking.

title: M.D. Bardeen Jr., a Broker, Fianc of Mary E. O'Connell
description: Mr. and Mrs. William F. O'Connell Jr. of Saratoga, Calif., formerly of Stamford, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mary Elizabeth O'Connell, to Maxwell Dickerman Bardeen Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bardeen of Kalamazoo, Mich. June wedding is planned.

title: Late Rally Downs Maple Leafs
description: TORONTO. Feb 24  For??fied like an enriched loaf of bread the Rangers beat a surprisingly mildmannered bunch of Toronto Maple Leafs tonight by 42. Having heard report of Toron to's aggresion in recent games, the Rangers dressed Frank Beaton and Dean Turner. noted for their enforcement tactics in the minor Jeagues. It was their first National Hockey League appearance.

title: Congress Gets Study on Injuries
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 24  There were more than one million injuries and 14 deaths in American secondary school and collegiate athletic programs during the 197576 school years, according to a report sent to Congress today by Health. Education and Welfare Secretary Joseph A. Califano Jr.

title: Soviet Union and China Trade Charges at the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 24 The Security Council resumed debate today on the Southeast Asia crisis and food opposing resolutions from the Soviet Union and China, each condemning the other for the spreading conflict

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: ATUDY of commuting patterns in the Stamford area released recently by the Southwestern Area Commerce & Industry Association has concluded, to no one's surprise, that thousands of workers drive to the area every day, over nearly every road in the region. But the report also found that many of them follow each other over similar routes, one person to a car, clogging the highways and fouling the air in the process.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The beleaguered Atlantic salmon, perhaps the world's most highlyprized food and game fish, may soon enjoy the protection of an international treaty, plans to that end being put forth by the United States come to fruition.

title: Around the Nation
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 24  Reductions in Federal grants, the construction of a new power plant and inflation will force the Harvard Medical School to raise its tuition 13 percent next September, Harvard officials have announced.

description: In today's Arts & Leisure Guide, the week's schedule for the New York City Opera should be:

description: A very rich man was showing his very old mother his apartment in Olympic Tower. She was obviously less than thrilled.

title: Mary Louise Coan Is Betrothed
description: Mary Lapwing Coan of Scarsdale, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mary Louise Coan, to Thomas Neil Thompson, son of Janet Thompson of Princeton, N.J., and the late Lawrance Thompson. The future bride is the daughter also of the late John Patrick Coan. A June wedding is planned.

title: Stephanie T. French Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. William T. French of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Stephanie Taylor French, to Amory Houghton 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Houghton Jr. of Corning, N.Y. A September wedding is planned.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: In the past, I used to keep a drawerful of names of likely board candidates, says an executive of one of the nation's largest publishing companies. Now I'm lucky if I can come up with single good name.

description: Ann Landers

title: Hawks 115, Suns 85
description: ATLANTA. Feb. 24 (AP)  John Drew's 27 points combined with a secondhalf scoring lull by Phoenix gave the Atlanta Hawks a 11585 triumph over the Suns tonight.

title: URANIUM LOSS FAILS TO CHANGE SECURITY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  Two international atomic energy agencies have made no substantive changes in their security procedures during the decade since they learned that Israel almost certainly had diverted 200 tons of uranium ore from a freighter headed for Italy, according to a Government report made public today.

title: Gale Duncan Plans Nuptials
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John C. Duncan 3d of New York and Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Gale Duncan, to William Barry Simmons; son of Mr. and Mrs. F. William Simmons of Pasadena, Calif.

title: Author's Query
description: For A biography of Archbishop Andrew Count Szeptyckyj, metropolitan of Lemberg, GallCia , I would appreciate hearing from anyone having letters or biographical information, especially knowledge concerning the prelate's visits to the United States in 1910 and 1921.

title: SHOPTALK
description: ENTRUSTING greatgreatgrandmother's Queen Anne chair to an unknown repair shop is unnerving, to say the least. The chair in question had already been misrepaired once, the wood even to the uninitiated eye  was rotting, and David Millson of Rebuild Guild said no one should sit in it again. But once he had refurbished it, he pronounced the chair eminently sitable.

title: Panel in New York to Monitor Human Rights in U.S
description: With a $400,000 Ford Foundation grant to cover its first two years, an American Helsinki Watch Committee has been organized to monitor United States compliance with the 1975 Helsinki agreements on human rights.

title: When to Look For Help
description: When does the doityourself taxpayer need the help of a professional in preparing a return? Sidney Kess of the accounting firm of Main Lafrentz & Company suggests that the following situations warrant at least doublechecking by a pro:

title: FollowUp on the News
description: After four years of planning and talk, the Oriental Land Corporatioa announced in Tokyo in November 1978 that it had reached an agreement with Walt Disney Productions under which 204acre Disneyland would be built near the Japanese capital. The Japanese company said that it expected to sign the final papers by the end of the year and that the amusement park would open in 1982. In Burbank, Calif., a Disney spokesman said. The announcement is premature.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Many scoffed five years ago when Lillian Nassau, the 79yearold doyenne of Art Nouveau dealers, predicted that Louis Comfort Tiffany lamps would sell at auction for $100,000 or much more within the decade.

description: International

title: Crossing the U.S. With a Man Who Won't Fly
description: There are two Isaac Asimovs. One believes that he stays cloistered with the typewriters in the dark cave of steel called his office, linked to the outside world only by telephone and the taxis that take him to his editors nearby. The other is willing to travel hundreds of miles by car or train into the hinterlands, where he mobbed at interviews, receptions, dinners, lectures and question sessions all without a typewriter in sight.

title: Investors Bilked by Gold Scam
description: Albert M. Lincoln, a 42yearold California businessman, paid $33,500 to the First National Bullion Corporation of New York in three separate transactions between last September and November. He says he was told that the money was a down payment toward purchasing 500 ounces of gold. Only later did he discover that it was all nonrefundable fees. It was all so goddamn convincing; they could have sold them to the pope, says the frustrated Mr. Lincoln.

title: A Movement Got Moving
description: ONE of the more striking historical parallels in American politics has to do with the similarity of the origins of the feminist movements of the 19th and 20th centuries: the former in the struggle for the abolition of slavery, the latter in the civilrights movement and the New Left.

title: For a National TeachIn on Economics
description: WASHINGTON  The rhetoric of the socalled war against inflation is beginning to have a familiar hollow ring. It is the sound of Government policy at odds with reality.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Old Wethersfield Antiques Show, Trinity Parish Hall, 300 Main Street, Wethersfield.

title: Stephen Sondheim Takes a Stab at Grand Guignol
description: The compositions of Stephen Sondheim, whose new musical Sweeney Todd opens Thursday at the Uris, with Angela Lansbury and Len Cariou in the leading roles, have been praised as sophisticated, elegant, highly literate, imaginative and witty. They have also been damned as too intricate for their own good, ambivalent in their attitudes and, above all, cold. Mr. Sondheim, some critics have said, is brilliant but lacks heart. He would rather play alienating musical games with his audience, these critics say, than send them out of the theater humming a good, oldfashioned tune. If only Mr. Sondheim could hitch his lyrics to the melodies of a newfound Richard Rodgers. If only he embraced sentiment instead of shrinking from it. If only he didn't insist on those plotless concept musicals. If only... .

title: Setting the Stage For a New Direction
description: IT'S the Hollywood version of the early American house, said New York designer William Turner. You can just imagine Loretta Young spinning out of every door.

title: U.S. Fears Soviet Wants Cam Ranh Bay as Navy Base
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  China's invasion of Vietnam has raised grave new concerns in the Carter Administration that the Soviet Union might use the conflict as a pretext to establish a naval facility at Cam Ranh Bay. one of the most strategically situated natural ports in the Western Pacific, authoritative sources said yesterday.

title: ALBANY PASSES BILL ASSISTING PUBLIC TV
description: ALBANY, Feb. 23  In a move to support noncommercial broadcasting, the State Senate gave final legislative approval this week to a bill that would give public television stations up to 50 cents in operating aid for every resident of the state.

title: Happy Letters
description: MARINA Letters and Diaries of Marina Sulzberger. Edited by C. L. Sulzberger. Illustrated. 530 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $15.

title: Frederica von StadeSinging Is a Direct Line to the Soul
description: Those who see the operatic world as more a competitive battlefield than an artistic arena are certain to be puzzled by the continued success of Frederica von Stade. She is a mezzosoprano who does not sing a popular repertory, her voice is caressing rather than aggressive, her personality is soft and noncombative, and her appearance is more that of a young, wellheeled member of the Metropolitan Opera Guild than a stel lar member of the Metropolitan Opera company.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Contrary to popular clich, the word is getting bigger, not smaller. The fact was borne in upon me recently by a man who had just sped in from Europe aboard the Concorde and told me about lunch in Switzerland the previous day.

title: East Asia, Once Again a Military Theater.
description: The Chinese invasion of Vietnam has demonstrated to the world, and particularly to its three military powers  the United States, the Soviet Union and China itself  the appropriateness of the Duke of Wellington's dictum that for a great power there is no such thing as a small war.

title: An Empty Nest Certainly Can Hold A Lot of Things
description: THEY call them empty nesters  those whose children have finally grown up (or claim they are grown up), those who have houses bigger than they need, those who for every logical reason should move to smaller quarters.

title: The Invasion of the CorporateBody Snatchers
description: The march of the foreign mergerminded merchants goes on. Last year, according to W.T. Grimm & Company, the Chicagobased merger specialists, there were 199 acquisitions of American concerns by overseas companies, up 23 percent from 1977  and that during year when the number of mergers, overall, declined by 5 percent.

title: EastBloc Jews Finding Refuge In West Berlin
description: WEST BERLIN, Feb. 24  A week after the showing of Holocaust to millions of West German viewers, Betty Simon, a 48year old Jewish schoolteacher, took time off to discuss the problems of Jewish life in Berlin today and to evaluate the effects of the American television series that deals with the mass killing of Jews.

title: City Aides Studying Address Lists For Pickup of Students Tomorrow
description: Staff members of the Mayor's office. the Police Department and the Board of Education sifted through long lists of names, addresses and street routes yesterday to coordinate the city's plan for driving physically handicapped children to school tomorrow.

title: Say, Did You Hear the One About..
description: NORTH MASSAPEQUA ROB BARTLETT (as in pears and Familiar Quotations ) had finished his impressions of a lollipop possessed by the devil and Darth Vader with the hiccups, his parody of a Spanishlanguage television show, his Rocky bit and his Saturday Night Fever bit. And now, picking up a guitar, the 21yearold Massapequa Park resident posed a question to the White House Inn audience that had come to see a collection of aspiring comedians display their talents.

title: A Melville Home Is Dammed
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., Feb. 24 (AP)A 199yearold house where Herman Melville wrote much of Moby Dick has been damaged by water spurting from frozen, bursting pipes. Arrowhead, the author's home from 1850 to 1863 and now National Historic Landmark open to the public, was flooded Monday night when water cascaded from pipes on the first and second floors of the house.

title: The Painter
description: NORWALK RUNNING a card and gift boutique in Westport, as Elizabeth Whiteford did for eight years, would seem to be a pleasant niche in life. Even more rewarding, perhaps, would be a fulltime career as an artist, which Marcia Tonner pursued for nine years.

title: 3 Tied For Lead In Golf
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24  In a day of charges and caveins  including Fuzzy Zoeller's four putts from five feet  the third round of the 53d Los

title: Wales, a Divided Nation. Seems Certain to Say No in Vote on Limited Self Government
description: LLANGADOG, Wales, Feb. 24  For 700 years, Wales has been a confused and sometimes tortured anomaly, says Jan Morris, the writer, about the place where she lives. It is not, like Scotland, linked to its tremendous English neighbor by a union of thrones.

title: Italian Leaders Meeting With PremierDesignate.
description: ROME, Feb. 24 (UPI)  Prime Ministerdesignate Ugo La Malfa called meetings with opposition leaders today in an attempt to form Italy's first nonChristian Democrat government in 34 years, an effort hampered by the former ruling party's unwillingness to allow Communists in the Cabinet.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: An Empty Nest Certainly Can Hold A Lot of Things
description: THEY call them empty nesters  those whose children have finally grown up (or claim they are grown up), those who have houses bigger than they need, those who for every logical reason should move to smaller quarters.

title: Letters; T 0  T H E  E D I T 0
description: The Ninth Precinct does have its share of the blues, but most of those who live within its boundaries also share a tremendous energy and love. Dan Greenburg's article (The Ninth Precinct Blues, Jan. 21) omitted to note the renaissance that is taking place. Our community boasts several theaters (Entermedia, the Theater for the New City, LaMaMa, etc.), synagogues and churches, New York University's Art Department, and dozens of thriving businesses that add life, excitement and revenues to New York City.

title: Police Merger Far From Settled
description: THE Deputy County Executive, J. Robert Dolan, has been invited with Sheriff Thomas J. Delaney and Chief Carl Fulgenzi of the County Parkway Police to attend a meeting of police officers in San Diego next week to explain the proposed merger of those two agencies in Westchester. They want to know how we pulled it off, Mr. Dolan said. I'm going to have to tell them, Wait until find out.

title: DINING OUT; Secaucus: Sunset Over the Pollution
description: THE creators of the new Meadowlands Hilton Hotel, part of the Harmon Cove development in Secaucus, have spared no expense in lavish interior design. To reach the main restaurant, a diner passes an indoor coffee garden on hisleft, an indoor swimming pool on his right, drops his coat by a blacklighted bar named Heathers and steps into a room with a spectacular view of Harmon Cove, which is famous for its mercury count.

title: ANTIQUES; North of the Border (and South, Too)
description: ALPINE ONE of the best ways to go antiquing is to set out early on nice day, knowing that, by the end of the afternoon, you will have traveled through a tryside, seen something of antiques and enjoyed a meal old inn.

title: An Absurdly Happy Man
description: WHILE I know a few people who are content and greater number who are holding their own against depression, I can think of only one person in my acquaintance who is actively happy. You might even say that he is absurdly happy, a phrase invented especially for our time.

title: Marriage Announcement 12 -- No Title
description: Dr. Barbara Bassil Sets Nuptials to a Professor

title: Conran's Is Putting Down New Roots
description: ALTHOUGH Michael Tyson is a relative newcomer to this country he has already determined three important things about Westchester County: Harrison gives tickets for speeding, Waccabuc has fine housing accomodations for families that include six children, and New Rochelle provides an excellent base from which to build a nationwide horns'furnishings complex.

title: Learning All About the Union Movement
description: ?? ENTLY, a young college ??duate seeking employ?? with our union informed ?? that he would like to be a ?? organizer, someone to help re?? new members for our local.

title: Mill Fabric Bargains Save Yards of Cash
description: TRYING to find inexpensive fabric by top designers and manufacturers is, to borrow the name of one of Angelo Donghia's prints, like shooting for the moon. But lunar shots are possible if you shop in mill outlets and discount fabric stores, which carry acres of cloth discounted 50 percent and sometimes more. Colors may be a touch off register or off shade from the pattern's standards, but this is usually of no concern to smalllot buyers. Sometimes, an inconspicuous thread is pulled, or nothing at all is wrong and the mill merely closing out the line.

title: A Practical Approach to Creative Arrangements
description: Patricia Vanderwarker says there's more to arranging flowers than creating a centerpiece for a dinner party or earning a blue ribbon at a flower show.

title: Robynne Fields Fiance Of Martin S. Kratchman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Raymond J. Fields of Wantagh, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robynne Maxine Fields, to Martin Seth Kratchman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Kratchman of North Bellmore, L.I. A June 16 weddine is planned.

title: Old Symphony Theater Becomes an Arts Center
description: A year ago, rumors on the Upper West Side had it that the building on the southeast corner of 95th Street and Broadway, for more than a halfcentury the home of the Symphony and Thalia Theaters. was about to be sold and that the developers who were eyeing it envisioned razing the movie houses to create a discotheque, flea market, bowling alley or even, in a neighborhood saturated with supermarkets, another supermarket.

title: WHITE HOUSE MAPS HOSPITAL COST PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  The White House strategy for enacting legislation to contain hospital costs calls for a swift, preemptive strike in the Senate, followed by a pincers movement to engulf the bill's major obstacle, the House Commerce Committee.

title: A Single Community (Pop. 250,000)
description: WHITE PLAINS AMONG the stories going around the singles' clubs across Westchester is the one about the woman from Peekskill who meets the man of her dreams at a singles' bar in White Plains. They marry, build a 20room nest in Bedford Hills and live happily ever after.

title: These Are My Children From 8 to 3
description: PINCHED, worried, haunted little face, he waits at 7:40... I'm free first and second periods. ... He must sleep away the medication his tortured psyche feeds on through these turbulent years. ... Brave child, he forces his attention awake in class for the pleasure of this sweet sleep. .. . His mother's tearful voice on the telephone seeking anonymity for her child, her guilt breaking through eachsyllable. He has no friends .. . he's sleepwalking through life .. . his father doesn't even see him anymore. I hear her pain. Look, he's coping . . . he goes to class . . . he does his assignments . . it's not uncommon . . . they do get well . . . they come back and visit me from college.

title: Deaths
description: KNOWLESElinor Townsend. Of 312 Roseland Ave.. Essex Fells, N.J. On Friday.February 23, 1979. Wife of Alan C. Knowles. Mother of Mrs. Stephen T. Carroll and William T. Knowles. Sister of Mrs. Richard H. Lennox. Also survived by 3 grandchildren. Memorial service will be held at Union Congregational Church, Cooper Ave.. Upper Mont. clair, N.J. Wednesday at 3 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the American Red Cross or the charity of your choice.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 24  Mark Lieberman paced Lehigh to the team lead today in the 75th Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association championships, recording two falls in two bouts as his team bid to become the first fourtime regional champion since 1908.

title: Shows and Events
description: Thursday through Saturday  Annual antiques show and sale sponsored by the Junior Woman's Club of Ridgewood. At the Ridgewood Woman's Club, West Ridgewood Avenue, Ridgewood. Thirty dealers. Hours: Thursday, 7 to 10 P.M.; Friday, 1 to 10 P.M.; Saturday, 11 A.M.5 P.M. Admission: $2, with profits going to local charities. For information, call (201) 4445789.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today  Taconic Auto Sports Club final icekhana of season; at Lake Osceola, behind Nino's Restaurant (Route EN). Jefferson Valley. N.Y. Registration: 9:30 A.M.: first car off 9:35. Limit 100 cars. Information on ice conditioris: (914)7372442.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The City University of New York tournament final between Staten land and Queens will be played at 7:30 P.M. tomorrow in City College's Nat Holman Gymnasium, West 138th Street and Convent Avenue. The Eastern College Athletic Conference's metropolitan regional tournament for New York and New Jersey will be played Thursday and Saturday at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I. Participants will be announced today. The E.C.A.C. southern regional is scheduled Thursday and Saturday at the Providence (R.I.) Civic Center. In the East Coast Eight tournament, Rutgers will play George Washington in the first round Tuesday night in Piscataway, N.J.

title: Other Ideas & Trends
description: Gov. Scott Matheson of Utah remembers the 1950's when the Government conducted about 100 aboveground atomic tests in Nevada. We used to get up early to see the detonations, he said last week. Sometimes later you could feel the particles settling down on you. Now the New England Journal of Medicine has published a study showing that among Utah children who were under age 15 during the testing period and lived in the path of the fallout, the number of deaths from leukemia was almost two and a half times the normal rate. The study's author. Dr. Joseph L. Lyon of the University of Utah. said there was a great degree of probability that the increase is connected to the fallout.

title: When Winter Comes ...
description: THE cold of this February turned a slightly warmerthannormal winter into a distinctly colder one, and another cold winter will make it three straight. The winters of 1971 through 1975 gave Westchester a reprieve from the worst of winter, but the cycle has turned cold, and we will have to endure it, as we do all weather.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: From about 100 B.C. to A.D. 6S, a Jewish monastic community, related to the rigorous minority sect of the Essenes, flourished near Qumran on the Dead Sea. Since 1947 more than 400 manuscripts of that community have been found, and scholars believe the writings have provided new information about Jewish life and about the circumstances in which Christianity arose. Now a summary of the Temple Scroll, the last known Dead Sea Scroll, has been published by the journal Biblical Archeologist. Some fits contents will puzzle scholars, according to the author of the summary, Prof. Jacbb Milgrom of the University of California at Berkeley.

title: How to Find
description: LOOKING for an interior designer might not be as crucial as, say, finding a new family physician, but for some people might be more confusing. The Individ ual who seeks professional attention for his home, and who has no acquaintance with the design field, may find himself confronted with a multiplicity of questions and no concrete answers.

title: TV: End of Roots II Delineates 60's
description: In its seventh and final installment, Roots: The Next Generations changes shape. Set in the 1960's, it presents an Alex Haley who is a more complex and sharpedged character than many of his nowfamous forebears. And it places him in highly charged situations in which the battle lines aren't clearly drawn. If the earlier episodes, however sweeping, had a tendency to be black and white in outlook as well as subject matter, the conclusion of the series is something else again. This last part of Roots is easily strong enough to be watched without reference to the rest of the series, and so beautifully acted that it adds an extra dimension to an already successful undertaking.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: I HAD come in from New Jersey for a welldeserved day in New York. My spirits were not quelled by the grimy welcome that the Port Authority Bus Terminal gave me or by the decrepit exterior of the terminal's barcafe, my first sight on emerging onto Eighth Avenue.

title: Scenic Design For a Barn On the Bank
description: WHEN Janek Liebgold and his wife Ann began to think about converting the 100yearold barn behind their hardware store in New Hope, Pa., to a home, they didn't consult an architect. Instead, they asked scenic designer Jim Hamilton of Design Associates in Lambertville, N.J., to draw up the plans.

title: Thaw Raises Hopes for Embattled Chicago Mayor
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 24  The first real thaw of a seemingly endless winter, at least since the ornate ice sculptures in the Loop's Richard J. Daley Plaza were reduced to puddling blobs just before Christmas, has settled mercifully on Chicago, shrinking the shoulderhigh drifts of sootblackened snow and bearing a distant promise of spring.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: At a time when kids will do anything to have a good time, Samuel J. Gulino's recent Opinion Page article, Marijuana: The Hazards for Young Users, is very relevant. Kids do not know the hazards of this drug and what, in the long run, it can and will do to them if they don't get their facts straight.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONE TO 354 2900 UNTIL 5:30 PM FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS UNTIL 2:30 PM ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 AM TO 4:30 P.M MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY NEW JERSEY (701) MARKET 3. 3900 WESTCHESTER CO AND NORTHERN NEW WORK STATE COUNTIES (314) WHITE PLAINS 95300 NASSAU CO (516) 1470500 SU??FOLK CO ??1800. CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: REMEMBER THE NEEDIEST!

title: POLITICS
description: HARTFORD AFTER years in the fast lane as legislative floor leader, party state chairman and candidate for statewide office  sometimes all three at the same time William A. O'Neill has moved over and throttled back to the more sedate pace of the Lieutenant Governor's office.

title: CHARLOTTE PELLER GANNETT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  Charlotte Feller Gannett, wife of Michael R. Gannett, a retired Foreign Service officer, died yesterday at her home in Chevy Chase, Md., of a heart attack. She was 58 years old.

title: U.S. PRESSES EUROPE ABOUT NEW MISSILE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  The Carter Administration, eager to avoid another major dispute ,in the Western alliance over nucleararms policy, is pressing allied Governments in Europe to agree this year to a plan for deploying a new mediumrange missile capable of striking the Soviet Union.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE BOOK OF INSULTS Ancient and Modern. By Nancy McPhee. A JonathanJames Bork. Illustrated. 160 pp. New York. St. Martin's Press. $6.95.

title: Blumenthal, in Peking, Voices Hope for Trade Pact
description: PEKING, Feb. 24  W. Michael Blumenthal, the Secretary of the Treasury, arrived here tonight to open negotiations that the Carter Administration hopes will help the United States make up, for lost time in developing its trade with China.

title: Discovering Two Sides of Antigua, an Island of Toleration
description: My husband and I arrived in Antigua wondering if our few days there could be worth the trouble. Winter vacations are expensive, feverish and short. We had left the States during a great blizzard in New York by the skin of our teeth and the efforts of a frazzled travel agent. A long flight requiring four stops had somewhat dampened our enthusiasm, and our traveling companions were making noises about cutting their stay on Antigua to two days and going on to San Juan.

title: A Summer House for All Seasons
description: MONA and Ed Sharkey respond changes in their lives by changing their life styles. As many do, they began married life in an apartment for two. A splitlevel house in the suburbs followed, ideal for raising daughters Lisa, Pam and Tina.

title: Deutschland iiber England
description: SSGB NaziOccupied Britain 1941. By Len Deighton. 344 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $9.95.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE LAST CONVERTIBLE, by Anton Myrer. (Berkley, $2.50.) Back in 1938, the shared ownership of a convertible called The Empress made buddies of five Harvard undergraduates. Anton Myrer follows the quintet through World War II, marriage, parenthood, to the accommodations of ripe middle age in what our reviewer Nora Johnson called a firstrate story, well told and constantly interesting.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: BIRMINGHAM. England  A soggy blueandwhite British Leyland banner hovered nearby as a knot of pickets poked at their fire and shuffled their feet in the slush, trying vainly to keep warm.

title: GARDENING; Not All Witch Hazel Comes in a Bottle
description: WINTER gardens in northern areas of New Jersey must depend on plant materials with lowkey but longenduring attractions, such as interesting branching patterns, colorful fruits or twigs and evergreen foliage.

title: Editors Choice
description: JOSEPH CONRAD, by Frederick R. Karl. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) Conrad's three lives  as Pole, as sailor, as writer  examined in the context of their historical background in a massive, thoughtful biography.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: MICHEL BLOCK TO PLAY

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The sixth edition of Donlon's United States Large Size Paper Money 1861 to 1923 has just been released and is now available at coin dealers, bookstores and hobby shoos. This popular catalog has been revised and brought up to date by A.M. Kagin and Don Kagin of Des Moines,Iowa.

title: Katherine Buechner Fiance of John Mullen
description: The Rev. and Mrs. Frederick Buechner of Rupert, Vt., have madeknown the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Ann Buechner, to John W. Mullen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Mullen of San Diego. Plans have been made for a May 5 wedding.

title: Robin Aaronson Plans Nuptials
description: Robin Leslie Aaronson, a registered nurse at Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami, and Dr. Gary M. Fox, a resident at Jackson, plan to be married May 19 in Miami. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. George Aaronson of West Islip, L.I., parents of the bridetobe, whose fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Fox of Miami.

title: Invasion Is Protested by 1,000 Near Chinese Office in New York
description: About 1,000 demonstrators from 15 groups demonstrated peacefully yesterday near the Chinese Mission to the United Nations to protest China's invasion of Vietnam.

title: The Making of a Candidate For Mayor of Yonkers, 1979
description: YONKERS SOME people say that on Feb 15, when Gerald E. Loehr won the Democratic designation to run for Mayor of Yonkers. it was because being 6 feet 2 inches tall, young and squarejawed and having an ease in speaking, he was politically more marketable than his opponent, Joseph D'Albora.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE Byrne Administration's $20 million special aid package for cities is one reason why politicians from New Jersey's suburbs are beginning to grumble aloud.

title: Marriage Announcement 9 -- No Title
description: ran A. Kurtis Will Be Wed To Roger H. Berman in June

title: Headliners
description: Dad taught me to never give up, said 11yearold Norman Ollestad Jr., and the boy paid attention. Last Monday, a light plane carrying Norman. his father and two other adults crashed in the mountains northeast of Los Angeles. Only Norman and Sandra Cressman, 30. survived. He suffered a broken hand and some cuts and bruises and she was more seriously Injured. After a few hours, they decided to try to walk down the mountain, but Miss Cressman could not make it and her body was later found about 100 yards from the plane. Norman went on, and after two miles of walking and sliding down the snowcovered mountain was able to reach an occupied house. I'm a little bit achy. That's about it, he said.

title: Art That's Meant To Be Walked On
description: MICHAEL MURDOLO likes to think of himsel, as an artist and a designer, but magician mig?? better describe him. In his studio above an auto ransmission service center in ??it, Mr. Murdolo cre?? ??shes for floors, walls ?? and ??ccessories.

description: Stephanie C. Greene To Be Wed May 19

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249, or to any of the following organizations:

title: Guilty Is Guilty, Insane or Not
description: CHESHIRE, Conn.  Is a person responsible for his behavior if he is insane or brainwashed?

title: Marionettes: An Alternative To Grand Opera in Salzburg
description: Papageno pines for Papagena, Tamino does likewise for Pamina, the Queen of the Night is being evil and Sarastro is being noble.

title: G.O.P. Rationale for Ripe, In L.I. Sales Tax Derided
description: Settlements anticipated for Civil Service unions this year and a cushion desired for future county budget increases were the major reasons for the Nassau Republican request for a 1 percent salestax in crease, high county officials said last week.

title: GOVERNOR SEEKING HEALTH CARE GAINS
description: Governor Carey has asked the State Legislature to support a comprehensive program aimed at improving access to healthcare services and at preventing disease, especially among disadvantgaged New Yorkers.

title: Carter Said to Name Army's Chief As Haig's Successor in NATO Post
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  President Carter has decided to name Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, the Army Chief of Staff, to be commander of United States Forces in Europe and to nominate him to succeed Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. as Supreme Commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Administration officials said today.

title: Liza Lloyd Is Betrothed to Charles Ingrasci
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Davis Lloyd have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Elizabeth Lloyd, to Charles James Ingrasci of Sausalito, Calif., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Ingrasci Jr. of Racine, Wis. The wedding is planned for April 3 in San Francisco.

title: On the Lookout for Drug Runners
description: MELVILLE FROM the bridge of the Point Wells, Boatswain's Mate 1st Class Paul Keller could just make out the spectral shape of ketch in the waters north of Gardiners Island. She was loW in the water and moving slowly westward under sail and power but her mast light was out, Petty Officer Keller said.

title: SHOP TALK
description: PATCHOGUE PATCHOGUE is Suffolk's largest shopping center, with more than 200 stores, including jewelry shops, clothing stores, department stores and delicatessens. And now is the time to shop here, because nearly every store along Main Street and North Ocean Avenue is having a sale.

title: Fashion; Art That Wears Well
description: There's a new, and growing emphasis on clothing and jewelry as art. Here are three of the craftsmen who are making a mark on fashion with their unique designs.

title: Title Fight Canceled In Rift Over Officials
description: LAS VEGAS. Nev. Feb 24 (AP) The World Boxing Association light heavyweight ??le bout between Mike Rossman and Victor Galindez wa??n celed today shortly before fight ?? because of a dispute over the ??ud??

title: Mets Start Phase 2 of New Era
description: ST PETERSBURG Fla.. Feb. 24The New York Mets. who proclaimed new era one year ago and then finished in last place again. opened spring training today with 28 players, and Manager Joe Torre announced: This is the second phase of the new era.'

title: Natalie Lichtenstein, a Lawyer, Engaged to Willard Tom
description: The engagement of Natalie Lichtenstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abba Lichtenstein of Tenafly, N.J., and Montauk, L.I., to Willard Ken Tom, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hing Yee Torn of Bonolulu, has been announced by the future bride's parents. A June 10 wedding in Tenafly is planned.

title: Policeman Is Charged With Murder After Man in Bar Shooting Dies
description: A highly decorated 29yearold policeman was arrested and charged with murder yesterday after the death of one of two men he was accused of shooting during an argument while he was off duty in a Bronx bar Wednesday night.

title: BRIDGE
description: Aquarter ?? a century ago expert ?? New York and for ?? most of the East ?? spoke a common ?? language. Such ?? as B. Jay Becker, John Crawford, George Rapee, Howard Schenken and Sam Stayman, world champions all, could and did switch partnerships with little effort and minimal danger of suffering misunderstandings.

title: TV VIEW
description: LONDON Nobody ever lost face at a British cocktail party by denigrating American television programs. From the days of Dragnet and Gunsmoke in the 1950's to Wonder Woman and Baretta today, imported U.S. television series have always been considered fair game among Britain's intelligentsia and that noisy minority calling itself the silent majority. These series have been dismissed repeatedly for being brash, violent, loud and rooted in a morality that considers the clenched fist to be the only argument subtler than the cocked gun

title: A Teacher Suspended as Not Fit In 1970 Is Granted New Hearing
description: A new hearing has been ordered for a Queens highschool teacher who has remained on an involuntary leave of absence without pay for more than eight years because the Board of Education decided she was mentally unfit to teach.

title: Linda Keniston Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Reinhold P. Schmitt Jr. of Glen Spey and Port Jervis, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Schmitt's daughter, Linda Keniston, to Richard Dubocq, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Dubocq of. Northport. L.I.

title: How to Keep House With a Pet
description: ASKED how he protects his home from his many pets, a friend of mine replied, It's easy. I take up all the carpets and install lots of those accordiantype gates in all the doorways.

title: South Bronx Debate; Dig It Now or Plan It Later
description: With the Board of Estimate's rejection of the Charlotte Street housing project still on their minds, Mayor Koch, Council President Carol Bellamy, Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens and Edward J. Logue, executive director of the South Bronx Redevelopment Office, gathered last week with New York Times reporters and editors of The Week in Review to discuss what went wrong and what can be set right. Mayor Koch and Mr. Logue stood by their support of the original project but went along with the need for more detailed scheme for the entire area. Miss Bellamy and Mr. Manes stood by their opposition to Charlotte Street but insisted their support was unwavering for a wellplanned, federally supported project for the South Bronx. Their conversation, sometimes affable, sometimes snappish, reflected the concerns and fears of people who live in the South Bronx and in the rest of the city. Excerpts from the discussion follow:

title: Ohio's Other Cities: A Rather Mixed Bag
description: CLEVELAND  When Cleveland announced in December that it couldn't meet $15.5 million in I.O.U.'s, officials of other Ohio cities jumped on planes for New York. Cleveland's problems aren't ours. they told the big investment houses and bondrating services. and we want to keep it that way. For the most part. they were right. As Cleveland's voters decide on Tuesday on two measures to pull their city out of default, many other urban centers in the country's Premier industrial state look to be in fiscal health.

title: Identical Twins Seen As Offering New Clues In a Psychology Study
description: LIMA, Ohio, Feb. 24 (AP)  A Minnesota psychologist wan's to study recently reunited identical twin brothers, James! Lewis and James Springer, to determine what effect environment and heredity! had on their development.

title: Radio
description: 12 A.M.6 P.M., WOR: Leukemia Radiothon Continues.(??

description: Picture Credits

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: AVON  Singles and Sequences, traditional and experimental styles of photography by Jim Hanelius, through March 11, Farmington Valley Arts Center, Studio 6A, 2 to 5 P.M. Weekends only. Information 6772132.

title: Koch Urges New Role for Community College to Get More State Aid
description: ALBANY, Feb. 21  Mayor Koch proposed this week that New York City Community College be made a technical school so it would be eligible to get more money from the state.

title: The Airport at Tikal  An Uneasy Deterioration
description: Just before the 55minute flight from Guatemala City to Tikal is over, passengers seated on the right side of the plane get a breathtaking view of Mayan ruins. Down below, peeking through the rain forest of Petn, are the elaborately sculptured roof combs of enormous pyramids, soaring hundreds of feet into the air.

title: Three Robbers Kill 2, Wound 2 in a Holdup Of a Club in Brooklyn
description: Two men were killed and a man and a woman were wounded before dawn yesterday in a barrage of gunfire by three holdup men who invaded a crowded Brooklyn social club, opened fire when a doorkeeper and a manager resisted their entry and fled with $200 from the club's till, the police reported.

title: Guards Move to Break Gang Members Grip At a Prison in Illinois
description: JOLIET, Ill., Feb. 24 (UPI)  In a surprise operation, stat officials used riotequipped guards and state police today to regain control of the Stateville Correctional Center from streetgang inmates.

title: INTERVIEW
description: BEDFORD HILLS IT'S not a bad dreamlhey can wake up from, PeggyMuncie said. Women are here to stay, becoming more and more integrated into the fabric of the church, and as soon as those people who are opposed to us realize that, we'll all be better off.

title: New Direction for the U.D.C.
description: A little more than a decade ago, the New York State Urban Development Corporation rose to national prominence as new governmental vehicle to rebuild slums with drastic powers to override local regulations, condemn properties, and issue taxexempt bonds.

title: Topics
description: Not so long ago, open marriages were all the rage among America's social avantgarde  a way to enjoy the pleasures of matrimony without its restrictions. But practitioners of open marriage are now beginning to get a closedin feeling as a result of the tribulations of Lee Marvin. The actor is being sued by a former roommate for more than a million dollars on the ground that she is entitled to some of the money he earned during the six years that she loved, honored and obeyed him.

title: Customs Advice: Know Before You Go
description: Jeffrey Haddow, a New York actor and writer, and his wife recently returned to the United States from a tour of the Far East. They were carrying four bottles of liquor, purcnasea auiyfree in Hong Kong. To their amazement, two of the bottles were confiscated by customs officials at San Francisco International Airport on the ground that one quart per person was the legal limit.

title: New Reasons Given for Nassau SalesTax Request
description: SETTLEMENTS anticipated for Civil Seivice unions this year and a cushion desired for future county budget increases were the major reasons for the Nassau Republican request for a 1 percent salestax increase, high county officials said last week.

title: Douglas Landback Fianc of Miss Finn
description: James A. Finn Jr. of Southport, Conn., and Rosemary B. Finn of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Macy Finn, to Douglas McDonald Landback, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Landback Jr. of Lewiston, N.Y.

title: Carole E. McMahon Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry Thomas McMahon Jr. of Kenilworth, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carole Elizabeth McMahon, to Willard Carlisle Butcher, a widower of Wilton, Conn. He is the son of Willard Ferris Butcher of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and the late Helen Calhoun Butcher. A June wedding is planned.

title: A Russian Fan's Notes
description: TO BUILD A CASTLE My Life as a Dissentir. By Vladimir Bukovsky. Translated by Michael Scammell. 438 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $17.50.

title: A Pennsylvania Legislator, Jailed For Contempt, Freed on Appeal
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 (UPI) State Representative Milton Street, under a 90day prison sentence and a fine of $5,000 for civil contempt of court, was freed from the House of Correction early today pending an appeal.

title: Token Clerk in Bulletproof Booth in Brooklyn Is Beaten and Robbed
description: A subway token clerk in a bulletproof booth was beaten and robbed at gunpoint early yesterday in Brooklyn by three teenagers who forced their way in by prying a panel off the booth and pointing a gun at him.

title: GARDENING
description: GARDENERS who have been penned up all winter are usually eager to flex their muscles at this time of year. Any kind of chore to take them outdoors is welcome.

title: Thousands Hail Queen Elizabeth As Her Yacht Lands in Abu Dhabi
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, Feb. 24 (UPI)  Queen Elizabeth II arrived in Abu Dhabi today to a warm Welcome from Government officials and thousands of cheering citizens.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Howell B. Smith, 81, a Founder Of Merchant Shipping Company

title: N.C.A.A. Delves Into the Recruiting Ruses
description: A private plane landed at a small Western airport last Sunday and then look off for points unknown with one of the best high school football players in the nation. The young athele was not cen by family or fiends until Wednesday when he reappeared at his home where he signed a National Letter of In tent to attend the college of his choice.

title: Martin Ritt Focuses on Labor Strife
description: LOS ANGELES The coffee tastes like burnt rubber. It slops over the edges of the styrofoam cup and dribbles down director Martin Ritt's jumpsuit. He hardly bothers to wipe it away. There is snow on the mountains and the track is last, a parlay potent enough to drag him away from his other passion, tennis.

title: ART VIEW
description: In the culture of the present moment, nothing seems more natural to us than that artists should regularly show their latest works in both solo and group exhibitions, that the art of the past should be removed from its place of origin and transported for exhibition abroad, and that critics should  as a matter of course  write about these events in the periodical Dress. We might complain about the failures of excesses of the exhibition system. and express dismay about the quality of the criticism our exhibitions receive, but we rarely question the preeminent place that our culture gives to exhibitions and criticism as a means of safeguarding our intercourse with art. On the contrary, the clamor nowadays is likely to be for more exhibitions and for more critical discussion of them. It is hard for us to imagine the life of art without them.

title: It's a Time for Testing
description: Kevin Donovan is a senior at Benjamin Franklin High School in East Harlem who is well on his way to completing his course requirements for a high school diploma. But he hasn't been able to make it past the math section of the state's new minimum competency program, and so he may not get the diploma. I need that degree to fall back on, he said the other day. It's a kind of cushion.

title: Fordham Women Capture State Basketball Crown
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 24 (AP)  Anne Gregory scored 17 points and pulled down 11 rebounds to lead Fordharn to a 6360 victory over Army and help it clinch the championship of the New York State Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women.

title: Long Island Becomes Major Port In Drug Smuggling, Officials Say
description: MELVILLE, L.I.  From the bridge of the Point Wells, Bintswain's Mate First Class Paul Keller could Just make out the spectral shape of a ketch in the waters north of Gardiners Island. She was low in the water and moving slowly westward under sail and power but her mast light was out. Petty Officer Keller said.

title: In Stamford, Six Acres of Personality
description: STAMFORD WE call it the junkyard with a personality, said John Lodato, strolling around his six acres strewn with farm wagons, auto bumpers, wreathed stone vases, concrete deities ranging from angels to Minervas, 1930'svintage refrigerators and washtubs, New York City street signs, and even an old subway car.

title: Williwaw Captures S.O.R.C. Yacht Crown
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas. Feb. 24 The champion of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference is Williwaw, Seymour Sinett's 45foot sloop from the Raritan Yacht Club and Perth Amboy, N.J. The Southern circuit's overall winner was decided in the sixth and final race of the series yesterday, the Nassau Cup, when Williwaw beat Acadia, Tenacious and High Roler over a 27mile, fivelegged course east of the island.

title: DEMOCRATS APPROVE NEW DELEGATE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  The Democratic Party, in its anxiety to assure that the 1980 convention fairly reflects the strength of contending candidates, has adopted a new set of rules that may produce some bizarre results in the selection of delegates.

title: New Raids Last Week Struck at the Guerrillas
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia  The cycle of violence turned again last week for Rhodesia's transitional Government and its guerrilla foes. This time it was the guerrillas who were the victims. Intelligence indicated a guerrilla offensive in the offing, and the Government dispatched its few precious Canberra and Mirage jets against guerrilla bases in Zambia and Mozambique. The sight of the camouflagepainted jets streaking back to base boosted the sagging morale of both whites and blacks whose fortunes ride with the provisional regime and its plan for limited black majority rule.

title: Deaths
description: PORTERVernette Stebbins.Widow of Professor David Burr Porter died Feb 20, at SanDie93, Calif Mother of John Stebbins Porter of Salem. Oregon and Elizabeth P Barraza of Coronado, Calif. Sur vived by six grandchildren and on great granddaughter. Mernoria; service Fri, Mar 2, apm, at Chris Church Bronxvilte. No flowers. Gifts may be made to Women of Christ Church, Mission Fund.

title: Conservative Groups Are Target Of Criticism at Educators' Parley
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP)Several hundred teachers took a crash course this weekend in the A B C's of politics as practiced by a variety of conservative groups known as the New Right.

title: Duke Five Conquers North Carolina, 4740
description: DURHAM. N.C.. Feb. 24 (AP) Jim Spanarkel scored a gamehigh 17 points and Duke overcame a surprise firsthalf fourcorners delay offense as the Blue Devils defeated North Carolina, 4740, and forced a lie for first place in the Atlantic Coast Conference tonight

title: Plane Crash Kills Student Pilot
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Feb. 23 (UPI) A student pilot was killed and his instructor critically burned in the crash of a small private plane that struck a brick building and burst into flames yesterday.

title: D. H. Lawrence's New Mexico Shrine
description: In northern New Mexico, above the old Spanish village of Taos, a rough dirt track climbs steeply from Arroyo Hondo to cross the mottled green ;lopes of Lobo Mountain, where cloud shadows sail like great birds.

title: DINING OUT; Spicing as It Should Be
description: HOMER'S Szechuan South, which recently opened in Massapequa Park, is the southent branch of Homer's Szechuan Star a deservedly popular restaurant in Woodbury Now the overflow Sunday crowd from Woodbury can simply zip down Route 135 to the new place, or vice versa. Good planning.

title: China's Soldier Is Put to Test
description: He is a short, wiry fellow; highly moti vated, strictly disciplined, with an extraordinary capacity tb survive reverses and physical hardship. He is the Chinese soldier. His enemy, the Vietnamese soldier, is skillful, wellarmed and, most all, experienced.

title: Miss Fitzgibbon, Andrew Watson Set July 14 Bridal
description: Margaret Mary Fitzgibbon of New York, a specialeducation teacher at Westwood (N.J.) High School, and Andrew Graham Watson, also of New York, a lawyer with the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, plan to be married July 14 in Ridgewood, N.J.

title: Conflict Between 2 Yemens
description: Fighting erupted between Southern Yemen and Yemen on the tip of the Arabian Peninsula, with each accusing the other of starting the fight. Page 11.

title: Dena Kleiman Sets Wedding to Lawyer
description: Dr. and Mrs. A.H. Kleiman of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dena Kleiman, to Ronald H. Shechtman, a partner in the New York law firm of Gordon & Shechtman.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: The happy heart of Whoopee lies in its extreme idiocy. And in the deep respect that the people from the Goodspeed Opera House, who mounted the show last summer an I rode it into town week ago, have shown that idiocy. Disinterring the musical comedies of the 1920's is of course skittish business. We can't stand a mile outside them and poke fun at what doesn't make sense. That would be crass us, would turn us into dolts and upstarts on the spot, because the musicals of the 1920's weren't supposed to make sense. They were, if you'll forgive the obviousness of the remark, meant to make nonsense. But one decade's nonsense is not another's (Polish jokes hadn't come along yet), and how do you slip under the skin of a lunacy whose special inflections may have been lost?

title: Bossy Ties League Mark by Scoring In 10th Game in Row; Rangers Win
description: UNIONDALE. L.I. Feb. 24  Mike Bossy, the New York Islanders highscoring right wing, did not keep the 14,995 fans in Nassau Coliseum waiting long this afternoon.

title: Incomes Up On the Island
description: WASHINGTON IN Nassau County's tiny, exclusive North Hills, the percapita income has soared past $50,000. At the other end of the income scale, the 5,200 people in Nassau's Island Park have a percapita income of considerably less than $5,000.

title: Police Kill Man, Shoot a Second In Robbery Near Station House
description: One gunman was killed and his ccomplice wounded last night when they held up a Brooklyn drugstore next to a Transit Authority police station house, the police reported.

title: Mondale Stresses Limits On Troop Use Overseas
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP)  Vice President Mondale says the Carter Administration has closed the door on the use of American troops in other countries except under the most extreme, compelling circumstances.

title: Brothers, Write Down Everything
description: FRAGMENTS OF ISABELLA A Memoir of Auschwitz. By Isabella Leitner. Edited and with an epilogue by Irving A. Leitner. 112 pp. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell. $7.95.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: LARGE houses are becoming increasingly difficult to sell. Small houses, on the other hand. have never been more in demand.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Elm City Kennel Club Gilbreed athern Connecticut State College Moote Adhouse Wintergreen Avenue New Haven 15dogs 5 A.M.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Y.W.C.A. Designers Show House 79, Glencliff, Sarles Street, Mount Kisco.

title: Best Sellers
description: NONFICTION

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets)  A Man for All Seasons, in an Actor's CafTheater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through March 17). $3.50$5.50; students and the elderly, $2.5044.50.(201) 4297662. Westminster Theater.

title: THE MARKETS
description: Last week, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company raised its dividend, bond prices slumped, the casino stocks went wild for a day or two and investors who weren't worrying about inflation expressed concern over the Chinese invasion of Vietnam. The net effect of all this, along with other assorted factors, on the Dow Jones industrial average was to send it down 3.73 points to 823.28.

title: CRIME
description: Richard Cunningham has done a great deal of research for his A CEREMONY IN THE LINCOLN TUNNEL (Sheed Andrews & McMeel, $9.95), and never for a moment does he let the reader forget it. He has read everything on the subject. But how to get it into a novel? He invents sandhogs talking about the past and other creaky devices, at:d gets page after page of mater tai into the book. A good deal of it could have been cut.

title: Building on Solid Character
description: THE Fairfield County home of Joe and Janet Harris is a mlange, an assembly of parts, collection  both personal and architectural. Built in the 20th century. Darts of the house came from razed New England barns and schoolhouses, and the furnishings are products of the couple's penchant for collecting on an international basis.

title: Deaths
description: GLANQUINTO  William M., M.D., on Thursday, Feb 22. 1979, beloved husband of Elizabeth M. (nee Williams), devoted father of Marie Ann, Elizabeth M. Cypress. Albert W., Theresa M. and Nina M. Glanquinto, brother of Mrs Mary Falcooe and Peter Glanquinto. Reposing at the Macken Mortuary. 52 Clinton Ave. Rockville Centre, NY. Mass of Resurrection, St. Agnes Cathedral, Monday, Feb 26, 10AM. The family will receive friends 25 and 79PM.

title: Nixon Campaign Unit Ignores Million in Bills And Registers a Profit
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI)  Rich and Nixon's 1972 campaign committee turned a $100,000 profit in 1978 while ig noring bills of more than $1 million from a number of Watergate figures.

title: No Fulyack He
description: IN MEMORY YET GREEN The Autobiography of Isaac Asimov. 19201954. Illustrated. 732 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $15.95.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: DEPUTY LEADER SAYS IRAN WILL RESTART OIL SALES IN 15 DAYS
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 24  Iran will begin selling oil abroad within 15 days, according to Abbas Amir Entezam, a Deputy Prime Minister. I can't tell you the amount, Mr. Entezam said today. It may be more, less than or equal to the exports of the previous Government.

title: Jewish Heritage Relived at Museum Of the Diaspora
description: It takes a lot of nerve to call yourself a historical museum and, in the same breath, boast that you do not house a solitary original historical artifact. But that's what Beth Hatefutsoth, the new and innovative $10 million museum of the Jewish Diaspora in Tel Aviv, has done, and, if public reaction is any indication, done quite successfully.

title: Rozhdestvensky Conducts Shostakovich's Fourth
description: Gennady Rozhaestvensky, the Soviet conductor, made his debut with the New York Philharmonic in this weekend's concerts. It was also the first time he had conducted an American orchestra here, and for his first program he led Mozart's Symphony No. 34 in (K. 338) and Shostakovich's Symphony No. 4 (Op. 43). The two works could hardly be more different in character.

title: 3,000 Union Members Hold Rally Backing a Virginia Shipyard Strike
description: NEWPORT NEWS. Va., Feb. 24 Striking shipyard workers and members of unions in Virginia affiliated with the American Federation of Labor and Congress of industrial Organizations held a march and rally here today in support of ?? strike by the United Steelworkers of America against the state's largest private employer, the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.

title: A House for the Blind: To Some, It's Segregation
description: A snake pit. That's how Sara Neufeld describes modern apartment houses. Circular walls, sunken plazas, shrubberylined walkways and artfully concealed elevators may be fine for most people, but for Mrs. Neufeld, who is blind, these eyepleasing architectural flourishes are at best a nuisance and sometimes even hazardous.

title: Knight Helps Knicks Subdue Nets, 111107
description: The Knicks ended a sevengame losing streak, their longest in 13 National Basketball Association seasons, last night by defeating the New Jersey Nets. 111107, at Madison Square Garden. It as only the Knicks' fourth triumph in the last 17 games and the first since they traded Bob McAdoo. their leading scoren to the Boston Celtics on Feb. 11.

title: L.I Mapping Strategy to Combat Gypsy Moth Infestation
description: WEST SAYVILLE, L.I., Feb. 20 While most of the Northeast was digging out of snow. Federal and Suffolk County officials met here today to worry about a summertime problem, the gypsy moth.

title: State Plans Limits on Camping in Areas of Catskills and Adirondacks
description: NEW PALTZ, N.Y.  Proposed restrictions to bar camping and campfires on the high peaks of the Adirondack and Catskill Mountains have been announced by the State Department of Environmental Conservation in an attempt to preserve the fragile alpine environment there.

title: Mixing Memory and Desire
description: FARE forward, says the poet, and most people do, Including Bruce Mason, hero of Wallace Stegner's 12th novel.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Police Searches: Who Cares?
description: WHEN the United States Su preme Court held last May in the case of Zurcher V. Stamford Daily that the Constitution did not prohibit unannounced police searches of newsrooms, it came close to inviting legislative or executive efforts to erect nonconstitutional protections for the press. Joining Congress and a number of other states, the Connecticut General Assembly is now considering legislation to do just that.

title: Planes in Runway Crash
description: MEMPHIS, Feb. 24 (AP)  A runway collision at Memphis International Air port early today heavily damaged two cargo planes, but all four crewmen es Gaped uninjured, the authorities said.

title: LETTER TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: A blueribbon panel has suggested that Connecticut finance education through a statewide tax program, which means that an income tax, long opposed by the great majority of Connecticut voters, is close at hand. State financing of education will also transfer responsibility for education from the cities and towns to the central government in Hartford.

title: Julie E. Johnston Is Bride Of Edward P. Golkowski
description: The marriage of Julie E. Johnston, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Frank N. Johnston of Manhasset, L.I., to Edward Palmer Golkowski, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Golkowski of Holyoke, Mass., took place yesterday.

title: The Gilded Age Revisited
description: THERE are several predictable responses to the architecture and furnishings of the Victorian period: amusement, disdain, or, as rebellion against the lessismore Artistic climate, pleasure in an abundance of ornament. But few people react with more than superficial knowledge or understanding, and until recently there has been practically no place to learn.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11:30 A.M. (2) Face the Nation Defense Secretary Harold Brown.

title: Putting a Miscellany in the Tank
description: WASHINGTON  For years, nearly all journalistic accounts of revolutionary new power sources for automobiles have been assumed to belong to the same genre as stories offering new hope for the dead. But one new fuel, gasohol, has caught the public's attention, and last week Holly Hodge. president of the National Gasohol Commission. fielded incessantly ringing telephones in his Lincoln, Neb., headquarters as he logged inquiries from Canadian, French and Finnish groups. I think gasohol is finally beginning to take off, he said.

title: The Press vs. the Corporation
description: SEVERAL years ago Rothwell Laboratories, a wellknown pharmaceutical manufacturer, developed a drug that proved remarkably effective in treating urinary infections. Prothorin, as it was called, received approval from the Food and Drug Administration and soon became the principal prescription In its field. A year or so later a young hematologist at the University of Alabama, working with new spectrographic techniques, found traces of Prothorin in the hair follicles of patients who had taken the drug and then suddenly turned prematurely bald. He reported his findings at a medical conference, where a science reporter for a leading newspaper happened to be present. The next day the reporter called Rothwell for their reaction to this alleged sideeffect.

title: Future Events March Lions Style In
description: Feb. 28  Andr Laug, the tall Roman, will oversee the showing of his readytowear and madetoorder collections this morning on Bergdorf Goodman's second floor. His favorite color for spring this year is apricot, with creamy pastels trimming his clothes for daytime and evening. Subtlety is his secret from the way he adds lace and the hand detailing. Subtlety also is a skill of the Youth Counseling League that will benefit from the showing, which offers aperitifs hued to the garments, and also kors d'oeuvres. The league, a merger of the Girls and Boys Service League and Youth Consultation Service, offers psychotherapy for young men and women, aged 19 to 25, through rap rooms in public schools or at its building in New York on East 19th Street and its office in White Plains. Some of the youngsters it helps are referred by courts and schools, some come because they decided they wanted help, or a friend said they needed help. Some pay nothing for the help they get. Some pay as little as 50 cents. Some even get carfare from the league to their sessions. Tickets: $20 from 4734300 or at Bergdorf's door.

title: Urban Arts Corps Faces Ouster And Search for a New Theater
description: The Urban Arts Corps, a theatrical training and producing group that put on the successful Broadway musical Don't Bother Me, I Can't Cope, is being evicted by new owners from the building housing the Urban Arts Corps Theater, at 26 West 20th Street. Vinnette Carroll, the corps' director, said We're desperate.

title: WHY 900 DIED IN GUYANA
description: Some who escaped the Jonestown massacre shed new light on the tragic mystery of how a megalomaniac leader  inspiring both faith and fear turned his own humanitarian vision into an orgy of suicide and murder.

title: Liquor Deregulation: A Shot in the Dark?
description: WHEN the dust finally settles around the decision of the Byrne administration to decontrol liquor prices in New Jersey, we may have been treated to an opportunity to watch pluralistic (call it specialinterest) politics at its most formidable.

title: An Estate May Be Key to Breaking
description: DARIEN AS it has done year after year for decades, the Planning and Zoning Commission will shortly consider whether Darien should permit apartments to legally exist. In the past, said Raymond Nurme, the town planner, the issue of multipleoccupancy housing Would be actively debated for 10 minutes and then firmly voted down. This year, however, there are subtle and perhaps inevitable hints of change in the it that are not without shades of irony.

title: Union Ordered to Pay $260,000
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 24 (AP  The Fall River Educators Associatio) has been ordered to pay $260,000 in fine for ignoring a backtowork order in las fall's teachers' strike. Superior Cour Judge August C. Taveira, who had levied the fines against the union, ordered the payment yesterday. The union said tha enforcement of the order would ruin i financially.

title: Just Desserts for Princeton Cartoonists
description: PRINCETON ONCE a week, Hilda, a waitress at The Annex, a restaurant here, plays mother to some of the many cartoonists who have chosen to live in this college town. As a result, says Tom George, the son of Rube Goldberg, the legendary cartoonist, Hilda knows more about us than we do.

title: FOOD
description: AS bluefish is in summer, whiting, cod and, to a certain extent, flounder are the staples in winter. Right now, whiting is the most plentitul and the cheapest fish coming in on local fishing boats, with a going price of about 98 cents pound. Can you think of another fish that regularly retails for under $1?

title: Bare Bones Of Sounds
description: On one level or another, almost all art is about itself, but the young composer William Hawley has taken this 20thcentury truism to an interesting extreme. The five nieces he presented at the Kitchen on Wednesday evening stripped music of melody and rhythm and reduced it to the barest bones of sound, often to simply one repeated note or chord.

title: THE BAKKE CASE MOVES TO THE FACTORY
description: Brian Weber is suing his company for excluding him from training in favor of a black. The outcome may profoundly affect America's work place.

title: Music, Anyone? The Choice Is Wide
description: DESPITE competition from New York City and Philadelphia, and even without a centralized major arts center. musical life in New Jersey is thriving.

title: A Jeweler With a Passion for the Past
description: A visitor to New York who drops in at Fred Leighton in search of a Mexican wedding dress is out of luck these days.

title: Elizabeth Sutcliffe Is Betrothed
description: Elizabeth Anne Sutcliffe, a staff nurse at Nassau Hospital in Mineola, Li., and Philip Russell Martin of Hackensack, N.J., a sales representative in Bergen County for the Procter & Gamble Company, plan to be married in June. Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Hyland Sutcliffe of Garden City, L.I., parents of the bridetobe, have announced the engagement. Mr. and Mrs. Rodney Martin of Syracuse are the future bridegroom's parents.

title: Emil Kratzman 3d Weds Deborah Dillworth
description: In St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Radnor, Pa., yesterday morning, Deborah M. Dillworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Dillworth of St. Davids, Pa., became the bride of Emil Arthur Kratzman 3d, son of Dr. E. Arthur Kratzman of Plainfield, N.J., and the late Mrs. Kratzman. The Rev. John A. Smart performed the ceremony.

title: Misadventures Of Cocoa Trade
description: The chocolate bar is an edible American flag, a security blanket for the distraught, barometer of a nation's economic health. It also the product of a secretive, volatile and bizarre global trade where beans are often sold simply to knock down prices or confuse the competition and export figures are distorted by substantial smuggling.

title: An Effort to Make It Safer for the Aged
description: THE Yonkers Office for Aging recently received a $16,000 grant from the state to help elderly residents learn to protect themselves against crime and establish a network of communication With other elderly people in publichousing projects.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: In 1960, Peck's Slip looked like the picture on this page: six small, old, vernacular Georgian houses of the 18th and early 19th Century standing against the splendid backdrop of the Brooklyn Bridge  one of the city's oldest and rarest, intact architectural survivals.

title: Diabetes Hearings Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP)  The Senate Subcommittee on Health and Scientific Research, headed by Senator Richard S. Schweiker, Rrepublican of Pennsylvania, will hold a hearing Monday on a bill aimed at improving efforts to prevent. diagnose and control diabetes.

title: Barbara Mosenthal Plans June Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Andreae Waters Mosenthal of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, and Corinth, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Andreae Mosenthal, to Alexander Brooke Wood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leighton C. Wood of New Canaan, Conn., and Jamaica, Vt.

title: Undersea Campus Helps in Oil Search
description: CHRISTIANSTED, St. Croix, V.I.

title: Marijean Raffetto, Lawyer, to Be Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Raffetto of Sea Girt, N.J., and Pompano Beach. Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marijean E. Raffetto, to Frederick William Stevens Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stevens of Spring Lake Heights, N.J.

title: Deaths
description: D?? MATTEORev. Msgr. Emilio. On Feb. 23rd, 1979, Pastor of Saint Anthony Church from 1940 to 1969. Reposing at Woodlawn Morticians Chapel, 4418 White Plains Road (near 238th St.), Bronx, Sunday 25 and 710 and Monday at Saint Anthony Church, 4505 Richardson Ave, 25, 78, Mass of the Eucharist, Monday 8 P.M. Archbishop John J. Maguire Principal Celebrant. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 10 A.M. Terrence Cardinal Cooke Principal Celebrant The Homilies wilt be delivered by Bishop Anthony Mestice, interment Gate at Heaven Cemeterv.

title: Kitchen Greenhouse Offers Nourishment To the Good Life
description: FAMILIES gain room to socialize, and good food and sweet flowers gain space in which to cohabit, in the greenhousekitchens that more and more are being added to country homes.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: SPANISH FORGER

title: 30 Short Subjects
description: POLITICS AND CINEMA is a trim collection of 30 reviews and essays that Andrew Sarris has published (mainly in the pages of the Village Voice) during the last eight years. The topics and Mr. Sarris's sentiments  are fairly predictable. He writes about censorship (he's against it), pornography (he prefers softcore to hard), violence (he concludes that each of us has a different threshold of outrage), and the left and right (his own position, he says, is rabidly centrist).

title: Paving for Oil
description: President Carter would now be facing a firstclass dilemma over oil and inflation even if nothing had happened in Iran. Any day now, he must decide whether or not to deregulate the price of oil. Rarely do competing interests involve such a headon collision:

title: The Nation
description: The Bureau of Labor Statistics. the Federal Reserve Board. and the A.F.L.C.I.O. all issued economic pronouncements last week that exceeded the recently established quota of pessimism about the prospects for inflation and the success of President Carter's program to combat it.

title: Milk Drivers' Union Starts Walkout
description: Milk drivers and dairy workers at plants in New York City and on Long Island struck last night, beginning a walkout that threatened to cut off milk supplies for 10 million people. Contract talks were not scheduled to resume until Tuesday.

title: Frank Olson Fianc Of Linda Mogerley
description: The engagement of Linda Susan Mogerley to Frank Blakely Olson has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Albert F. Mogerley of HoHoKus, N.J., parents of the future bride. Mr. Olson is a son of Mr and Mrs. Frank A. Olson of Ridgewood, N.J., and Prouts Neck, Me.

title: . . . Can Spring Be Far?
description: FEBRUARY is a mean month in Westchester, a narrowlipped, Puritan month with a switch in its back pocket. Only a penitential saint could love it. After the exhilaration of the December holidays, the uplifting hopes for ourselves in the first month of a new year, February slams us to the wall with an icy hand and says: Forget it, sucker. It's a gritty, dingy world and you'll never make it out of here alive.

title: Miss York Engaged To S.P. Goldsmith
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Porch of North Windham, Me., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Porch's daughter, Martha H. York, to Stephen Price Goldsmith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Price Goldsmith of Scarsdale. N.Y.

title: Also Known as Bertie
description: EDWARD VII Prince and King. By Giles St. Aubyn. Illustrated. 555 pp. New York: Atheneum. $19.95.

title: A Composers Label That Survived
description: Back in the early 1950's, during the first years of the longplaying record, small specialist labels appeared by the dozens, flourished for a while and then died a quick natural death.
