One that refused to go under, although few people would have laid favorable odds on its survival at the time, was Composers Reconlines. Inc., better known under its initials, CRI. This year, in fact, marks CRI's 25th anniversary, and if the company is hardly raking in pots of money (for the past two years the label has been operating as a nonprofit, taxexempt organization), it is decidedly a going concern and one with reasonably bright prospects for the future.

title: 5 New Southern Governors Seek Bold Changes Despite the Risks,
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 24  Since he took office la'st month, Gov. Foxrest H. James Jr. of Alabama has dismissed 700 politically wellconnected state employees, proposed the first new State Constitution in 100 years that was not designed to disfranchise blacks, and stunned the state's education establishment by ordering achievement tests for every pupil in Alabama's lowranking public schools.

title: To the Roots Of Fairfield With a Recorder
description: I have lived in this area half my life and thought I knew it extremely well, yet the insights I gained during a recent gig as an oral historian were wholly new. I interviewed a dozen men and women who had come as immigrants to the WestportNorwalk area, some recently, some at the beginning of the century. I recorded vivid word picture of Saugatuck when most of its residents were Italian; thoughtful dialogue between a husband and wife from Costa Rica about bringing up their daughters in the United States; a teacher's recollection of im migrant schoolchildren in Norwalk in 1928.

title: MIRRORS OF OUR TIME
description: T he exhibition Transformations in Modem Architecture, which opens at the Museum of Modem Art this week, is the big roundup of building of the last 20 years that the museum has promised to deliver for some time, and for which the art and architectural worlds have been waiting with something akin to bated breath. This listing of trends and achievements, this summing up of styles, these nominations to an ephemeral hall of fame or cabinet of curiosities  all are clearly meant to be the definitive presentation as well as a kind of architectural box score of recent years. Their purpose is to tell us what really has been going on in this time of recordbreaking building activity and intense esthetic debate.

title: STAMPS
description: Albert Einstein was an obscure young man of 25 in 1904, and could be seen daily in the late afternoon wheeling a baby carriage on the streets of Bern, Switzerland. He would halt now and then, unmindful of the traffic about him, to scribble down some mathematical symbols. in a notebook that shared the carriage with his infant son.

title: Andrea M. Praeger Fiance of Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephan J. Blaut of New York and Chilmark, Mass., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Blaut's daughter, Andrea Maxine Praeger, to Henry Samuel Hacker, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank E. Hacker of Beacon, N.Y. A spring wedding is planned.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING
description: THE buyer of a new tie,An(:, particularly the first limar often lulls himself into thinking that, between signing the contract and the actual closing, all wil proceed smoothly with the construe tion.

title: Infants' Deaths in Italy Traced to Known Disorders
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 23  The mysterious deaths among infants in Naples, Italy, were not caused by a new lethal virus, as was suspected, but by outbreaks of previously known disorders, according to a member of the international team of doctors that investigated the situation.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: THEATER

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: E.R. Meaney Is the Fianc Of Miss Duffy
description: Angenette Mallory Duffy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Duffy of Greenwich, Conn., and Hilton Head Isand, S.C., was married yesterday evening to E. Robert Meaney. He is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Meaney of Philadelphia, where his faner was a vice president of the Welngton Fund.

title: The World
description: Revolutionary Iran has twin governments but they are not very fraternal The secretive Islamic revolutionary committee of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini last week ordered the execution of four more of the Shah's generals without the knowledge of Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan.

title: Calendar: Baskets,
description: Fiber Forms Exhibit, The Yellow Door, 24 Washington Avenue, Tenafly.

title: The Case for Decimating Gerrymandering
description: THE County Charter requires the County Board of Legislators to redraw or reapportion boundaries of the 17 legislative districts based on population changes after each decennial census, the next one of which will be conducted next year.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Forty years ago. there was a war on in the American dance world. a war between classical ballet and modern dance. Classicists accused the moderns of being technically limited and esthetically eccentric. while the moderns charged that ballet was a European art form irrelevant to America.

title: Some Reflections On Soviet N.H.L. Series at Garden
description: I was somewhat delighted to see the Soviet national team win the Challenge Cup series from the National Hockey League AllStars. Indeed. I considered it a victory for pure hockey over hooliganism.

title: Great Human Beings of Boxing
description: There was this assemblage of human beings in the Barron Suite of the Waldorf. The host was Don King, a great human being who promotes fights, and the Hilton Hotels Corporation was picking up the tab. Don King said Barron Hilton was a great human being. He introduced a great human being named Frank G.

title: Dubious Delicacies for the Vegetable Patch
description: The seed catalogues are offering some dubious delicacies this year that just may grow into a fascinating harvest. How about a square tomato or a hollow one or a white one? A blue potato? A black radish or a yellow beet? Or a purple cauliflower? Gardeners who are game, can push aside ordinary peas and beans and make room for suchnovelties.

title: Mill Fabric Bargains Save Yards of Cash
description: TRYING to find inexpensive fabric by top designers and manufacturers is, to borrow the name of one of Angelo Donghia's prints, like shooting for the moon. But lunar shots are possible if you shop in mill outlets and discount fabric stores, which carry acres of cloth discounted 50 percent and sometimes more. Colors may be a touch off register or off shade from the pattern's standards, but this is usually of no concern to smalllot buyers. Sometimes, an inconspicuous thread is pulled, or nothing at all is wrong and the mill is merely closing out the line.

title: An Empty Nest Certainly Can Hold A Lot of Things
description: THEY call them empty nesters  those whose children have finally grown up (or claim they are grown up), those who have houses bigger than they need, those who for every logical reason should move to smaller quarters.

title: South Africa Golfer Is Convicted Of Shooting a Black in the Back
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 24 (AP) Bobby Locke, a leading South African golfer, has been sentenced to pay a $140 fine or spend 60 days in jail after he was convicted of having shot a black laborer in the back.

title: A Shopper's Guide to Hong Kong
description: Once upon a time Hong Kong was, for Americans, the bargain capital of the world, with quality goods of all kinds available for less than in the country of origin. No longer. The dollar is down, and overhead and prices are up here as elsewhere. Nonetheless, good buys can still be found, off the beaten track in back alleys, factory districts and even private homes.

title: Slowly, the Vatican Is Moving From the Palaces to the Pueblos
description: When Pope John Paul II last week denounced exploitation of man by man as well as by the state and economic systems, he was asserting a view of the Roman Catholic church's proper relationship to the temporal realm that is at variance with much of the theory and practice of ages of Christian history.

title: 570 Who Died in Guyana to Be Buried on the Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO. Feb. 24  They lie in 20gauge steel coffins in Delaware, 570 bodies that no one has claimed. But after months of political and financial maneuvering. the remaining bodies of People's Temple members who died last November in Guyana will be returned to California for burial.

title: Other World Events
description: Last week Bangladesh took one hesitant step toward democracy by electing a new parliament. Since 1975, the country has been ruled under martial law by President Ziaur Rahman, who took power in a coup d'tat shortly after Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the country's founder, was killed another coup. General Zia, whose National Party won 203 300 legislative seats, promised to lift martial law within week after Parliament convenes in March. But he is keeping real power to himself for now. He will remain as President and he will not decide about resigning as armed forces commander in chief until he sees how parliamentary government develops. One key barometer will be the extent of foreign investment; General Zia said that is what the democratization was all about.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Greenhouse Insulation

title: Kitchen Greenhouse Offers Nourishment To the Good Life
description: FAMILIES gain room to socialize, and good food and sweet flowers gain space in which to cohabit, in the greenhousekitchens that more and more are being added to country homes.

title: FILM VIEW
description: 0nethird of the way into The Deer Hunter, there's a scene that ought to give anyone a kingsized fright. After an hour devoted to deerstalking and wedding festivities in western Pennsylvania, the movie abruptly shifts gears and transports three of its principals to Vietnam, where they are soon imprisoned by enemy soldiers and tortured. The seauence involves rats. underwater cages and a compulsory game of Russian roulette, but what really ought to give you the willies is a glance at your watch. At this juncture, The Deer Hunter has set up a sharp contrast between its bucolic smalltown setting and the atrocities in Vietnam, has introduced an element of genuinely unbearable violence, and still has two hours to go. Will you, the captive audience, spend the rest of that time being scared?

title: 2,000 Watch Russian Take Lead in Luge
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 24. Luge racing, on an official international basis, was introduced today in this Adirondack community as 86 athletes representing 19 nations competed in singles events on the new $4.8 million Mount Van Hoevenberg run.

title: Correction
description: In the review of The Wild Boy of Burundi by Harlan Lane and Richard Psillard (Feb. 4), the photographer Marion Kaplan was inadvertently identified as a man.

title: Aging Revolutionary
description: HONG KONG  In 1929, a young Chinese Communist named Teng fisiaopirw, was sent to a remote mountainous area in Kwangsi province near the border of then French Indochina to organize a peasant uprising. Mr. Teng's mission brought him into contart with Vietname ?? bels, anti when French warplanes bombed his gaerrilla base in pursuit of the Vietnamese. we shot one down, Mr. Teng later recalled. It was the bez,inning of Mr. Teng's long career as a ??? volutiencry A brilliant but blunt and often impatient man, he would later challenge Mao Tsetung and be twice purged for his temerity. Yet he sumived to become China's key leader.

title: What's Doing in MONACO
description: FOR BIG SPENDERS  Before you read any farther, be warned. Unless something wonderful happens to the dollar, or you are dead certain you know when 13 will come up three times running on the Casino's Big Wheel (the last recorded observation of this phenomenon was in 1894), you probably cannot afford to visit Monaco this year  well, at least not in the style to which it has become accustomed to be visited.

title: In Spain, the Don't Knows May Decide The Elections
description: MADRID  In the last 26 months, Spaniards have been thrice called to the polls to express their views on the nation's impressive transformation from dictatorship to democracy. On Thursday, the 26.8 million voters will again be summoned to vote for a new Parliament, but politicians are worried that their nonstop politicking since Francisco Franco's death in November 1975 has bored the population.

title: Notes: Britain Prepares a Welcome
description: There's a bottle of champagne  and probably a few other rewards  waiting for the two millionth American to visit Britain this year. The champagne will be presented by Sir Henry Marking, chairman the British Authority, who was in New York not long ago to call attention to the fact that the authority is observing its 50th year as the agency charged with the responsibility of attracting travelers to England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

title: An Empty Nest Certainly Can Hold A Lot of Things
description: THEY call them empty nest ers  those whose children have finally grown up (o claim they are grown up) those who have houses bigger than they need, those who for every logical rea son should move to smaller quarters.

title: THEATER; There's Trouble in River City
description: EAST WINDSOR THERE are 21 performers involved in the Coachlight production of Meredith Wilison's 1957 hit musical, The Music Man. Considering how tiny the stage at the Coachlight is, that no one crashes into any into anyone else throughout is a tribute to the staging of David Guthrie and to the choreography of Connie Shafer. The costumes and the use of assorted summery pastels meant to suggest Middle America in 1912 are most attractive. Obviously, the production is on the right track visually. That it goes wrong emotionally, is largely because of its star in the title role, billed as Mr. Ronald Young, and quite likely because of David Guthrie, the director, who allowed him to get away, with his conception of the role.

title: Stories Sly as a Pike
description: LIVE BAIT And Other Stories. By Frank Tuohy. 181 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $7.95.

title: Housing Aid for Mine Area
description: RINGWOOD, N.J.  It is difficult to see the work that has been going on in the Appalachialike region of this corn, munity at the foot of the Ramapo Mountains just under the New York State border. The latest snowfall has left a light blanket that covers the area. But under that powder are brand new roofs, trenches dug for septic tanks and other signs of construction busyness

title: We Used to Run This Country, Said a Departing American Last Week
description: TEHERAN, Iran  On Wednesday, United States Ambassador William H. Sullivan paid his first visit to Iran's new Prime Minister, Mehdi Bazargan, the former opposition leader whom he studiously ignored for months while he conferred almost daily with the nowexiled Shah.

title: Foreign Policy Issues Test Definitions of Presidential Leadership
description: WASHINGTON  The battlelines for 1980 have begun to form. The psychological buffeting this nation has suffered abroad in the past fortnight  the most painful period of foreign policy setbacks since the fall of Vietnam  has fired the first debate of the campaign, a crucial quarrel over leadership.

title: GARDENING
description: GARDENERS who have been penned up all winter are usually eager to flex their muscles at this time of year. Any kind of chore to take them outdoors is welcome

title: HOME CLINIC; Keeping Rooms Warm and Thawing Frozen Pipes
description: DURING very cold weather, when temperatures often drop to zero or below, some homeowners (and many apartmentdwellers) find that their heating systems just cannot supply the heat required to keep the house at 68 degrees or more. For these people, as well as for anyone interested in conserving fuel, any step one can take to conserve heat or redirect it in the right direction is worth taking.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Franco Agostini's piano recital last Saturday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall was an oddly mixed bag. Mr. Agostini, who teaches at the Bologna Conservatory and is currently artist in residence at Washington University in St. Louis, numbers among his teachers one of Busoni's last pupils, Alessanaro Constantinides, and is himself a Busoni specialist, both musically and musicologically. Yet his program only included one, fiveminute piece by Busoni, the choral prelude on Mein Seele bangt und hofft zu Dir.

title: Silent on Location
description: THE WAIL THE WEST, AND TICE WILDERNESS By Kevin Brownlow. Illustrated. G02 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: About New Jersey: Paterson's Resurgence
description: PATERSON HAVE you been to this city lately? If not, you should take a look at what is happening in this somewhat depressed, often overlooked municipality, a place that to many is nothing more than the city for which WPAT, radio's beautiful music station, is named and the site of a rather glum downtown.

title: Next School Test: Quality
description: HARTFORD WHILE the debate over the financing of public schools has been occupying center stage in the state, another controversy has been brewing over how to make sure the quality of education from district to district is as equal as its financing.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: BOSTON As of o??e ame in 1981, the Boston Museum of Fine Arts will be half as big again as it is now. And none too soon, either: For the Museum of Fine Arts is one of the world's great holding institutions, and altogether too large a proportion of what it holds is at present way down out of sight.

title: They Sing Praises of Pasta In Its Infinite Variety
description: WASHINGTON THE trouble with most Americans is that they don't experiment with pasta, John Denton Scott was saying recently as he deftly spooned a savory clam sauce over a steaming bowl of drained marazette (little shells).

title: A NoFrills Approach to Product Safety
description: WASHINGTON Item: 495 people were killed in 1975 and 1976 trying to install television and citizen band antennas  the No. cause of electrocution in this country.

title: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Woolf
description: THE UNKNOWN VIRGINIA WOOLF By Roger Poole. 285 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $11.95.

title: Designers: Where, Why and How Much
description: YOU'RE moving out of a 15room house to a luxury condominium, at half the space and twice the price. Or you've had it with communal clustering, and are forsaking the garden apartment for a coveted singlefamily house. Or, perhaps, you're fed up with vacuuming carpets and dusting heirlooms, or are just plain tired of your carpets, drapes and living room sofa.

title: Home on the Prairie
description: LIMITS OF THE LAND By Curtis Harnack. 232 pp. New York: Doubleday &Co. $8.95.

title: Catherine C. Ziehl Sets June 24 Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Ziehl of Greens Farms, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Cornelia Ziehl, to Larry Earl Nirenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Nirenberg of Springfield, Mass. The wedding is planned for June 24 at the Ziehl home.

title: ExShipyard Worker Keeps List of Victims Of Radiation Disease
description: KITTERY, Me., Feb. 24 (AP)  Roland Belhumeur keeps a list of his friends at the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard who have died. The list, once a single page, now includes several folders of death certificates, autopsy reports and radiation data. There are 90 names on the list.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: LOS ANGELES  In the musical form known as a canon, two voices state the same theme, note for note, interval by interval, one slightly after another. To the untrained ear they may sound different, but they are not. Foreign policy debates sometimes take the same form. Dean Rusk, testifying before J. W. Fulbright, would say, The United States can't be policeman for the entire world. And, as if in harsh contradiction, the Senator would repeat, The United States can't be policeman for the entire world. Counterpoint, but subtle.

title: Making Space A Tangible Bit og Life
description: AFTER waiting and planning for a year to remodel their shingled cottage, things weren't going well for the Long Island couple. Artistic and sensitive to good design, they nevertheless found themselves with expensive furniture they didn't particularly like and a fragmented scheme that just wasn't pulled together.

title: Crustaceans of all Nations
description: Fish and seafood have a curious habit of thriving in one set of waters and floundering  no pun intended  in others. The sole of the English Channel do not thrive in American waters although efforts have been made to cultivate them here. American lobsters are choosy, too, about their habitat.

title: Jersey Measure Stymied
description: Trenton, Feb. 24  Efforts to raise the legal age for drinking alcohol in New Jersey from 18 to 19 years appears to have been stymied in the Judiciary Committee of the Assembly. But a member of the committee said a package of bills dealing with teenage drinking was being Prepared.

title: Focus Is on Morris In Housing Dispute
description: MORRISTOWN THE most sweeping legal challenge to the suburban right to exclude cityscape sights highrise buildings, row housing, mobile homes  is working its way toward a decision in Morris County.

title: Langtry, Tex., Where Judge Roy Bean Was the Law
description: A shrine to a nutty old reprobate who set himself up as a tinhorn dictator in the Rio Grande country less than a century ago is Judge Roy Bean's Jersey Lilly Saloon, in Langtry, Tex. The fact that Bean's combination courthouse and barroom is now preserved by, the state probably has him spinning in his grave.

title: 2Job Professor Violated Ethics, Rutgers Alleges
description: Until early 1977, Charles I. Villiers was a tenured faculty member at two college in the metropolitan area  Rutgers University, where he taught night classes in French literature, and the C.W. Post Cen ter of Long Island University.

title: City's SchoolBus Dispute Issues
description: Parties: The bus drivers' strike differs from most labormanagement conflicts. It is a wildcat strike, not officially authorized by the drivers' union, Locals 1181 and 1061 of the Amalgamated Transit Union. The drivers' nommal employers, bus compames including the Varsity and Pioneer companies, have said they are in sympathy with the strike. The drivers' dispute is with New York City's Board of Education, which contracts with the companies for their services and is seeking to change the system under which bus contracts are let.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Based on the recent Howe Cup Tournament, Princeton has the toprated women's squash team, with Yale and Harvard close behind. But Don Russell, director of athletics and coach of the women's squash team at Wesleyan University in Middletown, where the United States National Women's Intercollegiate Squash Tournament will be held Friday through next Sunday, rates Gail Ramsey of Penn State about the best in the country.

title: Auto Workers Getting Increase
description: DETROIT, Feb. 24 (UPI)  The United Automobile Workers union says that 820,000 members in the United States and Canada will get a 13centanhour raise in their costofliving allowance because of the latest increase in the Consumer Price Index.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING
description: NAMING streets and roads for persons living or dead, famous or obscure, was a practice that was rare until this century. It peaked in the 1950's and is now infrequent.

title: The Disco DrumBeating in Perspective
description: In just the past few weeks, disco has become downright fat and sassy. A recent spate of articles has given the impression that rock and indeed all other forms of popular music are pass, and that disco alone remains as the true spirit of the 1970's. Starting tomorrow, Billboard Magazine's fifth annual Disco Forum convention begins in New York. and is likely to be full of hortatory selfcongratulation along the same lines.

title: U.S. Officials Suggest Presence of More Sites Of Radioactive Waste
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  Government officials said today that more old radioactive waste dumps of the kind discovered this month in Denver were prob. ably scattered around the country. But. the officials said that nobody knew how many such sites there were, where they were situated or how much of a hazard they presented to public health.

title: Deaths
description: BARNETTJack. Son of the late Harry and Mollie Barnett. Brother O' the late Jean Grodetsky. Beloved uncle of Merrill and Sandra. Service Sunday 12:30 at The Westchester Riverside, 21 West Broad St, Mt Vernon. N.Y. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Jack Barnett Scholar ship Fund. Lehigh University, will be appreciated

title: His Own Hero
description: ALWAYS MERRY AND BRIGHT The Life of Henry Miller. By Jay Martin. Illustrated. 560 pp. Santa Barbara, Calif.: Capra Press. $15.

title: Designers: Where
description: RESIDENTS of New Jersey who wanted to redo their living quarters or to transform a barn into a weekend refuge, once had to cross the Hudson to find a decorator. But no more.

title: Miss Susskind To Be a Bride
description: Pamela Susskind of South Hadley, Mass., and Robert Pettier, a lawyer and rarebook dealer, plan to be married June 17.

title: Knicks Seeking Same Old Ending to Same Old Story
description: There was turmoil. The coach was dismissed early in the season. The Knicks greeted their new coach with resounding victory, but in the end they fell to last place. They had committed themselves to building through the college draft. The crop in the college draft was said to be a poor one.

title: Even to Sold Out Festivals There Are Always Tickets
description: Every year tens of thousands of Americans head for Europe in hopes of partaking of the cultural feast that is the Continent's music festivals. Some find instead that they are left with a famine, especially if they arrive without tickets or their cash runs low.

title: Miami's Airport: Awful on Sunday
description: One of the three baggage carousels in the international arrival section of Miami International Airport clicks into motion and the first bags off an overseas flight pop out a dark hole and slide down a short chute onto steel plates moving in a circle.

title: Winner of the War Between the Maras
description: Now that the Giants have hired George Young and Ray Perkins to plot their future, a truce exists in the War Beween the Maras, although a truce does not assure a lasting peace. But maybe the war was worth it. Out of the verbal disagreements between Wellington Mara, the 62yearold uncle, and Tim Mara. the 43yearold

title: Memorial to Franklin Roosevelt Held Too Costly by Interior Dept.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP)  A proposed memorial to the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt is being opposed by the Interior Department as too costly to construct and maintain.

title: Michigan Court Bars Oil Drilling in Forest To Protect Elk Habitat
description: WOLVERINE, Mich., Feb. 24  Michi gan's dwindling elk herd, the only one cast of the Mississippi River, has been reprieved by a ruling in the Michigan Supreme Court.

title: BATTLE AT LANG SON ON VIETNAM BORDER IS REPORTED BEGUN
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 24  Western analysts said here today that a majoor battle between Chinese invaders and Vietnamese regular troops appeared to have begun around Lang Son, 85 miles northeast of Hanoi, and that action of similar scale appeared to be taking place near Lao Cai, northwest of the Vietnamese capital.

title: I.R.S. Eyes Some Special Cases
description: This year the Internal Revenue Service is applying a finetooth comb to certain sections of tax returns.

title: ART
description: NEW BRUNSWICK WHAT prompts collectors to collect? The reasons for collecting art objects are numerous, but some of the most rudimentary ones have to do with pride of possession, the appreciation of beauty and the necessity to be near it.

title: Shadow of Khomeini Falls On the Mideast Peace Talks
description: WASHINGTON  In hindsight, the warnings at the first Camp David meeting were there, but no one noticed. On Sept. 8, just as President Carter, President Anwar elSadat and Prime Minister Menachem Begin were getting down to business, Shah Mo. hammed Riza Pahlevi's army opened fire and killed 58 Iranians in the streets of Teheran. It was an early sign of the turmoil that was to explode and transform the political terrain of the Middle East.

title: Rikers I. Inmate, 41, Found Dead; Correction Dept. Calls It Suicide
description: A 41yearold inmate at Rikers Island who was being held in a mentalobservation area and was to be released tomorrow committed suicide Friday night, authorities said yesterday.

title: Marriage Announcement 11 -- No Title
description: Larry Sheer, Dental Student, To Many Randy B. Meredith

title: Garrett List's A1 Band Blends Individual Styles
description: Garrett List's A1 Band has survived several complete transformations and explored a bewildering number of musical directions, but the latest edition of the group, which appeared in concert at New York University on Friday night, has staked out a territory all its own. It's a broad territory indeed. Electronics sound poetry bebop free jazz, country and western songs, and ethnic influences from around the world are a few of the ingredients, and the wonder is, everything the band touches becomes imbued with its peculiar personality.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: The Hollywood connection. The future of the paperback lies in showbiz. In fact, some people are saying that the softcover book is becoming more closely tied to the entertainment world than to hardcover publishing. This recent outburst from the officer of a major paperback house sent us hurrying to discover whether a large section of the industry really is about to go Hollywood. Here's what we found:

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Donations to Neediest Continuing
description: The 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund recorded $6,119.72 in donations yesterday, bringing total contributions for the current drive to $1.096.956.80.

title: Other National Events
description: Stockton, Calif., won a dubious distinction last week from the Bureau of Labor Statistics the highest metropolitan unemployment rate in the country. 11.2 percent. As in many cities, work in Stockton is seasonal. But in the San Joaquin Valley, it is especially so. Stockton's fields, packing sheds and canneries have provided generations of Californians with fourtofive months' work a year. best. The local unemployment office is called, optimistically, the Employment Development Department.

title: Thousands Go West for a Total Solar Eclipse Tomorrow
description: BIG SKY, Mont., Feb. 24  Tens of thousands of eclipse enthusiasts joined professional astronomers filling hotels and lodges along a wide stretch of the northwestern United States today seeking perches for the total eclipse of the sun on Monday. It will be the last one in the continental United States until the year 2017

title: Prospects Grow Dim for Aqueduct Accord
description: You're nothing but garbage, a picketing parimutuel clerk screamed at a horseplayer yesterday outside the main entrance to Aqueduct.

title: On Taking the Bus And Leaving the Driving to the State
description: ADECADE ago, New Jersey, in response to a threatened halt of major bus service, enacted a $500,000 emergency subsidy program for eight private carriers.

title: McGuinn Rock Group at a Club
description: It wasn't the Second Coming, but McGuinn, Clark and Hillman's opening set at the Bottom Line Friday evening was certainly a pleasant and rousing surprise. When a rock group reunites. it's usually a desperate, disheartening affair, especially when the band in its original incarnation was as magical as the Byrds were during the 1960's.

title: ANTIQUES; The Island's Own Style
description: IDENTIFICATION of regional characteristics is an important factor in studying American furniture. The use of specific, locally available woods, the preference for certain decorative devices, and the constructional mannerisms of individual craftsmen are among the features that provide the necessary evidence for attributing'a piece of furniture to a geographic area.

title: The Music of Lawrence Kucharz
description: Lawrence Kucharz, who opened a weeklong series of performances by various artists at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation on Wednesday, is a formalist. What that means, in the context of the SoHo experimental music milieu, is that Mr. Kucharz evidences an apparent distrust of exoticism, repetition for hypnotic purposes and the last gasps of postSerialism. His music is so minimal there is no place in it for melody, nor does harmonic resonance play a very important part.

title: Defects Cited In New Buses
description: WHITE PLAINS ONE morning last month after a torrential rain, Westchester officials were appalled to discover that the fleet of brand new buses they are counting on to revitalize mass transit in the suburbs leaked.

title: Beauty
description: Oldfashioned, homemade cosmetic formulas are still with us  and some of them do live up to their reputation, though none work miracles. However, the ingredients are easy to find and the preparations fun to make.

title: PEOPLE
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, it was learned last week, will stop issuing Master Charge credit cards, and it blamed Louis J. Lefkowitz, former New York State Attorney General, for the move.

title: Annie Damaz, Expert On the Placement of Art
description: Annie Damaz, an art consultant to architects and an expert in French stained glass, died Feb. 17 at her home in New York City. She was 60 years old and was the wife of Paul F. Damaz, the architect.

title: First War Reports in Peking Depict Charging Chinese
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 24  Chinese troops have charged fortified Vietnamese positions to the call of bugles and some have deliberately sacrificed themselves to blow up Vietnamese mountaintop bunkers, the Chinese press agency, Hsinhua. said today.

title: J. Bradley Colburn, 76, a Partner With a New York City Law Firm
description: J. Bradley Colburn, senior partner in the law firm of Barnes, Richardson & Colburn of New York and Washington, died Friday in St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. Mr. Colburn, a resident of Port Wash ington, L.I., was 76 years old.

title: Hearings Set on Utility Cutoffs
description: TEANECK DR. ROBERT GROSKIN says he finds it ironic that New Jersey's largest utility company should have public service in its corporate name. He believes that the Public Service Electric and Gas Company is interested only in increased profits, even if that means cutting off heat and light in the dead of winter to a family that falls behind in its payments.

title: IN BRIEF
description: In the wake of the cutoff of Iranian crudeoil supplies, which is having major impact on world oil prices, the oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries anflounced last week that they would meet in Geneva on March 26 to discuss the current market situation.... The OPEC announcement was followed by a 5 percent oilprice rise by Libya and reports by several American oil companies that they would reduce deliveries to their customers as the effects of the shutdown since Dec. 27 of Iranian oil production continued to spread. Shell Oil, Phillips Petroleum, Atlantic Richfield and Exxon announced they would curtail some of their oil deliveries in the United States.

title: DINING OUT
description: HERE and there, as one wanders about the state, one encounters pleasant little restaurants that, while not especially distinguished, offer an agreeable contrast to the impersonality of the ubiquitous fastfood chains. Such modest restaurants are often popular lunchtime magnets for local office workers or fill a local need for a light, unpretentious noon or evening meal at reasonable enough cost. While not the place one might choose for a celebratory dinner or special occasion, such a restaurant provides a decent light meal in an informal atmosphere.

title: At Home: Absurdly Happy
description: WRILE I know a few people who are content and a greater number who are holding their own against depression, I can think of only one person in my acquaintance who is actively happy. You might even say that he is absurdly happy, a phrase invented especially for our time.

title: An Avenue for StreetWise Art by the Young
description: IT IS not the usual museum exhibit. And at first glance the casual visitor might be confused at the sight of children's crayon drawings of cars, flowers, buildings and people sharing a wall with sophisticated studies in pen and ink, of black and white and color photographs hanging next to paintings done in oil and watercolor, of whimsical wooden constructions displayed near huge bronze busts.

title: Werewolves Blend Pop Strains
description: The Werewolves are produced by Andrew Loog Oldham, discoverer of the Rolling Stones, and their rockandroll is flavored with country and soul. They even do hardrock arrangements of the honkytonk standard Crazy Arms and the Wilson Pickett soul hit Three Time Loser. So this writer was prepared to like them immensely when he went to hear them at Hurrah on Thursday night, but he didn't.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: A Decorator and
description: APROMINENT Parisian antiques dealer recently wandered into Frederick P. Victoria's Dakota apartment in Manhattan, his eyes focusing with admiration on an ornate 18thcentury clock and barometer set.

title: Judgeship List Includes Women and Minorities
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI)  Two blacks, two women and a MexicanAmerican are among 23 persons selected as candidates for at least five newly created Federal appeals court judgeships, the Justice Department has announced

title: CAROL BELLAMY: COMING ON STRONG
description: Only a couple of years ago, Carol Bellamy was practically unknown. Today she is New York City Council President. Sooner or later says a prominent admirer. 'she is going to be the highest woman executive in the state.

title: Klansmen in Alabama Defy a Ban on Firearms
description: DECATUR. Ala., Feb. 24 (AP) About 150 robed Ku Klux Klansmen drove pickup trucks through this city in northcentral Alabama today, waving guns in defiance of a city ordinance banning firearms at demonstrations.

title: Charles Edward Miller Fianc of Gayle Wilson
description: Mr. and Mrs. John C. Wilson of Halifax, Nova Scotia, have announced the engagement of their daughter B. Gayle Wilson, to Charles Edward Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Miller of Greenwich. Conn.

title: The Metamorphosis of a Salesman
description: SUNNYVALE, Calif.  It's hard to tell the players in the booming semiconductor industry without an insider's scorecard: Nobody knows more about circuit design than the Intel Corporation, Texas Instruments is the best managed, National Semiconductor has the best manufacturing capabilities. As for Advanced Micro Devices, well . . .

title: Conran's Is Putting
description: ALTHOUGH Michael Tyson is a relative newcomer to this country he has already determined three important things about Westchester County: Harrison gives tickets for speeding, Waccabuc has fine housing accomodations for families that include six children, and New Rochelle provides an excellent base from which to build a nationwide homefurnishings complex.

title: Mother of 2 Renews An Olympic Quest
description: In 1959, Jessica Newberry helped the United States win the team silver medal in dressage at the PanAmerican Games in Chicago.

title: An Exploratory Visit To the First Hilton In Communist Europe
description: Life in Hungary's sybaritic Westernstyle hotels can be so pleasant that visitors run the risk of turning their backs on the real morld outside, including the ancient landmarks they came so far to see. Something akin to this happened to my wife, Valerie, and me when we stayed at the Budapest Hilton, the chain's first facility in the Communist world. We were so entranced that we found it difficult to venture into the wondrous city outside.

title: U.S. Project Seeking to Measure Effectiveness of Electric Vehicles
description: A Federal demonstration project on the feasibility of electricpowered vehicles getting under way in New York City and on Long Island. The Consolidated Edison Company even bolds out hope for some eventual help on holding down electric costs for all customers.

title: Russell Dumas Offers 2 Dances
description: The dances of Russell Dumas are like easy, incompleted line drawings or small knots of clay that suggest divine proportion. On Friday. Mr. Dumas presented two pieces in the fifth floor loft of the 541 Broadway studio complex. It was an evening of abstract dance that often resembled simple movement exercises but was, nonetheless, full of modest pleasures.

title: Americans Sweep Skating
description: GRENOBLE, France, Feb. 24 (A)  Beth Heiden smashed two world records and Craig Kressler won both men's events to give the Americans a dean sweep on the first day of the world junior speed skating championships.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: IT took 20 years, but H.D.'s rapturous account of her close relationship with Ezra Pound in the early years of this century will finally reach book form next May when New Directions brings out End to Torment.

title: Silverman Offers Peace To Hollywood Producers
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23  In his first major speech since he became president of the National Broadcasting Company last June, Fred Silverman extended an olive branch to the Hollywood production companies that create and produce primetime entertainment programming. Stressing that he was disturbed by the adversary relationship that has grown up between the networks and their suppliers, Mr. Silverman insisted that both parties must stop acting like the Hatfields and the McCoys.

title: Holding Down the Costs Of Traveling Overseas ... In Japan
description: Total: $130 a day. That, according to the latest State Department survey, is the shockingly high cost of living as a traveler in Tokyo, Fukioko, Antwerp and Brussels, making them the most expensivetovisit cities in the world. Small wonder that the the tourist industry in Japan is suffering from shock.

title: Billy Carter in Hospital in Georgia
description: AMERICUS, Ga., Feb. 24 (UPI)Billy Carter was reported in good condition today at the AmericusSumter County Hospital, where he was admitted yesterday for treatment of chronic bronchitis.

title: Around the Nation
description: Prison Shakedown in Illinois Yields Weapons and Drugs

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Steinbrenner Criticizes Martin's Pressure Tactic
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 25  George Steinbrenner, adding his own words to the ones Al Rosen spoke for him 24 hours earlier, said today that Billy Martin and Martin's agent were trying to pressure him in their escalating contract dispute by having Martin show up at the Yankee training camp last week.

title: Uncle Sam as Uncle Sugar
description: In the Washington world of special interest politics, no issue is more complex than Federal price supports for sugar. On one side are the growers of cane and beet sugar and their sometime allies. the producers of liquid corn sweetener. On the other are the big commercial customers  pastry, soft drink and candy companies  backed by State Department officials who are eager to keep open the American market to sugar growers in underdeveloped countries.

title: Olympic Trainer Has Some Tips For the Skier
description: OF the estimated total of 7.5 million skiers who will have headed down the slopes by the end of the season, 30,000 are not making the trip back up, because of fractures, sprains and strains. And many more thousands are feeling lesser hurts that will take much of the fun out of the sport's latewinter bustle.

title: 1936 Mercedes Is Auctioned For $400,000 in California
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 25  An unidentified auto enthusiast, bidding by telephone from Monte Carlo, today bought a 1936 Mercedes Benz 500K roadster for $400,000, almost twice the record ever paid for an automobile at auction. Christie's declined to identify the buyer further.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Farewell to the Heights

title: Supplies of Milk Being Depleted In Drivers Strike
description: The surprise strike of milk drivers and processing workers set off a milk rush yesterday in New York City and on Long Island, stripping many grocerystore dairy sections and prompting some families into making buying forays into New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: T.P.R.: Bullets Margin Shrinks as Kings Surge
description: This week's presentation of The New York Times's computerized team power ratings, for games of the National Basketball Association through last Monday, shows a slight loosening of the Washington Bullets grip on first place. The Bullets margin of 34 T.P.R. points over the secondplace team has shrunk to 13 since the most recent evaluation of the N.B.A., two weeks ago.

title: DOCTORS IN A SURVEY CHANGE CANCER VIEW
description: In a major change in attitude, most physicians who responded in a survey said they no longer kept the diagnosis of cancer secret from their patients, according to a report today in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Study Finds Women Lagging in Craft Jobs
description: Although women are slowly winning more highpaying, whitecollar jobs, they have made virtually no progress in breaking into traditionally maledominated work, a new study shows.

title: Fibak Captures Denver Tourney
description: DENVER, Feb. 25 (AP)  Wojtek Fibak solved Victor Amaya's blistering serve and rolled to a 64, 61 victory today in the final of a $125,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament.

title: Khomeini Meets Krethlin Envoy, Issues Warning
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 25  Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian Islamic leader, met last night with the Soviet Ambassador to Iran for what were believed to be the Shiite leader's first discussions with a foreign envoy in Teheran.

title: World News Briefs
description: NEW DELHI, Monday, Feb. 26 (Rent ers)  Sanjay Gandhi, the son of former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, was con. victed by a Delhi court today of five charges, including criminal conspiracy.

title: Battling on the Ice for Safety on the Job
Lettuce Strike Crippling 40% of California Output
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 25 In the rich Imperial Valley on the Mexican border, more than $10 million worth of lettuce is rotting in the fields. Striking members of the United Farm Workers of America, waving their red-andblack banners in protest, have prevented the harvesting of about 40 percent of the nation's winter lettuce crop.

title: Putting It Into B.T.U.'s
description: WASHINGTON  How can we expect Americans to participate knowledgeably in debate about our energy future if we have no common frame of reference?

title: A Kalashnikov Is Status Symbol in Yemen
description: AMRAN, Yemen  The shopkeeper reached back into his cluttered stall past other merchandise  canned fruit, cooking oil, kerosene lanterns and nulled out a sliahtiv used Soviet Kalashnikov assault rifle. He cleared the oiled chamber, stroked the polished wooden stock and handed it to a prospective customer for inspection. The price: 12,000 rials, or $2,670.

title: Shortage of Housing in Israel Reaches Crisis Proportions
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 25 With military service, the 1973 Middle East war and the university behind him, Yehuda Yahiri got married and then began what he described as the toughest ordeal in his life: searching for a decent apartment.

title: When Will Sun Shine on Torre?
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 25A lot of rain fell into the life of the manager of the New York Mets today. His second workout of spring training was cut short by storms sweeping off the Gulf of Mexico. His left thigh was hurting because he had strained a mus- cle while pitching in batting practice. And his house back in Demarest, N.J., was ransacked by burglars.

title: Joseph (Newsboy) Moriarty, 68, Longtime Jersey Gambler, Dies
description: Joseph Vincent (Newsboy) Moriarty, longtime gambling boss of Hudson County, N.J., died Saturday in Christ Hospital in Jersey City after a long illness. Mr. Moriarty was 68 years old and a lifelong resident of Jersey City.

title: Digest BUSINESS Dgest
description: Venezuela is reportedly raising fuel oil prices by $2 a barrel, or about 14 percent. The move by Venezuela, a big supplier of heavy fuel oil to the East Coast, where fuel prices are already soaring, would follow smaller increases on crude oil by three other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. [Page A1.]

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON AMIDST all the talk of the Federal budget deficit, little attention is being paid to the size of the equally important combined deficits of states and municipalities.

title: Treasury Bond Peak Precedes U.S. Note Sale
description: The credit markets fell sharply in price last week, driving interest rates higher. Longterm Treasury bonds yielded as much as 9.11 percent, their highest level on record.

title: Communist Bastion Faces Nibbling Attack by Lisbon
description: EVORA, Portugal  As the wet, cold evening envelops this city founded by Julius Caesar and crowded with some of the finest medieval buildings in Portugal, it seems calmly locked in its rich past. Al City Hall, however, the Mayor, a Communist, is talking not about the past but about the immediate future.

title: Assailant Hurls A Man to Death On IND Tracks
description: A man harassing subway passengers waiting at the West Fourth Street IND station hurled one to his death in front of an onrushing D train early yesterday.

title: Resurgence Of a Species
description: Varyinghare populations dropped precipitously in all but the remotest regions of the Northeast when it was settled and land cleared for agriculture. Now, with farm land reverting back to woods in many places, good hare habitats are being created.

title: Bullets Subdue Warriors
description: LANDOVER, Md., Feb. 25 (AP) Elvin Hayes poured in 31 points today as he led the Washington Bullets to a 99- 439 victory over the injuryriddled Golden State Warriors.

title: Commodities
description: CORN is the nation's biggest crop and secondmost actively traded commodity futures contract, after soybeans. The price of this basic feed grain has a direct impact on the cost of all foodstuffs.

title: U.S. Wants to Hamstring a Radio Pirate
description: Federal Investigators have combed the city with revolving directional antennas for the last two weekends in search of a foulmouthed pirate radio broadcaster who has made himelf at home at 1600 kilohertz on the AM dial.

title: 4 Seized As Big A Vandals
description: Four men were arrested for acts of vandalism yesterday at Aqueduct Race Track, where members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Local 3 have been on strike for 10 days. In a separate incident a pipe bomb exploded in the clubhouse, causing minor damage.

title: Three Iranians Flogged For Violations oF Laws
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 25  Although the semblance of normal life was returning today to Teheran, which bustled with traffic and shoppers strollin under a warm winter sun, Iran was still struggling with the reality of the new Islamic order.

title: The Dark of the Sun
description: I don't care that today's eclipse of the sun, which will be total in some regions, is the last total eclipse that most North Americans will see until the year 2017. I saw my total eclipse when I was nine years old, and it was a strange and not altogether benign event.

title: City Studies Artists Protests Over Rents at Carnegie Hall
description: Spurred by letters of complaint from tenants, Mayor Koch's office has engaged Touche Ross & Company, the publicaccounting and managementconsulting concern, to investigate a dispute between the Carnegie Hall Corporation and the artists who live aria work in 50 of the building's 190 studios on West 57th Street.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Tom Fleming of the New York A.C. won the 20th annual Mike Hannon Memorial 20mile run yesterday for the seventh time. His time was 1 hour 41 minutes 46 seconds.

title: Miss Hahn, Soprano, In Debut
description: EUN JAE HAHN, whose New York debut took place Saturday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall, is a Korean singer with degrees from Seoul National University and the Accademia di Santa Cecilia in Rome. She impressed as an engaging artist, with a generally fresh, bright soprano and a manner that is poised and sincere.

title: RealWage Insurance
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Congressional prospects for enactment of realwage insurance have been going up and down.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Not everyone is bearish on the bond market.

title: Piano: Janina Fialkowska Has Debut
description: THERE are two obvious disadvantages to programming such thricefamiliar keyboard works as Liszt's B minor Sonata, Bach's Bflat Partita and Chopin's Bflat minor Scherzo, all of which figured in Janina Fialkowska's New York debut recital Saturday night at the 92d Street Young Men'sYoung Women's Hebrew Association. One disadvantage is that some of the magic of this music inevitably wears off as a result of frequent exposure. The other is that superior performances are so common that the odds are stacked against hearing a performance that really stands out.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Stage: Artichoke, a Comic Ballad, at Manhattan Theater Club
description: THERE is no music in Arilchoke, aside from a little discordant humming, but it has the feel of a comic ballad, and in many respects a delightful one.

title: Luge: East Germans Sweep Trials
description: LAKE PLACID. N.Y., Feb. 25 Gunther Dettler and Melitta Spillman of East Germany, both world champions, won the singles loge trials today at the new Olympic run here.

title: Vietnamese Are Locked in Battle With Chinese at 3 Frontier Towns
description: Vietnamese and Chinese infantry and artillery were locked in a series of stubbornly fought battles yesterday in Vietnam's frontier region, according to United States officials.

title: Bullets: On Top but Still I
description: LANDOVER. MD. IN 1968 Abe Pollin, one of two sons of a Maryland real estate contractor, bought out his two partners, Earl Foreman and Arnold Heft, to get full ownership of the Baltimore Bullets, a mediocre National Basketball Association franchise playing in a renovated auditorium known as the Baltimore Civic Center.

title: ModelPlane Show Draws Thousands in White Plains
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 25  It started for many who crowded into one of the nation's largest and most advanced modelairplane shows here today with rubber power, the windup propellers that carried balsa wood and thin paper planes aloft, briefly and often haphazardly.

title: Partial Eclipse Is Due Over New York City
description: In today's eclipse, only 61.percent of the sun will be covered over New York City. The city's partial eclipse will begin at about 10:59 A.M. and will last until about 1:31 P.M. The eclipse over New York will be maximum at about 12:15 P.M., when the sun is almost due south. The first nick to appear in the solar disk as the eclipse begins will be in the part of the sun's face corresponding to 2:45 on the face of a clock.

title: Cosmos Victors, 61; Chinaglia Scores 2
description: NASSAU, The Bahamas, Feb. 25 (UPI)  The Cosmos, behind a pair of goals by Giorgio Chinaglia. ran off to a 50 halftime lead today, then coasted to a 6I exhibition victory over an allstar team.

title: Bossy's Streak Ends as Rangers Topple Islanders, 32
description: The Rangers ended Mike Bossy's goalscoring streak last night and beat the Islanders, 32, at Madison SquareGarden young Ranger goalie who was starting for the first time since last Jan. 15. In that game Soetaert was bombed out by the Minnesota North Stars and shortly afterward sent down to the minors for conditioning. He and Wayne Thomas were filling in for John Davidson, the regular goalie who had a pulled hamstring muscle.

title: Still a Hoax to FlatEarth Group
description: Most people have come to accept the idea that the sun, the earth and the moon are all spheres, and that eclipses occur because of the rotation of the earth around tne sun and ox tne moon around the earth. But one group of people, the International Flat Earth Research Society, contends that such an explanation is merely part of a gigantic hoax.

title: Sidney R. Cooperband, Director Of Cancer Research, Dies at 47
description: BOSTON,Feb. 25 (AP)  Sidney R. Cooperband, director of the Hubert H. Humphrey Cancer Research Center at Boston University's School of Medicine, died last night at University Hospital here after a long illness, Boston University reported. He was 47 years old.

title: Carter Asks Support for Trade Pact
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 25  President Carter appealed today to the nation's governors to help him win Congressional approval of a new international trade agreement being negotiated in Geneva, saying greater world commerce not only brings prosperity but also opens 'new avenues to peace.

title: A Nazi Rally Fails to Materialize In Park Near Independence Hall
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 (AP)  A Nazi rally scheduled for noon in a park across from Independence Hall and several counterdemonstrations failed to materialize today.

title: E.C.A.C. Issues Berth Selections
description: CENTERVIL1.E, Mass , Feb. 25 (UPI)  Berths for this week's three Eastern College Athletic Conference Division I basketball tournaments were announced today.

title: Cornelius Cosman, 64, Consultant on Minerals
description: Cornelius M. Cosman, a metallurgist, researcher and consultant, died of cancer Saturday in Phelps Memorial Hospital, Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 64 years old and a resident of Swarthmore, Pa.

title: Iraq Discounts Religious Element in Iran Uprising
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 25  The Govermnent of Iraq, a Moslem nation with a Shiite majority but a predominantly Sunni leadership, is said to view the revolution in neighboring Iran as an internal affair and not a general Shiite uprising that threatens to spread.

title: VENEZUELA RAISING OIL PRICES BY 14%, TRADE SOURCES SAY
description: Venezuela has decided to raise fueloil prices by more than $2 a barrel, or about 19 percent. effective March 1, according to industry sources. The increase reportedly would affect only heavy fuel oil, which Venezuela exports mainly to the East Coast of the United States and which accounts for roughly a third of Venezuela's total oil exports.

title: New York Seeks U.S. Aid to Cover Care of Derelicts and Proud Poor
description: ALBANY, Feb. 25  State and New York City officials are working on a plan they say would pump at least $27 million in extra aid this year into the city by getting the Federal Government to pay for a larger share of healthcare programs for derelicts and the proud poor, who are unwilling to apply for Federal Medicaid assistance.

title: Yemen Seeks Arab League Session on Border Fighting
description: CAIRO, Feb. 25  Yemen today formally requested a meeting of the Arab League Council to discuss what it charged was a military attack from Southern Yemen.

title: Travelers Are Stranded In Midwest Snowstorm
description: A powerful storm dumped as much as two feet of snow on Arkansas, Illinois and Missouri today, stranding travelers and cutting off power to 90,000 customers.

title: Grading the Nation's Prisons
description: Given the taxpayer revolt and the prevailing tough attitude toward criminals, it is harder than ever to get state and local governments to spend enough to maintain prisons adequately. But they will have little choice if courts Keep jailing offenders in record numbers, straining an already overcrowded penal system. In state after state, inmates protesting the condition of correctional facilities have persuaded judges to order an end to crowded cells, inadequate medical care  or worse.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Dinner at the Elusive Otto's: The Disappointing Details
description: SHOHOLA, Pa.  What else but the promise of an extraordinary dinner could lure three serious eaters out on a rainy night to drive for two hours across two rivers (the Hudson and the Delaware), through an everthickening peasoup fog, along unmarked and unlighted back roads that wind and dip through the foothills of the Poconos to this wayside hamlet?

title: Carter Telling Friends He Disavows Comment By Brother About Jews
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  President Carter has disavowed comments about Jews made by his brother Billy, saying that they do not reflect his own feelings and that he regrets that they had been made at all. ,

title: Advertising
description: Competing For Young Mommas

title: Men's Styles: FlagWaving Is in Order
description: The peacock revolution, which brought men out of their sack suits and into love beads, Nehru jackets and bleached jeans in the 1960's, has moved on. Designers have emerged, almost as prominently as in the women's fashion field. Indeed, many names, such as Pierre Cardin in Paris and Calvin Klein and Geoffrey Beene in this country, straddle both the men's and the women's fashion arenas.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: HARRY LEVI
description: Harry Levi, a founding member of the ZionistRevisionist Movement with Vladimir Jabotinsky and an activist for the rights of Soviet Jews, died Saturday in New York City. He was 72 years old.

title: Israeli Gasoline Nears $3 a Gallon
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 25 (Reuters)  Israel tonight increased the price of gasoline by 39 percent in response to the cutoff of oil supplies from Iran.

title: First Full Lulu of Berg Draws World Notables to Paris Opera
description: PARIS, Feb. 25 Perhaps the most important and glamorous operatic premiere since the end of World War II took place at the Opera last night when Alban Berg's Lulu was presented for the first time in its original three acts. Adding to the suspense of the longawaited premiere was the threat of a stagehands strike on the evening of the performance. But the opera, conducted by Pierre Boulez, with a controversial staging by Patrice Chereau, did go on as scheduled, and the great first night is now part of history. There were cheers and bravos at the end  but many critics and Berg specialists walked out muttering. the first time in its original three acts. Adding to the suspense of the longawaited premiere was the threat of a stagehands strike on the evening of the performance. But the opera, conducted by Pierre Boulez, with a controversial staging by Patrice Chereau, did go on as scheduled, and the great first night is now part of history. There were cheers and bravos at the end  but many critics and Berg specialists walked out muttering.

title: U.S. Negotiator Sees 2 Last Hurdles in Trade Talks
description: GENEVA, Feb 25  The United States negotiator sees only two major issues remaining to be settled at the Tokyo Round of trade talks here, although he concedes there still are a number of question marks.

title: WNET Fund Drive Lists Special Events
description: WNETTV's annual fundraising campaign, which it calls Festival/ Thirteen, a membership and public awareness drive, will run for 16 days starting Saturday. It will include nearly the entire gamut of Channel 13 programming, from The Grand Old Opry through Beethoven, a film on elephants, Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet and MGM musicals to Albert Einstein.

title: Letter: On Lloyd's of New York; Is It Legal? Is It Fair?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meeting for week follows:

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: When William A. Mitchell retired from the General Foods Corporation in 1976, he thought he would remain active by working as a consultant to the big food company and other corporations. Little did he imagine how busy he would be, especially during the last two months.

title: Foreign Banks Get U.S. Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) The Federal Reserve Board has adopted standards governing the operations of foreign banks in the United States.

title: Elizabeth, on Arab Tour, Gets Gifts That Are Worth Millions
description: LONDON, Feb. 25  Queen Elizabeth H, heading into the final third of her 18day goodwill visit to the Persian Gulf, has been showered with millions of dollars in gifts by her Arab hosts_

title: News Summary
description: Menachem Begin will be asked tojoin President Carter and Prime Minister Mustafa Khalil of Egypt at the Camp David IsraeliEgyptian peace talks. President Carter said that plans were being made for Prime Minister Begin to come to the United States for another, perhaps decisive, effort to conclude the negotiations. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: The Man Who Came to Dinner
description: THE man who came to dinner died the other day. His name was Tommy Brophy, and in all their lives Bill and Mildred O'Brien never had a more agreeable guest. In 1946 on his way home to Elmhurst, Queens, from World War II, Tom stopped to say hello to the O'Brien in their apartment on West 116th Street. They persuaded him to stay for the weekend. He stayed 14 years.

title: Cello: Grossman Plays Brahms, Janacek, Bartok
description: THERE is nothing quite like hearing a young musician in complete technical command of his instrument and fired with the will to communicate music for which he feels a special empathy. This was the feeling one got at Jerry urossman's cello recital Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and the concert was indeed a splendid one on all counts.

title: Gothaum Calls Koch Bus Plan Strikebreaking
description: Victor Gotbaum, the municipal union leader, yesterday attacked as strikebreaking Mayor Koch's assignment of municipal employees to drive stranded handicapped children to school today.

title: New Site Planned For Title Fight
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 25 (UPI)  A new site for yesterday's canceled World Boxing Association lightheavyweight title bout between Mike Rossman, the champion, and Victor Galindez of Argentina will be announced within a few days for sometime in April, Bob Arum, the Top Rank Inc. promoter, said today.

title: Skating: Beth Heiden Wins
description: GRENOBLE, France, Feb. 25 (AP)  Beth Heiden of Madison, Wis., swept to the world junior speedskating championship, winning every women's event today and yesterday and setting world junior records in each.

title: Connors Conquers Gerulaitis in Final
description: DORADO, P. R., Feb. 25 (UPI)  Jimmy Connors maintained his mastery over Vitas Gerulaitis in the final of a $200,000, sixman tournament today, 6-5.6-0, 64.

title: Meany Backs Reporter In Action by Teamsters
description: BAL HARBOUR. Fla., Feb. 25 (AP) George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations. says the teamsters union ought to be ashamed of themselves for trying to subpoena the notes of a reporter in connection with a suit filed by a teamster dissident.

title: TV SPORTS
description: TONIGHT

title: Peking and Hanoi Assailed by Asian Neighbor at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 25 The countries of Southeast Asia closest to the Indochina fighting called here today on China and Vietnam to halt hostilities and for the withdrawal of foreign troops from Vietnam and Cambodia.

title: Seagram Tower Offered for Sale At $75 Million
description: The Seagram Building, the 38story bronze-and-glass Park Avenue tower widely acclaimed as New York City's finest postwar skyscraper, has been offered for sale at a minimum price of $75 milIlion.

title: An Innovator in Machine Tools
description: FRASER, Mich.  Ralph E. Cross, chhirman of the Cross & Trecker Corporation, stood next to a large machinetool complex and said with pride, This is one of the few of its kind in the world.

title: If Praise Overflows, It's Tourney Time
description: College basketball fans can tell that it's getting to be tournament time by the effusive compliments being spouted by coaches about their impending opponents.

title: Sporting Gear
description: For skiers who don't have the right kind of car for over-the-roof or over-the-trunk ski racks, here's an alternative: SkiHiker mountings for side windows. Straps hook under the glass, and the racks are held firmly in place by suction cups. The basic set can hold two pairs of crosscountry skis or one pair of Alpine. There is also a larger model, for four pairs of crosscountry or two of Alpine. The racks come with locks and are available in red or yellow. Order directly from Ruffolo Enterprises, Box 597. Kenosha, Wis. 53141. Telephone: (414) 6523126. The prices, which include shipping charges, are $11.95 for the small model and $18.95 for the large. If you already have the small set and want to turn it into a large one, send $7.50 to Ruffolo for conversion brackets.

title: Notes on People
description: The name is Walstein Chester Findlay, but for the longest time he's been called Wally. Of course, the Wally Findlay Galleries are big business, with outlets in several cities, including one on East 57th Street in Manhattan. At the age of 76, Mr. Findlay hardly needs affirmation of his success, but recognition of an unusual sort will come anyway, tomorrow night at the French consulate in New York.

title: Women's Program Gets U.S. Support
description: WASHINGTON (UPI)  Commerce Secretary Juanita Kreps Sunday announced $235,000 in grants for an innovative program aimed at preparing women to own and operate businesses.

title: Outdoors
description: WESTON, VT. IT was cold, about 6 below zero. Deep in the woods, I was out of the wind, however, and comfortable even though standing still as I listened to the muffled baying of our beagle, Champ, who was plowing through the snow on the trail of a varying hare. Champ was in the interior of a thick and extensive plantation of young spruces near Weston, on the northeastern edge of the Green Mountains. The plantation was too dense for a hunter on snowshoes to enter, so I was stationed on its outskirts waiting for the hare, or snowshoe rabbit, to emerge. Some distance away, also on the outskirts, were my companions  Bart Jacob of Winhall, Vt., the dog's owner, and Niles Oesterle of Bennington, Vt.

title: Koch Says State Must Help Close Hospitals in City
description: Mayor Koch has warned Governor Carey that New York City will be unable to meet the requirements of its financial plan for closing the budget gap unless the state cooperates in determining which hospitals in the city should be closed to eliminate costly unneeded bed space.

title: Bossy: Composition of Rare Player
description: When Rocket Richard scored 50 goals in a season, when Boom Boom Geoffrion and Bobby Hull first did it, the number 50 was magic, a coldweather version of Babe Ruth's 60 home runs. Then came longer schedules and weaker teams. Now 20 players have scored 50 or more in a season.

description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAT BE TELEPHONED TO 354 3300 UNTIL 530 P M FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS UNTIL 7 30, P M 04 SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION IN REGIONAL OFFICES 300 A AT TO 4 30 P M MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY, NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900, WESTCHESTER CO AND NORTHERN NEW TOW STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300. title: The Marketplace
description: The Battle For UV Industries

title: Susan Carol Batkin Married To Bernard Mendik, Realtor
description: Susan Carol Batkin, a certified public accountant, was married yesterday in Lawrence, L.I.. to Bernard H. Mendik, president of the Mendik Realty company, realestate cevetopers in New York. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alex Batkin.

title: The Region
description: ALBANY (AP)  The chairman of the New York State Power Authority, Frederick.R. Clark, says he plans to resign because the job entails too much work for its $25,000ayear, parttime status.

title: Leonore Richman Wed To Rabbi Melvin Sirner
description: Leonore Madeline Richman, daughter of Lucille Richman of Brooklyn and Royal Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Morris Richman, was marriea yesterday in New Rochelle, N.Y., to Rabbi Melvin N. Sirner, son of Mr., and Mrs. David Sirner of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: PEKING RULES OUT A DRIVE FOR HANOI
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 25  Chinese forces attacking Vietnam will not advance from the mountainous frontier region down toward the populous Red River Delta or to Hanoi, a ranking Chinese official said in Peking tonight.

title: Boys Five Ousts Hamilton, 6160
description: In a game featuring a frantic finish that left Boys and Girls High School as the best team in Brooklyn, the Kangaroos defeated Alexander Hamilton, 6160, yesterday on a layup by Todd Mills with 13 seconds to play in their Public Schools Athletic League quarterfinal playoff at Pratt Institute.

title: Leadership Jobs In Congress Won By New Yorkers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  Early legis. lative maneuvering this year has thrust several Congressmen from the New YorkNew JerseyConnecticut area into new positions of leadership on Capiitol Hill.

title: Nets, Led by Jordan, Beat Knicks, 116102
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Feb. 25 Eddie Jordan, the New Jersey Nets backcourt man, had good reason to oppose the 11man player rosters in the National Basketball Association. The change from 12man rosters last season almost put an end to his young pro basketball career.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: PEARLY everlasting; goatsbeard; merrybell wood lily; false Solomon's seal; yellow stargrass; showy lady's slipper; rue anemone, columbine; pussytoes; largeleaved aster.

title: NEW ORLEANS ISSUES IN STRIKE CIRDED
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 25  As New Orleans settles in for what may be a long police strike that could expand to include other workers, the city's residents are trying to sort out what it has been all about. From, the start, the 10dayold walkout by 1,100 of New Orleans's 1,500 policemen has been shrouded in confusion and clouded even more by the emotional reaction to the curtailment of Mardi Gras.

title: Soviet Astronauts Are Sent Aloft
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 25 (UPI)  The Soviet Union sent two astronauts into space today aboard Soyuz 32 to check the abandoned Salyut 6 space laboratory for possible use by Russian spacemen, the official Soviet press agency, Tass, reported.

title: De Gustibus
description: Over the years, based on letters from readers, we have accumulated a catalogue of recipes that arouse fits of passion in the bosoms of American cooks. The list includes such obvious favorites as clam chowder, fried chicken, chill con carne and cheesecake. Bat I was astonished by the volume of mail I received on the seemingly innocuous subject of preserved citron.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Soviet Carrier Leaves Black Sea
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 2.5 (Reuters) The Soviet Union's newest aircraft carrier, the 45,000ton Minsk, passed through the Bosporus and Dardanelles Straits today on its way to the Mediterranean. the Istanbul port authority announced. The authority said it was the first time the Minsk had left the Black Sea, where it is based. Its destination was not known.

title: Rain Postpones L.P.G.A. Tourney
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 25 (UPI)  Heavy rains, accompanied by lightning, inundated the Pasadena Country Club course today, forcing a oneday postponement of the final round of the Ladies Professional Golf Association's $15,000 Orange Blossom Classic.

title: Dance: Baryshmkov at the White House
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 25  Mikhail Baryshnikov. partnering Patricia McBride and Heather Watts of the New York City Ballet, danced this afternoon at the White House at the invitation of President and Mrs. Carter.

title: PRESIDENT INDICATES BEGIN MAY VISIT U.S. FOR TALK ON TREATY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  President Carter raised the prospect today that Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel would join him and Prime Minister Mustafa Khalil of Egypt at Camp David at the end of the week in another effort to conclude an EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty.

title: Bridge:
description: A major upset marked Saturday's Grand National Team play at Farmingdale, L.I. In Swiss team competition, a favored sextet, including Emmett Pollenz of East Meadow, Howard Chandross of Atlantic Beach, Lew Handelsman of Malverne and Bill Holland of Massapequa Park, all of Long Island, and Mike Radin and JerryShakofsky of New York, failed to make the cut by reaching one of the top 17 positions in the field of 60 teams.

title: AT HOME ABROAD A Reasonable Law
description: JOHANNESBURG  For the last four weeks, near downtown Johannesburg, a middleclass family has been living in a tent pitched on the sidewalk. Mother, father and three daughters, 8yearold twins and a baby, have been there through dusty heat and drenching storms.

title: California Air Fares May Rise
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Airline deregulation, which has generally tended to decrease passenger fares, could have the opposite effect for many Californians.

title: Astronomers Looking for Fireworks From Total Eclipse of Sun in the West
description: BIG SKY, Mont., Feb. 25  As the shadow of the moon races across the United States and Canada tomorrow morning, thousands of amateur astronomers were to join professionals in looking for the undiscovered comets and solar storms that sometimes become visible durine eclipses.

title: Churches in U.S. Back Christians Who Seek To Quit Soviet Union
description: For more than a decade, emigration from the Soviet Union has been a human rights issue focused on Russian Jews. Recently, however, it has become an issue for Christians, too.

title: U.S. Shift From Oil Has Begun
description: Americans made a pronounced shift last year from using oil to other energy sources. According to energy economists, they probably started a trend that could eventually end the nation's traditional reliance on oil as the prime mover of its economic system.

title: Hooray For Hollywood
description: Los ANGELES

title: Pothole Recipe: Mix Frost, Snow, Thaw and Heavy Rain
description: A destructive sequence of frost, snow, thaw and heavy rain, aggravated by sprayed and melted rock salt, turned streets and highways in the metropolitan area into cratered obstacle courses for motorists over the weekend.

title: UV Sues Posner to Stop Further Share Purchases
description: UV Industries, a diversified company that is planning to liquidate itself and distribute the assets to its shareholders, is suing Victor Posner (a major UV shareholder) and three corporations he heads for $130 million in damages. The lawsuits were filed Friday in New York  two in state Supreme Court and one in Federal District Court.

title: A Town in Texas Ponders Mystery of 1897 Spaceman
description: AURORA, Tex., Feb. 23  If the little man from outer space hadn't died when his cigarshaped spaceship plowed into Judge J.S.
