Proctor's window on April 19, 1897, this would be like any other rural community left to wither when the railroad went elsewhere just after the turn of the century.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Did the National Hockey League ever have major and minor penalty shots? If so, what was the difference?

title: Going out Guide
description: THE GOOD EARTH Starting tomorrow, the public is invited, free of charge, to the first exhibition of Venezuelan landscapes to be shown outside that country. The place is the gallery of the Center for InterAmerican Relations, 680 Park Avenue, at 68th Street. The show is en titled A Century or Venezuelan Landscapes: Escuela de Caracas, 18451945.

title: Skepticism Meets Claims of Texas Businessman That He Arranged Release of 2 Employees Held in Iran
description: DALLAS, Feb. 24  American diplomats and other officials are viewing with increasing skepticism the recent assertion by H. Ross Perot, the flamboyant Texas millionaire, that be arranged for and financed a mob assault two weeks ago on a Teberan prison where two of his employees were being held.

title: TV: Billy, Flatbush Have Premieres on CBS
description: ONLY recently William S. Paley, chairman of CBS Inc., proposed that the three networks agree to devote two hours a week to highquality primetime television programming for a special segment of the audience. While we all hold our breatn, waiting for that great day to arrive, CBS will present another hour for the same old audience from 8 to 9 o'clock tonight with the premieres of two egregiously wretched situation comedies, Billy and Flatbush.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Apache Corporation, Minneapolis, a diversified company, has named Raymond Plank chairman in addition to his position as chief executive. Also announced was the election of John A. Kocur to the office of president.

title: New York Trio Performs
description: THE New York Piano Trio, heard Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is composed of the violinist Christopher Collins Lee, the cellist Pamela Frame and the pianist Lily Friedman. Mr. Lee and Miss Frame are doctoral candidates at the State University of New York's Stony Brook campus, and Miss Friedman holds a master's degree from Juilliard. Mr. Lee, in particular, impressed as a stylish violinist with something to say, but both his partners are certainly capable players.

title: Bangladesh Raises Food Output, lying Its Imports Over 5 Years
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Feb. 23  Despite marginal success in controlling its population growth, Bangladesh has cut its foreign foodaid requirements in half during the last five years, and Govern. meat leaders are talking optimistically about achieving selfsufficiency in food by 1985.

title: TURKS EXTEND RULE BY MILITARY FORCES
description: ANKARA, Turkey. Feb. 25  The Turkish Parliament approved the extension of martial law today for two more months, a move expected to signal the start of tougher measures against widesnread terrorism.

title: ESSAY Who to Root For
description: WASHINGTON  To a public uncomfortable with the feeling that Adierica does not count for much in world affairs, Mr. Carter last week offered an Orwellian theme: Weakness Is Strength. It takes guts to cave in everywhere with equanimity, he argues; to assert our national interest, as those jingoistic cold warriors suggest, would be Taking the Easy Way. In rafshooned halls, a 1980 slogan is bruited about: Keep Cool With Carter.

title: 2 Ulster Youths Killed by Bomb Believed Meant for British Army
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 25 (Reuters)  Northern Ireland's guerrilla war claimed two more lives last night.

title: Labor Leaders opposition to Cuts In Deficit Creating Wide Divisions
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 24  The leaders of organized labor say the Federal deficit is not high enough, that balanced budgets will not curb inflation, and that controls on wages and prices must be all or nothing, with nothing possibly preferred today.

title: Wadkins Wins by Stroke
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 25  Lanny Wadkins shot a brilliant birdie 4 on the 613yard 17th hole and miraculously saved a par 4 on the 18th this afternoon to win the 53d Los Angeles open. He had to sink a desperate clutch putt of 10 feet on the 18th to clinch the victory.

title: BusStop Shelter Concern Accuses New York Officials of Impropriety
description: The continuing struggle for the city's lucrative franchise for busstop shelters has yielded a rare glimpse into the behind-the-scenes interaction of some of the city's prominent lawyers and its agencies.

title: Baritone: Krause and Schubert
description: SCHUBERT'S Die Winterreise, as any masterpiece, sustains many different interpretations ranging from quiet, rapt introspection to outgoing, fullthroated drama. Tom Krause, the Finnish baritone who sang the song cycle yesterday atternoon at the 92d Street Young Men'sYoung Women's Hebrew Association with Irwin Gage at the piano, opted for the latter approach.

title: Indiana State, Bird (49) Roll
description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Feb. 25 Larry Bird and his undefeated Indiana State basketball team may have finally convinced those who have refused to rank the Sycamores No. 1 in the college hasketball polis.

title: Mr. Meany's Odd Leadership
description: We had been wondering what really happened at the peace talks between President Carter and his arch critic, George Meany, last month. When the meeting ended. neither side would say much about it. Now we know why. President Carter failed in his attempt to enlist the crusty union leader's support of his program to fight inflation. And since then, Mr. Meany has spun about like a top out of control, attacking the President one day, saluting him the next and, in the process, damaging what hope remains of reducing inflation without a long and painful recession.

title: World Bobsled Title To West Germans
description: KOENIGSEE, West Germany, Feb. 25 (AP)  The West Germany No. 1 sled won the fourman world bobsled championship today, only onehundreth of a second ahead of East Germany No. 1, and 19hundreths of a second in front of Switzerland No.1.

title: Ambach Readies for Regents Fight
description: Preparing for his first major confrontation with the Board of Regents, Gordon M. Ambach, the State Education Commissioner, informed members of the board this weekend that he would continue to favor certificates of achievement for students who failed to meet the state's new requirements for high school diplomas.

title: U.S. Will Seek $35,000 In Suit Against Eilberg
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb  25 (UPI) Former Representative Joshua Eilberg, who pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal conflict of interest laws in a plea bargain, may have to pay back the money he received for helping a hospital obtain a $14.5 million Federal grant.

title: Moscow Abuzz Over the Perils Of War in Asia
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 25  One morning last week, after the Chinese had invaded Vietnam, a Russian woman walked into a sauna reserved for Moscow's elite and said, Well, girls, will there be war or not? The steamy room erupted into an excited chatter of worried voices.

title: Badillo Bemused by Analyzing of Motives
description: Deputy Mayor Herman Badillo says he is bemused by the intense speculation over his motives in charting a separate course from the Mayor's over redevelopment of the South Bronx and over the Mayor's motives in letting him get away with it. He says he wants to put a couch in the City Hall press room to make it easier for reporters to psychoanalyze him.

title: U.S. Is Expected to Trim Its Plan to Aid Handicapped Transit Riders
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  Under pressure from inflation fighters and municipalities, the Department of Transportation is expected to substantially cut back its proposals to require access for the handicapped to transit facilities, according to various Administration sources.

title: 2 Aides Say U.S. Will Defend Oil Interests in Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  Both the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Energy said today that the United States would defend its vital interests in the Middle East and the Persian Gulf with military force if necessary.

title: Recital: Christa Ludwig
description: ANYONE who remembers Christa Ludwig in the early years of her career as a hilariously impetuous Cherubino or as a splendidly featherbrained soubrette in other roles cannot be surprised to find that the mezzosoprano is still a singer of extraordinary wit.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Moondance Stresses Lighting for Its Effect
description: JUNE ANDERSON and James Pelletier, the creators of Moondance, may very possibly have wanted their mixedmedia event to resemble a fairy tale a fairy tale of the technological age, that is. Presented Saturday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio, Moondance certainly looked mysterious, and it contained touches of technological magic.

title: Hospitals Are Assailed On Purchases of Drugs
description: New York City's 17 municipal hospitals spent more than $1 million more than necessary in purchasing $20 million worth of drugs in the last two fiscal years, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin declared yesterday.

title: DeCormier Leads Verdi Requiem
description: ROBERT DECORMIER led the New York Choral Society and Orchestra in a rather special presentation of the Verdi Requiem Saturday night in Carnegie Hall. The concert was dedicated to the memory of the singers, instrumentalists and conductor who performed the work in 1944 at Terezin, a German concentration camp just outside Prague.

title: USLIFE Plans Acquisition
description: The USLIFE Corporation said over the weekend that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Sooner Life Insurance Company of Ponca City, Okla. USLIFE would pay $17.5 million  51 percent in its common stock and 49 percent in cash. The agreement is subject to execution of a definitive agreement, approval by both companies boards, Sooner's shareholders and regulatory authorities, and other conditions.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Music

title: Piano: Palestine Shows His Massed Harmonics
description: TRUDGING up stairs out of the rain to Charlemagne Palestine's loft concert on Saturday night, one began to hear a rich, continuous sound, like deep organ chords, coming from above. In a darkened room, people were sitting against the walls while Mr. Palestine manipulated a Bosendorfer grand piano working the foot pedals furiously, hitting the keys in a fast, precise sequence. The organ chords, and they were as thick, as luminous, and as sustained as chords played on a giant pipe organ, came floating up out of the piano's insides. They were the harmonics of the resonating piano strings, and they had an almost physical presence.

title: Ugandan Town Reported Captured
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 25 (Reuters) President Idi Amin of Uganda said today that a regional center in southern Uganda had been captured by a force of Tanzanians, mercenaries and Ugandan exiles and that another town was threatened by th envarforc

title: Soviet Quintet Routs Louisville, 91-76
description: LOUISVILLE. Ky., Feb. 25 (AP)  Anatoli Mishkin scored 18 points to lead the Soviet national team to a 9176 exhibition game victory over 13thranked Louisville today in a nationally televised basketball contest.

title: Supplementary O-T-C Listings
description: Week Ended Feb. 23,1978

title: 50% Rise in World Population Forecast by Year 2000
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  Despite widespread signs that the world population growth rate has finally started to decline, the Census Bureau reported today that the population could be expected to increase by about 50 percent, reaching 6.35 billion by the year 2000.

title: Chess:
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. 23 When Viktor Korchnoi is out to win  and when is he ever not?  he leaves no strategy unturned. Here in the Sao Paulo International Tournament at the Clube De Xadrez, he is giving a clear picture of his will to win.

title: Pennsylvania Oil Cleanup
description: HATFIELD, Pa., Feb. 25 (UPI) State and Federal agencies continued) their efforts today to clean up 90,000 galIons of No. 2 heating oil that spilled into the Neshaminy Creek yesterday after the collapses of two earthen dams at the Hallowell Company in Montgomery County.

title: The City
description: Another murder charge will be filed against Police Officer Kevin Durkin following the death yesterday of the second of two Bronx men he is accused of having shot last week, according to a spokesman for Bronx District Attorney Mario Merola.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Msodev. Feb 26, 1979

title: Milk: How Much Do We Need It?
description: New Yorkers may have to forgo cream in their coffee and children may be forced to acquire a taste for dried milk products, but other than minor inconvenience, it is unlikely that the current milk strike will hurt anyone's diet in the area.

title: South African Objections
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Feb. 26South Africa strongly hinted today that it might pose objections to provisions for a ceasefire in SouthWest Africa.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Administration sent its proposed standby plan for fuel conservation in an emergency to Congress, including gasoline rationing as a last resort, while stressing that it was separate from the steps being drafted to cope with the loss of Iranian oil. [Page A1.]

title: State Asserts Closings Of Hospitals Must Get Backing of 2 Agencies
description: State hospital officials warned New York City yesterday that Governor Carey would not support the arbitrary closing of hospitals without the broad support of state and local hospitalplarming agencies.

title: President's Sister Arrested
description: AMERICUS, Ga., Feb. 26  One of President Carter's sisters was arrested last weekend in an incident at a restaurant here in which she refused to stop playing a harmonica when the manager asked her to.

title: Bridge:
description: Dying twice is almost as rare in bridge as it is in life, and dying three times is surely unique. But it may happen soon to one of New York's most powerful bridge squads in the Grand National Team Championship.

title: Carter Will Meet Press At Whitellouse Today
description: President Carter will hold a news conference in the White House at 4 o'clock this afternoon.

title: Blue Jeans Were Never Like This
description: Up on the platform, a dozen lithe young men in skintight blue jeans were skipping rope, lifting weights, bouncing on a minitrampoline, hauling energetically at a rowing machine, pedaling on an exercycle, doing situps at a furious pace on a slant board, and dancing sinuously from one workout to the next as the Bee Gees wailed in the background.

title: Vietnam Said to Weigh Giving Sihanouk a Role
description: NEW YORK, Feb. 26 (UPI)  Rep. Elizabeth Holtzman, a Brooklyn Democrat, returned to the United States today from a threeday tour of Vietnam and said Vietnamese officials told her they might consider allowing Cambodia to establish a nonaligned government unaer Prince Norodom Sihanouk.

title: Opera: Two Make Debuts With the City Troupe
description: TWO artists made debuts at the New York City Opera on Sunday Elyakum Shapirra, who conducted Carmen in the afternoon, and Maria Coronada, who sang Maddalena in the evening performance of Andrea Chenier.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: VOICES OF EXPERIENCE In a distinguished writing career, Robert Penn Warren's bestknown work remains All the King's Men (1946), the Pulitzer Prizewinning novel about a Southern political demagogue. Mr. Warren is the only person who won Pulitzers for both fiction and poetry with his 1958 book of verse, Promises. The author has taught English literature at Yale for 23 years. His most recent books, published in 1977, were the novel A Place to Come To and Selected Poems.

title: McGraw Urged To Change Stance
description: A grassroots campaign to convince McGrawHill Inc. to consider a $1 billion takeover bid by the American Express Company appeared to be developing yesterday in Hilton Head Island, S.C.

title: Recital: Songs by Frederica von Stade
description: THE growth of a gifted vocalist. into a great singer is a gradual and by no means inevitable rocess. But Frederica von Stade's recital at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night reinforced the impression, gained from live performances and recordings in recent years, that the mezzosoprano is growing in all the to ht directions. She is certainly one of An more appealing recitalists of her generation, and it is difficult to imagme her getting anything but better.

title: Canadian Delivers Best Punch
description: Once again proving that the bigger they are, the duller they are liable to be, heavyweight fighters lost main event billing last night at the Felt Forum to a pair of lightweights who know how to box.

title: Books: The Dual Personality Called Daniel Webster
description: IRVING BARTLETT's Daniel Webster recreates a living man,  a person in the round, a dynamic actor on the political stage. Much of this is due. to Mr. Bartlett's skill in marshalling the facts and organizing them into a continuing narrative that DANIEL WEBSTER. By Irving H. Bartlett. 333 pages. Norton. $12.95. manages to keep Webster in the center of events even as it unfolds the history of the first half of the 19th century.

title: Arson at an Epidemic Rate, With 300% Rise in 3 Years
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 26  For Anibal Cotto and the other adult males who live at 356 York Street, the night is not for sleeping. Instead, it is the time to be alert, to wait and to watch so that if the arsonist tries again they can get their families out alive.

title: American Is Held in Iran On Plundering Charge
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 26 (AP)  An American, two Britons and a Belgian employed by a Californiabased construction company were arrested today in southern Iran on charges of plundering the wealth of Iran by charging exorbitant prices, a spokesman for the company said.

title: Frontiers: Biology
description: AS you are reading this, thousands of chemical reactions are taking place within and among your body's cells. If you happen to be eating at the same time, additional chemical steps are Delng set In motion. 11 you cross or uncross your legs, other chemical changes will take place in each muscle involved.

title: Cat Wins Role Sought by 300
description: The word on Broadway is that Jonesy has been selected to play the part of Uncle Elizabeth in an upcoming musical version of I Remember Mama, with Liv Ullmann. Honey will be her understudy.

title: Money
description: MONDAY, FEB. 26. 1979

title: Tidrow Certain of His Value to Yanks
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 26  When it was suggested to Dick Tidrow one day last week that the Yankees could have a serene and sane season, he raised a bushy eyebrow and said, I don't see it.

title: Barbara Tuchman: A Loner at the Top of Her Field
description: Barbara W. Tuchman wanted to talk about excellence.

title: Some Podiatrists Said to Overcharge Runners for Customized Shoe Device
description: Longdistance runners with pain in their feet are receiving an even stiffer jolt in their pocketbooks from some podiatrists, Fred Lebow, the president of the New York Road Runners Club, said yesterday.

title: If Lyle Is in Camp, Can Season Be Far Behind?
description: Sparky Lyle made his earliest appearance in 12 years. Pete Rose will be absent with official leave. Bobby Bonds is still dragging his feet over reporting to his sixth team in six years. Gaylord Perry, at age 41, and Mickey Lolich at 39, are already on the mound, and Bill Bordley, the most promising pitcher from the University of Southern California since Tom Seaver, reported to the Giants camp. Those were a few of the signs yesterday that spring training was in full swing.

title: City Officials Fight. Weather And Traffic to Bus Pupils
description: The routes were unfamiliar, the schedules were makeshift, traffic was horrendous and the weather was terrible, but Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis and Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bruce C. Rattner each drove three handicapped children to and from school in Manhattan yesterday.

title: The Hungarian Father and Son
description: During their Super Bowl years, when Larry Csonka and Jim Kiick were riding high as Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid of the Miami Dolphins, they were dis- cussing their relationship with Don Shula, their stern coach. Csonka mentioned the day that new goal posts had been installed on the practice field. Inside the empty crates were green strips of rubber that resembled snakeskin. Always looking to break the monotony of practice, Zonk could not resist picking up one of the strips and hold ing it behind his back as he wandered down to where Don Shula was supervising the punting unit. That's all I think about at practice, Csonka said. Some way to get something happy going, be Cause It's so Mal. Ana soon von Salad noticed that his big fullback was standing nearby, hold- ing something in his hand.

title: U.S. Is Sending Arms to Yemenis
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (Reuters) The United States is sending more the $100 million worth of arms to Yemen to help in its fight with Southern Yemen, which is backed by the Soviet Union, a State Department official said today.

title: Voyager 1 Nears Jupiter Rendezvous
description: BEYOND the orbit of Mars and the asteroid belt, out where sunlight is diminished and the worlds are large and virtually unexplored, Voyager 1 is moving swiftly toward a rendezvous next Mon- day with Jupiter and several of the moons in its mighty embrace.

title: TV: Movie Tells Story Of West Point Women
description: THE first women at West Point can't have made as much trouble as the film crew that shot this television movie about them, marching all over tile grounds of that venerable institution shooting backgrounds for this fictionalized account of the groundbreaking group (in 1976) of women cadets. Still, the women apparently made waves. Women at West Point, a lively if unsurprising look at their travails, Will be shown at 8 o'clock this evening on CBSTV.

title: Wage Insurance Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations is seeking to amend the Administration's real wage insurance legislation to include both broader coverage and a tax on excess corporate profits.

title: EDUCATION
description: AFTER more than two decades of producing what officials acknowledge have been little more than electronic correspondence courses, New York's public television station, WNET, has decided to broaden both the target audience and the content of its adult educational programs.

title: IN THE NATION No Nuclear Credibility
description: A lot of Americans either have lost or are beginning to lose confidence in Government and industry assurances that nuclear energy production is safe. A few items, published over one recent weekend, suggest the reason why even though only one of them had anything to do with nuclear energy as such:

title: Advertising
description: CARLING NATIONAL BREWERIES, whose Colt 45 dominated the maltliquor market for many years, is preparing to introduce a new brand aimed at unseating Bull, the Schlitz malt liquor that has been No. 1 for the last couple of years such powerhouse nonDetroit advertisPillsbury Company, United Brands(Chiquita Banana) and CBS Network Sports.

title: COMMODITIES Silver and Platinum Drop Limit and Gold Falls $8
description: Prices of precious metals futures crumbled yesterday, despite the lack of any bearish news. Indeed, the declines came even as the dollar fell, which reflected the prospect of costlier oil, and uncertainty persisted in Vietnam and Iran.

title: SovietChinese War
description: On the evening of July 11, 1959, I strived at Government House at Ulan Bator and shook hands with Premier Yumjaagiyn Tsedenbal of the Mongolian Peoples Republic at a reception celebrating the national holiday of Nadam.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Spanish Poll Reveals Suarez Edge
description: MADRID, Feb. 26 As Spain's monthlong election campaign neared its climax today, a poll commissioned by the respected Madrid newspaper El Pais showed that Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez's governing party would probably edge out the secondranked Socialists in Thursday's parliamentary voting.

title: Keeping Tabs on Skylab's Flight
description: AGROUP of Washingtonarea computer experts has banded together to make continuous computer estimates of where Skylab, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's orbiting laboratory, is most likely to fall to earth.

title: Making New York's FAIR Plan Fairer
description: New York State offers every building owner a fire insurance policy, no matter how bad the fire record the neighborhood. Without this Fair Access to Insurance Requirements plan (FAIR), owners denied normal fire insurance because of location would permit their properties to deteriorate. But FAIR will be still fairer if the State Senate this week passes a bill that has already passed the Assembly.

title: Soviet Scientist May Get Einstein Chair at City U.
description: ALBANY, Feb. 26  Veniamin G. Levich, the renowned Soviet scientist who was given permission to leave the Soviet Union in December after a sevenyear struggle, is expected to be named an Einstein Professor later this week by the New York State Board of Regents.

title: On Baffin Island, Universal Sounds of Joy and Wonder
description: PANGNIRGUNG, Northwest Territories, Canada, Feb. 26 Few of the hundred or so Inuit who tramped or snowmobiled out onto the break ice of Pangnirgung Fiord shortly past noon today remembered that Eskimos once saw in the solar eclipse a time for Padli and her brother, Amarok  the sun and the moon  to come down to make sure things were all right on Earth.

title: Waldheim Proposes Namibia ceaseFire in 2 Weeks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 26 Secretary General Kurt Waldheim today proposed March 15 as the date for a cease fire in the guerrilla conflict in SouthWest Africa and the arrival of the first part of the United Nations peace force that would monitor the election leading to the territory's independence as the new black nation of Namibia.

title: Books of The Times
description: As a boy in the Middle. West, Thomas Alva Edison was a poor student and a troublemaker. As a young man wandering around the country from telegraph office to telegraph office, he was an unpopular practical joker with a tendency to cause explosions during unauthorized experiments. As an aauit in New Jersey, he lived on pie and coffee, slept in a closet with his clothes on, neglectedboth of his wives, seldom paid his bills, exploited his employees, and, because he had so many different contracts with so many conflicting interests from the Vanderbilts to Jay Gouldwas constantly in litigation.

title: Knicks Checking Up On Draft Class of '79
description: There were airline and hotel guides and maps scattered around the table where Eddie Donovan, Red Holzman, Dick McGuire and Fuzzy Levane sat yesterday. There were also several bound scouting reports that Marty Blake prepares for the National Basketball Association.

title: Stage: Thomas Babe's Taken in Marriage at the Public Theater
description: TAKEN IN MARRIAGE offers a dazzlement of acting and a good deal of entertaining detail. Except for one cry of anguish in the second act, though, it is less a play than an opportunity for players.

title: Saudis Reject Idea of a U.S. Base
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  The United States recently offered to station an American Military force in Saudi Arabia, but was turned down by the Saudi Government, Administration officials said today.

title: Eclipse, Winds And Rain Bring. Tidal Flooding
description: Unusually high tides accompanying a persistent rainstorm were swelled by strong winds and the added gravitational pull caused by the S1 percent solar eclipse in the New York metropilitan area yesterday to cause some severe flooding in lowlvinu areas.

title: Science Watch
description: Industrial Radiation

title: Hospital Reports Gains By Duchess of Windsor
description: PARIS, Feb. 26 (UPI)  The Duchess of Windsor was making satisfactory progress from an operation Saturday, the American Hospital said today.

title: About New York
description: There is a burnedout, boardedup apartment visible on the second floor at 28 East 70th Street, a very good address, the Hampton House; which makes the boards all the more noticeable, like a nub of lint on a welltailored coat.

title: Dance: Duncan And Chopin
description: SUNDAY afternoon's performance by the Isadora Duncan/ MariaTheresa Heritage Group attracted a large audience to the Y.W.C.A. at Lexington Avenue and East 53d Street. At least two good reasons may account for this.

title: Clouds Cheat New Yorkers
description: WITH soupy gray clouds smothering the metropolitan area yesterday, New Yorkers could hardly see the neighboring block, much less the partial eclipse of the sun taking place above them.

title: Around the Nation
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 26 (AP)  Striking St. Louis teachers announced today that they will hold a rally tomorrow to show their solidarity as the Board of Education pre- pared to reopen the city's 156 schools, which have been closed for 42 days.

title: Hilo Harbor Repair Funds Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)  The Army Corps of Engineers is seeking to appropriate almost twothirds of the maintenance budget of its Pacific division in the next fiscal year to repair the Hilo harbor breakwater on Hawaii Island because it is slowly being breached, officials said today. The Corps is asking Congress for $1.2 million for repairs to avoid having to close the harbor. The division's entire maintenance budget is $1.86 million.

title: Talmadge Says He Took Woes To the Bottle
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Feb. 26  Publicly and candidly confessing that in recent years he had taken his problems to the bottle rather than to my Maker, Senator Herman E. Talmadge of Georgia announced today after five weeks of hospitalization that he had stopped drinking and was prepared to return to Washington and the Senate ethics investigation that awaited himthere.

title: Factory Orders Up By 4.1%
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)  The nation's demand for steel, autos, ships and machinery rose sharply in January, a sign that the economy is still growing steadily, Government figuies indicated today.

title: Screen: Tent of Miracles
description: TENT OF MIRACLES is to be commended on a couple of scores: It condemns racism and it was made in Brazil, a country whose films don't receive much representation in this country. It's also the story of a very saintly Man, and certainly such stories are rare these days. That said, Tent of Miracles is also too messy and jumbled to have many other selling points.

title: Total Eclipse of the Sun Darkens Skies in Northwest
description: LAVINA, Mont., Feb. 26  The moon's dark shadow swept across the northwestern states today, treating thousands of spellbound viewers to the last total solar eclipse the continental United States will see until the year 2017.

title: Speed and Togetherness Keep Wagner Streaking
description: Peter A. Carlesimo, an assistant to the vice president at Fordham University, was not convinced that the oldest of his 10 children, Peter J., was making a smart move when he accepted the Job of basketball coach at Wagner College three years ago.

title: Staten Island Defeats Queens for City U. Title, 9278
description: Steve Cunningham scored a gamehigh 29 points last night as the College of Staten Island routed Queens College, 9278, to capture the City University basketball tournament at City College's Nat Holman Gymnasium.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: A new approach to meeting an old problem  wrongdoing that may involve Government officials  was recently tried for the first time. The initial run was smooth, though some Justice Department officials fear it may spin out of control during next year's political season if it encourages careless charges.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Gromyko Says China Obstructs Improved U.S.Soviet Relations
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 26  Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko charged today that SovietAmerican relations were being obstructed by Peking. But, he said, Moscow still seeks a more stable political climate in relations with Washington.

title: Dow Falls 2.16
description: Takeover situations and gambling stocks surged back into favor yesterday, while stocks in general moved moderately lower for the third session in a row.

title: The Chinese Push: Waiting for the Climax
description: China's invasion of Vietnam is expected to reach a climax this week, probably with a major attack on the city of Lang Son, military sources in Washington said yesterday.

title: Mail to Ireland Is Curbed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  The United States Postal Service said today that all surface mail bound for Ireland would be held until a stake by Irish postal workers was settled and that all airmail to Ireland would be returned to senders. No additional mail for Ireland will be accepted until further notice, the agency said.

title: CITY BUSES STUDENTS AS MEDIATION FAILS
description: Striking schoolbus drivers, chanting no, no, no way, late yesterday rejected their union's request to return to work.

title: Soyuz Links Up
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 26 (AP)  Two Soviet astronauts docked their Soyuz capsule and boarded the space laboratory Salyut 6 today to begin a series of experiments in the lab, which has been orbiting the earth for nearly a year and a half.

title: 30 Children Reported to Have Died This Year From Apparent Neglect
description: Thirty children have died in New York State so far this year apparently because of abuse or neglect, compared with 119 such reported cases for all of 1978, state officials said yesterday. Fifteen of the deaths occurred in New York City.

title: KUWAIT ESCALATES OIL PRICE INCREASES
description: Kuwait told its oil customers yesterday that it had raised prices by 9.35 percent, escalating the increases recently announced by other oilexporting countries.

title: Larger U.S. Deficit Seen Due to Iran
description: The upheaval in Iran has had a major negative impact on the United States economy  from the balance-ofpayments deficit to the rate of inflation to the level of export sales  according to today's issue of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company's World Financial Markets.

title: NATHAN GOLDBERG
description: Nathan Goldberg, emeritus professor of sociology at Yeshiva University, died of a stroke Friday at North Central Bronx Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 563 South Broadway in Yonkers.

title: Soviet to Try Tatar Dissident
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 26 (Reuters)  Mustafa Dzhemilev, a Crimean Tatar dissident, is to stand trial Thursday in Tashkent on charges of violating probation, dissident sources said today. Mr. Dzhemilev, 35 years old, has served labor camp terms for activities on behalf of the exiled Crimean Tatars.

title: Vietnam Asserti Chinese Invaders Have Advanced as Far as 25 Miles
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 26  Vietnam said today that Chinese forces had advanced as much as 25 miles into Vietnamese territory, but did not specify in which areas.

title: Mets Eye 2 Castoffs As Pitchers
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 26 The New York Mets, who traded their best pitchers during the last two years, opened their training camp to unemployed pitchers again today in a seeming desperate attempt to rebuild their staff.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Son and ExMinister Are Convicted
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 26  A court case stemming from the emergency rule of former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi ended today with the conviction of her son, Sanjay, and one of her Cabinet members on charges of stealing and destroying a motion picture satirizing her regime.

title: The City
description: Representatives of a dozen companies that supply heating oil to New York City buildings told city officials yesterda} that their suppliers Exxon, Mobil, Amoco and others were reducing their oil allotments by 50 percent and that they would have to cut back on their deliveries to the city.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: City's Pupils and Millions in Area Cut Off From Fresh Milk by Strike
description: Seven hundred thousand New York City schoolchildren and millions of other consumers in the city and on Long Island were unable to buy fresh milk yesterday as the full effect of a strike by milk processors and deliverers cut off most of the area's supply.

title: Music: Katya Kabanaiva By Opera Orchestra
description: FOR its first concertopera presentation this season, in Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, the Opera Orchestra of New York departed somewhat from its customary practice of reviving a rarely heard 19thcentury work featuring at least one glittering vocal personality. The opera this time was Janacek's starkly dramatic Katya Kabanova, not exactly a breadandbutter item but hardly unknown either, and the cast contained no luminary figures to send the fans into ecstasy.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: When the citizens of Cleveland vote today on whether to increase the city income tax and whether to sell the municipally owned electric utility, the man on the spot is, of course, Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich. But also under pressure  and probably watching the referendum as closely as anyone  is M. Brock Weir, chairman and chief executive officer of the Cleveland Trust Company.

title: Radio
description: WNCN. 2 Preludes for Piano. Szymanowski; Aria from La Gioconda, Ponchielil.

title: Rossman Given Defense Deadline
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 26 (UPI)  Fernando Mandry Galindez, the World Boxing Association president, who ordered the cancellation of Saturday's lightheavyweight title bout between Mike Rossman and Victor Galindez in Las Vegas, Nev., said today the W.B.A. would strip Rossman of his title unless he fichts Galindez by March 15.

title: Karl Bopp, ExPresident Of Bank in Philadelphia
description: FORT MYERS, Fla., Feb. 26 (AP) Karl R. Bopp, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank in Philadelphia from 1958 to 1970, died Saturday. He was 73 years old.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: GENERAL

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Ogden Corporation, the big metals producer, said yesterday that its subsidiary, Tillie Foods Inc. of Stockton, Calif., had agreed to acquire for $35 million the Progresso Foods Corporation, a division of the Imasco Foods Corporation of Rochelle Park, N.J.

title: OBSERVER The Bard Alibi
description: William Paley, better known as CBS, would like to see all three networks forget the cash register for two primetime hours each week and present programs for people who have knowledge and a higherthan average degree of intelligence, and who are interested in the affairs of the world.

title: Miss Blalock, With a Final 70, Wins by 6 Shots on Record 205
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 26 (UPI)  Jane Blalock overcame a chilling wind today to shoot a twounderpar 70 and capture the raindelayed, $75,000 Orange Blossom golf tournament.

title: U.S. Is Warned On Protectionism
description: Count Otto Lambsdorff, West Germany's Minister of Economics, warned the United States yesterday that any moves to protect domestic industries from foreign competition might backfire in a wave of European protectionism aimed at American products.

title: Market Place
description: NOW that Resorts International has a permanent license to operate gaming casinos in Atlantic City, Wall Streeters and investors generally are trying to figure out what the company is worth.

title: China Likely to Admit News Bureaus Shortly
description: PEKING, Feb. 26  A Foreign Ministry official said today that China would very soon admit a number of permanent American reporters to residence in Peking. He hinted that the notice, to be effective at once, could come within a week or two.

title: EARNINGS Profit at Loews Up 41.6% in 4th Quarter
description: The Loews Corporation reported yesterday a 41.6 percent jump in net earnings for the fourth quarter, while the net for all of 1978 dipped 3.6 percent because of a nonrecurring gam the year before. The company's activities range from hotels; movie theaters; Lorillard cigarettes, will such [MIMS as Kent, Spring, Newport and True, to its 57 percentowned CNA insurance operation.

title: Teamsters Negotiations Are Resuming in Florida
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 26  Contract negotiations between the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the nation's trucking industry resume tomorrow in Florida, but there is no immediate Prospect of a settlement.

title: World News Briefs
description: RAWALPINDI, Paldstan, Feb. 26 (UPI) - The military ruler of Pakistan has repeated his determination that only a commutation of the death sentence by the nation's supreme court can spare the life of former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What are the plans now for the detection of extraterrestrial intelligence?

title: Events/Sports
description: 4 P.M., WCBSAM, WINS, WMCA. WNYC.AM: President Carter's News Conference. (Live).

title: Pentagon Spending
description: WASHINGTON  Only in the rarified atmosphere of Pentagon spending can a $10 billion net increase in a budget be described as very austere.

title: CLEVELAND TO VOTE ON FINANCES TODAY
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 26  As Cleveland's climactic special election on ways to avert bankruptcy approaches, Mayor Dennis J Kucinich appears once again to be on the verge of turning things his way.

title: CONGRESS IS WARNED ON BUDGET MEASURE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  Governors warned Congress today not to trifle with the drive for a constitutional amendment to require the Federal budget to be balanced and not to try to punish the states who supported it by cutting back Federal revenue sharing.

title: Rhodesia Jets Raid Angola Camp
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 26 (Reut: ers)  Rhodesian bombers attacked a reputed guerrilla base 185 miles inside Angola today in the deepest penetration yet into a blackgoverned country.

title: The Balanced Budget Boomerang
description: The drive by state legislatures for a balancedbudget amendment to the Constitution has come up against reality. Major members of Congress, led by Senator Muskie, who heads the Senate Budget Committee, have put the deficit cutters on notice: If Washington is forced hastily to slash its $29billion deficit zero, spending cuts would come mainly out of the hides of the state and local governments themselves.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Bonds Fail to Hold Early Gains
description: The credit markets tried yesterday to throw off their pessimism, but they did not succeed.

title: Corporate Earnings Are Reported for the Quarter
description: For periods as harm. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) Me American Stole Exchange and (0) over-thecounter.

title: Leader in P.L.O. Says Iran Officials Support Retaking of Jerusalem
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 26  A senior official of the Palestine Liberation Organization said here tonight that the new Government of Iran has made the liberation of Jerusalem from Israeli occupation one of its foremost religious and moral commitments.

title: Charlotte Heussy McAllister, 72; Worked in Conservation Projects
description: Charlotte Heussy McAllister, a conservationist, died of cancer Saturday in her New York City home. Mrs. McAllister, who also maintained a residence in Pound Ridge, N.Y., was 72 years old.

title: Oldsmobile Settlement Overturned
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 26  The United States Appeals Court here threw out today a multimilliondollar settlement won by Oldsmobile owners who had bought cars that turned out to have Chevrolet eneines.

title: SouthWest Africa: A Rich Colony, an Occupied People
description: In 1884, the spikehelmeted soldiers of Kaiser Wilhelm I of Germany established white control in SouthWest Africa, a vast, sparsely populated territory as rich in diamonds and copper as it is in raw beauty.

title: Letters
description: To SCIENCE TIMES:

title: Woodcock Is Approved By Senate in China Job
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)  The Senate voted today to confirm President Carter's nomination of Leonard Woodcock as the first fullfledged Ambassador to China since 1949.

title: The Region
description: ALBANY  Over objections that it would misdirect state financing and deprive qualified welfare recipients of assistance, the Assembly approved legislation last night intended to insure that employable recipients were actively seeking work. The bill, sponsored by Assemblyman James R. TalIon, a Broome County Democrat, was passed 122 to 17 after long debate. Its future in the Senate is uncertain.

title: 3Month Bills Sold at 9.451%
description: The Treasury sold threemonth bills yesterday at an average discount rate of 9.451 percent, up from 9.293 percent in its preceding weekly auction and the highest rate for these key shortterm securities since they were sold at the peak rate of 9.908 percent on Aug. 26, 1974.

title: 4 Accused of Blue Cross Fraud
description: Three men and a woman were indicted in Manhattan yesterday on Federal charges that they submitted fraudulent medical bills to Blue Cross and Blue Shield for $57,000. George E. Wilson, the prossecutor Sald the defedants had allegedly used a post office box in Bogota, Colombia, in a scheme to obtain reimbursement for medical services they supposedly received in Bogota hospitals. The defendants are Alfonso Silva and Mario Fernandez of the Bronx, and Gustavo Munoz and Dora Castrom of Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: PRESIDENT REGRETS BROTHER'S REMARKS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  The White House said today that President Carter had formally disassociated himself from objectionable comments that his brother, Billy, had made about Jews; but stopped short of condemning the remarks.

title: U.S.Saudi Relations: A Surprising Communications Gap
description: A surprisingly wide gap of communications has emerged between the United States and Saudi Arabia.

title: Lippincott and Crowell Consolidating
description: Two of the oldest publishing houses in the country  J. B. Lippincott, founded in 1792, and Thomas Y. Crowell, founded in 1834  are combining their editorial forces in an effort to strengthen both.

title: Some in Iran Ask if the Retribution Is Going Too Far
description: TEHERAN. Iran, Feb. 26  A 10th execution has been performed at the behest of the secret revolutionary tribunal, and as word of the execution spread here today, and the daily list of arrested persons was published, questions were being asked in some quarters whether the retributions needed to be controlled.ers and cooks lined up outside the Prime Minister's palace in an attempt to prove that they had nothing to do with torture or killing. A spokesman was recording names, to be passed on to one of the Deputy Prime Ministers.

title: Swedish Prices Up 0.6%
description: STOCKHOLM, Feb. 26 (AP) Sweden's consumer price index climbed sixtenths of 1 percent last month and was 5.9 percent above the yearearlier level, the Government reported today.

title: White House Review Of E.P.A. Regulations Is Attacked by Muskie
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Senator Edmund S. Muskie opened a counterattack today against White House intervention in efforts by the Environmental Protection Agency to carry out the nation's antipollution laws.

title: Deficit for Philippines
description: MANILA. Feb. 26 (UPI)  The Philippines had a $95.59 million deficit in its balance of payments last month. the nation's central bank announced today, in contrast to a surplus of 18.15 million in January 1978. The Philip.. pines spent $428 million for imports in January, up $83 million from a year before. Export receipts in January totaled $231 minligh up $28 million.

title: Supreme Court Roundup Police Tactics to Gain Confession Face Study in Rhode Island Case
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  The Supreme Court agreed today to decide a case that could define when the police, in trying to get a confession from a criminal suspect, cross the line between subtle powers of suggestion and unconstitutional psychological pressure.

title: Iran Asked to Guarantee Rights of Fallen Leaders
description: GENEVA, Feb. 26  The International Commission of Jurists called today on Iran's new Government to guarantee defense rights to persons accused of crimes committed during Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi's rule.

title: County's Strengths Attract Continued Corporate Growth
description: An ideal geographical location, a well planned transportation network and an exceptional mix of housing, commercial and recreational facilities have made Westchester County the Keystone corporate growth orea of the Northeast.

title: Klan Fights Leftists and Nazis at Its Elthibit
description: WINSTONSALEM, N.C., Feb. 26 A Ku Klux Klansponsored exhibit of Klan paraphernalia at the city's main public library ended only an hour after it began tonight when fighting broke out among Klansmen, leftists and a contingent of four crewcut, swastikabearing and uniformed Nazis who crashed into the exhibit hall shouting, Sieg Heil!  and giving the stiffarmed Nazi salute.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times on Sunday reported erroneously that Symphony Space Inc., a nonprofit group rehabilitating the Symphony Theater at 95th Street and Broadway, collects rent from two businesses on its property. Though it is the titular owner of the property, Symphony Space receives no rent from any business there.

title: Wider Use Is Urged For Rh Vaccine
description: Avaccine that was a research triumph in the 1960's is fulfilling much of its promise in reducing brain damage and infant mortality, but a Connecticut campaign to insure that it is used wherever necessary suggests that many more babies could be saved if other states began such drives.

title: 33 Food Places Found Unsanitary
description: The New York City Health Department released yesterday the names of 33 food establishments that it said had violated the Health Code. It also announced that two restaurants had been closed for failing final inspection and that one had reopened after correcting its violations. The places listed were as follows:

title: Harold B. Wess, at 84; A Professor of Business
description: Harold B. Wess, professor emeritus of business administration and marketing in the School of Business Administration at American University in Washington, and a former executive of Macy's in New York, died Saturday at the age of 84 in the Bay Village retirement community in Sarasota, Fla. He lived in New York and Washington before moving to Sarasota in 1970.

title: Mortgage Rate Seen Firming
description: Activity yesterday in the home mortgage market seemed to indicate that interest rates on home loans would not peak during the first half of the year, an economist for the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation suggested.

title: EDWARD MAVERICK, DESIGN EXPERT, DIES
description: Edward Maverick, a consultant on period design, died of cancer last Wednesday in the Cabrini Health Care Center. He was 77 years old and a resident of New York City.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: A New Pattern at Kimberly Knitwear
description: What can a company do that has lost leadership in its field because it failed to keep up with changing technology and consumer demand?

title: Democrats in Chicago Vote in Primary Today
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 26  Chicago's Democratic mayoral primary election tomorrow could be close, according to two weekend mils.

title: Can Stored Oil Relieve a Crisis?; U.S. Stockpile Limited in Size, Accessibility
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 26  Outside the control center of the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve program in a suburban New Orleans office building a display board that changes daybyday tells the running story: more than 75 million barrels and rising.

title: Resorts Wins a Permanent License To Operate Casino in Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 26  New Jersey's first gambling casino  the leader in the planned transformation of this seashore resort into a center of billions of dollars in legal betting  was granted a permanent license today.

title: Scientists Debate Acceptable Risk
description: IS the convenience of riding in automobiles worth a l-in-5,000 chance of being killed in any given year? If so, does it follow that a risk of only one in 750,000 is worth taking in exchange for the benefits of a nuclear power plant?

title: Judge Orders New Trial for Flood
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)  Judge Oliver Gasch of Federal District Court today denied Representative Daniel J. Flood's motion to stop the Government from prosecuting him a second time on bribery and perjury charges.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Cosmic Clues on Jupiter's Moons
description: THE 34 celestial bodies known to be circling the planets of the solar system are all called moons. There the similarity ends.

title: Termination of Alimony To Lesbian Adds To Legal Debate
description: Like many another man involved in separation or divorce, John Smith signed an agreement in 1972, promising to pay alimony to his wife, Jane, until such time as she remarries or dies.

title: Safety Study on Nuclear Reactor Is Defended by Its Chief Author
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  Dr. Norman C. Rasmussen, the principal author of a controversial nuclear safety study, testified at a House subcommittee hearing today that his findings were largely valid and that the risk of a serious reactor accident is acceptably low.

title: Sadat Decision About Peace Talks Creates Difficulties, U.S. Concedes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  Administration officials said today that President Anwar elSadat's decision not to participate in a new round of Camp David negotiations with President Carter and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel had aroused some Israeli suspicions and had made it more difficult for the United States to appear evenhanded.

title: 5 Asian Nations Work On a U.N. Resolution For Indochinese Peace
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 26Five nonCommunist Asian nations, in private consultations here today, were preparing a draft Security Council resolution calling for a cessation of hostilities in Southeast Asia, according to Asian and European diplomats.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, FEB 26, 1979

title: Miss Holtzman Accuses Vietnam of Refugee Racket
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 26  Representative Elizabeth Holtzman charged today that Vietnamese officials had extorted at least $30 million from refugees fleeing the country in what she said appeared to be an organized racket in human beings.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: Notes on People
description: Sevenmonthold Herbert Quinones Jr. of Brooklyn is said to be doing well in a Toronto hospital, where he underwent surgery for three and a half hours yesterday to correct a throat deformity that had nearly killed him 30 times in his young life. Baby Herbie got caught in a bureaucratic contretemps between Canada and New York State over who would pay for the operation  a dispute that arose because his parents, Leticia and Herbert Sr.  he is a $100aweek grocery clerk  wanted the surgery to be performed by a Toronto surgeon on the recommendation of their doctor In Brooklyn.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 27,1979

title: TextileApparel Accord Sets Tighter Import Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  The Carter Administration plans to aggressively control import surges under a global import evaluation system for the textile and apparel industry to be put into effect before the end of March.

title: U.S.China Talks Open On Trade
description: PEKING, Feb. 26 Highevel negotiations on major economic issues between the United States and China opened here today on what American officials regarded as a positive note.

title: About Education. A Booster Shot For the Three R's
description: JUST as the Three R's are coming back into fashion, some educators are warning that basic skills are not enbugh. If children are taught the even more basic skill of thinking, they say, reading, writing and math scores will go up, too. A study by the Educational Testing Service in Princeton offers at least preliminary evidence that the theory works, not as a substitute for the Three R's. but as a booster shot.

title: News of Dance Work Tank at the O'Neill Center
description: CARMEN DE LAVALLADE, who has enjoyed a long and luminous career as a dancer, has now won success in a differ- ent kind of endeavor. She has just created her first ballet. Sensemaya, which was the critics when praised by the Dance Theater of Harlem gave it its premiere last week at the City Center55th Street Theater. It will be seen again there next Sunday afternoon.

title: Chrysler Quarterly Net at $43 Million
description: DETROIT, Feb. 26 The financially troubled Chrysler Corporation, the nation's No. 3 auto maker, today reported a profit of $43.2 million, or 61 cents a share, for the fourth quarter of 1978, compared with a $49.7 million loss for the comparable period a year earlier.

title: CARTER ASKS POWER TO RATION GASOLINE IN EXTREME CRISES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  President Carter sent Congress the details of his proposal for mandatory fuelsaving measures late today and asked for authority to impose gasoline rationing if he decides it is necessary, Administration officials said tonight.

title: Miss Sills Outlines 3Year Financing and 5Year Repertory Plans for City Opera
description: Beverly Sills, who will become director of the New York City Opera on July 1, yesterday announced that she was starting a threeyear, $12, million campaign for funds and that she already had a gift of $500,000 from an anonymous donor toward that goal. She also sketched out a fiveyear plan for repertory that includes a series of early Verdi works and rarities, such as Kurt Weill's Silbersee.

title: Governors to Convene In Atlantic City in 81
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  The ninemember executive committee of the National Governor's Association unanimously voted last night to hold the association's summer convention in Atlantic City in 1981.

title: Researchers Seek A Vaccine Booster
description: TO make the vaccines of tomorrow more effective and more universally protective, scientists are turning to artificial chemistry in a field dominated for centuries by natural products.

title: Civil Settlement Reportedly Sought In Sales Abroad by Arms Company
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  Justice Department officials here, despite evidence of criminal violations gathered in a field investigation, are attempting to negotiate a civil settlement of charges that major arms manufacturer illegally sold military equipment to Libya, Government and private lawyers said in interviews.

title: Two Jets in Landing Mishaps
description: NORFOLK. Va., Feb. 26 (AP)  Two jetliners ran off runways into mud while landing at Norfolk International Airport and at Patrick Henry International Airport yesterday in nearby Newport News. There were no injuries.

title: High Court Rejects Appraisal Cost Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a property owner who is fighting an attempt by the Government to take his land by eminent domain is not entitled to reimbursement for the cost of hiring his own appraiser to challenge the value the Government put on the land.

title: Koch, Criticized by Many Blacks, Seeks to Re'pair Ties With Them
description: One recent morning, Mayor Koch journeyed to St. Philip's Church on West 134th Street in Harlem for a meeting with a small but influential group of black religious, civic and entertainment figures.

title: Observing the Largest Planet
description: In addition to daily photography of Jupiter, Voyager l's scientific investigations in the coming week will include the following:

title: Kaiser Lifts Aluminum Prices 5%
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation raised prices yesterday by an average of about 5 percent on various aluminum products, including primary aluminum ingot, which will go up by 3 cents.

title: Camp David and the Uses of Ambiguity
description: So President Sadat, who dared go to Jerusalem, refuses to return to Camp David for one final effort conclude a peace treaty with Prime Minister Begin. This news is either very good or very bad; Mr. Begin had better come alone to find out which it is.

title: Foreign Assets Invested in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) Foreign assets invested in the United States increased by $30.9 billion in 1978, compared with an increase of $35.5 billion the previous year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Main Issues in Strike By Dairy Workers
description: Parties: The Greater New York Milk Dealers represents 85 distributors in New York City and Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Eleven of the plants handle the major processing, pasteurizing and cartonine.

title: Taxes
description: NEW YORK continued to have the second heaviest tax burden in the nation during the 1977 fiscal year, with per capita state and local taxes rising almost 10 percent to $1,252. This put New York behind only Alaska, with taxes of $2,296, and just ahead of California, with taxes of $1,089.

title: Kenneth Campbell, 78, Reporter, Correspondent With Times, Dies
description: Kenneth A. Campbell, a reporter and foreign correspondent for The New York Times for 25 years, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital after a threeweek illness. He was 78 years old and had lived at 454 Riverside Drive.

title: Bernard H. Stuchin, 58, New Rochelle Financier
description: Bernard H. Stuchin, a financier and realestate investor, died Monday of heart attack while on business in Meridan, Conn. He was 58 years old and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Voters in Cleveland Back Kucinich on Tax Rise and Keeping Utility
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 27  Cleveland's voters overwhelmingly approved a 50 percent increase in the city income tax rate today and voted to retain the city's embattled municipal electric utility.

title: 4 Boys Die in Boston Fire
description: BOSTON, Feb. 27 (UPI)  Four young brothers died early today and their parents and sister were critically injured in a fire that spread like lightning through a thirdfloor tenement apartment; The boys died from smoke inhalation. They were identified as Joel Roman, 6 years old; Israel, 4; Jose Luis, 2, and Richard, 41 days. The only surviving child was 18monthold Karen, who was taken to Boston Children's Hospital where she is listed on the danger list. The parents, Jose Roman, 29, and his wife Gladys, 23, were on the danger list at Boston City Hospital.

title: Rhodesia's Tourist Trade Is a Casualty of Air Crash
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 23For the last few years, one of the more unusual aspects of the Rhodesian war has been the persistence of tourism. But aftez the crash of a Viscount airliner on Feb. 12, the second crash in six months to be caused by a guerrilla missile, even tour promoters have thrown in the towel.

title: Treasury Drops a Plan For Gun Regulations After Rood of Protests
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)  The Treasury Department dropped proposed firearms regulations today after thousands of letter writers asserted that, the rules were the first step toward nationwide gun registration.

title: Judge Orders Release Of Galante From Jail
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 27 (AP)  A Federal judge today ordered the release of Carmine Galante, the reputed organizedcrime boss, from the Federal Correctional Institution at Milan, Mich.

title: Mardi Gras 1979: Lot of Spirit but a Little Less Fat
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 27  I'll tell you one thing, the master of ceremonies said on Bacchus Sunday Night in the Superdome. The Mayor ain't gonna have a Mardi Gras, and the police ain't gonna have a Mardi Gras, but the people ARE gonna have a Mardi Gras!

title: Topics
description: The Great Bus Shelter Controversy is a continuing drama, but now the plot has become a bit thick. First, New York City's franchise was taken away from one company and awarded to another in a storm of claims and counterclaims. Now, in the latest development, the Board of Estimate wants tostop the bulldozer. In New York, they may have to chain themselves to bus stop shelters.

title: John W. Donaldson, 86, ExNew York Financier
description: John W. Donaldson, a former NewYork financier, died Friday in St. Joseph's Hospital in Tucson, Ariz. He was 86 years old, and had lived for many years in Millbrook, N. Y., and in recent years in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Cretans Protest Lending of Antiquities
description: HERAIKLEION, Crete, Feb. 27 (AP)  The Mayor and 14 Municipal Coun- cilors of this city were detained for several hours and charged with leading a group of demonstrators trying to pre- vent the export of antiquities for exhibi- tion in the United States, the police said today.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Treasury sold $2.5 billion of fouryear notes yesterday at an average yield of 9.35 percent, the lower end of the range dealers had expected, and the securities were quoted late in the afternoon at a slight premium.

title: Voyager Discovers Jupiter Has Dazzling Lights Similar to Those in the Arctic Regions
description: PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 27  There may be very few similarities between Earth and the huge gaseous planet Jupiter, but the Voyager 1 spacecraft has discovered one of them  the existence of intense auroral activity on Jupiter, not unlike the dazzling lights of the aurora borealis in the Earth's Arctic regions.

title: Kitchen Equipment Grills
description: IN all the years I've been in this country, I've never been able to accustom myself to the way most Americans cook steaks, chops and hamburgers. The broiling that's so common here tends to impart a baked flavor to meat. And fryingeither in a pan or on a griddle  causes the meat to sit in its own juices, a soggy way to do the job.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Kansas City Mayor Loses
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 27 (AP) Mayor Charles B. Wheeler, a selfdescribed product of the Harry Truman school of politics, failed tonight in his bid fora third term.

title: 3 Gillies Goals Pace 73 Rout of Montreal
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 27  Clark Gillies, a left wing, stole the spotlight from the two outstanding right wings at Nassau Coliseum tonight as the New York Islanders crushed the Montreal Canadiens. 73.

title: PreLenten Tradition Gets Modern Twist
description: Yesterday was Fat Tuesday, but about 30 women may have new worries about being fat Wednesday, after they competed in a preLenten pancakeeat. ing contest to see who could down a giant pancake the fastest. The winner was Eileen Pine, an employee of the Immigration and Naturalization Serv

title: Response Favorable as Carter Asks Congress to Back Court Reform
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  President Carter called on Congress today to adopt my program to reform the Federal civil justice system and won favorable but subdued responses from Senate and House leaders, including Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: We started out with good intentions we would go to exercise classes faithfully and do our daily dozen in between. Then the weather got bad, or we took a trip. and the pattern got broken. Without the teacher's crisp commands, we found ourselves getting lazy about exercising at home. The Nickolaus Exercise Centers have come up with a simple idea to get us back on the exercise mat. They've put 15 minutes of warmup exercises on a cassette that can easily be carried to the office or played in a hotel room. if one can't manage the home routine. The cassette and an instruction booklet may be had from the Nickolaus center at 509 Fifth Avenue, or ordered by mail from the same address (the zip is New York 10017). Include a check for $7.50.

title: Time Inc. Buys Threshold Shares
description: Threshold Technology Inc., a speechdevice company, disclosed that Time Inc. had purchased 100,000 shares, or 6 percent, of its 1.6 million outstanding shares for $500.000.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: New Dangers, and More Delay, on Namibia
description: PRETORIA. South Africa, Feb 27 Once again, the United Nations peace plan for SouthWest Africa, among the most ambitious operations undertaken by the world organization, is in danger of collapsing.

title: A Fat Freezer and a Shed Full of Wood
description: WHEN my husband and I apply for loans or credit cards, and were asked to list our assets, I am always tempted to put our freezer at the head of the list. Not that it's a particularly valuable appliance. There are probably a million freezers like it humming softly in kitchens all across America. And I would hum, too, if I had 30 pints of raspberries in me.

title: T.W.A. Flight Cutbacks
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. Feb. 27 (AP) Trans World Airlines canceled 10 more flights today because of a jet fuel shortage, and will have to cancel more flights tomorrow, the fourth day of cutbacks. The flights canceled for tomorrow are roundtrip runs from Kansas City to New York, Chicago and St. Louis. A T.W.A. spokesman said the airline expected to be back to full operation by Thursday. Texaco, which supplies about 50 percent of T.W.A.'s fuel at Kansas City, has reported several spot shortages recently, mostly as a result of a cutoff in Iranian oil and a travel boom stemming from lower air fares.

title: Stage: Downtown Setting For Antarctic Adventure
description: FOR Southern Exposure, JoAnne Akalaitis's exploration of Antarctica; a corner of the annex of the Performing Ga rage has been transformed into a snowywhite box of a set. Platforms, canvas and papered walls crisscross into the theatrical equivalent of polar ice shelves, a scenic cousin to Malevich's White on White painting.

title: TV: As You Like It on Channel 13
description: ON paper, it would be difficult to devise a nobler and more uplifting television project than producing all 37 plays of Shakespeare', as is being done by the British Broadcasting Corporation in as- sociation with TimeLife Films. But there are clear and present dangers.

title: LAKE TAHOE ACCORD PERILED BY NEVADA
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 27  A compact that Federal officials laboriously worked out between California and Nevada to arrest the deterioration of the scenic Lake Tahoe Basin is running into trouble.

title: O'Malley Resting Well
description: VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP) Walter O'Malley, 75yearold board chairman of the Los Angeles Dodgers, spent a restful day today in the Mayo Clinic at Rochester, Minn. He was flown there yesterday after complaining of dizziness. He was reported doing well and will undergo more tests.

title: Chinese Commune Raided
description: The Vietnamese Army has made two small attacks into Chinese territory, Peking's press agency said yesterday.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, Feb. 19, to Sunday. Feb. 25), fisted according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of Untied States households with television sets.

title: 2 New Plays Will Close Circle Repertory Season
description: A new play by Lanford Wilson that stars Judd Hirsch and a new musical by William Whitehead that stars Conchata Farrell will close the Circle Repertory Company's 10th anniversary season.

title: U. N. AT STALEMATE ON INDOCHINA WARS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 27 Britain urged the Security Council, which was deadlocked tonight about how to deal with the fighting in Vietnam and Cambodia, to issue a clear call for the foreign troops in both countries to go home.

title: The Teachings of Mr. Teng
description: Instead of complaining, says Teng Hsiaoping, Americans should be grateful for China's invasion of Vietnam. We cannot tolerate the Cubans to go swashbuckling unchecked in Africa, the Middle East and other areas, he says, nor can we tolerate the Cubans of the Orient [Vietnam] to go swashbuckling unchecked in Laos, Cambodia or even China's border areas. I think the people of the world should not tolerate such actions:

title: Real Estate
description: WHEN Olympic Tower was built on Fifth Avenue in the early 1970's it was given a floorarea bonus because the design allowed for retail space along an enclosed plaza. But though the building has been open for five years, the retail space has never been rented out.

title: French Judge Californians
description: PARIS

title: New York Savings Banks in Squeeze
description: New York City's mutual savings banks are experiencing a severe profit squeeze, severe enough, according to some industry sources, to lead to a spate of mergers in the next few years.

title: Who Won in Atlantic City?
description: When Resorts International won a permanent license the other day to keep running its highly profitable Atlantic City casino, its questionable past counted for little. In rendering its 50 decision, New Jersey's Casino Control Commission focused on Resorts present performance and on Atlantic City's future.

title: Few Losses Found at Lance Bank
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)  Ben Lance, the former director of the Office of Management and Budget, and others received preferential treatment from the bank that Mr. Lance headed, but any loss was insignificant and would not be worth pursuing, an investigator said today

title: Asbestos Corp. Assails Share Study
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 27 (AP)  The findinof a study commissioned by the Quebec government that shares of the Asbestos Corporation should be valued at about $40 (United States currency) each is totally wrong, the company's president, Maurice Taschereau, said todain a letter to stockholders.

title: Murder Conviction of S.L.A. Soldier Overturned
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 27 (AP) A state appeals court today reversed the murder conviction of Russell Little, soldier in the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army, in the 1973 slaying of a school superintendent. The conviction of a codefendant, Joseph Remiro, was upheld.

title: Tigers Fidrych Throws Painlessly
description: Mark (The Bird) Fidrych, the righthander for the Detroit Tigers who has been plagued by tendinitis the last two seasons, threw easily and without pain for the fourth straight day at the club's training site in Lakeland, Fla., yesterday. Although it was not at full speed, the Tigers are pleased that the 1976 American League rookie of the year had no pain after pitching more than five minutes of batting practice.

title: Westinghouse Unit: $5 Million Worth of Bad Loans
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 27  The Westinghouse Credit Corporation of Cleveland, a subsidiary of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, has made bad loans estimated at more than $5 million to clients who used bad checks or fictitious mining and construction equipment as collateral. it has been learned.

title: Britain Frees Jailed Terrorist
description: LONDON, Feb. 27 (ReLiters)  The last member of the Angry Brigade anarchist group jailed after a series of bomb attacks in Britain has been released, Government officials said today. Jake Prescott, 33 years old. was freed last Wednesday after serving 8 years of a 10year sentence.

title: The Unending Feud Between Mayor Koch and the Blacks
description: The sniping between Mayor Koch and New York City's blacks never seems to stop. There are quiet times, as after the appointment last fall of Ronald T. Gault as an adviser in City Hall. But almost inevitably the anger peaks again, as it did Urban Affairs last week with State Senator Vander L. Beatty's announcement that he would initiate a petition campaign to recall the Mayor. Mr. Koch, for his part, said he Was not distressed that he had not been invited to the Black and Puerto Rican Caucus dinner: Who wanted to go to Albany anyway?

title: Legionnaires Bacteria Is Found In 2 Cooling Towers in Vermont.
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Feb. 27 (AP)Bacteria responsible for legionnaires disease has been found in water samples taken from air cooling towers on the roofs of two Burlington buildings, the State Health Department said today.

title: Now for a British Challenge: HandRaised Meat Pies
description: ONE of the real gems of English cookery is the handraised meat pie. These pies are as common in London as a potato knish is in New York (although they are definitely of a different culinary class).

title: U.S. Study Asks Caution On LowLevel Radiation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  The Carter Administration advised Americans today to be wary of exposing themselves to low levels of radiation but shied away from seeking to impose stricter standards on permissible amounts.

title: Yanks Find Jackson at Top of Talk Form
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 27  At 9:30 this morning, Reggie Jackson walked into the clubhouse for the first day of spring training in his third year as a Yankee. A black beard adorned his face. At 10:20, he headed for the field for his first workout in the chilly Florida air. Except for a mustache and glasses, his face was bare.

title: Texas International
description: HOUSTON  Texas International Airlines is committed to providing airline service to the public at the lowest possible price.

title: FreeAgent Lilt to Swan's Song
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 27 Just when the New York Mets start rebuilding their pitching staff, they get the bad news: Craig Swan, who had the best earnedrun average in the National League last season, is looking ahead two years to the day when he can become a free agent.

title: Con Ed Late Charges On Gas Bills Upheld
description: Extra charges that Consolidated Edison has imposed on nonresidential customers for paying their gas bills late were upheld yesterday in a unanimous ruling by a state appeals court.

title: N.Y.R.A. to Resume Talks With Clerks Union Today
description: Negotiations are to resume today at 2 P.M. in the labor dispute between the New York Racing Association and its I parimutuel clerks.

title: Gannett Holders Approve Merger
description: The Gannett Company, the newspaper publishing and broadcasting concern, announced that its shareholders had approved the merger of Gannett and the Combined Communications Corporation of Phoenix. Shareholders of Combined Communications approved the merger on Monday.

title: Ford Urges U. S. Calm On PekingHanoi War
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 (AP) Former President Gerald R. Ford said today that the United States should keep its cool with regard to the potentially explosive situation of the ChineseVietnamese border war.

title: Notes on People
description: Yesterday, almost a year to the day after Mayor Koch complained that his official car was a deathtrap, he started riding around in a new Chrysler Newport. The 1979 model, described by Chrysler as nightwatch blue, was delivered last week, but because of the foul weather, it was kept off New York's snowclogged streets.
